column1: 5 Technology Companies That Could IPO in 2017;3/14/2017;"After a tepid 2016
column2: the Initial Public Offering (IPO) market has been rejuvenated in 2017
column3: primarily on the back of the recent $24 billion Snap Inc. IPO. Snap's public market debut was the biggest technology IPO since Alibaba's in 2014 and the second-largest U.S. technology based IPO ever
column4: behind onlyFacebookFB
column5: its closest competitor and a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) stock. You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 (Strong Buy) Rank   stocks here.makeArticleAd();Snap's blockbuster IPO clearly demonstrated investors' pent-up demand for technology companies. The loss-making company sold 200 million non-voting shares for $17 per share
column6: above the expected range of $14-$16. Shares were up a massive 44% from its IPO price at the very first day of trading.Snap's hit IPO has opened up flood gates for the next round of public money seekers. This includes the likes of Mule Soft

column8: Carbon Black
column9: AppNexus
column10: Forescout
column11: and Cloudera
column12: all of which are primarily tech unicorns (emerging technology companies that have a valuation of more than $1 billion).However
column13: two high profile technology companies - Uber and Airbnb - are not expected to debut this year as both of them have raised funds in recent times.  Reportedly
column14: Uber raised $3.5 billion from the investment arm of Saudi Arabia in Jun 2016. Airbnb recently closed $1 billion in funding
column15: which puts the company's valuation at $31 billion.Technology IPO Market is HotAlthough Snap's recent price slide is a deterrent to IPO investors
column16: we note that most of the issues are company specific. In fact
column17: we believe that the current macro-economic environment is most conducive for IPO investing based on President Donald Trump's plan of spending $1 trillion on U.S. infrastructure overhauling along with regulatory and tax reforms.We note that lowering of tax rate from 35% to 15% - as proposed by President Trump during his campaign days - will be beneficial to small and mid-cap companies
column18: particularly in the technology sector. This will surely attract IPO investors to this market going ahead.The IPO pipeline remains strong as evident from recent Renaissance Capital data
column19: which showed that 25 IPOs have already been filed this year
column20: up 13.6% compared with the same period last year. Moreover
column21: technology trails only healthcare in filing most IPOs in the last 12 months.Further
column22: ongoing consolidation in the technology market provides a significant opportunity for investors to buy new stocks that have significant growth prospects over the long term.Tech IPOs for the Rest of 2017If a favorable environment prevails

column1: Intel Corp. and Qualcomm
column2: Inc.: On a Collision Course;3/14/2017;"For years
column3: there has been very little intersection betweenIntel's(NASDAQ: INTC) core businesses andQualcomm's(NASDAQ: QCOM) . Intel's revenue today comes primarily from   sales of personal-computer processors
column4: processors for enterprise   and cloud servers
column5: and networking applications.Qualcomm
column6: on the other hand
column7: makes most of its profit from   licensing wireless technologies and patents
column8: and generates most   of its revenue by selling chips that go into smartphones and
column9: to   a lesser extent
column10: other mobile devices like tablets.Image source: Qualcomm.makeArticleAd();For years
column11: it has been widely known that Qualcomm was working   on processors designed to attack Intel's data-center dominance;   first commercial shipments are expected to begin in the second   half of 2017. And for years
column12: Intel has been going on about trying   to attack Qualcomm's wireless-chip business -- achieving its   first real success last year when it captured cellular-modem   share from Qualcomm inApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) iPhone 7-series smartphones.In other words
column13: these two chip giants are on a collision   course. Let's look at what each side could lose
column14: what each side   stands to gain
column15: and what this coming battle might mean for   investors in either company.Intel deals its major -- but potentially only -- blowIn the past
column16: Intel had told investors that it expected to   compete broadly across the mobile-processor market. Indeed
column17: the   company said it was developing a whole stack of chips
column18: designed   to span everything from low-end smartphones to what the company   referred to as ""hero devices.""In addition to those chips
column19: Intel had been pursuing   stand-alone cellular-modem efforts for quite some time
column20: though   with little success until recently.Investors might be aware that Intel canceled its pipeline of   mobile-processor products and substantially reduced its   investment levels there. (Intel said at its most recent investor   meeting that from 2015 to 2017
column21: its spending in mobile will go   down about 55%.)So
column22: Intel is
column23: by and large
column24: neutralized as a threat to   Qualcomm's mobile-processor business.However
column25: the company won a large portion of the cellular-modem   spots inside Apple's iPhone 7 series of smartphones
column26: which led to   a reasonable bump in revenue for Intel and a corresponding   decrement to Qualcomm's revenues.Qualcomm sharpening its knivesThough Intel's mobile efforts ultimately translated into   Qualcomm losing some business at Apple
column27: Qualcomm's ambitions are   much more significant.Qualcomm announced that it will be working with software giantMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) to bring personal computers running Windows 10 on   Qualcomm's Snapdragon 835 processors to market during the second   half of 2017 -- directly attacking Intel's largest business.To make matters worse for Intel (and perhaps sweeten the deal   for Qualcomm)
column28: Qualcomm seems committed to developing data-center   processors for now. Significant share gains on Qualcomm's part   (and corresponding share losses on Intel's part) -- should they   occur -- aren't likely to happen overnight.However
column29: Qualcomm's upcoming Centriq 2400 chips havealready gotten Microsoft's blessingfor its internal use
column30: which lends credibility to the notion that   major data-center customers may be willing -- and
column31: frankly
column32: eager   -- to work with alternative suppliers rather than Intel.The upside and downside for each companyFor Intel
column33: the only upside I see in this contest is its   potential to gain some additional cellular-modem share from   Qualcomm at Apple. The opportunity likely isn't that big from the   standpoint of annual revenue
column34: and that revenue would likely come   at a much lower margin than Intel's corporate average. Right now
column35: Intel's ability to hurt Qualcomm in its core wireless-chip   business seems limited.The upside for Qualcomm
column36: on the other hand
column37: seems greater. It   can take share from Intel in the latter company's core business   of personal-computer chips
column38: as well as its data-center business
column39: starting from essentially zero share.Intel certainly has significant resources with which to defend   itself
column40: so it's probably not prudent for investors in either   company to model in substantial market-share shifts to Qualcomm   anytime soon. But
column41: in terms of which company has more to gain and   which has more to lose: The answers come up Qualcomm and Intel
column42: respectively.10 stocks we like better than QualcommWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column43: it can pay to listen. After all
column44: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column45: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column46: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Qualcomm wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column47: 2017Teresa Kersten is an employee of LinkedIn and is a member     of The Motley Fool's board of directors. LinkedIn is owned by     Microsoft.Ashraf Eassaowns shares of Intel and Qualcomm. The Motley Fool owns shares     of and recommends Apple and Qualcomm. The Motley Fool has the     following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and     short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley Fool     recommends Intel. column1: 3 Reasons Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is Becoming Tougher to Own;3/14/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsBy most accounts
column3: the future looks bright forApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL). Citi recently upped its price target on Apple stock in anticipation of a massive wave of upgrades from iPhone owners who have aging models
column4: and the company's plans to double its high-margin service revenue over the course of the coming four years doesn't seem un-doable.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockAfter all
column5: AAPL has been beefing up its app and digital content business at a rather brisk pace for some time now.And yet
column6: to observers not looking at the company through rose-colored glasses
column7: there's potential trouble ahead. Here's a closer look at three headwinds that could slow AAPL shares down more than most traders might expect.Three Troubling Realities for Apple StockLast week
column8: analysts with Citi raised their price target on Apple stock from $140 to $160 per share (maintaining the research outfit's ""Buy"" rating)
column9: thinking a wide swath of the 715 million iPhone owners out there right now are on the verge of finally upgrading their device
column10: as31% of those owners haven't upgraded in a couple of years.It's not bad logic; we know the company's best new customers are its old ones.10 Dangerous Dividend Stocks to Dump NowMeanwhile
column11: though it was little more than an afterthought just a year ago
column12: CEO Tim Cook has put plenty of emphasis on sales of services and digital content. He's only scratched the surface
column13: however. After generating roughly $25 billion in revenue in 2016
column14: Apple is aiming for $50 billion in services revenue by $50 billion. That's still only a fraction of the $215 billion worth of revenue Apple mustered in 2016
column15: but digital sales now make up the company's second-biggest segment; the iPhone is still the biggest.Before we pop the corks on the champagne bottles though
column16: there are three red flags everyone would be wise to process.1. The iPhone 8 (probably) costs too muchWhile the launch of the iPhone 7 in the fall of last year could be considered a success in that the company sold arecord-breaking 78.2 million units in the previous quarter
column17: given thehype surrounding the device
column18: the company should have blown away sales figures for its iPhone 6.Some (many) suspect the demand that should have materialized for the 7 was ultimately displaced to the iPhone 8
column19: which is supposed to be unveiled in September of this year. The word is that the admittedly impressive device is going togo for a cool $1000 each. At that price
column20: even the most loyal of Apple fans could balk.2. The popular smartphone is preemptively cannibalizing itselfAside from sticker shock
column21: would-be owners of the upcoming iPhone 8 may keep their wallet closed for the same reason many potential buyers of the iPhone 7 didn't pull the trigger - they're waiting for the phone after the next phone
column22: which is sure to be even more amazing.To that end
column23: what's currently being referred to as the iPhone 9 already promises (in rumors) to be an amazing piece of hardware
column24: complete with a folding screen. That may postpone purchases of the iPhone 8 later this year
column25: though 2018's iPhone 9 could see softer demand because whispers of the iPhone 10 rumors will be circulating by then.It's a vicious cycle
column26: with Apple arguably unable to ever really log a blowout iPhone launch.Fitbit Has BlackBerry Syndrome (FIT)3. The Google Pixel is really
column27: really impressiveFinally
column28: as solid as the recent Pixel phone fromAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column29: NASDAQ:GOOGL) subsidiary Google was
column30: it wasn't a game-changer. Analysts estimate the companyonly sold about 2.5 million of the device.Bear in mind
column31: however
column32: this is Google's first direct foray into the smartphone world
column33: and could be considered little more than a dry run.The Pixel 2 is slated to debut sometime this year
column34: and it's a good bet the company has made a point of learning a lot with its first outing.Bottom Line for AAPL StockInvariably
column35: some (or several) owners of Apple stock interpret these concerns as a call that the company is doomed
column36: and then proceed to ""colorfully disagree."" So
column37: let me clarify something that shouldn't need saying. That is
column38: even on AAPL stock's worst day it's still essentially unstoppable to other smartphone players. Don't read too much into the worries.On the flipside
column39: in that Apple stock is all too often found on investors' pedestals - lifted there by assumptions that the company is infallible - it's never a bad idea to recognize all plausible risks. These three risks could each end up stirring up surprising headwinds
column40: and nothing takes a toll on a stock like an unexpected disappointment.As of this writing
column41: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Blue-Chip Stocks Holding You Back7 Future Blue-Chip Stocks You Need to BuyThe post3 Reasons Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is Becoming Tougher to Ownappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: It's Time To Use This Winning Trade Again;3/14/2017;Earnings season is virtually over
column2: and with 99% of the   companies in the S&P 500 reporting
column3: results are a little   better than expected. About two-thirds of companies beat   analysts' expectations
column4: in line with the long-term average rate.   Earnings per share (EPS) came in about 4.9% higher than they were a year ago
column5: the first   time we've seen year-over-year growth in earnings for two   consecutive quarters in two years.It seems as if the earnings outlook should be bullish for the   stock market based on the growth in EPS
column6: but many analysts are   warning that the market is overvalued. Such warnings are often   based on charts like the one below
column7: which shows the   price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio is higher than average.This chart looks back at the past 10 years. Interestingly
column8: to   me
column9: the P/E ratio reached its high in the first quarter of 2010
column10: as the stock market was bottoming. Bears were arguing the market   was overvalued when it was at the beginning of what would prove   to be an extended bull market.You could argue that the recession was an extraordinary time   for the economy and no one could forecast what would happen next.   The president
column11: Congress
column12: the Federal Reserve and regulators were   all doing what they could to boost the economy.I would argue those same sentiments apply to 2017. No one   knows what will happen next on tax policy
column13: regulation or even   interest rate policy. Washington is in turmoil
column14: and upcoming   changes could boost earnings
column15: which might make the current P/E   ratio of 21.5 look like a bargain.We know there is talk of a tax cut. Corporate rates could fall   from 35% to 20% or even lower. These rumored changes are expected   to happen by August
column16: and I believe it will be retroactive to the   beginning of the year. A tax cut of that magnitude would raise   EPS sharply.For now
column17: analysts expect EPS of $131.28 for the companies in   the S&P 500. To be conservative
column18: we can assume the drastic   reduction in taxes increases earnings by just 8%
column19: an amount equal   to about one-third the reduction in rates. This would boost   earnings to $142 a share.A decrease in regulatory costs could also increase company's   bottom lines.It's important to remember these changes don't occur in a   vacuum. Real action from Congress should increase consumer   sentiment
column20: which would be reflected in higher sales and earnings   for large companies. In short
column21: the economy could grow much more   than expected this year
column22: and EPS could be much higher than   expected when the fourth quarter is actually reported.Stocks are pricing in higher earnings
column23: and some analysts   believe current levels are dangerous
column24: as prices could decline if   Congress becomes deadlocked. I see opportunity for now but am   watching closely for signs of irrational exuberance in the   market.While I am bullish in the long run
column25: I do believe caution is   warranted in the short run. Stocks have moved up quickly since   the election
column26: and we've had more than two weeks' worth of   consecutive record highs in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. Now   is a time for caution
column27: and I want to turn to a trade with a high   degree of safety
column28: a short-term put sale in Apple (Nasdaq:AAPL).I've successfully sold puts on AAPL five times since July 2016   for annualized returns of 44.8% 27.4%
column30: 64.3% and even   78.9%. Needless to say
column31: it's one of my favorite companies to   generate income from and a common recommendation for myIncome Tradersubscribers.If you want the details of my latest AAPL trade
column32: or would like   to learn more about my put selling strategy
column33: follow this link.Related ArticlesWhy Starbucks' Stock Could Soon Hit Record       LevelsDon't Make These 3 Common Pre-IPO Investing       MistakesA Value Buy In The World's Best Industry

column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of a possible reveal time frame for the next generation of iPad devices. Today
column3: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Monday.makeArticleAd();iPad Reveal:A new rumor claims that Apple is preparing to reveal its new iPad devices sometime next week
column4: reportsMacRumors. The rumor claims that the tech company will announce the next generation of its tablets sometime between Monday and Friday of next week. This news came from insider sources in AAPL's supply chain. However
column5: the sources didn't identify what new iPad models will be coming with the announcement next week.iPad Test:Apple is apparently testing out new iPad devices at its headquarters in Cupertino
column6: Tech Crunchnotes. Fiksu
column7: a mobile marketing firm
column8: has collected raw data on four different iPad devices that are in testing right now. This data comes from the firm's tracking and attribution SDK that can be found in many apps. While four iPad devices are listed in the data
column9: that doesn't mean four new tablets are on the way. Fisku also saw four tablets being tested before the release of the latest two iPad Pro models.iOS 10.3 Beta:Developers can now download the newest beta of iOS 10.3
column10: reports9to5Mac.The new beta made available by AAPL is the sixth version of the iOS 10.3 beta that has been sent out for developers. It includes several new features that will be coming to the public when the final version of the update comes out. This includes a feature for finding missing AirPods. A version of the beta for public testers will likely come out in the next few days.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postMonday Apple Rumors: Apple May Reveal Its New iPads Next Weekappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Can Pandora Catch Up to Apple Music and Spotify?;3/13/2017;"Pandora(NYSE: P)  is finally throwing its hat into the premium   on-demand streaming ring. Pandora will roll out Pandora Premium   on Wednesday
column2: giving music fans the ability to pick out the   actual songs that they want to hear.Pandora Premium is the right product
column3: but it's also easy to   wonder if the music discovery pioneer is too late to this niche.   Spotify andApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) already seem to have the premium on-demand market   carved out with more than 70 million paying subscribers between   the two of them. Where does Pandora fit in?The new service won't win anyone over on price. Pandora   Premium is anchored to the same $9.99 a month price point of   Spotify
column4: with 50 million paid accounts
column5: and Apple Music
column6: which   topped 20 million premium users late last year. A distinctive   feature for Pandora Premium will be how it incorporates elements   of its flagship service that's consumed largely as a free   ad-supported service
column7: but it may not be enough to sway its   current users to pay up
column8: since they're already seemingly getting   what they want for free.makeArticleAd();Image source: Pandora.Around the dialPandora closed out the fourth quarter with 81 million active   listeners
column9: but they are mostly freeloaders. Just 4.39 million of   those active listeners are paying for access to ad-free streams   with less restrictive parameters in a platform called Pandora   Plus. Pandora will give those subscribers six-month trials to   Pandora Premium at no additional cost
column10: a sweet deal since they're   only paying half as much now. How many of those 4.39 million   users will be willing to pay $9.99 a month come September? How   will Pandora smoke out new subscribers? The answers aren't clear
column11: and this could be why Pandora stock seems to be stuck in a rut   outside of the pockets of time when buyout speculation starts to   percolate.Pandora has a problem with user growth. It had 81.1 million   active listeners a year ago
column12: so its audience base has stalled.   Folks on the platform still spend a lot of time on Pandora
column13: but   it could be because they can't or won't pay Apple
column14: Spotify
column15: or   other tech giants in this crowded field for on-demand   streaming.There's no denying that on-demand streaming is hot. Spotify is   tacking on 10 million more subscribers worldwide every six   months. Apple Music is up to 20 million users in less than two   years
column16: and it has the advantage of pushing subscriptions through   its iOS devices.How will Pandora Plus stand out? Existing Pandora users will   be able to access all of the tracks that they have ever given a   thumbs up to as its own playlist. There's also a feature where   users can pick a song or two and have a playlist automatically   populated based on Pandora's time-tested music-matching   algorithms
column17: but that's close to what they can already enjoy   today.Pandora is late
column18: but it's desperate and hungry. Its chances of   being anything more than a distant bronze medallist in on-demand   streaming -- at best -- are slim
column19: but at least it's now in the   conversation of being trendy and relevant. We won't know until   much later this year if folks on free trials are sticking around
column20: but current investors should take some degree of comfort in   knowing that expectations are low and the stock price reflects   exactly that.10 stocks we like better than Pandora MediaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: How Apple Inc. Can Keep the Premium iPhone a Step Ahead;3/13/2017;"Later this year
column2: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) is expected to launch a premium iPhone in addition   to two direct successors to today's iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus.   The differentiating features of the new iPhone are expected to be   the use of an OLED display (in contrast to less advanced liquid   crystal displays) as well as a newer
column3: more premium-looking   industrial design.However
column4: at some point -- quite possibly with iPhone models   that will launch in the fall of 2018 -- the more ""mainstream""   iPhone models will see design makeovers and incorporate the newer   OLED display technology.Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();How
column5: then
column6: after introducing a ""premium"" iPhone in the fall of   2017
column7: can Apple continue to bring out differentiated premium   iPhone models in the years ahead that will be worthy of a   meaningful premium to the ""standard"" models.In this column
column8: I'd like to go over a couple of ways that come   to mind.Better camerasOne of the big selling points of this year's iPhone 7 Plus was   the addition of a dual camera system. Apple used the dual cameras   to enable a 2X optical zoom feature as well as a depth of field   feature (Apple marketed it as ""portrait mode"").Given that Apple reported that the iPhone 7 Plus is proving to   be the company'sbest ""Plus"" model everin terms of mix within the company's iPhone 7-series shipments
column9: it's probably reasonable to assume that potential customers are   willing to pay more for interesting camera features.Going forward
column10: I could see Apple introducing three tiers of   camera functionality: a baseline camera tier for the standard   iPhone
column11: an upgraded version for the Plus variant
column12: and then a   still more feature-rich camera subsystem for the premium   iPhone.Indeed
column13: as Apple will obviously want to charge more for said   premium iPhone
column14: it should have greater room in its bill of   materials to use more expensive technologies (image sensors
column15: lenses
column16: etc.)Better processorsToday
column17: Apple uses the same A-series chips for its standard   iPhone and its Plus iPhone model. The only iOS product that gets   a fundamentally better processor is the company's iPad.Going forward
column18: though
column19: it might make sense for Apple to   differentiate its lineup based on the processors inside --   classic performance segmentation. The standard iPhone models   could use the standard A-series chip (i.e. A11
column21: etc.) while   the premium iPhone model could get
column22: say
column23: a ""+"" variant of that   chip (i.e. A11+
column25: etc.)Apple wouldn't need to go crazy in necessarily building an   all-new chip just for the premium iPhone (though there might be a   compelling case for that)
column26: but what it could do is be more   aggressive about picking the very best A-series processors that   roll off the line and run them at higher speeds than what the   ""standard"" A-series chips run at to deliver better   performance.A slightly faster chip by itself likely isn't going to   convince many to go with a premium iPhone if they had no   intention of doing so anyway
column27: but such a marketing point could   tip the scales if a customer is trying to figure out if the   better
column28: higher-priced model is really the way to go.Better displaysToday
column29: Apple already differentiates its iPhone models by   display quality -- the Plus models use sharper displays than   their standard counterparts. And
column30: of course
column31: Apple seems to be   readying to segment by display technology even further in the   coming product cycle (i.e. OLED for the premium model
column32: LCDs for   the standard models).Apple should continue to do that going forward. Even once the   mainstream iPhone models have gotten their eventual OLED   upgrades
column33: Apple can still differentiate its premium iPhone with   other display enhancements such as curved displays
column34: higher   resolution displays
column35: brighter displays
column36: and so on.Foolish takeawayAt the end of the day
column37: Apple's job is this: it needs to build   increasingly compelling products to drive iPhone upgrades (and   potentially share gains)
column38: and it needs to segment its product   line more aggressively to drive upsell and therefore maximize   average selling prices/profitability for a given level of unit   shipments.Apple appears well on its way to fully exploiting the   potential that exists here
column39: and I think over the next couple of   years -- beginning with the coming iPhone cycle -- investors will   see an acceleration in these efforts that may ultimately enhance   shareholder value.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Can Pandora's New Subscription Service Compete with Spotify?;3/13/2017;"Just three months after the company announced initial plans
column2: internet radio giant PandoraPis ready to debut its streaming music service. For $9.99 a month
column3: Pandora Premium lets subscribers play and choose any song or album
column4: as well as utilize new playlist creation features.Pandora has been around since 2000
column5: and is known for its free
column6: ad-supported radio service. While users cannot choose a specific song
column7: they can pick artists and music genres
column8: and give songs thumbs up or thumbs down to help narrow downs choices.For $4.99 a month
column9: the company currently offers Pandora Plus
column10: which lets subscribers listen to music without ads
column11: skip more songs they dislike
column12: and download songs for offline listening. Pandora Premium
column13: however
column14: could help the company compete with the likes of Spotify and Apple'sAAPLApple Music.""Every day tens of millions of people trust us to choose the exact right song for them. That's why they spend more time with Pandora than any other music service
column15: said Pandora CEO and founder Tim Westergren in a statement. ""With Premium
column16: we're leveraging our immense trove of data and everything we've learned about personalization to offer a listening experience that sets a new standard for what a music service should be.""With Pandora Premium

column18: albums

column23: which includes every song they've thumbed up on Pandora.But can Pandora Premium successfully compete with Spotify?To be blunt

column25: without a doubt

column29: but some may stop for a second look. Pandora has about 80 million current users-4.39 million of whom are already paying for Pandora Plus-and the company stands to benefit from transitioning its current users

column1: Why Japanese Beer Stocks Could Be the Next Big Play of 2017;3/13/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsCall it the silent arrow of Abenomics
column3: the series of economic plans proposed by Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's administration. Inspired by an ancient tax code from the 19th century
column4: Japanese beer is an absolute enigma from a legal perspective. Rather than impose a fairly simpleexcise taxon alcoholic beverages
column5: Japanese beer has agradation policy. This has prevented many of the nation's beer stocks from truly reaching their potential.makeArticleAd();Source:Moyan Brenn via FlickrBreweries in Japan are regulated by malt content - the greater the malt
column6: the more taxes you pay.If you thought that was weird
column7: hold on - it gets worse! Real Japanese beer is labeled at the grocery markets as such: beer. But for those that want to avoid the onerous taxation of standard malt beverages
column8: breweries can produce beer knockoffs
column9: or derisively known as ""happoshu."" These beverages integrate peas
column10: corn
column11: or soybeans
column12: essentially anything undesirable to drop the malt content.In fact
column13: the ""Big Four"" of Japanese beer stocks -Asahi Group Holdings Ltd(OTCMKTS:ASBRF)
column14: Kirin Holdings Co Ltd(ADR)(OTCMKTS:KNBWY)
column15: Suntory Beverage & Food Ltd(OTCMKTS:STBFY) andSapporo Holdings NPV(OTCMKTS:SOOBF) - have an unwritten policy of flooding the market with happoshu. This way
column16: they can still sell their alcoholic beverages while getting underneath the taxation threshold.Japanese Beer Stocks Versus the GovernmentThe current iteration of Japanese beer laws dates back to 1953
column17: according toJapan Inc. Since then
column18: two revisions were introduced - one in 1962
column19: and one in 1989. The latter year was the most burdensome for the country's beer stocks
column20: ironic because it was the pinnacle of the Nikkei 225 index.7 Cheap Dividend Stocks to Buy NowAt that time
column21: several goods saw their tax liabilities reduced. Unfortunately for Japanese beer stocks
column22: their brew was not affected. Deciding not to take the disparity lightly
column23: STBFY was the first among the beer stocks tointroduce happoshuin 1994. Shortly thereafter
column24: ASBRF
column25: KNBWY and SOOBF followed suit with their own variants of cheap beer.What was a creative
column26: but literally distasteful way
column27: of getting around Japan's archaic alcohol laws was a short-lived victory. The suits in Tokyo caught on to the scheme
column28: and began adjusting their malt threshold lower. In response
column29: Japanese beer stocks became creative in their concoctions. The back and forth provided jobs for research and development teams
column30: but was a nightmare for anyone who enjoys a cold one.Inarguably
column31: though
column32: Japan's craft brewery industry absorbed the most pain. Because craft beer containsexotic ingredients
column33: the government often classifies them as happoshu. That wouldn't be a problem except for one thing - craft beer is expensive to make. But since they're labeled as happoshu
column34: domestic powerhouse STBFY overwhelms them. After all
column35: why pay more for cheap beer?For independent Japanese beer companies
column36: the choices are limited. Domestically
column37: the term happoshu has a negative connotation. Internationally
column38: they would get clobbered by the mainstay beer stocks ASBRF
column39: KNBWY
column40: and SOOBF.Beer Stocks Critical for AbenomicsFortunately
column41: change is on the horizon. According toBloomberg
column42: the ""Finance Ministry
column43: in an effort to boost the competitiveness of Japanese beers in the international market
column44: will change the tax rates for beer and the substitutes starting in 2020
column45: continuing through 2026. In 2018 it will expand the list of ingredients allowed inside the can. Leveling the taxes and removing the happoshu stigma could mean fast growth for the nation's craft brewers.""With smaller beer stocks able to compete in a more transparent environment
column46: Japan can boost its regional economies.This falls right into the core principle of Abenomics - revitalize Japan through removing its shackles. In recent years
column47: this translated into a national dialogue of women in the workplace and attracting immigration. Of course
column48: as a country steeped in tradition
column49: some of the arrows of Abenomics are more palatable than others.Should Apple Inc. Cut Its Dividend? (AAPL)The best part about Japanese beer stocks is that no one is going to turn down a cold one. Even the worst ideas sound great after alcohol consumption. But in all seriousness
column50: the revamped tax codes make so much sense. Bloomberg further notes that domestic ""shipments of all beer have declined for 12 straight years
column51: according to the Brewers Association of Japan""; giving craft breweries a reason to exist is an important and necessary step.New Policy a Welcome ChangeThe policy shift isn't just favorable for independent beer stocks. The majors are welcoming this transition with open arms. KNBWY CEO Yoshinori Isozaki bluntly stated that ""Too much attention has been given to winning market share through price wars
column52: and we have left behind what is most important - the customer.""ASBRF and SOOBF have issued similar complaints for years. The average tax on Japanese beer is 800% higher than American beer
column53: and 1
column54: 800% more expensive than its German counterpart. Antiquated laws were killing Japanese beer stocks from the inside out. But with the changing political tide
column55: major brewers like STBFY arereinvesting in premiumbeverages.So far
column56: this dynamic has occurred relatively quietly
column57: and understandably so. Japan of today isn't the Japan of the 1980s. Nevertheless
column58: the new Japanese beer policy is one of the most dramatic changes in the nation's retail distribution. As a result
column59: don't be surprised to find that Japanese beer stocks will remain silent no longer!As of this writing
column60: Josh Enomoto did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Monthly Dividend Stocks to Buy to Pay the Bills8 Energy Stocks in Peril as Crude Oil Breaks DownThe postWhy Japanese Beer Stocks Could Be the Next Big Play of 2017appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Apple Inc. Building Graphics Chip Team in the U.K.;3/13/2017;"It's no secret at this point thatApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) is building its own graphics processors. In fact
column2: not only is Apple working on its own graphics processors
column3: but   microprocessor expert David Kanterrevealedlast year that Apple has been employing its own graphics   processors inside of its A-series processors since the launch of   its A8 system-on-a-chip in the fall of 2014.Based on where many of the graphics-oriented Apple employees   that I see onLinkedInappear to be located
column4: the company apparently has a graphics   processor design site in Orlando
column5: FL.Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();While perusing LinkedIn
column6: I noticed that one of my connections   began advertising the fact that Apple is looking to fill   positions in its U.K.-based ""Apple Hardware Design Center.""Unsurprisingly
column7: as you can see in the screenshot below
column8: all   the positions that came up were graphics related:Image source: LinkedIn.Further
column9: when I clicked on one of the positions (""Graphics   Modeling Engineer"")
column10: the job description says ""This is a career   defining opportunity to get in at the ground floor as we build   our UK Design Centre.""It's clear that the company is building a graphics processor   design team in the U.K. So
column11: why is the company doing that?Increasing the pace of innovationWhat I suspect Apple is doing is building a parallel graphics   processor team to the one(s) that it already has in place. If   that hypothesis is correct
column12: it'll mean that the company will gain   the ability to work on multiple graphics processors in a ""leap   frogging"" fashion.That is
column13: Team 1 works on the graphics processor that'll be   used in some iPhone (let's call it iPhone x) while Team 2 works   in parallel on the graphics processor that will be used in the   follow-on iPhone
column14: iPhone x+1. Then
column15: once Team 1 finishes its work   on the graphics processor for iPhone x
column16: it begins working on the   graphics processor for iPhone x+2.Under such a development methodology -- and it is a common one   in the chip industry -- a company can increase the pace and the   scope of the innovation that it can bring with each new   design.Why is Apple doubling-down on graphics?Apple CEO Tim Cook is on record stating that he believes that   augmented reality will be ahuge deal. To fully capitalize on the opportunities in both virtual   reality and augmented reality
column17: companies are likely going to need   to have significant expertise when it comes to efficient
column18: high-performance graphics processors.In other words
column19: it's an intellectual property that could be   very important for the future of the iPhone and mobile devices in   general.Beyond the iPhone
column20: though
column21: Apple surely wants to have   best-in-class graphics to enable the kinds of workloads and   experiences that it can deliver through its iPad (which it is   positioning as a notebook/PC replacement) as well as through its   Apple TV products (better graphics could help Apple TV inch   closer to becoming a game console competitor).Apple appears to recognize the importance of having excellent   graphics technologies in-house and I think what we are seeing is   Apple simply making financial bets commensurate with that   viewpoint.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column23: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Should Apple Inc. Cut Its Dividend? (AAPL);3/13/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) is the world's largest technology company
column3: and it once was one of the best growth stocks on the market. It has shifted gears
column4: though
column5: and now Apple stock is one of the more promising dividend growth plays on the market.makeArticleAd();Source:FlickrAAPL paid its first dividend - at least since 1995 - on Aug. 16
column6: 2012. It paid investors 38.9 cents per share on a split-adjusted basis.The payout has been hiked four times since
column7: and currently sits at 57 cents per share. That's a compound annual growth rate of 10%
column8: with 2017's dividend increase expected to be similar. After all
column9: AAPL stock only has a payout ratio of 27% of its trailing earnings and a 1.6% yield.When you look at shareholder yield - dividends plus buybacks - Apple's record is even more impressive. The company spent $12.2 billion on dividends and a whopping $29.2 billion on share repurchases in 2016. That works out to a shareholder yield of 5.6%.AAPL is returning capital at a blistering pace.10 Monthly Dividend Stocks to Buy to Pay the BillsHowever
column10: while most shareholders are ecstatic with the dividend on Apple stock
column11: allow me to present an alternate argument:Apple should cut its payout … and maybe even eliminate it altogether.Apple
column12: Meet AlphabetLet's take a minute to compare Apple to one of its peers
column13: Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL).Alphabet's dividend policy is pretty clear. It saidin its 2016 10-K filing
column14: ""We have never declared or paid any cash dividend on our common or capital stock. We intend to retain any future earnings and do not expect to pay any cash dividends in the foreseeable future.""Alphabet can easily afford a dividend
column15: too. It made $19.5 billion in 2016
column16: or $28.32 per share.The reasoning behind this is simple. Alphabet is aggressively investing in the kinds of projects that can really boost its top line. It has been working on a self-driving car since 2009. It invested more than$6 billion on Google Fiber. Alphabet also teamed up withFidelitytoinvest $1 billion inSpaceX.In total
column17: Alphabet spent $13.9 billion on research and development in 2016
column18: as well as $10.2 billion on capital expenditures.Apple is still investing in the future
column19: but not as aggressively as Alphabet. AAPL spent $10 billion on research and development and $13.5 billion on capital expenditures in 2016
column20: despite making a net profit of $45.7 billion.In other words
column21: Alphabet reinvested $24.1 billion back into its business in 2016 while earning $19.5 billion. Apple reinvested $23.5 billion while earning $45.7 billion. AAPL barely reinvested half of its earnings back into its business.AAPL Needs to Make Some AcquisitionsApple does have some exciting plans. One of the tech world's worst-kept secrets is Apple's plans to somehow be a part of thecar of the future. It has also been working in thevirtual reality space
column22: and many expect big improvements toApple TV. These investments are great. But I don't think they'll be enough to usher in a new era of growth.It's time for Apple to go shopping.Apple could easily take the $41 billion it gave back to shareholders in 2016 and use it to make a huge splash.Say Apple agreed to buyNetflix
column23: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX) at a 50% premium to today's price - so
column24: roughly $91 billion. AAPL could pay off the deal in just a few years from its existing cash flow alone
column25: and would own a company that has doubled revenues in the last three years.Intel Corporation (INTC) Buys Mobileye NV (MBLY) to Win the Auto MarketApple's main growth driver today is service revenue. In its most recent quarter
column26: AAPL grew its top line 3% on a quarter-over-quarter basis.It grew services revenue by 18%. Acquiring Netflix would would not only supercharge that division
column27: it would give Apple access to Netflix's whole library of content.The Bottom Line on Apple StockThere's a reason why AAPL trades at the same multiple as the rest of the market. Investors assume - rightfully so - that it is a mature company with no immediate growth prospects. If Apple slashed its dividend and announced it was using that money for acquisitions
column28: investors would sit up and take notice.There's no guarantee such sentiment would send Apple stock soaring right away. In fact
column29: it'd be easy to see the market taking the short-term view that something is amiss
column30: and selling AAPL as a result.But if executed right
column31: such a strategy would make Apple shareholders richer in the long run.As of this writing
column32: Nelson Smith did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities. You can follow him onTwitter
column33: or his own personal blog

Comparing the most recent share price to the 200 day moving average can also be a useful technical analysis technique --learn more about the 200 day moving average ».Exchange traded funds (ETFs) trade just like stocks
column22: but instead of ''shares'' investors are actually buying and selling ''units''. These ''units'' can be traded back and forth just like stocks
column23: but can also be created or destroyed to accommodate investor demand. Each week we monitor the week-over-week change in shares outstanding data
column24: to keep a lookout for those ETFs experiencing notable inflows (many new units created) or outflows (many old units destroyed). Creation of new units will mean the underlying holdings of the ETF need to be purchased
column25: while destruction of units involves selling underlying holdings
column26: so large flows can also impact the individual components held within ETFs.Click here to find out which 9 other ETFs had notable inflows »"

column1: Report: Apple Inc.'s Revolutionary OLED iPhone Will Have a Flat Display;3/13/2017;"A market research analyst with IHS Markit told MacRumors thatApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) upcoming premium iPhone -- which is widely   expected to usher in an all-new industrial design with an OLED   display -- will not use acurvedOLED display. Instead
column2: it will use a ""flat"" OLED display that the   analyst says will be ""analogous to the current 2.5D glass   design.""The IHS Markit analyst isn't the first credible source to   claim that Apple's OLED iPhone will have a flat OLED display;   MacRumors points out that KGI Securities analyst Ming-Chi Kuo as   well as TrendForce -- both credible sources with good track   records -- had previously reported that the OLED iPhone would use   ""2.5D cover glass.""Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();What does this news mean for Apple's business and
column3: ultimately
column4: investors? Here's my take.Curved or not
column5: this is a big jumpThe OLED iPhone
column6: whether it has a curved display or not
column7: is   likely going to be a real improvement in form factor and   aesthetics compared with the current-generation models. The OLED   display itself should enable much improved image quality (if   Apple can make this display HDR-capable
column8: then that'd be an even   bigger bonus)
column9: and the form factor is said to include a   stainless-steel frame as well as a higher screen-to-body ratio   than the current iPhone models do.The display and form factor changes
column10: coupled with what are   sure to be solid improvements in camera capabilities
column11: internal   specifications
column12: and even the rumored 3D sensing capabilities
column13: are   probably going to be enough to trigger a so-called iPhone ""super   cycle"" -- at least if such a cyclecanstill occur these days.If Apple can ship the devices with a curved OLED display
column14: that'd be nice
column15: but this is unlikely to make or break the   commercial success of the device.Saving curved displays for next time?Interestingly
column16: a report from The Bell (via MacRumors) claims   that Apple aims to switch over completely to OLED-based displays   for its iPhone product line by 2019.I suspect that once Apple introduces this rumored premium   iPhone in its product stack
column17: it is going to want to continue to   have products at that price point in future generations even as   technologies originally introduced at that premium price point   trickle down into the more mainstream models.Image source: Apple.What Apple could do
column18: then
column19: is ""save"" the curved display for   the premium iPhone that it introduces next year
column20: while   transitioning its mainstream iPhone products to flat OLED   displays. That way
column21: Apple improves the appeal of its products   across its product stack while keeping the best technological   goodies in the most expensive products.An exciting product cycle ahead for AppleThe main point is this: Apple appears to have an exciting   product cycle ahead of it as it introduces the premium OLED   iPhone alongside what are expected to be refreshed versions of   the current iPhone 7/7 Plus designs.What remains an open question
column22: though
column23: is how Apple intends to   maintain/grow iPhone demand following the potentially upcoming   ""super cycle.""Apple may be able to further stimulate demand by bringing flat   OLED displays to the ""standard"" price points while introducing 3D   curved displays in the next-generation premium model
column24: but without   a significant delta in features/functionality between the   ""premium"" model and the ""standard"" models
column25: Apple might risk   seeing a mix down in its product shipments in the following   cycle.That said
column26: I have some thoughts on how Apple can counter that   -- but that's a topic that I'm saving for my next Apple-related   column. Stay tuned.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: The Next iPhone Could Be a Big Catalyst for These Apple Suppliers;3/13/2017;"Rumor has itApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL)  10th anniversary edition iPhone
column2: expected   this year
column3: is going to be groundbreaking. From its having a glass   body to sporting more memory to having an edge-to-edge OLED   display
column4: the rumors around the next iPhone are aplenty. One rumor   that seems to have gained some credibility of late is the   inclusion of wireless charging in Apple's next flagship   model.JPMorgananalyst Harlan Sur believes that at least one of Apple's iPhones   this year will sport customized wireless charging. Sur's forecast   is in agreement with what other analysts have been saying.   Ming-Chi Kuo of KGI Securities expects that all the iPhones Apple   releases this year will have the wireless-charging feature.Whether wireless charging will be part of the next iPhone and   whether that would boost sales is unknown. But it's not just   Apple fans who will be watching developments closely.Broadcom(NASDAQ: AVGO)  andDialog Semiconductor(NASDAQOTH: DLGNF) also stand to benefit from wireless charging   in iPhones.makeArticleAd();Broadcom can make big money from Apple's wireless   chargingSur's research note says that Apple and Broadcom have been   working on wireless-charging technology for a couple of   years. Apple's partnership with Broadcom does not come as a   surprise: The latter company was one of the first movers in this   space.Image source: Broadcom.Around three years back
column5: Broadcom launched a multistandard   wireless system-on-a-chip (SoC) -- the BCM59350 wireless-charging   power management unit -- for use in smartphones. Broadcom's   product was compatible with all of the wireless-charging   standards -- including the Wireless Power Consortium's -- so that   it can be used by different smartphone OEMs.At that time
column6: Broadcom had said that it was sampling the power   management unit with ""select customers
column7: but there has been no   update on the chip since. This leaves open the possibility of   Apple entering into an exclusivity arrangement with Broadcom; the   smartphone giant has been known in the past toforce its suppliersinto such deals.Additionally
column8: CNBC reports that Apple has entered the Wireless   Power Consortium
column9: which sets one of the standards that Broadcom's   chip supports. Moreover
column10: Sure also said that the rumored glass   case on the back of the upcoming iPhone will support wireless   charging
column11: since it is prone to less interference than a metal   case.The likelihood of Apple using Broadcom's chips to enable   wireless charging is definitely there. If this  turns out to   be the case
column12: Sur said
column13: Broadcom's iPhone revenue opportunity   from wireless charging could be worth $500 million to $600   million. But Broadcom might not be alone in the race for Apple's   wireless-charging riches.This Apple supplier could also be in the frayDialog Semiconductor relies heavily on Apple for revenue. The   U.K.-based company reportedly gets around 75% of its revenue from   Apple by supplying power management integrated circuits.In December 2016
column14: Dialog made a $10 million investment inEnergous(NASDAQ: WATT)
column15: which has developed a proprietary long-distance   wireless-charging technology known as WattUp. This technology can   charge smartphones from a distance of up to 15 feet.Image source: Energous.This February
column16: the two companies launched a small RF (radio   frequency) power circuit that's cheaper than the previous   generation and occupies less space. The companies have already   started sampling this chip to customers
column17: which means that   Broadcom might not be the lone contender for any Apple   wireless-charging content.Additionally
column18: Energous' technology is not new to Apple. As   reported by VentureBeat
column19: Energous' products and reference designs   have already undergone compliance testing at Apple
column20: which means   that the latter company could be considering its technology for   wireless charging. What's more
column21: Energous CEO Steve Rizzone   dropped a major hint that his company's wireless-charging tech   could be coming to mainstream devices later this year.The Vergequoted him as talking about a partnership with ""one of   the largest consumer electronics companies in the world. I cannot   tell you who it is
column22: but I can virtual guarantee that you have   products from this company on your person
column23: sitting on your desk
column24: or at home.""Investors in Dialog and Broadcom will be watching closely as   we get closer to having the next iPhone go on sale.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: How Will a Supplier's Factory Fire Affect Apple Inc.?;3/13/2017;"According to analysts with research firm BlueFin Research   Partners (by way ofBarron's)
column2: a ""small fire"" broke out in the basement of the clean room in   ST Microelectronics' manufacturing plant
column3: commonly referred to in   the chip industry as a fab
column4: short for ""fabrication plant
column5: in   Crolles
column6: France.""This fab is the sole manufacturing facility for 3D sensors""   at ST Microelectronics
column7: the analysts explain
column8: adding that this   ""incident has currently shut down the facility"" and that their   research ""indicates [that] it could take several weeks to   requalify the fab and resume production.""Why is this news? Because it's believed thatST Microelectronics(NYSE: STM) will be providing 3D image sensors toApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) for its upcoming premium iPhone.makeArticleAd();Image source: Apple.To make matters worse
column9: the analysts say these 3D sensors have   a ""long production cycle time"" and ""relatively low yield   rate."" BlueFin says these factors ""will make it difficult to   get back on their production schedule target with each day that   the fab is incapacitated.""Let's go over what the implications to Apple's upcoming   premium iPhone could be.Understanding the problemIt's important to understand that in the chip industry
column10: it   takes a long time to go from a blank silicon wafer to a fully   processed one with usable chips on it. The time it takes for the   wafer to go through the manufacturing process is called the   ""cycle time.""Cycle time is typically about three months
column11: give or take
column12: depending on several factors. According to BlueFin
column13: ST Micro's 3D   sensors have a ""long production cycle time
column14: so it might take   more like four months for these 3D sensors to be   manufactured.If the fab is taken offline for a significant amount of time
column15: that pushes out the entire chip production schedule. What this   ultimately could mean
column16: then
column17: is that Apple won't be able to build   as many iPhones as it had originally planned to ahead of the   launch.What is Apple to do?The BlueFin analysts say they ""believe it is likely that   [Apple] and [ST Micro] are assessing the impact to the schedule   and are working on a recovery plan."" Additionally
column18: they say they   ""have yet to see any corresponding push out of the iPhone 8/X   builds with the rest of the supply chain.""To be blunt
column19: I could see Apple simply going along with its   product launches as expected and simply having customers order   the phones
column20: even if it means that those customers must wait   several weeks for their devices to come in.You may recall that Apple facedmanufacturing yieldissues on its iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus devices in jet black. It   took a while before everyone's orders were fulfilled
column21: but people   got their orders in
column22: they waited
column23: and they eventually got   them.And
column24: of course
column25: Apple reached supply/demand balance for all   its iPhone models by January.Don't panicDesigning and building innovative devices with a whole host of   new and possibly difficult-to-manufacture components isn't easy
column26: and companies that try to stay at the forefront of device   innovation are necessarily going to face challenges in bringing   new products to market.That's just the reality of the situation
column27: and investors need   to get comfortable with that.The fire at ST Micro's fab is unfortunate
column28: and it's a headache   that both Apple and ST Micro could have gone without
column29: but I have   confidence that the experienced professionals at both companies   will do their best to contain the situation and launch the new   iPhones as soon as practicable.10 stocks we like better than STMicroelectronicsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Better Buy: Qualcomm Inc. vs. Intel Corporation;3/13/2017;"Big changes are afoot for bothQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) andIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) . Qualcomm has been making significant strides in   its efforts to expand its product suite beyond its dominant   smartphone leadership position. Artificial intelligence
column2: the   Internet of Things (IoT)
column3: and ""smart"" devices for the home and   car are a few up-and-coming markets on Qualcomm's radar.Meanwhile
column4: CEO Brian Krzanich has Intel keenly focused on its   own IoT
column5: smart devices
column6: and cloud-based data center ambitions.   Though Intel's transformation is showing signs of life
column7: its stock   price has languished much of the last year.So far in 2017
column8: Intel shares are down 1%
column9: while Qualcomm stock   has nosedived 11%. The two companies promise both growth and   income
column10: and have the potential to be sound value plays. Which one   is the better buy? Let's take a look.makeArticleAd();Snapdragon processor. Image source: Qualcomm.The Qualcomm caseRecent discussions involving Qualcomm involve ongoing legal   battles and the possible ramifications on its all-important   licensing revenue. There's also the proposed $47 billion deal for   Netherlands-basedNXP Semiconductors(NASDAQ: NXPI)
column11: which may not be quite the slam dunk Qualcomm   had hoped for.Qualcomm is facing multiple lawsuits brought by longtime   customerApple
column12: which is alleging unfair licensing fees for its patented   technologies. South Korea's Fair Trade Commission levied a record   $898 million fine against Qualcomm for much the same reason.   Legal back-and-forth in the tech sector is nothing new
column13: but even   the hint that Qualcomm's licensing revenue could be in jeopardy   has had investors running for the hills.Last quarter's 4% increase in total revenue to $6 billion was   driven by Qualcomm's impressive 13% jump in licensing sales to   $1.81 billion. Licensing is hands-down Qualcomm's leading profit   generator. Earnings before taxes in the segment tallied an   astounding $1.53 billion in fiscal 2017's first quarter
column14: equal to   85% of the unit's revenue. By contrast
column15: Qualcomm's mobile access   division generated $4.1 billion in quarterly sales
column16: but just 18%
column17: or $724 million
column18: of that total were earnings before taxes.As for NXP
column19: Qualcomm has recently extended its ""final"" offer   once again in an attempt to get the deal closed. CEO Steve   Mollenkopf cited the pending NXP acquisition as a key element in   Qualcomm's transition to IoT
column20: smart cars
column21: and data security   markets. If the NXP transaction falls through
column22: investors can   expect more near-term pressure on Qualcomm's stock price.Intel processor. Image source: Intel.The Intel caseBased on its stock price
column23: it's easy to forget Intel is coming   off a record-breaking quarter and year. Since the company   announced its record $16.4 billion in sales last quarter and   $59.4 billion in annual revenue
column24: Intel stock is down nearly 5%.   Investors' seemingly blase attitude toward Intel translates to it   being one of the best values in its sector.At just 12 times forward earnings
column25: Intel stock is woefully   undervalued
column26: which is great news for investors. The even-better   news is that Intel set its revenue records thanks to delivering   on its key growth areas. While a stronger-than-expected PC market   helped push client computing sales up 2%
column27: to $32.9 billion
column29: it was data center
column30: IoT
column31: and security results that put   Intel over the top.Cloud data centers generated $17.2 billion in revenue last   year
column32: up 8% from 2015. Intel followed that up with a 15% jump in   IoT sales
column33: to $2.6 billion
column34: and $2.2 billion in security revenue
column35: good for a 9% improvement. The three units combined continue to   make up an increasingly larger piece of Intel's revenue
column36: which   should help ease long-standing fears that the company is overly   reliant on PCs.Which is the better buy?As Krzanich put it recently
column37: Intel is shifting ""from a server   and CPU company to a data center company
column38: a transition that   investors will eventually buy into. Qualcomm's recent legal   and acquisition hiccups will likely sort themselves out before   long
column39: bringing investors back into the fold.Priced at just 12 times future earnings
column40: Qualcomm offers a   great deal of upside -- along with a 3.95% dividend yield -- for   investors willing to ride out the near-term storms. For the   more risk-averse
column41: Intel's 2.9% dividend and depressed stock price   offer a relatively stable long-term alternative to Qualcomm. The   better buy depends in part on your investing temperament.10 stocks we like better than QualcommWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Why Apple Should Be Scared of This Company;3/12/2017;"Image source: Getty Images.Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) andSamsung's(NASDAQOTH: SSNLF) reign at the top of the smartphone market is   under threat. Slowly but steadily
column2: Chinese telecom giant Huawei   has been spreading its wings across key global markets
column3: in a bid   to displace Apple and Samsung from the top of the smartphone   heap.makeArticleAd();Huawei's ambition of becoming the second-largest smartphone   company in the world received a shot in the arm in 2016
column4: as its   smartphone sales increased close to 27% from the year before. In   stark contrast
column5: both Apple's and Samsung's shipments fell 4.3%   over the same period
column6: according toGartner. The strong growth in shipments gave Huawei 8.9% of the   smartphone market in 2016 compared to 7.3% a year ago.By comparison
column7: the market shares of both Apple and Samsung   took a beating. The Cupertino-based smartphone giant's share of   the market fell by 1.5 percentage points to 14.4%
column8: while   Samsung's market share fell by two percentage points to 20.5%.   Huawei
column9: however
column10: has managed to consistently increase its   smartphone shipments
column11: leading to market-share gains:Data sources: Strategy Analytics and Counterpoint Technology     Market Research. Chart by author.Having already occupied the third place in the smartphone   race
column12: the Chinese vendor will now go all out to achieve its lofty   ambitions. In November 2016
column13: the chief executive of Huawei's   consumer business group told Reuters that it wants to become the   second-largest smartphone company in two years. But will it be   able to meet this aggressive target?China and India will be tailwinds for HuaweiThe Chinese company has been seeking growth in its home   market. Last year
column14: Huawei shipped 76.6 million phones in China   and sat in the second place with a market share of 16.4%.   Meanwhile
column15: Apple's Chinese shipments dropped an alarming 23% to   44.9 million units
column16: giving it a single-digit market share of just   9.6%.This means that Huawei has opened a huge gap over Apple in   China
column17: as its smartphone shipments there are up almost 22% in   2016. China will be the key to Huawei's global smartphone   dominance
column18: since it is the world's biggest smartphone market and   accounted for 21% of global shipments last year.What's more
column19: the growing adoption of LTE connections in China   means that smartphone demand in the country will remain strong.   GSMA Intelligence forecasts that China will have 1 billion   4G connections by 2020
column20: compared to 762 million at the end of   2016. The increased adoption of 4G means that customers will need   toupgrade to smartphonesfrom feature phones as they move away from legacy technologies   such as 2G and 3G.On the other hand
column21: Huawei is also looking to make inroads into   the Indian market. Last year
column22: it said that it aims to have 10% of   the Indian smartphone market by the end of 2017. In fact
column23: Huawei's Indian consumer operations reports directly to the   Chinese headquarters
column24: showing the company recognizes the   importance of this market.This is not surprising as annual smartphone sales in India are   expected to top 200 million units in 2020 (rising from 102   million units last year)
column25: making it the world's second-largest   market. If Huawei manages to carve out a 10% share for itself in   India
column26: it can add 20 million units in smartphone sales.This looks like an uphill task since it had just 0.5% of the   Indian market in the first half of 2016. But in September 2016
column27: Huawei began its smartphone manufacturing operations in India
column28: and it plans to manufacture 3 million units by the end of 2017.   If it is able to convert all these units into sales this year
column29: the company's Indian market share will gain respectability.By comparison
column30: Apple is yet to get its manufacturing   operations in India into full swing. Though its manufacturing   partner Wistron has set up a plant in the southern part of the   country
column31: it will only produce around 300
column33: 000 units of   the iPhone SE initially. This is a far cry from Huawei's   manufacturing capacity.The secret behind Huawei's growthHuawei has a smart formula to win over customers in big   smartphone markets -- offline sales. In China
column34: Huawei plans to   set up 1
column35: 000 stores across all counties
column36: apart from striking   partnerships with distributors and retailers. It also plans to   deploy 460 service stores in 45 nations.Meanwhile
column37: Huawei has partnered with more than 50
column38: 000 retail   outlets in India and is going to set up more than 200 service   centers. The company's offline-store strategy for emerging   markets is a smart one
column39: allowing it to gain more eyeballs and   eventually increase sales.In fact
column40: offline sales in markets such as India have been the   key to the success of Chinese smartphone companies
column41: since   customers have been able to touch and feel their phones before   buying. And
column42: just 35% of the Indian population had access to the   internet last year
column43: which could be another reason that Huawei has   been busy opening retail outlets in smaller cities.A similar scenario is unfolding in China
column44: where offline   smartphone sales are gaining momentum. The growing shift toward   offline smartphone sales has encouraged Huawei to drastically   ramp up its company-owned stores.Huawei had bumped its global store count by 116% to 35
column45: 000   toward the end of May 2016. The company has further strengthened   its retail presence as it planned to open another 15
column46: 000 stores   in 2016 itself. Around half of its stores are on the Chinese   mainland and across the rest of Asia
column47: with the next-largest   fraction in Europe.By comparison
column48: Apple has 491 stores spread across the globe
column49: and over half of them are in the U.S. What's more
column50: its store   presence in markets such as India and China is negligible   compared to Huawei's. Apple reportedly had 40 stores in China by   the end of June 2016
column51: when Huawei had over 11
column52: 000 stores on the   mainland. On the other hand
column53: Apple's plans to open stores in   India have been slowed by regulations
column54: though it might open up   three of them this year.Huawei's strong retail presence is complemented by the   company's strategy of offering both budget and premium   smartphones. The Honor 5C
column55: which some reviewers count among the   top budget phones
column56: costs less than $170 in India at current   exchange rates
column57: placing it way below the global-average   smartphone price of $256.In fact
column58: Huawei also sells feature phones in emerging markets   that cost less than $100. These budget phones help bring   customers to its stores and improve brand awareness. The company   is now gradually moving into the higher segment of the market by   launching more mid-range and premium phones
column59: which should   eventually improve the average selling prices of its phones.Image source: Huawei.The takeawayA strong retail presence and an extensive product portfolio   that covers all segments of the smartphone market have been the   catalysts behind Huawei's growth. In fact
column60: the company's   two-pronged strategy has put it in the limelight
column61: as the value of   its brand grew 28% in 2016 on the back of high-end devices and   marketing campaigns.Apple and Samsung
column62: therefore
column63: have a fierce competitor that   looks capable of breaking into the top two in the smartphone   market.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
