column1: Voice: The Next Computing Empire;3/11/2017;"This article is the first in a two-part series aimed at     exploring the rapidly developing state of voice computing from     the investor's perspective. In Part I
column2: I discuss why it's now     increasingly clear that the human voice will become society's     next major computing interface
column3: and why it will continue     proliferating through our homes and businesses. In Part II
column4: I'll dive deeper into the new and emerging business models. In     Part II
column5: I'll discuss the various players involved in the race     to commercialize the technology -- those best-positioned to     profit today
column6: those positioning themselves to thrive tomorrow
column7: and those dropping the ball entirely. I'll also dive deeper     into the fascinating business models voice computing will soon     enable
column8: and how those models will evolve as the technology     continues to improve.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();For nearly 40 years
column9: we've seen the computer evolve into an   indispensable accessory of Western society driven by three   powerful technologies that defined their eras and played a   monumental role for investors along the way.The personal computer gave many of us our first glimpse at the   digital world
column10: normalizing the idea that such machines have a   place in our homes and everyday lives. The internet tapped us   into that world
column11: offering us endless floods of information
column12: entertainment
column13: and commerce around which we willingly began   shaping our civilization. And then the smartphone encouraged us   to take that digital world everywhere we go
column14: leaving nothing but   a few taps on a touchscreen between us
column15: our computers
column16: and   constant immersion.Now
column17: a fourth technology -- voice computing--is removing that last barrier.Reimagining the roles computers playImagine driving down the highway
column18: coming home from work
column19: and     without taking your hands off the wheel or hitting any buttons
column20: asking your car to turn up the heat in your house
column21: preheat the     oven for dinner
column22: and play your favorite album
column23: all in the same     breath. Picture negotiating with a street vendor in Beijing
column24: having your phone translate the entire conversation between     Mandarin and English out loud
column25: so you can haggle in real time.     Or how about a stuffed animal that can tell your daughter     interactive stories every night before bed
column26: reshaping the     adventure at every twist and turn based on her responses and     reactions.These aren't hypothetical scenarios -- they're happening     right now.The human voice is well on its way to becoming the next     major medium we use to interact with computers
column27: and as we'll     explore in this two-part series
column28: voicecomputingis the burgeoning field of technology making it possible.     Already spanning multiple consumer and enterprise ventures     (think call center routing
column29: digital dictation
column30: or the virtual     assistants on smartphones)
column31: the industry's ultimate aim is     enabling people to carry on hands-free
column32: conversational-style     interactions with computers.It's an ambitious prospect capable of significantly     expanding the roles computers play in our everyday lives
column33: but     it's also one that appears inevitable when considering the     trajectory computers have taken
column34: without fail
column35: since their     introduction
column36: evolving in shape and form around contemporary     technology to solve unmet needs.Image Source: Getty ImagesAnd yet voice computing's evolution is different. Unlike any     form of computing to come before it
column37: the technology bypasses     the physical realm
column38: allowing users to query the internet
column39: manage their surroundings
column40: and connect to third-party services     without ever having to touch a physical device -- all in the     time it takes to form a sentence.If that sounds unnecessary
column41: then consider just how limitless     the applications could be. From the surgeon who needs to     rapidly adjust the conditions of her operating room     mid-procedure
column42: to the disabled veteran who simply hopes to     access the appliances in his home. The sheer number of everyday     applications for such a technology has prompted Grand View     Research to project the global market for voice recognition     technology will reach $128 billion annually by 2024
column43: an     estimate that may undershoot the overall economic opportunity     at play considering the potential verticals include healthcare
column44: defense
column45: entertainment
column46: consumer goods
column47: and more (I'll discuss     these in more detail in Part II).There is one thing we can be certain of
column48: however. Voice     computing is extremely likely to transform the way we interact     with technology in society
column49: but before that can happen
column50: a     large-scale societal shift toward adopting the interface must     occur
column51: a shift thatcannotoccur until several key hurdles are overcome.Understanding the challenges aheadTo analyze those obstacles
column52: let's turn to the most       promising application of voice-driven technology today:       virtual digital assistants.Data Sources: Socratic Technologies
column53: Vantiv
column54: Statista.         Chart by AuthorThanks to the success of the iPhone andApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) other devices
column55: Siri is currently the most       wildly used virtual assistant in the United States
column56: but until       recently
column57: it's also perfectly exemplified what's holding       voice computing back. To put it simply
column58: speaking with Siri       can often feel more like a novelty than a time-saver
column59: a       sentiment shared not just among Apple users
column60: but most       smartphone owners with access to similar voice computing       technology.It's a problem we can break down into three fundamental       hurdles.The first is that users must often resort to awkward       combinations of hyper-specific phrasing and hurried       robo-speak to have their speech accurately recognized. Andrew       Ng
column61: chief scientist atBaidu(NASDAQ: BIDU) and one the most respected names in the field
column62: perhaps put it best in 2015 when he noted
column63: ""Speech       recognition
column64: depending on the circumstances
column65: is say 95 per       cent accurate. So maybe it gets one word in 20 wrong. That's       really annoying if it gets one in 20 wrong and you probably       don't want to use it very often. That's probably where speech       recognition is today.""The second hurdle is that even when our speech iscorrectlyrecognized
column66: there still remains a strong chance it will bemisinterpretedwhile undergoing natural language understanding
column67: a process in       which the assistant attempts to comprehend what we want using       the sequence of words (and eventually
column68: the tone
column69: pace
column70: and       inflection) we give. And even if that speech is correctly       understood
column71: an assistant may still simply be unable to solve       for the request due to technical constraints. Examples of       both cases can be seen in the screenshot below
column72: along with a       sense of how frustrating the encounter can be.Image Source: Author's iPhoneEncounters like these make us feel as though we're wasting       our time trusting our phones to do what we could have done       ourselves with only a little more effort upfront. Over time
column73: they build up
column74: eventually discouraging us from even tryingto       use our assistants for anything complex
column75: instead relying on       them only for the most trivial of tasks
column76: like setting alarms       or creating reminders.Thankfully
column77: these first two hurdles are solvable with data
column78: third-party partnerships
column79: and time
column80: each of which the major   players in this space have been actively accruing for years.   Returning to our example
column81: since Siri was introduced to the world   in 2011
column82: virtual assistants have grown far more capable of   correctly interpreting requests thanks to advances in deep   learning
column83: a thriving field of AI being utilized byAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)
column84: Amazon(NASDAQ: AMZN)
column85: Baidu
column86: and others to improve speech recognition
column87: natural language understanding
column88: and other components of voice   computing at astounding rates. (Click herefor an outstanding story byThe New York Timeson Google's significant role in making this happen).Equally as important
column89: decisions by Apple and its competitors   to open their platforms up to third-party services have made   today's voice-based assistants feel far more capable than in   years past. These decisions allow Siri
column90: for example
column91: to call you   a ride using your Uber account
column92: or order a pizza through your   storedDomino'sinformation -- not unlike anactualsecretary would do.As the potential behind voice computing becomes increasingly   obvious in the coming months and years
column93: we should expect more and   more third parties to hop on board
column94: eventually expanding the   scope of what a partnership could entail (instead of ordering an   Uber
column95: imagine ordering a plane ticket). One look at the rate of   growth for third-party commands available on Amazon's voice-based   assistant
column96: Alexa
column97: can tell us a lot.Data Source: Voicebot. Chart by AuthorWith time
column98: these technical achievements and partnerships will   continue compounding
column99: eventually making for a highly practical   voice computing experience. Even marginal improvements in the   technology will convince users to begin using voice as an   interface more frequently. In the same talk regarding the current   state of the voice industry
column100: Ng went on to say
column101: ""I think that as   speech recognition accuracy goes from say 95 per cent to 98
column103: all of us in the room will go from barely using it   today
column104: to using it all the time."" He added
column105: ""Most people   underestimate the difference between 95 and 99 per cent ... 99   per cent is a game changer.""Although we're not yet able to predict when the technology   will reach that point
column106: if the recent pace of progress is any   indication -- since Ng's speech
column107: Baidu has built a program   capable of dictating English three times faster
column108: and with 20%   less errors
column109: than human beings -- it won't be much longer.In the meantime
column110: an arguably far more important hurdle stands   in the way. It's a problem shared by every other major computing   medium in use today
column111: only voice is actually solving for it.An instantaneous computing experienceNo matter the medium
column112: we've always interacted with computers   by issuing commands. In the 1950s
column113: we meticulously punched those   commands into cards before feeding them into hulking machines.   Now
column114: technology allows us to simply type
column115: click
column116: and
column117: increasingly
column118: speak them and expect a result.Yet despite these advancements
column119: today's mediums still subject   users to a unique set of delays
column120: a sort of friction that   inherently slows down the process betweenthinkinga command and actually being able tocommunicatethat command to your devices. A decade ago
column121: that friction most   likely entailed tracking down a PC with internet
column122: using the mouse   to open a browser
column123: using the keyboard to run a search
column124: and then   sorting for the result. But today
column126: it simply   means reaching into our pockets for our phone
column128: and tapping away.It's a process so effortless
column129: the average American now checks   their phone an estimated 46 times per day. It's even become   fashionable to argue there's no longerenoughfriction separating society from our devices; that we'retooplugged in to the digital world.So when you consider that voice computing's primary advantage   iseliminatingfriction
column130: it becomes tempting to dismiss the technology as a   solution to a trivial problem. What that argument critically   fails to consider
column132: is that friction is about more than   simple convenience
column133: and that any amount of friction
column135: fundamentally limits the dynamic between a user and   their computing medium in two ways.Let's take the smartphone for example.Image Source: PixabayThe seemingly trivial motions we make when reaching for our   phone still require us to be in immediate proximity of the   device. We have to walk over to kitchen counter if we left our   phone there; we have to remember it's on the counter even before   we can do that. Then
column137: we're   required to physically handle it
column138: a process that generally   requires we have one hand free and able.That may not sound like much
column139: but these limitations force our   computing experience to revolve around the location of our   device
column140: as opposed to it revolving around us.They can create roadblocks for those with disabilities affecting   their vision or hands (or really
column141: even those who just have sticky   hands
column144: those far away from their   device
column146: those with an immediate computing   need.There's a reason speech is our most instinctual form of   communication.If we have a question
column147: and if we know those around us can   answer that question
column148: we don't pull out our phone and run a   search
column149: we open our mouths and ask. We do that because it's   instantaneous. Now contrast that with having to locate your   phone
column150: having to type in your password
column151: having to navigate to an   app
column154: or speak your command. These behaviors   are not instinctual
column155: but we put up with them because the people around us usually   don't have the answers
column156: and because smartphones are our best   alternative.But they don't have to be.The rise of voiceIt's not obvious quite yet
column157: but today's physically bound   mediums have left a large hole to fill and voice computing is   starting to fill it.Over the past two years
column158: the technology has begun manifesting   itself in the form of always-on
column159: always-listening devices able to   virtually bypass the friction inherent in today's major computing   mediums. Currently
column160: these devices are best exemplified by   Amazon's line of Echo smart speakers
column161: which employ far-field   voice recognition technology allowing users to command Alexa from   across multiple rooms and through various background noises at   any time simply by calling for it out loud.Image Source: Amazon.com.Put another way
column163: Amazon's Echo is giving   consumers their first glimpse at a frictionless computing   experience. Following its initial setup
column165: no looking around for the device
column166: and no navigating   through screens to issue a command. When it works correctly (like   Siri
column167: Alexa is still very much in its infancy and subject to   misinterpreting commands) it really does allow users to convert   their thoughts to a command in the time it takes to form a   sentence
column168: capturing the essential promise of voice as a   medium.And if the early estimated adoption rate for the device is any   indication -- Amazon hasn't officially released sales   figures
column170: Consumer Intelligence Research   Partners (CIRP) estimates a staggering 8.2 million Echos have   already been sold in the U.S. (a number that pales in comparison   to Morgan Stanley's estimates of over 11 million)
column171: suggesting the   device has achieved well over 5% household penetration -- early   demand for a seamless computing experience is strong
column172: and will   likely grow stronger as capable competitors race to introduce   their own offerings (see Google's Home
column177: and third-party   support continue improving at rapid pace.Data Sources: VoiceLabs
column180: InfoScout. *2017     figures are VoiceLab projections. Chart by AuthorTo be clear
column181: these devices will never replace today's existing   computing mediums
column182: but will rather augment them. While   screens will remain the preferred medium for our more detailed   and visual computing needs
column183: voice will begin its ascent by taking   on an increasing share of our more ""conversational"" demands
column184: common requests we want addressed with the immediacy we expect   from dialogue (""Cancel my doctor's appointment."" ""Pause that   music!"" ""What's a good non-fiction book to read on the beach? ...   Great
column185: order that one."")As the technology grows capable of handling increasingly   nuanced and complex requests
column186: and as voice-enabled devices   proliferate and evolve
column187: we can expect more users to grow   comfortable engaging with the technology around the home
column189: and gradually more pervasive aspects of society.Andthat'swhere the real opportunities begin.The opportunity at handSome of the biggest tech empires in modern history have been   built around the personal computer
column192: each of which has provided the infrastructure for technology to   penetrate deeper and more reflexively into everyday life
column193: allowing creative companies to reach consumers in entirely new   ways.In just 10 years
column194: the iPhone helped Apple grow to become the   largest corporation in the world
column195: but it also popularized   smartphone technology in the U.S.
column196: helping to create the   infrastructure that in turn enabledFacebook(NASDAQ: FB)
column203: and countless others to create businesses that   reach deeper into our lives than any before.Image Source: Author's iPhoneAnd yet voice technology is going deeper.It's becoming an invisible
column205: weaving itself more seamlessly into the fabric of   our lives than any before it. It's called on using our most   instinctual
column207: and it's accessible   in the time it takes to form words. It's a technology that   provides tomorrow's innovators a far more intimate and pervasive   way to help us satisfy our digital wants.It's a startling but increasingly inevitable reality for both   investors and society.In Part II: The Playing Field
column208: I'll discuss various players   involved in the race to commercialize voice computing. To be the   first to know when Part II is released

column1: The 3 Best Stocks to Profit From the Rise of China;3/11/2017;"With a massive
column2: growing economy and a ballooning middle class
column3: China represents a major opportunity for many American companies.   Here's whyWalt Disney(NYSE: DIS)
column4: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column5: andCheniere Energy(NYSEMKT: LNG) are well-positioned to benefit from the continued   rise of China.The world's most beloved entertainment companyBeth McKenna(Walt Disney):I can't think of a better way to profit from the ever-rising   number of Chinese citizens joining the middle class than to   invest inDisney stock. Last June
column6: the legendary entertainment giant opened its   first theme park in mainland China
column7: the massive $5.5 billion   Shanghai Disney
column8: as it aims to capture the ballooning disposable   dollars of many Chinese consumers.So far
column9: Disney Shanghai's results have surpassed the company's   expectations. The park had hosted more than 7 million guests at   the time of the company's first-quarter earnings call on Feb.   8. Disney's management has said on the last two quarterly   earnings calls that the park is expected to come very close to   breaking even in fiscal 2017
column10: which is impressive given how new   it is and its humongous cost to build. This
column11: of course
column12: means   that the park should start contributing to Disney's profits in   fiscal 2018.makeArticleAd();Disney Shanghai. Image source: Disney.Disney has been delighting people in the Western world for   generations with its iconic theme parks
column13: as well as its movies
column14: TV shows
column15: and dizzying array of consumer products. So
column16: there's   every reason to believe that the Chinese people and visitors to   China will come to love Disney Shanghai just as much as Americans   and visitors to the United States adore Disneyland and Disney   World. That
column17: coupled with Disney's unmatched intellectual   property of characters makes Disney a great stock to own as   China's economy continues to expand in the decades ahead.Trouble and opportunityTim Green(Apple):Apple has been having all sorts of trouble in China lately. Total   sales in China dropped 12% year over year during Apple's first   quarter despite a rise in global revenue. This disappointing   result was actually an improvement: Fourth-quarter sales in China   tumbled 30% year over year
column18: and third-quarter sales crashed   33%.Apple's weak performance in China during the past few quarters   doesn't mean the company's growth opportunities in the country   are dead. Apple faces intense competition in China from local   companies as well asSamsung
column19: and its brand doesn't quite have the same power as it has in   the U.S. But an innovative product -- perhaps a revamped iPhone 8   later this year -- could reverse its fortunes and force its   rivals to scramble to keep up.Image source: Apple.Regaining market share in China won't be easy
column20: and it's   possible that competition is just too fierce for the company to   both grow sales and maintain its margins in the country. Flagship   phones from Chinese companies selling at a fraction of the price   Apple charges will be tough to beat. Apple will need to come up   with something truly unique to drive sales higher. It certainly   has the resources to do it.Filling one of China's largest needsTyler Crowe(Cheniere Energy):There are countless stories about the size and scale of   China's thirst for commodities. Ever since China switched gears   to a more market-driven economy
column21: demand for basic materials and   energy has grown by a staggering amount. Recently
column22: though
column23: we   have seen a shift in the types of commodities China wants
column24: and   those shifting trade winds are opening up new opportunities
column25: namely in liquefied natural gas (LNG).One thing that China has been working on rather remarkably in   recent years is reducing pollution in its cities. The biggest   culprit for air pollution has been burning coal for power
column26: making   steel
column27: and other industrial practices. So the country has been   shifting away from coal. In fact
column28: in January China announced it   was canceling prior plans to install 120 gigawatts of coal-fired   power plants -- that's equivalent to 10% of the U.S.' total   generation capacity. With incomes growing and urbanization still   happening at a rapid rate
column29: China is going to need to fill those   energy demands
column30: and LNG is going to be one of the major power   sources to fill that gap.We're already seeing this happen. In 2016
column31: total imports of   LNG into China increased 32.8% to 26.06 million metric tons
column32: and that is expected to grow to more than 105 million metric tons   per year by 2030. There are few companies out there better   positioned to take advantage of this coming LNG boom than   U.S.-based Cheniere Energy. As the U.S.' first LNG exporter
column33: the   company already sent 10% of its 2016 cargoes to China
column34: and that   was only from two of the possibly 11 liquefaction trains that   Cheniere has on the docket to develop over the next half   decade.Some might argue that Cheniere will struggle to deliver to the   Asian market because of its locations in the U.S. Gulf Coast. column1: 3 Growth Stocks I'd Buy Right Now;3/11/2017;"The recent bull market has pushed many growth stocks'   valuations into the stratosphere. Thankfully
column2: not every growth   stock is priced for perfection.Skyworks Solutions(NASDAQ: SWKS)
column3: Regeneron Pharmaceuticals(NASDAQ: REGN)
column4: andUnder Armour(NYSE: UA) (NYSE: UAA) all hold promising growth potential
column5: yet   are currently trading at attractive valuations. Here's why I'd   happily buy any of them today.Image Source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();The smartphone slump is overSkyworks Solutions is a leading manufacturer of radio   frequency chips that help devices connect to the internet. While   this company's stock has been rallying for several years now
column6: it   put investors on an unpleasant roller coaster ride in   2016. Shares were slammed over concerns that demand for   smartphones was slowing. Those fears proved to be well-founded.   The company went on to produced a series ofearnings reportsthat saw its top line head in the wrong direction. That's not   something growth investors wanted to see
column7: leading many traders to   hit the sell button.Thankfully
column8: the worst of the smartphone slowdown appears to be   over. When Skyworks reported fiscal first-quarter results in   January
column9: management predicted that revenue in the upcoming   quarterwould rise by 8%. Better yet
column10: management credited its upbeat guidance to an   ""expanding product pipeline and accelerating design win   momentum."" That hints that its efforts to diversify its business   away fromAppleandSamsung-- which are two of its biggest customers -- are starting to pay   off.Looking ahead
column11: investors have reasons to believe that the   top-line growth is here to stay. Skyworks is well positioned   to benefit from the ""Internet of Things"" trend. In addition
column12: the   rollout of 5G wireless technology also promises to be a massive   tailwind. When adding in the potential for margin improvement and   the company's habit of buying back stock
column13: analysts believe   that Skyworks' bottom line will grow by nearly 15% annually over   the next five years. That's quite a fast growth rate for a   company trading for less than 14 times forward earnings.New drugs to the rescueWhile long-term investors in biotech giant Regeneron   Pharmaceuticals haveenjoyed a phenomenal run
column14: the company's recent performance hasn't been all that   impressive. Shares are down more than 34% from their highs in   2015. What gives?You can blame the downfall on a number of factors. First
column15: the   company reported ahandfulofclinicalsetbacks in 2016 that gave investors pause. Next
column16: the FDA   rejected sarilumab -- a hopeful treatment for rheumatoid   arthritis -- because of manufacturing concerns. Finally
column17: the   company is losing a legal battle withAmgenover its new cholesterol-busting drug
column18: Praluent. When adding in   slowing sales of its top-selling drug
column19: Eylea
column20: it's no wonder   shares have headed in reverse.Despite all of the bummer news
column21: I think there are reasons for   optimism. First
column22: Regeneron andSanofiare slated to receive a go/no-go decision from the FDA in   the coming weeks about their new eczema drug candidate
column23: Dupixent. Many believe this drug holds blockbuster   potential
column24: so getting the green light could help to reignite   investors' enthusiasm. Next
column25: sarilumab should be resubmitted to   the FDA soon now that the manufacturing issues are completed.   Finally
column26: while Eylea's state-side growth rates are stalling
column27: the   drug is still growing by double-digits overseas.When added together
column28: Regeneron offers reasons to believe that   it is still a growth company. Market watchers appear to agree.   Current estimates call for bottom-line growth of nearly 19%   annually over the next five years. With shares trading for 25   times forward earnings estimates
column29: I think this is a growth stock   worthy of your capital.This growth story isn't bustedThe last year hasn't been kind to shareholders of Under   Armour. The company's stock has shed more than half of its value   after management took an ax to profit growth projections. The   original forecast called for $800 million in profits by 2018
column30: but   the company has since abandoned that target. When adding in a   holiday quarter that featured sales growth of just 12%
column31: it is   understandable why some investors fear that this growth story is   over.Despite the pain
column32: I refuse to give up on Under Armour. In   fact
column33: I think the huge sell-off is actually a great opportunity   to get in.Why am I still bullish? First
column34: why sales growth was   disappointing in the fourth quarter
column35: there are a handful of   factors that explain the slowdown. North American retail stores   in general performed poorly during the holiday season
column36: and 85% of   Under Armour's revenue is derived stateside. That means the   company isn't immune to the slowdown in retail. In addition
column37: 2016   also featured a number of high-profile bankruptcies from   retailers like Sport's Authority
column38: Eastern Mountain Sports
column39: Sports   Chalet
column40: and more. Those headwinds should abate in 2017
column41: and a new   partnership withKohl'sshould also help to shore up the company's retail   presence.Second
column42: while overall results were weak
column43: Under Armour did have   a few pockets of strength. International sales were especially   strong
column44: rising 63% last year. That tells me that this brand has   overseas appeal
column45: which is most certainly a positive sign.Finally
column46: the company's direct-to-consumer strategy also   appears to be working. Revenue from this channel grew 23%   last year and comprises 40% of total sales. Continued growth here   could go a long way toward offsetting any future retail sales   weakness.While Under Armour's stock doesn't look classically cheap   --it never does-- I still think this company has enough growth potential left to   more than justify an investment.10 stocks we like better than Under Armour (A   Shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Top Stocks Billionaires Are Buying Now;3/10/2017;"Keeping tabs on what iconic billionaire investors George Soros
column2: Warren Buffett
column3: and Carl Icahn are doing with their money can help you find new money-making ideas. What have Soros
column4: Buffett
column5: and Icahn been buying lately? According to reports
column6: Celgene Corp(NASDAQ: CELG)
column7: Apple Inc.(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column8: andBristol-Myers Squibb(NYSE: BMY)  are among the stocks they've recently been adding to their portfolios. Since these companies have catalysts that could send shares higher
column9: it might be time to buy them in your portfolio
column10: too.Soros buys CelgeneGeorge Soros is known for a rapid-fire investment approach
column11: and that means the stocks that get bought by Soros Fund Management might not stick around too long.makeArticleAd();Image source: Celgene Corp.Although Soros short-term style means following in his footsteps might not be the best way to build a long-term portfolio
column12: there are reasons why you might want to follow his lead and buy Celgene's shares
column13: and then hold onto them even after Soros sells.According to quarterly filings with the SEC
column14: Soros Fund Management bought a small stake in Celgene during the fourth quarter
column15: and while the position was tiny relative to Soros money under management
column16: it could still prove to be very profit-friendly.Celgene is arguably the best in its industry at developing and commercializing billion dollar blockbuster drugs. It markets top-selling medicine used in multiple myeloma
column17: pancreatic cancer
column18: and psoriasis
column19: and in February
column20: it reported data that could eventually lead to it having a best-seller in multiple sclerosis
column21: too.Specifically
column22: management told investors last month that a pivotal trial for ozanimod
column23: its oral multiple sclerosis drug
column24: was a success. Ozanimod reduced MS relapses more than Avonex
column25: an injection-based therapy that generates $2 billion in annual sales
column26: and importantly
column27: it did so with safety data strong enough to have me thinking it will disrupt this $19 billion per year market.The oral MS drugs that are currently available generate over $8 billion in annual sales
column28: but there are concerns over their safety. Tecfidera
column29: the top-selling oral MS drug
column30: has been associated with a rare brain disease
column31: and Gilenya
column32: the second-best selling oral MS drug
column33: can cause a worrisome drop in heart rate. If ozanimod notches FDA approval
column34: then I think it could win away considerable market share from those two drugs.Ozanimod could also be a blockbuster because of ongoing trials that may expand its use into ulcerative colitics and Crohn's disease.Because Celgene thinks its revenue will surge from about $11 billion this year to $21 billion in 2020
column35: and its earnings per share will more than double to at least $13 during the period
column36: there appears to be no shortage of growth on the horizon. Since it boast one of the industry's best balance sheets
column37: it has a proven track record of successfully marketing new drugs
column38: and it has ozanimod in the wings
column39: I think there's plenty of reason why this Soros buy can be added to every day investor portfolios.Warren Buffett takes a big bite of AppleWarren Buffett still uses a flip phone to make calls
column40: but that didn't stop him from making consumer device giant Apple one of hisbiggest stock holdings.Image source: Getty Images.Apple showed up inBerkshire Hathaway's portfolio early last year
column41: and since then it's become his second largest position. Berkshire Hathaway's quarterly 13F report with the SEC shows he owned 57 million shares of Apple in December
column42: but recently Buffett told CNBC that his Apple stake has climbed to more than 130 million shares.Buffett's interest in Apple could be driven by optimism that consumers who had previously held off on upgrading their iPhone's are finally doing so. Last quarter
column43: Apple reported that iPhone revenue began to climb again
column44: reaching a record. He may also be attracted to the company's huge user base
column45: which provides plenty of profit-friendly growth opportunities for Apple's services
column46: including iTunes. Furthermore
column47: he may be drawn to Apple's massive cash flow. Last year
column48: $27 billion in cash flow helped it increase its cash and investments stockpile to a breath-taking $245 billion.Clearly
column49: there's a lot to like about Apple right now. If the company can keep its foot on the innovation pedal
column50: it should maintain the financial flexibility necessary to return increasingly more money to investors via its dividend. At current share prices
column51: the company's dividend yield is 1.6%
column52: but that dividend rate could grow if Apple increases its dividend payout. The company last increased its dividend by 10% in 2016
column53: so another dividend increasecould be in the workssoon.Icahn targets Bristol-Myers SquibbIn February
column54: The Wall Street Journalreported that iconic activist investor Carl Icahn is cozying up to biopharma giant Bristol-Myers Squibb. Icahn is quiet about his intentions
column55: but his track record suggests profit-friendly changes could be coming at the drugmaker. In the past
column56: Icahn's used his sway to shake-up C-suites
column57: win seats on boards
column58: arm-wrestle spin-offs
column59: and convince companies tosell themselves outright.Who knows what his strategy is for Bristol-Myers Squibb
column60: but the company's got a lot going on that makes it an intriguing target for Icahn (and potentially
column61: you).Its best-selling drug is Opdivo
column62: an immunotherapy that makes it more difficult for cancer cells to avoid detection by the immune system. Opdivo's won FDA approval in a few cancer indications
column63: but it's widely used in battling advanced lung cancer and melanoma. The drug's ability to combat those cancers has made it a blockbuster seller
column64: with annualized sales of $5.2 billion exiting the fourth quarter.While Opdivo unquestionably remains a top-selling medicine
column65: Bristol-Myers Squibb's shares tumbled last year when a trial designed to further increase Opdivo's use in lung cancer fell short
column66: and a competitors trial succeeded. The news was disappointing
column67: but it's arguably turned Bristol-Myers Squibb's shares into a bargain bin buy.Bristol-Myers has dozens of ongoing trials that could expand Opdivo's use
column68: including additional trials in lung cancer that could make last year's failure a moot point. Furthermore
column69: Opdivo isn't its only fast-growing drug. It also co-markets the top-selling anticoagulant Eliquis with Pfizer. Last year
column70: Eliquis sales jumped 80% to $3.3 billion.Because Bristol-Myers Squibb is forecasting sales growth again this year
column71: but it's lost $30 billion in market cap since last fall
column72: it's valuation has become much more attractive. Its trailing 12-month price to earnings ratio
column73: for example
column74: has fallen from above 30 to about 21. The sell-off in its shares has also resulted in its dividend yield growing from less than 2% last year to nearly 2.7% now.Admittedly
column75: only Icahn can tell us what his plans are to rekindle Bristol-Myers Squibb's share price
column76: but with big-time drugs already on the market
column77: and a far more reasonable share price than a year ago
column78: this stock might be worth investing in.10 stocks we like better than Bristol-Myers SquibbWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

But those gains are all the more reason why you should by Verizon stock now.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart Via FlickrVerizon stock has been lagging as the company's growth has been tepid. The wireless market is saturated and competitive.In the most recent quarter
column5: Verizon posted a slight earnings miss and a decline in sales. Meanwhile
column6: earnings are barely supposed to inch higher in the next few years - far from the double-digit growth of the half decade prior. In fact
column7: Wall Street's forward-looking estimates are slowly but surely shrinking with each month.7 Future Blue-Chip Stocks You Need to BuyBut the decline in Verizon stock spells opportunity. The company has three solid avenues toward growth and
column8: if none of those pan out
column9: another way to reward loyal investors. Take a look.Unlimited DataRecently
column10: some analysts have suggested that Verizon's move to offer unlimited data is going to crush its margins. I disagree. Offering unlimited data is more mental than practical; it's a marketing move - one that puts Verizon back above a competitor likeT-Mobile US Inc(NASDAQ:TMUS) - as opposed to a margins-eater.T-Mobile has been competing mostly with appealing offers
column11: but can't compete on speed and coverage. Unlimited data tips the scales back to Verizon. At this stage
column12: gaining customers is one of the most important avenues for Verizon to grow
column13: especially as its AOL and landline businesses are dead and buried.Yahoo AcquisitionThere has been some uncertainty around Verizon's acquisition of Yahoo due the latter's data breach. But while that's a short-term hurdle to deal with
column14: it doesn't change the appeal of the buy.As Verizon's CFO said during the most recent earnings call: ""Our pending Yahoo acquisition would further increase our opportunity to scale in the digital media space
column15: with its 1 billion-plus monthly average unique viewers.""The deal is expected to close in the second quarter
column16: so the April 20 earnings call may have more details that will help regain investor confidence in the buy.Internet of ThingsThe most promising part of recent Verizon earnings report has been growth in Internet of Things (IoT) revenue. In the most recent quarter
column17: IoT enjoyed a 21% year-over-year expansion. Meanwhile
column18: including acquisitions
column19: IoT revenues increased more than 60% in fourth-quarter 2016. Verizon expects to sustain this trend to continue
column20: which could drive revenue growth back into the red.Bottom Line on Verizon StockThe best part about Verizon stock
column21: though

column23: the company will still reward loyal investors with a consistent quarterly payout. Verizon paid $9.3 billion in dividends in 2016 and current sports a forward annual dividend yield of almost 5% and plenty of cash to keep that chugging. Verizon boasts $2.88 billion in cash - double its debt as of the most recent quarter.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is a Jekyll-and-Hyde Trade Right NowWhile Verizon stock has been lagging of late
column24: that softness translates to a sweet yield. And if earnings get back on track due to any of the aforementioned drivers
column25: you can bet investors will have an especially mouth-watering yield on cost.Hilary Kramer is the editor ofGameChangers

column1: Why General Electric Company (GE) Stock Is STILL a Powerhouse;3/10/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsInvestors should consider holding diversified companies as part of their investing strategy. These conglomerates operate in multinational jurisdictions

column4: pay out a regular dividend.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)General Electric Company(NYSE:GE)
column5: whose shares are valued at just 15.7 times forward earnings
column6: has a dividend yielding 3.2%.Its long-term debt (of 1.39x equity) is more than manageable. If GE stock dips more
column7: this is the stock to consider. In the third quarter
column8: General Electric was third only toMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) andApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) in buying back shares.In Q3
column9: the company bought back $3.7 billion. Apple repurchased $6 billion
column10: while Microsoft bought back $4.4 billion. GE returned $30.5 billion to shareholders last year. This included a share buyback of $22 billion.The company is not a favorite pick among the analysts

column12: citing sub-par core operating performance.8 Dividend Growth Stocks Raising The BarInvestors need not pay any attention to analysts there. General Electric has strong leadership under CEO Jeffrey Immelt. Despite the challenging oil and gas market ahead

column14: General Electric saidthe sector is stabilizing:""In oil and gas
column15: the environment continues to be challenging and activity levels remain muted
column16: external market indicators appear to be stabilizing with expected more balanced supply and demand fundamentals
column17: partly influenced by the recent OPEC production agreement. U.S. onshore rig count grew 33% versus the third quarter
column18: but was essentially flat versus the beginning of the year.""Although orders fell 27% year-over-year
column19: GE forecast no change in E&P spending. If the oil and gas market bottomed late last year
column20: the company will start seeing orders growing at its Alstom unit.The offshore drilling and sub-sea will still be a drag this year. General Electric hopes business picks up in North America onshore. It also needs the Middle East and Europe to stabilize. If that does not happen
column21: this segment will not meet the company's expectation of a smaller revenue decline in the second half of the year.General Electric's Earnings OutlookThe 2017 earnings-per-share forecast of $1.60 to $1.70 a share may prove too low an estimate for GE stock. In the meantime

column23: revenue at HCS (health and life science) grew by 2 %. Immelt expects Aviation to grow again this year. GE is also improving its operating efficiency. A new IT structure that runs horizontally will save the company around $450 million.Investors shouldn't only consider General Electric the bellwether of the U.S. economy's health

column25: which hit a two-year high
column26: is just a one indicator suggesting GE stock's outlook is bright.As of this writing

column1: Celgene Corporation (CELG) Stock Is Staging a Tempting Breakout;3/10/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIf there was ever a doubt
column3: the latest price action inCelgene Corporation(NASDAQ:CELG) should help ease those fears and usher in more investor cheer in the coming weeks. For investors sharing that vision

Or maybe UBS was an influence? The broker initiated coverage of CELG on Thursday with a""buy"" rating and $140 price target.Alternatively

column1: Warren Buffett Isn't Trying to Beat the Market;3/9/2017;"If you're expecting high returns fromBerkshire Hathaway's(NYSE: BRK-A) (NYSE: BRK-B) stock portfolio
column2: you may want to   pay attention to what Charlie Munger has to say
column3: and then   carefully reconsider your assumption.At the recentDaily Journalmeeting
column4: Warren Buffett's sidekick
column5: Charlie Munger
column6: explained   that Buffett doesn't necessarily have high returns in mind when   he buys a stock for Berkshire's portfolio. Munger used Berkshire   Hathaway's purchase ofExxonMobilstock as an example in how Buffett's investment process has   changed:[Y]ou know why Warren bought Exxon? As a cash substitute. He     would have never done that in the old days. We had a lot of     cash and we thought Exxon was better than cash over the     short-term. That's a different kind of thinking than the way     Warren came up.makeArticleAd();Munger isn't kidding. This is very different than how Buffett   has traditionally invested.The Exxon tradeIn 2013
column7: Berkshire paid $90.86 per share for its multibillion   dollar Exxon stake. In the fourth quarter of 2014
column8: when Berkshire   liquidated its investment
column9: Exxon shares traded for an average of   $93.27 per share
column10: according to a report byBloomberg. Thus
column11: Buffett purchased and subsequently sold about $4 billion   of Exxon stock in a round-trip that earned Berkshire shareholders   a single-digit return after dividends. Most importantly
column12: Berkshire was in and out in less than two years.This quick trade is very uncharacteristic of Buffett
column13: who is   famous for taking the long view. In his 1996 letter to   shareholders
column14: Buffett wrote: ""If you aren't willing to own a   stock for ten years
column15: don't even think about owning it for ten   minutes.""That advice
column16: it seems
column17: no longer applies to how Berkshire   manages its portfolio.Image source: Getty Images.One of the most important lessons I've ever learned as an   investor is that there are no accidents in disclosure
column18: whether   the contextual clues appear in SEC filings or the documents that   accompany them. That's why I find it so interesting that Buffett   went out of his way to clarify how Berkshire views its stock   portfolio in his annual letter to shareholders this year.Buffett wrote the following on page 20 of his annual   letter:Sometimes the comments of shareholders or media imply that     we will own certain stocks ""forever."" It is true that we own     some stocks that I have no intention of selling for as far as     the eye can see (and we're talking 20/20 vision). But we have     made nocommitmentthat Berkshire will holdanyof its marketable securities forever.He added
column19: ""[W]e regard any marketable security as available   for sale
column20: however unlikely such a sale now seems.""With that
column21: Buffett makes it clear that its portfolio of public   stocks is always for sale
column22: if the price is right
column23: or if Berkshire   has better uses for the cash. It's a curious new detail
column24: one that   comes just months after Berkshire put more than $16 billion to   work purchasing shares ofAppleand four airlines
column25: industries that Buffett might be willing to   invest in
column26: but only if he doesn't have to commit to holding   forever.10 stocks we like better than Berkshire Hathaway (A   shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column27: it can pay to listen. After all
column28: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column29: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column30: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Berkshire Hathaway (A   shares) wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10   stocks are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

The Motley Fool owns shares of XOM and has the     following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on AAPL and     short January 2018 $95 calls on AAPL. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Apple Inc. Should Thank WikiLeaks for Its CIA Reveal;3/9/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOn Tuesday
column3: WikiLeaks released ""Vault 7
column4: a huge collection of documents that reveal hacking tools used by the CIA. While the dump paints the CIA in an unflattering light
column5: the fallout may well be worse for some of the world's largest tech companies
column6: includingApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL).makeArticleAd();Source: AppleSpecifically
column7: the CIA has a long list of iOS exploits it has used to gain access to iPhones. Despite being named along with numerous other giants of tech
column8: the latest WikiLeaks dump actually highlights a key advantage for Apple in particular.And while its aura of security may emerge tarnished
column9: the iPhone may actually come out ahead over the long term thanks to WikiLeaks.What Was in WikiLeaks Vault 7?The latestWikiLeaks dump involves 8
column10: 761 documentsoutlining a wide range of CIA hacking tools
column11: including viruses
column12: malware
column13: zero-day exploits
column14: trojans and remote control systems.In addition there are 14 iOS exploits listed
column15: several dozen Android vulnerabilities and methods for accessing encrypted chats (essentially reading the contentsbeforethey are encrypted by gaining access to the host device).9 Stocks to Buy That Are Growing Faster Than AmazonIt's not all smartphones
column16: either. The CIA has developedmalware to infect computersrunning macOS
column17: Windows and Linux. It's even capable of turning Samsung Smart TVs on their owners
column18: using them as listening devices to record conversations.This Doesn't Look Good for AppleApple has long positioned itself as a privacy advocate. It has always played up the security of the iPhone and evenrefused an FBI request to unlock the iPhoneused by a shooter in 2015's San Bernardino terrorist attack.Apple CEO Tim Cook released a written statement at the time
column19: saying:""… the U.S. government has asked us for something we simply do not have
column20: and something we consider too dangerous to create. They have asked us to build a backdoor to the iPhone.""The WikiLeaks Vault 7 release made it clear that iOS wasn't as secure as Apple had thought.How Apple Could Come Out AheadWikiLeaks is bad news for Apple in the short term. But the reveal of CIA hacking of mobile devices and consumer electronics could actually be good news for the company in the long run. Apple quickly went on record as saying many of the vulnerabilities identified in the WikiLeaks Vault 7 documentswere already addressed with iOS 10. And it is working to identify and patch any new issues.Apple and Google chose very different strategies when it comes to smartphones. Apple controls every aspect of iOS - its mobile operating system - as well as the hardware. It pushes out new major new iOS versions yearly and update releases (the kind that fix bugs or security issues) on demand. As a result
column21: nearly 80% of all iPhones are currently running iOS 10.Google also releases new versions of Android yearly
column22: but largely relies on smartphone manufacturers and wireless carriers to approve and push updates. They have little incentive to do so
column23: since lacking the latest Android features could be a reason to buy a new smartphone.With such a wildly varying assortment of smartphones
column24: updates can often be problematic
column25: leading to support issues. As a result
column26: the latest version of Android is on just 2% of all Android smartphones
column27: while themajority are running software released in 2014 or earlier.In other words
column28: even if Googlehadaddressed most of the issues in Android Nougat as claimed
column29: right now
column30: there arehundreds of millions of Android devices that could still be affectedbecause they're running old software. Most iPhone users
column31: however
column32: should be okay
column33: and the rest can be assured that Apple's consistent program of releases will address any outstanding issues.Apple has a similar approach with macOS. It updates its Mac computer operating system regularly and pushes out security updates as issues are discovered. With the smart home
column34: Apple takes extreme security measures
column35: including costly custom chips
column36: factory inspections and end-to-end encryption between connected devices. This approach has meant slower adoption for its HomeKit platform
column37: but with the benefit of being far more secure than the competition.As for smart TVs eavesdropping on you
column38: that's just another reason to buy a relatively inexpensive streaming box - like an Apple TV - instead.The Age of Privacy Is OverMany people had been living with a probably naive expectation that everything they did with their smartphone was private and secure
column39: especially when using encrypted apps. The latest WikiLeaks dump should end that notion and leave people watching their TV
column40: PC and even smart thermostat with suspicion.Snap Inc. (SNAP) Aims to Win Where Disney (DIS) FailedBut by the time this plays out
column41: it's also likely to make it clearer than ever before that some products are more secure than others
column42: and some companies are in a better position to fix any vulnerabilities.Apple may have been named as one of the victims of CIA hacking
column43: but it was quick to respond and quick to make it clear many of the WikiLeaks exploits have already been addressed. Perhaps more importantly
column44: Apple's product strategy puts it in the position to be a leader in offering the most secure devices possible going forward.As of this writing
column45: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceApple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is a Jekyll-and-Hyde Trade Right NowApple Inc. iPhone Grabs Even More Market ShareThe postApple Inc. Should Thank WikiLeaks for Its CIA Revealappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column22: and G SuiteSeveral big wins for Google cloud were also touted at Next 2017.SAP SE (ADR)(NYSE:SAP) is the world leader in enterprise resource planning software
column23: counting over 345
column24: 000 companies as customers. Many large corporations rely on SAP software and it's big enough to be hosting its own cloud services. However
column25: it has signed on for its SAP HANA database to be hosted on Google cloud
column26: instead of at its own data centers.AsTechCrunchnotes
column27: Microsoft and Amazon already had deals signed with SAP. Beating AWS and Azure to host HANA has an even greater significance given that the competition already had an established relationship with SAP.Drop Advanced Micro Devices

column30: 000 employees
column31: moving them instead to Google's G Suite.Look for Google to continue aggressively pushing Google cloud services in 2017. The company has been spending big on ramping up its infrastructure
column32: its ""Other"" revenue (which includes cloud revenue) wasup 62% in the last quarterand the majority of its 2
column33: 100 hires in Q4 went to cloud operations.As Google cloud's Diane Greene said onstage
column34: ""I think 2017 will be a good year
column35: too.""As of this writing

column1: The Bull Market Turns 8: These Dow Stocks Led the Way Higher;3/9/2017;"It's hard to believe
column2: but eight years ago today
column3: theDow Jones Industrials(DJINDICES: ^DJI) were below 7
column5: and many feared further losses that could send the global financial markets into chaos. Just eight years later
column6: the Dow has tripled from those levels
column7: and the mood going forward is much more optimistic. When you look at what has powered the Dow's advance
column8: the most interesting thing you'll notice is that seven component replacements within the venerable average have happened in relatively short order
column9: and those additions have been major contributors to the gains that the average has enjoyed.makeArticleAd();^DJIdata byYCharts.The key winners in the DowBelow
column10: you can see the stocks among the Dow's current components that have produced the largest total returns for shareholders over the past eight years:StockTotal Return Since 3/9/2009Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL)1
column11: 191%UnitedHealth(NYSE: UNH)954%Home Depot893%American Express750%Walt Disney691%Visa(NYSE: V)658%Boeing624%JPMorgan Chase584%DuPont576%Nike(NYSE: NKE)552%Data source:S&P Global Market Intelligence.It's illuminating that the top two returners and four in the top 10 have joined the Dow in just the past eight years. UnitedHealth Group came into the index in 2012
column12: while Visa and Nike became Dow components in 2013. Apple is the most recent company to join the average
column13: getting its invitation in 2015.Note that their late entry hasn't prevented some of these key stocks from having huge impacts on the average. Visa
column14: for instance
column15: has seen its stock nearly double since joining the index as international electronic payments volume has dramatically increased. Economic expansion has helped increase money flows
column16: and Visa's ability to dip into that stream with its global payment network has paid off. Moreover
column17: before Visa decided to split its stock
column18: its high share price made it one of the most influential components within the Dow Jones Industrials
column19: and the overall average benefited disproportionately from its gains than from moves in lower-priced stocks.For Apple
column20: though
column21: the influence hasn't been as significant. The tech giant's admission to the Dow came near its high point
column22: shortly after a 7-for-1 stock split that brought its share price low enough to attract the attention of those who run the price-weighted average. In the following year
column23: Apple lost a third of its value
column24: but in the recent push higher for the Dow to new record levels
column25: the iPhone maker has played an instrumental role
column26: and shareholders have finally enjoyed some of the benefits.Image source: Getty Images.Making the Dow healthierUnitedHealth Group has given the Dow strong performance since its admission in 2012
column27: with its share price more than tripling over that time span. The healthcare industry has seen a lot of change over that period
column28: with the rise and seemingly imminent fall of the Affordable Care Act having presented substantial challenges to the health insurance industry. UnitedHealth has been able to benefit dramatically from going beyond health insurance through its Optum line of businesses
column29: which incorporate pharmacy benefit management and various health-related services to try to get corporate customers to encourage wellness and health improvement practices. These services have helped clients cut their healthcare costs
column30: and they've proved immensely profitable for UnitedHealth in its tenure as a Dow component.Finally
column31: Nike has continued to prosper from the popularity of athletic apparel and footwear
column32: but share price gains since it joined the Dow in 2013 have been more modest
column33: amounting to a roughly 50% to 60% rise. New competition has emerged in the space
column34: and that has forced Nike to retrench and find ways to use its powerful brand presence to stoke growth. The company remains the giant in the industry
column35: but it will have to keep fighting in order to regain its dominance and send its stock back toward record levels.The Dow's climb since 2009 is monumental
column36: and newly admitted stocks to the average have played a vital role. More importantly
column37: Apple
column38: UnitedHealth
column39: Visa
column40: and Nike will have to keep doing well if the Dow is to stay in and move further into record territory in 2017 and beyond.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column41: it can pay to listen. After all
column42: the newsletter they have run for over a decade
column43: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column44: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Short International Business Machines Corp. (IBM) Stock For Free;3/9/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI have been a long time critic ofInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM). The problem is
column3: for the past 12 months
column4: Wall Street hasn't shared my opinion
column5: and IBM stock has been on fire.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockSo
column6: I recently wrote abouthow to get paidto trade IBM stock. The trade
column7: although not a home run
column8: yielded easy profits.Today
column9: I want to take the other side.IBM stock is near its all time highs
column10: but it's showing a whiff of weakness. With so much uncertainty ahead of markets
column11: I fear downside pressure in the near-term. So consider this short idea more a call against price action rather than company pessimism.By the way
column12: I still don't like IBM's prospects
column13: from a fundamental standpoint. They have failed to adopt their mega-machine of old into the new tech world. The highest-profile IBM focus has recently been artificial intelligence
column14: but that is an old headline.It's taking too long to blossom into a cash cow.7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Lows in 2017Assuming that experts are correct with their expectations of big things from artificial intelligence
column15: I can use this in my trade as a fundamental basis for the long-term prospects of IBM. Affirmation to this is the recent headline of IBM's alliance withSalesforce.com
column16: Inc.(NYSE:CRM).Maybe hanging to the coattails of the growth monster like Salesforce could keep IBM's momentum going.How to Short IBM Stock for FreeThe bet:Buy IBM Apr $180/$175 debit put spread for $2 per contract. This is my maximum potential loss. The faster IBM stock falls through my spread
column17: the faster my profits will accrue. I have a chance to double my money.Click to EnlargeSince this more of a technically driven trade
column18: I want to lower my out of pocket risk. To do this I will sell downside risk against levels that I deem safe.The bank:Sell the IBM Jan 2018 $135 put for $3. I need IBM stock to stay above my strike sold or be put the stock. I only sell naked puts if I am willing and able to own IBM shares at that price. The 24% price buffer gives me a 90% theoretical chance of success on this leg.Drop Advanced Micro Devices
column19: Inc. (AMD) Stock. Here's Why.By taking both trades
column20: I would be getting paid to short IBM through April. Ideally
column21: I need IBM stock to fall past my debit spread but stay above my credit sold. As long as IBM stock stays above my sold put
column22: any premium I recapture from selling my debit spread would be profit. So I can still profit even if IBM does nothing.I am not required to hold my trades open through expiration. I can close them early for partial gains or losses. I only risk what I can afford to lose.Nicolas Chahine is the managing director ofSellSpreads.com. As of this writing

column1: Why You Really Need to Diversify;3/9/2017;"Diversification
column2: and the benefits thereof
column3: is something I have written about multiple times before. Recently
column4: however
column5: I have discovered two pieces of data that really highlight how important diversification is to a well-rounded investment strategy. The numbers are enough to terrify even the most devoted
column6: concentrated investor.Time to diversify?The world's most well-known investors are all recognized for their love of concentrated stock portfolios. Several have even remarked that diversification is a waste of time and the only way to make money in the market is to have a concentrated equity portfolio. This is all well and good
column7: but it is really not suitable advice for the average investor.makeArticleAd();The most famous investing gurus got where they are today by being good investors
column8: but that is not to say there was not a degree of luck involved as well.What would have happened toWarren Buffett(Trades
column9: Portfolio) if hisAmerican Express(AXP) investment had not worked out and the Salad Oil scandal had taken down the company? Or ifCoca-Cola(KO) was hit with such a massive bout of negative publicity it could never recover? If either of these scenarios unfolded
column10: Buffett would not be where he is today.To give another example
column11: what would have happened toCarl Icahn(Trades
column12: Portfolio) if lawmakers had viewed his actions at TWA as criminal and thrown him in jail?There are certainly cases where this has happened
column13: but because the ranks of the world's most famous investors are stalked by survivorship bias
column14: it is difficult to realize that for every one Buffett there are tens of thousands of failed investors.That is why diversification is so important and critical for long-term investing success.Numbers don't lieResearch by Arizona State University finance professor Hendrik Bessembinder shows exactly why this is the case. To try and figure out the average return of single stocks over the long term
column15: he studied the returns of 26
column16: 000 equities over the period of 1926 to 2015. Over this nine-decade period
column17: equities created $31.8 trillion of wealth. The shocking thing is that all of this wealth was generated by just 4% of equities; 96% of stocks achieved nothing. Including inflation
column18: the real return on 96% of the universe was actually negative. To put it another way
column19: the average investor has a one in 24 chance of picking a stock that will generate positive returns over the long term.ExxonMobil(XOM) alone accounted for 3% of the wealth created over the period andApple(AAPL) accounted for about 2%.These findings are only reinforced by a report issued by JPMorgan last year. According to the report
column20: titled ""The Agony & Ecstasy: The Risks And Rewards Of A Concentrated Stock Position
column21: the return on the median stock since its inception versus an investment in the Russell 3000 Index is -54%.Furthermore
column22: since 1980
column23: 320 companies have been removed from the S&P 500 due to reasons of ""distress."" So
column24: during the past three-and-a-half decades
column25: 64% of the index has been turned over. Based on these figures
column26: JPMorgan calculates the chance of actually finding an extreme winner is just 7%. Since the 1980s
column27: 40% of all companies experienced a severe loss and never recovered.The bottom lineDiversification is not a bad strategy. Some of the world's most famous investors may advocate concentrated portfolios
column28: but as the figures above show
column29: you have to be very lucky to correctly pick a stock that produces positive returns over the long term. The chances of picking a winner are so low it is hard to justify even trying. That is possibly why Buffett advocates an index tracker fund for most investors -- the risk of picking the wrong stock and losing money over the long term is just too high!.Disclosure: The author owns no stock mentioned.Start afree 7-day trial of Premium Membershipto GuruFocus.Premium MembersThis article first appeared onGuruFocus."

column1: Stocks to Buy: 3 Tech Stocks Paying Nice Dividends;3/9/2017;"Many of the bestdividend   stocksare found in sectors where the rate of change and disruption is   slow -- sectors like consumer staples
column2: utilities
column3: and banks. But   there are some excellent dividend stocks in the tech sector
column4: too.Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column5: IBM(NYSE: IBM)
column6: andMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT)
column7: for instance
column8: all pay solid
column9: growing   dividends.Here's a look at why each of these tech giants represents a   good bet for investors looking for income.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Apple: dividend upsideApple offers the smallest dividend yield -- 1.6% -- of these   three stocks. But investors shouldn't overlook its   attractiveness. Apple's dividend easily makes up what it lacks in   yield with growth potential.Currently
column10: Apple is paying out just 27% of its earnings
column11: leaving significant upside for dividend increases in the future.   Further
column12: management has demonstrated how it's prioritizing   dividend growth since the company initiated its dividend in 2012.   Adjusted for a 7-to-1 stock split in 2014
column13: Apple's dividend has   increased 50% since 2012.Apple's annual dividend increases have steadily remained at   about 10% -- a rate the company looks like it could sustain for   years to come.IBM: an above-average yieldWith a dividend yield of about 3.1%
column14: IBM has the fattest   per-share payout of these three stocks. Even more
column15: while IBM's   44% payout ratio -- the percentage of annual earnings it is   paying out in dividends -- is well above Apple's 27% payout   ratio
column16: it's still low enough for investors to expect meaningful   dividend growth for years to come.Indeed
column17: IBM's dividend has grown at a very healthy average   annualized rate of about 14% during the past five years. However
column18: the company's most recent dividend increase wasn't as substantial   as in past years. In 2016
column19: IBM's dividend increased 7.7%
column20: down   from an 18.2% hike in 2015
column21: as the company'songoing transformationhas put pressure on net income.Despite the slowdown in IBM's dividend increases
column22: the   company's 21 consecutive years of dividend increases
column23: along with   its low payout ratio
column24: set a solid precedent for ongoing dividend   increases over the long haul.Microsoft: enduring cash flow from a profitable business   modelMicrosoft's ability to generate heady levels of cash flow from   its profitable business model is undeniable. For the past 10   years
column25: Microsoft's gross profit margin
column26: or gross profit as a   percentage of revenue
column27: has been between about 61% and 81%. Sure
column28: the software giant's gross profit margin is on the low end of   this range today -- at 61%. But the inherent profitability of   Microsoft's software-focused business
column29: combined with the   stickiness of its Office suite and its enterprise applications   and services
column30: means it can count on enduring cash flow for years   to come
column31: to continue feeding investors solid dividends.Image source: Getty Images.With a 2.4% dividend yield
column32: Microsoft offers investors a   better dividend yield than Apple
column33: but it's still well behind   IBM's 3.1% dividend yield. While Microsoft's payout ratio of   69.5% is higher than IBM's
column34: Microsoft's dividend as a percentage   of free cash flow -- at 42% -- better captures the software   giant's room for dividend increases. Recent one-time charges   against earnings and restructuring charges have suppressed net   income and pushed the company's payout ratio higher. By   comparison
column35: Apple and IBM are paying out 23% and 41% of their   free cash flow in dividends.Microsoft's most recent annual increase was 8% -- and the   company's financials look set to support similar increases over   time.In general
column36: income investors may not find many great dividend   stocks in tech. But these three stocks are just as worthy of a   spot in an income portfolio as go-to Dividend Aristocrats in   consumer staples
column37: utilities
column38: and banking.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Why Universal Display Corporation Stock Popped 28.6% in February;3/9/2017;"What happenedShares ofUniversal Display Corporation(NASDAQ: OLED) jumped 28.6% in the month of   February
column2: according to data provided byS&P Global Market Intelligence
column3: after the OLED specialist announcedstrong fourth-quarter 2016 resultsand encouraging guidance.So whatRevenue for the quarter grew 19.7% year over year
column4: to $74.6   million
column5: and it resulted in a 42.7% increase in net income to   25.8 million. Net income per share also climbed 41%
column6: to $0.55. By   comparison
column7: Wall Street was looking for revenue of just $68.6   million
column8: and earnings of $0.42 per share.IMAGE SOURCE: UNIVERSAL DISPLAY.makeArticleAd();Universal Display's growth was driven by a combination of     higher OLED material sales (up 5%
column9: to $29.2 million)
column10: an     increase in royalty and license fees (up 27%
column11: to $43.6     million)
column12: and $1.8 million in contract research services     revenue from its acquisition of Adesis last year.But more importantly -- and just asUniversal Display management suggestedlast August -- the company finally saw customers commence     adoption of its next-generation phosphorescent OLED emitter     products. The company also made a $15 million investment in a     Barberton
column13: Ohio
column14: manufacturing plant owned byPPG Industries
column15: which should double commercial production capacity for its     emitters.Now whatUniversal Display also told investors to expect full-year 2017   revenue to be in the range of $230 million to $250 million
column16: or up   15.6% to 25.7% from 2016. That includes a $15 million license fee   increase under Universal Display's long-term deal withSamsungDisplay
column17: and -- if recent supply chain reports prove accurate --   thecontinued adoptionof its flagship materials by other technology behemoths
column18: includingApple.Of course
column19: Universal Display was quick to note that the OLED   industry is still in its early stages
column20: so there are many   variables that could temporarily stifle that growth. But as the   company's technology becomes more ubiquitous with each passing   day
column21: it's no surprise to see Universal Display stock trading near   all-time highs right now.10 stocks we like better than Universal     DisplayWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
