column1: Can You Beat the S&P 500 at Its Own Game?;3/9/2017;"The S&P 500 isthebenchmark for most investors.The important stock index consists of 500 of the largest companies that are listed on the NYSE or the Nasdaq
column2: and securities are weighted in the benchmark by market capitalization levels. Currently
column3: top stocks in the benchmark include Apple (AAPL) at about 3.6% of the total
column4: Microsoft (MSFT) at 2.5% of the total
column5: and Exxon Mobil (XOM) at 1.65%.But while this approach is a great barometer for market health
column6: is it the best way for investors to put their money to work? Investors have numerous options in this department
column7: including products likeSPY
column8: VOO
column9: orIVV
column10: as these simply follow the benchmark exactly as laid-out by the index creators. But is there a potentially better way?Enter Equal WeightIn this edition ofthe Dutram Report
column11: I look for an alternate approach in a talk with Michael Willis
column12: the lead portfolio manager of INDEX Funds. His key product
column13: the Index Funds S&P 500 Equal Weight (INDEX)
column14: takes the same S&P 500 stocks
column15: but invests in them equally.This means that instead of Apple accounting for nearly 4% of the total
column16: or Microsoft making up 2.5% of the fund
column17: each account for roughly 0.2% of the total
column18: at least at rebalancing dates. And not just the mega caps
column19: but each and every stock comes with this same weight
column20: giving the fund an equal interest in giants like Exxon
column21: and the smallest S&P 500 components alike.While this might sound like a small difference
column22: we go over in the podcast how this actually ends up being something very important to overall returns. Michael discusses how nearly half of the S&P 500 (market cap weighted) is tied up in about 50 companies
column23: and that the remaining 450 have to fight over the remainder. He argues that the equal weight is a much more balanced way to achieve exposure
column24: while thefund's fact sheetshows that this approach has outperformed the market over long time periods.We also talk about the pros and cons of this approach
column25: such as its potentially heavier weighting in mid-cap securities and what this means for investors
column26: as well as some important fund specifics. This includes information regarding the cost and minimum investment
column27: and also the reason for selecting a fund structure. We then go over the ways that INDEX differs from the ETF counterpart out there
column28: the Guggenheim S&P 500 Equal Weight ETF (RSP)
column29: looking beyond the lower cost of INDEX when compared to the Guggenheim fund.Bottom LineEqual weight investing is an overlooked strategy for targeting stocks
column30: but it is clearly one that can lead to outperformance over long time periods. If you are curious about this approach
column31: check out this podcast for everything you need to know about how it works
column32: and if this can help improve returns for long-term investors.So
column33: make sure to listen to this edition ofthe Dutram Reportfor a closer look at equal weight investing
column34: and what the pros and cons of this approach are for those seeking a different way to play the S&P 500. And if you have any thoughts or comments
column35: reach us on SoundCloud
column36: or at podcast @ zacks.com for email. We'd love to know what you think of this chat
column37: and if you have any other topics you'd like us to cover in the future too.But for more news and discussion regarding the world of ETFs
column38: make sure to be on the lookout forthe next edition of the Dutram Report
column39: and check out themany other great Zacks podcasts as well!Want key ETF info delivered straight to your   inbox?Zacks' free Fund Newsletter will brief you on top news and analysis
column40: as well as top-performing ETFs
column41: each week.Get it free >>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today
column42: you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days.Click to get this free reportmakeArticleAd();Apple Inc. (AAPL): Free Stock Analysis ReportMicrosoft Corporation (MSFT): Free Stock Analysis ReportSPDR-SP 500 TR (SPY): ETF Research ReportsExxon Mobil Corporation (XOM): Free Stock Analysis ReportVANGD-SP5 ETF (VOO): ETF Research ReportsISHARS-SP500 (IVV): ETF Research ReportsGUGG-SP5 EQ ETF (RSP): ETF Research ReportsGet Your Free (INDEX): Fund Analysis ReportTo read this article on Zacks.com click here.Zacks Investment Research"

column1: Thursday Apple Rumors: iPad Reveal Event May Take Place on April 4;3/9/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is a possible reveal date for new iPad devices. Today
column3: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Thursday.makeArticleAd();iPad Reveal:A new rumor claims that Apple will show off its next generation of iPad tablets on April 4
column5: reportsBGR. This rumor is based on rumored availability dates for many of AAPL's next generation tablets
column6: many of which are April 4. The rumor also claims that the tech company will hold a special event to introduce the tablets. It claims this event will take place at the new Steve Jobs. The theater is set to open in early April.MacBook Pro:Apple is now selling refurbished 2016 MacBook Pro laptops through its online store
column7: MacRumorsnoted. The new option allows customers to purchase refurbished 2016 MacBook Pro computers with various different specs. One thing that all of these refurbished MacBook Pro laptops have in common is that they lack the Touch Bar that was introduced last year. Many of them also seem to be high-end laptops
column8: but listings change over time and others will likely start showing up soon.App Store:Apple is now restricting iOS app updates that change app permissions without App Store approval
column9: reportsAppleInsider. This means that many apps that download their own updates outside of the App Store may not be able to do so in the future. This restriction has always been in place since AAPL created the App Store
column10: but it hasn't strongly enforced it until just recently. This means it may take app developers longer to push out updates in the future due to having to wait for App Store approval.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postThursday Apple Rumors: iPad Reveal Event May Take Place on April 4appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Warren Buffett Isn't Trying to Beat the Market;3/9/2017;"If you're expecting high returns fromBerkshire Hathaway's(NYSE: BRK-A) (NYSE: BRK-B) stock portfolio
column2: you may want to   pay attention to what Charlie Munger has to say
column3: and then   carefully reconsider your assumption.At the recentDaily Journalmeeting
column4: Warren Buffett's sidekick
column5: Charlie Munger
column6: explained   that Buffett doesn't necessarily have high returns in mind when   he buys a stock for Berkshire's portfolio. Munger used Berkshire   Hathaway's purchase ofExxonMobilstock as an example in how Buffett's investment process has   changed:[Y]ou know why Warren bought Exxon? As a cash substitute. He     would have never done that in the old days. We had a lot of     cash and we thought Exxon was better than cash over the     short-term. That's a different kind of thinking than the way     Warren came up.makeArticleAd();Munger isn't kidding. This is very different than how Buffett   has traditionally invested.The Exxon tradeIn 2013
column7: Berkshire paid $90.86 per share for its multibillion   dollar Exxon stake. In the fourth quarter of 2014
column8: when Berkshire   liquidated its investment
column9: Exxon shares traded for an average of   $93.27 per share
column10: according to a report byBloomberg. Thus
column11: Buffett purchased and subsequently sold about $4 billion   of Exxon stock in a round-trip that earned Berkshire shareholders   a single-digit return after dividends. Most importantly
column12: Berkshire was in and out in less than two years.This quick trade is very uncharacteristic of Buffett
column13: who is   famous for taking the long view. In his 1996 letter to   shareholders
column14: Buffett wrote: ""If you aren't willing to own a   stock for ten years
column15: don't even think about owning it for ten   minutes.""That advice
column16: it seems
column17: no longer applies to how Berkshire   manages its portfolio.Image source: Getty Images.One of the most important lessons I've ever learned as an   investor is that there are no accidents in disclosure
column18: whether   the contextual clues appear in SEC filings or the documents that   accompany them. That's why I find it so interesting that Buffett   went out of his way to clarify how Berkshire views its stock   portfolio in his annual letter to shareholders this year.Buffett wrote the following on page 20 of his annual   letter:Sometimes the comments of shareholders or media imply that     we will own certain stocks ""forever."" It is true that we own     some stocks that I have no intention of selling for as far as     the eye can see (and we're talking 20/20 vision). But we have     made nocommitmentthat Berkshire will holdanyof its marketable securities forever.He added
column19: ""[W]e regard any marketable security as available   for sale
column20: however unlikely such a sale now seems.""With that
column21: Buffett makes it clear that its portfolio of public   stocks is always for sale
column22: if the price is right
column23: or if Berkshire   has better uses for the cash. It's a curious new detail
column24: one that   comes just months after Berkshire put more than $16 billion to   work purchasing shares ofAppleand four airlines
column25: industries that Buffett might be willing to   invest in
column26: but only if he doesn't have to commit to holding   forever.10 stocks we like better than Berkshire Hathaway (A   shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column27: it can pay to listen. After all
column28: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column29: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column30: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Berkshire Hathaway (A   shares) wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10   stocks are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column31: 2017Jordan Wathenhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends AAPL and Berkshire Hathaway (B     shares). The Motley Fool owns shares of XOM and has the     following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on AAPL and     short January 2018 $95 calls on AAPL. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Apple Inc. Should Thank WikiLeaks for Its CIA Reveal;3/9/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOn Tuesday
column3: WikiLeaks released ""Vault 7
column4: a huge collection of documents that reveal hacking tools used by the CIA. While the dump paints the CIA in an unflattering light
column5: the fallout may well be worse for some of the world's largest tech companies
column6: includingApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL).makeArticleAd();Source: AppleSpecifically
column7: the CIA has a long list of iOS exploits it has used to gain access to iPhones. Despite being named along with numerous other giants of tech
column8: the latest WikiLeaks dump actually highlights a key advantage for Apple in particular.And while its aura of security may emerge tarnished
column9: the iPhone may actually come out ahead over the long term thanks to WikiLeaks.What Was in WikiLeaks Vault 7?The latestWikiLeaks dump involves 8
column10: 761 documentsoutlining a wide range of CIA hacking tools
column11: including viruses
column12: malware
column13: zero-day exploits
column14: trojans and remote control systems.In addition there are 14 iOS exploits listed
column15: several dozen Android vulnerabilities and methods for accessing encrypted chats (essentially reading the contentsbeforethey are encrypted by gaining access to the host device).9 Stocks to Buy That Are Growing Faster Than AmazonIt's not all smartphones
column16: either. The CIA has developedmalware to infect computersrunning macOS
column17: Windows and Linux. It's even capable of turning Samsung Smart TVs on their owners
column18: using them as listening devices to record conversations.This Doesn't Look Good for AppleApple has long positioned itself as a privacy advocate. It has always played up the security of the iPhone and evenrefused an FBI request to unlock the iPhoneused by a shooter in 2015's San Bernardino terrorist attack.Apple CEO Tim Cook released a written statement at the time
column19: saying:""… the U.S. government has asked us for something we simply do not have
column20: and something we consider too dangerous to create. They have asked us to build a backdoor to the iPhone.""The WikiLeaks Vault 7 release made it clear that iOS wasn't as secure as Apple had thought.How Apple Could Come Out AheadWikiLeaks is bad news for Apple in the short term. But the reveal of CIA hacking of mobile devices and consumer electronics could actually be good news for the company in the long run. Apple quickly went on record as saying many of the vulnerabilities identified in the WikiLeaks Vault 7 documentswere already addressed with iOS 10. And it is working to identify and patch any new issues.Apple and Google chose very different strategies when it comes to smartphones. Apple controls every aspect of iOS - its mobile operating system - as well as the hardware. It pushes out new major new iOS versions yearly and update releases (the kind that fix bugs or security issues) on demand. As a result
column21: nearly 80% of all iPhones are currently running iOS 10.Google also releases new versions of Android yearly
column22: but largely relies on smartphone manufacturers and wireless carriers to approve and push updates. They have little incentive to do so
column23: since lacking the latest Android features could be a reason to buy a new smartphone.With such a wildly varying assortment of smartphones
column24: updates can often be problematic
column25: leading to support issues. As a result
column26: the latest version of Android is on just 2% of all Android smartphones
column27: while themajority are running software released in 2014 or earlier.In other words
column28: even if Googlehadaddressed most of the issues in Android Nougat as claimed
column29: right now
column30: there arehundreds of millions of Android devices that could still be affectedbecause they're running old software. Most iPhone users
column31: however
column32: should be okay
column33: and the rest can be assured that Apple's consistent program of releases will address any outstanding issues.Apple has a similar approach with macOS. It updates its Mac computer operating system regularly and pushes out security updates as issues are discovered. With the smart home
column34: Apple takes extreme security measures
column35: including costly custom chips
column36: factory inspections and end-to-end encryption between connected devices. This approach has meant slower adoption for its HomeKit platform
column37: but with the benefit of being far more secure than the competition.As for smart TVs eavesdropping on you
column38: that's just another reason to buy a relatively inexpensive streaming box - like an Apple TV - instead.The Age of Privacy Is OverMany people had been living with a probably naive expectation that everything they did with their smartphone was private and secure
column39: especially when using encrypted apps. The latest WikiLeaks dump should end that notion and leave people watching their TV
column40: PC and even smart thermostat with suspicion.Snap Inc. (SNAP) Aims to Win Where Disney (DIS) FailedBut by the time this plays out
column41: it's also likely to make it clearer than ever before that some products are more secure than others
column42: and some companies are in a better position to fix any vulnerabilities.Apple may have been named as one of the victims of CIA hacking
column43: but it was quick to respond and quick to make it clear many of the WikiLeaks exploits have already been addressed. Perhaps more importantly
column44: Apple's product strategy puts it in the position to be a leader in offering the most secure devices possible going forward.As of this writing
column45: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceApple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is a Jekyll-and-Hyde Trade Right NowApple Inc. iPhone Grabs Even More Market ShareThe postApple Inc. Should Thank WikiLeaks for Its CIA Revealappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: The Bull Market Turns 8: These Dow Stocks Led the Way Higher;3/9/2017;"It's hard to believe
column2: but eight years ago today
column3: theDow Jones Industrials(DJINDICES: ^DJI) were below 7
column5: and many feared further losses that could send the global financial markets into chaos. Just eight years later
column6: the Dow has tripled from those levels
column7: and the mood going forward is much more optimistic. When you look at what has powered the Dow's advance
column8: the most interesting thing you'll notice is that seven component replacements within the venerable average have happened in relatively short order
column9: and those additions have been major contributors to the gains that the average has enjoyed.makeArticleAd();^DJIdata byYCharts.The key winners in the DowBelow
column10: you can see the stocks among the Dow's current components that have produced the largest total returns for shareholders over the past eight years:StockTotal Return Since 3/9/2009Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL)1
column11: 191%UnitedHealth(NYSE: UNH)954%Home Depot893%American Express750%Walt Disney691%Visa(NYSE: V)658%Boeing624%JPMorgan Chase584%DuPont576%Nike(NYSE: NKE)552%Data source:S&P Global Market Intelligence.It's illuminating that the top two returners and four in the top 10 have joined the Dow in just the past eight years. UnitedHealth Group came into the index in 2012
column12: while Visa and Nike became Dow components in 2013. Apple is the most recent company to join the average
column13: getting its invitation in 2015.Note that their late entry hasn't prevented some of these key stocks from having huge impacts on the average. Visa
column14: for instance
column15: has seen its stock nearly double since joining the index as international electronic payments volume has dramatically increased. Economic expansion has helped increase money flows
column16: and Visa's ability to dip into that stream with its global payment network has paid off. Moreover
column17: before Visa decided to split its stock
column18: its high share price made it one of the most influential components within the Dow Jones Industrials
column19: and the overall average benefited disproportionately from its gains than from moves in lower-priced stocks.For Apple
column20: though
column21: the influence hasn't been as significant. The tech giant's admission to the Dow came near its high point
column22: shortly after a 7-for-1 stock split that brought its share price low enough to attract the attention of those who run the price-weighted average. In the following year
column23: Apple lost a third of its value
column24: but in the recent push higher for the Dow to new record levels
column25: the iPhone maker has played an instrumental role
column26: and shareholders have finally enjoyed some of the benefits.Image source: Getty Images.Making the Dow healthierUnitedHealth Group has given the Dow strong performance since its admission in 2012
column27: with its share price more than tripling over that time span. The healthcare industry has seen a lot of change over that period
column28: with the rise and seemingly imminent fall of the Affordable Care Act having presented substantial challenges to the health insurance industry. UnitedHealth has been able to benefit dramatically from going beyond health insurance through its Optum line of businesses
column29: which incorporate pharmacy benefit management and various health-related services to try to get corporate customers to encourage wellness and health improvement practices. These services have helped clients cut their healthcare costs
column30: and they've proved immensely profitable for UnitedHealth in its tenure as a Dow component.Finally
column31: Nike has continued to prosper from the popularity of athletic apparel and footwear
column32: but share price gains since it joined the Dow in 2013 have been more modest
column33: amounting to a roughly 50% to 60% rise. New competition has emerged in the space
column34: and that has forced Nike to retrench and find ways to use its powerful brand presence to stoke growth. The company remains the giant in the industry
column35: but it will have to keep fighting in order to regain its dominance and send its stock back toward record levels.The Dow's climb since 2009 is monumental
column36: and newly admitted stocks to the average have played a vital role. More importantly
column37: Apple
column38: UnitedHealth
column39: Visa
column40: and Nike will have to keep doing well if the Dow is to stay in and move further into record territory in 2017 and beyond.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Why You Really Need to Diversify;3/9/2017;"Diversification
column2: and the benefits thereof
column3: is something I have written about multiple times before. Recently
column4: however
column5: I have discovered two pieces of data that really highlight how important diversification is to a well-rounded investment strategy. The numbers are enough to terrify even the most devoted
column6: concentrated investor.Time to diversify?The world's most well-known investors are all recognized for their love of concentrated stock portfolios. Several have even remarked that diversification is a waste of time and the only way to make money in the market is to have a concentrated equity portfolio. This is all well and good
column7: but it is really not suitable advice for the average investor.makeArticleAd();The most famous investing gurus got where they are today by being good investors
column8: but that is not to say there was not a degree of luck involved as well.What would have happened toWarren Buffett(Trades
column9: Portfolio) if hisAmerican Express(AXP) investment had not worked out and the Salad Oil scandal had taken down the company? Or ifCoca-Cola(KO) was hit with such a massive bout of negative publicity it could never recover? If either of these scenarios unfolded
column10: Buffett would not be where he is today.To give another example
column11: what would have happened toCarl Icahn(Trades
column12: Portfolio) if lawmakers had viewed his actions at TWA as criminal and thrown him in jail?There are certainly cases where this has happened
column13: but because the ranks of the world's most famous investors are stalked by survivorship bias
column14: it is difficult to realize that for every one Buffett there are tens of thousands of failed investors.That is why diversification is so important and critical for long-term investing success.Numbers don't lieResearch by Arizona State University finance professor Hendrik Bessembinder shows exactly why this is the case. To try and figure out the average return of single stocks over the long term
column15: he studied the returns of 26
column16: 000 equities over the period of 1926 to 2015. Over this nine-decade period
column17: equities created $31.8 trillion of wealth. The shocking thing is that all of this wealth was generated by just 4% of equities; 96% of stocks achieved nothing. Including inflation
column18: the real return on 96% of the universe was actually negative. To put it another way
column19: the average investor has a one in 24 chance of picking a stock that will generate positive returns over the long term.ExxonMobil(XOM) alone accounted for 3% of the wealth created over the period andApple(AAPL) accounted for about 2%.These findings are only reinforced by a report issued by JPMorgan last year. According to the report
column20: titled ""The Agony & Ecstasy: The Risks And Rewards Of A Concentrated Stock Position
column21: the return on the median stock since its inception versus an investment in the Russell 3000 Index is -54%.Furthermore
column22: since 1980
column23: 320 companies have been removed from the S&P 500 due to reasons of ""distress."" So
column24: during the past three-and-a-half decades
column25: 64% of the index has been turned over. Based on these figures
column26: JPMorgan calculates the chance of actually finding an extreme winner is just 7%. Since the 1980s
column27: 40% of all companies experienced a severe loss and never recovered.The bottom lineDiversification is not a bad strategy. Some of the world's most famous investors may advocate concentrated portfolios
column28: but as the figures above show
column29: you have to be very lucky to correctly pick a stock that produces positive returns over the long term. The chances of picking a winner are so low it is hard to justify even trying. That is possibly why Buffett advocates an index tracker fund for most investors -- the risk of picking the wrong stock and losing money over the long term is just too high!.Disclosure: The author owns no stock mentioned.Start afree 7-day trial of Premium Membershipto GuruFocus.Premium MembersThis article first appeared onGuruFocus."

column1: American International Group Inc (AIG) CEO Fired for Doing His Job;3/9/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhen a CEO is made to walk the plank under the orders of a big investor
column3: middle-aged men get as giddy as schoolgirls dishing on a Hollywood starlet's failing marriage. The resignation ofAmerican International Group Inc(NYSE:AIG) CEO Peter Hancock
column4: for instance
column5: was cheered in a tweet by investor Carl Icahn
column6: and AIG stock was up almost 2% in Thursday's trade.makeArticleAd();Source:Eflon via Flickr (Modified)Hancock's crime? He let insurance do what it's supposed to. He bookeda $5.6 billion chargeagainst earnings last month
column7: resulting ina $3 billion loss for the company's fourth quarter
column8: because the companies it insured against property and casualty claims suffered losses.That's the way insurance is supposed to work. You bet that people won't suffer the catastrophes their actions could cause
column9: but when those catastrophes happen
column10: you lose your money. Of course
column11: when things work out that way
column12: Wall Street punishes you.Life is as unfair in New York as in Hollywood.Hancock's CrimesHancock's actions were conservative in the best sense. He had previously paidBerkshire Hathaway Inc.(NYSE:BRK.A
column13: NYSE:BRK.B) $10.2 billion to take 80% of AIG's reserve risk against its U.S. commercial insurance exposure before 2016.7 Cheap Dividend Stocks to Buy NowThe reserve charge came to about $1.2 billion per year for 2013 to 2015
column14: slightly more for 2016
column15: and it should set the industry on course to raise rates
column16: and book fat profits
column17: starting later this year
column18: assuming loss ratios return to normal.Hancock called his decision""a dramatic move to reduce uncertainty
column19: predicting better times ahead. But Icahn doesn't want reduced uncertainty. What he wants is a breakup of the company so it will no longer be ""systemically important
column20: allowing it to reduce its capital cushion and allowing him to book a fast profit.Icahn also wanted Hancock's head on a platter
column21: and this is being delivered to him
column22: as soon as the board can install a replacement. Hancock had been named CEO in 2014 to replace the late Robert Benmosche
column23: after running AIG's property insurance unit for four years.Maybe AIG's property insurance pricing was low under Hancock
column24: but in a competitive market you take the price you need to get the business
column25: not the price you want. When investment returns are great (as they have been for years now)
column26: a lot of players will take low prices
column27: expecting investment returns to make up for any losses.There is one area where Hancock was charged rightfully.The company's tech platform is a mess
column28: and Hancock took the resignation of CIO Philip Fasano over it early this month. Technology is very complicated
column29: and AIG has generally been late to the technology disruption party.As a result of its IT problems
column30: the physical breakup of AIG will be harder than Icahn thinks.Icahn Bad for the EconomyIcahn's thinking is great for Icahn
column31: but bad for the economy.Breaking up AIG means it can hold less capital against losses
column32: but it makes all the pieces more vulnerable to those losses. Instead of the one big collapse suffered by AIG's dumb bet on mortgage insurance in the last decade
column33: you could have a bunch of smaller collapses caused by rising risks to all insurers from the Trump administration's denial of global warming and its pending military buildup.Sears Holdings Corp (SHLD) Q4 Earnings Beat
column34: But They're AWFULOf course
column35: Icahn is as giddy as those schoolgirls over President Donald Trump.Our Tyler Craig recently called AIG""atrocious
column36: suggesting an option trade to capture a downturn
column37: but the Hancock resignation reversed the trend. The next leader of AIG is now widely assumed to be targeting a breakup of the company
column38: so Icahn will get his profit.It's just this kind of short-term thinking on Wall Street that has led the U.S. economy to repeated recessions since computing and bar codes made inventory recessions disappear in the early 1980s. We're headed down that road again. Icahn will lead us there.Meanwhile
column39: however
column40: buy AIG stock and take some of Icahn's profit.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column41: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing
column42: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceApple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is a Jekyll-and-Hyde Trade Right NowUse a Free Coupon in Chipotle Mexican Grill
column43: Inc. (CMG) Stock3 Biotech Stocks That Could Double OvernightThe postAmerican International Group Inc (AIG) CEO Fired for Doing His Jobappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column7: shares of manufacturing giantCaterpillar Inc. (NYSE:CAT-Free Report)are sliding
column8: down about 1.5% in late-morning trading after a new report
column9: commissioned by the government
column10: accused the company of tax and accounting fraud
column11: according toThe New York Times.The report
column12: which theTimeshad access to and viewed
column13: though it has not been made public or made available to Caterpillar
column14: focused on the company's offshore tax arrangement
column15: and discovered that the company did not pay U.S. taxes on billions of dollars
column16: primarily from its Swiss units and affiliates. TheTimesalso said it wasn't clear which government agency commissioned the report.""Caterpillar did not comply with either U.S. tax law or U.S. financial reporting rules
column17: Leslie A Robinson
column18: an accounting professor at the Tuck School for Business at Dartmouth College and author of the report wrote
column19: according to theTimes. ""I believe that the company's noncompliance with these rules was deliberate and primarily with the intention of maintaining a higher share price. These actions were fraudulent rather than negligent.""A Caterpillar spokeswoman told theTimesthat the company was not provided with a copy of the report
column20: and wouldn't comment any further.For years
column21: Caterpillar has defended its tax strategies
column22: saying what they utilize are practical and lawful among big U.S. corporations; they have also helped save the company billions of dollars. But since a 2014 Senate hearing
column23: Caterpillar's tax strategies have been under the microscope of government investigators
column24: notes theTimes. The hearings found that the manufacturer cut its tax bill by $2.4 billion over 13 years
column25: moving its earnings out of the U.S. and into a Swiss subsidiary.Caterpillar is also currently contesting an I.R.S demand that it pay $2 billion in taxes and penalties for profits to the subsidiary between 2007 and 2012.Apparently
column26: federal officials searched three Caterpillar locations last week to execute a search and seizure warrant
column27: including its headquarters in Peoria
column28: Illinois. Caterpillar said it was cooperating with law enforcement.Multinational corporations like Caterpillar
column29: as well as Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report) and Pfizer (NYSE:PFE-Free Report)
column30: are hit with a 35% tax rate in the U.S.
column31: which is much higher than in other developed economies. But
column32: ""they are permitted to defer the taxes owed on the profits generated offshore until they bring those earnings back to the States
column33: a process known as repatriation
column34: notes theTimes.President Donald Trump has proposed that corporations with large amounts of cash in overseas accounts should be able to return the income at a 10% rate.Which Stocks are Zacks Experts Talking About?Stocks in today's headlines may be tempting buys

column1: Trade United States Oil Fund LP (ETF) (USO) for Big Volatility Profits;3/9/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAfter lying dormant for months
column3: the volatility beast has finally returned to wreak havoc in the oil pits. TheUnited States Oil Fund LP (ETF)(NYSEARCA:USO)
column4: king of all oil-based ETFs
column5: suffered a 5.3% drubbing on Monday
column6: falling to a three-month low on substantial volume.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockLet's not mince words. It was ugly.Joining USO in the hair-raising plunge were energy stocks of all stripes. Some of the hardest-hit names includeMurphy Oil Corporation(NYSE:MUR) andDevon Energy Corp(NYSE:DVN) which slipped 6.7% and 6.5%
column7: respectively. Even the big boys joined the sell-fest.ConocoPhillips(NYSE:COP) fell 3.8% whileExxon Mobil Corporation(NYSE:XOM) dropped 1.8%.Support levels gave way across the land as sellers pressed their advantage all the way to the closing bell.But
column8: do you know who's celebrating the newfound volatility in USO? Option sellers.8 Energy Stocks in Peril as Crude Oil Breaks DownThe oil fund had become boring
column9: really boring. Over the past quarter
column10: USO has been behaving more like an old consumer staple stock. As a result
column11: the implied volatility for USO options has been more depressed than Hillary Clinton supporters after the election. With flaccid premiums
column12: strategies like covered calls and naked puts have lacked any kind of profit-giving pizzazz of late.Click to EnlargeSource: OptionsAnalytixAnd that is what makes Monday a gift from the market gods.See
column13: implied volatility ramped all day long as investor demand for options soared. The implied volatility rank quickly ascended from the low single digits to 25% by day's end. Here's to hoping we see some downside follow through in oil prices tomorrow. Further bloodshed should propel implied vol even higher.And that'll make option premiums even riper for the picking.Embrace the Fear
column14: Queue up USO PutsThere are two ways to view Monday's oil spill. Either it's the beginning of a prolonged downturn
column15: or it's a dip to be bought.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is a Jekyll-and-Hyde Trade Right NowAt this point
column16: I favor the latter view. And that means sooner than later it will be time to strike with short puts in USO. Selling out-of-the-money puts lines up perfectly with the dip buying mentality. Not to mention it capitalizes on the now juiced up option premiums.Sell the USO Apr $10 puts for 20 to 25 cents.To further increase your odds of success
column17: consider scaling in. That is
column18: sell a portion of the desired naked puts now
column19: then wait to see if further selling increases the value of the $10 strike puts to 30 cents or 40 cents. At that point
column20: you could sell the rest of your naked puts at a higher credit. This tactic will increase the average credit received
column21: which reduces your expiration breakeven price.The max reward is limited to the initial credit and will be pocketed if the USO ETF sits above $10 at expiration. By selling the put
column22: you are obligating yourself to buy 100 shares of USO for each contract sold if the fund sits below $10 at expiration.As of this writing
column23: Tyler Craig held neutral option positions in XOM.More From InvestorPlace3 Stocks to Watch on Thursday: Snap Inc. (SNAP)

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is a Jekyll-and-Hyde Trade Right Now;3/9/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsShares ofApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) are higher by a solid 20% year-to-date
column3: and AAPL stock is up 40% over the past 12 months. Making ""bets"" on a stock based on its recent percentage moves doesn't make much sense
column4: though
column5: in a raging risk-on environment such as we've seen since last November.makeArticleAd();Over my career
column6: I have found that applying a multi-time-frame approach to stock trading and investing not only allows for better perspective
column7: but as a result
column8: also results in superior risk management - and dare I say ""timing"" of trade entries and exits.I make it a point in this column to often remind ye faithful that stocks are a highly correlated asset class
column9: particularly compared to other asset classes such as commodities. While the price of pork bellies has little correlation with the price of gold
column10: within the stock market
column11: around 80% of stocks tend to rise and fall together at any given time. I point this out because while the year-to-date rally in AAPL stock is impressive and worth respecting until it reverses
column12: there also has been a broader stock market risk-on trade thus far in 2017.More than anything
column13: I highlight this for perspective.When I last discussed Apple stock onFeb. 2following the latest earnings report
column14: I said that shares were reaching a critical technical area of resistance through a multimonth lens. While AAPL has since marginally pushed above this technical area
column15: the tale of two time frames remains.7 Cheap Dividend Stocks to Buy NowToday
column16: I would like to reiterate and update this analysis.AAPL Stock ChartsOn the multiyear weekly chart
column17: we see that Apple over the years has greatly respected its 200-week simple moving average (red)
column18: which was a source of technical support in 2013 and again just last year.Click to EnlargeAt the same time
column19: we also see that each time AAPL stock gets overly extended above this moving average
column20: it tends to fall into a consolidation phase. Currently
column21: the stock trades roughly 30% above this moving average; at past extremes
column22: Apple traded as much as 50% above it.From this perspective
column23: AAPL stock could have further to run on the upside.On the other hand
column24: the MACD momentum oscillator at the bottom of the chart has now reached levels that in the past led to some downside pressure.Lastly - and I believe most importantly - the rate of change (i.e.
column25: the near-vertical rally over the past couple months) has pushed AAPL stock back above its 2015 highs. While this in and of itself is a positive development
column26: previous important highs rarely if ever are overcome on a sustainable basis until and unless some consolidation near those previous highs has taken place.Apple stock has yet to consolidate. Thus
column27: it likely will find the current upside momentum unsustainable over the next few weeks or even months.Apple Inc. (AAPL) iPhone 8: New Name
column28: Late Release?On the daily chart
column29: we see that AAPL gapped higher again following its Jan. 31 earnings report
column30: and despite already being overbought by plenty of measures
column31: kept pushing higher as the broader stock market animal spirits brought in fresh momentum.Click to EnlargeNote that except for a couple days in early January
column32: AAPL stock has now held above its 8-day simple moving average (blue) since early December 2016. That is alongstretch to be trading above such a near-term moving average. I feel it increasingly begs for some consolidation lower.At the same time
column33: until this moving average is broken on the downside
column34: one must continue to respect the uptrend.Through this near-term lens
column35: if AAPL can close above $140
column36: a next squeeze higher into $143 - $144 looks plausible. Alternatively
column37: a break and hold below $138.50 could set in motion a better consolidation move lower with first downside targets near $136 and $132.Like what you see? Sign up for our dailyBeat the Belle-letter and get Serge's investment advice delivered to your inbox every morning! (AAPL) Stock Is a Jekyll-and-Hyde Trade Right Nowappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Report: Apple Inc. to See 3D Touch Component Costs Rise for OLED iPhone;3/9/2017;"In 2015
column2: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) introduced the iPhone 6s and 6s Plus series of   smartphones. The unique selling point for those devices at the   time was the inclusion of 3D Touch functionality. 3D Touch
column3: according to Apple
column4: allows compatible devices to sense ""how   deeply users press the display.""Developing this functionality was certainlynon-trivial
column5: and implementing it obviously increased the bill of materials   of the iPhone 6s-series relative to the prior-generation iPhone   6-series devices.Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();According to DigiTimes
column6: which doesn't cite specific sources
column7: the current 3D Touch solution
column8: which is ""glass based
column9: costs   about $9. The report then goes on to say that Apple's   next-generation OLED-based iPhone will require a fundamentally   different ""thin film-based 3D touch sensor.""That different sensor structure is expected to cost ""over   US$15
column10: meaning that cost per device goes up by at least $6.Why the OLED iPhone will be so expensiveThe OLED iPhone that Apple is expected to release at some   point soon is expected to be priced significantly higher than the   standard iPhone models. Although some may view this as an Apple   ""money grab
column11: the reality is that this new phone is likely to be   much more expensive to manufacture than its non-OLED   counterparts.The OLED displays themselves are likely to be more expensive   than the LCDs that Apple uses in other devices
column12: clearly the 3D   Touch implementation will get more expensive
column13: and I wouldn't be   surprised if the industrial design of the OLED iPhone is just   more expensive to build in general.These costs add up
column14: which means that for Apple to simply   maintain the same gross profit margin percentage on those devices   as it does on its non-OLED iPhones
column15: it needs to charge more.Customers will likely pay for valueThe bad news is that prices for something like an OLED iPhone   are going to necessarily be higher than LCD-equipped iPhones. The   good news
column16: though
column17: is that those cost-adders aren't being   implemented just because Apple feels like making a more expensive   phone -- these are features that Apple thinks customers are   likely going to be willing to pay for.Apple already saw a mix shift up toward its iPhone 7 Plus from   the iPhone 7 in the early innings of the iPhone 7-series product   cycle
column18: likely driven by the dual-camera functionality on the   former. If camera functionality is enough to drive a meaningful   mix shift up
column19: then a better industrial design and superior   display should be enough to drive a large portion of the iPhone   customer base toward a relatively expensive iPhone.Segmentation will be keyWhile I do think there will be many customers interested in --   and willing to pay a premium for -- a more expensive OLED-based   iPhone
column20: there will be individuals who can't or simply won't pay   for all those extra features.For those customers
column21: Apple still needs to put out compelling   new products. Apple is rumored to be updating the current iPhone   7 and iPhone 7 Plus models with superior internals in what would   be a typical ""s"" release. Simply updating the current-generation   phones with better internals and features should drive the value   proposition of those products up while keeping the price points   the same.The point
column22: though
column23: is that Apple will need to be smart about   how it segments its product lines -- it needs to continue to   offer compelling products at familiar price points while   exploiting the latent demand for higher-end
column24: higher-priced
column25: and   ultimately more feature-rich iPhones.If Apple can pull that off
column26: its iPhone business could be   poised to enjoy significant revenue and profit growth in the   coming product cycle -- and potentially beyond.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column27: it can pay to listen. After all
column28: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column29: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column30: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!   That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better   buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column31: 2017Ashraf Eassahas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Apple. The Motley Fool has the     following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and     short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Investors
column2: Inflation-Proof Your Assets;3/9/2017;"Until recently
column3: investors haven't had to worry much about inflation. Rather
column4: the threat of deflation--persistently falling prices--has been the more pressing concern for several years. But like the proverbial frog oblivious to the rise in water temperature until it's too late
column5: says Russ Koesterich
column6: a portfolio manager at BlackRock
column7: investors are starting to experience a stealthy increase in prices.See Also:Rocky Road Ahead for Bond InvestorsThe consumer price index rose 2.1% in 2016
column8: way ahead of the 0.7% rise in 2015 and the 0.8% increase in 2014. One key reason is the rebound inoil prices
column9: which have climbed from $27 a barrel in early 2016 to $53 today. Housing costs are rising at the quickest pace in nearly 10 years (seeHome Prices Keep Climbing)
column10: and medical costs
column11: which had been mostly moderating since 2008
column12: are ticking higher again. Overall
column13: Kiplinger sees consumer prices rising 2.4% in 2017.The new president will surely keep inflation on the front burner. ""Donald Trump has put forward a set of ideas that may involve higher fiscal deficits
column14: a large infrastructure build-out and protectionist trade policies
column15: all of which could support higher inflation
column16: says Orhan Imer
column17: who specializes in inflation-linked strategies at Columbia Threadneedle Investments.makeAd('4'
column19: 'mktsnews'
column20: 'vanguard'
column22: '');No one is talking about a return to the double-digit inflation of the late 1970s. Interconnected global markets and technological innovations that improve productivity are powerful forces for holding down price increases for goods and services. But that doesn't mean you can let your guard down. ""Even low levels of inflation can be an insidious drag on your portfolio and erode your buying power
column23: says Joanna Bewick
column24: comanager of Fidelity Strategic Real Return Fund (symbolFSRRX). Investors who have not done so already should consider protecting against such erosion with some of these in­flation hedges.What to buy. Among your bond holdings
column25: consider adding Treasury inflation-protected securities. The principal value of these government issues is adjusted each month to keep pace with inflation--so yields of 0.4% for TIPS maturing in 10 years look paltry before you add the inflation rate. You can buy TIPS directly from Uncle Sam atwww.treasurydirect.gov. Plan on holding your TIPS until they mature.Investors who don't hold the bonds to maturity or who invest via funds should be aware that TIPS prices
column26: like those of most bonds
column27: fall when interest rates rise--which is what normally happens when inflation is accelerating. GivenKiplinger's forecast for higher rates in 2017
column28: fund investors should focus on portfolios that invest in short-term TIPS. Those funds will yield less than those that own longer-term TIPS
column29: but they will be less sensitive to rate swings. A good choice is Vanguard Short-Term Inflation-Protected Securities (VTiPX) or its exchange-traded namesake (VTIP
column30: $49). Yields for both versions are negative
column31: but the funds should deliver positive returns once the inflation adjustments are made. (Prices and yields are as of January 31.)You can take advantage of the higher rates that go hand in hand with inflation with a floating-rate fund. Such funds hold debt with rates that adjust along with a short-term benchmark. Many of these funds invest in loans made by banks to companies with substandard credit ratings. But with the economy growing
column32: defaults should remain manageable for now. Fidelity Floating Rate High Income (FFRHX
column33: yield 3.3%) and PowerShares Senior Loan ETF (BKLN
column36: a member of the Kiplinger ETF 20
column37: hold securities that are a little higher in quality than some of their peers. If you want to minimize credit risk and are willing to accept a lower yield
column38: try IShares Floating Rate Bond ETF (FLOT
column41: which holds bonds with investment-grade ratings.Stocks will crater if there's an in­flation shock--something on the order of an oil embargo or food crisis--but should beat inflation over the long haul. However
column42: some stock sectors do better with inflation than others. InvesTech Research
column43: a market research firm
column44: looked at eight periods of accelerating inflation from 1950 through 2012 and found that energy
column45: materials and industrials stocks
column46: among the most sensitive to swings in the economy
column47: were top performers; rate-sensitive sectors such as utilities and telecommunications lagged the market. When consumers are watching every penny
column48: ""you want to go with companies that have good brands and a competitive advantage
column49: that can raise prices and make them stick
column50: says Chris Zaccarelli
column51: chief investment officer at Cornerstone Wealth
column52: based in Charlotte
column53: N.C.Think companies such as Apple (AAPL
column54: $121) and Walt Disney Co. (DIS
column55: $111). Strategists at Goldman Sachs recommend companies with low labor costs as a percentage of revenues; their bottom lines won't suffer as much as those of high-wage firms as pay rises. The group includes insurer Aflac (AFL
column57: food processor Archer-Daniels-Midland (ADM
column59: pharmacy benefit manager Express Scripts (ESRX
column60: $69) and homebuilder PulteGroup (PHM
column61: $22).Commodity prices respond quickly to increases in demand when the economy is growing. They're often the first signal of rising inflation
column62: as well as a hedge against it. The downside is their notorious volatility. Commodity prices have been on the upswing since early 2016
column63: reversing a nearly 50% slide from April 2014. Harbor Commodity Real Return Strategy (HACMX) is a commodity fund with a twist. Its managers use some of the fund's assets to buy derivatives that track the prices of oil
column64: metals and agricultural commodities. With the rest of the assets
column65: they assemble an actively managed portfolio of TIPS and other bonds. You can gain exposure to commodities indirectly via SPDR S&P Global Natural Resources ETF (GNR
column67: which holds stocks in the energy
column68: agriculture
column69: and metals and mining sectors.You may be surprised to learn that gold is not the inflation hedge it's cracked up to be. It has outpaced in­flation only about half the time in successive 12-month periods starting in December 1973. Still
column70: if inflation expectations accelerate sharply
column71: gold
column72: which also provides portfolio protection in times of geo­political upheaval
column73: would likely perform well
column74: says BlackRock's Koesterich. Consider putting a small amount of assets in a low-cost exchange-traded product
column75: such as iShares Gold Trust (IAU
column77: which charges 0.25% annually.Real estate is a classic inflation hedge
column78: as anyone who owns a home is well aware. You can also own real estate indirectly
column79: through a real estate investment trust that owns commercial properties. REITs give investors a twofer in times of rising inflation
column80: says Kevin Brosious
column81: an investment adviser in Allentown
column82: Pa. The value of the underlying real estate appreciates along with inflation
column83: while rents paid by tenants rise
column84: too. One fund worth a look is T. Rowe Price Real Estate (TRREX

column7: which theTimeshad access to and viewed
column8: though it has not been made public or made available to Caterpillar
column9: focused on the company's offshore tax arrangement
column10: and discovered that the company did not pay U.S. taxes on billions of dollars
column11: primarily from its Swiss units and affiliates. TheTimesalso said it wasn't clear which government agency commissioned the report.""Caterpillar did not comply with either U.S. tax law or U.S. financial reporting rules
column12: Leslie A Robinson
column13: an accounting professor at the Tuck School for Business at Dartmouth College and author of the report wrote
column14: according to theTimes. ""I believe that the company's noncompliance with these rules was deliberate and primarily with the intention of maintaining a higher share price. These actions were fraudulent rather than negligent.""A Caterpillar spokeswoman told theTimesthat the company was not provided with a copy of the report
column15: and wouldn't comment any further.For years
column16: Caterpillar has defended its tax strategies
column17: saying what they utilize are practical and lawful among big U.S. corporations; they have also helped save the company billions of dollars. But since a 2014 Senate hearing
column18: Caterpillar's tax strategies have been under the microscope of government investigators

column20: moving its earnings out of the U.S. and into a Swiss subsidiary.Caterpillar is also currently contesting an I.R.S demand that it pay $2 billion in taxes and penalties for profits to the subsidiary between 2007 and 2012.Apparently

column22: including its headquarters in Peoria
column23: Illinois. Caterpillar said it was cooperating with law enforcement.Multinational corporations like Caterpillar
column24: as well as AppleAAPLand PfizerPFE. are hit with a 35% tax rate in the U.S.
column25: which is much higher than in other developed economies. But
column26: ""they are permitted to defer the taxes owed on the profits generated offshore until they bring those earnings back to the States
column27: a process known as repatriation

column12: Roku

column1: Broadcom Ltd. Expects Samsung to Try to Claw Back Premium Smartphone Share;3/8/2017;"Broadcom(NASDAQ: AVGO) is an interesting chip company to follow
column2: particularly for investors looking to get reads on howApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) andSamsung(NASDAQOTH: SSNLF) are doing in the high-end smartphone   market.Indeed
column3: Broadcom is a key supplier of Wi-Fi and RF chips to   both companies
column4: as well as to other high-end smartphone vendors.   As Broadcom's wireless chip business depends heavily on those two   companies' sales
column5: its financial commentary often includes ""clues""   that indicate that the near-term future might hold for Apple
column6: Samsung
column7: and others.Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();One key takeaway from Broadcom's most recent earnings results   is that Samsung is looking to make a serious effort to take   high-end smartphone market share
column8: potentially at Apple's   expense.Apple revenue down
column9: Samsung revenue upApple and Samsung don't launch flagship smartphones at the   same time -- Apple's products come in the fall
column10: while Samsung's   flagship Galaxy S devices tend to arrive in the spring. The word   is that Samsung will announce the Galaxy S8-series smartphones in   late March of 2017 with availability happening in late April.According to Broadcom CEO Hock Tan
column11: Broadcom's wireless   revenue dropped 13% sequentially in the company's most recent   quarter ""driven by the expected seasonal decline in demand from a   major North American customer.""In other words
column12: demand for wireless chips that go into the   iPhone was down as Apple moves past the peak of the iPhone 7   product cycle.For the second quarter of 2017
column13: Broadcom says it expects to   ""hit the bottom of annual product cycle transition at a major   North American customer"" -- in other words
column14: sales of components   to Apple in support of the iPhone 7 cycle will trough in the   current quarter
column15: with sales likely rebounding as Apple begins to   build up inventory of its next-generation iPhones.However -- and this is where it gets good -- Tan says that the   company expects that a ""significant portion"" of the decline that   it expects to see from Apple to be offset by the ramp up of sales   to its ""large Korean smartphone customer."" In other words
column16: Samsung.To be clear
column17: Tan says that the company still expects wireless   revenue to be down quarter over quarter (so the Samsung ramp-up   won't completely offset the iPhone ramp down)
column18: but he expects an   increase in Broadcom chip content inside of the new Samsung   phones to help drive a high-single-digit decline that's ""better   than the typical double-digit declines [Broadcom has] experienced   in prior years.""Potentially more than just contentBroadcom's financial commentary and expectations vis-a-vis the   Samsung S8 ramp appear to be driven more by the content increase   rather than potential market share gain. However
column19: Tan did   indicate that Samsung is trying quite hard to recapture   share.Indeed
column20: he said that Broadcom's ""Korean customer"" is ""coming   in with a vengeance to try to recover share.""Only time will tell how much share Samsung can recapture with   its Galaxy S8 line of smartphones (and if that share gain comes   at Apple's expense or that of other Android phone vendors)
column21: but   initial leaks show that the device at leastlooksnice
column22: with a very high screen-to-body ratio as well as   top-notch specifications.However
column23: it won't be too long before Samsung formally launches   the devices and the company gives some indication of the initial   sales velocity of the new phones.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column25: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Why Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Is Becoming a ‘Battleground Stock’;3/8/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) stock has pulled back sharply over the past few weeks. Nvidia stock hit an all-time closing high of $119.31 on Feb. 8. At that point
column3: Nvidia had risen $370% in just a year
column4: and was up nearly six times in the past 24 months.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockGiven the optimism toward NVDA
column5: a reversal in that trend seemed highly unlikely.Since then
column6: however
column7: NVDA stock has pulled back sharply - in a bull market
column8: no less.Nvidia trades more than 15% lower than it did barely three weeks ago. A modest selloff followed Q4 earnings in early February
column9: despite numbers that came in well above expectations. Since then
column10: a series of analyst downgrades and overall valuation concerns have pulled the high-flying stock back to Earth.From here
column11: the decline seems to make some sense. Nvidia has done a fantastic job of driving growth the past few years. Fiscal 2017 (ending January) revenue increased 55%; net income more than doubled. But valuation matters
column12: too
column13: and NVDA stock had reached at a point that in retrospect looks unsustainable.With Nvidia still trading at 36 times FY18 consensus EPS
column14: there could be more downside.The NVDA Stock Bears AwakenThe first sign that NVDA was seeing valuation questions came after its Q4 earnings report early last month. The headline numbers in the quarter were hugely impressive. EPS of $1.13 beat estimates by 30 cents; revenue growth of 55% was more than four points higher than expected. In morning trading the next day
column15: Nvidia stock cleared $120.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: The Experts' PicksBut it couldn't hold those gains; shares wound up declining 2% on the day. Nvidia declined another 7% in the next session
column16: with investors appearing to take profits after the huge bull run.Two weeks after the earnings report
column17: NVDA was rocked by two analyst downgrades:Instinet analyst Romit Shahcut the stockto ""Reduce
column18: largely citing valuation concerns. Shah pointed to two previous product cycles - motherboard CPU in 2007 and the Tegra chip line in 2011 - which had driven similar optimism toward NVDA stock. In both cases
column19: NVDA multiples had compressed. In this case
column20: with Nvidia's enterprise-value-to-sales ratio having jumped from 2x to 7x in just a year
column21: Shah argued a similar
column22: potentially dangerous
column23: cycle was occurring.BMO Capital Marketsadded its own downgradethe same day
column24: citing a ""perfect storm"" of fundamentals that had driven the stock higher. BMO's target was actually lower than that of Instinet: $85 versus $90. The firm
column25: like Instinent
column26: highlighted valuation concerns
column27: while also seeing tougher competition in 2017.The combination of two somewhat rare ""Sell""-equivalent ratings sent NVDA stock almost 10% in a single day.Does the Bear Case for Nvidia Stock Hold Water?Other analysts have come to Nvidia's defense. Goldman Sachsmaintainedthe stock on its ""Conviction Buy"" list. Mizuho & UBS both responded with ""buy the dip"" arguments. All three analysts set a target price for NVIDIA stock around $130
column28: implying close to 30% upside from current levels.But the downgrades clearly have made a dent in the narrative surrounding NVDA - and with good reason
column29: I believe.Valuation was stretched
column30: with the stock at $120 trading at 40x 2017 EPS even excluding the company's $8 per share in net cash. As strong as FY17 results were
column31: Nvidia still is a semiconductor company. That's a difficult
column32: highly cyclical business
column33: one where growth is difficult and multiples stay compressed.Product cycles tend to limit long-term growth trajectories. Moore's Law - and competition - both mean that prices generally decline over the cycle
column34: pressuring margins and profits.That's why even growing chip makers tend to have low valuations. BothCypress Semiconductor Corporation(NASDAQ:CY) andMellanox Technologies
column35: Ltd.(NASDAQ:MLNX) trade right around 14 times forward earnings.Intel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) is valued even lower
column36: though it has some growth problems. (Instinet analyst Shah suggested investors swap INTC for NVDA
column37: in part due to valuation.)The pullback in Nvidia stock makes some sense
column38: simply from a valuation standpoint. Even NVDA bears are forecastingsomegrowth - it's a question of how much
column39: and at what price.And competition isn't to be ignored. Most notably
column40: in automotive
column41: Nvidia will go head-to-head with industry leaderMobileye NV(NYSE:MBLY).I think MBLY is overvalued
column42: and similar over-enthusiasm may be boosting NVDA stock as well.How to Buy Advanced Micro Devices
column43: Inc. (AMD) Stock the RIGHT WaySimply put
column44: growth will get more difficult for Nvidia going forward. That's the nature of the semiconductor space. And slowing growth isn't priced into NVDA stock - even after the 15% pullback.How to Play NVDA From HereAt this point
column45: Nvidia looks more reasonably valued - even if I think it's a bit overpriced.A short of Nvidia stock seems too aggressive at this point
column46: to be sure
column47: but a long play might be too early. It seems likely that NVDA will be a battleground for the next few months
column48: with bulls and bears arguing over the outlook. That will drive some volatility
column49: but likely not much in the way of movement.I'd think bulls and bears alike might consider letting the dust settle here
column50: particularly until first-quarter earnings in May. Both sides make some good points
column51: and both sides will continue to make those points.I doubt either the bulls or the bears will make much progress
column52: however
column53: until at least the next earnings report.As of this writing

column1: 2 New Technologies That Could Power Cirrus Logic Higher;3/8/2017;"Image Source: Cirrus LogicCirrus Logic(NASDAQ: CRUS) paid the price ofdependingonApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) for 85% of its revenue in the third quarter.   Though it delivered a tremendous financial performance due to the   ramp up in iPhone 7 production
column2: a tepid outlook sent alarm bells   ringing. The stock market took note of Cirrus Logic's weak   outlook and its sharesdropped 14% the next day.makeArticleAd();The problem is that Cirrus' revenue is highly dependent on the   iPhone production cycle
column3: which is like putting all your eggs in   one basket. If Apple does not increase Cirrus' content in its   phones or cuts its production volumes
column4: the latter's financial   performance gets severely impacted. Apple is not expected to   bring any new Cirrus technology into its next iPhone.No increase in chip content at Apple is going to hurt Cirrus'   revenue growth. Consensus estimates indicate that its revenue   will grow only 6.5% in fiscal year 2018 as compared to estimated   gains of 31% in the current fiscal year.Cirrus needs the power of diversification in order to sustain   its strong revenue growth and avoid Apple-related fluctuations.   The good news for Cirrus investors is that there are two key   technologies that could help it diversify not just in smartphones   but into other industries as well.Voice biometrics will be a big dealCirrus' research in voice biometrics will play a major role in   its push to diversify itself as this technology
column5: which allows   people to interact with their devices via voice
column6: will find   application in a variety of fields. Voice biometrics has several   use cases
column7: ranging from connected cars to smart homes to the   Internet of Things. The technology is also gaining traction in   the fields of banking and financial services for user   authentication.Infiniti Research forecasts that the voice recognition   biometrics market will grow at an annual pace of almost 19.4%   from 2017 to 2021. This is close to the 22.9% annual growth   expected by Tractica in the overall biometrics market
column8: which   includes other sub-segments such as facial
column9: fingerprint
column10: and iris   recognition.In all
column11: the total biometrics market is expected to be worth   $15.1 billion by 2025
column12: according to Tractica
column13: and voice   recognition stands to be an important pillar of its growth due to   its application across industries. Banks
column14: for instance
column15: are   increasingly deploying voice biometrics. BothBarclaysandHSBCstarted using voice recognition to securely identify customers   last year.What's more
column16: the adoption of voice biometrics in mobile   devices is also expected to pick up pace going forward. Apple   itself filed a patent last February related to   voice-recognition-based authentication. Apple's patent filing   says that:A device can be configured to receive speech input from a     user. The speech input can include a command for accessing a     restricted feature of the device. The speech input can be     compared to a voiceprint (e.g.
column17: text-independent voiceprint) of     the user's voice to authenticate the user to the device.Cirrus can capitalize on the possibility of Apple deploying   voice biometrics in its future phones as it is all set to ""tape   out"" its first component in 2017. Cirrus management says that the   company will start sampling its voice-biometrics-enabling   components in the quarter that runs July September of 2017.Cirrus believes that it could start generating revenue from   this technology after the next fiscal year ends. Therefore
column18: it   won't be surprising if Cirrus' growth gets back on track after a   weak fiscal 2018 once it launches its voice biometrics-enabling   chips.Active noise cancellation is a more immediate     catalystTechSci Research forecasts that the market for earphones and   headphones could surpass $19 billion in revenue over the next   five years as smartphone makers try to deliver a superior audio   experience to customers. The use of active noise cancellation   (ANC) technology is one way to deliver an immersive audio   experience.Samsung(NASDAQOTH: SSNLF)
column19: for instance
column20: is expected to sell   ANC-enabled wireless headphones alongside the upcoming Galaxy S8.   Samsung believes that the use of ANC will allow it to cut out   ambient noise by a maximum of 20 decibels and result in a better   audio experience
column21: which will give it a differentiating factor   against rivals.An immersive audio experience
column22: however
column23: will not come cheap as   Samsung is expected to charge 130 euros (or $138 approximately)   for the headphones. Now
column24: Cirrus' first headset with ANC   technology is expected to be launched soon. As Samsung is one of   its customers
column25: it is likely that a Cirrus chip is powering the   Korean giant's ANC-enabled headphone.What's more
column26: Cirrus is already in talks with more customers   for its ANC headsets and seems to have landed a few design wins   already. As the design wins materialize and the adoption of voice   biometrics and ANC gains traction
column27: Cirrus Logic will find new   avenues to augment its growth. Therefore
column28: despite a year of slow   growth in fiscal 2018
column29: Cirrus Logic's long-term prospects appear   to be bright based on the possibilities presented by these two   technologies.10 stocks we like better than Cirrus LogicWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip
