column1: Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Looks Overbought. It Isn’t.;3/8/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFew names in the markets have almost universal appeal.Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) is one of them. Sure
column3: Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) products have more appeal
column4: Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column5: NASDAQ:GOOGL) is more popular andAmazon.com
column6: Inc(NASDAQ:AMZN) is more engaging
column7: but let's give credit where credit is due. Most of us have grown up with Microsoft programs
column8: and we continue to use them frequently to this day.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockOf course
column9: emotional sentiment only goes so far. To prove its relevance in a changing world
column10: Microsoft must deliver the goods. For most of this decade
column11: the results for Microsoft stock have been fantastic.We're talking five out of seven years in the black
column12: with an average annual profit of nearly 14%. In addition
column13: MSFT stock has enjoyed four consecutive years of double-digit growth.I don't care how many caveats you can mention about the proverbial old dog … that's a trick that's tough to master at any age. Seemingly
column14: the change at the top of the Microsoft war room
column15: from Steve Ballmer to Satya Nadella
column16: is working wonders. Most importantly
column17: the willingness to aggressively push into new territory is encouraging for potential Microsoft shareholders.9 Stocks to Buy That Are Growing Faster Than AmazonInvestorPlace contributor Will Ashworth took this confidence further by declaring that MSFT stock willhit $80 this year. Is this wishful thinking
column18: or is there more to this than mere bravado?Challenges Facing MSFT stockFirst things first - I admire the guts Ashworth displayed. That's putting yourself out there and giving clarity to your point of view. It's something I wish I could see in Washington
column19: but that's a whole different ballgame.With MSFT stock specifically
column20: the bullish argument is an easy one
column21: but so is the cautious approach. Shares have soared despite the wave of competition in the consumer tech sector. InvestorPlace contributor Vince Martin speaks for a lot of people whenhe wrote
column22: ""I continue to be surprised at the strength shown by Microsoft stock. MSFT stock has risen roughly 150% in just four years - despite little movement in profits.""The lack of fundamental growth is even more perplexing when you consider Microsoft's position within the fierce environment. The company is either lagging
column23: or is getting challenged by rising up-and-comers. Martin writes:""For Office 365
column24: Tableau Software Inc(NYSE:DATA) is challenging Excel - and 27% revenue growth in 2016 suggests DATA is taking share from MSFT. Behemoths likeOracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) and many others are in the cloud space. Microsoft's Dynamics CRM product is a distant second tosalesforce.com
column25: inc. (NYSE:CRM).""A huge concern for those trading MSFT stock is the market capitalization. I'm not a fan of focusing on any one metric. Still
column26: with its equity valued at half a trillion dollars
column27: you have to take a step back. Is Microsoft stock really worth that much?Click to EnlargeKeep in mind that despite four consecutive years of double-digit growth
column28: the magnitude has also declined. The first strike was 39.5% in 2013
column29: followed by performances of 28.4%
column30: 21.9% and 16.5%.Microsoft Stock Is a Proven WinnerAdmittedly
column31: that's not the direction the trend should go. Nevertheless
column32: I think Ashworth is going to be a happy camper. Like other tech names
column33: Microsoft stock starts off the year fairly slowly. For example
column34: its first quarter returns are a relatively pedestrian 8%.But at year's end
column35: the average return jumps up to 30.7%
column36: nearly four times higher. That also means that those who are concerned about this year's slow start for MSFT stock shouldn't be.The other attribute that is remarkable about Microsoft is its resiliency. Between 2000 and 2011
column37: MSFT stock suffered a negative Q1 performance ten times. But in four of those instances
column38: shares managed to claw back positive returns for the year. That provides a lot of security for those making strongly optimistic calls for Microsoft stock.While investors have reason to look at MSFT cautiously
column39: I think Wall Street is giving Nadella and company a fair shake. They want to see what it can do with its long-term strategy
column40: and the signs are encouraging. A prime example is Microsoft'shigh-profile acquisitionofLinkedIn. By integrating its intellectual capital with Microsoft's vast networks
column41: it can do serious damage in the social media sphere.Snap Inc (SNAP) Stock: Stay Away at All Costs!Overall
column42: $80 for Microsoft stock is very reasonable. Although not dominant
column43: it's competing well in some of the most exciting and high-growth sectors. Both the company and the markets are loving the change in leadership and culture. Finally
column44: Microsoft continues to find ways to do well
column45: even in the most trying of circumstances. The only question is
column46: can I be the first to call $100 in 2018?As of this writing
column47: Josh Enomoto did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 Drug Stocks Hit by Trump's Call for Lower Prices4 Food Stocks at Risk Thanks to Record HeatThe postMicrosoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Looks Overbought. It Isn't.appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: The Zacks Analyst Blog Highlights: Apple
column2: Pandora
column3: Alphabet and Sony;3/8/2017;"For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column4: IL -March 08
column5: 2017 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst Blog. Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the financial markets. Stocks recently featured in the blog includeApple's(NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report)
column6: Pandora(NYSE:P-Free Report)
column7: Alphabet Inc.'s(NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report)
column8: andSony(NYSE:SNE-Free Report).Today
column9: Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free.Here are highlights from Tuesday's Analyst Blog:Will Spotify Stream into an IPO in 2017?Launched in 2008 by entrepreneurs Daniel Ek and Martin Lorentzon
column10: Stockholm
column11: Sweden-basedSpotifyis one of the most popular streaming services on the market today. With its desktop and mobile app version
column12: the company allows users to search or browse
column13: for free
column14: through its extensive music library. Spotify also offers a ""Premium"" subscription for $9.99 per month that removes advertisements and lets users download music to listen to offline.CompetitionSpotify recently announced that it now has 100 million monthly active users
column15: with 50 million paying for the service. This achievement has cemented its status as the biggest subscription music service by user count
column16: and the leader in the increasingly crowded music streaming industry.Arguably Spotify's biggest market rival is Apple's (NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report) Apple Music. Launched in 2015
column17: Apple Music is a streaming music service based on Beats Music
column18: which has drawn listeners with playlists made by experts
column19: not algorithms. The service is also known for its collaborations with high-profile musicians like Drake and Taylor Swift. It costs $9.99 per month
column20: and users can download music from an extensive digital library
column21: just like Spotify. Apple Music offers listeners a free
column22: three-month initial trial.There's also Tidal
column23: the Scandinavian streaming service that rapper and mogul Jay Z scooped up back in 2015 for $56 million. It has a similar price of $9.99 per month for normal streaming
column24: while also offering a $19.99 per month option that includes high-fidelity sound quality. Like Apple Music
column25: Tidal is known for its partnerships with big music names. Rihanna
column26: Beyoncé
column27: and Kanye West all exclusively debuted their latest albums on Tidal before a wider release.Other top rivals include Rdio
column28: which provides access to online radio stations
column29: with different levels of on-demand access
column30: for $3.99 to $9.99 per month; Pandora (NYSE:P-Free Report)
column31: one of the original internet radio companies
column32: goes for $4.99 per month to avoid ads; Rhapsody
column33: the original streaming music subscription service
column34: has been around since 2001
column35: and is available for $9.99 per month; and Alphabet Inc.'s (NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report) Google Play Music
column36: which offers online music storage and a streaming service for $9.99 per month.ControversiesDespite its popularity
column37: Spotify tends to draw out negative publicity
column38: mainly over debates about its free advertising-supported service. This service allows people who are prepared to sit through occasional ads to listen to songs for free on demand. Music labels-Spotify is in compliance with Sony (NYSE:SNE-Free Report)
column39: EMI
column40: Warner Music Group
column41: and Universal
column42: among others-understandably dislike the free service because it dismantles album sales
column43: and pays less in royalties than the subscription does.We all remember Spotify's battle with Taylor Swift. The popstar withdrew her entire catalog from the service because she ""didn't like the way it felt. I think there should be an inherent value placed on art. I didn't see that happening
column44: perception-wise
column45: when I put my music on Spotify
column46: shesaid in an interviewwithTime.Other musicians soon followed in her footsteps. Icelandic singer Björk made her latest albumVulnicuraunavailable on Spotify and other streaming services
column47: though her back catalogue remained available. And in 2015
column48: British songstress Adele similarly restricted her Grammy-winning album25from all streaming services-however
column49: you can currently listen to it on Spotify
column50: along with her other albums
column51: 19and21-on its release date
column52: tellingTimethat ""I believe music should be an event.""Last year
column53: Spotify was embroiled in issues surrounding its updated Terms and Conditions of Use
column54: where in ablog post
column55: the company's user communications manager Candace Katz explains ""We may ask for customer permission to collect information from new sources
column56: such as address book
column57: location
column58: and sensor data [and photos
column59: voice controls
column60: and contacts] from the mobile device to improve the customer experience and inform product decisions.""This unexpectedly caused an uproar
column61: with many calling Spotify's new privacy policy ""eerie"" and ""creepy"" and pledging to unsubscribe from the service. The backlash was bad enough that CEO Ek wrote another blog post
column62: aptly called ""SORRY"" in order to explain that users don't have to share this information if they don't want to. ""We will ask for your express permission before accessing any of this data - and we will only use it for specific purposes that will allow you to customize your Spotify experience.""An IPO on the Horizon?Over the past few years or so
column63: Spotify has been on the hunt for new funding. The company closed funding rounds in 2012 and 2013
column64: raising $100 million and $250 million
column65: respectively. In 2016
column66: Spotify completed a whopping $526 million round of funding
column67: putting it at a valuation of roughly $8.5 billion
column68: a move that showed investors its desire for expansion and new forms of content-a few months before this funding round
column69: Spotify announced its plan to add videos and podcasts from partners like ESPN
column70: NBC
column71: Comedy Central
column72: and Condé Nast.And about a year ago
column73: the company raised $1 billion in convertible debt on the promise that its new investors will receive a 30% discount on shares when it files for an IPO. Spotify will have to pay 5% annual interest on the debt
column74: however
column75: and 1% more every six months
column76: up to a total of 10%
column77: until it goes public.This decision to raise money through convertible debt was a smart move
column78: as Spotify was able to maintain its high valuation without diluting its existing shareholders. It does suggest the company is seriously thinking about an IPO
column79: since the latest round of funding encourages Spotify to go public sooner rather than later.Or
column80: at least
column81: that's what was originally thought.According toTechCrunch
column82: Spotify is apparently considering delaying its IPO to 2018
column83: with sources saying the company wants to use the time to ""build a better balance sheet and work on shifting its business model to improve its margins."" But in reality
column84: the delay is likely linked to Spotify's inability to finalize new licensing deals with the big record labels like Universal
column85: Sony
column86: and Warner
column87: whom control 80% of recorded music.There's no doubt about Spotify's rapid growth and universal reach

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) iPhone 8: New Name
column2: Late Release?;3/8/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) upcoming flagship smartphone continues to be the subject of intense speculation. With the countdown on to finalizing design and starting production of the new iPhone
column4: two details in particular have seen conflicting theories: the name and the display size.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleA new post from Japan'sMac Otakarasuggests AAPL will go with the iPhone Edition - instead of iPhone 8 or 10th anniversary iPhone - for its flagship model.The website also feels it has nailed the display size
column5: and agrees with a previous report that the new iPhone could arrive significantly later than usual.iPhone 8 = iPhone Edition?What to call the new iPhone is actually a big deal this year. The regular naming sequence will continue with the iPhone 7s and iPhone 7s Plus. Those are the phones for everyone. But what do you call the all-new flagship AAPL is expected to release -the $1
column6: 000+ smartphonethat celebrates a decade in the business (and hopefully helps to propel sales to stratospheric levels)?The iPhone X
column7: 10th Anniversary iPhone and iPhone 8 have been the front runners. But what would you call the 10th Anniversary iPhonenextyear? And iPhone 8 would mess up Apple's naming scheme for its mainstream models.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Can't Commit to HollywoodMac OtakarathinksAAPL will go with the iPhone Edition. The premium Apple Watch model is the Apple Watch Edition
column8: so the precedent has already been set and it would be consistent. This would also solve the continuity problem associated with naming a new iPhone specifically around the 10th anniversary
column9: without messing up the current iPhone naming scheme. iPhone Edition makes sense.About the New iPhone DisplayOutside of whether it would be curved or not
column10: or OLED or not
column11: there have been conflicting reports about the display's size. Most analysts have been calling for a 5.8-inch display with bezels practically eliminated. That would let AAPL fit a larger display into an iPhone that's smaller than the 5.5-inch iPhone 7 Plus.It's a similar approach to whatSamsung Electronics Co Ltd(OTCMKTS:SSNLF)appears to have taken with the Galaxy S8.However
column12: Mac Otakarahas always maintained - and still insists - that the new iPhone will have a 5-inch display. Which seems weird
column13: given the consumer preference for big screens.Mac Rumorsconnected the dotsand theorizes that the information given to the Japanese website is for theusablespace. The remaining display area would be where AAPL has a row of virtual buttons - a feature that has already been mentioned as replacing the Home button and mimicking the functionality of the new MacBook Pro Touch Bar.Take a 5.8-inch display
column14: reserve the bottom of that display for the virtual buttons
column15: and you end up with what is effectively a 5-inch display in terms of what the owner can make use of.The math is starting to add up.iPhone Edition Could Be DelayedFinally
column16: Mac Otakaraagrees with the growing number of analysts who are predicting the iPhone 8 - or iPhone Edition - is going to face a delayed release.A few days ago
column17: 9to5 Macreported the iPhone 7s series would go into production in July
column18: as expected. But there are rumors that the TouchID sensor that AAPL is integrating into the new iPhone Edition's display is proving challenging. The added manufacturing complexity may push mass production for the new flagship model to September. That would mean severe supply constraints
column19: including the possibility that theiPhone Edition would not begin shipping until a month after the iPhone 7s
column20: with only early pre-orders being delivered in 2017.If the production issues turn out to be true
column21: the results could be problematic … but not necessarily.Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Is Still ""The One""On the downside
column22: Apple would face the possibility that potential iPhone 7s buyers hold off until they can physically compare it against the iPhone Edition
column23: delaying that wave of upgrades. Potential iPhone Edition buyers could also shrug and order the iPhone 7s instead
column24: not wishing to wait a few months for their new smartphone. And without the 1-2 punch of the 7s and iPhone Edition together
column25: AAPL could miss out on the spectacularly record-smashing launch sales weekend it is gunning for to celebrate that 10th anniversary.On the upside
column26: the annual crest of sales that accompany every new iPhone release could be extended. The iPhone 7s would get the first rush
column27: followed by the iPhone Edition.It's possible.As always
column28: stay tuned. At this stage
column29: everything we ""know"" about the new iPhone is speculation. But with AAPL's supply chain starting to crank up for production
column30: the pieces are beginning to fall into place.As of this writing
column31: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceHow to Buy Advanced Micro Devices
column32: Inc. (AMD) Stock the RIGHT WayTuesday Apple Rumors: AAPL Files Patent for Facial Detection SoftwareApple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is Going to Frustrate YouThe postApple Inc. (AAPL) iPhone 8: New Name
column33: Late Release?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 5 Top Stocks to Buy on the Dollar Rally;3/8/2017;"If corporate executives have been fretting over a stronger dollar
column2: the scenario is likely to take a turn for the worse soon. With the Federal Reserve hinting at an interest rate hike this month and the euro losing value post the French election surprise
column3: the dollar is set to grow stronger.A stronger dollar is denting profits for U.S. multinationals that rely heavily on exports. However
column4: smaller
column5: domestically focused companies gain appeal. Such companies are unperturbed by currency gyrations as they generate most of their revenues from within the U.S.Fed Lending Support to the DollarThe ICE Dollar Index rose 0.4% to settle at 100.28 late on Mar 7. The dollar
column6: which drifted lower in the past two months after hitting a 14-year high in mid-December
column7: is preparing to bounce back. The dollar had already been able to surpass its major resistance level of 100
column8: with several traders saying that such a resistance level has become support.The dollar strengthened against most of its rivals on rate hike expectations. Yellen indicated that a rate hike is in the offing this month with more slated to follow later this year
column9: in a speech to The Executive's Club of Chicago. She said that the ""Federal Open Market Committee will evaluate whether employment and inflation are continuing to evolve in line with our expectations
column10: in which case a further adjustment of the Federal funds rate would likely be appropriate"". The language is similar to what Fed had used in the past to signal at a rate hike. Fed officials
column11: including some dovish members
column12: also reiterated that a March interest rate increase is 'on the Table'.Based on CME Group 30-Day Fed Fund futures prices
column13: which have long been used to express the market's views on the likelihood of changes in U.S. monetary policy
column14: indicate an 84% chance of a rate hike this month. By increasing interest rates
column15: a nation can attract foreign investors who seek highest risk-adjusted returns. Subsequently
column16: there is an increase in demand for the home currency in order to be able to invest in areas where the interest rates are higher.Euro Dips as French Election Plot ThickensWeakness in the euro due to uncertainty over the upcoming elections in France also boosted the dollar. Alain Juppe
column17: the former Prime Minister of the country
column18: confirmed that he was not ready to run the election. This development is likely to boost the chances of anti-European Union candidate Marine Le Pen.If Juppe contested the elections
column19: he would have won the first round
column20: with centrist candidate Emmanuel Macron coming second
column21: which eventually could have knocked Le Pen from contention
column22: according to an opinion poll. Juppe replaced the scandal-hit Francois Fillon as the centre-right candidate.The news sent the euro to $1.0592
column23: down 0.25% from $1.0621 ahead of the Juppe announcement. Markets are also uneasy about the elections to be held in Germany and Netherlands
column24: which constrained the euro despite upbeat economic data across the Eurozone.Who Benefits from a Stronger Dollar?Stronger dollar hammers profits at multinationals. The strengthening of the dollar makes large U.S. companies with significant international exposure bleed as exported products become expensive to foreign buyers. A stronger dollar clearly makes U.S. multinationals less competitive
column25: from technology to energy.Technology is most vulnerable to movements in dollar. A number of big brand names including Apple Inc.AAPL
column26: International Business Machines CorporationIBMand Oracle CorporationORCLgenerate half of their sales abroad. The energy industry is also affected by currency fluctuations and could affect major players such as Occidental Petroleum CorporationOXYand Halliburton CompanyHAL.On the contrary
column27: U.S. small-caps are relatively immune to the dollar strength and stand to benefit.  These companies generate the bulk of their revenues from the U.S. and thus don't have to worry about their products becoming expensive for non-U.S. buyers or foreign exchange risks while repatriating overseas profits.5 Top Domestic Players to BuyAs mentioned above

column1: Apple Stock Nears $140: Still a Buy?;3/6/2017;"Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) stock has seen a roaring comeback recently
column2: with   shares soaring about 28% in the past three months and hitting new   all-time highs. At the time of this writing
column3: shares are trading   at about $139
column4: well above their price of approximately $110 three   months ago and significantly higher than the low $90s they hit   last summer.With the stock trading so much higher recently
column5: is itstilla buy? This is a good question
column6: particularly following legendary   investor Warren Buffett's recent move toload up on Apple
column7: making itBerkshire Hathaway's(NYSE: BRK-B) (NYSE: BRK-A) second-largest equity holding.iPhone 7 Plus.Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Reasons for optimismReinforced byApple stock's 15% rise since its Jan. 31 first-quarter earnings release
column8: investors seem pleased with the tech giant's performance   recently. The recently ended quarter marked an important turning   point for Apple as it returned to revenue growth
column9: thanks   primarily to a strong iPhone launch in September. The new iPhone   7 and 7 Plus models' popularity have helped the iPhone segment
column10: which accounts for over 60% of total revenue
column11: return to   growth.Data source: Apple quarterly SEC filings. Chart by     author.In its Dec. 31-ending holiday quarter
column12: iPhone revenue and   units increased 5% year over year as consumers bought up new   iPhones. Apple sold 78.3 million iPhones
column13: generating a record   $54.4 billion in revenue for the segment
column14: up from $51.6 billion   in iPhone revenue in the year-ago quarter. The rise in revenue
column15: combined with a $1.1 billion increase in its services revenue
column16: helped Apple increase its total revenue 3% year over year.The return to growth was a promising sign for Apple's ability   to move product. But signs to be bullish didn't end there. Apple   also guided for a 2% to 6% year-over-year increase in revenue   during its second quarter
column17: suggesting the return to growth may be   here to stick around.No longer the screaming buy it wasBut Apple's stock price appreciation accompanying its solid   business performance recently means the stock isn't the solid buy   it was. Indeed
column18: even Buffett seems to be rethinking how   attractive Apple stock is after its sharp increase recently.""I want to emphasize
column19: we have not bought at this price. I   mean
column20: we quit buying when the earnings came out
column21: Buffett said in   a recent interview with CNBC. Importantly
column22: Buffett was also   careful to emphasize that Berkshire is ""certainly not selling   either.""Putting Apple stock's soaring valuation into perspective
column23: the   rising stock price has pushed its price-to-earnings ratio from   about 11 one year ago to nearly 17 today.AAPL P/E Ratio (TTM)data byYCharts.However
column24: Apple's pricier valuation today shouldn't lead   investors to immediately conclude the stock is no longer a buy.   Apple stock still trades much more conservatively than many other   companies. For instance
column25: the average P/E ratio for stocks in theS&P 500is 26. Combining Apple's conservative valuation with the   company's recent growth
column26: the stock is still a good long-term bet   -- even at $139. But it's obviously not as good as a buy as itwasaround $100 a year ago or even at January's $120.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip

column1: Spotify Growth Surges Despite Apple
column2: Inc.'s Revamped Apple Music;3/6/2017;"Apple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) launch of its Spotify-like streaming music   service in 2015 was an important move for the tech giant. Not   only did it bolster Apple's services business with a new   subscription offering
column3: but it strengthened the overall integrated   ecosystem of Apple-branded hardware
column4: software
column5: and services that   help customers stay locked into Apple's products.But is Apple's music service failing to live up to its   potential? Spotify's rapid growth since Apple Music's launch   suggests Apple's new music service may not be resonating with   customers the way investors hoped it would.Image source: Spotify.makeArticleAd();Spotify vs. Apple Music: By the numbersApple Music recently made headlines when Apple Internet   Software and Products Vice President Eddy Cue toldBillboardthat the music service had surpassed 20 million subscribers. Cue   also took the opportunity to give the world a glimpse of Apple's   ambition with the service
column6: noting that the company went from zero   subscribers in June 2015 to 20 million in December 2016. ""[O]f   course we want more and we want it to go faster -- we're hungry!""   Cue toldBillboard.But despite Apple Music hitting the 20-million subscriber   milestone
column7: Spotify's March 2 announcement that it just hit 50   million subscribers shows how its service is growing   significantly faster than Apple Music recently. Spotify's   reported 50 million paid subscribers is up from 40 million in the   middle of September. This represents a growth rate of about 1.8   million paid users a month. Apple's most recent milestone of 20   million was up about 3 million users in three months compared to   its last update on its paid users for Apple Music
column8: representing a   growth rate of about 1 million per month.Maybe Spotify is a bit hungrier than Apple?There's no excuse for Apple Music's underperformanceAhead of Apple Music's launch
column9: everything lined up for the   music service to quickly grow to rival Spotify
column10: or at least to   hit a point where it can sustain Spotify's growth rates. After   all
column11: Apple was already a music juggernaut with its iTunes. With   Apple reporting in 2014 it had 800 million credit card numbers   linked to iTunes
column12: the service easily has over a billion credit   cards on file in 2017. Adding to the growing list of reasons for   Apple Music to be a smashing hit
column13: Apple even redesigned Apple   Music ""from the ground up"" this summer in an effort to accelerate   demand for the service. Apple Music should have easily built on   this strong foundation and catapulted the new music service to a   level that threatened Spotify's dominance.Apple Music. Image source: Apple.What's even more concerning is that Spotify's meteoric growth   only highlights how unfortunate it is that Apple hasn't built a   streaming music service compelling enough to keep up with   Spotify's stronger ability to attract new customers. Growing from   30 million paid subscribers last March to 40 million about three   months ago to about 50 million now
column14: Spotify is putting the   spotlight on the strength of the streaming music market.On the other hand
column15: with Spotify's growth continuing to outpace   Apple Music's
column16: this new milestone for Spotify could potentially   serve as a wake-up call for Apple management to begin investing   more aggressively in its streaming music offering. And given   Apple's $50 billion-plus in annual free cash flow
column17: its resources   to invest in its music service are virtually unlimited compared   to Spotify's business model
column18: which has yet to achieve   profitability.But given Spotify's ability to outperform Apple Music so far
column19: Apple investors shouldn't count on Apple Music catching up to   Spotify.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip

column21: the newsletter they       have run for over a decade

column1: Why Intel Corporation Is Unlikely to Lose the Apple Inc. Mac Anytime Soon;3/6/2017;"Rumors are swirling that microprocessor giantIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) may be on the verge of losing its spot as the   supplier of the processors that powerApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) iMac desktop and MacBook notebook products.Hypotheses range from Apple's designing its own chip for the   Mac to speculation that Apple will use chips from alternative   processor vendors. However
column2: I believe that based on Intel's   recent commentary at its Feb. 9 investor day
column3: it is unlikely that   the company is going to lose these orders.Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Intel's CCG financial guidanceIf Intel were to lose some -- or all -- of the Mac processor   orders
column4: this would manifest as a reduction in the company's   Client Computing Group (CCG) revenue and operating profits. If we   estimate that Apple pays an average of $200 for Intel processors   and related components
column5: then that's $4 billion in revenue that   could potentially be at risk.Put another way
column6: if that $4 billion were to disappear (or drop   significantly)
column7: then Intel could potentially see more than 10% of   its CCG revenue vanish. That wouldn't be the end of the world
column8: but it's the sort of thing that would sting.At its investor day
column9: Intel said that it expects its revenue in   CCG to decline at a ""low-single-digits"" pace -- or an average of   1%-3% annually over the next three years. If we compound the low   and high ends of that range
column10: Intel is planning for between a 3%   and a 9% decline in CCG revenue from 2016 levels by the end of   2019.Here's a translation to hard dollar figures: Intel is planning   for CCG revenue to drop by a total of between $1 billion and $3   billion in that three-year period -- $2 billion at the   midpoint.At the same time
column11: CEO Brian Krzanich said in his investor   meeting presentation that he expects the PC processor total   addressable market to be worth around $30 billion in 2021 -- $2   billion down from where the company pegged the total addressable   market in 2016.Putting the numbers togetherIf Intel expects the PC processor total addressable market to   drop by around $2 billion by 2021 and is planning for   ""low-single-digit"" declines in CCG through 2019 (a $2 billion   decline at the midpoint)
column12: then it doesn't look to me like the   company is guiding for significant personal-computer processor   revenue share loss.Now
column13: it's worth noting that forecasts this long out aren't   going to be perfect
column14: but Intel likely has visibility into the   personal-computer design win pipelines at its various customers
column15: including Apple. If Apple were preparing to shift away from Intel   processors for Macs released over the next couple of years
column16: then   Intel would likely be aware of that imminent shift and should   have included that expectation in its multi-year forecast.Based on this analysis
column17: I don't think Intel investors ought to   worry too much about Apple's switching away from Intel processors   anytime soon in its MacBook or iMac products.Over the long term
column18: however
column19: anything is possible
column20: so Intel   will have to make sure that it has an increasingly compelling   product pipeline to keep Apple interested.10 stocks we like better than IntelWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: How Long Until I Get My Driverless Car?;3/6/2017;"Autonomous cars have been the buzz of the energy and tech   sectors for years now
column2: but how close are we as consumers to   actually having fully autonomous cars in our driveways?In this week's episode ofIndustry Focus: Industrials
column3: analyst Sean O'Reilly talks with Motley Fool senior auto   specialist John Rosevear about the state of autonomous driving   tech today
column4: and when consumers will start to see the fruits of   the industry's labors.Tune in to find out what the different levels of automation   are and why they matter; where companies likeTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA)
column5: Ford(NYSE: F)
column6: andFiat Chryslerfit into the story; whereAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Waymo andApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) alleged car project seem to be heading; and   more.makeArticleAd();A full transcript follows the video.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column11: 2017This podcast was recorded on March 2
column12: 2017.Sean O'Reilly:Welcome toIndustry Focus
column13: the podcast that dives into a different sector of the stock   market every day. Today is Thursday
column14: March 2
column16: so   we're talking about energy
column17: materials
column18: and   industrials. I am your host
column19: Sean O'Reilly
column20: and joining   me today via phone is Motley Fool senior auto   specialist
column21: Mr. John Rosevear. Good morning
column22: John!John Rosevear:Good morning
column23: Sean! How are you
column24: today?O'Reilly:Extremely well. It's good to hear your voice. It's been   awhile
column25: a month or two
column26: since we last had a podcast
column27: and I   missed you
column28: buddy.Rosevear:Yeah
column29: it's been a few weeks.O'Reilly:I had to get you in here to answer an all-important question.Rosevear:What's the question?O'Reilly:You're the only guy I know who can answer this for   me. I hate driving
column30: I live in D.C.
column31: it's very tiring
column32: I   want to know when I'm going to get my self-driving car.Rosevear:Well
column33: it depends on what you mean by get
column34: and   really depends on what you mean by   self-driving
column35: [laughs] unfortunately.O'Reilly:I'm not touching the wheel in my driveway.Rosevear:Let's back up and define some terms here. This system of   classification for things that assist drivers has become   pretty universal. It was developed by the Society of Automotive   Engineers in the U.S. The U.S. government has adopted   it
column36: other governments have adopted it
column37: it's the way all   automakers talk now. They categorize it in six levels that   are helpfully numbered from zero to five. A level zero system
column38: there's no automation
column39: the driver does everything. This might   even include warning systems like lane departure warning. But
column40: the driver actually has to do everything. Level one is when   you get some basic level of driver   assistance
column41: assistance that parallel parks for   you
column42: that kind of stuff. That's a level one system.O'Reilly:Does that include anti-lock brakes? I'm surprised   that's on here.Rosevear:That's...O'Reilly:Eye of the beholder?Rosevear:The driver is still executing that. They count that as an   intervention system. It's when the car decides to break for you   that it starts to become assisted. These emergency   stopping systems that they have now where the radar is on   the front of the car
column43: the levels one through five require some   level of sensing what's going on around a car. So
column44: yeah
column45: these   parallel park systems where the car spins the wheel for you and   backs into the spot
column46: that kind of thing
column47: that's a level one.   Level two is where it starts to get interesting. This is the   system where you're on the highway and the traffic jam assist   systems
column48: maybe the earliest versions of Tesla's   autopilot
column49: where you can kind of take your hand off the   wheel under certain circumstances
column50: and the car will maintain and   adjust its speed relative to the cars around to you
column51: and it   will keep itself in its lane. It's doing a little   steering and a little accelerating and decelerating on its   own. But there still has to be a human driver
column52: the human   driver has to be ready to grab the wheel. In fact
column53: a lot of   these systems require you to actually touch the wheel every   minute or two
column54: or something like that. Level three is   when it kind of gets into self driving. This is a system that can   drive under certain conditions
column55: we might say highway   driving
column56: this is where Tesla's autopilot is starting to go
column57: this is where some of the systems
column58: GM's(NYSE: GM) Super Cruise that will come out on Cadillac   soon
column59: this is where it ends up
column60: level three.O'Reilly:Super Cruise? [laughs]Rosevear:That's what they call it. That's what they've been   calling it for a few years
column61: I'm not completely sure   that's what they're going to call it when it comes to   market. Anyway
column62: the gist here is
column63: it's self-driving until   suddenly it isn't
column64: the driver has to be ready to grab the   wheel. That makes it a little tricky. We'll talk about that   in a minute.O'Reilly:The Motley Fool's Dan Sparks did that article about a year   ago
column65: he lives out in Colorado and he has a Tesla
column66: how   far did he get

column1: Monday Apple Rumors: All iPhones May Have OLED Displays in 2019;3/6/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of the company's OLED display plans. Today
column3: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Monday.makeArticleAd();OLED Display:A new rumor claims that Apple will completely switch the iPhone to OLED displays in 2019
column4: reportsMacRumors. According to this rumor
column5: the tech company is planning to introduce its first iPhone with an OLED display later this year. This report claims that it will increase the number of iPhone devices that carry the displays in 2018. It notes that the company will then have all iPhone devices made with OLED displays in 2019. AAPL's iPhone 8 is expected to be the first of its smartphones to have an OLED display.iPhone 8:Yet another report claims that the iPhone 8 will bring major changes this year
column6: 9to5Mac. This new rumor claims that Apple will be releasing an iPhone this year that comes with a 5.8-inch OLED display. It also claims that the company will release two other smartphones this year as well. These smartphones are rumored to have LCD panels instead of OLED displays. It also talks about the function area at the bottom of the device that other rumors have mentioned.Cologne Store:Apple is preparing to open its second psychical retail location in Cologne
column7: Germany
column8: reportsAppleInsider. The tech company is planning to open the new store location in Schildergasse on March 25. Previous rumors claimed that the company was going to open a new retail location here. Some photos of a building in the area spotted an AAPL logo hiding behind a couple of tarps earlier this year.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postMonday Apple Rumors: All iPhones May Have OLED Displays in 2019appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Should Qualcomm Inc. Worry About Xiaomi's New Chips?;3/6/2017;"Mobile chipmakerQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) and Chinese smartphone giantXiaomiare often considered close partners. Qualcomm became one of   Xiaomi's earliest investors in 2011
column2: and all of Xiaomi's flagship   devices use Qualcomm chips. When regulatory troubles in China   forced Qualcomm to renegotiate its licensing terms with OEMs
column3: Xiaomi was one of the first companies tosign a new dealwith the chipmaker.However
column4: that alliance gradually weakened. Xiaomi eventually   started using moreMediaTek(NASDAQOTH: MDTKF) chips in its cheaper devices
column5: and    ongoing rumors indicated that the company was developing   first-party chips. Those rumors were finally confirmed in late   February
column6: when Xiaomi unveiled the Surge S1 chip for its new   mid-range Mi 5c smartphone.Xiaomi's Mi5c. Image source: Xiaomi.makeArticleAd();The Surge S1 is a 28nm chip with eight cores
column7: four of which   run at 2.2GHz with another four running at 1.4GHz. Its Mali T-860   MP4 GPU is capable of playing 4K videos. Those specs make it   slightly more  powerful than Qualcomm's Snapdragon 625
column8: a   popular octa-core processor which powers mid-range devices like   the international variant of Xiaomi's Mi Note 4. The S1 was   produced by Xiaomi's subsidiary Pinecone Electronics via a   partnership with Chinese chipmakerLeadcore.Why Xiaomi needed to make its own chipsBack in 2014
column9: Xiaomi became the biggest smartphone maker in   China. But by the end of 2016
column10: it had dropped to fifth place   afterOppo
column11: Huawei
column12: Vivo
column13: andApple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column14: in that order. That decline was caused by   competitors flooding the market with comparably priced phones
column15: a   shift in consumer tastes toward pricier devices
column16: and an overall   slowdown across the Chinese smartphone market.Last November
column17: Xiaomi admitted that its  core phone   business wasn't profitable. In January
column18: it stopped disclosing   annual shipment  figures and abruptly announced that it   would skip this year's Mobile World Congress. Those moves all   indicated that the company was struggling to stay afloat in the   crowded Chinese market.However
column19: Xiaomi also noticed that it could follow Apple
column20: Huawei
column21: andSamsung's(NASDAQOTH: SSNLF) lead and develop first-party ARM chips.   Producing first-party chips is a pricey investment
column22: but it's a   smart long-term play because it reduces Xiaomi's dependence on   chipmakers like Qualcomm
column23: cuts production costs
column24: tightens up the   supply chain
column25: and gives it full control over the hardware and the   software -- which could better optimize its devices for Xiaomi's   MIUI custom Android OS.Xiaomi's Mi Air Purifier. Image source: Xiaomi.In addition to lowering costs and boosting performance
column26: IDC   analyst Bryan Ma also noted that Xiaomi's first-party chips could   work better with its smart home ecosystem
column27: which already includes   air purifiers
column28: bathroom scales
column29: lights
column30: and even rice cookers.   Xiaomi could also use its first-party chips to bypass a ban on   MediaTek chips in India
column31: which occurred due to a patent dispute   withEricsson.What this means for QualcommXiaomi's introduction of first-party chips isn't good news for   Qualcomm
column32: but there's no indication that Xiaomi will stop using   Qualcomm chips altogether. The Mi 5c merely represents the budget   device of its flagship Mi 5 family -- which includes the original   Mi 5
column33: the Mi 5S
column34: and the Mi 5S Plus. All three of the other Mi 5   devices use Qualcomm chips.Therefore
column35: the Surge S1 could actually hurt MediaTek -- which   supplies Xiaomi with chips for variants of its low and mid-range   devices -- instead of Qualcomm. If the Surge S1 becomes Xiaomi's   official mid-range chipset
column36: it could stop using MediaTek chips as   Qualcomm chips remain in high-end devices.Qualcomm's Snapdragon could lose its spot in mid-range devices   like the Mi Note 4
column37: but the overall impact on its chipmaking   business might be minimal. Xiaomi's global market share is   already likely below 5%
column38: based on IDC estimates
column39: and could   continue fading as Oppo
column40: Huawei
column41: and Vivo launch new devices.   SincesomeOppo
column42: Huawei
column43: and Vivo devices use Qualcomm chips
column44: higher sales   at those leading brands could easily offset any design losses at   Xiaomi.So should Qualcomm investors be worried?If Xiaomi had revealed the Surge S1 back in 2014
column45: then swapped   out all Qualcomm chips with its own silicon
column46: I think investors   would have been worried. But Xiaomi is merely aiming its new   chips at the mid-range market today
column47: and any losses from Xiaomi   could probably be offset by higher sales of other rival Android   devices.Therefore
column48: investors shouldn't consider Xiaomi's announcement   to be a major blow to Qualcomm on its own. Nonetheless
column49: the   overall trend is worrisome
column50: because it indicates that Qualcomm's   chipmaking business -- which posted flat year-over-year sales   growth last quarter -- will likely continue ceding market share   to first-party ARM chips for the foreseeable future.10 stocks we like better than QualcommWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column51: it can pay to listen. After all
column52: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column53: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column54: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Qualcomm wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Can’t Commit to Hollywood;3/7/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsRumors abounded last week as two executives fromApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) were involved in a series ofclosed-door discussionsin Hollywood
column3: involving some high-ranking TV and film producers.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleWhile few details of those meetings have been made public

column6: to acquisition and partnership negotiations.Eddy Cue
column7: Apple's Senior Vice President of Internet Software and Services
column8: held meetings last week with executives from various film studios
column9: including Sony Pictures Entertainment
column10: the cinema division ofSony Corp (ADR)(NYSE:SNE)
column11: and Paramount Pictures Corporation
column12: a subsidiary ofViacom
column13: Inc.(NASDAQ:VIAB).Apple's Endeavors in Hollywood Are UnclearBecause last week's meetings between Cue and film studio execs remain under wraps

column15: though

column20: however

column26: the company is reportedly attempting to create a hybrid service that ties together Apple Music and Apple TV
column27: though many analysts are concerned that such a service wouldnot perform wellin today's entertainment marketplace.PatentlyAppleopined
column28: ""The market is going to be so saturated with new TV services that Apple will have to do something rather dramatic for their new hybrid service to stand out
column29: but ""Apple TV's greatness has always been 'just around the corner' and hasneverreally materialized .""What's confusing to some AAPL stock investors
column30: though
column31: is Apple's seemingly mixed signals regarding the company's intentions for the streaming movie and television space. One one hand

column33: We're not trying to compete with Netflix or compete with Comcast.""CEO Tim Cook purportedlyverified the company's current lack of direction
column34: stating:""In terms of original content
column35: we've put our toe in the water doing some original content for Apple Music
column36: and that will be rolling out throughout the year. We're learning from that and we'll go from there.""However
column37: considering both last week's meetings with top Hollywood film studio executives and the failed takeover negotiations with Imagine Entertainment
column38: it certainly does look like Apple is trying its hardest to break into the streaming media niche. In fact
column39: longtime Apple stock analyst Gene Munster predicted thatApple will win an Oscar within the next five years.What This Means for AAPL StockAll things considered
column40: with the current state of affairs regarding Apple TV
column41: original content production and Hollywood film studio acquisitions
column42: there hasn't been much that's legitimately concrete.5 Value Traps Every Investor Must Steer Clear FromSure
column43: if we were talking about any other company
column44: this myriad of rumors and speculation combined with executive statements to the contrary could be enough to cause some wild swings in stock prices. But
column45: for AAPL stock
column46: this doesn't even move the needle.The company has so many other revenue streams and products on which to focus that its film and TV floundering have basically gone unnoticed. Apple stock investors have been hearing about the upcoming Apple TV revolution for years
column47: but nothing has materialized.This current buzz of activity may have caught the attention of some
column48: but until - or unless - management officially announces something groundbreaking
column49: AAPL stock will remain unaffected.As of this writing

column1: The New Fitbit Alta HR Isn’t Enough to Break the Fitbit Inc (FIT) Slump;3/7/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFitbit Inc(NYSE:FIT) has had a rough year already. Sales have been down significantly as it gets squeezed between increasingly fitness-focused smartwatches on the high end and cheap fitness trackers from China on the low end. Making matters worse

column4: 2015.makeArticleAd();Source: FitbitThe company just announced a new Fitbit Alta HR activity tracker
column5: but is adding heart rate monitoring to an existing fitness bracelet (and boosting the price) going to help turn things around for FIT stock?Fitbit Alta HRYesterday
column6: Fitbit announced theFitbit Alta HR. The company followed the same basic strategy it used with last year's Charge 2: Take an existing fitness tracker and add heart rate monitoring.In this case
column7: the Alta - FIT's fitness bracelet aimed at more fashion-conscious consumers - was updated with the company's PurePulse heart rate sensor. FIT is billing it as ""the world's slimmest fitness wristband with continuous heart rate."" The new version is also more expensive: $149.95 compared to $129.95 for the original.This price point makes the new Fitbit tracker the exact same price as the Charge 2. Both offer pretty much the same features
column8: including heart rate monitoring and the ability to switch bands for different looks. The primary difference between the two (besides a slimmer form factor) appears to be that the Alta HR lacks the Charge 2's ability to use a connected smartphone's GPS. However
column9: the new Fitbit offers superior battery life to the Charge 2
column10: with a claimed 7-days between charges instead of 5-days.7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Lows in 2017FIT's Challenging YearThe trouble for Fitbit stock actually started in earnest as 2016 began to wind down.The company faced a litany of problems
column11: including production issues with its latest models and ongoing legal issues with rivalJawbone.Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) released the Apple Watch Series 2 in September
column12: adding an even greater focus on fitness. AAPL lowered the price of the original Apple Watch
column13: making it more tempting to customers who had been considering a new Fitbit because the smartwatch was too expensive. The icing on the cake was Apple'sNike Inc(NYSE:NKE) partnership that resulted in theApple Watch Nike+fitness smartwatch
column14: which arrived just in time to tempt holiday shoppers.FITbought the IP from struggling smartwatch pioneer Pebblein December
column15: but that move has not had any material impact on on its product line as yet. If anything
column16: the move angered Pebble fans.In the latest bit of bad news for Fitbit stock
column17: a report for Q4 wearable sales showsApple hit a new record with the Apple Watch
column18: while China'sXiaomisaw its fitness tracker sales grow 96.2% year-over-year. FIT had a rough quarter
column19: with sales down 22.7%.Are Products Like the Fitbit Alta HR the Answer?In its quarterly report on wearables
column20: IDC summarized the challenges FIT faces:""However
column21: the company also faced one of its largest declines ever as it remained heavily focused on the U.S.
column22: a market that is quickly approaching saturation for fitness trackers. Though the company has grown in other parts of the world
column23: it also remained challenged as low-cost competitors eat away at Fitbit's market share.""The Fitbit Alta HR is without a doubt a good fitness tracker. But is heart rate monitoring a big enough new feature to convince Alta owners to upgrade? For those looking for a first fitness tracker (in this increasingly saturated U.S. market)
column24: the identically priced Charge 2 makes for a confusing choice.Apple Inc. Fesses Up to iPhone 6 Battery Issue
column25: Releases FixFor those who want a fitness tracker without spending $150
column26: Xiaomi's MI Band 2
column27: which offers the same basic features as the new Fitbit
column28: including heart rate monitoring
column29: OLED display
column30: sleep tracking
column31: smart phone alerts and interchangeable bands - goes for under $30. Clearly FIT won't sell many of its new Fitbit trackers in China and online retailers are selling cheap MI Bands to U.S. buyers as well.In other words
column32: the Fibit Alta HR isn't likely to do much to turn around Fitbit's fortunes. If the company is able to integrate that Pebble know-how it acquired into a device that satisfies its hardcore user base while attracting potential smartwatch buyers - something the Fitbit Blaze has struggled to do - then it might be on to something.For now
column33: it seems like FIT is treading water.As of this writing
column34: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceWWDC 2017: Here's What Apple Inc. Might RevealReport: Apple Inc. iPhone 8 Could Cost More Than $1
column35: 000 (AAPL)The postThe New Fitbit Alta HR Isn't Enough to Break the Fitbit Inc (FIT) Slumpappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Why Home Depot Inc (HD) Stock Is Perfect for Income Investors;3/7/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsSinceHome Depot Inc(NYSE:HD) ""crushed"" earnings estimates on Feb. 21
column3: you would think the HD stock price would be rocketing upward
column4: right?makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)Wrong.Home Depot stock starts Mar. 7 lower than it did immediatelyafter reporting those results: Net earnings of $1.74 billion - $1.44 per share - on revenue of $22.21 billion
column5: a 5.8% year-over-year sales increase. This handily beat estimates of $1.35 per sharein earnings.The company also set a $15 billion HD stock repurchase plan and hiked the dividend from 69 cents per share to 89 cents.The market's reaction? Mostly yawns.You can argue that the reason for that is market anticipation of a good report. Home Depot stock is up 9.7% for the year
column6: and 17% over the last 12 months.7 Stocks to Buy That Are ALMOST in Buffett Buying RangeBut I think something else is going on with HD stock … I think the nature of the company's investment case is changing.HD Stock: From Capital Gains to YieldThe company was founded in 1978
column7: around the time ofApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL)
column8: and since coming public in 1981 it has had an Apple-like trajectory. Home Depot stock has split nine times in those 36 years
column9: and a dollar invested at the IPO is now worth over $420
column10: 000.This is why co-founder Bernie Marcus could build his hometown of Atlanta a giant aquarium and still be worth$4.1 billion
column11: while his partner
column12: Arthur Blank
column13: could buy the Atlanta Falcons and be worth$3.4 billion. The company has about 2
column14: 200 stores and dominates its market.But there is a natural limit to the middle of the home improvement market
column15: as there isn't (yet) in the device-and-cloud business. With fiscal 2017 sales of over $94 billion
column16: Home Depot is bumping up against those limits. Growth has slowed to a steady $5 to $6 billion in sales each year
column17: net income is level at about 8% of sales.The company's board has been doing the wise and natural thing: They're sharing the wealth with shareholders. The dividend was 29 cents per share five years ago
column18: and will now be 89 cents when it is paid out later this month. That's a huge increase
column19: and income investors who bought HD stock in 2012 at about $48 per share are now earning $3.56 per share on that money.Don't let the current yield of 2.42%
column20: based on the Home Depot stock price of $147
column21: fool you. This is a yield play - not a growth play - for the future.HD's Changing PerformanceYield investors are not like growth investors.When you are looking for income
column22: an income investor won't watch the daily averages the way a growth investor would. So long as the dividend is rising
column23: or just staying level
column24: an income investor will hang on until death or taxes.Snap Inc (SNAP) Stock: Stay Away at All Costs!One result is that yield plays tend to be less volatile stocks than growth plays
column25: and the volatility becomes more predictable and more seasonal.This can be seen instories about Home Depot options.Options can deliver big returns on tiny changes in a stock's price
column26: and a regular pattern helps.The pattern for HD stock indicates that some backing-and-filling is due following earnings
column27: and that's precisely what is happening. The recent price action
column28: in other words
column29: is predictable.Bottom Line on Home Depot StockDoes this mean HD stock is no longer a great stock? For a growth investor
column30: as I have been
column31: there are better investments
column32: and I sold out my position a few months ago
column33: at a fat profit.On the other hand
column34: if you are an income investor and if you're retired and need to make money on your money to live out your days in comfort
column35: then Home Depot stock is a great investment for you. As is often said in Atlanta
column36: that 2.42% yield is going to rise-up over time
column37: as the company continues to share its profits with you.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column38: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing
column39: he owned no shares in companies mentioned in this article.More From InvestorPlace10 Dangerous Dividend Stocks to Dump Now5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Buy in MarchThe postWhy Home Depot Inc (HD) Stock Is Perfect for Income Investorsappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: iShares Nasdaq Biotechnology Index (ETF) (IBB) Is at a Crossroads;3/7/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsBiotechnology stocks - as represented by theiShares Nasdaq Biotechnology Index (ETF)(NASDAQ:IBB) - have rallied 13% year-to-date. That's notable considering that over the past 12 months
column3: the IBB ETF has ""only"" rallied by about 14%.makeArticleAd();Many traders in recent days have pointed to the continued strength in biotech stocks as a sign that the broader market is not yet ready to roll over. But it is notable that the IBB
column4: as a result of the recent rally
column5: has now reached an important technical level on the charts that may offer better technical resistance.A simple yet effective ""trick"" that I repeatedly use to gauge the internal strength of the broader stock market is by checking the pulse of the so called ""risk-on"" groups. While these groups change over the years
column6: they often include technology and financial stocks. In recent years
column7: biotech
column8: tech as a whole and small-cap stocks
column9: among others
column10: have led the risk-on pack.Over the past few weeks
column11: biotech stocks and the IBB ETF have showed both absolute and relative strength versus the broader stock market. Through this lens
column12: one could argue that it is premature to get too defensive on the stock market in the near-term and possibly the intermediate-term until biotech stocks begin to back off some.When I last discussed the state of biotech stocks onFeb. 1
column13: I offered that the IBB's bullish reversal from Jan. 31 could be the beginning of a next swing higher with price targets in the $285-$290 area. Two weeks later
column14: the upper end of this price target had been reached
column15: and last week the IBB ETF further extended this rally into the $300 level.7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Lows in 2017Now
column16: let's look at the charts.IBB ETF ChartsOn the multiyear weekly chart
column17: we see that this recent rally has brought the IBB back to the very upper end of a sideways channel
column18: which now also lines up with the 100-week simple moving average (blue).Click to EnlargeThis confluence of technical resistance around the $300 area could provide a more meaningful challenge to be overcome.On the daily chart
column19: we see that last week
column20: the IBB already marginally pushed above previous horizontal technical resistance from August and September 2016.Click to EnlargeMoreover
column21: we can see that over the past few trading days
column22: the IBB ETF has been consolidating in a narrow range right at (or marginally above) those August and September 2016 highs.At this juncture
column23: biotech's path of least resistance on the daily chart - despite the bigger technical resistance from the first chart above - continues to point higher.Here's Why GoPro Inc. Stock (GRPO) CrashedNote also that the 50-
column24: 100- and 200-day moving averages are also now beginning to curl higher again. Considering that price action is the ultimate arbiter
column25: however
column26: I believe the IBB (from a trading perspective) must now be able to clear above $302.50 for a next move toward $312 and possibly $315 to stand a better chance.As usual
column27: any bearish reversal would serve as a stop-loss signal on swing trading longs.Like what you see? Sign up for our dailyBeat the Belle-letter and get Serge's investment advice delivered to your inbox every morning! Download Serge's Free Special Report:6 Keys for Successful Trading and Investing.More From InvestorPlaceAdvanced Micro Devices

column1: Apple Stock Nears $140: Still a Buy?;3/6/2017;"Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) stock has seen a roaring comeback recently
column2: with   shares soaring about 28% in the past three months and hitting new   all-time highs. At the time of this writing
column3: shares are trading   at about $139
column4: well above their price of approximately $110 three   months ago and significantly higher than the low $90s they hit   last summer.With the stock trading so much higher recently
column5: is itstilla buy? This is a good question
column6: particularly following legendary   investor Warren Buffett's recent move toload up on Apple
column7: making itBerkshire Hathaway's(NYSE: BRK-B) (NYSE: BRK-A) second-largest equity holding.iPhone 7 Plus.Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Reasons for optimismReinforced byApple stock's 15% rise since its Jan. 31 first-quarter earnings release
column8: investors seem pleased with the tech giant's performance   recently. The recently ended quarter marked an important turning   point for Apple as it returned to revenue growth
column9: thanks   primarily to a strong iPhone launch in September. The new iPhone   7 and 7 Plus models' popularity have helped the iPhone segment
column10: which accounts for over 60% of total revenue
column11: return to   growth.Data source: Apple quarterly SEC filings. Chart by     author.In its Dec. 31-ending holiday quarter
column12: iPhone revenue and   units increased 5% year over year as consumers bought up new   iPhones. Apple sold 78.3 million iPhones
column13: generating a record   $54.4 billion in revenue for the segment
column14: up from $51.6 billion   in iPhone revenue in the year-ago quarter. The rise in revenue
column15: combined with a $1.1 billion increase in its services revenue
column16: helped Apple increase its total revenue 3% year over year.The return to growth was a promising sign for Apple's ability   to move product. But signs to be bullish didn't end there. Apple   also guided for a 2% to 6% year-over-year increase in revenue   during its second quarter
column17: suggesting the return to growth may be   here to stick around.No longer the screaming buy it wasBut Apple's stock price appreciation accompanying its solid   business performance recently means the stock isn't the solid buy   it was. Indeed
column18: even Buffett seems to be rethinking how   attractive Apple stock is after its sharp increase recently.""I want to emphasize
column19: we have not bought at this price. I   mean
column20: we quit buying when the earnings came out
column21: Buffett said in   a recent interview with CNBC. Importantly
column22: Buffett was also   careful to emphasize that Berkshire is ""certainly not selling   either.""Putting Apple stock's soaring valuation into perspective
column23: the   rising stock price has pushed its price-to-earnings ratio from   about 11 one year ago to nearly 17 today.AAPL P/E Ratio (TTM)data byYCharts.However
column24: Apple's pricier valuation today shouldn't lead   investors to immediately conclude the stock is no longer a buy.   Apple stock still trades much more conservatively than many other   companies. For instance
column25: the average P/E ratio for stocks in theS&P 500is 26. Combining Apple's conservative valuation with the   company's recent growth
column26: the stock is still a good long-term bet   -- even at $139. But it's obviously not as good as a buy as itwasaround $100 a year ago or even at January's $120.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip
column27: it can pay to listen. After all
column28: the newsletter they       have run for over a decade
column29: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column30: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of       them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even       better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column31: 2017Daniel Sparksowns shares of Apple. The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Apple and Berkshire Hathaway (B shares). The Motley     Fool has the following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on     Apple and short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley     Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Spotify Growth Surges Despite Apple
column2: Inc.'s Revamped Apple Music;3/6/2017;"Apple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) launch of its Spotify-like streaming music   service in 2015 was an important move for the tech giant. Not   only did it bolster Apple's services business with a new   subscription offering
column3: but it strengthened the overall integrated   ecosystem of Apple-branded hardware
column4: software
column5: and services that   help customers stay locked into Apple's products.But is Apple's music service failing to live up to its   potential? Spotify's rapid growth since Apple Music's launch   suggests Apple's new music service may not be resonating with   customers the way investors hoped it would.Image source: Spotify.makeArticleAd();Spotify vs. Apple Music: By the numbersApple Music recently made headlines when Apple Internet   Software and Products Vice President Eddy Cue toldBillboardthat the music service had surpassed 20 million subscribers. Cue   also took the opportunity to give the world a glimpse of Apple's   ambition with the service
column6: noting that the company went from zero   subscribers in June 2015 to 20 million in December 2016. ""[O]f   course we want more and we want it to go faster -- we're hungry!""   Cue toldBillboard.But despite Apple Music hitting the 20-million subscriber   milestone
column7: Spotify's March 2 announcement that it just hit 50   million subscribers shows how its service is growing   significantly faster than Apple Music recently. Spotify's   reported 50 million paid subscribers is up from 40 million in the   middle of September. This represents a growth rate of about 1.8   million paid users a month. Apple's most recent milestone of 20   million was up about 3 million users in three months compared to   its last update on its paid users for Apple Music
column8: representing a   growth rate of about 1 million per month.Maybe Spotify is a bit hungrier than Apple?There's no excuse for Apple Music's underperformanceAhead of Apple Music's launch
column9: everything lined up for the   music service to quickly grow to rival Spotify
column10: or at least to   hit a point where it can sustain Spotify's growth rates. After   all
column11: Apple was already a music juggernaut with its iTunes. With   Apple reporting in 2014 it had 800 million credit card numbers   linked to iTunes
column12: the service easily has over a billion credit   cards on file in 2017. Adding to the growing list of reasons for   Apple Music to be a smashing hit
column13: Apple even redesigned Apple   Music ""from the ground up"" this summer in an effort to accelerate   demand for the service. Apple Music should have easily built on   this strong foundation and catapulted the new music service to a   level that threatened Spotify's dominance.Apple Music. Image source: Apple.What's even more concerning is that Spotify's meteoric growth   only highlights how unfortunate it is that Apple hasn't built a   streaming music service compelling enough to keep up with   Spotify's stronger ability to attract new customers. Growing from   30 million paid subscribers last March to 40 million about three   months ago to about 50 million now
column14: Spotify is putting the   spotlight on the strength of the streaming music market.On the other hand
column15: with Spotify's growth continuing to outpace   Apple Music's
column16: this new milestone for Spotify could potentially   serve as a wake-up call for Apple management to begin investing   more aggressively in its streaming music offering. And given   Apple's $50 billion-plus in annual free cash flow
column17: its resources   to invest in its music service are virtually unlimited compared   to Spotify's business model
column18: which has yet to achieve   profitability.But given Spotify's ability to outperform Apple Music so far
column19: Apple investors shouldn't count on Apple Music catching up to   Spotify.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip
column20: it can pay to listen. After all
column21: the newsletter they       have run for over a decade

That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even       better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Why Intel Corporation Is Unlikely to Lose the Apple Inc. Mac Anytime Soon;3/6/2017;"Rumors are swirling that microprocessor giantIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) may be on the verge of losing its spot as the   supplier of the processors that powerApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) iMac desktop and MacBook notebook products.Hypotheses range from Apple's designing its own chip for the   Mac to speculation that Apple will use chips from alternative   processor vendors. However
column2: I believe that based on Intel's   recent commentary at its Feb. 9 investor day
column3: it is unlikely that   the company is going to lose these orders.Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Intel's CCG financial guidanceIf Intel were to lose some -- or all -- of the Mac processor   orders
column4: this would manifest as a reduction in the company's   Client Computing Group (CCG) revenue and operating profits. If we   estimate that Apple pays an average of $200 for Intel processors   and related components
column5: then that's $4 billion in revenue that   could potentially be at risk.Put another way
column6: if that $4 billion were to disappear (or drop   significantly)
column7: then Intel could potentially see more than 10% of   its CCG revenue vanish. That wouldn't be the end of the world
column8: but it's the sort of thing that would sting.At its investor day
column9: Intel said that it expects its revenue in   CCG to decline at a ""low-single-digits"" pace -- or an average of   1%-3% annually over the next three years. If we compound the low   and high ends of that range
column10: Intel is planning for between a 3%   and a 9% decline in CCG revenue from 2016 levels by the end of   2019.Here's a translation to hard dollar figures: Intel is planning   for CCG revenue to drop by a total of between $1 billion and $3   billion in that three-year period -- $2 billion at the   midpoint.At the same time
column11: CEO Brian Krzanich said in his investor   meeting presentation that he expects the PC processor total   addressable market to be worth around $30 billion in 2021 -- $2   billion down from where the company pegged the total addressable   market in 2016.Putting the numbers togetherIf Intel expects the PC processor total addressable market to   drop by around $2 billion by 2021 and is planning for   ""low-single-digit"" declines in CCG through 2019 (a $2 billion   decline at the midpoint)
column12: then it doesn't look to me like the   company is guiding for significant personal-computer processor   revenue share loss.Now
column13: it's worth noting that forecasts this long out aren't   going to be perfect
column14: but Intel likely has visibility into the   personal-computer design win pipelines at its various customers
column15: including Apple. If Apple were preparing to shift away from Intel   processors for Macs released over the next couple of years
column16: then   Intel would likely be aware of that imminent shift and should   have included that expectation in its multi-year forecast.Based on this analysis
column17: I don't think Intel investors ought to   worry too much about Apple's switching away from Intel processors   anytime soon in its MacBook or iMac products.Over the long term
column18: however
column19: anything is possible
column20: so Intel   will have to make sure that it has an increasingly compelling   product pipeline to keep Apple interested.10 stocks we like better than IntelWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column21: it can pay to listen. After all
column22: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: How Long Until I Get My Driverless Car?;3/6/2017;"Autonomous cars have been the buzz of the energy and tech   sectors for years now
column2: but how close are we as consumers to   actually having fully autonomous cars in our driveways?In this week's episode ofIndustry Focus: Industrials
column3: analyst Sean O'Reilly talks with Motley Fool senior auto   specialist John Rosevear about the state of autonomous driving   tech today
column4: and when consumers will start to see the fruits of   the industry's labors.Tune in to find out what the different levels of automation   are and why they matter; where companies likeTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA)
column5: Ford(NYSE: F)
column6: andFiat Chryslerfit into the story; whereAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Waymo andApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) alleged car project seem to be heading; and   more.makeArticleAd();A full transcript follows the video.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
