column1: Monday Apple Rumors: All iPhones May Have OLED Displays in 2019;3/6/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of the company's OLED display plans. Today
column3: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Monday.makeArticleAd();OLED Display:A new rumor claims that Apple will completely switch the iPhone to OLED displays in 2019
column4: reportsMacRumors. According to this rumor
column5: the tech company is planning to introduce its first iPhone with an OLED display later this year. This report claims that it will increase the number of iPhone devices that carry the displays in 2018. It notes that the company will then have all iPhone devices made with OLED displays in 2019. AAPL's iPhone 8 is expected to be the first of its smartphones to have an OLED display.iPhone 8:Yet another report claims that the iPhone 8 will bring major changes this year
column6: 9to5Mac. This new rumor claims that Apple will be releasing an iPhone this year that comes with a 5.8-inch OLED display. It also claims that the company will release two other smartphones this year as well. These smartphones are rumored to have LCD panels instead of OLED displays. It also talks about the function area at the bottom of the device that other rumors have mentioned.Cologne Store:Apple is preparing to open its second psychical retail location in Cologne
column7: Germany
column8: reportsAppleInsider. The tech company is planning to open the new store location in Schildergasse on March 25. Previous rumors claimed that the company was going to open a new retail location here. Some photos of a building in the area spotted an AAPL logo hiding behind a couple of tarps earlier this year.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postMonday Apple Rumors: All iPhones May Have OLED Displays in 2019appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Should Qualcomm Inc. Worry About Xiaomi's New Chips?;3/6/2017;"Mobile chipmakerQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) and Chinese smartphone giantXiaomiare often considered close partners. Qualcomm became one of   Xiaomi's earliest investors in 2011
column2: and all of Xiaomi's flagship   devices use Qualcomm chips. When regulatory troubles in China   forced Qualcomm to renegotiate its licensing terms with OEMs
column3: Xiaomi was one of the first companies tosign a new dealwith the chipmaker.However
column4: that alliance gradually weakened. Xiaomi eventually   started using moreMediaTek(NASDAQOTH: MDTKF) chips in its cheaper devices
column5: and    ongoing rumors indicated that the company was developing   first-party chips. Those rumors were finally confirmed in late   February
column6: when Xiaomi unveiled the Surge S1 chip for its new   mid-range Mi 5c smartphone.Xiaomi's Mi5c. Image source: Xiaomi.makeArticleAd();The Surge S1 is a 28nm chip with eight cores
column7: four of which   run at 2.2GHz with another four running at 1.4GHz. Its Mali T-860   MP4 GPU is capable of playing 4K videos. Those specs make it   slightly more  powerful than Qualcomm's Snapdragon 625
column8: a   popular octa-core processor which powers mid-range devices like   the international variant of Xiaomi's Mi Note 4. The S1 was   produced by Xiaomi's subsidiary Pinecone Electronics via a   partnership with Chinese chipmakerLeadcore.Why Xiaomi needed to make its own chipsBack in 2014
column9: Xiaomi became the biggest smartphone maker in   China. But by the end of 2016
column10: it had dropped to fifth place   afterOppo
column11: Huawei
column12: Vivo
column13: andApple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column14: in that order. That decline was caused by   competitors flooding the market with comparably priced phones
column15: a   shift in consumer tastes toward pricier devices
column16: and an overall   slowdown across the Chinese smartphone market.Last November
column17: Xiaomi admitted that its  core phone   business wasn't profitable. In January
column18: it stopped disclosing   annual shipment  figures and abruptly announced that it   would skip this year's Mobile World Congress. Those moves all   indicated that the company was struggling to stay afloat in the   crowded Chinese market.However
column19: Xiaomi also noticed that it could follow Apple
column20: Huawei
column21: andSamsung's(NASDAQOTH: SSNLF) lead and develop first-party ARM chips.   Producing first-party chips is a pricey investment
column22: but it's a   smart long-term play because it reduces Xiaomi's dependence on   chipmakers like Qualcomm
column23: cuts production costs
column24: tightens up the   supply chain
column25: and gives it full control over the hardware and the   software -- which could better optimize its devices for Xiaomi's   MIUI custom Android OS.Xiaomi's Mi Air Purifier. Image source: Xiaomi.In addition to lowering costs and boosting performance
column26: IDC   analyst Bryan Ma also noted that Xiaomi's first-party chips could   work better with its smart home ecosystem
column27: which already includes   air purifiers
column28: bathroom scales
column29: lights
column30: and even rice cookers.   Xiaomi could also use its first-party chips to bypass a ban on   MediaTek chips in India
column31: which occurred due to a patent dispute   withEricsson.What this means for QualcommXiaomi's introduction of first-party chips isn't good news for   Qualcomm
column32: but there's no indication that Xiaomi will stop using   Qualcomm chips altogether. The Mi 5c merely represents the budget   device of its flagship Mi 5 family -- which includes the original   Mi 5
column33: the Mi 5S
column34: and the Mi 5S Plus. All three of the other Mi 5   devices use Qualcomm chips.Therefore
column35: the Surge S1 could actually hurt MediaTek -- which   supplies Xiaomi with chips for variants of its low and mid-range   devices -- instead of Qualcomm. If the Surge S1 becomes Xiaomi's   official mid-range chipset
column36: it could stop using MediaTek chips as   Qualcomm chips remain in high-end devices.Qualcomm's Snapdragon could lose its spot in mid-range devices   like the Mi Note 4
column37: but the overall impact on its chipmaking   business might be minimal. Xiaomi's global market share is   already likely below 5%
column38: based on IDC estimates
column39: and could   continue fading as Oppo
column40: Huawei
column41: and Vivo launch new devices.   SincesomeOppo
column42: Huawei
column43: and Vivo devices use Qualcomm chips
column44: higher sales   at those leading brands could easily offset any design losses at   Xiaomi.So should Qualcomm investors be worried?If Xiaomi had revealed the Surge S1 back in 2014
column45: then swapped   out all Qualcomm chips with its own silicon
column46: I think investors   would have been worried. But Xiaomi is merely aiming its new   chips at the mid-range market today
column47: and any losses from Xiaomi   could probably be offset by higher sales of other rival Android   devices.Therefore
column48: investors shouldn't consider Xiaomi's announcement   to be a major blow to Qualcomm on its own. Nonetheless
column49: the   overall trend is worrisome
column50: because it indicates that Qualcomm's   chipmaking business -- which posted flat year-over-year sales   growth last quarter -- will likely continue ceding market share   to first-party ARM chips for the foreseeable future.10 stocks we like better than QualcommWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column51: it can pay to listen. After all
column52: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column53: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column54: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Qualcomm wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Should I Buy BlackBerry Ltd (BBRY)? 3 Pros
column2: 3 Cons;3/6/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe collapse ofBlackBerry Ltd(NASDAQ:BBRY) has been stunning. But in the tech world
column4: such things do happen with regularity.makeArticleAd();Source:WEi WEi via FlickrYet BBRY stock is still far from dead. Hey
column5: if anything
column6: it's amazing that the company has been able to recover from having to deal with the onslaught of mega operators likeApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) andSamsung(OTCMKTS:SSNLF). Let's face it
column7: evenMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) couldn't put up successful fight. This was certainly a major reason why CEO Steve Ballmer stepped aside.But survival is not enough
column8: of course. So it should be no surprise that - for the past five years - BBRY stock is off about 50%.OK then
column9: what about the future? Might there be a turnaround? Well
column10: right now
column11: it may seem kind of tough to imagine. But then again
column12: this was the sentiment for say
column13: Advanced Micro Devices
column14: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMD)
column15: a year ago
column16: right?Definitely.7 Telecom Stocks That Are High-Yield Money TrapsSo to gauge the potential opportunity of BlackBerry stock
column17: let's take a look at three pros and cons:3 Pros On BBRY StockLeadership: The CEO of BBRY
column18: John Chen
column19: is a proven veteran in the tech industry. Back in 1997
column20: he took the helm ofSybase
column21: which was struggling againstOracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL). But he restructured the operations and redirected the company towards enterprise mobility and commerce. He would ultimately sell Sybase toSAP SE (ADR)(NYSE:SAP) for a hefty $5.8 billion.Yet Chen also has strongtechnical chops. Consider that he has a master's in electrical engineering from California Institute of Technology. He also got his first job as an engineer withBurroughsin 1979.Reinvention: Transitioning a company from hardware to software is no easy feat. But Chen has definitely made lots of progress with this strategy. In the latest quarter
column22: the revenues from Software & Services came to roughly55% of the total. Oh
column23: and about 80% was recurring. In all
column24: there were over 3
column25: 000 enterprise customer orders in the quarter.For Chen
column26: he has made some savvy acquisitions
column27: such as forEncription
column28: Good TechnologyandAtHoc. And another important part of the strategy has been to outsource phone development. This has meant fewer distractions as well as the opportunity to pick-up high-margin licensing revenues.Something else: Chen has done a good job in leveraging some of the long-time core technology assets. An example of this is BlackBerry Secure
column29: which is a full-blown suite of mobile enterprise apps.Long-Term Opportunities: BBRY is trying to position itself to get a share of the embedded technology market
column30: which is seeing tremendous growth from the auto sector. Note that the company has BlackBerry QNX
column31: which is a software development platform that provides top-notch security features and has been awarded the ISO 26262 ASIL D certification for cars. The system is optimized to support leading vendors likeNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA)
column32: Intel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) and AMD.As a testament to the advantages of QNX
column33: BBRY recently signed an agreement withFord Motor Company(NYSE:F) to cover more car models.3 Cons On BBRY StockBrand Issues: Back in 2007
column34: BBRY was the global leader in the fast-growing smartphone market. But the iPhone would quickly end this dominance. What's more
column35: BBRY made plenty of blunders
column36: such as in terms of awful launches.The result is that the BlackBerry brand is fairly tarnished. Granted
column37: this many not seem to matter as much since the company has moved away from the consumer market. However
column38: the brand could still be a problem with business customers as well. Why use technology from a company that seems to have a dicey future?Competition: It's intense. When it comes to the security market
column39: there are many players that have great offerings likeFortinet Inc(NASDAQ:FTNT)
column40: Palo Alto Networks Inc(NYSE:PANW) andCheck Point Software Technologies Ltd.(NASDAQ:CHKP).But of course
column41: the market for enterprise mobility solutions also has many tough operators. Just some includeVMware
column42: Inc.(NYSE:VMW)
column43: MSFT
column44: International Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM) and SAP.And finally
column45: BBRY's offerings in the messaging category also must fight against stiff competition
column46: such as withFacebook Inc's(NASDAQ:FB) WhatsApp
column47: MSFT's Skype
column48: AAPL's iMessage and even Snap Inc's(NYSE:SNAP) Snapchat.M&A: For the most part
column49: BBRY seems to be good buyout bait. The company's cost structure has been streamlined
column50: there are strong technology assets and a large customer base.Yet According toInvestorPlace.com's Richard Saintvilus: ""It has become clear that Chen - who was brought in to build BlackBerry into an M&A target - has taken this company as far as he can take it. Despite all of the boasting the company has done about its superior security capabilities
column51: BBRY stock has had no M&A suitors
column52: suggesting companies likeCisco Systems
column53: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO)
column54: Oracle Corporation and other enterprise-focused companies with which BlackBerry has often been linked
column55: don't care.""Bottom Line On BBRY StockAgain
column56: Chen has done a great job. Let's face it
column57: BBRY was a complete mess when he came on board in late 2013.Use Micron Technology
column58: Inc. (MU) Stock to Unlock Free ProfitsHe wasted little time with cost cutting and outsourcing of the phone business. More importantly
column59: he has invested in areas like security
column60: embedded systems and even the Internet of Things (IoT).However
column61: despite all this
column62: the fact remains that progress has been grudging. If anything
column63: it will probably still take some time - say a year or so - for the changes to have a real impact. In other words
column64: for those looking at BBRY stock
column65: it's probably best not to rush to buy it right now.Tom Taulli runs the InvestorPlace blogIPO Playbookand is the author of various books
column66: includingTaxes 2017: Saving A Bundle.Follow him on Twitter at@ttaulli. As of this writing
column67: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Buy in March7 ETFs Offering 20% Plus Returns Since ElectionThe postShould I Buy BlackBerry Ltd (BBRY)? 3 Pros

column1: 6 Things You Didn't Know About Fitbit Inc.;3/6/2017;"The meteoric rise and epic fall of fitness tracker makerFitbit(NYSE: FIT)  occurred in less than two years. Fitbit went   public in June 2015 at $20 per share
column2: surged to nearly $50 the   following month
column3: then plummeted to about $6 today.Investors might recall thebullet pointsin that story: demand initially surged as the public embraced   fitness tracking devices and apps
column4: but the market was quickly   saturated with cheaper devices that crushed Fitbit's top and   bottom line growth. However
column5: investors might not know these six   lesser-known facts about the company.Fitbit's Charge 2. Image source: Fitbit.makeArticleAd();1. The founders were inspired by the Nintendo     WiiFitbit CEO James Park and  CTO Eric Friedman co-founded   Fitbit in 2007
column6: after noticing howNintendo's(NASDAQOTH: NTDOY) Wii combined motion sensors with software to   gamify personal fitness.Park
column7: who felt out of shape at the time
column8: wanted to create a   fitness-tracking device priced between basic $25 pedometers and   pricier sports watches. The idea initially secured $400
column9: 000 in   funding from the founders' family and friends
column10: and raised tens of   millions more via official funding rounds
column11: but the company almost   failedseven timesbefore it filed for an IPO in 2015.2. Park and Friedman sold their previous start-up to     CNETAfter dropping out of Harvard
column12: Park worked atMorgan Stanleyfor a year. He subsequently co-founded software firm Epesi   Technologies
column13: where Friedman served as the founding engineer.   Park and Friedman subsequently co-founded Windup Labs
column14: a digital   photo sharing service which they sold to CNET in 2005.3. It recently stopped suing JawboneFitbit's first serious competitor emerged in 2011
column15: whenJawbonelaunched its UP activity tracker. In 2015
column16: Jawbone sued Fitbit   for  allegedly infringing its patents and stealing trade   secrets by hiring its employees.The legal clashes resulted in several patents being   invalidated
column17: then revalidated
column18: and Fitbit gradually gained the   upper hand against Jawbone. But last December
column19: Fitbit abruptly   dropped a key ITC lawsuit against Jawbone
column20: claiming that a   victory would be worthless because Jawbone was teetering on the   brink of bankruptcy.4. Why Applereallybooted it from its storesAs competition from Jawbone faded
column21: a bigger threat emerged   whenApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) introduced the Apple Watch in late 2014. Shortly   after the announcement
column22: Apple stopped selling Fitbit devices at    its brick-and-mortar and online stores.Image source: Apple.Many consumers probably think that Apple did that to reduce   direct competition for the Apple Watch
column23: but that was only partly   true. The main reason was actually Fitbit's refusal to sync its   devices to Apple's HealthKit platform
column24: which pulls data from   multiple devices and apps to a unified dashboard -- similar to   Google Fit. Fitbit wanted to grow its own digital ecosystem   without Apple pulling away its users
column25: but the decision greatly   reduced its exposure to Apple's customers.5. Doctors have questioned the accuracy of its     devicesA major criticism which has plagued Fitbit since its earliest   days is that it isn't a certified medical device. In late 2015
column26: oncologist Dr. Andrew Trister
column27: who  works at Sage   Bionetworks
column28: noted that many patients brought Excel spreadsheets   full of fitness tracker data
column29: but that he and other doctors had   ""no idea"" what to do with the information since they weren't   collected from certified medical devices.In a Jan. 2016 article at  iMedicalApps
column30: Dr. Satish Misra   -- a Cardiology Fellow at Johns Hopkins -- stated that he   couldn't ""help but wonder about risks when recommending specific
column31: unvalidated devices"" (like Fitbit trackers)
column32: and that it ""would   be prudent to stick to validated devices that at least have solid   evidence behind them.""These arguments cast serious doubts on the growth of Fitbit's   corporate wellness programs
column33: but Fitbit's recent partnership with   medical device giantMedtronicto monitor diabetic patients couldboost its credibilityamong medical professionals.6. It will likely buy up more wearable techAs Fitbit runs out of room to grow
column34: it's looking toward   inorganic growth to boost its top line growth again. Over the   past year
column35: it acquired mobile payments companyCoin
column36: the assets of  smartwatch makerPebble
column37: and high-end smartwatch makerVector.Vector's Luna and Meridian smartwatches. Image source:     Vector.These moves all indicate that Fitbit wants to diversify its   portfolio and create more technically advanced smartwatches.   However
column38: doing so could send it on a collision course with Apple   and Android Wear device makers in the high-end market -- which   are all battling it out to dominate a relatively small niche   market. It could also ""diworsify"" Fitbit's core business and   cause its margins to contract -- which could be devastating to   its long-term growth.10 stocks we like better than FitbitWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column39: it can pay to listen. After all
column40: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Interesting December Stock Options for AAPL;3/6/2017;"Consistently
column2: one of the more popular stocks people enter into theirstock options watchlistat Stock Options Channel is Apple Inc (Symbol: AAPL). So this week we highlight one interesting put contract
column3: and one interesting call contract
column4: from the December expiration for AAPL. The put contract our YieldBoost algorithm identified as particularly interesting
column5: is at the $115 strike
column6: which has a bid at the time of this writing of $3.05. Collecting that bid as the premium represents a 2.6% return against the $115 commitment
column7: or a 3.4% annualized rate of return (at Stock Options Channel we call this theYieldBoost).Selling a put does not give an investor access to AAPL's upside potential the way owning shares would
column8: because the put seller only ends up owning shares in the scenario where the contract is exercised. So unless Apple Inc sees its shares fall 17.1% and the contract is exercised (resulting in a cost basis of $111.95 per share before broker commissions
column9: subtracting the $3.05 from $115)
column10: the only upside to the put seller is from collecting that premium for the 3.4% annualized rate of return.makeArticleAd();Interestingly
column11: that annualized 3.4% figure actually exceeds the 1.6% annualized dividend paid by Apple Inc by 1.8%
column12: based on the current share price of $138.73. And yet
column13: if an investor was to buy the stock at the going market price in order to collect the dividend
column14: there is greater downside because the stock would have to fall 17.11% to reach the $115 strike price.Always important when discussing dividends is the fact that
column15: in general
column16: dividend amounts are not always predictable and tend to follow the ups and downs of profitability at each company. In the case of Apple Inc
column17: looking at the dividend history chart for AAPL below can help in judging whether the most recent dividend is likely to continue
column18: and in turn whether it is a reasonable expectation to expect a 1.6% annualized dividend yield.Turning to the other side of the option chain
column19: we highlight one call contract of particular interest for the December expiration
column20: for shareholders of Apple Inc (Symbol: AAPL) looking to boost their income beyond the stock's 1.6% annualized dividend yield. Selling the covered call at the $160 strike and collecting the premium based on the $3.40 bid
column21: annualizes to an additional 3.1% rate of return against the current stock price (this is what we at Stock Options Channel refer to as theYieldBoost)
column22: for a total of 4.8% annualized rate in the scenario where the stock is not called away. Any upside above $160 would be lost if the stock rises there and is called away
column23: but AAPL shares would have to advance 15.3% from current levels for that to happen
column24: meaning that in the scenario where the stock is called
column25: the shareholder has earned a 17.8% return from this trading level
column26: in addition to any dividends collected before the stock was called.The chart below shows the trailing twelve month trading history for Apple Inc
column27: highlighting in green where the $115 strike is located relative to that history
column28: and highlighting the $160 strike in red:The chart above
column29: and the stock's historical volatility
column30: can be a helpful guide in combination with fundamental analysis to judge whether selling the December put or call options highlighted in this article deliver a rate of return that represents good reward for the risks. We calculate the trailing twelve month volatility for Apple Inc (considering the last 251 trading dayAAPL historical stock pricesusing closing values
column31: as well as today's price of $138.73) to be 20%.Top YieldBoost AAPL Calls »"

column1: This 5-Stock Portfolio Crushes the S&P 500;3/6/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsMost investorsstilldon't understand dividend stocks.makeArticleAd();Why?Because they spendwaytoo much time obsessing over one figure - the dividend yield - and ignore stocks with payouts below some arbitrary number
column3: say 2%
column4: which is about what theSPDR S&P 500 ETF(SPY) pays.ConsiderVisa Inc(V)
column5: a stock that getszerolove from the dividend crowd
column6: no thanks to its 0.69% trailing-twelve-month yield
column7: which has gone nowhere for five years:Visa's Dividend DownerBut if you've ignored Visa because of its low yield
column8: you've missed out big time-this ""boring"" chart is actually a sign ofpowerful growth.Because what it's really showing us is that investors have been bidding up V's share price in lockstep with its payout hikes (because you calculate yield by dividing the annual dividend by the current share price).And that dividend growth has been obscene:The Story Yield Doesn't TellThat comes out to a 200% increase over five years! Put it all together
column9: and you can see exactly how those hikes have thrown a relentless lift under the share price
column10: propelling the stock up almost exactly as much as the dividend.An Unmistakable PatternSo if you'd bought in five years ago
column11: you'd actually be sitting on a 215% total return (including dividends) on your Visa shares today. And forget about a 0.69% yield-you'd be reaping 2.3%.Which brings me to the other reason why investors sometimes shun V: its seemingly high forward price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio of 26.7. But the truth is
column12: it's averaged almost precisely that over the last five years
column13: when the stock went on its stellar run.5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Buy in MarchThe bottom line? You need to look beyond yield and P/E when picking dividend stocks. Adding two other stats will give you a more complete picture:The payout ratio-or the percentage of earnings paid out as dividends in the last 12 months-is a measly 23%
column14: so V has plenty of dividend-growth juice left. I consider any figure below 50% a sign of a safe dividend (and higher forreal estate investment trusts (REITs)
column15: as I'll explain in a moment.Earnings growth:in its fiscal 2017 first quarter
column16: Visa's earnings per share (EPS) jumped 7.5%
column17: to $0.86 from $0.80 a year ago; the Street expected EPS tofallto $0.78. For all of fiscal 2017
column18: analysts see EPS hitting $3.32
column19: up from $2.84 in fiscal '16.4 More Dividend Growers With Big Hikes AheadTo find more stocks ready to set us up for big dividend (and share price) growth in the next five years
column20: I've scanned the market for names with the same telltale signs as Visa.As a kicker
column21: I've also screened for stocks that hiked their dividends around this timelastyear-boosting the odds of a big payout increase (and corresponding pop in the share price) as soon as this spring.Keep in mind that one (LSI) is a REIT
column22: so I've used funds from operations (FFO)-a staple when it comes to measuring REIT performance-rather than EPS for that stock in the last two columns.Here's a closer look at our four picks.The Perfect Business: Life Storage Inc (LSI)Life Storage Inc(LSI) operates 650 self-storage facilities in 29 states. This is one of the best businesses there is: once you build these facilities
column23: you really only have to keep the dust off the shelves and hand out keys.Life's payout ratio is higher than those of our other stocks
column24: at 79.4%. But that's manageable for REITs
column25: which generate steady revenue from their various properties; ratios of 85% to 90% of FFO are common in the REIT world.The trust handed shareholders a 12% dividend hike last March and has plenty of room to do so again: it's forecasting FFO of $5.50 to $5.60 a share this year-and the midpoint of that range is up 28.4% from last year. That's a lot of growth for a very reasonable forward price-to-FFO ratio of 16.0.A Steady Stream of Dividend Growth: American Water Works Company (AWK)American Water Works Company(AWK) provides water and wastewater services in 47 states and drips out double-digit dividend increases like clockwork: last April
column26: it announced a 10.3% hike
column27: following a 9.7% increase in April 2015 and a similar rise the year before that.Before I say more
column28: let me address a contradiction you've likely noticed: AWK's payout ratio. At 57%
column29: it's above my 50% ""safe line.""However
column30: management's calling for earnings of $2.98 to $3.08 this year
column31: up from $2.82 last year (which was itself a 7.6% rise from the year before). If AWK hits the midpoint of that target
column32: the payout ratio would slip back to 49.5%.7 Best Stocks to Buy for a Donald Trump Green LightAnd management's done a solid job of straddling that 50% mark:Like Visa
column33: you shouldn't worry about AWK's forward P/E of 25.6. It's in line with the five-year average and won't cap any upside from the stock's payout growth.The Breakup Play: Sealed Air Corp (SEE)Sealed Air Corp(SEE) is so boring it makes Life Storage look likeApple (AAPL).The company makes packing materials (including bubble wrap) for food
column34: cosmetics and a range of other products.SEE has the slowest dividend growth of our five stocks
column35: because all of it came with last March's hike. Prior to that
column36: the payout hadn't budged since 2010:SEE's Dividend ReignitesThe company disappointed the Street when it forecast adjusted EPS of $2.70 for fiscal 2017
column37: well below the $2.95 analysts were expecting. But that's still up from $2.66 in fiscal 2016.SEE also plans to sell or spin off of its Diversey Care cleaning-product business
column38: which would simplify the company's structure-and should spur the stock.As for the dividend
column39: SEE's steady earnings and low 25.6% payout ratio give it the flexibility to give investors another raise this month
column40: and the forward P/E of 17.3 is still below the five-year average of 17.7.Not Too Late to Buy Travelers Companies Inc (TRV)Travelers Companies Inc(TRV)is a provider of car
column41: home and business insurance that's been around since 1853.I hope you bought this one when Irecommended iton November 21. If so
column42: you're sitting on a 12.3% total return in a little over three months. If not
column43: don't worry. There's another catalyst coming: a double-digit dividend increase.Last April
column44: TRV dropped a 9.8% hike on shareholders
column45: and it's got plenty of room to do more this April
column46: with earnings arcing higher and its payout ratio at just 25.1%.Like all insurers
column47: TRV invests the premiums it collects in interest-bearing securities
column48: so it will profit as interest rates rise.The 7 Best ETFs for Retirement InvestorsThe stock is still reasonably priced at 13.7 times forward earnings. Its dividend hikes and share buybacks (it's taken 28% of its outstanding shares off the market in the last five years) also hand you some nice downside protection.Putting It All TogetherWhen we combine all five of our dividend-growth picks (including Visa) into a diversified portfolio
column49: we see that all have easily beaten the S&P 500 over the past decade on a total-return basis:Clobbering the BenchmarkI think we'll see a similar chart five years out-which makes now a terrific time to buy.6 More Stealth Buys for Double-Digit Gains This YearThese 5 stocks are ripe for buying now … but you can still get the same spectacular growth they offer without sacrificing income today.In fact
column50: I've found a way for you to get at least 7% to 15% price upside in the next 12 monthson top ofan 8.0% current yield.That's a 15% to 23% total return by next March
column51: with a big piece of it locked in-in cash!It comes in the form of the 6 bargain-priced income wonders in my new8.0% ""No-Withdrawal"" retirement portfolio. (As you've probably guessed
column52: 8.0% is the average yield these 6 rock-solid income plays throw off-but some go as high as 10.1%!)With the Dow cracking 21
column53: 000 and correction fears rampant
column54: these 6 picks areexactlywhat you need to hold now: because of their fat discounts
column55: they'll simply trade flat if the market takes a tumble…and we'll still collect their outsized 8.0% payouts!I'm ready to take you inside this collection of can't-miss investments. Simplyclick here to get my their names
column56: tickers and my complete strategy right away.The postThis 5-Stock Portfolio Crushes the S&P 500appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: UBS Says Netflix
column2: Inc. (NFLX) Stock Has 26% Upside;3/6/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsNetflix
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX) is wafting up north of 2% Monday morning thanks to an analyst upgrade that has NFLX stock reversing its recent funk.makeArticleAd();Source:Via NetflixUBS analysts upgraded Netflix shares from ""neutral"" to ""buy"" on Monday
column5: raising their price target to $175 from $136. The analysts
column6: led by Doug Mitchelson
column7: based their upgrade on better-than-expected improvements toNetflix's subscriber growth in Europe
column8: Latin America and Japan.Mitchelson expects most of the growth from the first two aforementioned countries
column9: while modest growth will come from Japan:""Netflix is certainly well-liked and not inexpensive
column10: but we do see the potential for Netflix to exceed Street subscriber growth expectations and believe that concerns regarding competition and content costs are misplaced. We expect Netflix's original content ramp to continue to drive accelerating international net additions
column11: especially as [Netflix] increases investment in local content overseas and adds more movies and nonfiction genre content.""NFLX stock had gained 12.4% for the year through last Friday
column12: mostly on the strength of itsfourth-quarter figures
column13: which saw the addition of 7.1 million subscribers and guidance of 5.2 million for Q1.8 of the Most Overrated Stocks on Wall Street Right NowAs with Q4
column14: the company expects most of its additions to come from its international markets
column15: where it grew subs by some 5.12 million in the previous quarter
column16: estimating global growth of 3.7 million in Q2.Indeed
column17: Netflix isn't pulling any punches in the international market. The company has lined up somemajor partnerships in India- includingAirtel Digital TVandVodafone Group Plc (ADR)(NASDAQ:VOD) - which allows Netflix to cultivate an audience even without access to smart televisions or other Netflix-enabled set-top boxes. VOD
column18: for its part
column19: boasts more than 200 million subscribers
column20: and will make Netflix content available in prepaid form.Then there's Korea
column21: where the California-based streaming service recently unveiled new original content in the form ofKingdom
column22: billed as a""historical zombie-thriller drama
column23: its second original Korean show.While international growth has been and continues to be the key driver of growth for Reed Hasting & Co.
column24: UBS also noted the role played byComcast Corporation(NASDAQ:CMCSA) in reducing churn for the subscription service. For instance
column25: Xfinity X1 users can integrate Netflix into their regular cable experience without having to switch devices.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is Going to Frustrate YouThe NFLX stock upgrade is not without concern
column26: however
column27: as Mitchelson cites the potential of the Republican-controlled Federal Communications Commission to alter the current net neutrality rules in a way that hurts Netflix.Netflix next reports earnings on April 19
column28: with analysts expecting per-share earnings of 37 cents on revenue of $2.64 billion.As of this writing
column29: John Kilhefner did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceGoPro Inc (GPRO) Stock Needs to Be Taken Out SoonIs Under Armour Inc (UAA) Stock a Value

column1: Is Under Armour Inc (UAA) Stock a Value
column2: Or Just Cheap?;3/6/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIt hasn't been a good 12 months forUnder Armour Inc(NYSE:UAA)
column4: to say the least. UAA stock is down by about half
column5: and the company's struggles have been well-documented.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockInvestors had insanely high expectations for Under Armour stock
column6: and analysts set their earnings targets accordingly. That had the natural and unfortunate effect of investors fleeing each time these expectations weren't met.The biggest carnage has come over the past couple quarters. In its recently reported Q4
column7: Under Armour's revenues of $1.31 billion and profits of 23 cents per share fell under estimates for $1.41 billion and 25 cents
column8: respectively. The company's Q3 was better - UAA beat analyst expectations on the top and bottom lines - the day was marred by CEO Kevin Plank telling investors growth was to be less than anticipated going forward.While growth investors have been dumping UAA stock
column9: though
column10: value investors have started sniffing around.So the question now is: Are Under Armour shares a bargain
column11: or just cheap?The Value Case For (And Against) Under Armour StockUnder Armour isn't a great value on many of the traditional metrics
column12: with shares trading at nearly 50 times earnings. The forward P/E of roughly 40 isn't anything to get excited about either
column13: with earnings expected to decline slightly in 2017. UAA isn't a bargain on the basis of price-to-book or price-to-cash flow
column14: either.5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Buy in MarchWe have to look a little further out for Under Armour stock to be a plausible value investment.UAA laid out plans back in March 2016 to grow the top line about 20% a year to reach $10 billion in sales by 2020. While that growth rate looks to be in jeopardy
column15: the company is still posting some impressive growth. Sales grew by 21% in 2016
column16: with analysts projecting revenue to increase by 11% in 2017 and 15% in 2018.Under Armour also will see a nice uptick in the top line in 2020
column17: when the sports apparel makertakes over Major League Baseball's uniform contract fromMajestic. That deal could kick in sooner if Majestic decides to opt out of its current deal before the deadline.So while UAA stock doesn't have a cheap P/E
column18: and it likely won't for a very long time
column19: if we factor in the company's strong growth potential
column20: we can at least argue that earnings will someday grow enough that you could consider Under Armour a bargain today.Let's assume the bottom line will grow by 20% a year after 2017. This is not an unreasonable assumption because Under Armour stock such a high implied revenue growth rate
column21: and as it gets bigger
column22: it's easier to wring out inefficiencies that crimp the bottom line. There will likely be a greater emphasis on profits going forward as well
column23: rather than revenue.Earnings are expected to be 42 cents per share in 2017. If UAA's bottom line grows by 20% a year
column24: the company will post earnings of 73 cents per share in 2020 and $1.81 per share in 2025. If investors then value Under Armour stock at today's P/E ratio of 49
column25: shares have an implied value of $35.77 in 2020 and $88.69 in 2025.The issue is
column26: of course
column27: will the market continue to value UAA stock at such a high premium?Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is Going to Frustrate YouIf Under Armour can post great results
column28: growth investors will flock back to it. If it struggles
column29: more impatient investors will likely leave
column30: driving down the valuation further.The Bottom Line on UAA StockIt's hard to consider Under Armour stock a value investment. The company has to post outstanding profit growth for a number of years while continuing to get a premium multiple. That's hard to do.There are still multiple ways an investment in UAA stock could still work out
column31: however.Thecompany could have a few nice quarters
column32: and investors could bump its inflated P/E ratio even higher. Under Armour also could poach a big-name athlete from a competitor likeNikeInc (NYSE:NKE) orAdidas AG (ADR)(OTCMKTS:ADDYY). Heck
column33: it could even be acquired.These are all suitable outcomes
column34: but not terribly likely. And they certainly don't make Under Armour a value investment today.As of this writing
column35: Nelson Smith did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities. You can follow him onTwitteror his own personal blog
column36: Financial Uproar.More From InvestorPlaceAdvanced Micro Devices
column37: Inc. (AMD) Stock Is Still a Buy on Any GOOD DipGoPro Inc (GPRO) Stock Needs to Be Taken Out Soon10 Best Stocks for 2017The postIs Under Armour Inc (UAA) Stock a Value
column38: Or Just Cheap?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: These Catalysts Will Give the Fintech Industry Its Next Leg Up;3/6/2017;"The financial technologies industry has been one of the few breakout markets over the last 10 years. One of the driving forces behind its growth and quick adoption has been the shift to mobile payments.PayPal Holdings Inc.(PYPL) is still the market leader
column2: which is largely due to its web platform services rather than its mobile wallet apps.In fact
column3: there is a huge debate regarding the penetration of mobile payments amongst consumers as some still question the security of their personal information. Even revolutionary mobile wallets such asApple(AAPL) Pay are yet to gain traction as previously predicted
column4: despite employing the use of fingerprint technology to execute transactions.As such

column1: Better Buy: Amazon.com
column2: Inc. vs. Microsoft;3/6/2017;"They're two of the five largest publicly traded companies in   the world. They're technology giants that are increasingly   competing against one another in multibillion-dollar growth   industries such as cloud computing and artificial intelligence.   They'reAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) andMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) .And they're vastly different companies in terms of their core   operational focuses
column3: their recent histories
column4: and their cultures.   So which is the better buy today? Let's examine Amazon.com   and Microsoft through three analytical lenses
column5: to determine which   tech stalwart represents the better stock to buy today.Financial fortitudeThough both companies are financial behemoths
column6: Microsoft beats   Amazon in this comparison of financial fortitude. Here's a quick   summary of several important liquidity and solvency measures for   each company.makeArticleAd();CompanyCash and InvestmentsDebtCash From OperationsCurrent RatioMicrosoft$122.7 billion$84.9 billion$36.7 billion2.1Amazon.com$25.9 billion$7.7 billion$16.4 billion1.0Data sources: Amazon.com and Microsoft investor relations
column7: Yahoo! Finance.Microsoft and Amazon are in fine financial shape. However
column8: even though Microsoft carries more debt than Amazon
column9: it earns a   win in this category by beating the world's largest e-commerce   provider in three categories. Plus
column10: only $600 million of   Microsoft's borrowings will come due this calendar   year.  The overwhelming majority of Microsoft's debt   comes due after 2020
column11: and then at very low interest rates. Given   the company's cash flow generation capabilities
column12: servicing that   debt should be no issue for Microsoft.It also bears noting that Microsoft
column13: likeApple
column14: keeps the bulk of its cash holdings overseas to shield it from   repatriation taxes. In its most recent 10-Q
column15: the company didn't   disclose how much cash lies offshore
column16: but its annual 10-K filing   showed that it kept approximately 96% overseas. But since it   generates plenty of operating cash flow to fund its domestic and   international operations
column17: this is really a non-issue for   investors.Winner: Microsoft.Durable competitive advantagesMicrosoft and Amazon.com each enjoy competitive advantages
column18: albeit of different sorts. Amazon's primary moats are its scale   and risk-taking culture. At this point
column19: Microsoft's competitive   insulation seems more structural and historic. Let's unpack each   of those a bit more.Amazon generates the bulk of its sales from its core   e-commerce operations
column20: accounting for 91% of revenue in   2016. As the world's largest e-commerce site by revenue
column21: Amazon has an incredible scale that allows it to consistently   offer low prices. More impressive still
column22: Amazon's unique ability   to turn its own platform into sources of revenue -- think Amazon   Web Services
column23: Fulfillment by Amazon
column24: third-party ads on Amazon.com
column25: and so on -- allows it to charge   the lowest prices possible on its e-commerce site
column26: which in turn   attracts more customers. This self-regenerating business   philosophy is best summarized in the idea of theFlywheel Effect
column27: which is at the core of Amazon's strategy and touches on its   unique culture.Image Source: Amazon.comTo create a culture that could invent profit centers to buoy   its low- or even negative-margin e-commerce sales
column28: Amazon CEO   Jeff Bezos and his team needed to create a culture where   risk-taking and unconventional thinking were the norm. Bezos   summarized risk-taking's foundational place in Amazon's culture   in the 2015 annual letter:A word about corporate cultures: For better or for worse
column29: they are enduring
column30: stable
column31: hard to change. ... One area where I     think we are especially distinctive is failure. I believe we     are the best place in the world to fail (we have plenty of     practice!)
column32: and failure and invention are inseparable     twins.Without its unique corporate mindset
column33: Amazon never would have   had the audaciousness and vision to launch many of its most   important initiatives
column34: making its culture arguably its most   important asset and source of enduring competitive advantage.Microsoft's source of competitive advantage
column35: on the other   hand
column36: can be summarized in one word: ""Office."" It remains   Microsoft's financial heart and soul and is the largest revenue   source at the company
column37: singlehandedly accounting for $23.5   billion
column38: or 27%
column39: of Microsoft's $85.3 billion in sales in fiscal   2016.CEO Satya Nadella's 2015-16 reorganization of Microsoft's   operations created three new reporting segments: productivity and   business processes (PBP)
column40: intelligent cloud
column41: and more personal   computing. PBP houses the consumer and commercial Office   operations
column42: as well as Microsoft's Dynamics CRM platform. The   entire segment generated $26.5 billion of Microsoft's total   sales
column43: so we know
column44: using the Office revenue figure
column45: that Office   drives the segment's performance.Its importance comes into greater focus when looking at   Microsoft's operating-profit breakdown. PBP -- again
column46: mostly   Office -- generated $12.4 billion
column47: or 62%
column48: of Microsoft's   $20.1 billion in fiscal 2016 operating income
column49: making it the   financial bellwether that guides Microsoft's financial   performance.Other segments
column50: particularly Intelligent Cloud
column51: have become   increasingly important pieces of Microsoft's financial footprint   as well. However
column52: Microsoft's core competitive advantage still   lies in the fact that Word
column53: Excel
column54: and PowerPoint make up the   default productivity software for the majority of world's   computer-using population
column55: and that's a source of tremendous   advantage -- and profit -- for the company.Winner: Tie.ValuationComparing the valuations of Microsoft and Amazon isn't the   simplest exercise
column56: given their different growth profiles. With   that in mind
column57: here are three of the most commonly used valuation   metrics for each company.CompanyP/EForward P/EEV/EBITDAMicrosoft30.219.716.8Amazon.com173.766.134.1EV = ENTERPRISE VALUE. EBITDA = EARNINGS BEFORE INTEREST
column58: TAXES
column59: DEPRECIATION
column60: AND AMORTIZATION. Data source: Yahoo!   Finance.Here we get a great comparison of two investing styles --   growth versus value. Neither comes out ahead here. More   conservative investors who prefer to own stocks with something of   a margin of safety will probably be drawn to Microsoft
column61: with its   more conservative valuation and 2.3% dividend yield. Of   course
column62: those same investors have always argued that Amazon is   overvalued
column63: even as the company's stock ascends ever higher.From the perspective of a long-term investor
column64: I believe   Amazon's ability to grow at above-average rates for years
column65: if not   decades to come
column66: will enable it to grow into and beyond its   current valuation. Microsoft's main issue
column67: meanwhile
column68: remains its   growth outlook.This analysis is somewhat subjective. More risk-averse   investors
column69: particularly those nearing retirement
column70: might want to   stay away from Amazon stock. However
column71: for those with the ability   to buy and hold a company for a decade or more
column72: I like Amazon   despite its aggressive valuation today.Winner: Tie.And the winner is... Amazon
column73: by a noseBoth Amazon and Microsoft offer investors attractive   investment opportunities
column74: in very different ways. As I mentioned
column75: Microsoft is probably a better option for more risk-averse   investors. It's a stable
column76: mature company and should derive the   bulk of its financial returns from growing profits and EPS
column77: rather than through rapidly expanding its top line. Amazon's   growth trajectory
column78: meanwhile
column79: is generational
column80: as it looks to   rewrite the rules of the global retail industry. In the end
column81: Amazon strikes me as the better stock for long-term investors to   buy today.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column82: it can pay to listen. After all
column83: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade

column85: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Microsoft wasn't one of   them! column1: How Apple Could Spend Its Cash Hoard;3/6/2017;"The problem ofApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) cash balance is a ""first-world problem"" in   the most literal sense of the phrase.Slightly larger than the annual economic output of Chile
column2: Apple's cash and marketable securities stockpile lies largely   overseas. As of the company's most recent earnings report
column3: $230   billion of Apple's $246 billion
column4: roughly 93%
column5: was held in   accounts controlled by Apple's international subsidiaries.Apple has caused quite a stir thanks to its controversial   decision to park its foreign profits abroad rather than pay what   it argues are onerous and unfair repatriation taxes. However
column6: the   whiff of tax policy overhaul percolating on Capitol Hill means   this dynamic could soon change. In anticipation of such a   scenario -- and in part because it's just fun to consider -- here   are three realistic ways Apple could deploy its billions in the   bank in the years ahead.makeArticleAd();Image source: Apple.Idea 1: Major acquisitionApple being a mature company
column7: you often see investors float   the idea of the Mac maker using its cash to fund a major   acquisition whenever this discussion appears. The idea isn't   without merit
column8: either
column9: although it is more complex than it might   seem on the surface for a few reasons.The first hurdle lies in correctly identifying a large company   that jives with Apple's plans for its own future. In terms of   companies that I (subjectively) think could conceivably pair well   with Apple
column10: only a handful of plausible candidates come to mind.   Among them areTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA)
column11: Netflix(NASDAQ: NFLX)
column12: andComcast(NASDAQ: CMCSA) (NASDAQ: CMCSK)
column13: three legitimately viable   options among publicly traded companies.We know Apple is interested in -- or possibly in the midst of   --developing an electric vehiclefrom the many leaks about its Project Titan
column14: though we don't know   much more than that. Tesla makes the most sense among automakers   for a few reasons. Much like Apple
column15: Tesla's mission is to   fundamentally alter the industries in which it operates. Its   headquarters in California would make working together simpler   than coordinating across the country with Detroit.In a similar vein
column16: Comcast and Netflix both cater to Apple's   long-held desire to launch its own content streaming service.   Apple's ability to secure content rights from major producers has   been the main thorn in its side. Both Netflix and Comcast control   considerable content rights
column17: though Netflix is newer to this   game. As such
column18: owning either Comcast or Netflix could supply   Apple with the negotiating leverage it needs to finally bring the   required parties to the table.Unfortunately
column19: acquiring any of these companies would require   Apple pay a significant premium to their current prices
column20: which   could be particularly troubling for already-expensive stocks like   Netflix and Tesla. There are also integration
column21: cultural
column22: and   regulatory considerations that could make such a maneuver highly   complex for Apple
column23: though the idea isn't entirely without   merit.Idea 2: More capital return?This comes from the ""if it ain't broke
column24: don't fix it"" school   of thought since Apple has thus far used its cash reserves to   finance its dividends and share buybacks. To do so
column25: Apple has   cleverly used its overseas riches as collateral to borrow against   to fund its massive capital return programto great effect.Apple has paid out a whopping $201 billion of its current $250   billion capital return program as of its most recent earnings   report
column26: including $15 billion in dividends and buybacks in its   latest quarter (Q1 FY 2017). Apple generated $27 billion in   operating cash flow last year
column27: and its capex requirements are   minimal -- $3 billion last quarter. This makes the status quo   seem sustainable
column28: although the recent rally inApple stockmakes this option increasingly less appealing.AAPL PE Ratio (TTM)data byYCharts.Stock buybacks become less effective as a company'svaluation increases
column29: so Apple's dramatic multiple expansion has made this tactic   less attractive than it was a year ago. However
column30: with Apple still   trading at a discount to the market
column31: and its cash balance rising
column32: there's certainly a fair case to be made that further buybacks   and dividends remain a worthy use of Apple's riches.Idea 3: Finance important capex?If Project Titan is indeed real
column33: I think the chances of Apple   implementing this third idea are quite strong. One of the most   important questions Apple must answer along the way is how will   it manufacture the electric vehicle?As I havenotedin the past
column34: automobile manufacturing is a capital-intensive
column35: low-margin business. This leaves Apple facing a potential   catch-22 with Project Titan
column36: driving meaningful sales growth   while also dramatically eroding its now-cushy profit margins in   the process.Perhaps the best solution to this problem is to follow a   tactic similar to Apple's contract manufacturing arrangements   with Asian assembly specialistsFoxconn. Apple designs products and maintains quality control
column37: but it   hands over the actual widget-making
column38: the low-margin part of the   process
column39: to someone else. This is how the majority of Apple's   consumer electronics get made today.The key speed bump with this idea is that there are no   large-scale automotive contract manufacturers that exist today to   provide this service to Apple
column40: and that's where Apple's mountains   of money come into play. Assuming it finds a willing and capable   partner to build Project Titan
column41: Apple could use its cash to   finance the construction of the factory infrastructure necessary   to bring Project Titan to life.In fact
column42: Apple has pursued a similar strategy in the past. It   partnered with the now-defunct GT Advanced Technologies to   finance the construction of a factory that GT Advanced planned to   use to produce commercial sapphire for Apple's fingerprint   scanners. If it does so
column43: Apple will want to take great care to   avoid past mistakes
column44: like bankrupting GT Advanced under the   onerous terms of its financing deal. Regardless
column45: this idea is   sound as long as Apple's auto ambitions are indeed as real as   portrayed in the media.Cash is kingOf course
column46: this only scratches the surface in terms of   possible uses of Apple's cash. U.S. tax policy overhaul will also   have a significant influence on Apple's options
column47: so interested   investors will want to stay in tune with the national discussion   around it in the coming months. At the end of the day
column48: though
column49: Apple's billions in the bank provide it with unparalleled   flexibility to pursue any number of possible actions
column50: and that's   something in which Apple investors can and should find great   comfort.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column51: it can pay to listen. After all
column52: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade

column17: though

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Apple Music Just Can’t Catch Spotify;3/4/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) Apple Music is a success by all counts
column3: but one target still remains elusive.makeArticleAd();Despite impressive subscriber gains since its 2015 launch
column4: AAPL's streaming music service has been unable to catch primary rivalSpotify. And in the latest sign that the competition is far from over
column5: Spotify just announced it has hit the 50 million paid subscriber mark.Spotify Hits 50 Million Paid SubscribersApple Music and Spotify are considered to be the two big players in the streaming music war.Spotify launched in 2008
column6: giving it a long lead in which to build up steam over Apple Music
column7: which didn't go live until 2015. Despite that head start - and predictions that after its initial free three-month trial expired
column8: Apple's streaming music service would see a big drop off of subscribers - Apple Music quickly began to gain obliterate Spotify's numbers.Apple Music hit 10 million paid subscribers after just six months
column9: a milestone that took Spotify nearly six years to reach. Since then
column10: Apple Music has continued to add paid subscribers at a rapid pace: 11 million by last February
column11: 13 million in April
column12: 17 million in September and 20 million in December.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Posts Best Q4 Apple Watch Sales EverHowever
column13: despite the rapidly increasing popularity of Apple's streaming music service
column14: Spotify stubbornly refuses to go away. In fact
column15: rather than stalling or beginning to slip as many expected
column16: Spotify's numbers have also been growing strongly.Spotify had roughly 20 million paid subscribers at the time Apple Music launched. This week
column17: the company announced it hashit 50 million.In other words
column18: Spotify is not going anywhere any time soon.A Little More CompetitionWhile the big streaming music battle has been between Apple Music and Spotify
column19: many other competitors are duking it out for the dollars of music fans. And rather than scare off new entrants
column20: the success of Apple Music led to a big new competitor taking a shot at the business.Amazon.com
column21: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)launched Amazon Music Unlimited last fall
column22: matching Apple Music's basic subscription rates. But Amazon added a twist by discounting the service for Amazon Prime members and slashing it it less than half the regular $9.99 monthly fee for owners of its Amazon Echo smart speaker.Will Apple Music Ever Catch Spotify? (And Does It Need to?)The success of Apple Music isn't just about bragging rights.The streaming music service is part of Apple's Services division. That division is increasingly important to the bottom line. It provides recurring revenue
column23: which helps to protect against shocks when hardware sales hit rough patches. In AAPL's most recent quarter
column24: Services posted thestrongest year-over-year growth of any of Apple's divisions.2016 revenue numbers for Spotify aren't yet available
column25: but the music streaming service has consistently lost money
column26: including $176.9 million in 2014 and $188.7 million. Thesituation looked grim a year ago
column27: with Apple Music growing rapidly. However
column28: big increases in paid subscriber drove a revenue gain of80% to $2.12 billion. That marked a turning point in the outlook for Spotify's survival.With profitability a distinct possibility in 2017
column29: Spotify could be in acquisition territory.Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL) andFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) have both been floated aspotential buyers. An initial public offering could also be in its future.Apple Inc. (AAPL) iPhone 8 Lightning Port Drama ContinuesRegardless
column30: Apple Music seems unlikely to knock Spotify off the top of the streaming music charts
column31: at least not in the near future.That doesn't mean Apple Music isn't a success. It quickly vaulted from zero to a contender for top spot in mere months and has continued to grow. As shown by the number of streaming music services that continue to attract paid subscribers
column32: there is still plenty of room for multiple big players to make money.Apple Music will continue to drive revenue into AAPL's Services division
column33: even if that coveted No. 1 spot remains elusive.As of this writing
column34: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceFriday Apple Rumors: iPhone Delay

column1: What Will Warren Buffett Buy Next With His $86 Billion War Chest?;3/4/2017;"According toBerkshire Hathaway's(NYSE: BRK-A) (NYSE: BRK-B) latest annual report
column2: Warren Buffett   and his team are sitting on an $86 billion stockpile of cash.   While the Oracle of Omaha likes to keep at least $20 billion in   cash or equivalents on the sidelines at all times
column3: this still   leaves a lot of money just waiting to be put to work. We have no   way of knowing exactly what Berkshire will buy next
column4: but we do   know what the company is looking for.Berkshire's cash hoard is different than most othersBerkshire Hathaway is not the only company with a massive cash   hoard
column5: and it is certainly not the biggest. The tech sector in   particular has several players with big stockpiles of cash
column6: such   asApple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column7: Microsoft
column8: Alphabet
column9: Cisco
column10: andOracle.Image Source: The Motley Fool.makeArticleAd();However
column11: these companies have most their cash stashed   overseas
column12: and can't bring it back without facing a large tax   bill. In fact
column13: Moody's estimates that about 87% of these five   tech giants' cash is stashed overseas.Berkshire Hathaway
column14: on the other hand
column15: doesn't have this   problem to worry about. 95% of Berkshire's $86 billion stockpile   of cash is held by U.S. entities. And
column16: the remaining 5% would   trigger big repatriation taxes
column17: as most of it was earned in   companies that impose big corporate taxes
column18: which would be used to   offset U.S. taxes upon repatriation of the cash.In a nutshell
column19: not only does Berkshire have $86 billion in   cash
column20: but this is cash that can actually be used without major   tax consequences.How Berkshire Hathaway chooses its acquisition targetsThe exact process Warren Buffett and his team use to evaluate   potential acquisition targets is a closely guarded secret.   However
column21: Berkshire Hathaway does actively encourage prospective   acquisitions to contact the company
column22: so long as the business   meets six criteria:The business must be large. Berkshire defines this as     having at least $75 million of pre-tax earnings per year. The     company will make an exception if it can fit into one of its     existing business units.The company must be able to demonstrate that it is     consistently profitable. Buffett and his team have no interest     in investing in unprofitable companies or companies that may or     may not become profitable.The business must have little or no debt and still produce     good returns on equity.There must already be management in place. I'd add to this     and say that there must begood management in place. I can't     emphasize enough the value Buffett places on good     managers.The business must be simple. Buffett doesn't invest in tech     companies or biotechs or anything else that he doesn't     understand.There must be an offering price on the table
column23: even if it's     just preliminary.Berkshire's target acquisition range is $5 to $20 billion.   This is not a set-in-stone rule
column24: as the company has certainly   made exceptions in the past. However
column25: the larger the company the   greater Berkshire's interest will be.It would be foolish to speculate as to which exact company   Buffett and his team may buy next. However
column26: it is fair to say   that was such a large stockpile of cash
column27: Brookshire will be on   the prowl for an acquisition that meets its criteria.Or
column28: will Buffett and company buy more stocks instead?In addition to its fully owned businesses
column29: Berkshire Hathaway   has a stock portfolio consists of about 45 different companies as   of this writing. The stocks that Warren Buffett is buying and   selling are closely followed by millions of investors.We already know for a fact that some of Berkshire's cash hoard   is being spent on common stocks in 2017. In an interview with   CNBC
column30: Buffett revealed that since the start of the year
column31: Berkshire has more than doubled its stake in Apple
column32: and now owns   about 2.5% of the tech giant.Just like with Berkshire's acquisitions of entire companies
column33: it would be silly to speculate on what stocks Buffett and his   team will buy next
column34: but the reasons behind the Apple investment   are a good example of what he looks for.Buffett said that he decided to boost Berkshire's Apple stake   because of the company's consumer-retaining power. After all
column35: people who use iPhones typically upgrade to a newer model of the   same product -- over and over. Buffett also praised CEO Tim   Cook's capital deployment strategies. In addition
column36: Apple trades   for a relatively low valuation when compared with the rest of the   market
column37: and looks cheaper still if you account for the company's   massive stockpile of cash.What it means to youAs I've mentioned before
column38: it would be silly to try to figure   out what companies are stocks Berkshire Hathaway will buy next.   However
column39: you can use the principles and rules discussed here to   find Buffett-like stocks for your own portfolio.10 stocks we like better than Berkshire     HathawayWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column41: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Believe It or Not
column2: Apple Came in Dead Last in Customer Loyalty in This $24 Billion Market;3/3/2017;"Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) knows what it's doing. The company is a market   leader in many fields
column3: and would often rather abandon a product   category rather than struggle on as a minor competitor to bigger   and better rivals.But even mighty Apple does the occasional swing-and-a-miss   routine. And some of Cupertino's whiffs come in vibrant   billion-dollar markets.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Apple ranks dead last in the $24 billion file-hosting   marketBrand Keysis a branding consultancy firm with more than three decades of   expertise-building history under its belt. The firm is best known   for its Customer Loyalty Engagement Index (CLEI) rankings
column4: where   a proprietary data-collection process builds customer-loyalty   ratings in more than 80 specific product categories.Apple
column5: of course
column6: dominates several of the latest Brand Keysratings. The iPhone shows up all comers in the smartphone category
column7: no   tablet can beat the iPad's consumer loyalty
column8: and MacBooks walks   away with the top rating among laptop brands. In something of an   upset
column9: Apple Musiceven takes home the online music segment.And then there's the file-storage category. There
column10: Apple   doesn't just miss the top spot
column11: but falls all the way to the   bottom of 13 ranked services.How bad is that result for Apple?To be clear
column12: Brand Keys claims that its measurements translate   directly into future sales prospects and revenues. According to   independent metrics fromMarkets and Markets
column13: cloud storage is a $24 billion market today -- and expected to   reach annual sales of $75 billion in just five years.In other words
column14: it looks like Apple is leaving a lot of cash   on the table. The iCloud file-storage service is not pulling its   weight
column15: or moving the needle for Apple. Instead
column16: consumers with a   need for off-site file-storage tools prefer free services like   Brand Keys' category winner
column17: Sabrecat -- or a plethora of   better-known options such as runner-up Dropbox
column18: or third-place   finisherGoogle(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Drive.Apple is not only missing a significant market opportunity
column19: but leaving a lot of that cash for Google parent Alphabet to grab   instead.Apple CEO Tim Cook. Image source: Apple.Why is Apple missing the boat?Apple's iCloud is
column20: in many ways
column21: very similar to Google Drive   and Dropbox. All three services allow users to store nearly any   type of file in a centrally managed cloud server
column22: accessible from   any networked computer. They all come with small storage limits   for a free account
column23: all offer a terabyte of storage for $9.99 per   month
column24: and come with various tools for managing your stored   files. But Apple does a few things differently.First and foremost
