column1: 3 Closed-End Funds With Sky-High Yields of 10% or More;3/3/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsClosed-end funds have become a kind of alternative vehicle to gobble up high yields
column3: ever since the Federal Reserve wiped out the bond market as a source for fixed income.makeArticleAd();Source:401(K) 2012 via FlickrCEFsoperate like a cross between a stock and mutual fund. CEFs raise equity via an IPO. The proceeds are then used to execute the desired investment strategy for the fund
column4: and a limited and finite number of shares are issued. Thus
column5: it trades like a stock but operates more like a mutual fund or exchange-traded fund
column6: since they hold a basket of securities.The trick withCEFsis finding the ones that are well-managed
column7: that offer commensurate reward to whatever risks they are taking.The 7 Best ETFs for Market-Beating ReturnsSo here are three different types of CEFs that are a bit riskier than I personally like
column8: but offer acceptable 10%-plus yields for those who don't mind that extra risk.Closed-End Funds to Buy: Eaton Vance Risk-Managed Diversified Equity Inc. (ETJ)Distribution Rate:11%Eaton Vance Risk-Mngd Dvrsfd Eqty Inc Fd(NYSE:ETJ) is pretty much what it is described as
column9: although its title doesn't mention its core strategy
column10: which is selling covered calls. I like ETJ because it takes a very similar approach that my forthcoming stock advisory newsletter
column11: The Liberty Portfolio
column12: takes. It buys certain high-quality stocks and then sells covered calls against them.ETJ buys stocks likeApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL)
column13: Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) andVisa
column14: Inc.(NYSE:V) and sells covered calls against them. That means they sell contracts for another party to buy that stock from the fund at a given price on or before a given day. Obviously
column15: if the stock is below that price
column16: the fund keeps the stock and can sell more calls. Most importantly
column17: it holds stocks that are quality companies
column18: so if the market tanks and they get stuck with those stocks … well
column19: there are worse things.The distribution rate is 11% and it currently trades at more than a 9% discount to net asset value.Closed-End Funds to Buy: Pimco High Income Fund (PHK)Distribution Rate:11%Pimco High Income Fund(NYSE:PHK) is one of the best CEFs that I have found
column20: in regards to diversification. PHK has 343 holdings across many different kinds of bonds. While half are corporate bonds
column21: 27% are asset-backed
column22: 12.5% are municipals and 5% are government bonds
column23: and they are spread across just about every kind of sector that exists. Maturities are also diversified
column24: with a healthy 38% maturing in 1-4 years
column25: 25% in 5-9 years
column26: 16% in 10-20 years
column27: and the rest are longer-term.The average coupon is 7.95%
column28: but manages to distribute about 10.9% annually
column29: thanks to capital gains. Since inception
column30: its annualized total returns are 13.8%
column31: almost twice that of the 7.4% category benchmark. That's also a major reason why the PHK trades at a 30% premium to its NAV.7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Highs in 2017Normally
column32: I wouldn't go near something trading with that premium
column33: except that it's about theaverageit has traded at since the financial crisis.Closed-End Funds to Buy: Franklin Limited Duration Income (FTF)Distribution Rate:10.8%Franklin Limited Duration Income Trust of Beneficial Interest(NYSE:FTF) is similar in structure to PHK
column34: but has a few important differences from other closed-end funds that invest in corporate debt. While 43% of the FTF portfolio consists of corporate bonds that offer generous yields
column35: 40% are invested in senior loans.What are senior loans? They are loans that are often secured by a company's assets. They are not considered investment grade and privately issued by various banks and institutional investors in a secondary market. They tend to be illiquid.The difference between senior loans and bonds is that the latter's interest rates are usually fixed whereas senior loan rates tend to float. Another big difference: bond prices will move inversely with interest rates
column36: but senior loan prices do not change when interest rates change. Thus
column37: they act as a hedge against rising short-term rates.FTF has a 10.8% distribution yield.Lawrence Meyers is the CEO of PDL Capital
column38: and manager of the forthcomingLiberty Portfolio stock newsletter. As of this writing
column39: has no position in any stock mentioned. He has 22 years' experience in the stock market
column40: and has written more than 1
column41: 600 articles on investing. Lawrence Meyers can be reached atTheLibertyPortfolio@gmail.com.The post3 Closed-End Funds With Sky-High Yields of 10% or Moreappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Report: Taiwan Semiconductor Mfg. Co. Ltd. and Samsung Facing 10-Nano Yield Issues;3/3/2017;"Contract chip manufacturersTaiwan Semiconductor Mfg. Co. Ltd.(NYSE: TSM) andSamsung(NASDAQOTH: SSNLF) both recently began mass production of chips   using their respective 10-nanometer chip manufacturing   technologies.Both companies' 10-nanometer technologies allow chipmakers to   build more densely packed (meaning more features) and   higher-performing products
column2: two things that are generally good in   the world of chips.Image source: Intel.makeArticleAd();However
column3: according to a recentreportfrom DigiTimes
column4: both TSMC and Samsung are facing manufacturing   yield issues with their respective 10-nanometer technologies.   Let's go over the implications of those yield challenges.Why are low manufacturing yields bad?Manufacturing yield refers to the percentage of manufactured   chips that both work and meet the performance and power   specifications mandated by the design. It generally costs a fixed   amount of money to manufacture a wafer of chips
column5: so the higher   the yield rate
column6: the greater the number of chips are produced for   a given cost
column7: which means lower effective per-chip cost.Conversely
column8: low yield rates mean higher costs. Such costs can   either be passed on to the customer
column9: the chip manufacturing   company itself could eat the costs
column10: or the responsibility could   be shared.Additionally
column11: chipmakers put in a certain amount of   manufacturing capacity in anticipation of customer demand. If   manufacturing yield rates are too far below plan
column12: then a customer   using the low-yielding technology may not be able to get ahold of   sufficient supply of products.So
column13: low manufacturing yields are generally bad for   business.Specific impacts on TSMC's and Samsung's     customersThe lead customer for TSMC's 10-nanometer technology appears   to be MediaTek
column14: which is using this technology to manufacture its   Helio X30 line of premium smartphone chips. In a statement to   Nikkei Asian Review
column15: a MediaTek executivesaidthat the X30 was ""delayed because the yield rate of 10   [nanometer] process technology [from TSMC] has not yet reached a   satisfactory level... and we are a bit stuck on that.""A silver lining here is that MediaTek doesn't expect   significant adoption of the X30 in premium smartphones (saying   that it expects the X30 to be used in ""less than 10 smartphone   models"")
column16: so these yield challenges are unlikely to significantly   disrupt MediaTek's business or the businesses of its   customers.For Samsung and its lead customer
column17: mobile chipmakerQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM)
column18: the struggle is more significant. The Samsung   Galaxy S8-series devices that are set to be formally announced   later this month are expected to Samsung's Exynos 8895 for some   variants and Qualcomm's Snapdragon 835 in other   variants. Both chips are believed to be manufactured by   Samsung using its 10-nanometer LPE technology. DigiTimes   says that Samsung delayed the rollout of the Galaxy S8-series   devices due ""unsatisfactory yield rates.""How about the iPhone?Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) is expected to tap TSMC to manufacture the   former's upcoming A11 applications processor on the latter's   10-nanometer technology. The bad news is that the yield   challenges described by DigiTimes could impact Apple's ability to   meet demand for its next-generation iPhones.The good news is that Apple's next iPhone models aren't   expected to launch until the fall
column19: which gives both Apple and   TSMC additional time to work out the kinks on the 10-nanometer   technology.Furthermore
column20: some of the yield issues that MediaTek may be   seeing could be related to its underlying chip design rather than   only due to TSMC's technology. In that case

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) iPhone 8 Lightning Port Drama Continues;3/3/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThere has been a flurry of excitement this week overApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) upcoming iPhone 8. The fuss started a few days ago whenThe Wall Street Journalpublished an update on the new iPhone and stated that the Lightning port would be dropped in favor of USB-C. Given the fuss over AAPL ditching the headphone jack in the iPhone 7
column3: the spectre of the company abandoning another legacy port evoked strong reaction.makeArticleAd();Source: Brad MoonNow
column4: a new report from a well-known Apple analyst claims all 2017 iPhones - including the 10th-anniversary iPhone 8 - will stick with Lightning ports
column5: butwilladopt USB-C's fast-charging technology.Here's the latest on the Lightning port controversy.New Theory: AAPL Keeps the Lightning PortMacRumorspublished KGI Securities analystMing-Chi Kuo's take on the controversy. He is certain all 2017 iPhones
column6: including the iPhone 8
column7: will keep their Lightning port. However
column8: he predicts that AAPL is investigating the adoption of the USB-C Power Delivery standard in that Lightning port. Doing so would retain compatibility with Lightning accessories
column9: but with the advantage of much faster wired charging for the new iPhones.5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Sell in MarchKuo also notes several reasons why AAPL would not choose to implement USB-C instead of staying with its proprietary Lightning port
column10: beyond the potential consumer backlash. The company would be giving up revenue from its MFi program that certifies Lightning accessories. And USB-C ports are physically larger than Lightning - given AAPL's obsession with making iPhones thinner
column11: switching to a larger port seems unlikely.Why Has USB-C Been Such a Flashpoint Issue?The meresuggestionthat AAPL would ditch the Lightning port in favor of USB-C has generated a huge number of articles and editorials and filled Apple forums. Why the fanfare over a simple charging port?There are actually two issues at play here.The first is a sensitivity to Apple eliminating legacy ports. After the company got rid of the decades-old standard 3.5mm jack on the iPhone 7
column12: there were accusations AAPL had done so arbitrarily - maybe to sell more Beats wireless headphones. Even rivalSamsung Electronic(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) hopped on the bandwagon
column13: mocking AAPL's decisionwhen it launched the Galaxy Note 7 - complete with headphone jack.After the Galaxy Note 7's exploding batteries
column14: Samsung may avoid such public taunting in the future. Karma….In the fall
column15: Apple released a new MacBook Pro that had all legacy connectivity ports replaced with USB-C. This infuriated many long-time Mac users because it meant having to buy adapters and dongles for all their current accessories and peripherals. A switch from Lightning to USB-C would be seen by many as another Apple move done more or less arbitrarily
column16: without consideration for the impact it may have on customers.On the other side of the equation
column17: there are also many Apple fans who would love to see the company ditch the proprietary Lightning port for USB-C
column18: which is becoming an industry standard.Snap Inc. (SNAP): Snapchat IPO ALMOST Beats the OddsCount MacBook Pro (and MacBook) owners in that group - they have to purchase a Lightning to USB-C cable if they want to connect an iPhone to their laptop. These people were excited to see theWall Street Journal'spredictionthat AAPL would make the big move.So Where Are We Now on the iPhone 8 Lightning Port?As usual
column19: no one knows for certain what AAPL's plans are. I tend to side with the analysts who are suggesting that Apple isn't about to court controversy with such a critical iPhone release
column20: and will keep the Lightning port but maybe pack in a USB-C cable or adapter this time around.The one thing youcanbet on is that AAPL is watching the conversation and evaluating reaction - if not for the iPhone 8
column21: then for a little further down the line.As of this writing
column22: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Highs in 20177 Stocks to Buy That Are ALMOST in Buffett Buying RangeThe postApple Inc. (AAPL) iPhone 8 Lightning Port Drama Continuesappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Nokia Corp (ADR) (NOK) Hopes Old Phone Revival Can Help NOK Stock;3/3/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe high-tech world is still buzzing afterNokia Corp (ADR)(NYSE:NOK) andBlackBerry Ltd(NASDAQ:BBRY) showed off new handsets at last weekend's Mobile World Conference. However
column3: I'm not sure nostalgia for candy bar phones and keyboard PDAs draws the right kind of attention to either company.makeArticleAd();Source:Open Grid Scheduler / Grid Engine via Flickr (Modified)For one
column4: NOK never really left the ""dumb"" end of the phone market behind
column5: so the company's grand ""return"" with a new version of its near-indestructible 3310 handset - popular in 2001 at a price around $120 - is only a shock to people who stopped paying attention
column6: which they did for a reason.Granted
column7: the feature phones that NOK recently pulled back out ofMicrosoft Corporation's(NASDAQ:MSFT) orbit accounted for 9% of the category last year
column8: but that No. 2 share behindSamsung Electronic(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) only added up to 35 million handsets
column9: or at best 2% of the global phone market.A Lesson in Scale for NOK StockSure
column10: it's remotely possible that the return of the 3310 at $50 will somehow dramatically reverse 16 years of technology progress
column11: and be enough to convince a new generation of back-to-basics consumers to trade in their smartphones
column12: I find it unlikely.7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Highs in 2017I just don't see that happening here in numbers that even double NOK's market share
column13: and even if it does
column14: an extra 35 million $50 handsets sold close to cost really isn't going to move the needle for NOK stock. Even if the company manages to book half the retail price on each phone as revenue
column15: it's going to take 120 million of them to add 10% to the top line.That's the real lesson of scale here. NOK never went away; it's still a big company
column16: built on the chassis of the old Alcatel and Lucent networking businesses. Now that it has its phones back from MSFT
column17: management needs to deploy them to embrace the future and expand on the role the company wants to play in the Internet of Things (IoT).To me
column18: that means developing phones that don't compete withApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) or Samsung for consumer pocket space
column19: but ones that instead let smart devices communicate with each other. Consider that
column20: in a world of billions of $50 machine-to-machine data relays
column21: the market becomes very interesting for NOK stock investors.It's a similar story for BBRY
column22: which was evolving nicely into an IoT proposition
column23: until now. We may feel nostalgic for the days of a ubiquitous business BlackBerry
column24: but that era was over more than a decade ago. We've since learned to type on virtual keyboards.7 Stocks to Buy That Are ALMOST in Buffett Buying RangeThe question I have about the next generation of BBRY devices revolves around what great things they can do to win consumers away from the iPhones and Androids that already dominate the market. They need to trigger a revolution and not just recapitulate the past.The bottom line is
column25: as interesting as it was to get a blast from the past from these two companies
column26: I just don't see this strategy being a boon for either stock right now.Hilary Kramer is the editor ofGameChangers

Comparing the most recent share price to the 200 day moving average can also be a useful technical analysis technique --learn more about the 200 day moving average ».makeArticleAd();Exchange traded funds (ETFs) trade just like stocks
column17: but instead of ''shares'' investors are actually buying and selling ''units''. These ''units'' can be traded back and forth just like stocks
column18: but can also be created or destroyed to accommodate investor demand. Each week we monitor the week-over-week change in shares outstanding data
column19: to keep a lookout for those ETFs experiencing notable inflows (many new units created) or outflows (many old units destroyed). Creation of new units will mean the underlying holdings of the ETF need to be purchased
column20: while destruction of units involves selling underlying holdings
column21: so large flows can also impact the individual components held within ETFs.Click here to find out which 9 other ETFs had   notable inflows »"

column1: Will Procter & Gamble (PG) Stock Get Its Activist Spark?;3/3/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThink you know what to expect to see next fromProcter & Gamble Co(NYSE:PG) now that activist investor Nelson Peltz has his hands on roughly $3.5 billion worth of PG stock?makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)If you're expecting some pressure on P&G's management to split the company up as a way of unlocking shareholder value (which is the consensus) you're probably right.'That being said
column3: such a development isn't a foregone conclusion. Peltz
column4: the chief of investment management outfit Trian Partners
column5: has just as much of a history of focusing on solving execution problems - and even spurring acquisitions - as he does splitting up companies.The question is
column6: what does Procter & Gamble need most?PG Stock Is an Easy Activist TargetThe purchase washinted at in December
column7: though unnamed at the time. In the meantime it's been confirmed Peltz was talking about what would eventually be 6.4 million shares of PG stock.The general consensus is that Peltz intends to start improving the company's profitability from the inside
column8: cutting costs and overhauling operations. More than just a few observers
column9: however
column10: suspect that is only a precursor to breaking the company up into more focused parts.And it's not as if the company couldn't use the help.10 Dangerous Dividend Stocks to Dump NowThe consumer products name behind brands such as Pampers diapers
column11: Ivory soap and Downy detergent was once a competitor nobody wanted to face
column12: and an investment everybody wanted to own. Time
column13: size
column14: and complexity have taken a toll on P&G.Revenue has been dwindling for a couple of years now
column15: and while income has held steady
column16: investors had good reason to expect growth.To its credit
column17: Procter & Gamble has been streamlining itself
column18: recently selling a wide swath of its beauty brands toCoty Inc(NYSE:COTY) -$11.3 billion worth of beauty brands
column19: to be precise. After alittle more than a year on the job though
column20: CEO David Taylor was expected by shareholders to show actual proof of life
column21: rather than just shrinking the company towards success. Its brand names - and the Procter & Gamble name itself - are too valuable to let languish.Enter Nelson PeltzTo figure out how the activist investor intends to handle a new project
column22: one only has to look at his previous activist efforts. Unfortunately
column23: Peltz has widely varied repertoire.Take Peltz's interest in Heinz
column24: for instance. Back in 2006 -well before it merged with Kraftto becomeKraft Heinz Co(NASDAQ:KHC) - Peltz took an interest and a controlling position in the venerable pickle and ketchup manufacturer
column25: partly to encourage the spinoff of weaker
column26: distracting divisions
column27: but mostly tocut costs the company's management seemed unwilling or unable to make. It was that newly created value that got Warren Buffett'sBerkshire Hathaway Inc.(NYSE:BRK.A
column28: NYSE:BRK.B) and 3G Capitalinterested in buying Heinz in 2013
column29: ultimately setting up the pairing with Kraft.However
column30: Peltz's $2.5 billion stake inGeneral Electric Company(NYSE:GE)
column31: taken in 2015
column32: wasalmost an entirely passive one. CEO Jeff Immelt was already streamlining the company and Peltz felt the market was undervaluing where GE was going. Peltz was just along for the ride
column33: mostly leaving the company alone.Still
column34: Trian Capital's reputation as an activist stakeholder is well-deserved
column35: as Peltz has in the past prioritized divestitures and acquisitions that management teams haven't wanted.Case in point: In 2013
column36: Peltz was pushingPepsiCo
column37: Inc.(NYSE:PEP) to acquire snack foods makerMondelez International Inc(NASDAQ:MDLZ)
column38: an outcome that surprisingly didn't materialize
column39: considering he was amajor shareholder in both companies. Once Peltz gave up on the idea of the marriage
column40: he began to push for the spinoff of PepsiCo's snack food division. It would have been a very close ""next best thing"" to a union of Mondelez and PepsiCo.Cost cuts were also always part of the discussions between Peltz and PepsiCo
column41: but never really the priority.Bottom Line for PG StockThe question is: which of those three previous situations does Procter & Gamble most resemble now? Is the consumer staples giant too big and too disparate for its own good and would be better off splitting itself up
column42: or is the organization just bloated
column43: with too many overlapping parts
column44: each incurring unnecessary expenses?Most long-term owners of PG stock likely see the organization's challenges aren't rooted in too much diversity
column45: but rather
column46: in years of sloppy integration of a variety of business lines. Indeed
column47: with the bulk of its brands all readily available in grocery stores
column48: the opportunities for synergies as well as cross-marketing are terrific; marketing is largely the same sort of shtick for each of its product lines.Costco Wholesale Corporation (COST) Stock: The Danger Is GrowingAt the same time
column49: there's little assurance that any divestiture would command an attractive price in the open market even if P&G and Peltz did want to spin off some units.That's arguably okay with Peltz
column50: who ismore of an operational activistthan one who simply ""unlocks value"" by breaking companies apart. In other words
column51: he's playing the long game here and that's a good thing for loyal shareholders. Current and prospective owners of PG stock have been waiting too long for this ride to get underway.Of course
column52: if that effort doesn't get traction
column53: Peltz isn't afraid to press for spinoffs
column54: either.As of this writing
column55: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceTrade Bank of America Corp (BAC) Stock for No-Cost ProfitsQualcomm

column1: Qualcomm
column2: Inc. (QCOM) Stock Has Problems Beyond Apple Inc. (AAPL);3/3/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe narrative surroundingQualcomm
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM) stock changed in late January
column5: whenApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) sued the chip maker for $1 billion. Qualcomm's high-margin fabless model had been a big part of the bull case for QCOM stock. Suddenly
column6: that royalty-based model looked more like that of a ""patent troll"" than a desirable licensing stream. QCOM stock fell 13% on the news
column7: and has regained only a portion of those losses.makeArticleAd();Source:Karlis Dambrans via FlickrWhile the AAPL lawsuit has been the headline news
column8: there are other concerns for Qualcomm shareholders. Competition
column9: regulatory pressure and earnings all present risks at the moment. It's not as if QCOM stock is pricing in incredible growth
column10: with the stock trading at about 12x 2017 analyst consensus EPS. But Qualcomm may not be pricing in all those risks
column11: either.AAPL and QCOM StockWhat's notable about the change in sentiment toward QCOM stock is that the recent concerns
column12: on their own
column13: shouldn't bethatbig a deal. The Apple lawsuit is no exception. AAPL is asking for $1 billion in damages
column14: which isn't a lot of money for Qualcomm. QCOM stock has a market cap of $82 billion; a $1 billion payment would represent about 1.2% of its value
column15: or about less than 70 cents per share.Meanwhile
column16: Qualcomm ended its first quarter (ending Dec. 25) with over $10 billion in cash and marketable securities on its balance sheet. QCOM quite literally could simply write a check for the $1 billion in damages - even if it loses or settles with Apple.But the concern is that the Apple lawsuit is just the tip of the iceberg
column17: so to speak. Apple's contention is that Qualcomm's pricing itself is unfair. QCOM - per Apple's interpretation - charges royalties based on the value of the entire device
column18: not just the technology being licensed.On AAPL's Q1 earnings call
column19: CEO Tim Cook said the strategy was ""somewhat like buying a sofa
column20: and you charge somebody a different price depending upon the price of the house that it goes into.""5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Sell in MarchQualcomm naturally has defended its strategy
column21: and it's too early to tell on whose side U.S. courts will fall. But the questions raised by the Apple lawsuit have implications that go beyond a single court case.QCOM Stock and Licensing RevenueThe core problem for QCOM stock is that Apple isn't alone in questioning its model. Qualcomm has been hit with an $800 million-plus fine in South Korea for alleged antitrust violations under a similar theory to that being pushed by AAPL. (That fine is under appeal.) Qualcomm already paid nearly a billion dollars to settle an investigation in China. And a week before the Apple lawsuit
column22: the U.S. FTC announced its own investigation.The issue isn't just fines and lawsuits
column23: or a billion dollars here and another billion there. The licensing model is the foundation of Qualcomm's business. Per the company's 10-K
column24: the licensing segment generated $6.5 billion in pre-tax earnings. The rest of the company created $2.2 billion in profit - barely one-third of the licensing business's total.If QCOM's royalty rate has to come down
column25: or the base on which those royalties is charged moves from the value of the product to the value of the part
column26: Qualcomm's profit margins and revenue can come down substantially. Potential changes in the licensing model are a legitimate risk to QCOM stock. And it's not the only risk out there.QCOM Stock Has Other Concerns
column27: TooEven if the licensing model stays largely intact
column28: Qualcomm's sales and earnings have other sources of pressure. Overall market growth for smartphones
column29: in particular
column30: is stalling out. That's one reason why AAPL stock - even at all-time highs - still has a relatively modest earnings multiple.In response
column31: Qualcomm is acquiringNXP Semiconductors NV(NASDAQ:NXPI)
column32: which will move the company into automotive and IoT (Internet of Things). But that acquisition also moves Qualcomm into a more traditional manufacturing model - and won't close until the end of this year
column33: per company guidance. Benefits from the merger will take some time to accrue
column34: and Qualcomm could see integration disruption in 2018.Snap Inc. (SNAP): Snapchat IPO ALMOST Beats the OddsFinally
column35: there's competition.Intel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) has partially displaced QCOM in some iPhone models
column36: and could take more slots if the legal battle takes time to play out. In automotive
column37: NXP will take onNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) andMobileye NV(NYSE:MBLY). That's a lot of giants taking on a tight market - one reason why NVDA stock has slumped more than 16% over the past few weeks.Is there enough to short QCOM? Probably not - not unless an investor is willing to aggressively bet on Apple's interpretation of Qualcomm's business model. But there's enough here to justify the recent slump in QCOM stock
column38: and an earnings multiple that looks simply too low. And the problem for Qualcomm is that while the Apple lawsuit is the most covered story
column39: it's not theonlystory that can hurt QCOM stock.As of this writing
column40: Vince Martin had no position in any securities mentioned.More From InvestorPlace10 Dangerous Dividend Stocks to Dump Now7 Stocks to Buy That Are ALMOST in Buffett Buying RangeThe postQualcomm
column41: Inc. (QCOM) Stock Has Problems Beyond Apple Inc. (AAPL)appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Bad News for Apple Inc.'s OLED iPhone;3/3/2017;"Later this year
column2: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) is expected to introduce three new iPhones. The   first two will be typical refreshes of its iPhone 7 and iPhone 7   Plus models
column3: respectively
column4: while the third is expected to be an   ultra-premium model with a curved OLED display and other features   that'll make it a technical tour-de-force.The general expectation is that the company plans to release   all three models this fall. However
column5: a new report from DigiTimes
column6: citing ""industry sources
column7: suggests that the company might not be   able to launch -- or
column8: at the very least
column9: begin shipping -- the   OLED iPhone until after the standard models launch.Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();A redesigned fingerprint scanner driving a     delayPer the report
column10: which cites ""industry sources
column11: Apple has   ""decided to use its own Authentec algorithm combined with   Privaris glass identification to redesign a new fingerprint ID   solution.""What's interesting is that Apple purchased nearly the entirety   of Privaris' patent portfolio between December 2012 and October   2014
column12: per CNN. Furthermore
column13: MacRumors reported back in 2015 that   Privaris had ""essentially shut down"" about five years prior to   the publication of the report.""This certainly appears to be a patent portfolio purchase   rather than a full acquisition of Privaris by Apple
column14: MacRumors'   Joe Rossignol wrote at the time.Based on DigiTimes' report and the information from CNN and   MacRumors
column15: it really looks like this new fingerprint   identification solution is a home-grown effort by Apple
column16: potentially years in the making.Due to Apple needing to redesign its fingerprint scanning   technology for the OLED iPhone
column17: DigiTimes' sources say that the   iDevice maker's OLED iPhone might not go into production until   September (the other two models
column18: DigiTimes says
column19: will go into   production in July).What does this mean for Apple and the OLED     iPhone?It takes some time to go from volume production to devices in   customers' hands. For example
column20: DigiTimes says that the iPhone   7s/7s Plus will go into production in July
column21: so we're looking at   about a two-month lag between when mass production starts and   when customers can get their new phones.So
column22: if DigiTimes is right
column23: customers might not be able to get   ahold of the new OLED iPhone until November.Now
column24: there are two courses of action that come to mind here.   The first is that Apple can simply announce the new OLED iPhone   alongside the other models in the fall
column25: begin to take pre-orders   for the OLED model
column26: and then just ship them out as soon as   practicable.Apple could also hold two separate launch events; the first   for the refreshed versions of the current iPhones
column27: with the   launch of the more expensive OLED iPhone just a few months   later.Personally
column28: I think that the first course of action is more   likely for a couple of reasons:If Apple doesn't launch the hotly anticipated OLED iPhone     in the fall
column29: customers who really want phones with curved OLED     displays might just give up on Apple and choose devices from     competitors (even if they would have preferred an Apple phone     all else equal).The OLED iPhone is likely to be significantly more     expensive than the regular models. Apple really shouldn't risk     potentially driving a ""mix down"" in iPhone sales by having some     customers opt for the cheaper iPhone 7s/7s Plus for lack of     another option when they would have been willing to pay more     for the more expensive OLED iPhone (if it were     announced/available for pre-order).Of course
column30: Apple is better off delaying a product a smidgen to   make sure it's ready to go and if the redesigned fingerprint   scanner meaningfully enhances the user experience
column31: then the delay   is probably worth it.But
column32: if it's true
column33: it'll be a bummer for some Apple customers   and could potentially push out when Apple begins to enjoy the   financial benefits of the next-generation iPhone cycle.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Posts Best Q4 Apple Watch Sales Ever;3/3/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAs last year's holiday sales were ramping up
column3: Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) faced claims that its Apple Watch was in trouble. Smartwatch sales were down - with AAPL doing worse than most - and some analysts were calling for a miserable Q4. Apple CEO Tim Cook even took the unusual measure of speaking to the press to claim Apple Watch sales were actually off the charts.makeAd('4'
column5: 'mktsnews'
column6: 'vanguard'
column8: '');Source: AppleHowever
column9: IDC just released its numbers for Q4 wearables
column10: and it looks like Apple was right. It booked its best Apple Watch Q4 numbers to date.Fitbit Inc(NYSE:FIT)
column11: on the other hand
column12: didn't do so well.The IDC Numbers on Q4 2016 Wearables SalesIDC just released itsnumbers for Q4 2016 wearables sales. This covers both fitness trackers and smartwatches. Overall sales were up 16.9% year-over-year with 102.4 million wearable devices being shipped during the quarter
column13: worldwide.The firm noted a continuing trend toward smartwatch makers adopting an activity tracking approach
column14: while traditional fitness tracker makers - like Fitbit - scrambled to add features
column15: becoming multi-use devices.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is Moving Markets - LiterallyThe results for the quarter show that Apple's strategy of making its second generation smartwatch even more fitness focused paid off
column16: with record Apple Watch sales.IDC had this to say:""AppleWatch Series 1 and Series 2 proved to be a magnificent success for the company as it was the company's best quarter ever in the wearables market. The lower entry price point and the inclusion of GPS on the Series 2 along with a completely revamped user interface have helped the company grow its presence. Apple is one of the few companies that has been able to quickly refocus its watch to gain traction in the consumer market and has also been leading the charge on introducing the smartwatch category to the commercial segment.""Fitbit
column17: on the other hand
column18: had a miserable quarter. Its smart wearables like the Blaze weren't enough to fend off the Apple Watch.The U.S. market (where its marketing is focused) is approaching saturation for basic fitness trackers. China'sXiaomicranked out cheap fitness trackers and added new more upscale models with features like heart rate tracking.As a result
column19: for Q4 Apple Watch sales were up 13% (to 4.6 million units for the quarter) and Xiaomi was up 96.2% (5.2 million units). Fitbit maintained its first-place position
column20: but sold just 6.5 million units
column21: a 22.7% drop compared to last year.Q4 Smartwatch Sales Show AAPL's Fitness Focus Paying OffThe IDC numbers vindicate Apple CEO Tim Cook's comments in December. Speaking in response to a a report (from IDC
column22: ironically) that suggested the smartwatch category was in trouble and the Apple Watch would face ""muted"" success
column23: Cook responded:""Our data shows that Apple Watch is doing great and looks to be one of the most popular holiday gifts this year. Sales growth is off the charts. In fact
column24: during the first week of holiday shopping
column25: our sell-through of Apple Watch was greater than any week in the product's history. And as we expected
column26: we're on track for the best quarter ever for Apple Watch.""That comment was looked at with some suspicion at the time. It seemed a little defensive and vague.Is the Reversal in Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock a Buying Opportunity?The Apple Watch series 2
column27: launched in September
column28: featured a renewed focus on fitness and activity
column29: including a built-in GPS that freed it from the smartwatch for running. A partnership withNike Inc(NYSE:NKE) resulted in theApple Watch Nike+aimed offered sports enthusiasts.At the same time
column30: Apple tweaked the performance of the Apple Watch and has continually improved its watchOS operating system.With record Q4 Apple Watch sales that exceeded the numbers from its launch year -when excitement about the all new smartwatch was running high- AAPL's strategy is clearly paying off. And contrary to that earlier IDC report from last year
column31: the Apple Watch is enjoying better than ""muted"" success.As of this writing
column32: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceApple Inc. (AAPL) CEO Tim Cook Raises Hopes for a New Mac ProSnap Inc. (SNAP): Snapchat IPO ALMOST Beats the OddsThe 7 Most Popular Vanguard Funds for 401k PlansThe postApple Inc. (AAPL) Posts Best Q4 Apple Watch Sales Everappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Buying Snap Today Could Be Like Buying Apple 35 Years Ago;3/3/2017;"Snapchat (Shutterstock photo)Many on Wall Street are comparing Snap Inc. (SNAP) to Facebook (FB) or Twitter (TWTR) and for now
column2: that's okay. All three can be considered social networks
column3: rely on daily active users and generate the majority of their revenue from advertising.In the future
column4: however
column5: Snap may wind up being more like another Silicon Valley giant than the aforementioned ones -- Apple (AAPL).makeArticleAd();Buying stock in Snap today is a bet on CEO Evan Spiegel more than it is on the company's prowess as an advertising behemoth. Spiegel
column7: is a product visionary the world has not seen seen Apple's Steve Jobs and to some extent
column8: Tesla Inc. (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk.There are similarities between Jobs and Spiegel
column9: both starting their companies after dropping out of college
column10: are wonderful salesmen and marketers
column11: but the similarities go further than that.Jobs is Spiegel's idol; he has a portrait of the legendary Apple co-founder hanging in his office. When unveiling Spectacles toThe Wall Street Journalthis past fall
column12: he even used Jobs-ian language
column13: saying ""You wanna see it?"" as he took off the towel covering the product. This mentality plays to the culture of secrecy at both companies
column14: not releasing products until they are ready to be talked about.And unlike other technology companies
column15: neither Snap or Apple have ""beta"" products. There is no group of early adopters buying and using a product so the companies can get an idea of how users are interacting with it and then continue to refine. Every meticulous detail is thought out and obsessed over and is not released until it's perfect.Aegis Capital analyst Victor Anthony said the company's most valuable asset is its demographic
column16: with 13-24 year olds comprising nearly 60% of its user base. While these are highly coveted by advertisers such as Procter & Gamble
column17: Clorox and others
column18: Spiegel is the company's most valuable asset. The ability to know what people want before they want or see it is an invaluable trait that very few executives have. It can not be measured or valued
column19: but it's something that investors need to keenly aware of when looking at where to put their investing dollars.Snap has positioned and sold itself as a camera company
column20: having mentioned that multiple times in its S-1. This can allow them to expand into everything and anything that has a camera.Despite the optimism surrounding Spiegel
column21: the stickiness of Snapchat (engagement levels are shockingly high) and the coveted user base
column22: it's not all roses for Snap at this stage.There are concerns about the company's financial picture
column23: as it still generates the majority of its revenue from advertising. Going up against Facebook and Google
column24: which have mountains of user data that advertisers love
column25: can be a daunting task (just ask Twitter).Issues surrounding slowing user growth
column26: the ability for competitors to copy product features
column27: lack of data analytics
column28: no voting control with Class A shares are all valid reasons to be wary of Snap
column29: especially at a $35 billion valuation.But again
column30: it comes down to be at the forefront of an area that's only going to expand with a product visionary for a CEO.Images
column31: whether it's augmented reality
column32: virtual reality
column33: moving or static
column34: are humanity's future. All you have to do is just look at the popularity of Instagram to see why. Snap
column35: with Snapchat
column36: its burgeoning hardware portfolio and most importantly Spiegel
column37: is poised to be at the forefront of this trend for many years to come."

column1: Don't Miss the Red Flags at Qorvo;3/3/2017;"In the third quarter
column2: just over a third ofQorvo's(NASDAQ: QRVO) revenue came from its largest customer. Though   Qorvo didn't name this customer explicitly
column3: it is widely   believedthe company's biggest account isApple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column4: to which it supplies radio frequency chips to   enhance signals. This would make Qorvo one of the more   diversified Apple suppliers
column5: especially compared toSkyworks Solutions(NASDAQ: SWKS) andCirrus Logic(NASDAQ: CRUS)
column6: which are reportedly dependent on Apple for 40%   and 85% of their revenues
column7: respectively.In that light
column8: Qorvo seems like a diversified bet. What's   more
column9: Qorvo's second-largest customer
column10: with 11% of revenue
column11: is   the fast-growing Chinese smartphone playerHuawei. Additionally
column12: it countsSamsung(NASDAQOTH: SSNLF) among its client list.All this diversification
column13: however
column14: couldn't save Qorvo from   setting weak guidance for the fourth quarter. Qorvo expects its   fourth-quarter revenue to be $630 million at the midpoint of its   guidance range. This is much lower than the consensus revenue   estimate of $719 million
column15: and if Qorvo manages to hit the   midpoint of its guidance
column16: its revenue will increase just 3.6%   from the prior-year period.makeArticleAd();Let's take a look at what's going on with the company and why   investors should take note.Image source: Qorvo.The problems at QorvoQorvo's key smartphone clients are under pressure
column17: and this is   reflected in the company's guidance. CFO Mark Murphy had the   following to say about the company's weak outlook during the Feb.   1 conference call (transcript viaSeeking Alpha)
column18: ""This guidance primarily reflects a greater than historical   sequential decline in the March quarter
column19: as two of our leading   customers in China and a tier 1 customer in Korea delayed   flagship smartphone launches.""The delayed smartphone launch by Qorvo's Korean customer seems   to be a reference to Samsung
column20: since the Galaxy S8 won't be   launched at the Mobile World Congress happening this week
column21: as the   S7 was last year. Samsung is reportedly going to launch its   flagship in April instead
column22: as it carries out intensive testing of   the device to avoid a Note7-like fiasco. There's no doubt that   this delay has pushed back Qorvo's potential revenue from Samsung   by at least a quarter and led to a weak outlook.Meanwhile
column23: Apple is believed to be slashing its iPhone   production by roughly 10% in the current quarter
column24: after producing   more units than it sold during the holiday period. Supply chain   data suggests that Apple placed orders to manufacture 89 million   iPhone units in the December-ended quarter
column25: while it sold only   78.3 million. This leaves Apple with a surplus of around 10   million iPhones for the current quarter
column26: so it has reportedly   decided to scale back production.In fact
column27: Ming-Chi Kuo of KGI Securities is of the opinion that   iPhone production will decline throughout the first half of 2017
column28: until the production cycle of the next model kicks in. So
column29: it   looks like Qorvo will not get any bump in its revenue from its   largest customer in the first half of 2017. But is there more   afoot here than just declining smartphone orders?Is Skyworks eating Qorvo's lunch?Qorvo is a direct competitor of Skyworks Solutions
column30: as both   companies make radio-frequency components for the same customers.   However
column31: Skyworks provided a strong outlookfor the current quarter when it released results in January. Its   revenue expectation of $840 million means that its top line could   grow 8% from the prior-year period and exceed consensus analyst   estimates of $818 million
column32: while Qorvo's revenue is expected to   increase just 3.6%.As Skyworks' outlook is rosier than Qorvo's
column33: the former could   be winning market share. Mike Walkley of Canaccord Genuity (viaBarron's) has a similar opinion
column34: writing:We also believe Skyworks is increasing content with Samsung     and is well positioned for content growth with new Samsung     products ramping in the upcoming quarters. We believe other     Chinese OEMs will follow Huawei's leadership with increased RF     content.Additionally
column35: Skyworks CEO Liam Griffin said that his company   has seen content wins in ""multiple devices across Samsung's   entire portfolio
column36: and gained momentum in China
column37: with key wins at   market leaders Oppo
column38: Vivo
column39: Meizu
column40: and Xiaomi."" The comments made   by Skyworks after its latest results indicate that it is winning   a lot of content in the same areas where Qorvo is not feeling   confident.In fact
column41: Huawei has now become Skyworks' second-largest   customer after Skyworks won almost all of the RF chip spots in   Huawei's P9 flagship smartphones last year. On the other hand
column42: Skyworks had reportedly won three spots in the iPhone 7
column43: while   Qorvo supplied two chips. In comparison
column44: both companies had two   chips each inside the iPhone 6s
column45: according to a teardown of the   device by Chipworks.The competition from Skyworks is a red flag that Qorvo   investors should not ignore.10 stocks we like better than QorvoWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: More Bad News for Apple Watch;3/2/2017;"The performance ofApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) first smartwatch remains an open question
column2: considering the fact that the company remains insistent on not   disclosing Apple Watch's financial results with investors. CEO   Tim Cook has long maintained that the decision around reporting ""says nothing about our expectations
column3: instead citing competitive reasons. Lacking official figures
column4: investors have little choice but to rely on third-party   estimates
column5: for better or for worse.Market researcher IDC has just put out its preliminary   estimates on the wearables market for 2016
column6: and there's a   particularly troublesome data point for Apple.Apple Watch Series 2. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Unit volumes declined (already)For the full year
column7: Apple shipped an estimated 10.7 million   Apple Watches
column8: which was down nearly 8% from the estimated 11.6   million units that the company shipped in 2015. Here are the top   five vendors:Vendor2015 Unit Shipments2016 Unit ShipmentsChange (YOY)Fitbit22 million22.5 million2.4%Xiaomi12 million15.7 million31%Apple11.6 million10.7 million(7.9%)Garmin5.8 million6.1 million5.4%Samsung3.2 million4.4 million38.6%Data source: IDC. YOY = year over year.It gets worse. The important context missing here is that   Apple launched Apple Watch in April 2015
column9: and wasn't able to   meaningfully ramp production until June 2016. So the estimated   11.6 million Apple Watches that the company shipped in 2015 only   cover two to three quarters out of the year
column10: while the 10.7   million units for 2016 represent both a full year of availabilityandthe second-generation update to Apple Watch Series 2.There are a few ways you could attempt to justify the   year-over-year decline. Perhaps the early adopter wave in 2015   was simply so strong due to years of rumors of a forthcoming   Apple wearable feeding pent-up demand that it created a tough   comparison for 2016. Maybe the expectations of a   second-generation model dampened sales for Series 1.Silver liningsThere are a couple silver linings
column11: chief among them being that   Apple sold a record 4.6 million Apple Watches in the fourth   quarter
column12: up 13% from Q4 2015. That shows that Apple indeed   enjoyed a busy holiday shopping season
column13: and that the Series 2   updates were fairly compelling. Apple previously said that Apple   Watch units and revenue were both atrecord levelslast quarter.It's also encouraging that the broader wearables market is   still growing
column14: up 25% to 102 million units for the year. Even if   within the wearables market smartwatches are stumbling
column15: the   overarching secular trend of wearable technology remains intact.   Apple is intent on being at the forefront of wearables (and even   considers certain headphone products like AirPods as wearables   for some strange reason)
column16: and as long as Apple continues to   invest in an expanding portfolio of wearable products
column17: it will   shape the way.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column18: it can pay to listen. After all
column19: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column20: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column21: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Alphabet Could Be Berkshire's Next Tech Buy;3/2/2017;"After loading up onApple(AAPL) shares
column2: couldBerkshire Hathaway(NYSE:BRK.A) (NYSE:BRK.B) buyAlphabet Inc.(GOOG) (GOOGL) shares next? Alphabet has been bought aggressively by multiple famous gurus. Buffett and Munger have commented favorably on the company's competitive position several times. The latest Berkshire shareholder letter indicates Buffett is very knowledgeable about the technology space.The fact that so many value investors are buying Alphabet at current multiples indicate it is a great business at a fair price. It is not immediately obvious how popular the stock is because Alphabet trades an A and a C share class
column3: which are treated as seperate companies by lists put together through automation. They are economically equivalent
column4: however
column5: and if you add them up
column6: Alphabet is one of the highest-owned stocks among the great investors tracked by GuruFocus.Back in 2009
column7: Warren Buffett(Trades
column8: Portfolio) talked aboutIBM(IBM)
column9: Apple and Google:makeArticleAd();""The chances of being way wrong in IBM are probably less
column10: at least for us
column11: than the chances of being way wrong in Google or Apple. I just don't know how to value them.I would not be at all surprised to see them be worth a lot more money 10 years from now but I would not buy either one of them. I sure as hell wouldn't short them either.""In addition
column12: Charlie Munger(Trades
column13: Portfolio) said:""Google has a huge new moat. In fact
column14: I've probably never seen such a wide moat.""Munger added it was also filled with sharks. It is impossible to assess a moat without understanding competitors and their chances to successfully assault a company's market share. In this case

column16: formerMicrosoft(MSFT) chairman and a good friend of Buffett

column18: Google founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin and Chairman Eric Schmidt traveled to Omaha to talk to Buffett when setting up the new Alphabet structure
column19: which is molded after Berkshire.Shortly before the trip

column24: ' which deals with whether a computer can successfully impersonate a human being. Inventor Ray Kurzweil took the opposing view. Each backed up his opinion with $10
column25: 000. I don't know who will win this bet
column26: but I will confidently wager that no computer will ever replicate Charlie.That same year
column27: Craig Mundie of Microsoft asserted that pilotless planes would routinely fly passengers by 2030
column28: while Eric Schmidt of Google argued otherwise. The stakes were $1
column29: 000 each. To ease any heartburn Eric might be experiencing from his outsized exposure
column30: I recently offered to take a piece of his action. He promptly laid off $500 with me. (I like his assumption that I'll be around in 2030 to contribute my payment
column31: should we lose.)""This paragraph shows Buffett has been studying the tech world very hard and is open to the possibility the Turing test will be cracked by 2029. He also must have looked into the dynamics of driverless or pilotless technology
column32: note the recent investment into airlines
column33: to take on a $500 bet. I do not think betting against Buffett is generally a profitable endeavour. What jumped out at me is
column34: apparently
column35: Alphabet's chairman and Buffett recently spoke again. They must have spoken for quite some time for the subject of this casual bet to come up.All these factors have led me to speculate on the potential of an Alphabet investment.The pieces are falling into place.Buffett has been studying tech intensely.Berkshire has made a 180 as far as tech investments go.Buffett and Munger view Alphabet as having an incredibly strong moat.Alphabet's valuation is at an attractive level given the interest from the value investing greats. Porat is a great addition to the executive suite

Alphabet continues to dole it out like it is candy on Halloween.I would go as far as to say it would greatly surprise me if we do not see Berkshire buying a stake in Alphabet in the next five years.Disclosure: Author owns none of these stocks.Start afree 7-day trial of Premium Membershipto GuruFocus.Premium MembersThis article first appeared onGuruFocus."

column1: What Does Warren Buffett See in Apple?;3/2/2017;"SinceWarren Buffett(Trades
column2: Portfolio)'s annual letter came out and he followed up with a lengthy interview on CNBC where he talked about how much moreApple(AAPL) stock Berkshire now owned - and how he was the one who bought most of it - I have gotten a lot of email questions asking about his purchase.This is not the first time I have received a slew of emails questioning the logic of one of Buffett's investments. Since I have been writing articles about investing
column3: he has made four investments that really got a reaction from value investors who doubted the logic of what he was doing. These include: Buffett's initial purchase of railroad stocks and his subsequent purchase of all of Burlington Northern
column4: his investment inIBM(IBM) despite him having said he does not invest in tech stocks
column5: his investment in the four major U.S. airlines despite the fact he has said the airline industry is a terrible one for investors and now his investment in Apple.Berkshire Hathaway's (NYSE:BRK.A)(NYSE:BRK.B) investment in Apple is far from the most controversial of these cases. A bunch of other value investors like the stock. It is a reasonably priced stock on an enterprise value basis - Apple has a lot of net cash
column6: so its market cap exaggerates the valuation being put on the company. But
column7: each of these investments by Buffett is an example of him moving into an area he had not previously touched. I am not sure Buffett ever invested in a railroad stock despite the fact that when he started his career - in the early 1950s - railroad stocks were a much bigger part of the investment landscape than they are today. Buffett may not have bought tech stocks before IBM - but it is
column8: in most every other respect
column9: the kind of stock Buffett would normally buy.makeArticleAd();Also
column10: Buffett previously said the reason he never ownedMicrosoft(MSFT) was because no matter whether it was true or not - people would assume the purchase was the result of inside information from his friend
column11: Bill Gates(Trades
column12: Portfolio). He also said
column13: however
column14: that at one pointMicrosoft stockgot to a price - presumably
column15: this is sometime after the 2008 financial crisis - that seemed low to him. Buffett rarely talks about whether the price of a stock seems low
column16: high
column17: etc. unless he understands something about that business and that industry. So
column18: it is not unreasonable to think Buffett believes he understands some things about Microsoft. And those things might allow him to - within a very wide value range - know whether even a tech stock like Microsoft is cheap or not.Now
column19: let's look at Apple. What does Buffett see in that stock? The number one thing that appeals to Buffett about Apple is something that should not matter at all to you. Buffett is attracted to Apple's size. It is a huge stock. Buffett said on that same CNBC interview I mentioned that Berkshire was unlikely to take a bigger than 10% stake in a company because of the problems that presents. Berkshire has ended up with more than 10% of a company's stock
column20: but that has often been helped along by share repurchases on the part of the company itself.Right now
column21: Ted Weschler and Todd Combs are each running $10 billion portfolios at Berkshire. Those are the small portfolios. Buffett is investing at a whole order of magnitude more in size. But
column22: let's start with just the kind of ideas Weschler and Combs need to come up with.Assume you are running a $10 billion portfolio that is fully invested in common stocks. Further assume you want to avoid buying more than 10% of a company's stock. Now
column23: assume you are a concentrated type investor the way Buffett is. As I write
column24: my own portfolio is 65% invested in just two stocks:Frost(CFR) andBWX Technologies(BWXT). It is 85% invested in just three stocks. The third stock
column25: however
column26: is a micro-cap. Managers investing billions of dollars cannot even look at a micro-cap. The very smallest stocks they can possibly buy are things like Frost and BWX Technologies. So
column27: how much of their portfolio could they put in those two stocks? Remember
column28: I have 65% of my portfolio in those stocks.Well
column29: if you are managing $10 billion
column30: and you are buying stock in a company with a market cap of about $6 billion (which is about the size of Frost and BWX)
column31: you can put just under $600 million into the company without crossing the 10% ownership threshold. So
column32: say you have two good ideas that are each $6 billion companies - put them both together and you get just 12% of your portfolio in those stocks. Now
column33: for me personally
column34: I do not want to spend time worrying about a stock that is much less than 20% of my portfolio. Here
column35: we are talking about stocks that are 6% of your portfolio if you buy absolutely as much of them as possible. You see the problem. And I have understated it.Buffett is running about 10 times what Weschler and Combs are running individually. And neither Frost nor BWX Technologies is a small company. Within its niche of Texan banks
column36: Frost is the biggest. And within its niche of nuclear work for governments rather than civilians
column37: BWX Technologies is the biggest. So
column38: Buffett cannot be looking for companies that have market caps of $6 billion. He wants companies with market caps of $60 billion or even $600 billion. Apple has a market cap of even more than $600 billion. So
column39: here we have a company where instead of putting just 5% of your portfolio into the stock at the very most
column40: you might get the chance to put 10%
column41: 20% or even 50% of your portfolio into the stock. When Buffett was running his partnership
column42: he liked to put 25% into his best idea. In the case ofAmerican Express(AXP)
column43: he even went beyond that. If we do a little math with the amount of money Buffett manages at Berkshire
column44: we can see that ideas in the $100 billion to $700 billion market cap range are really
column45: really useful to him because he can potentially deploy $10 billion to $70 billion (10% of the value of these kinds of companies) into such gigantic public companies.Think about what kinds of companies you have in the $100 billion to $700 billion range. It is pretty limited. Buffett likes focused companies. He likes brands. A great idea for Buffett is something likeCoca-Cola(KO)
column46: American Express
column47: Wells Fargo(WFC)
column48: Moody's(MCO)
column49: or Gillette. Those were great ideas because they were not just big companies. They did very few things in a very big way. Buffett's stake in Gillette got swapped intoProcter & Gamble(PG) stock. He eventually did a deal to get out of P&G by taking control of Duracell. Duracell is a big brand like Gillette. P&G is an even bigger company
column50: but only a few of its brands are huge in a way that is useful to Buffett. P&G as a whole is more diversified into things that are not really as good as Gillette is on a standalone basis.Not only is Apple a huge company
column51: it is a hugely focused company
column52: which is attractive to Buffett. Apple's fortunes are now tied to one brand (as they really always have been) and largely to one product (the iPhone). When you listen to what Buffett said about Apple
column53: you realize how important this is. Buffett said he likes Apple. He said he sees how integral the iPhone is to the lives of people - especially young people - who now have it. And he says that he sees - at places like the Nebraska Furniture Mart stores he owns - that people upgrade from one iPhone to another instead of considering competing brands. So
column54: the investment thesis is surprisingly focused for a giant company. It really has to do with one brand and one product
column55: the iPhone. That is it. Buffett can evaluate the stickiness of one consumer product and one brand. That makes Apple easier to understand than Procter & Gamble orDisney(DIS) or other giant consumer-oriented businesses that are actually much more diversified. Apple is not diversified. That is the potential attraction.Moving on
column56: Buffett thinks Apple
column57: like IBM
column58: is not going to do a lot of big acquisitions. He thinks the company is going to buy back a lot of its own stock. This is a very common theme in a lot of his investments. One of the surest signs you can find for a ""catalyst"" that might change his thinking about a company is that company turning inward and focusing on the things it does best while dedicating its free cash flow toward reducing its share count year after year instead of expanding into other areas.Buffett is not an activist investor
column59: but if you look at those areas where he has been most vocal - either while on a board
column60: in the way he abstained from a vote or what he said to the press - it is almost always a capital allocation decision. It is usually related to the issuance of company stock. Sometimes it is related to overpaying. Nonetheless
column61: he is constantly urging the management of the companies he invests in to focus on widening their moat
column62: doing what they do best and investing in themselves at a reasonable price (by buying back their own stock) rather than investing in somebody else by overpaying.The only times I can think of Buffett having any complaints about Coca-Cola had to do with an acquisition the company wanted to do (at too high a price) or with giving stock to top executives. The stock grants to executives incident at Coke was reported in the press as Buffett complaining about executives being overpaid. I think the reason he abstained on that vote had more to do with the fact the company would be permitted to cause a lot of dilution if it used the program to the full extent it was asking shareholder approval for. So
column63: it was probably more about Buffett wanting Coca-Cola to shrink its share count rather than grow it.When Buffett was asked on CNBC about the growth prospects of both IBM and Apple
column64: he answered by talking about share buybacks. Before Buffett bought it
column65: IBM had one of the longest and most aggressive histories of buying back its own stock you can find at any public company. A lot of Berkshire's investments have this feature. Look at how much American Express has shrunk its share count since Buffett bought that position. Or look at how much Coca-Cola has bought back of its own stock. In both cases
column66: I'm pretty sure Berkshire's investments are worth at least 33% more than they otherwise would be because these companies have shrunk their share count by more than 25% while Berkshire owned them. Buffett mentioned in the CNBC interview that Apple had bought back almost 5% of its stock in a year. That is unlikely to be a one-time thing. Apple will have problems with where its cash is located - it will end up with a lot of cash that would be taxed if brought back to the U.S. - but it does not need cash to grow
column67: it cannot grow that fast anymore organically and it does not do big acquisitions.For a tech company its size
column68: Apple has historically been especially averse to acquisitions. A company as profitable as Apple that does not use money on high-priced
column69: transformative acquisitions is eventually going to have to use that cash to buy back its own stock. There just are not any other realistic options. It could pay dividends; and because of Berkshire's own tax status
column70: Buffett would benefit at least as much from dividends as from (fairly or overpriced) buybacks. He does not mind dividends
column71: and he certainly does not mind buybacks at stocks he chose in the first place.What about Apple's lack of future growth? I think this actually attracts Buffett. That sounds counterintuitive. But
column72: let me explain. Apple is a tech stock and a consumer product company. The most dangerous time to invest in tech stocks and consumer product stocks is when they sell a high-priced product to a small pool of customers. The reason for this is that it allows market entry at the low end. If you are selling $1
column73: 000 watches or $10
column74: 000 computers
column75: someone can come in selling a cheaper and more basic version of the product to a large group of people who have never owned the product. All sorts of market leaders run into this problem. They have the biggest dollar share of the industry
column76: but economies of scale - and certainly gains in experience - are driven in large by the unit volume you do. The leader is in an awkward position because trying to expand the market cuts into their profitability on a per-customer basis.If you are selling computers to corporate customers - you are not dreaming of the day when every living room in America can have a cheap
column77: basic desktop. That future is potentially bad for you in several ways. One
column78: it teaches whoever you are competing with a lot about many of the things you do. Two
column79: it cheapens the image of what you are selling. Three
column80: it changes the way you will have to sell what you are selling. Almost all technology
column81: especially any sort of consumer tech
column82: follows this pattern. It can be very tough for investors because it leads to a two-stage adoption of the technology.In phase one
column83: one leader establishes their dominance in the ""pro"" market and the stock looks great. But
column84: in phase two
column85: another - and usually different - leader establishes their dominance in the ""consumer"" market. Then that stock looks great at the expense of the first leader. We could be talking about computers or cell phones here. But if you go back further in history
column86: TVs and radios followed the same pattern too. These things are always invented long
column87: long before you remember them being invented
column88: but were not adopted quickly. People tend to remember when they started seeing cell phones everywhere
column89: when they started using the internet in their own home and so on. Those years have nothing to do with when these products were first invented
column90: commercialized and so forth. Often
column91: there was a company you have completely forgotten about that made and lost a fortune before the time period you even think of the new consumer tech as being suddenly important to society.What does this have to do with Apple? It is part of a broader question. Just how ""moaty"" are consumer technology companies? At least on one side of the economic value equation
column92: companies like Apple
column93: Facebook(FB) andAlphabet's Google (GOOG)(GOOGL) depend entirely on the mass appeal of their product. We call them technology companies. Internally
column94: I am sure they seem very technical to those inside the organization. But how much does technology drive the economic returns at these companies? And
column95: at this point
column96: how easy is it to attack any of these business models on some technical difference between your product and theirs? How much of what makes the iPhone successful is the Apple brand
column97: the fact a customer already owns an iPhone and is used to using it
column98: the fact a customer's friends
column99: family and peers already own an iPhone and
column100: as a consequence
column101: the fact other entrepreneurs and organizations have invested time money and effort in trying to reach people by designing products to be used on an iPhone?In other words
column102: has the iPhone become the default choice for customers because the Apple brand is good enough
column103: the status quo is good enough
column104: people are not all going to jump on another bandwagon together and the suppliers are going to be where the demand is? Is the iPhone always going to be the easiest choice? This is exactly the same question for Facebook and Google. A very long time ago
column105: I wrote that while I did not ownGoogle stockand did not know how the organization would develop over time as a company
column106: I did know that understanding anything technical about a search engine no longer mattered. Google does not need to be the world's best search engine to be the world's most popular search engine. The advantages it has are too entrenched and the differences between one set of search results and another are so small - Google does not really have to compete on quality anymore. Google is enough of a brand and search is enough of a commodity that it does not matter.The things that got Apple to the position it is now in are not necessarily the things that will keep it there. A lot of readers emailed me asking about Apple's brand and whether it would last. The answer to that is yes and no. It will be a recognizable brand that is seen as good enough in a decade or two. I would be very surprised if that changed. On the other hand
column107: I would be surprised if the Apple brand was seen as being particularly innovative or standing for very specific design choices or anything like that in a decade or two. Coca-Cola is a great brand
column108: but it is not a very specific brand. It cannot be anymore. When people think cola they think Coca-Cola. And when people think phone - they think Apple. But
column109: Apple will not need to convince anyone to try a smartphone for the first time anymore. They do not really even have to convince anyone to try an Apple product for the first time anymore.Apple has very high returns on the money it actually ties up in its business. The numbers look lower because they have excess cash. Likewise
column110: the stock looks more expensive than it is because it has a lot of excess cash. If Apple's sales grow somewhere between nominal GDP and the rate of inflation in the countries where it operates in and the company dedicates every cent it makes - or more
column111: since Apple already has net cash - to buying back its own shares
column112: it will still be a ""growth"" stock on an EPS basis. For an example of this
column113: see BWX Technologies. It is not really a growth company at all in terms of what it does. It does not gain new customers (outside of the U.S. Navy). It does not win totally new projects (outside of the carriers and subs it has long provided reactors for). And it does not even get many more orders for a higher build rate for the number of those ships now than it did in the recent past. Despite all that
column114: the company just put out a press release saying it expected a ""low double-digit"" EPS growth rate for the next three to five years. That is a growth stock
column115: but it is one because it is doing something very
column116: very profitable on a return on capital basis. It is retaining all the business it already has and growing the business it retains a tiny but consistent bit
column117: and then it is taking all the money it makes and buying back its own stock. When a super high-quality business buys back its own stock
column118: it is not impossible to turn an underlying 5% type growth rate in how much more your customers actually want into more like a 10% growth rate in the earnings you report per share.IBM is another good example of that. In the 10 years before Buffett bought the stock
column119: it was not very good at company-wide revenue growth. Over the last decade
column120: IBM had close to 9% annual EPS growth at the same time it had close to zero percent revenue growth. A lot of that is accomplished simply by not growing the assets you tie up in the business at all (IBM's net tangible assets actually shrank over the last decade) and then taking all your free cash flow and - instead of growing assets like most companies do - use it to reduce your share count.What Warren Buffett (Trades
column121: Portfolio) sees in Apple is probably a slow growth
column122: wide moat consumer brand that can use all its free cash flow to buy back its own stock and thereby be a high-growth stock in terms of EPS
column123: even while it is slow growth in terms of additional units sold. Apple may not be a growth company anymore
column124: but that does not mean it cannot be a growth stock. All Buffett cares about is the growth in earnings per share. So
column125: he is not necessarily betting Apple can sell a lot more iPhones over the next five to 10 years. What Buffett's betting on is Apple's ability to report a lot more in earnings per share over the next five to 10 years.Disclosures: Long CFR
