column1: 'Diamonds' ETF Shines Bright: 3 Ways To Play The Dow Renaissance;3/1/2017;"The Dow Jones Industrial Average has had quite the turn in the spotlight of late
column2: breaching the 20
column3: 000 level for the first time in its 120-year history and then stringing 12 straight record closes for its longest winning streak in decades.This hot streak for the blue chip index
column4: and the exchange traded funds that track it
column5: came as investors cheered President Donald Trump's proposals to deregulate industries
column6: cut taxes and boost infrastructure spending.makeArticleAd();Relative to the S&P 500
column7: the Dow has far more exposure to industrials
column8: financials and consumer discretionary - economically sensitive sectors that could disproportionately benefit from the Trump vision - and zero exposure to defensively oriented utilities and real estate
column9: points out Todd Rosenbluth
column10: director of ETF research at CFRA Research.On Wednesday
column11: following Trump's well-receivedmaiden speech to Congress
column12: SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) soared to a fresh all-time high powered by big jumps forApple(AAPL)
column13: Goldman Sachs(GS) andJPMorgan Chase(JPM).[ibdchart symbol=""dia"" type=""daily"" size=""quarter"" position=""leftchart"" ]""The optimism following the (Trump) speech
column14: as well as increased confidence that the Fed is going to raise rates sooner
column15: is driving more cyclical stocks and sectors
column16: said Rosenbluth. The Dow ETF
column17: he added
column18: ""has experienced a renaissance in the past few months.""Interest ticked up as the elite components of the Dow outperformed the S&P 500 after Trump's election win.From Nov. 8 through Tuesday's close
column19: the SPDR Dow ETF jumped 9.1% vs. a 5.9% gain for SDPR S&P 500 (SPY). Of note
column20: some top-performing stocks over the past three months
column21: such asBoeing(BA) and Goldman Sachs
column22: have a far bigger presence in the price-weighted Dow than in the cap-weighted S&P 500.DIA saw net inflow of more than $1 billion per month in November
column23: December and January
column24: following four months of net outflow. ""Diamonds"" was the No. 1 ETF in terms of flow of money in the week ended Feb. 9
column25: attracting $1.1 billion. But over February as a whole
column26: DIA leaked $826 million
column27: including $2.03 billion on Feb. 15
column28: reportedly the biggest one-day outflow in its nearly 20-year history.Rosenbluth describes the ETF as ideal for investors looking for a more economically sensitive slant to their large-cap exposure under the new regime.But
column29: he cautioned
column30: its concentrated 30-stock portfolio won't give them the same degree of diversification as S&P 500 funds.ThoseETF investorswho believe the Dow rally could continue have several ways to participate in the trend. These include:SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average(DIA)
column31: the $16.26 billion ETF known as 'Diamonds
column32: ' offers easy
column33: one-click exposure to the blue chips that many investors choose to own individually.The portfolio is broadly representative of the stock market
column34: but price-weighting makes for some idiosyncratic stock positions and sector bets. Higher priced stocks get a bigger portfolio stake
column35: which means Goldman Sachs
column36: trading at around 250
column37: currently has the top spot in the portfolio
column38: at an 8.2% weighting vs. 0.5% in the S&P 500. Industrial giant3M(MMM)
column39: trading near 190
column40: is No. 2.Morningstar analyst Alex Bryan calls price weighting ""a relic from the 19th century"" that lacks a sound economic basis.At the same time
column41: he believes Dow stocks boast a more competitive edge - or ""wide economic moats
column42: in his words - than S&P 500 companies.DIA is up 5.7% year to date and has produced an average annual 7.4% gain over the past 15 years
column43: in line with the S&P 500 over both periods.The ETF has a 0.17% expense ratio vs. 0.10% for SPY. DIA trades roughly 3.5 million shares a day on average.Guggenheim Dow Jones Industrial Average Dividend(DJD)
column44: a $7.5 million ETF
column45: selects the Dow securities that have consistently paid dividends over the past four quarters and weights them by their 12-month dividend yields.This approach ""tends to weed out few if any stocks
column46: highlighting the need for conviction in the Dow's names in the first place
column47: according to ETF.com. However
column48: Guggenheim says its dividend-focused approach ""should be of interest to investors as reinvested dividends historically have been a significant source of the DJIA's total return.""The top two holdings are Boeing
column49: with a yield of 3.2%
column50: andChevron(CVX)
column51: yielding 3.8%.DJD debuted in December 2015 and charges 0.30% of assets in expenses. It yields 2.46% vs. 2.17% for DIA.Rosenbluth believes this relatively new product merits the additional scrutiny required of smaller
column52: less liquid ETFs.ProShares Ultra Dow30[ticker symb=DDM] offers leveraged exposure to the Dow
column53: delivering twice the daily returns of the benchmark index.Leveraged ETFs generally are short-term tactical tools
column54: traded for a single day. Over longer periods

column1: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Just Succeeded Where Apple Inc. (AAPL) Failed;3/1/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL) isn't exactly a direct competitor toApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL)
column3: but the former just eclipsed the latter
column4: and seemingly out of nowhere.makeAd('4'
column6: 'mktsnews'
column7: 'vanguard'
column9: '');Source: GoogleOne of the worst-kept secrets in the industry has been Apple's determination to get into the TV business. The company has been working for years trying to put together an online TV service
column10: hoping to offer 25 channels for between $30 and $40 monthly. That project seemed to have been put on hold when AAPL and broadcasters couldn't reach an agreement on price.But Alphabet has just succeeded where Apple failed.YouTube TV - live TV from over 40 providers including the big networks for $35 per month - is now official.YouTube TV Takes on CableYouTube TVwas announced on Tuesday. Launching ""soon"" in the U.S.
column11: this is Google's skinny TV bundle for cord cutters. The four major networks are onboard. So isWalt Disney Co's(NYSE:DIS) ESPN
column12: along with regional sports networks. Google is also including some content from its premium YouTube Red service. All told
column13: there will be over 40 different content providers - not bad for $35 per month.Subscribers get unlimited cloud DVR storage
column14: search powered by Google's AI
column15: six user accounts (three streams can be active simultaneously) and the ability to watch YouTube TV on a variety of devices including smartphones
column16: tablets
column17: PCs and Google Chromecast.Why Apple Inc. (AAPL) Will Become a Trillion-Dollar CompanyIn other word
column18: this is pretty much what Apple has been struggling to release.YouTubeTV is Eerily Similar to Apple's Television PlansApple has to have been watching Google's YouTube TV announcement with dismay. Its rival beat it to the punch with the streaming TV bundle it had envisioned offering with the Apple TV.What makes it even more galling is how close YouTube TV is to what AAPL was negotiating.In May 2015
column19: AAPL andCBS Corporation(NYSE:CBS) were in talks about a subscription Apple television streaming service
column20: butmoney was reportedly a sticking point. In December of that year
column21: CBS CEO Les Moonves confirmed toBusiness Insiderthat his network had been in talks with Apple
column22: and were close to settling on a monthly price to charge consumers. Moonves was throwing around $35 - exactly the price that YouTube TV is charging.Apple balked. Apparently Google was waiting in the wings.Where Does This Leave AAPL and Its TV Strategy?At this point
column23: Apple's entire television strategy seems to be struggling.There was hope that the new Apple TV that launched in 2015 would come with a streaming TV bundle. That didn't happen. Now Apple's set-top streamer is suffering from disappointing sales. The box costs twice what Google andAmazon.com
column24: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) charge for their streamers
column25: but lacks the 4K support rivals offer.Last year
column26: AAPL was showing off anew TV appthat would serve as a hub for streaming content
column27: tracking use across multiple services and devices. But it failed to get buy-in fromNetflix
column28: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX)
column29: making its usefulness questionable.Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Could Break $1
column30: 000 If ...Google's YouTube TV launch is the icing on the cake.Where Can Apple Go From Here?Don't expect Apple to give up on its plans
column31: of course.The signs of a renewed push toward taking over your living room began last month. Applehired the former head of Amazon's Fire TVto take over as the head of marketing for Apple TV. This move has raised expectations that AAPL will revamp its Apple TV hardware. It also freed up the previous head of Apple TV to helplead Apple's efforts to sign content deals- something he had considerable experience in from his previous role as senior VP of content distribution atHulu.While YouTube TV offers a fixed content bundle
column32: AAPL had always pushed for subscribers having an option to choose their own bundle
column33: Moonves says. If the company can accomplish that goal
column34: it still can position an Apple television streaming service as being something unique.With YouTube TV
column35: Google may have beaten Apple to the punch when it comes to being first of the tech giants to offer a cheap way to cut the cable
column36: but the war is likely just beginning.As of this writing
column37: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceWhat Is Apple Inc. column1: Berkshire Hathaway: Repurchase Limit Crosses $135 Per Share;3/1/2017;"In addition to the release ofWarren Buffett(Trades
column2: Portfolio)'s shareholder letter this past weekend
column3: Berkshire Hathaway(BRK.A) (BRK.B) reported full-year fiscal 2016 financial results as well - so let's dive in.Berkshire reported $24 billion in net income in 2016
column4: comparable to 2015. On 2.466 billion equivalent B shares
column5: that's equal to roughly $9.75 per share in 2016 reported earnings.I personally make a few adjustments to try and normalize these results. First
column6: I largely back out the roughly $6.7 billion in investment and derivatives gains included in net income (replaced by roughly $2.3 billion in income
column7: which is equal to ~50% of the trailing five-year average). Second
column8: I add back unreported earnings from the ""Big Five"" -The Coca-Cola Co.(KO)
column9: American Express(AXP)
column10: Wells Fargo(WFC)
column11: IBM(IBM) andApple(AAPL); by my math
column12: there was roughly $3.1 billion (aftertax) in unreported earnings from these five holdings (the Apple stake is adjusted to reflect the disclosures Buffett made Monday morning on CNBC). Finally
column13: I make a few other adjustments that I believe are reasonable (most notably an estimate of earnings power on the excess cash Berkshire holds and higher depreciation expense at BNSF to account for the real maintenance cost attributable to the railroad). All in
column14: my math estimates that Berkshire Hathaway's normalized earnings power is approaching $10 per B share.makeArticleAd();For the full year
column15: Berkshire generated $32.5 billion in cash flow from operations (a decade ago that number was ~$10 billion). Roughly $13 billion was reinvested in the business as capital expenditures with $5.1 billion and $3.8 billion spent at Berkshire Hathaway Energy and Burlington Northern Santa Fe. Another $31.4 billion was spent on acquisitions (largelyPrecision Castparts[PCP] but also $1.4 billion for bolt-on acquisitions). The net shortfall from these three buckets (roughly $12 billion) was covered by incremental long-term debt issued at low single-digit interest rates.Insurance businessesBerkshire's insurance businesses reported a pretax underwriting gain of ~$2.1 billion in 2016
column16: an increase of 16% from 2015. The gain was attributable to Berkshire Hathaway Reinsurance Group
column17: where underwriting income nearly doubled
column18: to $822 million. Within BHRG
column19: ""Retroactive Reinsurance"" losses declined from $469 million to $49 million. It's difficult to say anything meaningful based on headline changes in the reported reinsurance results from year to year. As an example
column20: the retroactive reinsurance agreement recently signed withAmerican International Group(AIG) - for which Berkshire received a premium of $10 billion- will generate $375 million in pretax deferred charge amortization losses for BHRG in 2017. Focusing only on the losses without considering the economics of the whole deal leads you to faulty conclusions.GEICO had another solid year of growth in 2016
column21: with earned premiums up 12%. For the year
column22: GEICO added nearly 1 million net auto policies in force (PIFs)
column23: compared to a net 700
column24: 000 additions in 2015. While the loss ratio increased in 2016
column25: pressuring profits
column26: this is a reasonable trade-off in the short term (it's worth noting that storm-related losses at GEICO increased by $260 million in 2016 as well). GEICO has a sustainable competitive advantage that becomes more powerful in an environment where consumers are increasingly cost conscious. Management has proven adept at managing the business for the long-term. GEICO will emerge from the industry's current challenges in a stronger position than it started.Berkshire Hathaway Primary Group continues to report solid numbers as well
column27: with earned premiums increasing to $6.3 billion in 2016 (up more than 40% from 2014). The combined ratio was just shy of 90%
column28: resulting in more than $650 million in pretax underwriting income.At the end of 2016
column29: the float attributable to Berkshire's insurance businesses exceeded $91 billion (compared to $70 billion five years). Inclusive of the AIG deal discussed a moment ago
column30: Berkshire's float exceeds $100 billion. In his letter
column31: Buffett restated his belief that a decline in float
column32: should it occur
column33: will be very gradual - ""at the outside no more than 3% per year.""Noninsurance businesses2016 was a tough year for rails generally and BNSF specifically
column34: with revenues falling 10% on comparable declines in volumes and average revenue per car. The coal business took a beating in 2016
column35: with volumes and revenues down 21% and 27%
column36: respectively; even after declining by more than one-quarter
column37: the coal business still accounted for ~17% of BNSF's revenues in 2016. The operating ratio increased in the face of sliding revenues (meaning lower operating margins)
column38: resulting in a 16% drop in earnings. 2016 was undoubtedly a struggle for BNSF; if guidance fromUnion Pacific(UNP) is any indication
column39: 2017 should be a step in the right direction.Berkshire Hathaway Energy reported $17.9 billion in 2016 revenues
column40: a low single-digit decline from 2015. A small increase in pretax income ended up as a 7% increase in aftertax profits
column41: partly attributable to a lower effective tax rate (down two points to 14%). There's plenty of room to run here: my research suggests production tax credits from wind-powered electricity generation will be a material tailwind to BHE's net income over the coming years (MidAmerican owns more wind-powered capacity than any other rate-regulated electric utility in the country).Berkshire's Manufacturing
column42: Service and Retailing (MSR) businesses reported ~$5.6 billion in earnings in 2016
column43: an increase of ~$1 billion versus the prior year (both measures exclude amortization of intangibles). The entirety of the gains came from the Manufacturing bucket due to the inclusion of Precision Castparts; pretax Manufacturing earnings declined in 2016 whenPrecision Castparts is backed out (largely due to a $365 million loss from the disposition of part of Lubrizol's business in the fourth quarter). MSR was also impacted by other one-time costs
column44: such as $110 million in acquisition/integration and transition costs from the Duracell deal.Finally
column45: Finance & Financial Products revenues increased 10% in 2016
column46: with earnings up 4%. Clayton Homes' reported a solid year
column47: selling more than 42
column48: 000 units (an impressive 25% increase from 2015). Strength in manufactured homes from Clayton offset less impressive results in the remainder of the business (notably at Marmon).ConclusionBook value increased by ~11% in 2016 to $115 per B share (trailing three-year CAGR of 8%). The repurchase authorization (up to 120% of book value) enables Buffett to buy back stock at ~$138 per B share. As he noted in the shareholder letter
column49: ""purchases at that level clearly bring an instant and material benefit to continuing shareholders"". Starting at ~$170 per share
column50: that would require a pullback of ~20%. Shares are reasonably valued at current levels.Berkshire's fortress balance sheet continues to offer significant optionality; at some unknown point in the future
column51: it will be used to create meaningful per-share value for investors. My favorite quote from Bufett's shareholder letter addressed this in a roundabout way:""Every decade or so
column52: dark clouds will fill the economic skies
column53: and they will briefly rain gold. When downpours of that sort occur
column54: it's imperative that we rush outdoors carrying washtubs
column55: not teaspoons. And that we will do.""Disclosure:Long BRK.B

column1: 5 Best Performing Stocks of February;3/1/2017;"Markets set a blistering set of gains over the month with new milestones being created on a regular basis. Over the month increasingly evident that President Trump's policy proposals have gone down extremely well with investors. Additionally
column2: economic data continued to be largely encouraging while earnings numbers have been impressive
column3: lending a firm basis to the long-running market rally.February's PerformanceFor the month
column4: the Dow
column5: S&P 500 and Nasdaq rose 4.8%
column7: respectively after President Trump vowed to bring back millions of jobs to the U.S. Additionally
column8: optimism over Trump's proposed market-friendly policies including tax cuts
column9: financial de-regulation and increase in infrastructure spending benefitted all the three key indexes. Fed's positive view of the economy and rally inoil pricesas well as upbeat earnings reports also boosted investor sentiment.Encouraging Domestic DataMost of the economic reports released during the month were encouraging in nature. The ISM manufacturing index increased while the services index declined only marginally for the month of January. Retail sales increased 0.4%
column10: following an upwardly revised 1% gain for December. Durable orders rebounded in January
column11: increasing by 1.8%. The Leading Indicators Index gained 0.6% following an increase of 0.5% in December.CPI and PPI both moved up 0.6% in January. Construction spending increased by 0.2% in December. However
column12: a few key reports were negative in nature. Industrial production declined 0.3% following a downwardly revised 0.6% increase for December. While durable orders fell by 0.4%
column13: consumer confidence dropped to 111.8.Q4 GDP's Second Estimate SlipsAccording to the ""second"" estimate by the Bureau of Economic Analysis
column14: fourth quarter output of goods and services increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.9% from the previous three months. This was lower than the consensus estimate of 2.1% growth. An increase in the foreign-trade deficit weighed on growth during the final three months of 2016. In the fourth quarter
column15: exports fell 4% while imports rose 8.5%.Business investment fell lower
column16: with spending on equipment decreasing 1.9%. Residential construction investment increased 9.6%
column17: revised downward from an initial estimate of a 10.2% gain. However
column18: strong gains in consumer spending had a positive impact on the domestic economy. Consumers
column19: the torchbearers for the U.S. economy
column20: increased spending by a solid 3%Housing Sector Recovery SlowsMost of the reports released across the month suggest that the housing sector's recovery has slowed down. Housing starts declined by 2.6% in January though building permits increased by 4.6%. The National Association of Home Builders (NAHB) Housing Market Index declined from 67 to 65 in February.In contrast
column21: existing homes sales jumped 3.3% in January to a seasonally adjusted rate of 5.69 million
column22: the highest level recorded in 10 years. New home sales increased 3.7% to a seasonally adjusted rate of 555
column23: 000. However
column24: the pending home sales index declined 2.8% in January to 106.4
column25: the lowest level in a year. The current scenario seems to be a consequence of demand outstripping supply and a sharp increase in home prices.Job Additions Rise
column26: Increase in Hourly Earnings   DipThe U.S. added 227
column27: 000 jobs in January
column28: higher than the consensus estimate of 174
column29: 000 job additions. This figure also exceeds December's reading of 157
column30: 000. These are the best monthly job gains since September.However
column31: expectations that the economy is moving towards a full employment scenario weighed on workers' pay
column32: with average hourly wages rising only 0.1% in January
column33: lower than December's downwardly revised gain of 0.2%. Further
column34: the unemployment rate
column35: meantime
column36: ticked up to 4.8% from 4.7% in January.Record Earnings Growth in Fourth QuarterThe absolute earnings total for the quarter is on track to be the highest ever. The bulk of the Q4 earnings season is now behind us
column37: with results from only a few of S&P 500 members still awaited. As of February 17
column39: Q4 results from 411 S&P 500 members
column40: or 82.2% of the index's total membership had been released. Total earnings for these 411 index members are up +8% on +4.9% higher revenues
column41: with 68.9% beating EPS estimates and 54.7% coming ahead of top-line expectations. (Read:Retail in Focus as Q4 Earnings Season Winds Down)Retail earnings grabbed the spotlight last month. Solid fourth-quarter reports from Wal-MartWMT
column42: Macy'sM
column43: and Home DepotHDprovided a major fillip to investor sentiment. Earlier in the month
column44: Apple Inc.'sAAPLfirst quarter fiscal results easily topped expectations. The good show was driven by impressive sales of Apple's latest smartphone model iPhone 7 and 7 Plus.Investors Ride ""Trump Rally""The euphoria surrounding President Donald Trump's proposed market-friendly policies including the prospect of massive tax cuts and an uptick in infrastructure spending propelled markets to new highs in February. The Dow closed at an all-time high for a twelfth straight session on Feb 27
column45: posting its longest such streak since 1987. Both the blue-chip index and S&P 500 settled at all-time high levels
column46: while the Nasdaq closed a few points short of a record. At present
column47: the blue-chip index continues to hover above the psychological milestone of 20
column48: 000.Trump's polices including tax cuts
column49: repealing regulations and pickup in infrastructure outlays restored expectations of a pro-growth agenda that helped the Dow push further into record territory. Trump is also planning a multi-trillion-dollar tax cut that will boost the U.S. economy and lift corporate profits.Deregulation Ensues
column50: Defense Spending to RiseTrump has also signed an executive order designed to scale back the Dodd-Frank Act. He views the Dodd-Frank regulatory overhaul as a harsh measure
column51: especially
column52: on banks as they had to beef up compliance compartments to deal with a list of new rules.Meanwhile
column53: Trump sent both the political parties a notice on Feb 27 stating that he intends to significantly raise defense related outlay. He will seek a $54 billion hike in spending on tanks
column54: ships and weapon systems and will trim other priorities. The defense budget will climb 10%
column55: according to the White House
column56: while Trump recommended $30 billion in supplementary military spending for this yearMaiden Speech to CongressUltimately
column57: the Dow snapped its record streak of gains ahead of Trump's first speech before a joint session of Congress on the last day of the month. Profit taking ensued due to a lack of details about Trump's policies.During his speech
column58: Trump adopted a measured approach to several contentious issues. However
column59: he reiterated his commitment to immigration reform and replacing Obamacare with a new healthcare law. At the same time
column60: the speech was light on details but for a request that Congress pass his trillion dollar infrastructure plan.FOMC MinutesMinutes from the Federal Reserve's January meeting adopted a similar tone
column61: keeping alive prospects of a potential near-term interest rate hike. The minutes said that ""many participants expressed the view that it might be appropriate to raise the federal funds rate again fairly soon if incoming information on the labor market and inflation was in line with or stronger than their current expectations or if the risks of overshooting the committee's maximum-employment and inflation objectives increased.""Fed Chair Janet Yellen expects a gradual rate increase amid a modestly expanding economy and inflation that should touch the Fed's desired target rate of 2% in the near term. She said that ""at our upcoming meetings
column62: the Fed will evaluate whether employment and inflation are continuing to evolve in line with…expectations
column63: in which case a further adjustment of the federal funds rate would likely be appropriate.""5 Star Performers for FebruaryI ran a screen onResearch Wizardfor companies with the following parameters:(Click here to sign up for a free trial to the Research Wizard today):Percentage price change over the last 4 weeks greater than or   equal to 15% (As of Oct 31

column1: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Could Break $1
column2: 000 If …;3/1/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAndroid
column4: fromAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL)
column5: is the dominant mobile operating system. It runs on nearly nine of every 10 mobile phones
column6: worldwide. But that's never really been a primary reason to by GOOGL stock … or at least not directly.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockFrom an investor standpoint
column7: you would still rather buyApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) because Apple monetizes iOS the way a butcher monetizes a pig. Google
column8: on the other hand
column9: just gives its OS away to OEMs.That's not to say Google doesn't make any money off Android
column10: though. Simply by offering its search engine and Google Play store through the software
column11: GOOGL rakes in billions of dollars.But
column12: the Android ecosystem is extremely fragmented. Compared toAmazon.com
column13: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) - which runs its own store and hasits own browser and search engine- Google's take is a mere fraction.What if that changed? Would it mean anything to GOOGL stock holders?Controlling AndroidWhile Google is not yet charging OEMs to use its software
column14: the company has been quietly trying to gain control of its creation. Management is pushing OEMs to deliver security updates on a monthly basis. This is important
column15: as crooks push malware onto older
column16: unpatched phones.7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Highs in 2017Google's newest handset
column17: the Pixel
column18: is designed to be as good as an iPhone. Reviews
column19: however
column20: have been mixed. The company is even trying to getback into Chinathrough its OEMs (the world's largest market tossed Google back in 2010 over censorship).Still
column21: Google has its work cut out for itself.Samsung Electronic(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) dominates the Android market. OEMs and consumers see this fragmentation as an advantage
column22: even though it allows bugs to multiply because they may appear on one device or brand only.The operating system itself is hopelessly fragmented. Google is only now rolling out its Marshmallow and Nougat versions of Android andstill developing the ""O"" version
column23: while many users have devices that still run the KitKat version. My own Android phone runs on Lollipop
column24: (simply because it lacks the storage to run anything newer).The way Google eventually gets its arms around all of this may be throughAndromeda
column25: an operating system for both Android and its laptop Chromebook devices. Unifying software platforms would give Alphabet Inc the kind of power that Microsoft only dreamed of with its Windows operating system.Bottom Line on GOOGL StockIf Alphabetwereto start monetizing Android
column26: would investors even notice?Alphabet continues to grow at 20% per year
column27: powered by advertising on its main Search site and YouTube. The company brings approximately 25 cents of every dollar to the net income line
column28: its balance sheet carries almost no debt
column29: and operating cash flow is ridiculous ($36 billion last year alone
column30: more than twice what it achieved just two years prior). In 2016
column31: Alphabet had revenue in excess of $90 billion.Over the last year
column32: the price of GOOGL stock is up nearly 17%
column33: and the non-voting GOOG shares are up even more. The company's market cap of $577 billion trails only that of Apple. Six months ago
column34: they were nearly level
column35: but that was before Apple's recent run to new highs.Alphabet Inc CFO Ruth Porat's program of paring non-performing assets and forcing ""other bets"" (like the company's self-driving car unit
column36: now called Waymo) to make it on their own has paid off. Google's investment balances have been growing steadily
column37: along with its asset base.Why Apple Inc. (AAPL) Will Become a Trillion-Dollar CompanyWhat's most amazing is how Alphabet continues to underperform. Android is not a major profit center
column38: and Google Cloud is often considered third in the market
column39: behind Amazon and Microsoft. Google was late to the voice party with Google Assistant
column40: which allowed Amazon to get the drop on it. Plus
column41: the hardware line is loaded with ""me too"" products
column42: and GOOGL leads in precisely zero categories.Still
column43: Porat has performed well in providing discipline to Google executives
column44: but she has not propelled Alphabet to market leadership outside of Search.If assets such as Android became true profit centers
column45: GOOGL stock would be well on its way to $1
column46: 000 per share and becoming the first trillion-dollar company.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column47: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing he owned shares in GOOGL

column1: Apple May Not Want to Own Netflix
column2: But It May Go After an Oscar;3/1/2017;"As Apple (AAPL) slowly moves into original video content with a couple of shows
column3: there's been a lot of speculation among investors and the media that it should just buy Netflix and be done with it.While that may happen much furtherdown the line
column4: Apple seems less likely about going after what Netflix is and more about what it has -- an Oscar.Former Piper Jaffray analyst turned venture capitalist Gene Munster believes Apple will win an Oscar relatively soon
column5: perhaps in the next five years.makeArticleAd();""We think Apple will win an Oscar in the next five years
column6: Munster's firm
column7: Loup Ventures wroterecently. ""That’s how long it will take for Apple to scale its original content spend from less than $200 [million] today to $5-7 [billion].""Netflix (NFLX) just won the first Oscar in company history forThe White Helmets
column8: a documentary about civilian first responder in Syria. Along with Amazon (which also won a few statues)
column9: Netflix is serious about changing how people watch and consume media.Apple seems intent on doing that too
column10: with Apple Music
column11: though at a different level.Apple is taking the slow route to original video content and is more likely to do what it did with Apple Music
column12: buying a small company and partnering with creative geniuses (Jimmy Iovine and Dr. Dre) than buying a big company like Netflix. It's already started to do that with James Corden
column13: buyingCarpool Karaokefor Apple Music and partnering with producer Ben Silverman to bringPlanet of the Apps
column14: a reality show about app developers
column15: to Apple Music.The Financial Timesreportedit had looked at buying Ron Howard and Brian Grazer's Imagine Entertainment
column16: but talks stalled. This is another example of Apple wanting to partner with titans of industry who can help shape the way consumers experience as opposed to buying a creative disruptor itself.The Wall Street Journalhasreportedthat Apple wants to make TV shows akin in quality toGame of Thronesfor its Apple Music service. It's a natural extension that down the line
column17: Apple would want to make similar quality movies available for its Apple Music subscribers as well
column18: despite what Apple media czar Eddy Cue sayspublicly. (Remember
column19: Apple is famous for eschewing something in public until it can make it better for its users).No matter who Apple winds up partnering with down the line for video content
column20: it's Apple's goal to remain culturally relevant. Cue hasreferenced MTVas a jumping off point for Apple Music
column21: making the cultural relevant mission all the more relevant.Investors shouldn't expect a Netflix-sized acquisition down the line
column22: but don't be caught off guard when Apple Films is up for an Oscar next decade."

column1: Stock Market News for March 01
column2: 2017;3/1/2017;"Benchmarks finished in the red on the last trading day of February as investors waited eagerly for President Trump's speech on Tuesday night. Dow closed in negative territory snapping its winning run of twelfth consecutive session gains
column3: the longest such streak since 1987. Additionally
column4: growth in the U.S economy remained unchanged in the fourth quarter after higher trade deficit offset gains from rising consumer spending. Although
column5: key indexes registered declines on Tuesday
column6: they registered strong gains last month on the back of the Trump-induced rally.For a look at the issues currently facing the markets
column7: make sure to read today'sAhead of Wall Streetarticle.The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJI) decreased 0.1%
column8: to close at 20

column10: 363.64. The tech-laden Nasdaq Composite Index closed at 5
column12: losing 0.6%. The fear-gauge CBOE Volatility Index (VIX) advanced 6.9% to settle at 12.92. A total of around 7.9 billion shares were traded on Tuesday higher than the last 20-session average of 6.9 billion shares. Decliners significantly outpaced advancing stocks on the NYSE. For 62% stocks that declined

column14: Trump spoke about making ""the government lean and accountable."" However
column15: investors waited for more clues from his big speech on Tuesday night.Additionally

column4: Advanced Micro Devices

column33: which currently has much of the marketshare for the datacenter.In light of the continued growth in cloud computing

column37: whichhosts35% of the websites in China.Finally

column1: Best Buy Inc Co (BBY) Stock Dives Into the Retail Dumpster;3/1/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsBest Buy(NYSE:BBY) announced slightly lower same-store sales during the holiday season
column3: and investors dumped BBY stock in a hurry.makeArticleAd();Source:Austin Kirk via FlickrThe drop was minor
column4: less than 1%. But it was unexpected
column5: and missed analyst estimates of a top-line gain of 0.5%.For the quarter
column6: Best Buy reported earnings of $607 million ($1.91 per share) on revenue of $13.48 billion. This compared with earnings of just $479 million ($1.40) but revenue of $13.62 billion a year earlier. More importantly
column7: while adjusted profits of $1.95 per share easily beat estimates of $1.67
column8: revenues fell short of analysts' expectations
column9: also for $13.62 billion.The revenue shortfall meant analysts threw Best Buy stock into the dumpster with retailers such asMacy's Inc.(NYSE:M)
column10: with shares down almost 5% early Wednesday
column11: to $42.40. During the Christmas season
column12: on Dec. 8
column13: the shares traded as high as $49.31.Were the analysts right
column14: or did they just offer smart investors a bargain? IsAmazon.com
column15: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) about to kill all retailers
column16: or is this just a case of Moore's Law in action?Great Expectations for Best BuyBest Buy even trounced the higher earnings whisper number of $1.66 per share. But actual estimateswere all over the map
column17: with some very bearish about the company's ability to cut costs and others bullish on margins.7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Highs in 2017The Zacks Metric Model noted that BBY stock had beaten estimates for four quarters
column18: and that shareholders had been rewarded with a 36% gain. In particular
column19: Best Buy was posting big gains in online sales - the so-called ""omni-channel"" approach - and Zacks was expecting an upside surprise.On the bottom line
column20: of course
column21: Best Buy delivered one. And considering the sizable beat
column22: BBY shares should've rocketed higher.But something else is at play … and that something is Moore's Law.Moore's Law Hits the Top LineMoore's Law
column23: which turned 50 in 2015
column24: was described byIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) co-founder Gordon Moore as an expected increase in circuit density on silicon
column25: doubling every 18 months ago as far as he could see
column26: in 1966.But
column27: as I have been writing for many years now
column28: Moore's Law alsoturned traditional economics on its head. Moore's Law is deflationary
column29: and the deflationary impact grows with time
column30: as integrated circuits are incorporated into more and more things
column31: and as the impact is compounded by its use in various ways.In the case of Best Buy
column32: this means the products it sells lose value as soon as they leave the factory
column33: and the retailer is under enormous pressure to get them out the door before their value disappears. This isn't new
column34: but in 2016 it hit one of the company's primary growth sectors: big-screen TVs.A TV that would have been unaffordable just a few years ago - 5 feet wide on the diagonal - is now available at Best Buy forjust $600. More important
column35: flat-screen sets just don't break. I still have one from 2001.Could Amazon.com
column36: Inc. (AMZN) Take a Hint From Best Buy Co Inc (BBY)?Best Buy still makes money on that 60-inch set
column37: but the price point is lower
column38: and this is true for all consumer electronics. Whole categories that used to represent big profits
column39: like back-up drives
column40: DVD players and packaged software
column41: have disappeared as consumers find they can get and save files to cloud services.Bottom Line on BBY StockThe new administration wants to whip deflation now and
column42: by allowing price hikes on oil and other resources
column43: they could achieve the goal. China
column44: too
column45: seems dedicated to fighting deflation
column46: giving raises to many workers in a more competitive market.This should mean good news for Best Buy
column47: which is focusing more on products like ovens and washing machines that have mechanical parts which sometimes break. A new round of high-end phones should also help the top line.Bottom line? At a price-to-earnings multiple of under 14
column48: and a dividend yielding 2.5% (that the company is in a great position to raise)
column49: BBY stock might be Best Buy's best bargain.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. His latest novel isBridget O'Flynn vs. Something Big & Ugly.Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing

column1: Could Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Take a Hint From Best Buy Co Inc (BBY)?;3/1/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAmazon.com
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) buysMacy's Inc(NYSE:M). It's a crazy idea
column5: right? AMZN stock has barely budged over the past couple of weeks sincereportssurfaced that Canada'sHudson's Bay Co(OTCMKTS:HBAYF) was in talks to buy America's largest seller of apparel. Clearly
column6: investors aren't holding their breath.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThe media
column7: on the other hand
column8: has been busy speculating on the odds of a company like Amazon getting into a bidding war with the iconic Canadian retailer that is run by an American and also ownsSaks IncandLord & Taylor.Opinions vary on whether Amazon boss Jeff Bezos would make such a move
column9: but let me assure you
column10: it won't be for the real estate.No
column11: if AMZN does make a play for Macy's it will be for other
column12: more-sensible business reasons. In fact
column13: you could say Amazon would be taking a page out of the playbook ofBest Buy Co Inc(NYSE:BBY)
column14: one of Amazon's biggest rivals in electronics retail.How's that
column15: you say? Let me explain.AMZN Apparel Market ShareIn case you missed it
column16: Amazon has been slowly entering the apparel businesssince debutingits own private-label brands in early 2016 with 1
column17: 800 products available for sale under names such as Scout and Ro
column18: Franklin and Freeman
column19: and Society New York.Essentially
column20: it's trying to fill the gaps not covered by its third-party sellers. However
column21: a bigger attraction of doing its own thing isn't lost on investors of AMZN stock
column22: which is that you make more selling your own stuff than you do somebody else's.7 Best Stocks to Buy for a Donald Trump Green LightAccording to Cowen & Co.
column23: Amazon is expected to pass Macy's in 2017 as America's top apparel seller and by 2022 should have16.2% market share.While it could do most of this through its websites
column24: having brick-and-mortar stores has always been on the minds of analysts and retail experts alike.""We believe this deal could address some of (Amazon's) major consumer pain points
column25: wrote Cowen & Co. analyst Oliver Chen in a recent report discussing the possibility of it buying Macy's. ""Amazon needs better brands
column26: a more curated assortment
column27: a physical place to return items
column28: and customers could use help with ensuring fit - Macy's would also give Amazon greater credibility in curation and fashion authority.""That last part's a bit of stretch. I'm pretty sure if Amazon knocked on your door and you're a private label apparel manufacturer
column29: you'd let them in.Real EstateTo take full advantage of its private label expansion
column30: real estate is going to become an important part of the equation as AMZN expands into brick-and-mortar locations. It's not a matter of if Amazon will do this
column31: in my opinion
column32: but when.Right now there is an abundance of retail real estate coming on stream through all the various store closings across America
column33: including68 Macy's stores- part of the bigger 100 store closings announcement from last summer - in 2017
column34: so finding space isn't going to be a problem for AMZN.If you remember what happened toTarget Corporation(NYSE:TGT) in Canada
column35: buying all those leases in one big deal ultimately was its undoing because it put way too much pressure on its employees to execute such a big undertaking.So
column36: there is the argument that Amazon could expand one target market at a time until it has stores across the U.S. Unfortunately
column37: that would take a decade or longer to execute. If it really wants to open retail stores this isn't an appropriate solution for a growth company like AMZN.Why Best Buy?Business wasn't looking good for the Minneapolis-based electronics retailer until CEO Hubert Joly turned the company upside down in 2012 implementing its infamous ""Renew Blue"" turnaround plan that turned physical store locations into local distribution hubs for its e-commerce business.Former CFO Sharon McCollamcalled the ship-from-storeinitiative in February 2016 ""one of the most important and strategic decisions in (Best Buy's) history.""The numbers don't lie. In November
column38: Best Buydelivered strongstrong Q3 2017 results that included continued growth for its e-commerce business along with positive same-store sales growth. It's taken multi-channel retail to the next level.Why Apple Inc. (AAPL) Will Become a Trillion-Dollar Company""Best Buy's third quarter online growth of over 24% results in a very solid quarter
column39: and continues to validate the company's multi-channel transformation
column40: Moody's lead retail analyst Charlie O'Sheasaid in November.Renew Blue's been such a success that retail expert Walter Loeb named Joly his 2016 Retailer of the Year.Bottom Line on AMZN StockBy acquiring Macy's
column41: AMZN would be able to push its products onto the store floors where it could learn more about what apparel shoppers want
column42: while seriously lowering its shipping expenses by implementing a ship-from-store initiative much like Best Buy.Yes
column43: it's already invested billions in warehouses across the country
column44: but getting closer to the customer is never a bad thing; buying Macy's might not happen but if it does
column45: it's got nothing to do with owning real estate and everything to do with AMZN owning the customer.As of this writing

column1: What Warren Buffett Likes About Sirius XM (SIRI);3/1/2017;"Who would have thought Sirius XM (SIRI)
column2: which once traded for pennies
column3: would ever qualify as a “Buffett stock?” But that’s precisely the claim the New York-based satellite radio station can now make.According to a recent regulatory filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission
column4: billionaire investor Warren Buffett
column5: CEO of Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A) (BRK.B)
column6: is now one of Sirius XM’s biggest fans after his conglomerate acquired 166.64 million Sirius shares between October and December 2016. Berkshire’s SIRI stake
column7: which now stands at 741
column8: 547 shares
column9: is was worth in the neighborhood of $750 million.What does Buffett see in SIRI?makeArticleAd();Once left for dead at the height of the 2008 recession
column10: Sirius XM
column11: which has a monopoly in the realm of automobile satellite radio
column12: has come roaring back with a vengeance
column13: thanks to booming U.S. auto sales over the past couple of years. SIRI stock
column14: which closed Tuesday at $5.09 per share
column15: has risen 38% over the past year
column16: including more than 14% year to date
column17: besting the S&P 500 index in both spans. And if you’ve held SIRI stock of the past five years
column18: you’re up 130%
column19: or about 26% gains annually.Obviously
column20: Buffett
column21: who arguably is the best value investor of all time
column22: would have loved to have bought Sirius shares much sooner. But the fact that he’s bought in now would suggest that he still sees value in the years ahead. Plus
column23: Buffett is known to place his long-term bets where he sees strong management teams. In that regard
column24: the fact that Sirius has posted better-than-expected revenue for most of the last ten quarters
column25: might have caught Buffett’s attention.Sirius’ streak of strong execution might have given Buffett the confidence to allay fears about competition from the likes of Apple’s (AAPL)
column26: which Buffett owns. Same goes for apps like Spotify
column27: Pandora (P)
column28: and so on. Over the past couple of years
column29: Sirius has taken each new entrant’s best shot and not only has survived
column30: it continues to generate tons of cash ($1.5 billion in FCF in 2016) and has implemented a dividend.In that regard
column31: while 2017 auto sales
column32: which Sirius relies on to grow its subscribers
column33: may have a tough comp against 2016
column34: Buffett is likely looking beyond 2017 and possibly other scenarios that may work in Sirius’ favor. An acquisition by Apple
column35: for example
column36: which has been rumored about for years
column37: can’t be ruled out. But until then
column38: Buffett is going to ride Sirius’ cash cow and dividend for as long as he can. And retail investors should pay attention."

column1: Nimble Storage: Why We Went Long;2/28/2017;"BySuhail Capital:We recently picked up some Nimble Storage (NYSE:NMBL) shares. The position is to a degree on the more speculative side of things for us as we have generally hated the flash storage vendor space and broader enterprise storage space for years
column2: but as is always the case in markets at some point things change.The starting point for this thesis has been our desire to look outside of semiconductors/platform tech giants/and enterprise software for some appealing longs in the broader technology industry. Storage has been that spot for us of late. We have dabbled since late last fall with outright investments in the likes of Network Appliance (NASDAQ:NTAP) or even related names with industry exposure like VMware (NYSE:VMW) on the software defined storage side or Nutanix (NASDAQ:NTNX) as far as hyper converged vendors pure plays go. But the operative word here is dabbled
column3: as we have been reluctant to commit to a bullish view on the sector.makeArticleAd();Why have we been so reluctant?A Brief Trip Down Storage Memory LaneWell
column4: in short the enterprise storage space has been a notoriously bad place to be long anything for a very long time. In fact there hasn't been a true public success story in the space since NTAP. And we define success by a public billion + sales company that is profitable and actually generates returns for shareholders. What the space has instead offered up is a very long list of fantastically hyped up short opportunities.Our experience here goes all the way back to STEC
column5: a leader in the SSD market with what was supposed to be game changing flash controller technology
column6: which in retrospect ended up providing the script for all enterprise flash storage related investing for years to come. Now we could probably write a short story about our experiences with STEC as we initially bought into the hyped disruptor pitch
column7: before quickly changing directions once we got to know the management and space. Whether it was dodgy CEOs
column8: mind-boggling related party transactions
column9: insider trading
column10: blue-chip customer name dropping
column11: or crazy one-time orders that never ever rematerialized; STEC had it all. But as far as this note is concerned all that mattered here is the stock and business quickly collapsed as the industry quickly shifted. Ultimately STEC's technology was acquired for a fraction of its previous value by [[WDC]].Naturally
column12: the STEC experience made us very wary of the next hot name in the space: Fusion-IO. This server side flash caching PCIe card company which Facebook (FB) and Apple (AAPL) couldn't live without and with genius Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak as CTO was an instant market darling. Fusion was also a tough short because their business didn't implode overnight. The demand for their technology was initially there
column13: but over time the growth and margins didn't pan out as expected as the broader demand for flash caching never really took off as expected. Why? Well
column14: in our view the technology became more complimentary versus necessary as the affordable all-flash array market took off. That being said
column15: selling out to Sandisk at half its IPO price from a couple years earlier ended up being a far better final outcome than the next hot name in the space would face.Violin Memory burst on the scene as the all-flash array game changer that was going to rock the storage market
column16: but that unraveled fairly quickly after HP dumped them to focus on their own in house 3par strategy. After problems with HP torpedoed a $2bl plus dream IPO
column17: Violin was forced to float at all costs just to sustain the business. The story was spun some
column18: but really you didn't need to be a genius to figure out this was a name to avoid. The subsequent IPO was a flop
column19: and the Violin model never got any better. The consensus view on what went wrong here was that Violin's custom memory-based approach to its all-flash array solution vs. commodity SSD was what killed them
column20: as the likes of Pure Storage (PSTG) arrived in their space and larger storage providers like EMC got more aggressive. Either way
column21: Violin went from IPO to Chapter 11 in 3 years. That's called a disaster
column22: and yet here we are about to make a case for going long Nimble Storage.A Little Nimble IPO HistoryNimble's IPO was around the same time as Violin's disaster
column23: but ended up being an instant success. Shares closed up over 60% on the first day of trading
column24: and within two months traded to a market value of just under $5 billion and valuation of 50x ttm revenue. Naturally
column25: we read the prospectus and sat back waiting for a short opportunity
column26: but at the time we were pretty busy with Veeva so couldn't do the detailed work. Anyway
column27: it didn't really matter as a good chunk of the Nimble bubble burst in the Spring of 2014 with the rest of the tech IPO bubble crowd. When we finally got around to looking closely at the stock we had our fair share of doubts. The story around Nimble was that Hybrid Arrays are simpler and cheaper than AFAs and easier to manage software wise
column28: and thus that its addressable market and growth opportunity outside of large enterprise were extremely appealing. The bull case was that the Enterprise AFA market would be left to the likes of Pure and EMC XtremIO to battle over
column29: while Nimble actually got profitable pretty quick with its commercial hybrid focus. That obviously hasn't panned out as the stock trades at roughly a quarter of its post-bubble collapse level
column30: has a market cap of roughly 2x its ttm revenue.So why do we like it now?The Case For NimbleThe case for Nimble obviously starts with the valuation. At a current enterprise value of roughly 1x expected 2017 revenue the stock is cheap
column31: and trading at a discount to Pure Storage's multiple of 1.7x. Of course
column32: in this space valuations can be misleading as technology can become obsolete awfully quick. So we are not really value hunting here in the traditional sense. In fact
column33: we took a small position in Nimble calls in front of its last earnings as we wanted to express the view that its push into the AFA space was working. Although the trade didn't work due to a seemingly sour market mood at the time
column34: we were pleased with the conference call and quarterly results. Anyway
column35: we have been keeping a close eye on the name ever since. All we needed to get a little more comfortable initiating a position in the stock was evidence that the sector in itself has stabilized enough
column36: and that broader tech hardware valuations could support a long case in the name. Well
column37: we feel we hit that point recently. Specifically
column38: the market headline tick the box type of bottom event that the Violin Memory bankruptcy provided in December gave us confidence that the cycle of shareholder value destruction in this space has probably come to an end. Thus
column39: we got more comfortable with testing out our long thesis in the stock.Anyway
column40: let's get a little more detailed here about what we were thinking thesis wise when we first started looking at Nimble. The bear case on the name has been pretty clear-cut. The short argument had been that Nimble didn't play at all in the enterprise all flash array market
column41: and that Pure Storage's launch of the M10 would start to eat away at their share in the commercial space. This take coupled with typical investor skepticism around customer rocking software differentiation for such a vendor
column42: plus the fact that hyper converged players like Nutanix tend to be viewed as more of an initial threat to use cases in Nimble's core market
column43: made being bearish on the name not very difficult. The argument essentially was that Nimble would gradually burn through its cash and never succeed as a stand-alone vendor.And to be clear on the surface it was pretty hard to argue with this thesis
column44: but then Nimble complicated things even further by announcing its entry into the all-flash array market. Thus
column45: you now had to worry about its new product strategy failing
column46: leading to an accelerating cash burn and becoming an unnecessary distraction for management in an already extremely cut-throat competitive environment. Basically
column47: get ready for Violin Memory part deux. But here is the thing……Its Strategy Worked.Nimble has quickly and brilliantly succeeded with its move into the AFA space. It got to the $100 million annualized booking run rate in two quarters
column48: and all the checks with customers that we have done have been overwhelmingly positive. Consequently
column49: Nimble's odds of surviving as a stand-alone vendor in the space have drastically improved. In fact
column50: our main concern now is that the company has become a glaring takeover target at these levels to just about half a dozen tech names with the resources and justification to pay 50%+ premium to the current share price to acquire them. And yet the stock is trading like viability going forward is still in question?How to Play ThisNimble reports its Q4 results next week and will guide on Q1. Consensus growth for next year is 22% while Pure's expectations are for 39%. We think Nimble is positioned to outgrow consensus and Pure is more likely to disappoint. So there is a nice pair trade here which looks even nicer because of the significant valuation gap between the two
column51: and the fact that Nimble's gains are likely to come more and more at the expense of Pure. That being said
column52: we think the current bull market in tech and glaring takeover appeal for an opportunistic suitor here make Nimble an easy outright long position for those who don't like to short/hedge with pairs.See alsoCenterPoint Energy
column53: Inc. 2016 Q4 - Results - Earnings Call Slideson seekingalpha.com"

column1: Uh Oh: Will Apple Inc. (AAPL) Ditch Lightning Port on iPhone 8?;2/28/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWe're at the stage where leaks and rumors are flying fast and furious aboutApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) upcoming 10th anniversary iPhone. Some of them - like the idea of a curved OLED display - have people excited. Others - like the possibility of a $1000-plus starting price - less so. But nothing is likely to generate the sort of controversy AAPL stock is courting with the latest rumored change. According toThe Wall Street Journal
column3: the iPhone 8 will ditch Apple's proprietary Lightning cable in favor of USB-C.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleWhat the WSJ Says About the iPhone 8The Wall Street Journalpublished a report this morning outlining some of the key changes it feels arecoming with the new iPhone.Most of the detail matches previous speculation on the device. That includes losing the Home button for an all-glass front. It's also calling for a lofty $1
column4: 000 price point for the iPhone 8 - which it speculates may end up going by the name of ""10th Anniversary Edition.""The WSJis also backing the theory that the new iPhone will be equipped with a curved OLED display
column5: similar to that used bySamsung Electronics Co Ltd(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) on its Galaxy S7 Edge smartphone.7 Blue-Chip Stocks That Are Flush With CashOne big change suggested by theWSJis a bombshell: Apple may ditch the Lightning port on the iPhone 8
column6: opting to replace it with USB-C.Why Would AAPL Court Controversy with the iPhone 8?Apple has a long history of making controversial changes to its products
column7: especially when it comes to eliminating or replacing ports.In the past year alone
column8: it has faced backlash over eliminating the long-time standard 3.5mm headphone jack on the iPhone 7. And it's still trying to appease buyers of the new MacBook Pro
column9: after eliminating all legacy ports andreplacing them with the new USB-C. Then there was the last big iPhone port change in 2012
column10: when Apple ditched the 30-pin dock connector it had used with every iOS device since the 2003 generation iPods
column11: rendering millions of docks useless.Its replacement? The Lightning port.Ditching the Lightning port on the iPhone 8 would be a long-term win for AAPL fans. USB-C is an industry standard and moving to it from a proprietary connection would mean not having to pay a premium for cables. It would also make Apple's overall product strategy a lot cleaner. Right now
column12: every new iPhone comes with a USB to Lightning cable for charging - but Apple's own MacBook and new MacBook Pro have only USB-C ports. So new iPhone buyers can't connect their new iPhone to their new laptop without first investing in another proprietary Apple cable.Unfortunately
column13: there are going to be iPhone 7 owners who bought new headphones equipped with a Lightning cable instead of the traditional 3.5mm headphone jack. Those people will not be thrilled that their new headphones - purchased because Apple ditched a standard port - will now be incompatible with the iPhone 8
column14: again because AAPL ditched a standard port. They'll have to look for an adapter.There will be a confusing period of overlap. All iOS devices since 2012 have used Lightning and AAPL also uses that port for charging accessories like its latest wireless keyboard and the Apple TV's Siri remote. It's also likely that AAPL won't mess with iPhone 7 design
column15: so the iPhone 7s - which will also release in 2017 - is likely to still have the Lightning connector. More potential for confusion …However
column16: it won't be as bad for APPL as the switch to Lightning in the first place. Most manufacturers learned their lesson then and speakers now are primarily wireless instead of using a physical dock
column17: so they won't be stranded. The iPhone 8 is also expected tosupport wireless chargingand combined with wireless updating and Bluetooth headphones
column18: many users won't need a physical connection at all anyway.How Likely Is Apple to Go With USB-C on the iPhone 8?Most of this information inThe Wall Street Journal'sreport isn't new. We were writing about thatcurved displayback in August
column19: for example. However
column20: at this point in the new iPhone's development cycle
column21: the final design is beginning to be nailed down. Rumors are becoming more concrete as Apple's supply chain starts ramping up
column22: however
column23: AAPL may yet back down and stick with the Lightning port on the iPhone 8 rather than risk controversy.Leave Sears Holdings Corp (SHLD) Stock to the SavagesIf it goes ahead with the change
column24: new iPhone buyers may shrug
column25: some may skip the iPhone 8
column26: or they may hold off on buying to see what the fallout is.The only outcome we know for certain? Dongle manufacturers have been making out like bandits with the new
column27: all-USB-C MacBook Pro. They should also have a banner year in 2017 with the iPhone 8. Expect it to be a good year for wireless Bluetooth headphone sales as well
column28: as smartphone owners move to avoid those pesky physical connections altogether.As of this writing
column29: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Best Stocks to Buy for a Donald Trump Green LightThe 7 Best ETFs for Retirement InvestorsThe postUh Oh: Will Apple Inc. (AAPL) Ditch Lightning Port on iPhone 8?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: The Zacks Analyst Blog Highlights: Berkshire Hathaway
column2: American Express
column3: Coca-Cola
column4: Apple and Wal-Mart;2/28/2017;"For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column5: IL - February 28
column6: 2017 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst Blog. Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the financial markets. Stocks recently featured in the blog includeBerkshire Hathaway(NYSE:BRK.B-Free Report)
column7: American Express(NYSE:AXP-Free Report)
column8: Coca-Cola(NYSE:KO-Free Report)
column9: Apple(NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report) andWal-Mart(NYSE:WMT-Free Report).Today
column10: Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free.Here are highlights from Monday's Analyst Blog:Warren Buffett on Active vs. Passive InvestingWarren Buffett
column11: billionaire fundamental investor and CEO of Berkshire Hathaway (NYSE:BRK.B-Free Report)
column12: released his annual report to shareholders outlining ""The Bet."" Nine years ago
column13: Mr. Buffett publicly bet that any set of five hedge funds could not outperform the S&P 500 index over a 10 year period of time; hedge funds charge high active management fees while the S&P 500 index is invested in through low cost index funds. Ted Seides
column14: co-manager of Protégé Partners
column15: stepped up to the plate against Mr. Buffett.Mr. Seides chose five funds-of-funds
column16: which invest in a variety of hedge funds
column17: and Mr. Buffett decided on a Vanguard S&P 500 index fund. The wager counted performance net of fees
column18: costs and expenses which boils down Mr. Buffett's thesis of his bet: passive investing will outperform active management in the long run because costs strip away high performance possibilities.Sure enough
column19: to date
column20: Mr. Buffett is ahead in the race and declared victory. The wager began on January 1
column21: 2008 and will end on December 31
column22: 2017. Through 2016
column23: the compounded annual increase for the Vanguard index fund is 7.1% and only an average of 2.2% for the five funds-of-funds.In his letter
column24: Mr. Buffett writes
column25: ""The bottom line: When trillions of dollars are managed by Wall Streeters charging high fees
column26: it will usually be the managers who reap outsized profits
column27: not the clients.""It is important to note that Mr. Buffett is not saying it is impossible to outperform the market. He prides himself on his ability to pick winning investments over losing investments. What Mr. Buffett is pointing to is that most active managers will fail; he states that more than $100 billion have been drained into bad investment advice in the past 10 years.Berkshire Hathaway never commits to holding a security
column28: says Mr. Buffett. ""It is true that we own stock that I have no intention of selling…But we have made no commitment that Berkshire will hold any of its marketable securities forever
column29: he wrote in his letter. There are positions which have been held onto for years such as American Express (NYSE:AXP-Free Report)
column30: and Coca-Cola (NYSE:KO-Free Report). However
column31: for example
column32: in 2016 Berkshire Hathaway bought large stakes in Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report) and sold a majority of their stake in Wal-Mart (NYSE:WMT-Free Report) in an active charge to find yield.Wall Street shows that investors are leaning towards low cost index funds over active managers who promise to beat the market.The Wall Street Journalwrites that last year
column33: investors pulled a net $342.4 billion out of active managers' hands and poured a record $505.6 billion into passively managed funds.Mr. Buffett's advice: it is best for investors to use low cost index funds rather than handing their assets to active managers who charge high fees. ""Both large and small investors should stick with low-cost index funds

column6: it turns out that Buffett wasn't done loading up on   Apple. Not by a long shot.Berkshire Hathaway is now the single largest holder of   AppleIn aninterview with CNBCthis morning
column7: Buffett shared some more about what Berkshire   Hathaway has been buying in the early innings of 2017. Spoiler   alert: even more Apple. Since the close of the fourth quarter   that's covered by the 13F
column8: Buffett said that Berkshire continued   to buy shares up until earnings; Berkshire stopped buying shares   after earnings when shares jumped. Berkshiremore than doubledits Apple position during the month of January
column9: and its total   holdings are now approximately 133 million shares
column10: valued at   around $17 billion.makeAd('4'

column16: it's even   more bullish when you compound that over a longer period of time.   As mentioned above
column17: Berkshire finished the third quarter with   15.2 million shares
column18: so a position of 133 million shares   represents a nearly tenfold increase in just 4 months.Data source: SEC filings and CNBC. Chart by author.Furthermore
column19: shares are already up about 13% for February
column20: so   Berkshire's Apple position continues to perform well
column21: as shares   now trade at all-time highs.As famously averse to tech as Buffett is

column23: and so many people have   integrated the device into their daily lives that it's become   indispensable. Apple customers are also incredibly loyal
column24: so they   stick with the brand at a higher rate relative to other consumer   electronics companies. That all feeds back into cash flow
column25: since   Apple is able to generate recurring hardware revenue with ongoing   product cycles.iPhone 7 with AirPods. Image source: Apple.At this point
column26: Berkshire is the single largest holder of   Apple
column27: with about a 2.5% stake in the company. The only companies   that hold more shares are fund companies like Vanguard and   Fidelity
column28: among others

column30: although there are certainly some active funds in the mix as   well. For example
column31: the single largest mutual fund holder of Apple   is theVanguard Total Stock Market Index Fund
column32: a passive index fund that had 109.5 million shares at the end   of January (Apple is its largest holding).It's mildly ironic that an investor that's not into tech is   now the largest owner of the largest tech company.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: The Best Way to Beat the S&P 500;2/27/2017;"Investors use the Standard & Poor's index's performance to judge their own
column2: and the Holy Grail is to outperform the index consistently.But what if I told you there was a way to outperform the index consistently by buying the index itself and doing almost no work for the additional gains?Sounds appealing and almost too good to be true.makeArticleAd();Well
column3: it is true
column4: and this technique is available to every investor.The reason this is possible is the way the S&P 500 is constructed. The index is computed by a weighted average market capitalization calculated by taking the number of shares outstanding of each company and multiplying the number by the company's current share price. This is a relatively lazy way of calculating an index and gives more weight to larger constituents and less weight to smaller companies so the index is disproportionately affected by a decline inApple(AAPL) compared to a smaller firm.OutdatedThis approach has worked well since the S&P 500's inception
column5: but it isn't the best approach. Because small companies usually grow faster than their larger counterparts
column6: it doesn't make much sense to give these companies a lower weighting in the index as it stunts their impact on the broader market. Surely
column7: if small caps are given more weight
column8: the index would perform better overall?That's exactly what the S&P 500 Equal Weight Index shows. The S&P 500 Equal Weight Index does what it says on the tin. The index gives each constituent an equal weight without taking into account market capitalization or other factors. The results of using this strategy have been extremely impressive. From 2003 through 2015
column10: 000 investment in the traditional S&P 500 index would have turned into $29
column11: 370. During that same period
column12: the same investment in the S&P 500 Equal Weight Index would have turned into $38
column13: 866. Over the past five years
column14: the S&P 500Equal Weight Index has returned 26.8% compared to the traditional S&P 500's return of 23.3%.What's behind the outperformance?There is a belief that the reason why equal weighted indexes outperform traditional market capitalization weighted peers is due to the weighting of small caps in the index. However
column15: according to research conducted by Robert Ferguson and David Schofield
column16: senior investment officer and president of Intech International
column17: there is another reason why equal weight indexes tend to outperform over the long term.They believe the outperformance of equal weighted indexes has more to do with the index's constituent rebalancing than anything else. For example
column18: to maintain required equal weights
column19: the index provider has to sell a stock after a recent run higher but also buy more of a company if it has drastically underperformed over a set period. Put simply this trading requirement creates a ""buy low sell high"" trading strategy
column20: which is both contrarian and momentum chasing.Ferguson and Schofield go on to note that surprisingly the underlying alpha source is always positive for such indicators
column21: which is another indication that excess return has something to do with volatility. Equal-weighted indexes have a higher tracking error over time relative to the capitalization weighted index. The reason why this is the case lies in diversity.Diversity is at its maximum if all stock capitalizations are equal. Changes in diversity influence relative return of the equal-weighted portfolio. As the capital distribution curve has a typical shape
column22: diversity must have a typical value with no long term trend. In this case
column23: the influence due to changes in diversity will be close to zero over time
column24: and the outperformance of the equal-weighted portfolio will be close to its volatility-based source
column25: which is necessarily positive (stock returns can be both positive and negative
column26: but volatility is always positive).When the effects of diversity are combined with contrarian/momentum investing
column27: the equal weight index can capture higher alpha and less severe underperformance periods.Disclosure:The author owns no stock mentioned.Start afree seven-day trialof Premium Membership to GuruFocus.GILD 15-Year Financial DataThe intrinsic value of GILDPeter Lynch Chart of GILDPremium MembersThis article first appeared onGuruFocus."

column1: Warren Buffett On Active vs. Passive Investing
column2: Outlines 'The Bet' In Berkshire Shareholder Letter;2/27/2017;"Warren Buffett
column3: billionaire fundamental investor and CEO of Berkshire HathawayBRK.B
column4: released his annual report to shareholders outlining ""The Bet"". Nine years ago
column5: Mr. Buffett publicly bet that any set of five hedge funds could not outperform the S&P 500 index over a 10 year period of time; hedge funds charge high active management fees while the S&P 500 index is invested in through low cost index funds. Ted Seides
column6: co-manager of Protégé Partners
column7: stepped up to the plate against Mr. Buffett.Mr. Seides chose five funds-of-funds
column8: which invest in a variety of hedge funds
column9: and Mr. Buffett decided on a Vanguard S&P 500 index fund. The wager counted performance net of fees
column10: costs and expenses which boils down Mr. Buffett's thesis of his bet: passive investing will outperform active management in the long run because costs strip away high performance possibilities.Sure enough
column11: to date
column12: Mr. Buffett is ahead in the race and declared victory. The wager began on January 1
column13: 2008 and will end on December 31
column14: 2017.  Through 2016
column15: the compounded annual increase for the Vanguard index fund is 7.1% and only an average of 2.2% for the five funds-of-funds.In his letter
column16: Mr. Buffett writes
column17: ""The bottom line: When trillions of dollars are managed by Wall Streeters charging high fees
column18: it will usually be the managers who reap outsized profits
column19: not the clients.""It is important to note that Mr. Buffett is not saying it is impossible to outperform the market. He prides himself on his ability to pick winning investments over losing investments. What Mr. Buffett is pointing to is that most active managers will fail; he states that more than $100 billion have been drained into bad investment advice in the past 10 years.Berkshire Hathaway never commits to holding a security
column20: says Mr. Buffett. ""It is true that we own stock that I have no intention of selling…But we have made no commitment that Berkshire will hold any of its marketable securities forever
column21: he wrote in his letter. There are positions which have been held onto for years such as Wells FargoWFC
column22: American ExpressAXP
column23: and Coca-ColaKO. However
column24: for example
column25: in 2016 Berkshire Hathaway bought large stakes in AppleAAPLand sold a majority of their stake in Wal-MartWMTin an active charge to find yield.Wall Street shows that investors are leaning towards low cost index funds over active managers who promise to beat the market.The Wall Street Journalwrites that last year
