column1: Get Paid to Trade International Business Machines Corp. (IBM) Stock;2/27/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI have not been a fan ofInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM) for a long time. It is my opinion that management was slow to shift cash cows. They lost their way and have yet to recover. They have been trying to carve a niche in artificial intelligence
column3: but that story has been over a decade in the making. To use a poker term
column4: they are pot-committed to AI.makeArticleAd();Luckily
column5: artificial intelligence has seen a recent resurgence in popularity so the wait may actually pay off to IBM longs.Experts are in awe of what Watson can do. Unfortunately
column6: its profit stream is taking too long to develop. IBM is no longer the sure long-term bet it once was. To me
column7: it more resembles a startup with a cool product still finding its way.Click to EnlargeUsually
column8: I like to sell longer-dated risk in companies that I believe are long-term winners likeAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column9: NASDAQ:GOOGL) orApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL). In this case
column10: I am putting my trust in the IBM price action more so than its fundamentals.The Bet:Sell the IBM Oct $130 put. This is a bullish trade for which I collect $1.40 per contract to open. This trade has a 90% theoretical chance of success. This sounds like a great idea now
column11: but it comes with risk. By selling the put naked
column12: I am committing to buying the stock at $130 per share if IBM falls below it. Anything below $128.60 per share would accrue losses for me.The 7 Best ETFs for Retirement InvestorsSelling naked puts is not suited for most investors
column13: so I can modify the trade to make it more attainable.The Alternate:Sell IBM $140/$135 credit put spread. This also is a bullish trade
column14: but one with a finite risk profile. I collect 40 cents per contract to open. The 22% price buffer is smaller than that of selling the $130 naked put but for the finite risk profile advantage.While 40 cents may sound too little
column15: it would represent an 8% yield on money risked and for the high chance of success it carries it should elate most investors.I chose longer-dated risk so I don't have to fret the short-term gyrations. I find that longer-dated options risk is easier to manage. Also
column16: I can close either of these trades at any time for partial gains or losses.Nicolas Chahine is the managing director ofSellSpreads.com. As of this writing
column17: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities. You can follow him on Twitter at@racernicand stocktwits at@racernic.More From InvestorPlace7 REITs That Should Be CondemnedExxon Mobil Corporation (XOM) Should Keep an Eye on Tesla Inc (TSLA)7 Blue-Chip Stocks That Are Flush With CashThe postGet Paid to Trade International Business Machines Corp. (IBM) Stockappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column3: BRK.B) Chairman and CEO Warren Buffett has bought 133 million shares ofApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) stock over the last year.makeArticleAd();Source:FlickrWarren Buffett says that he bought 120 million shares of Apple Inc. stock in January 2017. This brings the total value of his investment in the company to $17 billion. The recent acquisition also makes AAPL the second-largest holding for Berkshire Hathaway Inc.When asked about the reason behind his recent investment in Apple Inc.
column4: Warren Buffett said that the company's ""strikes me as having quite a sticky product."" He also said that he feels that AAPL CEO Tim Cook is doing a""terrific job""with the company
column5: reportsReuters.Warren Buffett investment in Apple Inc. now gives him a2.5% stakein the tech company. Despite taking such an interest in AAPL
column6: Buffett doesn't own an iPhone. The investor does own an iPad
column7: but he notes that it was given to him.In his interview withCNBC
column8: Warren Buffett was asked which company would reach a $1 trillion valuation fist: Apple Inc. or his own Berkshire Hathaway Inc.? Buffett responded that he believes AAPL is in the better position to reach that milestone than his own company.Warren Buffett's investment in Apple Inc. was made after the start of the new year

column1: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. (BRK.B) Stock Is Even Stronger Than Before;2/27/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAs if investors needed another reason to ownBerkshire Hathaway Inc.(NYSE:BRK.A
column3: NYSE:BRK.B) stock
column4: Warren Buffett's gone and done just that. You'd have to be living under a rock somewhere not to be aware of the factApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL)becamethe world's most valuable company in early February; the first to surpass $700 billion in market cap enriching all those owning Apple stock.makeArticleAd();Source:Pete Souza via Wikimedia (Modified)Only months ago
column5: Apple waspassedbyAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column6: NASDAQ:GOOGL) as the world's most valuable company
column7: but since then
column8: AAPL stock has gone on a huge run
column9: up 52% since May 12
column11: the day the two companies switched roles.By comparison
column12: GOOGL stock is up 16% in the same period. A respectable performance - 200 basis points better than theSPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust(NYSEARCA:SPY) - but not enough to keep it in the top spot.Why AAPL Stock Gives Berkshire Hathaway a Big BoostApparently
column13: Warren Buffett and/or his two money managers - Todd Combs and Ted Weschler - were buying heavily in the fourth quarter of the year. At the end of Q3 2016
column14: BRK.B held 15.2 million shares of Apple stock; by the end of the year that ballooned 268.2% to57.4million shares
column15: a stake currently worth $7.8 billion through Feb. 23.As a result of this buying binge
column16: Berkshire Hathaway is one of AAPL's 10 largest shareholders owning 1.1% of Apple stock. Of greater importance to BRK.B stock owners is the fact AAPL stock is now its sixth largest equity position representing5%of the entire portfolio and not too far off Berkshire's investment inInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM)
column17: which accounts for 9% of the equity portfolio.7 Best Stocks to Buy for a Donald Trump Green LightIt's amazing to think that Buffett didn't own any tech stocks in2011when he started buying IBM and now these two businesses represent one-seventh of Berkshire Hathaway's $148 billion equity portfolio.So
column18: if diversification is your thing
column19: Buffett's move into Apple stock is just another reason why you might want to own BRK.B stock.Sure
column20: the company is firing on all cylinders
column21: not to mention AAPL stock is still relatively cheap at 16 times earnings or about 25% lower than theS&P 500
column22: but those iPhone sales have a way of going sideways at a moments notice.Remember the first half of 2016?It wasn't all peaches and cream as investors fretted about Apple's continuing sales slowdown. Ebbs and flows are common in the tech business. Holding AAPL stock within the Berkshire Hathaway fortress allows you to benefit from Apple's good times without suffering as much when it gets its next tech flu - and it will.A recentMarketwatcharticlediscussed possible acquisition candidates for Apple's $200 billion in cash should Trump lower the tax it would pay to repatriate the money sitting in foreign bank accounts.Qualcomm

column24: including its head of content

column28: generates annual free cash flow of more than $1.5 billion and continues to grow the top- and bottom-line.Bottom Line on BRK.B StockMore importantly
column29: Buffett bought 166 million shares of its stock in the fourth quarter to go along with shares alreadyheldinLiberty Media's SiriusXMtracking stock. Combining Apple Music with SiriusXM satellite radio wouldn't be the worse move in the world.Heck

column1: Cisco Systems
column2: Inc. (CSCO) Is in a Rut
column3: and Income Investors Love It;2/27/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsCisco Systems
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO) has justdelivered second-quarter FY17 earningsthat beat expectations on Wall Street
column6: but once again proved that Cisco stock will not be returning to growth any time soon.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockCisco reported fourth-quarter revenue of $11.6 billion
column7: $50 million above Wall Street consensus estimate
column8: but -1.7% year-over-year. That marked the fifth straight quarter that the company has posted falling revenue.Sadly
column9: things appears set to remain that way for at least the next few quarters. After all
column10: Cisco guided to revenue growth of -2% to breakeven for the current quarter
column11: and sees non-GAAP per-share earnings coming in at 57 cents 59 cents
column12: in line with Wall Street's consensus of 58 cents.Oddly enough
column13: Cisco stock has tucked on gains of 6% since the earnings call
column14: reversing the selloff that happened immediately after the results. Cisco stock is now up a solid 13.3% year-to-date. So why
column15: pray
column16: are investors celebrating Cisco's revenue tailspin?Business Model Transition for Cisco StockCSCO is stuck in the throes of a serious business model transition. Since its early days
column17: the company has been in the business of selling switches and routers that move data around the internet. That's still true in a big way since the company still derives more than 40% of its revenue from this networking business.But with more and more companies relying on rented computing services from the likes ofMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) andAmazon.com
column18: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)
column19: they are buying less and less of Cisco's hardware for their data centers.Even worse is the fact that when they do buy
column20: they are upgrading to newer devices less often. Further
column21: Cisco is increasingly facing tougher competition and cheaper offerings from the likes ofArista Networks Inc(NYSE:ANET)
column22: a company that was founded by former top Cisco executives.Throw in the fact that more companies are experimenting with software-defined networking (SDN)
column23: and Cisco is finding itself caught between a rock and hard place. Last quarter's results say it all: Cisco's switching and routing revenue for the quarter fell 5%  and 10% to $3.3 billion and $1.8 billion
column24: respectively.But CSCO has
column25: over the past few years
column26: been working on a grand plan that involves pushing for a recurring subscription-based revenue model. This essentially means developing businesses that will protect it from the vagaries of the boom-and-bust cycles of its core business.Chief executive Chuck Robbins is optimistic that Cisco can leverage the lessons gleaned from its subscription-based businesses
column27: such as Meraki cloud-controlled WiFi
column28: Security software and Collaboration to build a solid subscription revenue businesses. Cisco's Security segment was the brightest spot in the earnings report after growing 14% to reach $528 million. Meanwhile the Collaboration business grew 4% to hit $1
column29: 062 million.Investors were pleased with Cisco's latest report is because it showed that the company is making progress discovering new recurring revenue streams. The company announced that product deferred revenue related to software and subscriptions grew 51% to reach $4 billion. Meanwhile
column30: 10% of its $9 billion Product sales is now of a recurring nature

column1: The Next Big Thing for Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN): Productivity Software;2/27/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAmazon.com
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) has taken on some unexpected targets lately. None more ambitious - and unforeseen - than sticking its Alexa personal assistant in the Amazon Echo smart speaker.makeArticleAd();Source: AmazonThat move has paid off with a big lead in the race to become the hub of the smart home
column5: despite AMZN's complete lack of smartphone presence.Per a report inThe Information
column6: Amazon is readying another bold move. If sources are correct
column7: AMZN is preparing to take onMicrosoft Corporation's(NASDAQ:MSFT) Microsoft Office andAlphabet Inc.'s(NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google G Suite with its own cloud-based productivity suite.Report: Amazon.com Is Working on a Productivity SuiteThe Informationbroke the news that Amazon.com isworking on its own productivity suiteto take on Microsoft and Google. The website says AMZN's Amazon Web Services - AWS - unit has told some of its ""large corporate customers"" of its plans to offer a new suite of productivity apps that will compete against the two dominant players.7 REITs That Should Be CondemnedMicrosoft Office has always been considered a cash cow for the company. The productivity suite quickly became the industry standard
column8: the applications of choice for enterprise
column9: schools and home PC users. To make its software seem more affordable
column10: to break free of the boom bust cycle between major versions of Microsoft Office
column11: and to address the growing threat of Google's free Google Apps suite
column12: five years ago
column13: the company began pushing Office 365.This subscription version of Microsoft Office brought recurring monthly revenue and other advantages. Microsoft expanded into Office apps for mobile devices likeApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) iPad and began to sell online storage for Office 365 users
column14: with OneDrive.Google Apps/G SuiteGoogle wasn't sitting still
column15: though
column16: refining Google Apps intoG Suite
column17: a full-on competitor to Office 365
column18: with paid monthly subscription plans and online storage options. The company has also leveraged Google Apps and its lightweight Chrome OS into Chromebooks - ultra-low-cost laptops that have been giving Microsoft fits
column19: especially in the education market.That education market is where the potential for disruption is really playing out. With its free Google Apps and low-cost Chromebooks
column20: Google upended the education market. By the end of 2015
column21: more than half of all device in U.S. classrooms were Chromebooks. This has repercussions beyond the classroom
column22: as those students turn into young professionals who are more comfortable with Google's productivity software than with Microsoft Office.I've seen the effect first hand. My kids do everything at school using G Suite
column23: despite Microsoft offering free Office 365 subscriptions to students and computer labs full of Windows PCs. They ignore Microsoft Office and Apple's Pages/Numbers on our home computers
column24: and instead log onto G Suite for doing homework.If Google could quickly make waves in one of Microsoft's key strongholds
column25: why couldn't Amazon.com march in and disrupt both companies?Why Amazon Would Take On Microsoft OfficeThis is a key question. Taking on the Google and Apple in the smart home with the Amazon Echo made sense because the smart speaker was a Trojan horse. It offers a growing number of ""Skills"" that let it control other smart devices by voice command
column26: or interact with online services.That ropes consumers into buying it. But Alexa is a voice-activated path to effortlessly order products directly from Amazon.com
column27: and gives an incentive to buy other Amazon products and services like Amazon Music Unlimited and Amazon Fire TV.Where's the win for AMZN in offering productivity software
column28: other than to tweak Microsoft and Google?For the answer
column29: look to AWS. Amazon Web Servicesdominates the market for cloud infrastructureand the profit from this division is a big driver of Amazon's overall growth. Amazon already has the servers in place and it has several of the components needed for a productivity suite
column30: including its WorkDocs and WorkMail apps and the recently announcedAmazon Chimevideo conferencing software. Stitch these together with a few additional components and Amazon could have its Microsoft Office and Google G Suite competitor.Google charges $5 to $10 per month for G Suite
column31: while Microsoft Office 365 has several tiered options starting at $5.99 per month.AMZN could charge a competitive rate for its new offering
column32: adding more subscription-based revenue to its bottom line while taking advantage of its existing cloud muscle. The base monthly fee could be supplemented by charging for additional online storage for enterprise customers - something it has plenty of.Productivity software could also become another free perk of Prime membership. Prime members that start using Amazon's productivity software could put pressure on their employers to invest in a subscription
column33: in an effect like Google's approach that sees students graduate and look to their employers to provide G Suite access.The Dow Jones Industrial Average Keeps Rising
column34: But a Correction Is ComingAMZN isn't commenting andThe Information'ssources say all of this is still in the early stages
column35: but the move makes sense. Amazon has been aggressively expanding beyond its role as an online retailer
column36: AWS has the infrastructure needed to support the initiative
column37: the company has been creeping into enterprise software with apps like WorkMail
column38: and Google proved that the Microsoft Office behemoth isn't invulnerable. A productivity software suite from Amazon.com could well be the company's next big thing.As of this writing
column39: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 High-Impact Tech Earnings: Tesla
column40: Fitbit and Square3 Dow Titans Buckling Under the PressureThe postThe Next Big Thing for Amazon.com

column1: Mobile World Congress: Apple Inc. (AAPL) vs. Everyone Else;2/27/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsMobile World Congress is the industry's largest event for smartphone launches. Everyone who's anyone is there -unless your company name isApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL).makeArticleAd();Source: BlackBerryMWC 2017 officially started today
column3: but the big announcements took place over the weekend.And in many ways
column4: they set the stage for the coming battle for best smartphone that will pit Apple's 10th anniversary iPhone 8 andSamsung Electronics Co Ltd's(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) comeback Galaxy S8 against everyone else.Here's what you need to know aboutMWC 2017.Cutting Edge New SmartphonesMobile World Congress is the venue where many manufacturers choose to launch their new smartphones. That means the trends are set for what to expect in the coming year. At MWC 2017
column5: there have been a few standouts that lead to some interesting conclusions.LG's new G6 smartphoneis one of the most talked about releases. The company abandoned the modular design it introduced in last year's G5. The new G6 incorporates design elements expected in the iPhone 8
column6: with a glass front and back held together with a stainless-steel band.7 Best Stocks to Buy for a Donald Trump Green LightWhile bezels are still there
column7: they're been minimized by moving the power button and fingerprint sensor to the back. The result is a 5.7-inch display in a compact body - and the display is wowing with its 564 ppi pixel density and support for HDR. The LG G6 also has a dual lens 13 megapixel camera
column8: but unlike the iPhone 7 Plus
column9: the extra lens is wide angle rather than telephone.Another interesting flagship release is theP10from China'sHuawei. This new premium smartphone includesLeica-branded cameras and a Portrait Mode to compete with iPhone 7 Plus feature. In addition
column10: the P10 uses Huawei's own processor
column11: the Kirin 960. This is bad news forQualcomm
column12: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM)
column13: which is seeing more smartphone makers follow the lead of Apple by ditching the Snapdragon to develop their own customized chips.When the iPhone 8 arrives in the fall
column14: its expected all-glass design isn't going to be as unique as Apple might have hoped. Cameras are going to be a big battleground
column15: too
column16: putting pressure on Apple to go further than it did with the dual-lens iPhone 7 Plus.No Galaxy S8 at MWC 2017Samsung traditionally unveils its new Galaxy S smartphones at Mobile World Congress. Not this year. Delayed by the Galaxy Note 7 battery investigation
column17: Samsung is expected tounveil the Galaxy S8at an event on March 29.The company did take the wraps offtwo new tablets
column18: though. The Galaxy Tab S3 and Galaxy Book. The latter is offered in two different sizes
column19: runs Windows 10
column20: comes with a snap-on keyboard case and stylus and is aimed atMicrosoft Corporation's(NASDAQ:MSFT) Surface Pro.Google Assistant Coming to Android Nougat and Marshmallow DevicesAlphabet Inc.(NASDAQ:GOOG
column21: NASDAQ:GOOGL) has had a big decision to make since introducing Google Assistant. The company broke with tradition to make its new AI-powered digital assistant exclusive to its own Google Pixel smartphones. But that restriction means the number of phones running Google Assistant are outnumbered by Siri-powered Apple devices andAmazon.com
column22: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) Alexa-powered smart speakers.Google chose MWC 2017 to announce it's decided to go back to the strategy of volume over exclusivity.Google Assistant will start rolling outto devices running Android Nougat and Marshmallow starting this week.BlackBerry and Nokia Makes a Splash at MWC 2017If you'd asked anyone a few months ago what companies would be generating buzz at MWC 2017
column23: it's doubtful thatBlackBerry Ltd(NASDAQ:BBRY) orNokia Corp (ADR)(NYSE:NOK) would be anywhere on that list. But they both pulled it off. Sort of.BlackBerry's last hurrah in smartphones is the newBlackBerry KeyOne. The last phone with the company's name on it that was designed in-house combines Android with a classic BlackBerry keyboard. There's grumbling about the $549 price
column24: but a general feeling that had BBRY releasedthisphone a few years ago
column25: it might still be relevant in the smartphone space.The other big surprise was the return of the Nokia brand. Finland'sHMD Globalbought the rights to use the Nokia name on phones
column26: and at MWC 2017 it announcedthree new Nokia Android smartphonesaimed at the Chinese market.The company is also bringing back the classic Nokia 3310 cell phone. Considered to be virtually indestructible
column27: the Nokia 3310 was first released in 2000 andsold over 126 million units. The new version is a little less sturdy
column28: but has new colors
column29: and updated display and runs just over $50.Nokia gets some licensing revenue out of this
column30: but was not involved in the development of the new phones bearing its brand.Everyone Against the iPhone 8The announcements from MWC 2017 largely set the stage for the coming battle for smartphone supremacy. Samsung still must take the wraps off the Galaxy S8
column31: but after that happens
column32: we'll largely know what Apple's iPhone 8 will be up against.Alibaba Group Holding Ltd (BABA) Will Try to Dominate IndiaIt looks like Apple's 10th anniversary iPhone will face a strong field with large displays
column33: impressive cameras
column34: Google Assistant on board and new designs - at least some of which follow the direction Apple is expected to take.Who will have the best smartphone of 2017? With the big Mobile World Congress reveals over with
column35: the ball is now in Samsung and Apple's court.As of this writing
column36: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Heavy-Hitting Small-Caps That Will Wallop the Market7 REITs That Should Be CondemnedThe postMobile World Congress: Apple Inc. (AAPL) vs. Everyone Elseappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Warren Buffett Has Boosted His Apple
column2: Inc. Position Nearly Tenfold in 4 Months;2/27/2017;"Just a couple weeks ago

column4: andBerkshire Hathaway's(NYSE: BRK-A) (NYSE: BRK-B) ownership disclosures showed thatWarren Buffett nearly quadrupledhisApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) position in the fourth quarter. The Oracle of   Omaha closed out 2016 with approximately 57.4 million shares
column5: up   from the 15.2 million shares that Berkshire Hathaway was holding   at the end of the third quarter.Well
column6: it turns out that Buffett wasn't done loading up on   Apple. Not by a long shot.Berkshire Hathaway is now the single largest holder of   AppleIn aninterview with CNBCthis morning
column7: Buffett shared some more about what Berkshire   Hathaway has been buying in the early innings of 2017. Spoiler   alert: even more Apple. Since the close of the fourth quarter   that's covered by the 13F
column8: Buffett said that Berkshire continued   to buy shares up until earnings; Berkshire stopped buying shares   after earnings when shares jumped. Berkshiremore than doubledits Apple position during the month of January
column9: and its total   holdings are now approximately 133 million shares
column10: valued at   around $17 billion.makeAd('4'
column12: 'mktsnews'
column13: 'vanguard'
column15: '');While doubling an already large position over the course of a   month is already a pretty bullish signal to investors
column16: it's even   more bullish when you compound that over a longer period of time.   As mentioned above
column17: Berkshire finished the third quarter with   15.2 million shares
column18: so a position of 133 million shares   represents a nearly tenfold increase in just 4 months.Data source: SEC filings and CNBC. Chart by author.Furthermore
column19: shares are already up about 13% for February
column20: so   Berkshire's Apple position continues to perform well
column21: as shares   now trade at all-time highs.As famously averse to tech as Buffett is

column23: and so many people have   integrated the device into their daily lives that it's become   indispensable. Apple customers are also incredibly loyal
column24: so they   stick with the brand at a higher rate relative to other consumer   electronics companies. That all feeds back into cash flow
column25: since   Apple is able to generate recurring hardware revenue with ongoing   product cycles.iPhone 7 with AirPods. Image source: Apple.At this point
column26: Berkshire is the single largest holder of   Apple

column28: among others
column29: who aggregate their holdings across all   funds for reporting purposes. That includes passive funds and   ETFs that only hold Apple in order to track an underlying index
column30: although there are certainly some active funds in the mix as   well. For example
column31: the single largest mutual fund holder of Apple   is theVanguard Total Stock Market Index Fund
column32: a passive index fund that had 109.5 million shares at the end   of January (Apple is its largest holding).It's mildly ironic that an investor that's not into tech is   now the largest owner of the largest tech company.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: The Best Way to Beat the S&P 500;2/27/2017;"Investors use the Standard & Poor's index's performance to judge their own
column2: and the Holy Grail is to outperform the index consistently.But what if I told you there was a way to outperform the index consistently by buying the index itself and doing almost no work for the additional gains?Sounds appealing and almost too good to be true.makeArticleAd();Well
column3: it is true
column4: and this technique is available to every investor.The reason this is possible is the way the S&P 500 is constructed. The index is computed by a weighted average market capitalization calculated by taking the number of shares outstanding of each company and multiplying the number by the company's current share price. This is a relatively lazy way of calculating an index and gives more weight to larger constituents and less weight to smaller companies so the index is disproportionately affected by a decline inApple(AAPL) compared to a smaller firm.OutdatedThis approach has worked well since the S&P 500's inception
column5: but it isn't the best approach. Because small companies usually grow faster than their larger counterparts
column6: it doesn't make much sense to give these companies a lower weighting in the index as it stunts their impact on the broader market. Surely
column7: if small caps are given more weight
column8: the index would perform better overall?That's exactly what the S&P 500 Equal Weight Index shows. The S&P 500 Equal Weight Index does what it says on the tin. The index gives each constituent an equal weight without taking into account market capitalization or other factors. The results of using this strategy have been extremely impressive. From 2003 through 2015
column10: 000 investment in the traditional S&P 500 index would have turned into $29
column11: 370. During that same period
column12: the same investment in the S&P 500 Equal Weight Index would have turned into $38
column13: 866. Over the past five years
column14: the S&P 500Equal Weight Index has returned 26.8% compared to the traditional S&P 500's return of 23.3%.What's behind the outperformance?There is a belief that the reason why equal weighted indexes outperform traditional market capitalization weighted peers is due to the weighting of small caps in the index. However
column15: according to research conducted by Robert Ferguson and David Schofield
column16: senior investment officer and president of Intech International
column17: there is another reason why equal weight indexes tend to outperform over the long term.They believe the outperformance of equal weighted indexes has more to do with the index's constituent rebalancing than anything else. For example
column18: to maintain required equal weights
column19: the index provider has to sell a stock after a recent run higher but also buy more of a company if it has drastically underperformed over a set period. Put simply this trading requirement creates a ""buy low sell high"" trading strategy
column20: which is both contrarian and momentum chasing.Ferguson and Schofield go on to note that surprisingly the underlying alpha source is always positive for such indicators
column21: which is another indication that excess return has something to do with volatility. Equal-weighted indexes have a higher tracking error over time relative to the capitalization weighted index. The reason why this is the case lies in diversity.Diversity is at its maximum if all stock capitalizations are equal. Changes in diversity influence relative return of the equal-weighted portfolio. As the capital distribution curve has a typical shape
column22: diversity must have a typical value with no long term trend. In this case
column23: the influence due to changes in diversity will be close to zero over time
column24: and the outperformance of the equal-weighted portfolio will be close to its volatility-based source
column25: which is necessarily positive (stock returns can be both positive and negative
column26: but volatility is always positive).When the effects of diversity are combined with contrarian/momentum investing
column27: the equal weight index can capture higher alpha and less severe underperformance periods.Disclosure:The author owns no stock mentioned.Start afree seven-day trialof Premium Membership to GuruFocus.GILD 15-Year Financial DataThe intrinsic value of GILDPeter Lynch Chart of GILDPremium MembersThis article first appeared onGuruFocus."

column1: Warren Buffett On Active vs. Passive Investing
column2: Outlines 'The Bet' In Berkshire Shareholder Letter;2/27/2017;"Warren Buffett
column3: billionaire fundamental investor and CEO of Berkshire HathawayBRK.B
column4: released his annual report to shareholders outlining ""The Bet"". Nine years ago
column5: Mr. Buffett publicly bet that any set of five hedge funds could not outperform the S&P 500 index over a 10 year period of time; hedge funds charge high active management fees while the S&P 500 index is invested in through low cost index funds. Ted Seides
column6: co-manager of Protégé Partners
column7: stepped up to the plate against Mr. Buffett.Mr. Seides chose five funds-of-funds
column8: which invest in a variety of hedge funds
column9: and Mr. Buffett decided on a Vanguard S&P 500 index fund. The wager counted performance net of fees
column10: costs and expenses which boils down Mr. Buffett's thesis of his bet: passive investing will outperform active management in the long run because costs strip away high performance possibilities.Sure enough
column11: to date
column12: Mr. Buffett is ahead in the race and declared victory. The wager began on January 1
column13: 2008 and will end on December 31
column14: 2017.  Through 2016
column15: the compounded annual increase for the Vanguard index fund is 7.1% and only an average of 2.2% for the five funds-of-funds.In his letter
column16: Mr. Buffett writes
column17: ""The bottom line: When trillions of dollars are managed by Wall Streeters charging high fees
column18: it will usually be the managers who reap outsized profits
column19: not the clients.""It is important to note that Mr. Buffett is not saying it is impossible to outperform the market. He prides himself on his ability to pick winning investments over losing investments. What Mr. Buffett is pointing to is that most active managers will fail; he states that more than $100 billion have been drained into bad investment advice in the past 10 years.Berkshire Hathaway never commits to holding a security

column1: Applied Materials (AMAT): Why Investors Should Include It In Their Portfolio;2/27/2017;"Applied Materials

column5: compared to its industry
column6: which has an average PE of 16.58. This means that Applied Materials is trading at a relative discount to its industry peers. It is reasonable to say that companies in this industry are decent choices for value investors but that Applied Materials is even better. No wonder

column1: Monday Apple Rumors: iPad Pro May Support 2224×1668 Resolution;2/27/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News

column3: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Monday.makeArticleAd();iPad Pro:A new rumor claims to know more about Apple's plans for the 10.5-inch iPad Pro

column5: the tech company is planning to release a 10.5-inch iPad Pro with a resolution of 2224×1668. This rumor claims that the device will have 264 PPI. It claims that the device will take up the same space as the 9.7-inch iPad Pro due to a slimmer bezel. This rumor also claims the device will launch sometime in March or ApriliPhone Warranty:Apple is changing its stance on iPhone screen repairs and warranties
column6: 9to5Macnotes. The tech company is changing its policy so that third-party screen repairs of iPhone devices no longer void the warranty. This was discovered in a new memo that was sent out to employees of its retail stores. However
column7: if the repaired display gets in the way of a repair
column8: customers will still have to pay the out of warranty fee. This is also true if the problem has to do with the third-party display.Developer Betas:Apple has released several new developer betas today

column10: macOS Sierra 10.12.4
column11: and watchOS 3.2. These betas give developers access to the updated operating systems before their final release to the public. This lets them test out new features that will be coming to the devices and prepare for changes.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postMonday Apple Rumors: iPad Pro May Support 2224×1668 Resolutionappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Get Paid to Trade International Business Machines Corp. (IBM) Stock;2/27/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI have not been a fan ofInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM) for a long time. It is my opinion that management was slow to shift cash cows. They lost their way and have yet to recover. They have been trying to carve a niche in artificial intelligence
column3: but that story has been over a decade in the making. To use a poker term
column4: they are pot-committed to AI.makeArticleAd();Luckily
column5: artificial intelligence has seen a recent resurgence in popularity so the wait may actually pay off to IBM longs.Experts are in awe of what Watson can do. Unfortunately
column6: its profit stream is taking too long to develop. IBM is no longer the sure long-term bet it once was. To me
column7: it more resembles a startup with a cool product still finding its way.Click to EnlargeUsually
column8: I like to sell longer-dated risk in companies that I believe are long-term winners likeAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column9: NASDAQ:GOOGL) orApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL). In this case
column10: I am putting my trust in the IBM price action more so than its fundamentals.The Bet:Sell the IBM Oct $130 put. This is a bullish trade for which I collect $1.40 per contract to open. This trade has a 90% theoretical chance of success. This sounds like a great idea now
column11: but it comes with risk. By selling the put naked
column12: I am committing to buying the stock at $130 per share if IBM falls below it. Anything below $128.60 per share would accrue losses for me.The 7 Best ETFs for Retirement InvestorsSelling naked puts is not suited for most investors
column13: so I can modify the trade to make it more attainable.The Alternate:Sell IBM $140/$135 credit put spread. This also is a bullish trade
column14: but one with a finite risk profile. I collect 40 cents per contract to open. The 22% price buffer is smaller than that of selling the $130 naked put but for the finite risk profile advantage.While 40 cents may sound too little
column15: it would represent an 8% yield on money risked and for the high chance of success it carries it should elate most investors.I chose longer-dated risk so I don't have to fret the short-term gyrations. I find that longer-dated options risk is easier to manage. Also
column16: I can close either of these trades at any time for partial gains or losses.Nicolas Chahine is the managing director ofSellSpreads.com. As of this writing
column17: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities. You can follow him on Twitter at@racernicand stocktwits at@racernic.More From InvestorPlace7 REITs That Should Be CondemnedExxon Mobil Corporation (XOM) Should Keep an Eye on Tesla Inc (TSLA)7 Blue-Chip Stocks That Are Flush With CashThe postGet Paid to Trade International Business Machines Corp. (IBM) Stockappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: These 2 High-Yield Dividend Stocks Are Ridiculously Cheap;2/26/2017;"Many dividend investors search for companies that have fat   yields and trade for an attractive valuation. Of course
column2: companies with high dividend yields can be risky
column3: so potential   owners need to be quite picky about which stocks they choose to   buy.Let's take a closer look at two stocks --Spark Energy(NASDAQ: SPKE) andGameStop(NYSE: GME)  -- that both have above-average yields and low   valuations. Is either stock worth buying?Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();A different energy choiceMany consumers who live in deregulated energy markets might be   surprised to learn they have a choice of electricity and gas   providers. Spark Energy is one of the many independent   retail energy-services companies in the country that offers a   competing choice.Spark Energy isn't an energy producer. It buys energy and gas   on the wholesale market and resells it to consumers at retail   prices. The company claims that switching to its service in   many cases can help its customers save money.While persuading customers to make the switch can be tough
column4: Spark has been in rapid growth mode over the past few years
column5: thanks to its healthy appetite for acquisitions. Since its 2014   IPO
column6: it has completed seven acquisitions
column7: which has helped   consistently drive its top line higher. When combined with the   company's generous dividend policy -- Spark's current yield is   5.7% -- shareholders have seen significant value   creation.SPKE Total Return Pricedata byYChartsGiven that the retail energy-services market is highly   fragmented
column8: Spark appears to help plenty of room left to expand.   With shares trading for about 9 times forward earnings
column9: the   numbers suggest that this could be a home-run investment in the   making.However
column10: while all of Spark's numbers look great
column11: there are a   few warning signs. For one
column12: companies that grow by acquisition   are notoriously difficult to understand
column13: since their   financial statements are always changing. That makes them   difficult to value
column14: and it can be easy for management to hide   internal problems. In addition
column15: Spark has received a lot of   terrible reviews on sites such asYelpand the Better Business Bureau
column16: from customers who claim the   company used high-pressure sales techniques to get them to switch   and who then saw their energy bills rise. Finally
column17: with more than   42% of the company's publicly available shares having been   shorted
column18: a lot of money managers are betting big against this   company.A retailer in transitionJust as in the DVD and music business
column19: video-game consumers   are gradually shifting away from buying physical products and   looking toward digital channels to get their fix. That trend has   been a thorn in the side of   video-game retailer GameStop over the past few   years. The increasing popularity of digital games has created   less of a need to visit one of the company's stores
column20: putting   downward pressure on its sales. Management has admitted that the   trend is here to stay and has projected a slow but steady decline   in its legacy business.However
column21: there are reasons to believe that the decline won't   be as steep as you'd first expect. Cutting-edge video games for   the PlayStation 4 or Xbox One can sometimes require up to 40   gigabytes of storage space to play
column22: which is many multiples   higher than video or music files. That's one reason digital   penetration of high-quality video games still remains relatively   low. In addition
column23: digital games can't be resold the way physical   games can. That provides an incentive for gamers to continue to   visit GameStop's stores.Meanwhile
column24: GameStop is looking for other ways to drive sales   growth. The company has created its own digital gaming   platform that currently rings up more than $1 billion in digital   sales. Management is also making a move into the collectible   space through its acquisition of ThinkGeek
column25: and sales are growing   quickly. In fact
column26: management believes that this business could   hit $1 billion in revenue by 2019.Finally
column27: GameStop is pushing hard into the mobile and   computing market with its Spring Mobile and Simply   Mac concepts. These stores are leading authorized resellers   of products fromAT&TandApple. Believe it or not
column28: these new sales channels are expected to   drive modest earningsgrowthover the next five years.Still
column29: many investors are worried that this strategy shift   won't work in the long run and have priced GameStop's shares   accordingly. The company is trading for less the ridiculously   cheap price of 7 times forward earnings
column30: and its dividend yield   has been pushed above 5.6%. More than 27% of the company's   publicly available stock has been sold sort
column31: which tells you how   little faith the markets have in this company.Is either worth buying?While Spark offers investors a high yield
column32: the potential for   growth
column33: and a cheap valuation
column34: I see too many warning signs to be   willing to put money into the stock. GameStop
column35: on the other hand
column36: is also a high-risk bet
column37: but the company is still highly   profitable and appears to have a realistic plan in place for   slowly turning its fortunes around. That makes me think GameStop   might be the better bet for daring investors.10 stocks we like better than GameStopWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column38: it can pay to listen. After all
column39: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column40: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column41: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and GameStop wasn't one of   them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better   buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column42: 2017Brian Feroldiowns shares of Apple.Brian Feroldihas the following options: short July 2017 $27 puts on     GameStop. The Motley Fool owns shares of and recommends Apple.     The Motley Fool has the following options: long January 2018     $90 calls on Apple
column43: short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple
column44: and     short April 2017 $28 puts on GameStop. The Motley Fool     recommends Yelp. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Will Apple Inc. Completely Ditch Qualcomm
column2: Inc. in the iPhone?;2/26/2017;"Analyst Christopher Rolland with Susquehanna (by way ofBarron's) recently put out a note suggesting thatIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) may be able to wrestle away more cellular modem   market share fromQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) in futureApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) iPhone models.By way of background
column3: Apple currently sources cellular modems   from both Intel and Qualcomm in its iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus   smartphones. Rolland estimates that Qualcomm has between a 50%   and 70% share of iPhone modem shipments
column4: leaving Intel with   between 30% and 50%.A wafer of Intel processors. Image source: Intel.makeArticleAd();The analyst points out that Intel's recently announced XMM   7560 modem supports the CDMA wireless standard
column5: a feature that   Intel's previous modems have lacked. Since some wireless carriers   require CDMA support
column6: Apple couldn't completely abandon Qualcomm   in the iPhone.""We believe CDMA support was a gating issue in winning the   majority of iPhone 7 sockets
column7: as select global carriers require   the standard
column8: Rolland writes.The analyst then says if Apple were to ditch Qualcomm   completely in favor of Intel modems
column9: it would lead to a $1.1   billion to $1.4 billion reduction in Qualcomm's revenue and a   drop of between $0.25 and $0.35 per share in earnings.Intel
column10: the analyst says
column11: could stand to see revenue grow by   between $800 million and $1.1 billion from such a switch
column12: with   earnings per share growing between $0.06 and $0.08.There's little doubt that having a CDMA-capable modem only   helps Intel and hurts Qualcomm as it relates to the iPhone
column13: but I   don't think it's realistic to expect Apple to fully ditch   Qualcomm. Here's why.Two suppliers are better than oneThere are good reasons to have multiple suppliers for critical   components. Having multiple suppliers helps to guard against   potential execution problems on the part of a single supplier
column14: such as supply issues and product-quality issues.To be blunt
column15: Qualcomm's track record with respect to cellular   modem advancements is impeccable; Intel's execution
column16: meanwhile
column17: seems to have improved solidly over the years
column18: but it's still not   a good idea to bet the iPhone on Intel.Beyond risk mitigation
column19: though
column20: having multiple competent   suppliers in the mix improves the buyer's ability to negotiate   prices to its benefit.Remember
column21: until Intel announced the XMM 7560
column22: Apple   essentially had one company from which it could buy CDMA-capable   LTE modems -- Qualcomm. So if Apple wanted to sell phones   compatible with networks that required CDMA support
column23: it needed to   buy chips from Qualcomm -- period.Moreover
column24: in a recent lawsuit that Apple filed against   Qualcomm
column25: the former claims the latter charged Apple a   ""monopolistic premium"" for cellular modems with CDMA support
column26: even though those chips were ""in all other respects identical to   the chipsets sold to Apple without CDMA functionality   enabled.""If Apple had previously had multiple supplier options for   CDMA-capable LTE modems
column27: Qualcomm might not have been able to get   away with charging such a premium.So by having both Qualcomm and Intel in the mix supplying   modems that are
column28: for all intents and purposes
column29: interchangeable
column30: Apple should be able to lower its component costs and ultimately   either boost its gross profit margins or redirect the savings to   adding more features to future iPhone models.Qualcomm may see lower allocationThough I don't think it's likely for Qualcomm to lose all the   iPhone business
column31: I could see Qualcomm's share at Apple come down.   Further
column32: I could see Qualcomm's average selling prices of the   chips that it does sell to Apple coming down from where they   would have otherwise been if Intel weren't on the verge of   releasing a CDMA-capable modem.The situation doesn't look great for Qualcomm
column33: and it looks   pretty good for Intel
column34: but in the scheme of both companies'   respective consolidated revenues
column35: this just isn't a potential   game changer for either one.10 stocks we like better than QualcommWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column36: it can pay to listen. After all
column37: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade

column1: 3 Horrendously Bad Stock Market Predictions From Otherwise Smart People;2/26/2017;"""It's tough to make predictions
column2: especially about the future.""-- Yogi BerramakeArticleAd();Every year
column3: the stock market either advances
column4: declines
column5: or stays flat. It's never clear beforehand which direction these indexes
column6: or the stocks that comprise them
column7: will move; the reasons for their price swings only make sense in retrospect.But that truth doesn't stop people from making aggressive predictions attempting to identify the Next Big Thing or to call a coming crash or boom. Here are a few classic examples of some smart market watchers getting burned by their stock calls.1. McDonald's will trounce Google as an investmentWhitney Tilsonhas used his value investing approach to produce awesome returns for himself and his investors over the years. Yet his tendency to bash ""expensive"" companies with high price-to-earnings ratios has also burned the hedge fund giant -- big time.For example
column8: back in 2004
column9: Tilson made abold prediction. Writing for The Motley Fool at the time
column10: he said the soon-to-be-publicAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOGL) (NASDAQ: GOOG) (a.k.a. Google) would almost certainly flame out as a business. ""I'd wager that odds are at least 90% that its profit margins and growth rate will be materially lower five years from now
column11: he argued.Tilson got even more specific
column12: saying thatMcDonald's(NYSE: MCD) would make a much better bet given its far lower valuation. ""I believe that it is virtually certain that Google's stock will be highly disappointing to investors foolish enough to participate in its overhyped offering -- you can hold me to that
column13: he concluded.GOOGL Market Capdata byYCharts.So how did that prediction pan out? Since 2005
column14: Alphabet shares are up roughly 16 times
column15: compared to less than a 400% return for the fast food titan. The search engine giant produced nearly $20 billion of net income last year
column16: versus McDonald's $4.5 billion. Today
column17: Alphabet is worth almost six times McDonald's in the eyes of the market.2. Smartphones will be a bustA deep understanding of technology isn't enough to protect you from being surprised by major shifts in the industry. Andrew Grove was one of the founders ofIntel
column18: which profoundly shaped the semiconductor industry. He wasTime Magazine's Man of The Year in 1997. Yet in 1992 he made a prediction that looks amazingly shortsighted in retrospect.Image source: Getty Images.ANew York Timesarticledescribed Grove as standing diametrically opposed to the position taken byApple(NASDAQ: AAPL)  that smartphones
column19: then imagined as ""personal communicators
column20: might develop into a huge business. They'd be ""the mother of all markets
column21: according to Apple's then-CEO
column22: John Sculley.Grove disagreed. The idea of a communicating device that people carried around with them is ""a pipe dream driven by greed
column23: he said. Ironically
column24: the article lists a few predictions about the technology that proved prescient. These personal communicators might handle emails
column25: use GPS to map directions
column26: and even allow someone to ""order pizza using a combination of custom electronic forms and wireless fax.""Today
column27: the smartphone industry is massive
column28: with Apple accounting for nearly 150 million iPhone sales in the past year. These devices helped spur over $24 billion of complementary service-based revenue
column29: which demonstrates that
column30: if anything
column31: investors weren't being greedy enough about the potential for smartphones to find a huge market.3. The Dow is headed to 36
column32: 000James Glassman's 1999 book titledDow 36
column33: 000hasn't aged well. In fact
column34: Washington Post economics columnist Neil Irwincalled it""perhaps the most spectacularly wrong investing book ever"" given that it forecast a massive rally for stocks between 1999 and 2004.Glassman's timing couldn't have been worse. The Dow hit 14
column35: 000 the year his book published before plummeting to a 15-year low of 7
column36: 000 in 2009. A roaring rally has pushed the blue-chip index back to new highs recently
column37: but today it's still 42% below the mark he believed the Dow would achieve over a decade ago.^DJIdata byYCharts.To his credit
column38: Glassman has taken a hard look at how his prediction could have been so far off the mark. He identified two major factors thathe and his co-author missed: earnings growth and the attitude of investors as reflected in the price-to-earnings multiples they are willing to pay for stocks. Neither trend went in the direction they had targeted.A better wayThese failed forecasts illustrate how overconfidence can prove fatal to your portfolio while predictions about economic trends are rarely more than a distraction from the business of accumulating stock market returns.Bold predictions are compelling because they attract debate and can pay big dividends if proven correct. But no one knows which direction stocks or markets will move over the short term. That's why investors are better off simply buying a diverse group of solid stocks and holding on to the shares for years (or decades) while allowing the power of compound returns to do all of the hard work.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column40: the newsletter they have run for over a decade

column1: 3 Great Stocks for Your Roth IRA;2/25/2017;"One of the best retirement vehicles investors can take   advantage of is aRoth IRA-- which is similar to a traditional IRA except that the money   put in is already taxed
column2: so that when the account owner needs to   pull it out later on
column3: they can do so without paying taxes on   those earnings and withdrawals. Limits on Roth IRAs are strict;   in 2017
column4: most investors can contribute just $5
column6: but once that   money is in there
column7: where should it go?For those looking for individual stocks that could make for   great long-term Roth IRA holdings
column8: here's whyApple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column9: Starbucks(NASDAQ: SBUX)
column10: andWalt Disney Co.(NYSE: DIS) could be prime targets.makeArticleAd();AppleApple has a lot going for it with a great track record of   generating market-beating returns while remaining robust enough   to be very stable amid market or regional corrections. The iPhone   still makes up the largest chunk of the company's sales
column11: and the   well-performing iPhone 7 showed that the company has plenty of   power left in that product -- and its future iterations -- for   continued growth.Image source: Apple Inc.Apple is also working to grow not only its personal computer   and other smaller segments
column12: but especially its services segment
column13: which includes revenue from services such as iTunes
column14: iCloud
column15: and   Apple Pay
column16: and it grew sales 18% year over year to $7.2 billion   (just under 10% of total sales) in fiscal 2017 Q1 ended Dec. 31.   When it comes to long-term future growth drivers
column17: Apple is   betting on areas like home artificial intelligence
column18: autonomous   driving
column19: and likely many areas the public doesn't know about   yet.The company has a whopping nearly $240 billion cash pile
column20: making it by farthe wealthiest company in the U.S.
column21: and in fiscal year 2016
column22: Apple increased its research and   development spending by about 25% to $10 billion -- a good sign   of exciting announcements to come in 2017 or the years to   come. Finally
column23: there's Apple's valuation. The stock   currently trades at just 16 times earnings -- only 13 times   forward earnings estimates -- making it one of the cheapest tech   stocks you could find for such a well-performing company.StarbucksThe joke that there's a Starbucks on every corner has been   around for a long time -- the clip below from the popular TV show   ""The Simpsons"" is from an episode that's nearly 20 years   old. And yet
column24: the company continues to announce ambitious   plans for store count growth. In the most recent earnings report
column25: Starbucks had a total of 25
column26: 734 locations open   worldwide
column27: with another 12
column28: 000 in the pipeline over the   next four years alone. A new Starbucks is currently opening in   China every 15 hours
column29: according to management.Starbucks continues to be a remarkable branding story
column30: and   that's especially true in regions like China
column31: where it's growing   its presence and prestige among younger generations there.   However
column32: it's not just that the company has a history of   continued store growth with plenty of open space for more   development
column33: but it's proven to be a shrewd operator with   increased efficiency to draw more and more profits from its   stores.For the recently announced fiscal 2017 Q1
column34: Starbucks reported   an 11% rise in EPS year over year
column35: and it expects a similar   result for full-year 2017. Starbucks' massively successful   loyalty program and the company's willingness to continually try   new initiatives like new high-end Reserve chains point to   this company's ability to continue to dominate in its market and   reward investors for many years to come.Image source: Walt Disney Co.Walt Disney Co.Disney stockhas been on an impressive run lately
column36: up 22% in the last four   months. Still
column37: that follows the company spending most of 2016 out   of Wall Street's favor
column38: falling from its high of around $120 in   November 2015 to below $90 in early 2016. The stock is still down   about 9% from its 2015 high
column39: but it could be prepared for much   higher long-term gains.Disney has multiple growth avenues ahead
column40: including the most   obvious of continuing to pump out record-setting movies within   its tentpole franchises like Star Wars and Marvel
column41: and also   original hits that the company proves it's apt to keep doing.   Other avenues for growth
column42: such as its successful theme park   segment
column43: which is likely to grow more in 2017 with the first full   year of the new Shanghai Disney Resort open and the recent   announcement that Disney is slightly raising ticket prices at its   U.S. theme parks
column44: continue to bode well for the company's future   earnings as well.Trading at just 19 times earnings and only 16 times   forward-looking earnings for next year's estimates
column45: Disney stock   looks plenty cheap now
column46: including a small but growing dividend
column47: solid balance sheet
column48: and strong operating cash growth. Add that   to the fact that the company grew diluted earnings per share 17%   year over year in fiscal year 2016 and is expected to   grow earnings per share 10% on average in each of the next   five years
column49: and the stock -- just like Apple and Starbucks --   looks like a great value for a long-term-focused Roth IRA.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Tech Most Popular Sector for Investment Fund Managers in 2017;2/24/2017;"Data show that Silicon Valley darlings once again captured the interest of stock fund managers looking to cash in on the sector's growth and dreams in the fourth quarter of 2016.In a ranking of the 20 S&P 500 stocks that U.S. funds managing more than $1 million bought the most

column4: Alphabet (GOOGL)

column7: Cisco (CSCO)
column8: Alphabet (GOOG) and Intel (INTC). Microsoft and Apple also saw the most buying in the S&P 500

column1: Texas Instruments vs. Skyworks: Which Semiconductor Stock Should You Buy?;2/24/2017;"After a short period of post-election uncertainty
column2: the technology sector rebounded with a strong fourth quarter earnings season. Within this broad sector
column3: the semiconductor industry has been one of the best performers this year
column4: and it is clear that demand for chips is high in a variety of different areas.While we are seeing strength throughout the semiconductor industry
column5: it has been the traditional giants that have really impressed investors recently. Companies like Skyworks SolutionsSWKShave garnered impressive momentum
column6: while behemoths like Texas InstrumentsTXNlook poised to continue growing thanks to changing consumer behavior.By taking a look at what is driving the semiconductor industry right now and familiarizing ourselves with the recent performance of these stocks
column7: we can make a more educated decision on whether Texas Instruments or Skyworks is the better fit for your portfolio.The State of SemiconductorsIt is always important to consider the impact that mobile phones have on the semiconductor industry
column8: as some companies-such as Skyworks-depend on supplying companies like AppleAAPLfor a solid chunk of their revenue.However
column9: newer demands like the Internet of Things (IoT) and driverless vehicles have opened up growth areas for these semiconductor giants. Our world is becoming increasingly connected and semiconductor companies stand to benefit.IoT technology promises to connect our household and commercial items to a wireless network in order to make our lives easier. This could mean the remote operation of a house's security system
column10: or it could mean manufacturers instantly tracking the performance of their machines. Either way
column11: semiconductor companies are the ones making the electronic and sensor technologies (also read:How to Invest in the ""Internet of Things"").We are also seeing a similar situation play out within the car. Sure
column12: fully autonomous cars are still a few years away from being commercially available
column13: but the new ""connected car"" is very much a modern-day reality. Over the past few years
column14: driving has evolved into an experience that now incorporates several new technologies to promote better comfort and safety. This has been another key growth area for semiconductors.Right now
column15: the Semiconductor-General industry sits in the Top 6% of the Zacks Industry Rank
column16: which really highlights the strength of this business.TXN vs. SWKSAs we jump into the head-to-head comparison between Texas Instruments and Skyworks
column17: let's check out a few key stats from both companies:TXNSWKSZacks Rank#1 (Strong Buy)#2 (Buy)VGM ScoreBAP/E Ratio21.0216.39Current Quarter Est. Revisions111Avg. Surprise (Trailing Four Quarters)7.09%2.65%Proj. EPS Growth9.86%12.71%YTD % Price Change5.84%29.53%Simply put
column18: there are several indicators of strength for both of these stocks right now. Skyworks is interesting because of its impressive VGM grade of ""A
column19: as well as its incredible momentum so far this year. The stock has significantly outpaced the S&P 500
column20: and despite its size
column21: the company is still growing earnings at a solid rate.Texas Instruments is also displaying some strong metrics. The company has seen a flurry of positive estimate revisions following its most recent earnings report and guidance. It's also impressive to see a company that was founded in the 50s still able to grow earnings at nearly a double-digit rate. Of course
column22: Texas Instruments also has a bit of an edge as it currently sits at a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy)
column23: just edging out Skyworks' Zacks Rank #2 (Buy).What's WorkingThe reason why both of these companies are positioned so strongly right now is that they have both been targeting these previously discussed high-growth areas.While Apple still accounts for about 40% of Skyworks' quarterly revenue
column24: the company has actively targeted the IoT market. During the most recent quarter
column25: Skyworks won contracts from multiple Tier 1 original equipment manufacturers
column26: and the company has been open about its belief that IoT
column27: connected cars
column28: and 5G will be significant growth drivers.Texas Instruments has a similar perspective
column29: and the company seems to have an even further focus on cars. ""Revenue increased 7 percent from the same quarter a year ago
column30: as demand for our products remained strong in the automotive market
column31: noted CEO Rich Templeton
column32: before stating that personal electronics demand was down slightly.Times are very much changing
column33: and the consumer electronics market is quite different than it was just a few years ago. But that doesn't mean semiconductor makers are struggling. In fact
column34: the companies that have successfully adapted to these changes are thriving.Stocks that Aren't in the News. Yet.You are invited to download the full
column35: up-to-the-minute list of 220 Zacks Rank #1 ""Strong Buys"" free of charge. Many of these companies are almost unheard of by the general public and just starting to get noticed by Wall Street. They have been pinpointed by the Zacks system that nearly tripled the market from 1988 through 2015 with a stellar average gain of +26% per year.See these high-potential stocks free >>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today
column36: you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days.Click to get this free reportmakeArticleAd();Skyworks Solutions

column1: Friday Apple Rumors: New iPad Pro Devices May Face Delay;2/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of new iPad Pro tablets being delayed. Today
column3: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Friday.makeArticleAd();iPad Pro Delay:A new rumor claims that AAPL is delaying shipments of its new iPad Pro devices
column4: reportsAppleInsider. According to this rumor
column5: the company will delay the 10.5-inch and 12.9-inch versions of the device. The rumor claims that these new tablets won't be out until sometime in May or June. Previous rumors have mentioned delays
column6: but many still expected the new tablets to come out during the first quarter of the year.iPhone 6 Shutdowns:Apple says that iOS 10.2.1 has fixed most of the iPhone 6 shutdown issues
column7: MacRumorsnotes. The tech company says that the update took care of 70% of shutdown issues that owners of the iPhone 6
column8: 6 Plus
column9: 6s and 6s Plus were dealing with. The update was released roughly a month ago. AAPL also notes that the problem that iOS 10.2.1 fixes wasn't the same one that had it recalling some of the devices to replace their batteries.MacBook Staingate:Apple is reportedly planning to extend its coverage of devices affected by Staingate
column10: reports9to5Mac. This report claims that the company will still be taking in certain MacBook laptops for repair that have the anti-reflective coating coming off. This problem first came to light in 2012
column11: but AAPL didn't offer a solution until 2015. The program will continue through October of 2017 and may extend even further. The tech company isn't planning to officially announce this change.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postFriday Apple Rumors: New iPad Pro Devices May Face Delayappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: How Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Can Squeeze $26B From LinkedIn;2/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIt's been six weeks sinceMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) closed its $26.5 billion acquisition of LinkedIn
column3: the largest deal ever made by the Seattle tech giant. Since the acquisition was announced in June 2016
column4: there have been plenty of opinions surrounding the steep price paid for the business networking site - somepositive
column5: somenegative- and those question marks will continue to follow Microsoft and MSFT stock until LinkedIn is able to pay its own way.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart Via FlickrI'm a fan of Microsoft stock - in late December
column6: I predicted it would hit $80 in 2017- so I'm definitely rooting for LinkedIn to keep delivering the goods as it did in its Q3 2016 earnings
column7: its last report as an independent company.Its$1.18 earnings per shareon a non-GAAP basis - 27 cents higher than what analysts were expecting - on $960 million in revenue was a major victory for LinkedIn which also saw memberships grow 18% to 467 million compared to the same quarter a year earlier. Most important
column8: it actually made a small GAAP profit of $9.1 million in the quarter.MSFT is on a roll
column9: but it will have to maintain momentum if it's going to have any chance of extracting future shareholder value of $26.5 billion or more over the next few years.Sure
column10: the LinkedIn acquisition is about more than money
column11: but ultimately that's one of the key criteria for evaluating a deal's success or failure.7 Blue-Chip Stocks That Are Flush With CashHere are the three things I believe will make the LinkedIn acquisition a success.Estimated Monthly UsersWhile LinkedIn is considered the top social media site for business networking
column12: it has just 106 million monthly active users (MAU) out of 467 million members.Facebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) has almost 18 times that
column13: with its1.86 billion MAU.Microsoft might have plans for LinkedIn that go beyond its user numbers but it's got to keep pushing the MAU metric higher because Facebook's not going to stop growing its user base
column14: especially when it comes to helping people find and secure new jobs.LinkedIn isn't going to capture anyone but the high-income segment of the workforce; currently
column15: 45% of those earning more than $75
column16: 000 use LinkedIn. That's got to be higher.Mobile Is KeyNielsen's2016 Social Media Reportreleased in January offered a really deep dive into the world of social media including mobile usage. Drawing data from 9
column17: 000 smartphone users 18 or older
column18: Nielsen was able to determine the number of unique mobile users for the top 10 social media platforms; Facebook had 178.2 million unique users compared to 60.1 million for LinkedIn or just three times the number.If LinkedIn wants to capture a bigger social media audience
column19: especially younger business professionals
column20: it's going to have to get very smart about its mobile game plan which it appears to have done delivering a revamped mobile site in 2016.""We are seeing good results with the core experience
column21: with our revamped mobile app driving significant engagement growth in 2016
column22: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella said during the company's Q2 2017 conference call. ""This quarter
column23: the sessions on LinkedIn grew more than 20% year over year
column24: a consistent level of growth throughout 2016. We also achieved record levels of mobile page view.""LinkedIn TalentThe best thing Microsoft has done to date regarding its purchase of LinkedIn ispromoting Kevin Scottto chief technology officer for the entire company. That suggests that Microsoft didn't just buy a great networking site but also got a lot of talented people including Scott
column25: who
column26: in addition to his existing roles at LinkedIn will lead Microsoft's technology plans as well.As CTO
column27: Scott will be empowered to continue to help grow Microsoft's cloud business by bringing it together with LinkedIn's network of professionals. Analysts see Microsoft's cloud businessgrowing by 33%annually over the next three years and accounting for 30% of Microsoft's overall revenue by the end of fiscal 2019.Apple Inc. vs. Alphabet Inc: Value or Growth?Often
column28: when companies merge
column29: the two businesses have vastly different corporate cultures creating turf wars between the different organizations. While early in the transition it appears that Nadella is very concerned about successfully integrating the LinkedIn team.Should this attitude remain
column30: Microsoft's got a great chance at reaping the rewards necessary to recoup its investment.Bottom Line on MSFT StockObviously
column31: it's way too early to assess the success or failure of the LinkedIn acquisition.However
column32: looking back at the last five fiscal years
column33: LinkedIn's best showing in terms of profitability was in 2012 when it had $56.9 million in operating profits on $972.3 million in revenue for an operating margin of 5.9%.If Microsoft can get LinkedIn to that operating margin within five years
column34: it will be generating approximately $354 million in operating profits on $6 billion in revenue (15% CAGR)
column35: a good start on the way to repaying the $26.5 billion.These three points will certainly help.As of this writing

The fund has a basket of 41 stocks with each security holding less than 4.57% of the assets.Information technology takes the top spot at 48.16% in terms of sectors
column20: followed by financials (27.5%) and materials (12.5%). The fund has amassed just $3.4 million in its asset base and trades in a paltry volume of roughly 1
column21: 200 shares. Expense ratio comes in at 0.80%. The fund is up about 11% in the year-to-date period (as of February 22
column22: 2017).Bottom LineWhile both funds have surged almost the same from a year-to-date perspective
column23: we suggest investors should go for EWT given its huge exposure in Taiwan Semiconductor and Hon Hai. These companies are believed to score higher on Apple's new launch.Though the economy runs risks of Trump's anti-outsourcing policy

column1: Facebook Inc Stock (FB) Pulls Back After Another High: Now What?;2/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFacebook Inc(FB) stock apparently hit a ceiling when it touched yetanother record high- the second record high in less than a month.makeArticleAd();FB shares soared to $136.79 on Wednesday before retreating on Thursday. The previous all-time high for Facebook stock was $135.49
column3: which was set on February 2.Facebook's Stock Move is Just Part of a Wider Tech TrendFB shares also managed a new record closing price on Wednesday at $136.12
column4: ahead of the previous record set on February 8
column5: which was $134.20.As Facebook stock retreated on Thursday
column6: so did most of the other big tech names that have also set record highs this year.Microsoft Corporation(MSFT)
column7: Amazon.com
column8: Inc.(AMZN)
column9: Netflix
column10: Inc.(NFLX)
column11: Alphabet Inc(GOOG) andApple Inc.(AAPL) were all in the red at the time of this writing.And all these big tech names are rising and falling pretty much in tandem with major indices
column12: including theS&P 500
column13: NASDAQ CompositeandDow Jones Industrial Average.Facebook Stock Could Drop Off SoonSo will Facebook stock be able to keep up themomentumfor the near future?Apple Inc. vs. Alphabet Inc: Value or Growth?Seeking Alphacontributor Damon Verial warns that it might not
column14: particularly because it almost always loses in March. He describes himself as ""strongly bullish"" on the name but adds that he only feels ""the urge to write about"" it when he thinks it is overvalued.He says he did call a pullback in Facebook stock in the past when it fell $10 to $123 per share over the four days following his call. Then it fell to $115 over the next two weeks.Of course the stock rallied
column15: as he says it ""always"" will
column16: but he notes that anyone who held through that pullback ""missed a significant buyback opportunity that would have more than accommodated a transition from capital gains tax on long-term holdings to income tax on short-term holdings for most sizable positions.""Verial noted that Facebook Inc (FB) stock has been in overbought territory since the end of January
column17: which means it probably won't take much to set off a downward spiral. He pointed to seasonal patterns in data on the stock showing where it almost always goes in each month.According to him
column18: Facebook stock almost always ends January in the green
column19: and its highest Sharpe ratio also is in January. Average gains during the month stand at 10%.But in February
column20: he said the stock's Sharpe ratio has fallen to zero
column21: making the month neutral. Then in March
column22: the Sharpe ratio turns negative
column23: ""hinting at a significant opportunity cost."" He adds that even long-term holders may find it beneficial to avoid the stock during the worst months
column24: which includes March
column25: May and August. These months aren't usuallyearningsmonths anyway
column26: and they're well after the holiday season at a time when spending on digital advertising starts to fall.He does feel that long is the only ""logical"" position to take on Facebook when looking at it from a long-term fundamental perspective.The postFacebook Stock Pulls Back After Touching Another Record Highappeared first onValueWalk.Many academics claim investing is a ""random walk."" We believe this to be only partially true. It is our core belief that value investing can outperform the market
column27: hence the name ""ValueWalk.""
