column1: Tuesday Apple Rumors: iPhone 8 May Come in 64GB & 256GB Versions;2/21/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today iPhone 8 specs. Today
column3: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Tuesday.makeArticleAd();iPhone 8 Specs:A new rumor may give some insight into the specs for the iPhone 8
column4: reportsMacRumors. According to this rumor
column5: Apple's next iPhone will include 3GB of RAM. It will also be available in 64GB and 256GB versions. This rumor claims the device will be 5.8-inches in size and that it won't have a fully curved display. The rumor also says that AAPL will release two other iPhone devices alongside this one later this year.Watch Display:Rumor has it that Apple will be using a different type of display when its next smartwatch comes out
column6: 9to5Macnotes. This rumor claims that the tech company is planning to use a display with a glass-film touch solution. The rumor says that this method will replace the current one
column7: which has touch panels that use two pieces of glass. The new displays will reportedly start shipping in the second half of 2017.Public Betas:Apple fans now have a couple of new public betas that they can play with
column8: reportsAppleInsider. AAPL has sent out the third public betas for iOS 10.3 and macOS 10.12.4. The iOS 10.3 beta can be downloaded over the air and the Mac App Store can be used to update to the newest macOS 10.12.4 beta. The new betas include a few new features that testers can try out before they reach the public in the final release. This includes the Find My AirPods feature on iOS and Night Shift mode for macOS.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postTuesday Apple Rumors: iPhone 8 May Come in 64GB & 256GB Versionsappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Why 42% Of Schwab Investors Are On The Prowl For Stocks;2/21/2017;"Investors know what they like
column2: and they liked the November election results and December's interest-rate increase by the Federal Reserve.Those events prompted a jump in investors who have retail accounts withCharles Schwab(SCHW) to declare themselves bullish. In a fourth-quarter survey of those investors
column3: Schwab found 42% of them said they now feel bullish. That was a big jump up from the 34% who felt that way in Q4 a year earlier.makeArticleAd();""As a result of the election
column4: clients saw an increased prospect for a reduction in personal and corporate tax rates
column5: an increased likelihood of spending on infrastructure
column6: and an increased likelihood of a reduction in regulatory burdens for some industries
column7: said Myhanh Hoskin
column8: a Schwab financial consultant
column9: who is based in Seal Beach
column10: Calif. ""The rate increase was a sign of growing strength in the economy.""Amid that widespread perception that the stock market had become increasingly worth investing in
column11: Schwab investors did as much buying as selling in the quarter.The top five U.S. holdings among all Schwab stock mutual funds wereApple(AAPL)
column12: Microsoft(MSFT)
column13: Exxon Mobil(XOM)
column14: Johnson & Johnson(JNJ) andJPMorgan Chase(JPM) as of Feb. 16
column15: according to Morningstar Inc.Apple is up 17% year to date
column16: while Microsoft is up 4%
column17: Exxon is down 10%
column18: Johnson & Johnson is up 3%
column19: and JPMorgan is up 5%.In Schwab's survey of its clients
column20: the general balance between buying and selling bodes well for the market in additional ways. ""It shows there isn't a sense of euphoria
column21: Hoskin said. ""It shows caution by many investors. And that suggests that we're not seeing a market top. That is a good thing. When you have too many people doing the same thing
column22: that tends to be a contrarian indicator.""On the other hand
column23: only 13% of investors said their top concern about the market is that it appears overdue for a correction
column24: suggesting a tone of overconfidence.In contrast
column25: a whopping 88% said they are confident about reaching their financial goals.Allocations And OutlookInvestors had 41.3% of their money in stocks
column26: 21.1% in cash
column27: 18.8% in mutual funds
column28: 11.9% in exchange traded funds
column29: and 6.9% in fixed income.And 21% of those investors said they planned to move more money into stocks during the current first quarter.Stocks were the most popular planned destination for additional allocations.ETFs were the second most popular target asset
column30: with 17% of investors saying that's where they planned to put more money.Mutual funds were the third most popular
column31: with 15% of investors saying they would move money into them in Q1.Investors were more inclined to get help in making investment decisions. The number of clients seeking planning advice rose 10% from a year earlier.RELATED:How This Mutual Fund Is Lighting Up Retirement AccountsAre Fidelity's Recent Stock Buys And Sells Retirement Account Hot Sauce?"

column1: These Are the 10-Most Admired Companies in the World;2/21/2017;"When the public votes for something the results can skew based   on perception
column2: emotion
column3: or sometimes even the desire to mess with   the outcome.That's how a $300 million state-of-the-art British polar   research ship earned the name ""Boaty McBoatface."" The question of   the ship's name was put to an internet vote
column4: and while over 7
column5: 000   names were submitted
column6: according toCNN
column7: ""Boaty McBoatface"" won easily with 124
column8: 109 votes. Votes being   open to the public have given us many questionable
column9: past-their-prime Major League Baseball all-stars
column10: as well as a   whale being tracked by Greenpeace being named Mr. Splashy   Pants.These are all ridiculous votes skewed by a playful public
column11: but   they illustrate that sometimes open voting can produce less-than   reliable results. In creating its annualMost-Admired Companies ListFortune does not leave the question open to a public vote
column12: instead the publication works with its partner Korn Ferry Hay   Group to build a list and then survey executives from the   companies that make the initial cut.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty.After starting with about 1
column13: 500 candidates (the 1
column14: 000 largest   U.S. companies ranked by revenue
column15: along with non-U.S. companies   in Fortune's Global 500 database that have revenues of $10   billion or more)
column16: the selections are cut down to the   highest-revenue companies in each industry. That leaves 680   companies in 28 countries
column17: and 3
column18: 800 insiders affiliated with   those companies voted on the list.""To determine the best-regarded companies in 51 industries
column19: Korn Ferry Hay Group asked executives
column20: directors
column21: and analysts to   rate enterprises in their own industry on nine criteria
column22: from   investment value and quality of management and products to social   responsibility and ability to attract talent
column23: Fortune explained.   This
column24: as you can see
column25: is not a fan vote
column26: but an insider's   perspective on which companies are most admired by their own   executives
column27: competitors

column1: Is Apple Inc. (AAPL) Preparing a Red iPhone 7?;2/21/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) faces a challenge over the next six months. There's an all-new iPhone 8 expected in the fall. And rivalSamsung Electronics Co Ltd(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) is expected to pull out all the stops with a comeback Galaxy S8 in coming weeks. With the threat of AAPL fans holding onto their cash for the new iPhone and the risk of Samsung getting all the attention
column3: how does the company keep sales of the relatively pedestrian iPhone 7 humming?makeArticleAd();Source: ColorWareIt sounds like AAPL may fall back to one of its favorite strategies: release a new color. If Japanese Apple blogMac Otakarais correct
column4: we could see a red iPhone 7 in March.Apple Could Face a Big Dip in iPhone SalesAAPL is accustomed to cyclical fluctuations in its iPhone sales. The numbers tend to slow in the lead-up to the fall
column5: when the new iPhone model is due to be released. However
column6: this year
column7: a confluence of factors could make that slowdown much more pronounced.The biggest factor is the iPhone 8. With the current iPhone 7
column8: AAPL is winding down its first three-year product development cycle. That means the iPhone it's trying to convince people to buy for the next six months looks virtually identical to the iPhone 6 and iPhone 6s.5 High-Tech Cash Cows Yielding Up To 6%That can already be a tough sell
column9: but the iPhone 8 isn't only the start of a new cycle - meaning it will look different and offer somecompelling new features- it's the10th anniversary iPhone. Everyone is looking to Apple to make a splash. Why would you buy a plain Jane iPhone 7 now if the completely new (and possiblyradicallynew) iPhone 8 is just months away?Then there's the Galaxy S8. Samsung is Apple's traditional rival for selling premium
column10: flagship smartphones. After having its reputation - and smartphone sales - torched by the Galaxy Note 7's exploding battery crisis
column11: Samsung is looking to the Galaxy S8 to mark its comeback. That is going to make things tougher for Apple over the next six months when it comes to attracting fence sitters
column12: upgraders and those buying their first smartphone.The Answer Is … A Red iPhone 7?Apple doesn't have many options here. It could cut iPhone 7 prices
column13: but AAPLneverdoes that. It could push up the iPhone 8 release
column14: butthat has many risks.Instead
column15: Mac Otakarais suggesting Apple will go to one of the oldest strategies in its marketing bag:a new color. And not just any new color. The blog (which has a reputation for getting a lot of these prediction right) is suggesting AAPL will release a red iPhone 7 in March.Apple has a long history of introducing new colors as a low-risk
column16: low-cost way of generating new interest in products that are getting long in the tooth. It perfected this strategy with the iPod line-up
column17: that would get a rainbow of new colors every year. It has done so in a more subdued way with the iPad and MacBook
column18: adding new variations like Rose Gold.It actually used the strategy once already with the iPhone 7
column19: introducing a glossy
column20: Jet Black option at launch.A red iPhone 7 would be the first time Apple has released such a bold color for its smartphones. I mocked one up using theskin generatorfromColorWare
column21: a company that has been successful at marketing flashy new appearances for a wide range of consumer electronics. There's no doubt
column22: a red iPhone 7 would be a looker.Apple could even release such a device under its(PRODUCT)REDbanner. This is a series of red Apple products that contribute toward a global fund to fight Aids. Most of these are accessories
column23: but a red iPhone 7 would fit right in and offer the advantage of letting AAPL promote the smartphone as part of the (PRODUCT)RED initiative
column24: making it seem less like a marketing ploy.Fossil Group Inc (FOSL) Stock Is Down
column25: But Not OutAccording toMac Otakara
column26: we should see the red iPhone 7 make an appearance in March
column27: at an event where AAPL is expected to refresh its iPad Pro lineup. Will a bold and shiny new color be enough to keep iPhone sales humming in the lead-up to the iPhone 8?That's a good question and one that will have a material impact to Apple's bottom line this year. AAPL has few other options and it sounds like the company may be willing to roll the dice with a new red iPhone 7.As of this writing
column28: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace9 Top Pharmaceutical Stocks to Buy for the Dividends7 Dividend Stocks for the Retirement You DeserveThe postIs Apple Inc. (AAPL) Preparing a Red iPhone 7?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Apple Inc. Reportedly Prepping 3 New iPhones for March Launch;2/21/2017;"Per a new report fromApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) -centric website Macotakara (viaMacRumors)
column2: Apple is prepping a couple of ""new"" iPhone models. The first   is a variant of the company's relatively low-cost
column3: small-screen   iPhone SE with 128 gigabytes of storage (current models come with   either 16 or 64 gigabytes of storage).Additionally
column4: Apple is reportedly planning to add new red   variants of both the iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus to its   lineup.Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Let's take a closer look at what these new products could   potentially do for the company's iPhone business.The new iPhone SE could help boost blended average     selling prices... or unit shipmentsOn Apple's April 2016 earnings call
column5: company CEO Tim Cook   explained that the iPhone SE ""is attracting two types of   customers.""The first set
column6: he explained
column7: are ""customers that wanted the   latest technology but wanted it in a more compact package.""""We clearly see even more people than we thought in that   category
column8: Cook added.The second set of potential iPhone SE customers
column9: per Cook
column10: were individuals ""who aspire to own an iPhone but couldn't quite   stretch to the entry price of the iPhone
column11: and we've established a   new entry [with the iPhone SE].""The iPhone SE with 16 gigabytes of storage currently sells for   $399
column12: with the 64-gigabyte version coming in at $449; the iPhone   6s with 32 gigabytes of storage sells for $549.With this rumored 128-gigabyte iPhone SE
column13: Apple has two   potential ways to try to boost revenue.The first is that it can simply ax the 16-gigabyte iPhone SE   model and offer the 64-gigabyte version at the $399 price point   and the 128-gigabyte variant at the $449 price point that the   64-gigabyte version currently occupies.That course of action has the potential to reduce blended   average selling prices (perhaps as mix shifts down to the $399   64-gigabyte version)
column14: but it could also boost overall unit demand   as value-oriented customers may be more inclined to grab an   iPhone.Alternatively
column15: Apple could simply add the 128-gigabyte iPhone   SE to the current lineup and charge
column16: perhaps $549 for it. This   might not stimulate a lot more unit demand
column17: but it could have the   effect of getting the portion of the iPhone SE-buying population   that is buying the iPhone SE for form factor and not for cost   reasons to buy a richer mix of products
column18: helping to boost blended   average selling prices.It'll be interesting to see what Apple's ultimate go-to-market   strategy will be for this product -- assuming it's real.iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus in rougeApple has been steadily adding new color choices to its iPhone   lineup over the years. In 2013
column19: Apple introduced gold
column20: in 2015 we   got rose gold
column21: and in 2016 we got black and jet black. It's   looking as though we're getting red this year.It's not clear how much impact bringing red color models into   the lineup will have on overall sales; after all
column22: are there truly   potential customers out there that haven't purchased a new iPhone   but totallywouldhave purchased an iPhone if only it had come in red?For what it's worth
column23: in a poll run by 9to5Mac
column24: 106 voters out   of a total of 15
column25: 558 said that they were most excited about a red   option coming to the iPhone 8 -- losing to all other potential   optionsexceptfor ""speed improvements.""We'll see if the introduction of red iPhone 7 and iPhone 7   Plus has any real impact on iPhone sales soon enough
column26: if this   rumor turns out to be true.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column27: it can pay to listen. After all
column28: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column30: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them! column1: Will Procter & Gamble (PG) Stock Stay Recession-Proof?;2/21/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsProcter & Gamble Co(NYSE:PG)
column3: historically one of the market's best recession insurance policies
column4: has caught fire this year. PG stock is 8% mostly on expectations activist Nelson Peltz of Trian Fund Management can turn it into a high-flyer.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)Trian has put$3.5 billioninto PG stock and now has about 2.4% of the common
column5: which has a market cap of $240 billion.Trian's track record hints it will seek board seats and push for operational changes at the Cincinnati-based company. While the fund has yet to publish a white paper onits proposals
column6: as it has done in the past
column7: speculators aren't waiting and are already piling into PG stock to watch the fun.What might fun mean for Procter & Gamble in the event of a recession?P&G Is Recession InsurancePG stock has a stellar track record as a place to ride out tough times and has paid dividends continuously for more than 125 years. While the value fell during the 2008 crisis
column8: from about $70 per share to $45
column9: the dividend increased 10% and the share price was back to its 2007 level within one year.The same thing happened following the 2000 dot-com collapse. The PG stock price halved but the dividend was increased
column10: and by 2002 it was again trading at pre-collapse levels. Procter & Gamble shares were barely touched in the 1987 crash
column11: and after two hikes in the dividend
column12: they split in 1989.7 Consumer Stocks That Will Knock Your Socks OffProcter & Gamble accomplished these financial miracles because its brands sell
column13: come rain or come shine. Crest
column14: Tide
column15: Dawn
column16: Bounty
column17: Pampers - these are essentials consumers buy when they stop buying everything else.In the current recovery
column18: Procter & Gamble has sought faster growth by consolidating brands
column19: selling its Duracell battery unit toBerkshire Hathaway Inc.(NYSE:BRK.A) and itsbeauty products unitstoCoty Inc.(NYSE:COTY).What Peltz WantsThe balance sheet currently shows over $13 billion in cash and $18 billion in long-term debt on $127 billion in assets. Cash flow from operations tops $15 billion per year. To me
column20: PG looks like a company poised to grow
column21: not downsize
column22: which is what Peltz usually wants.How can Peltz top what Procter has done already
column23: slimming from 165 brands to 66
column24: growing margins
column25: raising the dividend and buying back shares to maintain the PG stock price?By focusing on short-term profits
column26: Peltz could wind up hurting both P&G and the economy. A little fat is what you need to get through tough times. He could also hurt the larger economy. Procter's size enables it to focus on large issues likefixing the Internet advertising supply chain
column27: currently a mass of incompatible metrics and unaccountable spending.So What Happens to PG Stock?Wall Street has all sorts of ideas for improving results
column28: some of which Peltz might demand P&G directors adopt.Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Is Itching to Break All-Time HighsHe could push the company to adopt zero-based budgeting
column29: as 3G Capital has done atKraft Heinz Co(NASDAQ:KHC) andRestaurant Brands International Inc(NYSE:QSR)
column30: which owns Burger King. The problem is that doesn't always work.Peltz could also demand a break up of Procter & Gamble
column31: perhapsinto three units
column32: forcing accountability on long-tenured staff and creating pressure to cut costs.Or
column33: he could refocus P&G on developing markets
column34: taking a page from the playbook atReckitt Benckiser Group Plc (ADR)(OTCMKTS:RBGLY)
column35: buying product categories that appeal to Asian consumers and selling the rest. That's a move I can personally get behind.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column36: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing
column37: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 Stocks to Watch on Monday: Home Depot Inc (HD)

column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTraders are being met with a host of retail earnings reports to start the holiday-shortened week.Wal-Mart Stores Inc(NYSE:WMT) is up solidly on its latest report

column5: another retailer -Home Depot Inc(NYSE:HD) - is on our list of stocks to watch thanks to its own earnings report

column7: Kraft Heinz Co(NASDAQ:KHC)
column8: which made noise on the M&A front.Home Depot Inc (HD)HD shares were up in Tuesday's early trading thanks to an easy beat on the earnings front
column9: and better-than-expected revenues to boot.For its fourth quarter
column10: Home Depot reported adjusted profits of $1.44 per share
column11: a dime better than the consensus estimate. HD's top-line beat wasn't as dramatic
column12: but revs of $22.21 billion were enough to beat the mark of $21.8 billion. That came on comparable-store sales that improved by 5.8%
column13: well ahead of expectations for 3.7%.The company also projected revenue and comps growth of 4.6% for full-year 2017
column14: as well as the opening of six new stores.The 10 Best Oil Stocks to Buy Now for Big-Time GainsDividend investors had plenty to cheer about
column15: too
column16: as the quarterly payout on HD stock was hiked by 29% to 89 cents per share. That came alongside the announcement that Home Depot would raise its target dividend payout ratio from 50% to 55% of net earnings.Home Depot also replaced its previous share repurchase program with a new $15 billion plan.HD stock is up 2% in Tuesday's premarket trade.Apple Inc. (AAPL)AAPLmade an acquisition over the weekendthat could change microtechnology as we know it.The tech giant closed a deal to bring in the services ofRealFace
column17: an Israeli company based out of Tel Aviv that develops facial recognition software. Apple bought the cybersecurity firm for an estimated $2 million
column18: according toTimes of Israel.RealFace's technology combines artificial intelligence with a human element that is integrated into the software. The move could mean that future smartphone and other smart Apple devices will come equipped with facial recognition technology that will ensure thieves are unable to steal your information or get inside your phone.RealFace has also developed an app called Pickeez
column19: which combined a person's best photos through various platforms with the recognition software. The app is no longer in use.AAPL shares are 17% year-to-date.Kraft Heinz Co (KHC)KHC is sliding hard on Tuesday morning after early talks about a deal to buyUnliever plc (ADR)(NYSE:UL) have quickly fallen apart.Specifically
column20: Krafthas had a change of heartand has withdrawn its $143 billion bid.Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Is Itching to Break All-Time HighsKHC revealed on Sunday that it was no longer negotiating with Unilever because the public disclosure of its bid so early in the process made it difficult for the former to continue discussing an acquisition. The talks were supposed to be confidential
column21: but the details of the bid were leaked somehow.Additionally
column22: the two companies have different business models and cultures that could ultimately create internal strife within the combined company.If the deal had gone through
column23: it would have been the third largest takeover in history and the largest acquisition of a U.K.-based company.KHC shares are down 5% on the news.More From InvestorPlaceWal-Mart Stores Inc (WMT) Stock Isn't Coming Back. column1: 3 Best Stocks for Your Roth IRA;2/20/2017;"They say that there are only two certainties in life: death   and taxes. While you can't cheat death and better not cheat on   your taxes
column2: you can at least avoid paying Uncle Sam taxes on any   gains earned from investments held in a Roth IRA. That's why we   think that the best stocks to own in a Roth are ones that will   likely have generated substantial gains by the time you   retire.Three that we think fit that bill areApple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column3: Paycom Software(NYSE: PAYC)
column4: andMedical Properties Trust(NYSE: MPW) .Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Reducing HR headaches and generating profitsDaniel Miller(Paycom Solutions):Roth IRAs have become wildly popular in recent years
column5: and it's   pretty easy to understand why. The big selling point for a Roth   IRA is that money contributed can grow completely tax-free for   life. That means investors should focus on companies that can   grow and compound over decades; when you withdraw the money in   retirement
column6: you won't pay a dime on those earnings.For that reason
column7: if you have decades as your investing   horizon

column9: cloud-based
column10: human capital management software that helps   companies lower labor costs and drive employee engagement. The   stock's been on fire
column11: driven by both its top- and bottom-line   gains:PAYCdata byYCharts.Here's why you should like the stock long-term for a Roth IRA.   First
column12: the company has a strong competitive advantage since once   HR departments use Paycom
column13: it becomes time-consuming
column14: difficult
column15: and expensive to switch away from using its software products.   That's driven its retention rate to a staggering 91%.Another reason to buy into the stock is that CEO Chad Richison   owns roughly 13% of shares outstanding

Paycom also boasts a strong   balance sheet due to the software-as-a-service (SaaS) business   model being cloud-based and thus capital-light. These factors   make Paycom look intriguing to hold in a Roth IRA over the coming   decades.Sit back and collect a healthy income streamMatt DiLallo(Medical Properties Trust):One of the many benefits of a Roth IRA is that investors never   pay taxes on the gains
column17: which include both capital gains and   dividend income. The tax savings on dividend income can be   substantial
column18: especially for high-yield investments like real   estate investment trusts. It's why REITs make great investments   for a Roth IRA.One of my favorite REITs is Medical Properties Trust. The   company currently owns 247 hospitals across the U.S. and Europe   that it leases to hospital operators. These companies run the   hospitals and pay Medical Properties rent each month
column19: which it   returns to investors in the form of a very healthy 7.2% dividend   yield.While a yield that high is sometimes an ominous sign

column23: which provides a little extra cushion as well as some   seed money to fund additional acquisitions.Speaking of acquisitions

column27: which   should provide healthy dividend growth for years to come.Focusing on this company's solid dividendBrian Stoffel(Apple):I think putting soliddividend   stocksin your Roth IRA makes a lot of sense. That's because price   appreciation via quarterly payments is a pretty sure bet. And   unlike a traditional IRA

column1: This Guru Loves Valeant; Should You?;2/20/2017;"Hedge funds' final 13F forms for 2016 were published last week
column2: and as usual
column3: the data has been scrutinized by the financial media. There were a few surprises in the figures
column4: includingWarren Buffett(Trades
column5: Portfolio)'s new favorite position
column6: Apple(AAPL)
column7: and the general rotation away from tech toward financials.One position change that stands out
column8: however
column9: is not Buffett's move but that ofFrancis Chou(Trades
column10: Portfolio). Chou's Chou Associates is a traditional value fund
column11: and Chou is well known in the value community for his investing style.Since inception
column12: the Chou Associates Fund has achieved an average annual return for investors of around 12% by following Chou's value style. Before purchasing distressed securities
column13: he asks the following questions:makeArticleAd();What would be left if the company was forced to liquidate?How competent is the management?Is the underlying business strong enough to generate consistent cash flow?Does the company have a strong enough balance sheet to make it worth the risk?He's looking for a company with strong management that's fallen out of favor with the market
column14: that's cheap and not going to go out of business anytime soon. With these investment criteria in mind
column15: some might wonder why Chou Associates increased its position in struggling pharmaceutical company Valeant during the fourth quarter.What's with Valeant?Chou has not been aValeant(VRX) supporter for long when compared to the likes of Bill Ackman (Trades
column16: Portfolio). The fund first started buying the company in the first quarter of 2016 after the stock had more than halved in price from its $250 per share high. Chou continued to buy in the second quarter
column17: adding 470
column18: 000 shares to his existing basket of 980
column19: 000 shares acquired during the first three months of the year. For the final quarter of 2016
column20: Chou increased his position further by 36% or 514
column21: 000 shares. Overall
column22: the stock now accounts for 9.4% of Chou's overall portfolio
column23: the third-largest position afterJPMorgan(JPM) andBerkshire Hathaway(NYSE:BRK.A).The big question is
column24: what should investors make of this buying by Chou? Does his buying signal there's value on offer at Valent?Value on offer?Interestingly
column25: Chou is one of the only fund managers to own Valent. Jeff Ubben's ValueAct Capital and Ackman are the only other managers to own substantial positions in the firm. This either means Chou sees something most don't
column26: or he's lost it
column27: which is what most people tend to think when a manager takes a nonconsensus position.Even though Chou is the only hedge fund manager buying the stock
column28: Valent isn't as unloved as most believe. In a substantial vote of confidence for the company
column29: management is also becoming one of the company's largest investors. Last year
column30: while Chou was adding to his position management acquired over $5 million of stock for itself
column31: a strong signal that it believes the company can return to health.But even if management is optimistic about Valent's outlook
column32: the one thing that's certain about the company is that its financials are a car crash and an accident waiting to happen. Even though the current management team has managed to lock in $2.1 billion of acquisitions
column33: debt remains high at $30 billion. Another $8 billion of acquisitions is currently in the cards. The company is dependent upon the kindness of capital markets to keep the lights on. If creditors get spooked
column34: there's no chance the group will be able to meet its obligations
column35: and that's a big red flag for value investors.Still
column36: the company is not a total basket case. Indeed
column37: JPMorgan analyst Chris Schott and team are expecting the group to report solid earnings figures this year
column38: making the stock look cheap on a forward basis:""Following Valeant's recently announced divestitures and ahead of 2017 guidance
column39: we wanted to refresh estimates and update our outlook for Valeant. We are again lowering our estimates to reflect 1) the company's recently announced asset sales
column40: 2) a more conservative view of Valeant's diversified products division
column41: and 3) FX headwinds. Our new 2017 EPS and EBITDA estimates are $4.30 billion and ~$3.7 billion.""Disclosure:The author owns no stock mentioned.Start a free seven-day trial of Premium Membership to GuruFocus.Premium MembersThis article first appeared onGuruFocus."

column1: 3 Companies That Need to Kick Their CEO to the Curb;2/19/2017;"Sometimes
column2: changes need to be made to the top because of   deep-rooted organizational problems. Other times
column3: someone else is   necessary to take a company to the next level. Our Motley Fool   contributors think it may be time for changes in management atFitbit(NYSE: FIT)
column4: Depomed(NASDAQ: DEPO)
column5: andTwitter(NYSE:TWTR) . Read on to see why they think these companies might do   better under someone else.Say it isn't soTim Brugger(Fitbit): When co-founder and CEO James Park announced preliminary fourth   quarter and 2016 annual results on Jan. 30 there was little   to like. Fitbit's poor revenue results are expected to be   well below analyst estimates
column6: and Fitbit will shave overhead   primarily through job cuts impacting ""approximately 110 people
column7: equal to 6% of its workforce. And the worst was yet to come.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Despite tepid revenue growth
column8: Fitbit's gross margins will be   ""materially below its previously issued 46% forecast"" due to   excess inventory. Fitbit sales are on an uptick
column9: but not close to   expectations. But the news that warrants Park being on the wrong   end of a kick -- if not to the curb
column10: then awfully close --   is Fitbit's plan to enter the smartwatch wars.The move to join the likes ofApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) and its Watch wasn't surprising given Fitbit's   recent acquisitions of Pebble and Vector Watch software assets
column11: but Park's decision is still wrong. Apple knows first-hand the   smartwatch boom many had expected hasn't materialized.According to IDC 2016's third calendar quarter was dismal for   smartwatch sales
column12: declining 52%. The Apple Watch no longer has   the appeal of being new which resulted in a 72% nosedive to 1.1   million units. And Fitbit wants to join the sinking smartwatch   ship?If watches actually become ""smart"" rather than expensive   fitness trackers the market may change. But if it does
column13: how many   consumers will opt for Fitbit over Apple orSamsung? And Fitbit will spend massive resources to develop its device
column14: above the acquisitions already squandered. Park is leading Fitbit   into a battle that's already lost.Investors could lobby for change at the topTodd Campbell(Depomed): Activist investor Starboard Value L.P. took a nearly 10% stake   in drugmaker Depomed last year to lobby for a sale
column15: but so far
column16: little has happened to encourage investors that will happen
column17: and   as a result
column18: Depomed's shares have sunk 46% since July   2015.Initially
column19: Depomed's board of directors clashed with Starboard   Value's Jeff Smith. However
column20: the board agreed last fall to allow   Smith to pick three people to join Depomed's board of directors.   Also
column21: because Smith had been critical of management's rejection   of a $33 per share offer fromHorizon Pharma(NASDAQ: HZNP) in mid-2015
column22: the board agreed to entertain bids   from suitors.Unfortunately
column23: Depomed's full-throttle rejection of Horizon   Pharma's prior bid appears to have soured Horizon Pharma on   making another offer. Rumors of interest from Purdue Pharma
column24: the maker of the top selling Oxycontin
column25: appear off-the-mark
column26: and   reported interest from investment firm KKR hasn't led to a deal   either.Absent a buyer
column27: I think pressure will mount on Depomed CEO Jim   Schoeneck to prove to investors that his course is the right   one. Previously
column28: rapid sales growth for Depomed's opioid   pain medicine
column29: Nucynta
column30: helped Schoeneck make his case
column31: but   opioid prescriptions have slumped on rising concern over abuse
column32: and that's slowing Nucynta's momentum.While Depomed hasn't reported its fourth-quarter figures yet
column33: anemic results in Q3
column34: including 5% year-over-year top-line   growth
column35: prompted Schoeneck to kick-off the company's third   quarter earnings conference call admitting that quarterly   results ""fell well short of our expectations.""Given Depomed's shares are trading at about half the price   that Horizon Pharma was once willing to pay
column36: and sales growth is   slowing
column37: it wouldn't shock me if Starboard's next move is to   lobby for replacing Schoeneck. Whether someone else would do   better is anyone's guess
column38: but bruised investors are eager for   some positive news out of this company
column39: and that could mean that   change is coming.Hey hey
column40: ho ho
column41: Jack Dorsey has got to go!Rich Smith(Twitter): Jack Dorsey
column42: ladies and gentleman! Let's give him a hand -- and   then show him the door!Jack Dorsey co-founded internet icon Twitter in 2006. For   this
column43: he deserves to be congratulated
column44: as Twitter has ultimately   grown into perhaps the most important tool for monitoring   breaking news on the internet. Where Dorsey has failed
column45: however
column46: is in taking this leading internet platform -- one so useful that   the President of the United States has adopted it as his go-to   medium for communicating with the public -- and finding a way to   earn a profit from it.I mean
column47: think about this for a second: Twitter has more than   300millionmonthly users. Donald Trump made Twitter an integral part of his   winning presidential campaign and continues to tweet from   the Oval Office. These days
column48: you can't open up a newspaper   without seeing a headline about some bit of breaking news from   the White House that first appeared on Twitter. And yet
column49: in the   same quarter in which Donald Trump was elected President
column50: Twitter   experienced literally zero user growth
column51: achieved only single   digit revenue growth -- and made no profit whatsoever.Apologies for speaking so bluntly here
column52: but while Dorsey has   the right tool in hand
column53: he clearly doesn't know how to use it.   Hand this guy a hammer
column54: and he'd try to open a can of beans with   it -- and fail.WithTwitter stocknow down 73% from its highs of 2013
column55: and down 40% from when   Dorsey re-took over the business as CEO in October 2015
column56: enough   is enough. Jack Dorsey had his chance to fix Twitter's business
column57: and he failed. It's time to place a want-ad and hire a   handyman who can use this tool to finally earn Twitter stock   owners some profit.10 stocks we like better than TwitterWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Is Apple
column2: Inc. About to Kill Touch ID?;2/19/2017;"Touch ID has been an unqualified success. By integrating   biometric security into iPhones
column3: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) raised the bar in terms of what consumers expect   of their smartphones
column4: and rivals expectedly followed suit by   implementing their own fingerprint sensors shortly thereafter.   But there's been some speculation for years that Apple is   interested in removing the home button on future iPhones
column5: which   just so happens to be where the Touch ID sensor is integrated.   Meanwhile
column6: it may adopt some sort of 3D facial recognition oriris scanningtechnology to bolster the iPhone's biometric security.Would Apple really kill Touch ID altogether?Rumor has itThat's the theory thatJPMorgananalyst Rod Hall is putting forth (viaMacRumors). Hall believes that Apple will finally pull the trigger on   killing the home button with the iPhone 8
column7: Apple's   10th-generation iPhone due out later this year. This would allow   the company to implement an edge-to-edge display. Apple is   reportedly looking to include a 3D laser scanner that would allow   for facial recognition
column8: a component that runs around $10 to   $15.makeArticleAd();Touch ID made Apple Pay possible. Image source: Apple.Hall notes that Touch ID sometimes fails
column9: like in wet   conditions. iPhones have been getting progressively more   waterproof
column10: so using Touch ID under wet conditions is more common   nowadays. Facial recognition could work more seamlessly
column11: and   could even be used for Apple Pay authentication. It's also worth   pointing out that since facial recognition is very   software-intensive
column12: the performance would likely be able to   improve over time via software updates as the recognition   algorithms improve over time. It's even possible that the laser   scanner could be used for augmented reality applications
column13: something CEO Tim Cook has beendiscussing at lengthin recent months
column14: which could similarly be added later on via a   software update.Third-party developers might eventually even get access to a   3D scanning application programming interface (API)
column15: which has   the potential to unleash a wave of innovation.Will Touch ID join the headphone jack?If you recall
column16: Touch ID was based on Apple's 2012 acquisition   ofAuthenTec for $356 million
column17: which itself was a clear signal that Apple was planning on   integrating fingerprint sensors. Touch ID would debut the   following year in 2013's iPhone 5S
column18: and subsequently made its way   throughout the iPhone portfolio. While it would be a shame to   shutter Touch ID
column19: Apple has sold 690 million total iPhones and   generated nearly $450 billion in iPhone revenue since the iPhone   5S launch
column20: so it certainly got its money worth from the   acquisition since Touch ID has been a key feature that   contributed to sales growth ever since.2016 MacBook Pros with Touch Bar were the first Macs to get     Touch ID. Image source: Apple.What's more peculiar
column21: however
column22: is the fact that Apple only   recently brought Touch ID to the Mac in last year's MacBook Pros   with Touch Bar. This was widely seen as a starting point
column23: and   Apple is expected to subsequently bring Touch ID to the rest of   the Mac lineup. Apple is already testing out stand-alone   keyboards with Touch ID for Mac desktops
column24: according to a   Bloomberg report from December.Instead of killing Touch ID
column25: Apple should just supplement it   with facial recognition instead of replacing it since Touch ID   has become an integral part of how users interact with their   devices. Until Apple's fall event
column26: which will probably be in   September as usual
column27: we won't know if Touch ID will suffer the   same fate as the headphone jack.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Is the iPad Dead?;2/19/2017;"Less than four years ago
column2: it seemed plausible thatApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) iPad product line was on track todominate the tablet marketand upend the global PC market.Today
column3: that idea looks laughable. iPad sales have been in free   fall for years. Potential catalysts like the launch of the   business-friendly iPad Pro lineup
column4: the availability of cheaper   iPads
column5: and the aging of the iPad installed base have all failed   to reinvigorate sales.With this backdrop
column6: it's reasonable to wonder if the iPad's   immense popularity was just a fad. There's still a chance for the   iPad to make a modest comeback
column7: though -- and if that's going to   happen
column8: it will almost certainly begin within the next year.makeArticleAd();The launch of the iPad Pro hasn't boosted iPad sales. Image     source: Apple.iPad sales continue to declineApple posted its first full-year iPad sales dip in fiscal   2014. Unit sales slipped 4% that year
column9: while revenue fell 5%.The sales declines accelerated thereafter. In fiscal 2015
column10: unit sales plunged 19% and revenue dropped by 23%. In fiscal   2016
column11: unit sales fell another 17%
column12: while revenue tumbled 11%.   Double-digit declines along both metrics continued in the first   quarter of fiscal 2017.The net result is that Apple shipped just 42.6 million iPads   during the 2016 calendar year
column13: down about 40% from the peak a few   years ago. In its most recent annual report
column14: it blamed the   decline in iPad sales on cannibalization by other products (most   notably phablets like the iPhone 6 Plus and its successors) and a   long replacement cycle for iPads. The strong dollar may have also   hurt sales outside the U.S.Does the iPad have a future?Despite the weak sales trend
column15: CEO Tim Cook reiterated on the   company's recent earnings call that he is bullish about the   iPad's long-term trajectory. Sales grew at a double-digit rate in   India and Mainland China last quarter. The iPad continues to gain   traction in the corporate sector. Moreover
column16: customer satisfaction   remains extremely high.Thus
column17: the big problem is that people who bought iPads several   years ago don't seem to be replacing their devices. The first   four full-size iPad generations and the original iPad Mini -- all   of which debuted between 2010 and 2012 -- still account formore than 45% of iPad usage
column18: according to Fiksu.It's becoming less and less plausible that a big iPad   replacement cycle is right around the corner. The iPad's heyday   was from fiscal 2012 to fiscal 2014. During that period
column19: Apple   sold an average of 65.8 million iPads per year
column20: bringing in over   $30 billion of revenue annually. Those devices are now three to   five years old. Even if iPads are destined to have a PC-like   upgrade cycle of four or five years
column21: Apple should already be   benefiting from a wave of upgrades.Still
column22: the high price tag of the iPad Pro and the lack of   updates to cheaper iPads (the iPad Air 2 was launched in 2014 and   the iPad Mini 4 debuted in 2015) haven't helped. It's possible   that an upgrade of the full iPad product lineup could get sales   growing again.Old iPad models have proven to be good enough for most     consumers. Image source: Apple.New iPads on the wayIf that's the case
column23: then help may be on the way. Many Apple   watchers expect the company to roll out an updated iPad lineup   this spring
column24: perhaps as soon as next month.There isn't a consensus as to how many new iPads will be   unveiled or what sizes they will be. Highly followed analyst   Ming-Chi Kuo has predicted thatthree new iPads-- successors to both versions of the iPad Pro as well as a   cheaper 9.7"" replacement for the iPad Air 2 -- will be released.   Other pundits expect Apple to release a new iPad Mini (either   called the iPad Mini 5 or the iPad Pro Mini).Given how easy the year-over-year comparisons are these days
column25: the simultaneous release of three or more new models ought to get   iPad sales growing again. Still
column26: investors need to curb their   enthusiasm. The current versions of the iPad Pro haven't sold all   that well. The older iPad Air 2 and the iPad mini lineup have   been far more popular over the past year
column27: indicating that most   consumers aren't willing to pay $600 or more for an iPad   anymore.Of course
column28: the most ardent iPad fans will still shell out big   bucks for the latest and greatest models. Apple may also drop the   prices of the first-generation iPad Pro and the iPad Mini 4. That   could lure more price-sensitive customers to upgrade their aging   iPads. But the iPad product line may never return to its previous   peak in terms of sales and profitability.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Is This the Next Industry Amazon Wants to Conquer?;2/19/2017;"Just days after announcing its 2016 fourth-quarter results
column2: Amazon.com
column3: Inc.(NASDAQ: AMZN) issued apress releasewith a bold headline: ""More than 33 Million Customers Have Used   Amazon Payments to Make a Purchase."" The release was seemingly   out of left field. In the conference call for the previous   quarter -- held less than a week before the press release was   issued -- Amazon's management failed to mention Amazon Payments   even once.Image source: Amazon.com
column4: Inc.makeArticleAd();That's not to say the rare detailed look Amazon management   gave us into the numbers wasn't impressive -- it was. The release   gave plenty of updated stats on its Pay with Amazon service
column5: a   platform that allows shoppers to make purchases from third-party   websites using the payment information from their Amazon   account. As the headline proclaimed
column6: more than 33 million   customers have now used Pay with Amazon to make a purchase. The   platform's payment volume doubled in 2016. Active merchants   accepting Amazon Payments grew 120% year over year. More than 50%   of the customers who used the platform were also Amazon Prime   members.How does Amazon Payments compare?Amazon Payments is the latest payment platform that allows   customers to pay for online purchases from a number of different   websites using one account. It joinsPayPal Holdings Inc(NASDAQ: PYPL) andApple Inc's(NASDAQ: AAPL) Apple Pay as other popular digital wallets with   a built-in customer base.In Apple's 2017 fiscal first-quarter conference call
column7: CEO Tim   Cook had some very positive things to say about Apple Pay. Among   other things
column8: Cook said that during the past year the number of   Apple Pay users had tripled and transaction volume for the   quarter was up 500% year over year.Image source: Visa Inc.While it's hard to make an apples-to-apples comparisons   (pardon the pun)
column9: PayPal is the unquestioned leader in this   space. In its most recently reported quarter
column10: PayPal had 197   million active accounts
column11: each averaging a shade more than 31   transactions per month. The company's total payment volume was   reported at more than $99 billion
column12: a 25% increase year over   year.The reason why these numbers don't easily compare is because   Apple and Amazon are still in the nascent stages of their efforts   and
column13: as such
column14: are working from much smaller bases. PayPal's   active accounts represent customers who are making regular   purchases or transactions. In Amazon's press release
column15: the   trumpeted 33 million customers were just customers who had used   the platformonce
column16: a far different metric than customers who are regularly engaged   with the platform.Online merchant coverage -- the availability of a company's   payment processing service -- is another arena where PayPal holds   a big lead. In a September 2016surveyconducted by PYMNTS.com
column17: of the top 965 online merchants
column19: or   roughly 68%
column20: featured PayPal's ""Buy"" buttons. In second place was   Amazon
column21: with 101 websites featuring its button. No other   competing payment service was featured on more than 10% of the   websites surveyed. Since that was the same month Apple Pay users   could begin using its service to make payments on the web
column22: stats   were not yet available for its merchant coverage.Furthermore
column23: while the percentage gain in users
column24: transactions
column25: and payment volume for both Apple Pay and Amazon Payments were   certainly impressive
column26: they were coming off much smaller bases   than PayPal's much higher numbers. That doesn't mean these two   companies might not overtake PayPal as the dominant digital   wallet one day
column27: just that it is far too early to make such a   prediction.PayPal is still the top dog -- for nowPayPal still emerges as the top digital wallet among   consumers. Its base of almost 200 million active accounts and   impressive online merchant coverage will be a tough moat to   overcome
column28: even by rivals with such deep pockets as Amazon and   Apple. Furthermore
column29: PayPal shows no sign of slowing growth. The   company's number of active accounts
column30: payment transactions
column31: and   total payment volume were all up by double-digit percentages in   its most recently reported quarter.Nor is PayPal resting on its laurels. Innovative and popular   new products like One Touch arepowering mobile growthand it continues to increase market share in thegrowing e-commerce movement.But none of that should take away what Amazon Payments and   Apple Pay have the potential to accomplish in this space. Apple   Pay has legions of loyal iPhone users. Last quarter alone
column32: Apple   sold more than 78 million iPhones.Amazon has a loyal base of about 63 million Amazon Prime   members. This gives it a lot of room for growth with customers   who already use their Amazon.com account for online purchases. column1: Could This Oil Stock Really Become the Next Apple?;2/19/2017;"Pioneer Natural Resources(NYSE: PXD) has long believed that it's sitting on one of -- if   notthe-- biggest oil fields in the world. In fact
column2: so much   low-cost oil saturates the rocks beneath the land it controls in   thePermian Basinof western Texas that the company recently unveiled a bold   decade-long plan to develop this resource. What's remarkable   about that plan is that the production from new wells will fuel   more than 20% annual cash flow growth over the next 10 years even   ifoil   pricesdon't budge.That's elite-level cash flow growth that
column3: according to an   analysis byJPMorgan
column4: only 15 companies have eclipsed over the past decade. Among   those cash flow growth kings were tech giantsApple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column5: Amazon
column6: andAlphabet. Given the historical performance of those tech giants and the   others on the list
column7: Pioneer's ambitious growth plan could fuel   its stock to deliver market-thrashing returns in the years   ahead.Sands Weems. Image source: Pioneer Natural Resources.makeArticleAd();Already a step aheadPioneer Natural Resources is one of the few oil companies that   has consistently grown production during the oil market's recent   downturn. The company has increased output every quarter since   oil prices collapsed in 2014
column8: with last year's production up 15%   versus 2015. Contrast this with similarly sized rivals like   Bakken Shale-focusedContinental Resources(NYSE: CLR) or diversified shale drillerEncana(NYSE: ECA) . In Continental Resources' case
column9: its production was   down 4.3% year over year in 2016 while Encana's output slumped   double-digits due in part to asset sales.The reason Pioneer could continue growing was due to its   cash-rich balance sheet and the fact it earns higher returns on   new wells thanks to the unique properties of the Permian.   Currently
column10: Pioneer Natural Resources' internal rates of return on   new wells in the Basin will range from 50% to 100% assuming $55   oil and $3 natural gas this year. Contrast this with Encana
column11: which earns a minimum 35% return from its best wells at those   prices or Continental's 40% return for Bakken wells at $55 oil.   Those higher returns enable Pioneer to generate more cash flow
column12: which it can reinvest to grow faster than its rivals.Drilling down into the planAs those returns suggest
column13: Pioneer Natural Resources controls   some prime drillable land. Thanks to a series of smart   acquisitions and organic leasing
column14: the company currently holds a   785
column15: 000-acre position that it built up over the past two decades.   The company believes that there are as much as 11 billion barrels   of oil equivalent resources underneath that land
column16: which it can   extract through an estimated 20
column17: 000 future drilling   locations.At current oil prices
column18: the company anticipates that it can   generate sufficient cash flow to drill enough new wells each year   to boost its production by 15% annually over the next decade.   That would grow the company's output from an average of 234
column19: 000   barrels of oil equivalent per day last year (BOE/D) up to an even   1 million BOE/D by the end of 2026. Moreover
column20: due to the   high-margin nature of these wells
column21: it would grow Pioneer Natural   Resources' cash flow by a more than 20% compound annual rate over   that same time frame assuming no further improvement in crude   prices.Image source: Getty Images.Putting things into perspectiveThose metrics would put the company in an elite category. For   example
column22: if it achieved its cash flow grow target
column23: it would   generate more than $10 billion in operating cash flow in 2026
column24: up   from $1.5 billion last year. Just to put that into perspective
column25: big oil giantConocoPhillips(NYSE: COP) generated roughly $4.4 billion in cash flow from   operating activities last year on more than 1.5 million BOE/D of   production. Though
column26: to be fair
column27: ConocoPhillips' realized price   per BOE was $28.35 last year
column28: so its cash flow would have been   higher using Pioneer's commodity price assumptions.However
column29: it's the sheer rate of Pioneer's growth that is so   remarkable
column30: not just for an oil producer
column31: but when taken in the   context of the broader market. As previously mentioned
column32: JPMorgan   found that just 15 stocks in the entire Russell 1000 Index have   grown cash flow by more than 20% annually over a 10-year period
column33: with the bulk of that elite group made up of tech giants such as   Apple. Needless to say
column34: that steadily growing cash flow has done   wonders for their stock prices:AAPLdata byYCharts.In fact
column35: according to the bank's research
column36: these 15 stocks   have delivered an average total shareholder return of 662% over   that timeframe
column37: or an average yearly return of nearly 19%. That's   not to say Pioneer will match those returns
column38: but it's 10-year   growth forecast certainly gives it the fuel to deliver   market-beating returns as long as oil prices don't collapse   again. Meanwhile
column39: if prices rise above Pioneer's outlook
column40: it   would likely grow cash flow by an even healthier clip.Bottom line
column41: Pioneer Natural Resources's forecast makes it a   stock that growth investors should seriously consider.10 stocks we like better than Pioneer Natural     ResourcesWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: 2 Top Internet-of-Things Stocks to Buy Now;2/18/2017;"The Internet of Things (IoT) is a $19 trillion   opportunity
column2: according to formerCisco SystemsCEO John Chambers. That figure may be overstating it
column3: but the IoT   does present one of the most significant investment opportunities   of our times.One of the best ways to invest in broad-based movements such   as the IoT is by buying shares in the companies that supply the   hardware and infrastructure powering the trend -- such asSkyworks Solutions(NASDAQ: SWKS) andNXP Semiconductor(NASDAQ: NXPI) . Let's dig into each company to see what makes   them two of the top IoT investments on the market today.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Skyworks SolutionsThough it manufactures about 2
column4: 500 kinds of   chips
column5: Skyworks Solutions mostly touches on a single theme   with its products: making complex connectivity tasks simple. For   example
column6: Skyworks' chips power a number of mission-critical tasks   inApple's iPhones
column7: such as solving connection interference problems
column8: increasing data transfer speeds
column9: and saving battery   power. The company's unique ability to offer turnkey   solutions for important tasks like this has made it a go-to   supplier for mobile devices
column10: a trend that will only grow with the   continued rise of the IoT.Skyworks' compelling value proposition continues to reveal   itself in its quarterly results. In its most recent quarter
column11: Skyworks increased sales 9% sequentially to $914 million
column12: which   also helped the company establish a new record for quarterly free   cash flow and net income. The company's financial   performance stands a strong chance of accelerating later this   year
column13: thanks to the anticipated debut of Apple's redesigned   iPhone; the Mac maker accounts for 40% of Skyworks' sales via its   contract manufacturing partner
column14: Foxconn. Overall
column15: the company should be able to maintain its   above-average earnings growth for years to come. The analyst   community estimates that Skyworks will grow its EPS at an average   annual rate of 14.7% over the next five years.Trading at 18 times its last 12 months'   earnings. Skyworks Solutions looks like an appealing way to   play the rise of the IoT.NXP SemiconductorDutch IoT player NXP Semiconductor specializes in enabling   secure connections between devices
column16: which makes the company a   candidate for strong growth as the number of devices that ""talk""   with one another increases in the years to come. The company   enjoys market leadership positions across a host of   connected-device applications
column17: including automotive in-car   networking and near-field communication
column18: to name just a   few. Its various leadership positions also provide NXP with   a strong margin profile
column19: as seen in its 48% GAAP gross margin   last quarter. This situation allows NXP to reinvest in R&D
column20: which spurs further innovation and extends its market leadership   in a virtuous cycle that CEO Rick Clemmer and team have   implemented to great effect.However
column21: for all of NXP's opportunity
column22: investing in the   company also comes with some important risks. Last October
column23: for   instance
column24: it agreed to a buyout offer from chip giantQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) for $110 per share; its shares trade at $102 at   the time of this writing. Qualcomm's offer was an all-cash   deal
column25: meaning that participating in NXP's continued growth will   require investors buy Qualcomm stock outright after the buyout   closes. But the outlook for Qualcomm's business -- aside from NXP   -- hasworsenedin the months since news of the NXP buyout broke.Qualcomm's patent licensing business
column26: which produces the bulk   of the company's profit
column27: has come under pressure in recent years
column28: as government regulators in China and the EU have accused the   company of charging excessive royalty rates to mobile-device   makers. This trend seems to have accelerated in recent months
column29: as   regulators in South Korea and the U.S. FTC have also sued   Qualcomm over charges of anticompetitive business practices.   Adding insult to injury
column30: Qualcomm customer Apple sued the   company in January over its patent licensing practices.Qualcomm plans to defend itself to the hilt and has presented   compelling counterarguments to some of the accusations. However
column31: given the weight of its current legal entanglements
column32: Qualcomm   seems risky as an investment
column33: even despite the long-term benefit   the NXP Semiconductor buyout is likely to add.10 stocks we like better than Skyworks SolutionsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Is Overdue for a Pullback
column2: But Upside Remains Great;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) is a stock I've been bullish on for a long time
column5: and my outlook hasn't changed in either the short or long term. AAPL stock has been incredibly strong recently (as has the overall market) and a healthy pullback in the next week or two is certainly a possibility.makeArticleAd();Apple stock gained 10% through all of 2016
column6: and in just the seven weeks so far in 2017 it is already up nearly 17%. In addition
column7: the relative strength index (RSI
column8: located at the bottom of the chart below) is up to 93
column9: which is the highest it's been in a year. Of course
column10: a stock can continue to rally even with an elevated RSI
column11: but there's no question the odds of a pullback are becoming higher.Apple has initial support at the old all-time high of $134.54
column12: but given AAPL stock's recent climb
column13: it's more realistic to expect a slightly larger dip. That would put the next level of support at the upper end of the large gap AAPL left after earnings in early February. If it gets anywhere close to that $127 area
column14: which would represent a healthy 6% pullback from current prices
column15: it would be considered a great buying opportunity.Bottom Line on Apple StockFrom a fundamental perspective
column16: Apple remains the largest company in the world
column17: but it is also very undervalued right now. AAPL stock currently trades with a forward P/E of approximately 15
column18: which is below the 17.5 P/E the S&P 500 garners today.3 Cheap Lithium Stocks to Buy That Will Energize Your PortfolioAlso
column19: keep in mind that the company should grow earnings at least as quickly as the index. Adding in Apple's intangibles and the cult-like following it continues to have around the world
column20: there's no question it should have a valuation above that of the market. If AAPL stock were to trade at the S&P's valuation of 17.5x 2017 EPS estimates
column21: share prices would be up around $156.27.Looking ahead
column22: I believe Apple will report much better 2017 earnings than Wall Street expects
column23: and I think $175 is a more reasonable price target over the next 12 months. That's a long way up from the price of Apple stock today

column1: Friday Apple Rumors: APPL to Start iPhone Production in India;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of the company planning to start iPhone production in India. Today
