Reports claim that the iPhone SE production in India will take place at Wistron's Karnataka facility.iPhone Stealth Case:A leak of the stealth case used for prototype iPhone devices is now online
column6: MacRumors notes. This stealth case is what the company uses when it has to transport prototype versions of its newest smartphones between different locations. The case is mostly black and covers the majority of the device so that it can't be seen. It also has a line of yellow tape around the back and sides. The company can tell if the case has been opened based on if this tape is broken.Touch ID:Rumor has it that Apple is planning to ditch Touch ID in its next iPhone
column7: reports BGR. This rumor claims that AAPL is looking to remove Touch ID from the iPhone 8 in favor of facial recognition technology. The argument here is that facial recognition is more secure than a fingerprint. The rumor also claims that this addition will eventually be used for other features
column8: and that developers will have access to the technology.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postFriday Apple Rumors: APPL to Start iPhone Production in Indiaappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Cognex Corporation Earnings Start 2017 on a Strong Note;2/17/2017;"Investors inCognex Corporation(NASDAQ: CGNX) are getting used to their company blasting past   its own guidance
column2: and the recent results proved no exception. The   solid set of fourth-quarter earnings capped off a very good year   for the company
column3: and management served notice that 2017 could be   even stronger. Let's take a look at the details and commentary   from the earnings presentation.Cognex Corporation fourth-quarter results: The raw   numbersStarting with the headline figures from the fourth   quarter:Revenue of $129 million came in significantly above the     guidance range of $115 million to $118 million.Gross margin of 79% came in at the high end of the guidance     range of mid-to-high 70%.Operating margin expanded to 31% from 20% in the same     quarter last year.Diluted net income from continuing operations increased to     $0.43 from $0.22 in last year's fourth quarter.In short
column4: a combination of strong revenue growth and what CEO   Robert Willett called ""the substantial leverage that incremental   revenue has on our business model"" led to a strong increase in   profits. In a nutshell
column5: Willett simply means that revenue   increases tend to lead to even greater earnings growth.makeArticleAd();As such
column6: the guidance for the first quarter is encouraging. As   a reminder
column7: Cognex doesn't tend to give guidance more than one   quarter ahead.First-quarter revenue guidance range of $122 million to     $125 million
column8: representing growth of 27% to 30%.Gross margin in the mid-to-high 70% range.Operating expenses to increase 10% on a sequential     basis.Management expects an effective tax rate of 18%.The guidance is impressive and reflective of the strength of   Cognex's order book. However
column9: the second and third quarters are   usually the strongest for the company -- largely because   customers are preparing for their key fourth quarters during   those six months -- and the lack of specific guidance for that   period means it's too early to definitively conclude Cognex will   have another stellar year.Image source: Cognex.Core areas growingThat said
column10: the indications from the earnings call are positive   for three reasons. First
column11: Willet spoke of ""better-than-expected   demand across a range of industries including automotives
column12: consumer electronics
column13: and logistics."" For reference
column14: the   automotive industry is Cognex's historical core industry
column15: and   consumer electronics and logistics are the key growth areas for   the company.According to Willett
column16: around 30% of 2016 revenue came from   consumer electronics
column17: with a similar figure from automotive
column18: while logistics and consumer products contributed a ""little less   than 10%"" apiece.U.S. improvingSecond
column19: it looks like Cognex is starting to see some   improvement in its factory automation revenue in America
column20: an area   of weakness in the last couple of years. Willett spoke of   mid-teens revenue growth in factory automation in the Americas in   the fourth quarter. Moreover
column21: it came from a range of industries
column22: and Willett confirmed ""that improvement has continued into   January
column23: and he sees continued improvement in 2017.Not just about AppleThird
column24: Cognex's largest customer isApple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column25: but the machine-vision company is no one-trick   pony. It's difficult for management to disclose too much about   its relationship with Apple
column26: but according to Willett's comments   on the earnings call
column27: the strength in the quarter wasn't down to   just one customer.For reference
column28: the large Apple deal involves sales booked in   Europe for business to China. In this regard
column29: Willett referred to   Europe having ""a terrific quarter in Q4
column30: independent of consumer   electronics business to China. It grew more than 30%   year-on-year
column31: with mention of strong performances in automotive   and logistics.Image source: Cognex.Looking aheadAll told
column32: it was another strong quarter for Cognex
column33: and the   company looks well-positioned for 2017. That said
column34: look out for   guidance in the next quarter in order to see if some of the deals   the company has been working on are likely to close or not.   According to management
column35: the environment remains favorable
column36: and   investors will be hoping Cognex can continue to exceed   expectations.10 stocks we like better than CognexWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column37: it can pay to listen. After all
column38: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column39: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column40: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Cognex wasn't one of them!   That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better   buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column41: 2017Lee Samahahas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Apple and Cognex. The Motley Fool has     the following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and     short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) May Have Different View On Trump’s iPhone Manufacturing Plans;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(AAPL) does not mind making Trump furious.makeArticleAd();The U.S. President has been targeting Apple's low-energy and economically-sensible overseasmanufacturingsince the beginning. Even though the iPhone maker has so far stayed away from this debate
column3: recent comments from CFO Luca Maestri suggest that the U.S. firm has no plans of closing up shop in China any time soon
column4: according toBGR.In response to a question about overseas manufacturing at a Goldman Sachs conference
column5: Maestri said
column6: ""One of the points that we are making in Washington is the fact that we have been a very large contributor to the US economy during the last decade. We made billions ofinvestmentsin the United States. In the last 10 years
column7: we created about 2 million jobs in this country - in the developer community in our retail stores in our call centers and through the supplier chain.""Maestri then talked about Apple's U.S.-located call centers
column8: adding that speculating on Apple's manufacturing plans is really difficult
column9: especially when Trump hasn't outlined any specific policies.He did note that imposition of a border tax on imported products would lead to an additional burden on the end consumer.This could also mean that Apple is making yet another attempt to take iPhone manufacturing off the table for discussions with Trump. It seems that the iPhone maker does not mind taking back ancillary services
column10: such as support centers
column11: back to the US
column12: but it doesn't want to move the entire iPhone supply chain
column13: notes BGR.Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Could Win Big With 'Windows Cloud'Apple's iPhone manufacturing has been in the news for quite some time now.Reportedly
column14: Apple asked its subsidiaries to examine the feasibility of iPhone manufacturing soon after Trump's electoral victory. This ledBreitbartto run an (untrue) story:Silicon Valley Bows to Trump: Apple to Build iPhones in America.Apple Back on Top in Smartphone WarsMeanwhile
column15: for the first time in the last eight quarters
column16: Apple has taken the lead overSamsung Electronics(SSNLF) to become the world's top smartphone vendor. According to Gartner
column17: during the crucial holiday season
column18: the U.S. firm shipped the most smartphones
column19: but it only enjoys a razor thin lead over the Korean firm.As per Gartner's estimate
column20: the U.S. firm shipped about 77.04 millionsmartphonesin the fourth-quarter
column21: just ahead of Samsungs's 76.78 million. Based on this
column22: Apple's share in the global smartphone market is 17.9%
column23: while that of Samsung is 17.8%. This is the smallest difference recorded by Gartner
column24: according toCNBC.The postApple Inc. May Have Different View On Trump's iPhone Manufacturing Plansappeared first onValueWalk.Many academics claim investing is a ""random walk."" We believe this to be only partially true. It is our core belief that value investing can outperform the market
column25: hence the name ""ValueWalk."" Your number one source for breaking news and evergreen content on everything value investing and hedge funds.Check out our new free Underrated Small Cap Stocks newsletterAlso Sign Up For Our Free Newsletter and receive in-depth ebooks on famous investorsMore From InvestorPlace7 Tech Stocks With Explosive Growth PotentialThe Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February5 Stocks to Buy to Defy a Weak FebruaryThe postApple Inc. (AAPL) May Have Different View On Trump's iPhone Manufacturing Plansappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: WWDC 2017: Here’s What Apple Inc. Might Reveal;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) has announced the date for its yearly developer conference. WWDC 2017 will take place in San Jose
column3: starting on June 5. What can you expect the company to announce at the Apple event?makeArticleAd();Source: AppleAs a developer conference
column4: Apple usually focuses on software at its June events and WWDC 2017 will follow the same pattern.The company likes to offer hints at what its upcoming operating system releases hold with demos during the keynote presentation.With the iPhone dominating Apple's bottom line
column5: iOS 11 - the next version of AAPL's mobile operating system - is bound to get the majority of the stage time.Wal-Mart Stores Inc (WMT) Stock Isn't Coming Back. Just Ask Buffett.You can expect to see the latest versions of Apple's other operating systems to be shown off as well. We'll find out which California geographical feature macOS 10.13 will be named after
column6: along with the latest new features for Mac users. Apple Watch's watchOS and the Apple TV's tvOS will also get mentions.WWDC 2017: What About the Hardware?Software is exciting to app developers. For everyone else
column7: maybe not so much
column8: especially when it's just a teaser or dives into technical details. What really gets people's attention - especially from an Apple event - is new hardware. AAPL doesn't put an emphasis on revealing new products on stage at these developer conferences
column9: but there have been exceptions
column10: including:Mac Pro at WWDC 2006iPhone 3G at WWDC 200813-inch MacBook Pro and iPhone 3GS at WWDC 2009iPhone 4 at WWDC 2010MacBook Pro with Retina Display WWDC 2012New Mac Pro at WWDC 2013Historically speaking
column11: we may be overdue for a hardware announcement and there are two possibilities that come into mind for WWDC 2017.WWDC 2017: iPhone 8?It's been many years since AAPL chose its summer Apple event to take the wraps off a new iPhone. It's a long shot
column12: but there's a possibility the company may choose WWDC 2017 to unveil the iPhone 8. Why?First
column13: there's the significance of the June conference date. 2017 is the 10th anniversary of the iPhone and the very first one first went on sale in June
column14: 2007. Then there are the rumors that Apple is planning toramp up iPhone 8 production in June
column15: which would be earlier than usual.But the most compelling reason why the company might show off the iPhone 8 early is the developers in attendance. We're pretty sure AAPL is going to make sweeping changes to the iPhone 8. Besides design changes
column16: that could mean anything from an optical scanner to a mini version of the new MacBook Pro's Touch Bar replacing the Home button.The company will want apps available at launch that make use of any new hardware and that means bringing developers into the loop early. Apple may decide to let the cat out of the bag at WWDC 2017 so developers have a chance to learn about the new features and capabilities.7 Stocks Warren Buffett Is Buying or SellingAnother possibility on the hardware front is a revamped Apple TV. AAPL has been struggling with its set-top streamer with sales once again dropping off. It recently hired the former head ofAmazon.com
column17: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) Fire TV division tohelp turn around the Apple TV's fortunes. One of the big missing pieces from the Apple TV is relatively easy to fix. A new box with 4K support would address the issue of being stuck in the 1080p era when everyone else is doing Ultra HD
column18: and it's possible Apple could have this ready for June.Of course
column19: we have a few months to wait until we find out for sure. Watch InvestorPlace for coverage of WWDC 2017. Once the keynote wraps up on June 5
column20: we'll be posting on all the major Apple event reveals.As of this writing
column21: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceAmazon.com
column22: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is Ready for a BreakoutDow Jones and Nasdaq Reach New All-Time Intraday HighsThe postWWDC 2017: Here's What Apple Inc. Might Revealappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 4 Stocks That Turned $1
column3: 000;2/17/2017;"Imagine investing just $1
column4: 000 and watching it grow 100 times   over -- or 10
column5: 000% -- and suddenly you have a holding worth   $100
column6: 000. That's what would have happened if you'd invested in   the companies below in the last few decades. The good news? There   are some similarities flowing through these companies that could   help us spot other potential future 100-baggers.The truth is
column7: there are many stocks that could make this list
column8: and many have reached it and fallen from grace later in their   life. Here's whyApple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column9: Home Depot(NYSE: HD)
column10: Nike(NYSE: NKE)
column11: andAdobe Systems(NASDAQ: ADBE)  each stand out in the market.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();4 stocks that have grown 100 times overCompanyGained 10
column12: 000% or More Since:Year Went PublicTotal Return Over LifeAppleMarch 2009198031.3K%Home DepotSeptember 19971981774.8K%NikeMarch 2003198047K%Adobe SystemsOctober 2002188659.9K%Total return price includes dividends. P/E = Price to   earnings. Data source:YCharts.Apple has been a standout in the market for a lot of reasons
column13: but one of the biggest is its ability to create incredible   technology
column14: and then also create the eco-system that goes with it   to retain customers and grow its empire ever larger. Going   forward
column15: Apple continues to dominate the smartphone market in the   U.S. and increasingly worldwide
column16: and now
column17: asthe wealthiest company in the U.S. by   far
column18: it looks to have plenty of opportunity for new growth   ahead.Apple is a prime example of how looking for great companies at   times when the overall market sells off could lead to a great   returns long term
column19: which is why Apple has been able to generate   such massive returns since 2009 following the 2008 recession.   Adobe is a similar example
column20: as it gained share price quickly in   the tech boom of the early 2000s but
column21: like many of its early   internet siblings
column22: was slammed by the tech bubble burst of 2001.   Still
column23: if you were an investor then who saw the value of this   company
column24: with industry-leading software that has really evolved   and modernized the graphic media space
column25: you could have made   10
column26: 000% by buying in on that 2002 dip.Home Depot is an interesting company because
column27: unlike Apple and   Adobe
column28: it's a relatively low-tech operation that
column29: instead of   changing the world with new innovations
column30: took an old model of   selling construction and home repair equipment and just did that   really well. Home Depot has certainly gone through its own rises   and dips based on market conditions
column31: but rather than having timed   a buy-in to this stock after a market sell-off
column32: Home Depot has   rewarded long-term investors who have stuck with it over the last   20 years.Nike has a lot of similarities to Home Depot in that it wasn't   the first to introduce innovative new footwear models to the   world
column33: but founder Phil Knight and his early team certainly   out-hustled many of its competitors to grow Nike into the   international sporting behemoth it is today. Nike has also been a   success story of international expansion -- international sales   now make up around half of its total sales -- and how a smart   international strategy can lead to exponential growth.Looking for the next 100-baggerIt's impossible to know which stocks are going to become these   kinds of serious market-beating holdings in the decades to come.   Still
column34: there are a few key themes that can help in your search --   the most important of which is to buy quality companies with   great competitive moats and strong management teams. The other   key takeaway is the importance of having a buy-and-hold   strategy over 5
column36: or even 20 years out
column37: as seen in Home   Depot's case
column38: which is what allows these quality businesses the   time they need to reward those investors who have stuck with   them.10 stocks we like better than Home DepotWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column39: it can pay to listen. After all
column40: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade

column2: Apple Inc.'s(AAPL)smartphone unit sales outpaced that of Samsung in the fourth quarter of 2016.According to data released by Gartner

column4: 000. The global smartphone market share of the iPhone maker is 17.9%

The company received a lot of flak for Samsung Galaxy Note 7 and recalled the same from the market
column8: which resulted in depleting sales in the last two quarters. Moreover

column23: Oppo and others.Going ahead

column1: Apple to Begin Assembling iPhone SE in India from April;2/17/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();Reportedly
column2: Apple Inc.AAPLin collaboration with its manufacturer
column3: Wistron Inc. will begin to assemble iPhone SE in India starting this April. The plant will be located in the state of Karnataka in south India.Though there is no official word on the matter from Apple or Wistron
column4: it has been reported that initially the Cupertino giant wants to assemble 0.3-0.4 million units of iPhone SE. Apple hasn't even waited for the numerous tax concessions that it sought from the India government including the 15-year customs duty holiday.Analysts observe that it was prudent on part of Apple to begin assembling its most economic iPhone offering
column5: SE
column6: which was launched to cater to cost sensitive markets like India. Plus
column7: it also will support future iOS upgrades unlike iPhone 5S
column8: which will soon be discontinued in most of the markets including India.Apple Inc. PriceApple Inc. Price|Apple Inc. QuoteWhy is Apple Keen on India?Since the last year
column9: Apple has been increasing its focus on India to claim a greater share of the vast smartphone market
column10: of which it reportedly holds only 2% as of now. Apple faces slowing iPhone demand in most of the regions
column11: either because of competition or regulatory hurdles (China) or market saturation (the U.S). Therefore
column12: it makes sense for the company to solidify its position in India
column13: which is projected to become the second largest smartphone market in the world. In fiscal 2016
column14: Apple sales in India grew approximately 50% over the prior fiscal.Furthermore
column15: a younger (and skilled) population and increasing investment in broadband network by the government also make India an attractive growth opportunity for Apple over the long run. In fact
column16: the government under PM Narendra Modi is eager to bring foreign capital and boost manufacturing facilities in India.The recently outlined FDI policy also bodes well for the company as it eliminates the requirement to locally source products for at least a three-year period. This will enable Apple to open its solely-owned retails stores in India. Thereafter
column17: the company will have to comply with the rule. The company has also partnered with telecom company Reliance
column18: which is providing its Jio (a unique all-IP network) service for free with the new iPhones.Last year
column19: Tim Cook was on a charm offensive in India. Besides meeting Modi
column20: he also announced the opening of an iOS App Design and Development Accelerator in Bengaluru and a map development office in another southern Indian city
column21: Hyderabad in collaboration with regional firm RMSI.ChallengesThe market is highly cost sensitive. Reportedly
column22: majority of the smartphones sold are priced around INR 10K (roughly $145). iPhone 7 on the other hand costs almost five times more. Even iPhone SE is priced at INR 30K. The lion's share of Apple's revenues in the country comes from devices
column23: which are a couple of generations old. Newer models have relatively low demand given the hefty price tag.  A few days back
column24: it was reported that the Apple team in India is trying to increase revenues to $3 billion by 2017-18 and by local assembling operations
column25: the company can start to operate its own retail outlets and avail a 10% tax benefit. This should lower prices.Plus
column26: Apple's rival Samsung along with a few Chinese smartphone makers dominates this market. Samsung has long been in the market and with reportedly 23% share
column27: it is a leading player in the country. Apple is quite late to the party.Also
column28: Apple's lack of focus on regional customers' demand is a concern. India is categorized by handsets that work on dual SIMs. Apparently
column29: Apple is not keen on making dual SIM handsets. This could be a very big impediment to growth in the country.Also
column30: analysts observe that Apple is ""relocating"" manufacturing to India from China
column31: given rising labor costs. However another analyst argues that though labor is cheap compared with China
column32: productivity is relatively better in China. Simple assembling may not drastically bring down prices. However
column33: the creation of a local supply chain as in China will be a big positive.Despite the pros and cons
column34: Apple is expected to continue its India drive. It will be taking up a lot more initiatives this year. However
column35: whether those initiatives yield desirable results remains a watch and see story.Apple
column36: of course
column37: is not the only tech player eyeing India for growth. Given the potential of this market
column38: Silicon Valley's interest is well understood. From Microsoft Corp.MSFTto AlphabetGOOGLto Facebook Inc.FBall remain laser focused on the market.Zacks Rank & Price MovementAt present
column39: Apple has a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stocks here.Over the past one year

column1: 7 Surprising Metrics Highlight 1 Major Catalyst for Apple
column2: Inc. Stock: Services;2/16/2017;"With the iPhone providing 64% of trailing 12-month revenue atApple Inc.(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column3: the tech giant's business is still primarily   driven by that segment. But it doesn't mean investors should   overlook Apple's other business segments. One is standing out   more than ever: the company's App Store
column4: iTunes
column5: Apple Music
column6: iCloud
column7: Apple Pay
column8: licensing
column9: and other services.Apple's App Store drives the majority of services revenue.     Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();1. $7.2 billion:In Apple's most recent quarter
column10: quarterly services revenue hit an   all-time high of $7.2 billion -- up 18% year over year
column11: handily   exceeding Apple's overall revenue growth of 3% and beating growth   in any other segment.But even this growth in Apple's services segment understates   how rapidly services revenue is growing. Apple CFO Luca Maestri   explained the discrepancy between reported growth and actual   segment growth in the company's first-quarter earnings call:Our run rate growth was actually higher when taking into     account two discrete items. On one hand
column12: the 14th week added to     Services revenue this December quarter. On the other hand
column13: that     benefit was more than offset by the comparison to the one-off     $548 million patent infringement payment included in Services     revenue a year ago.2. 9.2%:Apple's services segment is growing as a proportion of total   revenue. In the company's most recent quarter
column14: services accounted   for 9.2% of total revenue
column15: up from 8% in the year-ago quarter and   6.4% in the same quarter two years ago.3. 43%:Adjusting for the extra week in Apple's first quarter this year
column16: App Store revenue soared 43% year over year
column17: shattering all   previous records. This was driven by growth both in average   revenue per paying account and in the total number of paying   accounts.As Maestri was sure to mention
column18: Apple's App Store revenue   growth outpaced the overall app industry
column19: and more than doubled   2016 revenue fromAlphabet's Google Play store.Going forward
column20: Maestri believes ""the App Store is going to be   a significant driver of growth.""4. $3 billion:If you had any doubts about the importance of the App Store to   Apple's services segment
column21: wonder no longer: It's critical. Apple   said fiscal first-quarter App Store revenue was $3 billion in   December alone.5. $60 billion:Based on the trajectory of developer revenue in 2016
column22: the   business of apps is just getting started. Apple's developer   community has now raked in $60 billion in earnings
column23: garnering   over $20 billion just in 2016.6. Over 150 million subscriptions:Between Apple's own subscription services and third-party content   subscriptions offered through the App Store
column24: the company has more   than 150 million paid customer subscriptions.Apple Music. Image source: Apple.7. $51 billion:What kind of growth should investors expect from Apple's services   segment? The business could double over the next four years
column25: according to Apple management. This would bring annual services   revenue to a staggering $51 billion in 2020.While these figures alone make a great case for investors to   pay close attention to Apple's services segment
column26: the very nature   of Apple's services themselves justify the segment's importance.   Unlike the unpredictable nature of focused product revenue from   iPhone
column27: Mac
column28: and iPad
column29: services revenue is more sustainable
column30: stable
column31: and predictable. Further
column32: it's a solid measure of the   degree to which a growing number of customers are becoming   increasingly invested in Apple's powerful ecosystem of hardware
column33: software
column34: and services.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column35: it can pay to listen. After all
column36: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column38: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: You'll Never Guess Where People Use Apple Pay the Most;2/16/2017;"Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) recently said some 4 million locations
column2: or about   35% of all retail stores in the U.S.
column3: accept its Apple   Pay mobile payment option. Although there are some notable   exceptions among the largest retailers
column4: such asWal-MartandTarget
column5: who don't offer it
column6: others likeGapdo
column7: or soon will feature the payment solution.Because it's available on mobile phones
column8: tablets
column9: and even the   Apple Watch
column10: its ubiquity and relative ease of use make it the   go-to choice for consumers on the go as well as those   dissatisfied with the hassle and delays of embedded chip   cards. According to data analytics firm TXN Solutions
column11: which   surveyed the transactions from over 3 million payment   cards
column12: Apple Pay usage has soared by 50% over the past   year.Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();The rise of Apple PayIndeed
column13: during Apple's first-quarter earnings conference call   with analysts last month
column14: CEO Tim Cook said transaction volume   had risen sixfold from the prior year as Apple Pay expanded into   four new countries
column15: including Japan
column16: Russia
column17: New Zealand
column18: and   Spain.While that would seem to clash somewhat with TXN's more muted   (though still significant) rise
column19: it comes down to a difference in   what's being measured. While Apple isn't particularly   forthcoming on details of the Apple Pay ecosystem
column20: it is talking   about the actual number of transactions made
column21: while the data   analytics firm is referencing the percentage of transactions from   its panel of consumers who provide their credit and debit card   data and whose banks distinguish Apple Pay transactions.While that naturally limits the universe of transactions   captured
column22: over time it still tracks the acceptance of the mobile   payment option and its growth
column23: and what it found was that   most people were using it in mobile apps and on   websites.A place to crash for the nightThat surprising conclusion was reached after finding that of   all the places Apple Pay users were using the payment   option
column24: getting a cheap hotel room at the last minute topped the   list. Ordering takeout was apparently the second favorite way to   use the service.Image source: HotelTonight.The TXN data
column25: which examined payments made between December   2015 and December 2016
column26: found mobile travel app HotelTonight
column27: a   last-minute reservation service
column28: had 3.4% of all its   credit cards transactions made with Apple Pay
column29: followed   by food delivery services Caviar
column30: Postmates
column31: and DoorDash
column32: which all had around 2.5% usage rates or slightly higher.What is more notable about the survey results is that despite   the broad proliferation of places accepting Apple Pay as an   option
column33: it really hasn't caught on among brick-and-mortar   retailers
column34: where most places saw it represent less than 1% of all   credit card transactions. And ultimately
column35: regardless of   where it is used
column36: it isn't creating much of a stir in the   payments industry
column37: as it represents just a small percentage   of total credit card transactions.But let's first cross off the names of stores where peoplearen'tusing Apple Pay.Starbucks' mobile ordering trumps Apple payAt the bottom of the list isStarbucks(NASDAQ: SBUX)
column38: which came in last on a list of the 13   top places processing Apple Pay transactions
column39: accounting for   about 0.5% of the coffee shop's total credit card   transactions. Considering Starbucks has its own highly   regarded mobile ordering and payment option
column40: which is often   looked at as the gold standard for convenience and ease of use
column41: it raises eyebrows that people are using Apple Pay there at   all.On its first-quarter earnings conference call with analysts   two weeks ago
column42: Starbucks President Kevin Johnson said
column43: ""Mobile   Order & Pay had a banner quarter
column44: representing more than 7%   of total transactions
column45: double the figure from Q1 last year
column46: and   we now have nearly 1
column47: 200 stores with 20% or more Mobile Order   & Pay transactions at peak
column48: compared to only 13 stores one   year ago."" When you have customer loyalty like that
column49: who   needs Apple Pay?Image source: Starbucks.Food retailers still represent the lion's share of places   seeing Apple Pay usage
column50: and Lowes Foods
column51: Sprouts Farmers Markets
column52: Panera Bread
column53: and Schnucks round out the bottom five places for users of the   mobile wallet
column54: with around 0.6% of their credit card transactions   accounted for using the payment method.A prescription for future growth?So
column55: if Starbucks and trendy grocery stores were bringing up   the rear
column56: who was it that was leading the brick-and-mortar pack?   Would you believe Duane Reade
column57: the New York metropolitan   area drugstore chain owned byWalgreens Boots Alliance(NASDAQ: WBA) ?According to the TXN data
column58: the pharmacy operator was the top   spot where people used Apple Pay
column59: with 1.8% of the credit card   transactions identifying the mobile payment option being chosen.   That put it slightly ahead of No. 2 retailerWhole Foods Market(Nasdaq: WFM)
column60: which had about 1.7% of its credit card   transactions using Apple Pay.Because both retailers have been with the service since Apple   launched Apple Pay in 2014
column61: it might not be so surprising they   were well ahead of the others
column62: including Canteen Vending at No. 3   with slightly less than 1% of its transactions
column63: and fourth place   Peet's Coffee with just under 0.8%.Whether that means Apple Pay will ever supplant EMV cards as a   preferred payment option remains to be seen
column64: but it seems hard to   believe it will replace Starbucks' mobile order and pay app   anytime soon. And though Apple Pay users seem to be a rare breed   indeed
column65: maybe all you need to see them in action is to   simply stop by your local pharmacy.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column66: it can pay to listen. After all
column67: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade

column69: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!   That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better   buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Top Stocks Warren Buffett Is Buying Now;2/16/2017;"Warren Buffett is arguably the best investor on the planet
column2: and his penchant for picking winners for long-haul portfolios   makes it worth paying attention to the stocks he's buying for hisBerkshire Hathaway(NYSE: BRK-A) (NYSE: BRK-B) . Fortunately
column3: big investors like   Buffett are required to file a 13F report with the SEC every   quarter that show what they've been up to.In Buffett's case
column4: he's been busy buyingApple Inc.(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column5: Delta Air Lines(NYSE: DAL)
column6: andMonsanto(NYSE: MON) . Should you buy these stocks too?A big win that's getting biggerBack in 2012
column7: Warren Buffett told investors that Steve Jobs   called him a few years prior with questions on how best to spend   Apple's cash war chest. Buffett told Jobs to buyback Apple's   stock
column8: but Jobs didn't.makeArticleAd();IMAGE SOURCE: GETTY IMAGES.It took a while
column9: and a sell-off
column10: but Warren Buffett has   finally followed his own advice and taken a big (and growing)   stake in Apple for Berkshire Hathaway.Apple shares showed up in Berkshire Hathaway's portfolio last   year
column11: and at the time
column12: Buffett said the shares had been bought by   one of his lieutenants. Maybe so
column13: but Berkshire's position in   Apple has grown steadily since then
column14: and now it's Berkshire   Hathaway's sixth largest holding
column15: by value.So far
column16: buying Apple shares has proven savvy. In the wake of   worry over slowing iPhone sales
column17: shares hit a low of $90 last   May. Today
column18: they're at $135.It's anyone's guess how long Apple will remain in Berkshire   Hathaway's portfolio
column19: or if Berkshire Hathaway will buy more   shares this year
column20: but there are reasons why investors might want   to look for a chance to pick up shares in the company
column21: too. Apple iPhone sales bounced back to growth last quarter
column22: and management's plans to double services sales by 2020 could   provide a lot of margin-friendly support to Apple's bottom   line.Investors may also benefit from any tax reform that allows the   company to repatriate some of the $200 million-plus in cash it   holds overseas. And investors should probably expect that Apple's   dividend payment is going higher
column23: not lower
column24: in the coming years.   Currently
column25: shares yield 1.7%.IMAGE SOURCE: GETTY IMAGES.Taking flightOne of the most surprising stocks that Warren Buffett has   bought in the past year is airline stocks
column26: including Delta Air   Lines
column27: Inc. In the past
column28: Buffett has called airline stocks   terrible investments
column29: but he appears to have changed his mind --   in a very big way.In the third quarter
column30: Berkshire Hathaway acquired roughly $1   billion worth of American Airlines
column31: Delta Air
column32: and United   Continental stock. After the news of those purchases broke
column33: Buffett told CNBC that he had picked up shares in Southwest
column34: too.The scattershot approach to airlines could mean that Buffett's   bet is less stock specific and more driven by the potential for   travel to pick up alongside economic growth. With unemployment   low
column35: wages beginning to climb more quickly
column36: and corporate   friendly tax reform on deck in Washington
column37: D.C.
column38: there's reason   to think that the travel industry could benefit from rising   demand.If so
column39: then Warren Buffett's decision to bulk up his position   in airlines stocks in the fourth quarter could be smart. In the   quarter
column40: Berkshire Hathaway's stake in Delta Air Lines   sky-rocketed 847%. That 60 million-plus share stake in Delta Air   Lines is worth more than $3 billion
column41: which makes it Berkshire   Hathaway's biggest airline investment.Delta Air Lines has said it wants to return 70% of its annual   free cash flow to investors. Considering the company's recent   history of big dividend increases and the fact that share   buybacks are wrapping up soon
column42: investors might be getting some   good news from management in the near future. The company has   increased its dividend payout by 237.5% since 2013
column43: including a   50% increase last May. Given that Delta's payout ratio is only   15.9%
column44: it wouldn't be a surprise if another large dividend   increase comes again this year.Couple the potential rewards of a rising dividend with the   potential for growing travel demand to support airfares and load   factor
column45: and maybe airlines aren't as terrible of an investment as   they used to be.Getting in on grainsWarren Buffett is also betting that Bayer's planned megamerger   with grains giant Monsanto passes muster with regulators.   Berkshire Hathaway's portfolio includes 8 million shares of   Monsanto as of Dec. 31.As a refresher
column46: Bayer inked a deal to buy Monsanto last year   for $128 per share in cash. However
column47: this merger would create a   global giant in seeds and crop protection
column48: and that may create a   lot of obstacles to overcome if the two hope to get government   approvals. According to number crunchers atBloomberg
column49: the odds of this deal closing were about 40% on Valentine's   Day.Those odds could understate the likelihood of this happening
column50: however
column51: given that the mood in Washington
column52: D.C. has become far   less anti-business since November's election. In January
column53: Bayer   and Monsanto executives may have helped their cause by offering   promises to boost jobs and spend $8 billion in the U.S. if the   deal closes.If the deal goes through
column54: then the all-cash nature of this   acquisition could make Monsanto's stock worth owning in   portfolios. Monsanto's currently trading at around $109
column55: which is   a 17% discount to the offer price.Even if the deal doesn't close
column56: Monsanto won't walk away   completely empty-handed. Bayer's on the hook to pay Monsanto a $2   billion break-up fee if the merger falls through. Even so
column57: this   one isn't your typical buy-and-hold Warren Buffett buy
column58: so   investors might be better off looking elsewhere.10 stocks we like better than MonsantoWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column59: it can pay to listen. After all
column60: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column61: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column62: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Monsanto wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column63: 2017Todd Campbellowns shares of Apple. His clients may have positions in the     companies mentioned. The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Apple and Berkshire Hathaway (B shares). The Motley     Fool has the following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on     Apple and short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley     Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Thursday Apple Rumors: Fifth Generation Apple TV May Offer 4K;2/16/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of the next Apple TV. Today
column3: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Thursday.makeArticleAd();Apple TV:A new rumor claims that the next version of the Apple TV will support 4K resolution
column4: reportsAppleInsider. According to this rumor
column5: the TV is currently in its in testing now. The rumor claims that the set-top box may be released as early as this year. The codename for the device is ""J105"". It may come as a disappointment
column6: but this rumor also claims that 4K may be the only new feature coming to the next generation of AAPL's TV.iPhone 8 Display:Rumor has it that AAPL's iPhone 8 will feature an upgraded display
column7: 9to5Macnotes. This rumor claims that the device will sport a display with 521 PPI
column8: which is higher than the iPhone 7's 320 PPI. It also suggests that the smartphone will feature 3x Retina scaling. This is a feature that is present on the iPhone 7 Plus. The big difference here is that rumors claim the iPhone 8 will be similar in size to AAPL's 4.7-inch devices. The source of this newest rumor is KGI analyst Ming-Chi Kuo.iPhone 8 Laser:There's a rumor going around that the iPhone 8 will feature laser technology
column9: reportsBGR. The rumor claims that AAPL is planning to introduce laser technology so that it can scan the face of the person using the smartphone. This facial recognition would act as an extra layer of security between the user and the device. This rumor falls in line with the tech company's acquisition of Emotient last year. Emotient is a company that specializes in facial recognition technology.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postThursday Apple Rumors: Fifth Generation Apple TV May Offer 4Kappeared first onInvestorPlace."

Franklin   Templeton had $378.7 billion in total net assets.Net inflow to passively run Fidelity funds - mainly exchange   traded funds - reduced its combined mutual-fund-and-ETF net   outflow by about $1 billion.Whether it was flow just to mutual funds or to funds plus   ETFs

Vanguard lured in a net $182.997   billion to its mutual funds.All other mutual fund complexes with inflow - there were 314   if them - had combined net inflow of $151 billion.Vanguard also attracted $94.26 billion in net inflow to its   ETFs.Still
column68: Fidelity had bright spots. Investors poured $37.2   billion in net inflow into passively run Fidelity mutual funds   and ETFs. The trouble was that investors yanked a net $60.5   billion from Fidelity's actively run funds and ETFs.And three Fidelity portfolios were among the 12 top stock   mutual funds of 2016 in terms of gathering net inflow. column1: Facebook Inc (FB) Is Losing the War Against Fake News;2/16/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) has begun fighting a war against fake news and
column3: so far at least
column4: it's losing. Failure could have profound implications for Facebook's bottom line
column5: and even threaten its ability to remain in business.makeAd('4'
column7: 'mktsnews'
column8: 'vanguard'
column10: '');Source: ShutterstockThe threat is deeper than Donald Trump. The power of Facebook's software tools
column11: and communication capabilities
column12: is a two-way street that benefits the darker side of human nature
column13: as well as its better angels.For example
column14: Facebook's Graph Search tool
column15: introduced in 2013
column16: can help you search the site efficiently. It can also help youstalk someone.Facebook Live
column17: which lets users stream live video on the site from their camera phones
column18: can let you show grandparents your kid's birthday party
column19: as it happens. It can also let youshow the child being killed.CEO Mark Zuckerberg promised to do something about this in November
column20: on his own Facebook page
column21: but has not come out with much useful beyond tags on disputed items and a vague statement from an underling thatsharing fake news is your prerogative.FB stock holders need to be worried.Facebook Is a Media Company
column22: Like It or NotFacebook has continually denied it is a media company
column23: subject to responsibility for what it posts
column24: fearing the need in that case for human interventionthat simply would not scale.7 Stocks Warren Buffett Is Buying or SellingThe latest statement from its vice president for partnerships
column25: Dan Rose
column26: is that Facebook is""a new type of platform …where people discovery a lot of media content.""That's about as mealy-mouthed as anything that could come from a corrupt politician.For FB
column27: however
column28: fake news is a global problem
column29: and most countries don't have regulations separating a ""telecommunications service"" from the responsibilities of a ""media outlet."" Thus
column30: Facebook's efforts at self-censorship are showing up first in international markets.The European Commission
column31: for instance
column32: has already warned Facebook
column33: and other networks
column34: thatthey face legal actionif the issue of fake news is not dealt with. AlongsideAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL)
column35: Facebook is testing a system calledCrossCheckfor flagging fake news in France
column36: which holds a presidential election this spring.This is being done in cooperation with local media
column37: but the reporting on it shows the difficulty.A Russian storyon the system calls the problem ""so-called fake news"" and calls CrossCheck a plot by the ""mainstream media.""Germany
column38: which holds its own elections this September
column39: is also threatening to imposea 500
column40: 000-euro finefor each fake news story it runs.How Bad Can It Get?To see how bad things can get with fake news and the abuse of Facebook Live
column41: Zuckerberg might look at South Sudan
column42: where expatriates are turning a civil conflict into genocide with social media messages or the Dominican Republic
column43: where two journalists were recently killed on Facebook Live as a message from crime gangs.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Careens Closer to Major AR AnnouncementA recent Pew Research study showed 44% of Americans get their news through Facebook
column44: and that most users get news from only one site
column45: meaning Facebook has political and media power commensurate with its financial power.That power: fourth-quarter revenue of $8.8 billion
column46: with $4.27 billion going to net income. FB stock has no debt but nearly $30 billion in cash on the books
column47: supporting a market cap of $385 billion - almost twice that ofWal-Mart Stores Inc.(NYSE:WMT).All this is severely threatened if Facebook can't get its arms around the problem of lies and abuse.Real lives are on the line
column48: not just cyber lives. Real dollars need to be invested.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column49: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing
column50: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: The Experts' PicksThe 7 Most Popular Vanguard Funds for 401k PlansNvidia Corporation (NVDA) Stock Isn't Done Correcting YetThe postFacebook Inc (FB) Is Losing the War Against Fake Newsappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Why Small-Caps Remain Some Of The Top Stocks To Invest In (MMYT);2/16/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe other day
column3: a headline in a financial publication caught my attention. ""Small Is No Longer Beautiful
column4: it read.makeArticleAd();I was intrigued. I knew all about the strength in small-cap stocks this past year and how their strong post-election rally started to fizzle in December.But would I go so far as to predict that these stocks have totally lost their appeal compared with their large and mega-cap peers?I don't think so.Yes
column5: it's true that the Russell 2000
column6: represented on the chart by theiShares Russell 2000 ETF(IWM)
column7: strongly outperformed theS&P 500(SPY) index of U.S. large-cap stocks over the past year.And it might also be true that the index was getting a little ahead of itself
column8: as suggested by its December pause.Russell 2000 (IWM) Up Big Last YearBut I'm not interested in buying the index.InGame-Changing Stocks
column9: my premium advisory
column10: I am tasked with finding companies - not indices - that are poised to break rules
column11: outgrow competition
column12: become household names or start new trends. I scour the market for the top stocks to invest in to follow developing technologies and trends. And here
column13: small caps carry some advantages.Incredibly
column14: even in our information age
column15: small-cap companies still don't get enough coverage compared with their large-cap peers.Virtually no development can go unnoticed for larger tech firms likeApple Inc.(AAPL) orFacebook Inc(FB). After all
column16: more than 50 Wall Street analysts cover each company
column17: not to mention TV and print journalists. On the other hand
column18: major developments in many smaller companies can go unnoticed for quite some time. These firms simply fly under radar.7 High-Risk
column19: High-Reward Stocks to Buy NowSmall companies on the verge of technological breakthroughs or on the forefront of a new trend can be fully expected to benefit from another feature of the market: Money is still cheap to borrow. Large companies
column20: especially tech leaders
column21: have a lot of cash on their balance sheets. That could lead to a spree of mergers and acquisitions
column22: which would be beneficial to the small caps being picked up.Cash On Hand
column23: Selected Large CapsWhen large-cap companies have this much cash on hand
column24: this means their ability to make money has exceeded their ability to be innovative. In such cases
column25: buying smaller innovators is often the easiest path to new breakthroughs. All things considered
column26: it's easy to predict that these tech giants' cash is going to provide long-term support to a period of strong merger-and-acquisition activity.And even if I'm overestimating the willingness of these tech giants to buy their smaller peers
column27: the mere fact that their cash balances have ballooned to these incredible amounts should serve as a support (or a ""floor"") under the smaller-cap companies' share prices
column28: especially for those companies that prove themselves to be on the forefront of the newest and most disruptive technologies.The rule-breakers and the game-changers are
column29: therefore
column30: likely to be in a position to leverage their achievements as their large- and mega-cap peers remain under pressure from the markets to deliver consistent quarterly earnings growth.As a group
column31: small caps are also set to benefit from other new developments that can make them some of the top stocks to invest in for 2017.One of those benefits is the tax reform expected from the new administration. Smaller companies are likely to benefit more than the others from corporate tax cuts: These smaller organizations usually have no resources to utilize tax-avoidance schemes
column32: and they are usually more domestically-oriented
column33: so they have less reason to stash cash abroad.Another reason for investors to continue concentrating in smaller-cap stocks is that there are literally thousands small-cap companies to choose from: The benchmark Russell 2000 Index contains 2
column34: 000 stocks
column35: and there are also smaller
column36: micro-capitalization stocks not included in the index. And that's even before we consider international small caps
column37: such asMakeMyTrip Limited(MMYT).Of course

column1: Intel Corporation Reportedly Prepping 14-Nanometer LTE Modem for 2018 Shipments;2/16/2017;"Analysts with Bernstein Research distributed a note to clients   after microprocessor giantIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) hosted its Feb. 9 investor meeting. In the note
column2: the analysts say that Intel plans to introduce cellular modems   manufactured in its 14-nanometer technology (rather than on   older
column3: third-party manufacturing technologies) in the second half   of 2018.The analysts say that Intel is not only planning to introduce   these chips
column4: but that they plan to ship ""tens of millions of   units"" in the second half of 2018.Intel wireless chief
column5: Aicha Evans. Image source: Intel.makeArticleAd();""Given the only high volume purchaser of stand-alone modems   remains [Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) ]
column6: this suggests share at least maintained if not   increased
column7: the analysts write.The report also says that Intel was ""coy on CDMA capability""   but that the analysts ""believe it is a possibility
column8: noting that   if Intel does indeed include CDMA capabilities in this modem
column9: it   would be a ""further potential headwind forQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) .""In this column
column10: I'd like to explain why the move to an   in-house manufactured modem is so important for Intel and Apple
column11: and why inclusion of CDMA capabilities could negatively impact   Qualcomm
column12: as the Bernstein analysts suggest.The advantages of going in-houseRight now
column13: Intel's modems are manufactured by a third party   (believed to beTaiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company(NYSE: TSM)
column14: though Intel hasn't
column15: to my knowledge
column16: officially   confirmed this). Moreover
column17: they are manufactured on relatively   old 28-nanometer chip technology.By moving the modem in-house
column18: Intel should enjoy several   benefits compared to its current manufacturing arrangement.First
column19: Intel must pay TSMC for each wafer of chips that the   latter manufactures. This means that Intel not only bears the   burden of the raw materials and manufacturing costs
column20: but TSMC   marks those wafers up and makes significant profit margin per   wafer sold (in the ballpark of 50%).By moving this to in-house manufacturing
column21: Intel is still on   the hook for raw materials and manufacturing cost (and some will   argue that Intel's per-wafer manufacturing costs are higher than   TSMC's)
column22: but it doesn't need to fork over profit margins to   TSMC.Instead
column23: Intel could theoretically be able to either boost its   own profit margin on the chips that it sells to Apple (this   assumes that Intel's wafer costs aren't so high that they offset   not having to pay TSMC's margins)
column24: or maintain the same margins   that it did before
column25: but lower its chip prices to Apple   (potentially opening share gain opportunities).Beyond that
column26: though
column27: newer manufacturing technologies tend to   bring power efficiency benefits over older ones. The transition   from TSMC's 28-nanometer technology to Intel's 14-nanometer   (presumably an ""optimized"" 14-nanometer+ or 14-nanometer++   variant) technology should enable a significant reduction in both   active and stand-by power -- potentially boosting battery   life.The more technically competent Intel's modems are (better   power efficiency is clearly a valuable example of that)
column28: the more   likely that Apple is going to want to use them in its   products.The CDMA questionRight now
column29: Apple uses Qualcomm modems in iPhone models that   support the CDMA wireless standard and Intel modems in the iPhone   models that don't. If Apple had to
column30: it could use Qualcomm modems   in every single iPhone sold and it wouldn't be a problem; the   same can't be said about the Intel modems which wouldn't work   properly on CDMA networks.If Intel can integrate CDMA capability into the modem that   it's expected to ship to Apple for the 2018 iPhone
column31: then Apple   will presumably be able to use either Intel or Qualcomm modems   interchangeably.That's a negative for Qualcomm because it opens the company up   to either additional potential share loss (Apple could keep   Qualcomm in the loop but further reduce its allocation)
column32: or it   could lead to an erosion of Qualcomm's pricing power (in a recent   lawsuit
column33: Apple alleges that Qualcomm charges it extra for modems   with CDMA capability enabled).Neither situation would be good for Qualcomm's Apple   business.As to whether we'll see CDMA in Intel's 2018 modem
column34: it's   interesting that Intel was reportedly ""coy"" about this
column35: per   Bernstein. Perhaps Intel is working to build the technology into   that 2018 modem
column36: but the company isn't confident that the   implementation will be robust enough to pass carrier   certification in the timeframe that it would need to for Apple to   be comfortable using it.I do expect that Intel will eventually implement CDMA in   future modems
column37: though.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column38: it can pay to listen. After all
column39: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column40: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column41: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

The Motley Fool has the     following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and     short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley Fool     recommends Intel. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Careens Closer to Major AR Announcement;2/16/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) CEO Tim Cook has been talking an awful lot lately about augmented reality - or AR. The latest episode was last week
column3: when hecompared the technology to the iPhonein terms of its potential to be big.makeArticleAd();Source: NanticAfter months of repeatedly playing up AR in public
column4: it's beginning to feel as if Cook is setting the expectations of the press and public about the technology.That begs the question: Is Apple Inc. planning a major augmented reality announcement?AR vs. VR: What's the Difference?Augmented reality is related to virtual reality - or VR - but the two are also very different.Virtual reality uses technology to completely immerse people in a virtual world. This requires powerful computing hardware and special headgear. VR has spent several years as the next big thing
column5: culminating withFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) buying VR pioneer Oculus for $2 billion in 2014.Virtual reality hasn't quite caught on in a big way - the expensive and awkward equipment is a big hurdle to overcome - but gamers have begun embracing it.7 Stocks Warren Buffett Is Buying or SellingSo far
column6: Apple has shown no interest in virtual reality and Tim Cook has actually made a point in several interviews of downplaying VR. In the latest
column7: when Cook spoke toThe Independent
column8: he laments the fact that virtual reality""closes the world out.""""Most people don't want to lock themselves out from the world for a long period of time and today you can't do that because you get sick from it.""The antisocial aspects of virtual reality
column9: the equipment requirements and side effects such as motion sickness have been common themes in Cook's argument against virtual reality.However
column10: he is very excited by augmented reality and its ability to go mainstream. Instead of locking a person into a virtual world
column11: AR overlays the existing world with additional information. One of the most popular examples of AR in action is the gamePokemon Go
column12: released last summer. That game was themost downloaded app of 2016on Apple Inc.'s App Store.Is Apple Inc. Planning a Major AR Announcement?Tim Cook's views on augmented reality seem to have been getting more positive in the past few months
column13: reaching the point where he's actively hyping the technology.In October
column14: he said:""I do think that a significant portion of the population of developed countries
column15: and eventually all countries
column16: will have AR experiences every day
column17: almost like eating three meals a day. It will become that much a part of you.""And last week
column18: he toldThe Independent:""I regard it as a big idea like the smartphone. The smartphone is for everyone
column19: we don't have to think the iPhone is about a certain demographic
column20: or country or vertical market: it's for everyone. I think AR is that big
column21: it's huge.""What's holding AR back is the technology.Hardware doesn't need to be as powerful as the silicon needed to drive virtual reality gear. And rather than a fully enclosed headpiece or goggles - that themselves are so complex they can cost $600 on top of the PC needed to drive them - augmented reality can be delivered through specialized eyeglasses or on a smartphone's display. The problem is current efforts haven't been quite good enough.Alphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOG
column22: NASDAQ:GOOGL) failed Google Glass is the best-known example of the AR overlay glasses model
column23: whilePokemon Goshows the relatively primitive AR experience that current smartphones can deliver.What if Tim Cook has been playing up augmented reality (and dissing VR) because Apple Inc. is preparing to make a major push into AR? It could be the company that takes augmented reality mainstream by nailing the hardware
column24: while everyone else is distracted by trying to get consumers to buy into VR.There has been speculation that Apple is working with German optics firmCarl Zeiss AGonApple-branded AR glasses. The iPhone 8 could also incorporate next generation hardware - from cameras to CPU and GPU - that are optimized to make AR a killer feature.Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Could Win Big With 'Windows Cloud'We'll have to wait until the company is ready to show its hand to know exactly what is up. But based on Tim Cook's continued promotion of the technology
column25: it seems likely that Apple Inc. is priming us for AR-related announcement.And if Cook is even close to being right about augmented reality having the potential to be as big as the iPhone
column26: the upside for Apple stock could be huge.As of this writing
column27: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Stocks to Sell or Short Before the Bears Strike3 Tire Stocks That Are Burning Rubber in ChinaThe postApple Inc. (AAPL) Careens Closer to Major AR Announcementappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Here's What Warren Buffett Is Buying and Selling -- Should You Join Him?;2/16/2017;"According toBerkshire Hathaway's(NYSE: BRK-A) (NYSE: BRK-B) latest SEC filing
column2: Warren Buffett and   company had an active fourth quarter in 2016. After sitting on a   company record $85 billion cash hoard at the end of the third   quarter
column3: and having said that Berkshire spent $12 billion on   common stocks in the wake of Donald Trump's election victory
column4: investors have been wondering what Berkshire has been up to.   Here's the answer.What Berkshire has been buyingWhile we don't necessarily know the reasoning behind   Berkshire's latest investments
column5: or whether they were initiated by   Warren Buffett himself or one of his trusted stock pickers
column6: we do   know what changed in Berkshire's portfolio during the fourth   quarter. Here are the most notable buys:Image Source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();1.Apple-- Berkshire already ownedApple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column7: although the company's $2 billion stake wasn't a   large amount by Berkshire's standards. During the fourth quarter
column8: Berkshire's Apple stake nearly quadrupled to about 57 million   shares
column9: which represent more than 1% of all the outstandingApple stock. It's interesting to note that Buffett's stock-pickers were the   ones who initiated the Apple investment
column10: but given the size of   the increase
column11: the latest Apple addition could have come from   Buffett himself.This investment did not surprise me at all. I'vewritten beforehow Apple still represented a compelling bargain at the price   levels it was trading for during the fourth quarter
column12: and that   Berkshire should take advantage. Well
column13: apparently
column14: management   agreed.2.Airlines-- Berkshire surprised many investors when it revealed its   third-quarter 2016 investments in several airline stocks. After   all
column15: Buffett has spoken out against airline stocks as investments   several times in his career
column16: During the third quarter
column17: Berkshire invested inAmerican Airlines
column18: Delta
column19: andUnited Continental
column20: and increased its stake in all three during the fourth quarter.   At the same time the initial airline stakes were revealed
column21: Buffett also said he made an investment inSouthwest Airlines. He didn't specify the amount at the time
column22: but we now know it's   a stake worth more than $2 billion.3.Monsanto-- Berkshire revealed a new stake inMonsanto
column23: of about eight million shares valued at about $872 million.   Monsanto currently trades for about $109 per share
column24: and the   company plans to sell itself to Bayer for $128. If the deal goes   through
column25: Buffett stands to make a quick profit
column26: but the market   doesn't seem convinced at this point.4.Sirius XM-- The final major change was the addition of a nearly 167   million share position in satellite radio operatorSirius XM. Granted
column27: because of the company's $4.80 share price as of this   writing
column28: this stake translates into a relatively small (for   Berkshire) $800 million investment.What Berkshire has been selling1.Wal-Mart-- Buffett has been gradually trimming hisWal-Martstake for some time
column29: but he sold a substantial number of his   remaining shares. Berkshire's investment in the retail giant has   been cut from about 13 million shares to 1.4 million. As I've   mentioned
column30: we don't know the reasoning
column31: but my guess is that the   success of online retailers like Amazon has changed the   competitive landscape in a way Buffett doesn't like.2.Verizon-- Berkshire sold nearly all of its 15 million shares ofVerizonduring the quarter. Since Berkshire also unloaded itsAT&Tstake earlier in 2016
column32: this didn't come as a huge surprise to   me.3.Kinder Morgan-- Buffett bought about 20 million shares ofKinder Morganin early 2016
column33: and sold his entire position during the fourth   quarter. Kinder Morgan has nearly doubled from its early 2016   lows
column34: so this could be a matter of the valuation simply not   looking attractive to Buffett anymore.4.Deere-- Just like Kinder Morgan
column35: Deerehas rallied sharply
column36: up by about 43% over the past year alone.   So
column37: while we don't know for sure
column38: this sale could potentially be   due to a valuation issue as well.Should you follow Buffett's moves?Not necessarily. For one thing
column39: by the time we even hear about   what Buffett is doing
column40: it can be a completely different market.   Since the fourth quarter ended
column41: the S&P has risen by more   than 4%
column42: and some of the stocks Buffett has bought have risen   even higher than that. Apple
column43: for example
column44: has risen by nearly   17% since the end of 2016
column45: and Apple was trading even cheaper for   much of the quarter. While I don't necessarily think Apple is too   expensive to buy right now
column46: it's fair to say that Buffett and   company likely got a far better deal on their Apple shares than   investors could get now.^SPXdata byYChartsIn addition
column47: while it can be fun to speculate
column48: we don't really   knowwhyBuffett bought or sold any of these stocks. For that reason
column49: it's   important to do your own research and make your investment   decisions based on what's best for you and your long-term   investing strategy -- not just because a billionaire did it   first.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column50: it can pay to listen. After all
column51: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column52: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column53: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: 3 Reasons Warren Buffett Is Buying Apple Stock;2/16/2017;"Warren Buffett nearly quadrupled his stake in Apple (symbolAAPL
column2: $135.51) during the last three months of 2016
column3: according to the latest 13-F filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Buffett's holding company
column4: Berkshire HathawayBRK.B. The big investment is already looking like a shrewd move. Apple shares are setting record highs this week and are up 17% so far in 2017. With a market capitalization
column5: or share price times total shares outstanding
column6: of $711 billion
column7: Apple is the most valuable public company in the world. (Prices as of February 15.)See Also:11 Dow Stocks Owned by Warren BuffettBerkshire initially bought shares in Apple in early 2016. The purchase gained a good deal of attention at the time. Apart from IBM
column8: a stock Buffett followed for more than 50 years before finally buying in 2011
column9: he had shown little interest in technology stocks. The disclosure about the new stake in Apple
column10: made last May
column11: coincided with a period when Apple's shares were on the downswing and sparked wide speculation that Buffett was calling a bottom in the stock.It's not always easy to decipher the reasoning behind Buffett's buying and selling. The Oracle of Omaha tends to be tight-lipped about his investments. It's made all the harder by the fact that changes to Berkshire's holdings aren't revealed to the public until weeks or even months after the fact in quarterly SEC filings. But for buy-and-hold investors
column12: Berkshire's big move into Apple - 57.4 million shares as of December 31
column13: up from 15.2 million at the end of September - can be instructive nonetheless. Here are three reasons we think Warren Buffett is buyingApple stock.makeArticleAd();His Top Guys Told Him to BuyBuffett doesn't deserve all the credit for Berkshire's investment in Apple. In fact
column14: he might deserve little of it. David Kass
column15: a professor at the University of Maryland's Robert H. Smith School of Business who studies Buffett and is a Berkshire shareholder
column16: suspects that one or both of Buffett's chief stock-picking lieutenants
column17: Ted Weschler and Todd Combs
column18: are behind the move into Apple. Still
column19: Apple does have some of the attributes Buffett has said he likes: It's a leader in its market
column20: and it has a ton of cash at its disposal ($246 billion in cash and securities as of the end of 2016).The Price Was RightAt $135
column21: Apple shares are much pricier today than they were when Berkshire was amassing its stake. During 2016
column22: the stock price ranged from a low of $90 to a high of $118. Still
column23: UBS analysts say the price gain is deserved due in large part to the high retention rates among iPhone buyers. UBS rates Apple stock a ""buy
column24: but picking up shares all at once at peak prices isn't necessarily the best approach. Instead
column25: take a cue from Buffett and spread out your buying to take advantage of any periodic dips.The Debut of iPhone 8This year marks the 10th anniversary of the iPhone
column26: and company watchers expect big things when Apple unveils the latest version of the mobile device. Apple sold 5% fewer iPhones year-over-year during the three months that ended in September
column27: the final quarter of its 2016 fiscal year. But year-over-year sales growth returned in the December quarter
column28: up 5%
column29: and the new iPhone 8 is expected to rejuvenate demand later this year. (A release date hasn't been announced.) Analysts believe the new smartphone will set sales records as it prompts users to upgrade from older iPhones.Take the Quiz:How Well Do You Really Know Warren Buffett?"
