column1: 15 Big Changes Since the S&P 500 Market Cap Doubled to $20 Trillion;2/15/2017;"Milestones seem to be falling at a breakneck pace over the   past couple of years. On Monday
column2: Feb. 13
column3: the broad-basedS&P 500(SNPINDEX: ^GSPC) closed at an all-time record high
column4: and in the   process
column5: the aggregate value of S&P 500 companies crossed the   $20 trillion threshold for the first time ever. For Wall Street
column6: the milestone represents affirmation that the bull-market rally   is here to stay.However
column7: it took quite some time for the S&P 500 to double   based on market cap from $10 trillion to $20 trillion - 19 years   -- given the dot-com bubble in 2000-2001
column8: as well as the Great   Recession. Here are just some of the things that've changed over   those 19 years.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL)stock:In 1998
column9: the technology giant was still nearly a decade from     introducing the world to the iPhone
column10: and it controlled about     0.06% of the S&P 500's weighting. Today
column11: at a better than     $700 billion market cap
column12: Apple and its army of loyal customers     is responsible for about 3.5% of the S&P 500's     weighting.Gallon of gas:A gallon of gas would set you back $1.07 by the end of January     1998
column13: whereas today the average gallon of gas costs $2.31.Image source: Getty Images.Price per ounce of gold:At the end of January 1998
column14: you could pick up an ounce of gold     for $302.02. Today
column15: that same ounce of gold will cost you about     $1
column16: 228.30.Price per ounce of silver:Toward the end of January 1998
column17: an ounce of silver could be     purchased for just $6.22. As of today
column18: that same silver ounce     is worth $17.94.Movie ticket price:Heading to the movies in 1998 would have cost an average of     $4.69 on an inflation-adjusted basis
column19: compared with an     estimated $8.65 per ticket today.Median home price:If you were purchasing a home in January 1998
column20: you were dealing     with a median home price of $148
column22: according to the Census     Bureau. As of the third quarter of 2016
column23: the median home prices     in the U.S. was up to $247
column24: 000.Unemployment rate:The unemployment picture is very similar
column25: with the unemployment     rate in January 1998 (4.6%) coming in just below that of     January 2017 (4.8%).Image source: Disneyland.Disney World ticket price:Heading toDisney(NYSE: DIS) World in Florida in 1998 would have cost $39.75 per     adult
column26: or $288 for an annual pass. Today
column27: a regular ticket runs     $115
column28: with an annual pass setting a consumer back $779. Mind     you
column29: Disney just increased its theme-park ticket prices this     week.Wilshire 5000:The Wilshire 5000 market-cap-weighted index contained more than     7
column30: 500 companies as of July 1998
column31: as private companies rushed to     meet investor demand and go public. By Dec. 31
column33: there     were only 3
column34: 618 publicly traded companies in the Wilshire     5000.30-year fixed mortgage rate:At the beginning of January 1998
column35: homebuyers would have been     dealing with an average 30-year mortgage rate of 6.99%. Today
column36: the 30-year rate is a more appealing 4.27%
column37: perBankrate.One dozen eggs:Back in 1998
column38: heading to the store for a dozen eggs would set     you back $1.09. As of December 2016
column39: the price for a dozen eggs     had only risen to $1.38 (although that's down 50% from December     2015).Image source: Pixabay.Bacon price per pound:Back in 1998
column40: a pound of sizzling bacon would set a consumer     back $2.96. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics
column41: a     pound of sliced bacon was selling for $5.10 in December     2016.National debt:All the way back in 1998
column42: the federal debt totaled ""just"" shy     of $5.8 trillion. Within a matter of weeks
column43: we're liable to     cross the $20 trillion federal debt threshold.Median household income:In 1998
column44: median household income was $51
column46: when adjusted for     inflation. By 2015
column47: the latest data available from Census data
column48: median household income had risen to $55
column49: 775.U.S. postage stamp:A U.S. postage stamp increased to $0.33 in 1998
column50: which     compares with the $0.47 consumers pay for postage stamps     today.Prices change
column51: but one aspect remains quite     steadyA lot has changed over the past 19 years as the S&P 500's   market cap has doubled in value. Yet despite these big changes
column52: one factor remains firmly in place: Over time
column53: the valuation of   the stock market
column54: and of high-quality companies
column55: tends to   increase.Image source: Getty Images.On average
column56: the stock market returns about 7% per year
column57: with   dividend reinvestment factored in. This would put the stock   market on track to double in value about once every decade.   Understand
column58: this is just an average
column59: and as we saw between 1998   and 2017
column60: it took a bit longer. Then again
column61: culling data can be   arbitrary. For example
column62: the S&P 500 has risen more than   threefold since its lows in 2009. If you had regularly been   buying stocks without paying any attention to where the S&P   500 was
column63: you'd likely have purchased companies that have   increased multiple times in value since 2009.According to data from Yardeni Research
column64: the S&P 500 has   undergone 35 stock market corrections of at least 10% since 1950
column65: when rounded to the nearest whole number. In every single   instance
column66: the stock-market correction was wiped out by a   bull-market rally. Sometimes it took weeks
column67: months
column68: and in rarer   cases a few years
column69: but when all was said and done
column70: patient   long-term investors were rewarded with a higher-marching stock   market.What's more
column71: a study released by J.P. Morgan Asset Management   found that holding the S&P 500 between January 1988 and   November 2015 would have led to an average annualized return of   10.8%. However
column72: missing just its 40 best days over this 27-year
column73: roughly 7
column74: 000-day period would have reduced your average annual   return to 2.9%!The data doesn't lie. Holding high-quality companies over the   long run
column75: and buying companies at regular intervals
column76: regardless   of where the S&P 500 or other indexes are valued
column77: is a   winning strategy.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock   tip
column78: it can pay to listen. After all
column79: the newsletter   they have run for over a decade
column80: the Motley Fool Stock   Advisor
column81: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are theten best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Wal-Mart wasn't one   of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even   better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as ofDecember 12

column1: Warren Buffett's Huge Stake in Apple: What He May See In AAPL;2/15/2017;"Warren Buffett and Berkshire Hathaway (BRK-A
column2: BRK-B) have long been adverse to investing in technology companies. That mantra started to change in 2011
column3: when Berkshire startedinvestingin IBM (IBM).Since then
column4: his investment manager lieutenants
column5: Todd Combs and Ted Weschler
column6: have added to Berkshire's investment portfolio
column7: buying up stakes in technology companies
column8: but never to the size and scope of the IBM investment
column9: which was $11 billion at the time.Now
column10: it looks as if Buffett is doing it again -- this time with Apple (AAPL).makeArticleAd();In a recently released SEC filing
column11: Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway revealed it now owns a sizable stake in the Cupertino
column12: Calif.-based tech giant. At the end of the fourth-quarter
column13: it owned  57.4 million shares
column14: up from 15.2 million shares in a previous filing. At current prices
column15: the stake is worth just over $7 billion
column16: likely making the stake with Buffett's approval
column17: if not done himself.Without putting words into his mouth
column18: the Apple stake is likely similar to IBM in Buffett's eyes
column19: as the venerable iPhone maker is becoming a services company
column20: one with steady revenue coming from dependable subscriptions.Buffett's investment isn't about what technology is the ""next big thing
column21: whether augmented reality is asbigas Apple thinks it will be or whether Apple is really making a car or not. It's pure and simple economics and the attractiveness of the subscription model.In Apple's fiscal first-quarter
column22: itgenerated$7.1 billion in Service revenue
column23: from things like Apple Music
column24: iTunes
column25: the App Store
column26: Apple Pay and more. It's the healthiest portion of Apple's business
column27: one that's growing at 18% year-over-year. CEO Tim Cook hassaidthat Apple's Service business will be the size of a Fortune 500 company sometime this year
column28: indicating that growth isn't slowing down anytime soon.Yes
column29: Apple is still beholden to sales of the iPhone
column30: iPad and the Mac for the majority of its revenue
column31: but the Service business is slowly
column32: but surely
column33: making Apple's revenue smoother and less lumpier from a quarterly perceptive. Visible
column34: growing revenue is worth significantly more than revenue from hardware that acts like a roller coaster
column35: with ups and downs.All investors need to do is look at the earnings multiples for companies like Salesforce.com (CRM)
column36: Microsoft (MSFT) and others to see the positive impact. Companies that have enormous subscription-based revenue
column37: which put off tremendous amounts of operating cash flow in a predictable manner are ultimately more valuable than ones that do not.The company has a goal of doubling its Service revenue by 2020
column38: which is an admittedly large task. But with a user base of over 1 billion active devices
column39: Apple should be able to continue to grow parts of its Service business
column40: like Apple Music and the App Store
column41: as it continues to add new features (namely
column42: TV shows for Apple Music).It's likely we will hear more about Buffett's Apple stake in the days and weeks to come. If we do get commentary from the Oracle of Omaha himself
column43: expect Services and predictable revenue to be a big part of the line of thinking.I know it would be for me."

column1: Apple Inc. Stock Keeps Rising
column2: Putting A Chokehold On Short-Sellers (AAPL);2/15/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(AAPL) stock is choking short-sellers afterGoldman Sachs Group Inc(GS) boosted its price target 13%
column4: pushing the iPhone maker's shares tonew highsagain and again.makeArticleAd();Analysts and investors are practically salivating over the yet-to-be revealed iPhone 8/ iPhone X
column5: and they lapped up Apple management's comments about services revenue doubling over the next four years.Meanwhile
column6: short interest in Apple stock rises along with the share price as bears bide their time and try to wait out the growing pain.GS's Apple Stock Target: $150 Per ShareIn a research note dated Feb. 13
column7: Goldman Sachs analyst Simona Jankowski said sheboosted her price targeton Apple stock from $133 to $150 per share. She noted that it's looking more and more like 3D sensing technology will be in the iPhone 8 this year
column8: based on data points from Lumentum. This technology paves the way for the inclusion of augmented reality features on the device
column9: marking a ""significant step-up in innovation"" for this year.Her supply chain checks back up the other reports pointing to a third iPhone model with a massive 5.8-inch display being released this year. She sees starting prices of $649 and $769 for the 4.7-inch and 5.5-inch iPhone models for this year
column10: which other analysts are calling the iPhone 7s and 7s Plus. Also like other reports from other sources
column11: Jankowski's checks suggest that the third model
column12: called the iPhone 8 or iPhone X
column13: will be priced higher than the other two models. Some reports have pegged the starting price at orabove $1
column15: although she didn't specify a starting price tag.The Goldman analyst's price target boost for Apple stock is based on a higher multiple of 16 times (versus 14 times previously) due to an expected acceleration in earnings growth over the next couple of years.Short-Sellers Burned by AAPL StockAfter touching a new record high on Monday
column16: Apple stock hit another high on Tuesday and continued to climb
column17: approaching $135 per share in the wake of Goldman's price target lift. Apple stock is now up by more than 16% year to date
column18: and short-sellers are down more than $71 million
column19: according to data from financial analytics firm S3 Partners.Apple Inc. Hits New All-Time Highs. What's Next?As is typical of short interest
column20: the firm said interest in Apple stock was rising along with the stock price between 2009 and 2014 for risk management and hedging purposes in addition to simple short bets.However
column21: over the last three years
column22: short interest in Apple stock has been falling as the shares kept hitting new record highs
column23: says S3.Last year
column24: short interest averaged $6.04 billion and traded between $4.4 billion and $6.9 billion
column25: although it spiked to $10 billion in late March amid the stock's lowest level in two years at $90.34. Short-sellers lost $432 million in total last year as Apple stock rose 9.93%.Short interest in the name is down this year
column26: but S3 Partners says portfolio managers' losses on their $5.6 billion short or hedging position are much bigger. The firm said financing costs surpassed $2.1 million in the first six weeks of this year
column27: but the mark to market P/L is a loss of $794.5 million.The shorts are down 14.26% year to date in total
column28: net of financing.With all the pain
column29: it's no surprise that few are just betting outright that Apple stock will fall. S3 said most currentshort interestin Apple stock is market-related portfolio heads or hedges for derivative securities. The firm added that core short interest in the name ranges from $4.5 billion to $7 billion
column30: so in order to say there's ""an appreciable"" number of short-sellers betting on a share price decline
column31: interest would have to trend past $7 billion.The postApple Stock Keeps Rising
column32: Putting A Chokehold On Short-Sellersappeared first onValueWalk.Many academics claim investing is a ""random walk."" We believe this to be only partially true. It is our core belief that value investing can outperform the market
column33: hence the name ""ValueWalk."" Your number one source for breaking news and evergreen content on everything value investing and hedge funds.Check out our new free Underrated Small Cap Stocks newsletterAlso Sign Up For Our Free Newsletter and receive in-depth ebooks on famous investorsMore From InvestorPlace7 Tech Stocks With Explosive Growth PotentialThe Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018The postApple Inc. Stock Keeps Rising
column34: Putting A Chokehold On Short-Sellers (AAPL)appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Move Over China: India's the Best Place to Invest Right Now;2/14/2017;"(1:30) - Apple to begin iPhone manufacturing in India(6:15) - Tesla speculates opening the doors into India's   Market(9:15) - Internet Expansion   in India(13:35) - Amazon's Big Investment into India(21:30) - India's influencing infrastructure(25:25) - Stock Re-capWelcome to Episode #70 of the Zacks Market Edge Podcast.Every week
column2: host and Zacks stock strategist
column3: Tracey Ryniec
column4: will be joined by guests to discuss the hottest investing topics in stocks
column5: bonds and ETFs and how it impacts your life.In this episode
column6: Tracey is joined by Neena Mishra
column7: Zacks Director of ETF Research and also the editor ofZacks Income Investor.But she's not on the show this week to talk about ETFs or income stocks. No
column8: she's joining Tracey to discuss a far more important topic: the investing opportunities in India.Neena just returned from a trip to India where she noticed that there was a lot more optimism about the economy.Prime Minister Modi has been trying to institute economic reforms to open up India's economy
column9: which has been notoriously closed off to foreign investment. Given the developments over the last few years
column10: it looks like he is succeeding.While many American technology and social media companies are shut out of China for various reasons
column11: India has seemingly opened its doors. With 1.2 billion people
column12: and growing
column13: many companies would love to tap that consumer base.With one of the largest populations of Millennials in the world
column14: and a growing middle class
column15: 2017 could be the year of India.Tracey and Neena discuss 5 ways in which investors can invest in India's rising economic power
column16: without even leaving the shores of the United States.5 Stocks to Play the Indian Growth Story1.AppleAAPLonly has 2% of India's smartphone market. Estimated at 300 million
column17: and growing
column18: that's just a small sliver of the market. But until 2017
column19: it hasn't been able to open Apple retail stores in the country. Thanks to a deal to manufacture the phones in India
column20: which will bring costs of the phones down for consumers
column21: Apple could soon be tapping India's growing elite.2.TeslaTSLAappears to be poised to enter the India market after CEO Elon Musk tweeted out in February 2017 that it is looking to enter India in mid-2017. There are also rumors that a long-awaited Tesla Asia manufacturing plant may get the green light in India
column22: instead of China. Stay tuned.3.FacebookFBhas long been shut out of the massive Chinese market
column23: but that's not the case in India. One problem in India
column24: however
column25: has been the poor Internet infrastructure. There are just 250 million data subscribers
column26: although that number is growing quickly. In 2016
column27: Facebook tried to give away the Internet in India but was shot down by the government. However
column28: data companies have been quickly expanding which is helping Facebook's reach. In the fourth quarter of last year
column29: India was Facebook's fastest growing market.4.AmazonAMZNhas put the most on the line in India as it has already spent about $5 billion to expand its fulfillment centers and delivery service in the country. Amazon Prime has launched in 100 cities. 10% of India's population speaks English
column30: which makes it the second largest English speaking country
column31: after the United States
column32: in the world. It's facing competition
column33: however
column34: from Alibaba and homegrown FlipKart and Snapdeal. But it has launched Amazon Video and a recent 3-day Great Indian Sale saw sales growth surge over 200% compared to a regular shopping day.5.NetflixNFLXhas an aggressive international expansion plan
column35: and it includes India. In December 2016
column36: just as Amazon Video launched
column37: Netflix announced a partnership with Bollywood movie star and producer
column38: Shah Rukh Khan. Right now
column39: Neena says Netflix is charging around $10 a month for its streaming service. That is high for India. But
column40: again
column41: companies are looking at the growth potential.What else should you know about India and investing in its hot growth story in 2017?Find out the answers to this and more on this week's podcast.Zacks' Best Investment Ideas for Long-Term ProfitmakeArticleAd();Today you can gain access to long-term trades with double and triple-digit profit potential rarely available to the public. Starting now
column42: you can look inside our stocks under $10
column43: home run and value stock portfolios
column44: plus more.Want a peek at this private information?Click here>>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today
column45: you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days.Click to get this free reportAmazon.com

column1: Visa Checkout Is Growing Fast -- but Is That Enough?;2/14/2017;"Visa Inc(NYSE: V) investors certainly had reason to celebrate in the days   following its 2017 first-quarter results. The stock price popped   on the revenue and earnings beat and is now up 9% year to date.   Underlying business fundamentals also look strong. Net operating   revenue
column2: adjusted net income
column3: and earnings per share were all up   more than 20% year over year. More importantly
column4: itsintegrationwith Visa Europe appears to be moving along smoothly and   efficiently.Image source: Visa Inc Newsroom.makeArticleAd();While Visa continues to show signs of growth
column5: management knows   it cannot take this growth for granted. The competition in the   payments industry is too fierce for any company not constantly   innovating to flourish for long. During the conference call   following the quarterly earnings release
column6: new CEO Al Kelly   identified six guiding pillars he believes are crucial to Visa's   foundation and future growth. The last of these pillars is   digital expansion
column7: which Kelly believes is best represented by   Visa's heavy investment in Visa Checkout. Kelly said:E-commerce enabled by mobile and other form factors is a     significant opportunity. And we are definitely investing behind     it. As payments move from the physical to digital world
column8: we're     leading the way in developing solutions for our clients
column9: our     partners and consumers. One great example of this is Visa     Checkout. We now have over 18 million consumer accounts in 23     countries and over 1
column10: 500 financial institutional partners     participating around the world. More than 300
column11: 000 online     merchants have signed on to accept Visa Checkout
column12: representing     $173 billion in addressable volume.Visa Checkout is the company's payment platform that allows   accountholders to store their credit card information and make   purchases from third-party retail websites. This allows consumers   to buy things online without having to enter their payment   information
column13: a cumbersome process especially difficult from   mobile devices. Retailers love these types of solutions because   it makes the checkout process smoother and quicker
column14: leading to   greater sales and lesscart abandonment.Visa Checkout's potent growthThe numbers Kelly cited for Visa Checkout's growth certainly   look impressive. The platform has grown its consumer accounts   80%
column15: its financial institution partners by 150%
column16: and online   merchants accepting the platform by 20% since last year's   first-quarter earnings report. That's some pretty strong   year-over-year growth.The Visa Checkout page on Pizza Hut's website. Image source:Visa Inc NewsroomNeedless to say
column17: the company invested a lot into Visa Checkout   this past year
column18: and it shows. In the 2016 fourth-quarter   conference call
column19: former CEO Charlie Scharf said Visa had rolled   out a redesigned Visa Checkout experience to all worldwide   merchants making it easier for customers to sign up and complete   purchases with mobile devices. The company also opened the   platform to its card-issuing partners
column20: allowing them to integrate   their own digital wallets into Visa Checkout. Judging by the   numbers
column21: these efforts have yielded decent results.Is the growth enough to justify another digital wallet?Despite the heady growth
column22: though
column23: there still seem to be some   lingering questions in CEO Kelly's mind about whether the heavy   investments in resources and effort are worth it. Later in the   conference call
column24: when answering a question from an analyst
column25: he   expressed some of these doubts:My personal view is that there are too many wallets out     there. Consumers are not going to ultimately want to have 50     wallets. And we're not necessarily anxious just to be in the     wallet business per se
column26: but we're anxious to be -- to take     advantage of us being a trusted acceptance mark in the payments     eco space and want to be able to make sure that we're taking a     leading position in establishing Visa as a trusted mark and as     an important partner to our issuers in terms of them trying to     establish as much volume as they can get in the digital     space.These misgivings are probably justified. While Visa Checkout   experienced significant growth to reach 18 million consumer   accounts
column27: PayPal Holdings Inc.currently has almost 200 million active accounts and   accounted for more than 1.75 billion payment transactions last   quarter.Meanwhile
column28: Amazon.com Inc.'s Amazon Payments recentlyannouncedit had 33 million customers who used its platform to make a   purchase
column29: and that payment volume had doubled year over year. In   September
column30: Apple Inc.announcedcustomers would be able to use Apple Pay to purchase products   online when using a Mac
column31: iPad
column32: or iPhone. Apple Pay also   experienced explosive annual growth
column33: as CEO Tim Cook announced   transaction volume had grown by more than 500% year over year in   the company's 2017 first-quarter conference call.Doubts or not
column34: Kelly knows Visa cannot just walk away from   hosting a digital wallet. In the quote above
column35: he acknowledges   that the company's card-issuing banking partners want ""as much   volume as they can get in the digital space."" These banks are   ultimately Visa's real customers
column36: and Visa cannot afford to lose   any simply because it doesn't want to invest in the space. For   this reason alone
column37: it is well worth Visa's time and resources to   continue to innovate and market Visa Checkout. Whether the   platform will ever really catch on with the end consumer is   another matter entirely and is anybody's guess.10 stocks we like better than VisaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column38: it can pay to listen. After all
column39: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column40: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column41: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now...and Visa wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column42: 2017.Matthew Cochraneowns shares of Amazon and PayPal Holdings. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Amazon
column43: Apple
column44: PayPal Holdings
column45: and     Visa. The Motley Fool has the following options: long January     2018 $90 calls on Apple and short January 2018 $95 calls on     Apple. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: iPhone 8 Rumors: Will Apple Use Long-Distance Charging From Energous?;2/14/2017;"Welcome to the newest Zacks exclusive podcast! On the very first episode of Zacks Tech Talk Tuesday
column2: Content Writer Ryan McQueeney explores some of the prevailing theories surrounding the iPhone 8
column3: including the rumor that Apple is teaming up with another company to deliver long-distance wireless charging in the upcoming phone.Tech Talk TuesdayBrought to you by the co-host of theZacks Friday Finish Line
column4: Tech Talk Tuesday is a new biweekly podcast designed for all of the tech-crazed investors out there. The show will focus specifically on the hardware and software products that drive the sales of some of the world's biggest technology companies.In the world of tech investing
column5: it is easy to get lost in the endless sea of market data. One can easily forget about what these companies are actually doing: innovating
column6: inventing
column7: and trying to change the word. Tech Talk Tuesday is here to remind us about the amazing technology of the present and the fascinating potential of the future.iPhone 8 RumorsFor the first Tech Talk Tuesday
column8: the focus was planted squarely on the tech world's biggest name: Apple Inc.AAPL.Apple is celebrating the 10-year anniversary of its flagship iPhone line
column9: and consumers are already expecting three new phones from the company in 2017. Apple will most likely deliver ""7s"" and ""7s Plus"" options in the first half of the year
column10: with the iPhone 8 coming towards holiday season.Of course
column11: this is just speculation at this point. But speculation is fun. Speculating about what Apple is going to do next is one of the most fun things ever. You literally never know exactly what the company is up to
column12: but it is fascinating to compile the leaks
column13: reports
column14: and rumors.As for the iPhone 8
column15: one of the main rumors so far is related to the inclusion of wireless charging technology in the phone. Wireless charging is an interesting concept
column16: and current options rely on magnetic energy to charge
column17: requiring users to place their device on some sort of compatible pad.Enter Energous CorporationWATT
column18: an innovative wireless charging company that uses RF waves to charge. Energous promises ""long-distance"" wireless charging
column19: and many people think the company could be teaming up with Apple to incorporate the tech in the iPhone 8.This week's episode explores the reality of Energous' involvement with the phone and raises some questions as to whether the company will ever be able to deliver the charging technology it claims to have.If you enjoy the episode
column20: make sure to subscribe and leave a rating! Thanks for joining
column21: and we will see you next time!Which Stocks are Zacks Experts Talking About?Stocks in today's headlines may be tempting buys

column1: Apple at All-Time High: Poised for More Growth as Anticipation for Next iPhone Builds;2/14/2017;"In anticipation of its 10thanniversary iPhone
column2: due out this spring
column3: Apple Inc.AAPLlooks poised to build on its already stellar 2017. The tech giant closed Monday at an all-time high of $133.31 per share in after-hours trading
column4: jumping 0.9%
column5: and it is up to $134.19 after early Tuesday morning trading. Apple's stock is up 15% since the beginning of 2017.The company posted all-time high quarterly revenue of $78.4 billion in its first fiscal quarter of 2017
column6: which ended December 31
column7: 2016. Apple has once again reached an elusive $700 billion market value
column8: after becoming the first publicly traded U.S. company to do so in February 2015. The $700 billion value places the company firmly at the top of the U.S. food chain
column9: nearly $120 billion above GoogleGOOGL
column10: now Alphabet.""We're thrilled to report that our holiday quarter results generated Apple's highest quarterly revenue ever
column11: and broke multiple records along the way
column12: Apple CEO Tim Cook said in a press release.""We sold more iPhones than ever before and set all-time revenue records for iPhone
column13: Services
column14: Mac and Apple Watch. Revenue from Services grew strongly over last year
column15: led by record customer activity on the App Store
column16: and we are very excited about the products in our pipeline.""The company's flagship product
column17: the iPhone
column18: was born on June 29
column19: 2007. The transformative smartphone helped catapult Apple to where it is today.Now
column20: nearly a decade later
column21: details of the iPhone 8
column22: or the iPhone X
column23: a rumored name
column24: might just pack enough new features to encourage a huge uptick in purchases. But more importantly
column25: it could signal that Apple is once again making massive jumps in innovation
column26: which the last few iPhones lacked.The normally measured Cook spoke recently about groundbreaking new plans
column27: which could include augmented reality.Leaks about the upcoming iPhone have started to come out
column28: and they are bold. Some of the ""supply chain"" leaks suggest Apple's new iPhone ""will change this industry deeply.""Speculation suggeststhe iPhone 8 could be made almost entirely of glass
column29: charge wirelessly and come in three different sizes.It could also have an OLED screen
column30: which would help boost battery life dramatically.Cook announced last month Apple's plan to double the company's $24.35 billion services business by 2021. The CEO also suggested upcoming tax reforms would allow the company to bring home cash held overseas to help bolster mergers and acquisitions.International sales accounted for 64% of Apple's first quarter revenue. This is massively important as the company tries to hold ground in highly competitive Asian markets
column31: especially China
column32: the world's largest smartphone market. Part of this growth is due to increased app purchases and streaming music subscriptions.Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc.
column33: BRK.Ahas poured millions of dollars into Apple over the last year
column34: which brings its stake to nearly $1.5 billion. The ""Wizard of Omaha"" backing a company is rarely a bad sign.However
column35: iPad sales have leveled off
column36: and the Apple Watch has not yet made the splash the company has hoped for. But the Apple Watch still claimed63% of the still new smartwatch marketin the fourth quarter. Its second-generation waterproof model could be bigger than the first.And still
column37: Apple's iOS products are on track toreach nearly a trillion dollars in sales.The company's Beats Electronics brand
column38: which it purchased for $3 billion in 2014
column39: holds a lot of cachet in popular culture
column40: including professional sports and music. And their new Airpod earbuds have potential to catch on quickly.An estimated 85% to 90% of iPhone users will buy another iPhone
column41: according to UBS. There are currentlyover 600 million iPhonesbeing used worldwide
column42: many of which are models 6 or lower. This means a lot of people could upgrade this year
column43: especially with the introduction of iPhone X
column44: its most game-changing phone in years.Which Stocks are Zacks Experts Talking About?makeArticleAd();Stocks in today's headlines may be tempting buys

column1: Apple
column2: Inc.'s First 2 Original TV Shows Are Almost Here;2/14/2017;"Investors have known for quite some time thatApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) ispushing into original content
column3: primarily as a way to differentiate its Apple Music service   from rival music streamers. Apple has been investing in a handful   of new TV shows that will be exclusive to Apple Music
column4: and the   first two are almost here.The first is a reality TV series that focuses on apps and app   developers
column5: calledPlanet of the Apps. Celebrity advisors Jessica Alba
column6: Gwyneth Paltrow
column7: Gary   Vaynerchuk
column8: and will.i.am will offer to guide new developers   in an effort to win funding from prominent Silicon Valley venture   capital firm Lightspeed Venture Partners
column9: which incidentally is   about to make a fortune on an app it funded years ago:Snap.Apple started casting for the show last summer
column10: which is kind   of likeThe Voicemixed withShark Tankbut for apps. Speaking at the Code Media conference last night
column11: Apple services chief Eddy Cue said the show would debut in the   spring on Apple Music as well as through a dedicated app.   Episodes will be released in a linear fashion
column12: one at a time   (sorry
column13: binge watchers).makeArticleAd();The second isCarpool Karaoke
column14: which is based on the popular segment of the same name fromThe Late Late Showwith James Corden. This one was already publicized
column15: as no one can   forget CEO Tim Cook singing ""Sweet Home Alabama"" at WWDC last   year before confirming that the series was coming to Apple Music.   The show will feature 16 celebrity hosts
column16: and will likewise be   released weekly instead of all at once.Personally
column17: neither show looks particularly compelling to me.   But that's precisely the challenge that Apple now faces.If the strategy fails
column18: it will fail (relatively) cheaplyGiven the extremely diverse spectrum of consumer preferences   when it comes to video content
column19: Apple will need to create content   across a wide range of genres that appeal to a wide range of   consumers if the company truly wants to position original content   as a differentiator and selling feature in a meaningful way. As   Apple Music expands around the world
column20: Apple will also need to   localize content and cater to local preferences in geographical   regions all around the world.That'sexpensive
column21: and a tough balance even for pure-play media companies that   specialize in and have deep experience with content. Apple has   neither
column22: even if it has deep pockets. Furthermore
column23: the company   has made it quite clear that it its content strategy is intended   to bolster Apple Music
column24: and has no intention to launch a   stand-alone video streaming service (although not for a lack of trying). Besides
column25: who subscribes to a music service specifically in   order to get video content?Apple Music. Image source: Apple.However
column26: there is some potential forPlanet of the Appsto inspire a new generation of developers
column27: which would be a   secondary benefit. Apple relies heavily on its army of   third-party developers to keep its digital repositories flush   with app content
column28: and culturally reinforcing its pipeline of   developers is a good thing. The show may serve in part as a giant   episodic marketing campaign to come develop for iOS.This is likely just the beginning for Apple
column29: and presumably   the company will diversify its content strategy further going   forward. Fortunately for investors
column30: the risks are fairly modest   for a company of this size. While shows are expensive -- a season   can easily cost tens of millions of dollars -- they're much less   than if Apple were to pursue some sort oftheoretical blockbuster acquisitionaround video streaming. On top of that
column31: Apple Music's revenue run   rate is in excess of $2.4 billion right now
column32: based on the 20   million subscribers it disclosed in December.I still think the original content strategy is misguided
column33: but   at least the financial risks are small if it fails.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column34: it can pay to listen. After all
column35: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column36: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column37: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Tuesday Apple Rumors: iPhone 7s May Use Aluminum Casing;2/14/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of iPhone 7s and iPhone 8 changes. Today
column3: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Tuesday.makeArticleAd();iPhone Casing:A new rumor claims that the iPhone 7s and iPhone 8 will use different casings
column4: reportsMacRumors. According to this rumor
column5: the tech company plans to continue using aluminum casings on its iPhone 7s. However it claims the iPhone 8 will use a glass casing with a stainless steel frame. This isn't the first time that this rumor has popped up. The current iteration of it comes from unnamed sources in AAPL's supply chain.Fingerprint Sensor:Apple has filed a patent for a new way to read fingerprints
column6: AppleInsidernotes. This new patent is for a way to scan a person's fingerprints without using a dedicated scanner. It includes using micro-LED technology that could sense the fingerprints. This technology is already available in most smartphones
column7: which could make it easy to integrate into AAPL's devices. It is possible that this method will make its way into the iPhone 8
column8: which rumors claim will have a full display on the front without a dedicated Home button.Apple Music:Eddy Cue
column9: AAPL's senior vice president of Internet Software and Services
column10: says that the company's music streaming service is still growing
column11: reports9to5Mac. According to Cue
column12: Music is now ""well past"" having 20 million subscribers. The service reached 20 million subscribers in December 2016. While Cue doesn't give exact numbers
column13: it appears that the music streaming service is doing well.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postTuesday Apple Rumors: iPhone 7s May Use Aluminum Casingappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Finding the Gems in the Dow;2/14/2017;"In late January
column2: the Dow Jones Industrial Average hit 20
column4: a milestone that was met with plenty of fanfare. Like many stock market-related headlines
column5: however
column6: the Dow's big day should be taken with a grain of salt. Yes
column7: it represents a rise in the index
column8: and that's not a bad thing
column9: but the number itself really isn't significant.As a matter of fact
column10: breaking 20
column11: 000 isn't even that remarkable when you consider the trajectory of the Dow since its inception in 1896. It took over a decade to reach 100
column12: then 66 years to reach 1
column14: then another 41 years to make 15
column15: 000 (in May 2013). In fact
column16: it hovered around 10
column17: 000 for a decade:makeArticleAd();All things considered
column18: rising by 5
column19: 000 in three-and-a-half years isn't that big a deal.The Motley Fool's Daniel Kline writes
column20: ""In practical terms
column22: 000 means nothing. It's just a round number
column23: and it's easier to celebrate those than picking a random one."" He says Trump's promises to ease regulation and lower business taxes were key drivers behind the Dow's push and argues
column24: ""Because Trump is something we have never seen before…we have no idea what might happen because there is no precedent.""Mohamed El-Erian
column25: Bloomberg columnist and chief economic adviser for Allianz
column26: is equally dispassionate about the market event. ""Let's start by acknowledging
column27: he writes
column28: ""that the DJIA is far from comprehensive when it comes to analytical content. The index covers a very narrow set of stocks and therefore is lacking in representation."" He argues that evaluating the implications of the ""hype about the Dow reaching 20
column29: 000 comes down to evaluating the volume of the signal
column30: the influence on investing and business behaviors
column31: and the implications for economic governance.""Like others
column32: I think the importance of this milestone has a relatively short shelf-life. Eventually
column33: the market will move on to more significant things like corporate earnings
column34: valuations
column35: industry developments
column36: and related issues. That said
column37: I think the market event presents two important takeaways for investors:The power of long-term investing and compounding returns. Over long periods of time
column38: the stock market is one of the best ways to generate long-term wealth. Since 1928
column39: the Dow Jones 30 has produced an annualized return of about 10%
column40: including dividends. By reaching 20
column42: the Dow reminds us of the long-term wealth creation that can be achieved when investing in the markets over time with discipline. If the returns over the next 7-10 years are close to the 10% annual return the Dow has generated historically
column43: we could see Dow 40
column44: 000 by around 2025-2027.Returns don't come in a straight line. If you are just getting into the market now or you have funds to put to work
column45: you shouldn't expect the same returns in the market over the next five years that the last five years have generated
column46: and there will be plenty of bumps along the way. The reason that stocks produce the returns they do is because they are risky in the short term. When you get excited by events like the Dow hitting 20
column47: 000 and think you might be missing out
column48: always remember that you have to be able to stomach short-term volatility to get the long-term gains stocks have produced.Using my guru-based stock screening models
column49: I found the following high-scoring picks among the Dow 30:International Business Machines Corporation (IBM)is a technology company that operates through five segments: Global Technology Services (GTS)
column50: Global Business Services (GBS)
column51: Software
column52: Systems Hardware and Global Financing. The company earns a perfect score under our James O'Shaughnessy-inspired stock screening model based on its size ($168.5 billion) and cash flow-per-share of $17.11 which is well above the market average of $1.43. Trailing 12-month sales of $79.9 billion are nearly 4 times the market average (required to be 1.5 times the average).UnitedHealth Group Incorporated (UNH)is a diversified healthcare company that earns high marks under our Martin Zweig-based investment methodology given its current price-earnings ratio of 22.13 which compares favorably with the market P/E of 18.0. In order to pass this screen
column53: revenue growth must not be substantially lower than earnings growth (for earnings to continue to grow over time they must be supported by a comparable or better sales growth rate). With revenue growth of 13.63% and earnings growth of 8.9% (based on 3
column54: 4 and 5 year averages)
column55: UNH passes this screen. The company also earns a perfect score under our O'Shaughnessy-based model due to its size (market capitalization of $152.7 billion) and persistence in earnings-per-share.Verizon Communications Inc. (VZ)
column56: through its subsidiaries
column57: provides communications
column58: information and entertainment products and services to consumers
column59: businesses and governmental agencies. The company is favored by our David Dreman-based screening model due to its size (market cap of $198.9 billion). Medium to large-sized companies (the largest 1500 companies) are preferred by this model because they are more in the public eye and an investor is less exposed to risk of ""accounting gimmickry"". VZ earns a perfect score under our O'Shaughnessy-based investment strategy due to its cash flow-per-share of $7.24
column60: well above the market mean of $1.43
column61: and its dividend yield of 4.73%.Apple Inc. (AAPL)
column62: the tech behemoth
column63: earns a perfect score under our Warren Buffett-inspired investment strategy due to its earnings predictability and ability to pay off all debt with earnings within two years. Average return-on-equity over the past ten years (31.5%) is more than double the required minimum of 15%
column64: and free cash flow per share of $7.30 indicates that the company is generating more cash that it is consuming. Management's use of retained earnings reflects a favorable return of 20.7%. The company also gets a thumb's up from our O'Shaughnessy-based model given its trailing 12-month sales ($218.1 billion) and the number of shares outstanding (5
column66: which is nearly nine times the market average (620 million).At the time of publication
column67: John Reese and his clients were   long IBM
column68: UNH
column69: VZ
column70: AAPL"

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Tips its Hand on iPhone 8 Wireless Charging;2/14/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThere are always plenty of rumors flying around aboutApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) coming iPhone releases. Usually
column3: these are based on information leaked from the AAPL supply chain
column4: but on a very few occasions
column5: Apple itself inadvertently tips its hand.makeArticleAd();Source: Wireless Power ConsortiumThat appears to be the case with the iPhone 8. For several months
column6: the 10th anniversary release has been rumored to feature wireless charging. Thanks to an AAPL move
column7: that now seems like a lock.AAPL Joins the Wireless Power ConsortiumBusiness Insiderbroke the newsthat Apple has joined the Wireless Power Consortium (or WPC). WPC is an industry association that oversees Qi
column8: the most widely used wireless charging technology. That puts AAPL in a group with over 220 other companies that are members
column9: including smartphone rivalSamsung Electronic(OTCMKTS:SSNLF)
column10: whose Galaxy S7 supports Qi wireless charging.Apple does already use Qi wireless charging for the Apple Watch
column11: but the company tweaked its implementation so it's not compatible with standard Qi chargers. And it never bothered to join WPC - until now. That move is a very strong indicator that AAPL is planning to incorporate Qi wireless charging on a larger scale
column12: and that points to the iPhone 8.7 Dividend Stocks for the Retirement You DeserveApple confirmed it had joined WPC (although the confirmation isn't really necessary given that it's nowlisted as a memberon the organization's website)
column13: but it did so by trying to minimize the implications. A company spokesperson toldBusiness Insider:""Apple is an active member of many standards development organizations
column14: as both a leader and contributor. Apple is joining the Wireless Power Consortium to be able to participate and contribute ideas to the open
column15: collaborative development of future wireless charging standards. We look forward to working together with the WPC and its members.""What WPC Membership Means for iPhone 8 Wireless ChargingDespite AAPL's attempt to position its move as business as usual
column16: joining WPC is a strong indication that rumors about the iPhone 8 offering wireless charging have been on the mark. However
column17: Qi isn't the advanced
column18: over-the-air wireless charging many people had been hoping AAPL would implement.Instead
column19: Qi - which has been in use since 2011- uses inductive charging. Rather than plugging an iPhone into a charger with a Lightning cable
column20: it would be placed on a charge pad. So there's still a recharger that requires physical contact
column21: and that recharger is still plugged into the wall.And it seems very plausible that wireless charging would be supported by the iPhone 8
column22: but only offered as an extra at an additional cost. There has already been speculation that AAPL would useoptional wireless chargingto further drive up the amount consumers spend on a new iPhone purchase. In this case
column23: they would have to add an Apple wireless charger to the tab (somethingSamsung charges an additional $49.99 forwith the Galaxy S7).Couldn't iPhone 8 buyers simply buy one of the many Qi charge pads already on the market? They would undoubtedly be less expensive than Apple's version.Well
column24: there's also a good chance that AAPL could pull a move like it did with the Apple Watch
column25: tweaking its Qi implementation slightly so someone buying the new iPhone couldn't simply use a standard third-party Qi charger.Will Qi Wireless Charging Make the iPhone 8 More Desirable?IHS Technology noted thepopularity of wireless charging with consumers
column26: suggesting it was a feature AAPL couldn't ignore with the iPhone 8:""The success of wireless charging adoption from Apple's competitors is something that Apple can no longer ignore. IHS Technology consumer survey data shows over 90% of consumers want wireless charging on their next device.""Consumers may be expecting somethingmorefrom the iPhone 8
column27: though.Qi wireless charging is mainstream now
column28: and there were hopes Apple would adopttruewireless charging
column29: going with over-the-air technology instead of following the pack. Many smartphone buyers skip Qi charging altogether (the charge pad can actually be larger and more cumbersome than a plug-in charger)
column30: especially if it's an additional cost.The ability to set a device on furniture or other accessories like speaker systems ordesk lamps that have integrated QI charge padsis cool
column31: but if AAPL chooses to go with a non-standard implementation
column32: those probably wouldn't work with the iPhone 8.Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Is on Cloud 9It may end up that wireless charging on the iPhone 8 is essentially a marketing move - a way to make extra money from those who care
column33: and a bullet point on the features list that keeps the new iPhone on par with the competition. Or maybe AAPL engineers will pull off something unexpected.Either way
column34: now that Apple has officially joined the WPC
column35: you can expect Qi wireless charging on the iPhone 8.As of this writing
column36: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace9 Top Pharmaceutical Stocks to Buy for the Dividends10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy TodayThe postApple Inc. (AAPL) Tips its Hand on iPhone 8 Wireless Chargingappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 4 Dividend-Growth Stocks to Own for the Next 10 Years;2/14/2017;"By Michael FosterIn my last article
column2: I talked aboutApple's (AAPL)destiny as a Dividend Aristocrat. The company doesn't have even   five years' worth of payouts under its belt
column3: but there are clear   indicators that it will never struggle to pay dividends.In a moment
column4: I'll show you how you can combine Tim Cook's   company with 3 other stocks and get a 4.6% yield in 10 years or   less--and triple-digit upside in the meantime.First
column5: back to Apple.makeArticleAd();The company's strong--and rising--free cash flow and its   operating margin
column6: which has surged over the last 20 years and   stayed at historically high levels
column7: indicate that Apple has   turned into a cash-producing machine investors should not   ignore.Ironically
column8: many people don't see Apple as a cash machine when   they buy or sell the stock; instead
column9: they obsess over iPhone and   iPad sales. This leads to a panic when these sales are weak and   euphoria when they're strong.But this short-termism is destined to lose because buying and   holding Apple will mean collecting a dividend that will grow   faster than those of supposedly ""safer"" and more boring stocks   likeGeneral Electric (GE)
column10: AT&T (T)
column11: Johnson & Johnson (JNJ)
column12: Chevron (CVX)
column13: Consolidated Edison (ED)andExxon Mobil (XOM).Yet Apple is thecheapeststock among this group when we look at its price-to-earnings   (P/E) ratio:Apple's a BargainWith a P/E ratio less than half that of XOM
column14: you'd expect   Apple's dividend to be more at risk
column15: right? This is where the   story really gets wild. Take a look at this chart:Whose Dividend Is Safe?Here's what this chart is telling us: Apple paid 23% of its   free cash flow as dividends in the last 12 months
column16: while XOM's   dividend was18.9 times greaterthan its free cash flow. And you're paying more than twice the   price for that negative dividend coverage.It's clear that Apple is a much better stock to buy for   dividend growth than the best-known large-cap dividend payers
column17: including some of the most respected and beloved Dividend   Aristocrats (or companies that have increased their payouts for   25 straight years or more).Now I want to show how you can create a portfolio with Apple   and some other
column18: lesser-known stocks with equal or better dividend   coverage and stronger dividend-growth potential. That
column19: in turn
column20: will help you get a portfolio yielding nearly 5% in the next 10   years
column21: while delivering big upside potential.In addition to Apple

column23: Amphenol (APH)andMB Financial (MBFI)I've chosen these companies because they have ridiculous dividend   growth. While Amphenol ""only"" saw its dividend rise by 204% in   the last five years
column24: MBFI's went up by 1
column25: 800% and BANR's rose   2
column26: 200%.This is partly due to the fact that these companies started   off with one-cent dividends
column27: so for my future projections
column28: I'm   going to be much more conservative and look only at the   dividend-growth rate over the last three years
column29: which is much   more modest
column30: at 60% or less. Here's how the numbers look:Reaching High Yields FastIt takes just a decade to get to a 4.6% yield for this   portfolio
column31: given our modest assumptions. In reality
column32: we'll likely   see much stronger dividend growth because each of these companies   has a really low payout ratio
column33: or the percentage of the last 12   months' worth of earnings paid out as dividends. (MBFI's is the   highest
column34: at just 28%
column35: while APH's sits at 21%). These companies   couldtripletheir payouts and still have enough cash to cover those   dividends.Additionally
column36: these companies have a strong history of price   growth
column37: thanks to improving revenues and/or earnings
column38: meaning   triple-digit returns in a few years:Years of Strong ReturnsNote also that these stocks aren't correlated to each other   (AAPL went down when BANR soared; APH was strong when MBFI was   flat and BANR was correcting). That's because we've got two   regional banks and two electronics companies--exposing us to   entirely separate sectors.This Portfolio Yields 8.0% NowA 4.6% yield is nice
column39: but why wait up to 10 years for that   when you can get a safe 8.0% right now?I'm talking about the reliable group of income generators   we've gathered together in our new ""No-Withdrawal"" retirement portfolio. They throw offrock-solid yields of 6%

column1: Bitcoin Meets Starbucks: iPayYou's Bold Bet Goes Live;2/14/2017;"By Michael ScottWith 2017 in full motion
column2: Bitcoin’s price climb to the mid-$900 range and beyond continues to raise eyebrows. For many
column3: this milestone is just one signal of cryptocurrency’s growing repute as a legitimate store of investment value.Little attention
column4: however
column5: has been given to Bitcoin’s utility as a day-to-day method of payment. Practical use cases involving consumer adoption
column6: in fact
column7: are rarely talked about. This is despite the well-documented cost
column8: efficiency and security advantages of the Bitcoin payment network for both consumers and businesses alike.makeArticleAd();A new U.S.-based startup company aims to change this through an effort to accelerate the everyday use of Bitcoin for consumers worldwide. Launched in May of 2016
column9: iPayYouis an online platform and digital wallet that promotes the viability of Bitcoin as a method of payment. It immediately saw early success through a unique feature known as Pay-by-Twitter — the first online platform site for peer-to-peer payments over Twitter (TWTR).Now in a bold bet sure to deliver a caffeine jolt to the retail sector
column10: iPayYou this past December introduced Bitcoin Direct to Starbucks (SBUX)
column11: a new way for coffee aficionados to pay for those espressos and other drinks through the use of Bitcoin.This feature allows users to seamlessly transfer bitcoins from their existing iPayYou Bitcoin wallet to their Starbucks mobile app. They select how much (in USD) they wish to transfer before prompting Bitcoin Direct to Starbucks to automatically withdraw that amount from their iPayYou account. Once deposited into that person’s Starbucks account
column12: purchases can be made via the mobile app at any Starbucks location.This latest addition to the iPayYou platform comes on the heels of iPayYou’s recent gift card integration
column13: allowing Bitcoin to be used for instant gift card purchases from retailers like Amazon (AMZN)
column14: Best Buy (BBY) and iTunes (AAPL).These creative payment applications are the mastermind of founder and CEO Gene Kavner
column15: former Worldwide Director of Amazon Associates. With extensive experience in the world of commerce
column16: including prominent positions at Microsoft (MSFT) and Expedia (EXPE)
column17: Kavner developed iPayYou with the intention of establishing a easy-to-use Bitcoin wallet with simple features and low costs.Regarding the strategic collaboration with Starbucks
column18: Kavner remarks: “The broader significance of this move is that iPayYou is able to encourage Bitcoins to be spent in ways that its creators intended — for everyday purchases from popular merchants without needing a bank account to do so. This arrangement with Starbucks allows coffee lovers to replenish their primary Starbucks account with their Bitcoin holdings.  We’ve accomplished this feat without Starbucks having to directly accept Bitcoin. Our hope is that through this demonstration Starbucks will soon begin accepting Bitcoin directly
column19: sooner rather than later.”In terms of advantages for Starbucks regulars
column20: Kavner continues: “We intend to show that Bitcoin is not only a great investment but is also becoming quite useful in everyday life. Because so many of us are addicted to coffee
column21: being able to use Bitcoin to purchase anything at Starbucks is an enormous win for everyday consumers. And Starbucks will benefit too due to the amount of Bitcoin users who will now become customers.”Over time
column22: Kavner believes that initiatives like this will encourage merchant acceptance of Bitcoin. “Probably the most important metric that every merchant looks at when deciding what methods of payment to accept is how many new customers will it help attract. A key reason for the slow merchant adoption of Bitcoin has been the relatively limited amount of people who wanted to use Bitcoin for POS transactions. Now
column23: I believe that more and more will.”In terms of what’s next for Bitcoin Direct for 2017 and beyond
column24: Kavner is optimistic: “We’re going to continue to make Bitcoin easier
column25: safer and more useful over 2017 and beyond. We are planning on expanding to enable more merchant adoption as well as adding many features that every Bitcoin wallet should have. At the same time
column26: we’ll make Bitcoin simple to understand
column27: not just to those of us who know and love Bitcoin already but for the everyday consumer who may not even know what Bitcoin is. We’ll continue to innovate to make Bitcoin easier and more useful for everyone.”"

column2: Gilead Sciences
column3: Inc. (GILD) and Microsoft Corporation (MSFT);2/14/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News

column1: Intel Corporation's Resource Shift;2/14/2017;"Back in April of 2016
column2: microprocessor giantIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) announced that it would be implementing   restructuring actions that the company said were designed to   achieve annual run rate operating expense savings of $1.4   billion.At the time
column3: Intel said that the restructuring was intended to   ""accelerate [Intel's] evolution from a [personal computer]   company to one that powers the cloud and billions of smart
column4: connected computing devices.""A wafer of Intel's 7tg generation Core chips. Image source:     Intel.makeArticleAd();At its Feb. 9 investor meeting
column5: Intel went into much more   detail about how it has shifted around its spending. Let's take a   closer look.Investment shift year-over-yearIntel provided the following chart which illustrates a   ""bridge"" from Intel's 2016 operating expenses to its projected   2017 operating expenses:How Intel's research and development spending is shifting     year-over-year. Image source: Intel.This ""bridge"" shows that Intel expects operating expenses to   drop year-over-year due to the spin-off of its Intel Security   group (which will now be a stand-alone company called McAfee) as   well as reductions in its Client Computing Group (CCG) investment   levels.Offsetting those declines
column6: though
column7: is an increase in   investment levels in what the company collectively refers to as   its ""growth businesses"" -- Data Center Group
column8: Internet of Things   Group
column9: and Non-Volatile Solutions Group.Additionally
column10: Intel says it's investing more in Moore's Law
column11: which means that it's boosting its investments in next generation   manufacturing technologies. This makes sense because the   company's new development methodology calls for the company to   continue to enhance existing manufacturing technologies while   simultaneously developing next-generation ones -- something that   it didn't really do before.All told
column12: Intel is looking at a modest reduction in operating   expenses
column13: year-over-year.Some additional detailIn addition to the broad year-over-year spending shifts that   Intel talked about above
column14: CFO Bob Swan showed an additional slide   that gives more insight into how much research and development   spending by market segment is expected to shift from 2015 through   2017.How Intel's research and development spending changed by     product category. Image source: Intel.Intel is apparently cutting its research and development   spending in personal computer processors by 5% in 2017 relative   to where it was in 2015. That's not all that much
column15: to be blunt
column16: and I'd imagine the bulk of that shift comes more from accounting   changes (i.e. allocating less of its shared operating expenses to   the PC segment and more of it to other segments
column17: like the Data   Center Group).Data Center spending is expected to be up by 25% in that   two-year period. I'd imagine that part of that increase is due to   the shared expense allocation
column18: but I also expect that Intel is   increasing its investments here in ways beyond simply a   reshuffling of expenses.Intel's investments in non-volatile memory -- a business that   Intel expects to be a key growth engine in the years ahead -- are   going up 40%. Considering that technology strength is critical to   succeeding in the non-volatile memory business (better technology   usually translates into a better cost structure
column19: allowing a   company to more effectively compete at good margin levels)
column20: the   boost in spending isn't a surprise.The company's investments in mobile are going to be down 55%   per the slide. That's not surprising considering that Intel has   refocused its mobile business away from trying to build a broad   range of platforms to address the broad range of smartphones   toward focusing primarily on stand-alone cellular modems
column21: withApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) being the company's principal (only?) smartphone   customer here.And
column22: finally
column23: Intel is expecting a big boost in its   investments within its Internet of Things Group. This business   has been growing steadily over the last several years and   management had indicated that they're making some big bets on new   areas like self-driving cars
column24: so a large increase in research and   development spending here makes sense -- especially as the odds   that those investments will ultimately pay off look good.Intel's sensible spending shiftsAt the end of the day
column25: these spending shifts are quite   reasonable -- the company is feeding those business segments that   have been growing and have the potential to continue to grow
column26: and   it's cutting back in areas that aren't expected to grow (i.e. PC   processors) as well as in areas where its efforts have fallen   flat and success appears unlikely (mobile system-on-chip).Intel management is investing for the long-term
column27: which is the   right thing to do. However
column28: investments in high technology   usually take years to bear fruit
column29: so don't expect these increased   investments made today to pay off tomorrow. It'll be a couple of   years before we know if Intel's increased investments will   ultimately pay off.10 stocks we like better than IntelWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column30: it can pay to listen. After all
column31: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column32: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column33: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Intel wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

The Motley Fool has the following options:     long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and short January 2018 $95     calls on Apple. The Motley Fool recommends Intel. The Motley     Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Don’t Count Out Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Stock Just Yet;2/14/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsBack on Jan. 30
column3: I quipped thatNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) was going to return to record highs. Of course
column4: NVDA stock did just that
column5: hitting $120.92 just three days prior to Nvidia's fourth-quarter earnings report.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockBut the love affair with $120-plus prices was short-lived
column6: and a strong sell-on-the-news bid following earnings sent Nvidia stock on an 11%-plus bender.Earnings were far from bad. In fact
column7: the company blew past Wall Street's estimatesby 16 cents per share on revenue that soared 50% year-over-year. Unfortunately for NVDA stock holders
column8: the pre-earnings rally left speculators hungry for profits
column9: and the ""weak"" second-quarter guidance of $1.9 billion (analysts are expecting $1.88 billion) just wasn't enough to sustain level of euphoria heading into the report.If you were lucky enough to get into the Feb $115/$120 call spreadI recommended on Jan. 30
column10: I hope you got out at the top on Feb. 7 and locked in a maximum return on the trade. There really was no reason to hold those NVDA options any longer once the stock topped $120.Alternately
column11: if you opted for the Feb $100 put sell position
column12: you locked in a nice profit of about $137 per contract when these options expired last Friday.But with Nvidia still caught in the throes of missed expectations
column13: where does that leave traders now?Nvidia Sentiment and TechnicalsFor one thing
column14: sentiment has improved sharply on the NVDA options front since I last checked in on the shares
column15: hinting at elevated expectations. At the time
column16: the the Feb. put/call open interest ratio rested at a lofty 1.31
column17: but the equivalent March put/call OI ratio has fallen to 0.8
column18: with calls now outnumbering puts among short-term options.7 High-Risk
column19: High-Reward Stocks to Buy NowFurthermore
column20: Wall Street analysts haven't budged an inch on their bullish Nvidia stance. Thomson/First Call ratings stand exactly where they were heading into earnings
column21: with 21 of the 35 analysts following NVDA stock rating the shares a ""buy"" or better.And herein lies the problem.Nvidia stock is saturated with hype right now. So much so
column22: that smart money is probably selling NVDA to take advantage of the situation. Keep in mind that this doesn't mean the stock's long-term uptrend won't remain intact. But a short-term correction could shake out the weak hands
column23: thus allowing smart money to step back in when the price is right.So
column24: what's the right price? Well
column25: that all depends on your trading outlook
column26: but I would argue that NVDA stock is a bargain buy on any trade below $100 given the company's prospects for 2017 and beyond.For short-term options traders
column27: however
column28: the equation is much simpler: Where do implieds suggest the stock will be trading in the next couple of months?Click to EnlargeFor this
column29: we turn to March implieds
column30: and discover that options are pricing in a potential move of about 6.2% for NVDA stock. This places the upper bound at about $114
column31: while the lower bound rests near key support at $100.2 Trades for NVDA StockCall Spread:While smart money may be selling NVDA stock right now
column32: I'm not willing to bet against the shares just yet. Nvidia's fourth-quarter report was nothing short of stellar
column33: meaning bargain hunters are bound to step in sooner rather than later.Intel Corporation (INTC) Stock Will Claw Its Way HigherTraders looking to take on a bit of risk and bet on a return to form for NVDA stock might consider a March $110/$115 bull call spread. At last check
column34: this spread was offered at $1.66
column35: or $166 per pair of contracts. Breakeven lies at $111.66
column36: while a maximum profit of $3.34
column37: or $334 per pair of contracts
column38: is possible if Nvidia closes at or above $115 when March options expire.Put Sell:But if an outright call spread is a bit too much risk to take on at the moment
column39: the $100 put sell trade still looks like a winner. Just roll that strike out to the March series
column40: and you're set.At last check
column41: the March $100 put was bid at $1.39
column42: or $139 per contract. If Nvidia offers up a repeat performance in March and closes above $100 at expiration
column43: then you get to keep the premium received. But
column44: if NVDA stock trades below $100 ahead of expiration
column45: then traders may be assigned 100 shares at a price of $100 per share
column46: for every contract sold.As of this writing

column13: currently around the $30-$31 area.9 Top Pharmaceutical Stocks to Buy for the DividendsWhile this support area is of no direct concern to my trade idea in INTC stock today

column18: which currently also coincides with the 2015 diagonal support line (purple-dotted line). The stock closed well off its intraday lows last Friday. This was followed by an up-day Monday

column1: Fossil (FOSL) Earnings Coming Up: Time For A Rebound?;2/14/2017;"Fossil (FOSL) is set to report fourth quarter fiscal 2016 results after the closing bell this afternoon. Although revenue and profits have been hard to come by amid increased competition from the likes of Apple (AAPL)

column3: the Texas-based company also makes jewelry
column4: handbags
column5: small leather goods
column6: belts
column7: sunglasses and a host of apparel. Not only has the company beaten Wall Street’s earnings estimates in two straight quarter
column8: Fossil has missed just once in the past eight quarters. And with a possible beat Tuesday and upbeat guidance
column9: Fossil
column10: which has seen its shares decline some 30% over the past year
column11: could be on a verge of a recovery.For the three months that ended December
column12: Wall Street’s expect Fossil to earn $1.20 per share on revenue of $977.13 million. This compares to the year-ago quarter when the company earned $1.46 per share on $992.5 million in revenue. For the full year
column13: earnings are projected to be $1.92 per share
column14: while revenue of $3.06 billion would decline 3% year over year.makeArticleAd();During third quarter
column15: Fossil reported net income of $17.4 million
column16: or 36 cents per share
column17: down from  $57.5 million for the third quarter of fiscal 2015. While citing a challenging environment for the traditional watch category
column18: the company lowered its fiscal 2016 outlook. But Fossil
column19: which currently operates 600 stores in 150 countries
column20: has begun to restructure the business to achieve not only greater profitability
column21: but also to speed up product innovation
column22: which has been a main driver in the company’s growth.In that regard
column23: as part of efforts to fast-track new products
column24: the company in October unveiled some forty hybrid smartwatches. Fossil at the time said the new products would not only help it fight off competition to gain market share
column25: but could also help boost profit margins from price increases. Combined with the company’s plan to emerge leaner from store closures
column26: FOSL stock
column27: which closed Monday at $22.98 looks like a relative bargain.The stock is priced at just 13 times fiscal 2017 estimates $1.78 per share
column28: which is about six points below the S&P 500 index. Yet those estimates don’t yet factor the company’s ability — amid its restructuring — to become more agile and respond more quickly to changing markets. As such
column29: from a risk versus reward perspective
column30: Fossil
column31: which now trades near 52-week lows
column32: is a stock to keep an eye on for the next 12 to 18 months. With a bit of luck these shares can shoot up to $28
column33: delivering 22% returns."

column1: HP (HPQ) Partners with Bromium; Unveils Sure Click Solution;2/14/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();Leading PC manufacturer

column1: Trade of the Day: New High for Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Beckons to Bulls;2/14/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsEDITOR'S NOTE: Sam Collins will return on Feb. 21.makeArticleAd();Fanboys rejoice! Order has once again been restored to the Wall Street hierarchy.Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) has finally joined the ranks of market leaders resting at all-time highs. At $133.29

column4: the question plaguing spectators is whether or not now is the time to take a bite.The answer
column5: in short
column6: is no.As exciting as milestones like new record highs can be
column7: the reality is Apple stock is extremely extended. Such lofty levels leave much to be desired on the risk/reward front. While the new highs may indeed spark renewed interest in the stock
column8: its overbought status is simply too big of a negative to ignore.Source: OptionsAnalytixRemember
column9: traders should focus less on what action they think may generate profitsthistime and more on what action they think will create profitsmostof the time.10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy TodayAnd let's be honest - most of the time
column10: chasing a stock already perched in the nosebleeds is a money loser.Sell AAPL Puts for ProfitStock investors should be praying to the market gods for an Apple stock dip in the coming days. Or
column11: better yet
column12: sell out-of-the-money puts to create a potential win-win scenario. Right now you can sell the Mar $130 put option for $1.08. The short put obligates you to buy 100 shares of AAPL if the stock falls below $130 by expiration. Since you received $1.08 up front
column13: your effective purchase price will drop to $128.92 which is a modest 3.3% discount to Monday's closing price.And if AAPL stock remains above $130
column14: you can simply keep the $1.08 and then consider selling another put for April.At the time of this writing
