column1: Apple
column2: Inc. CEO Tim Cook Talks Up Augmented Reality's Potential (Again);2/10/2017;"Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) has emerged as the next champion of augmented   reality (AR). Despite the company's penchant for secrecy
column3: it's   become increasingly clear that Apple has something in the   pipeline given that CEO Tim Cook keeps talking about AR's   transformative potential. This is that whole ""ship leaking from   the top"" bit that Steve Jobs always referred to.Every few months
column4: Cook weighs in on the debate
column5: either when   asked on an earnings conference call or during a media interview.   While Cook has never been a product visionary type
column6: even by his   own admission
column7: his rationale for why AR has more potential than   virtual reality (VR) makes an awful lot of sense
column8: given Apple's   never-ending pursuit of technologies that have mainstream   appeal.Tim Cook holding the billionth iPhone. Image source:     Apple.makeArticleAd();The most recent interview is withThe Independent
column9: which was published earlier today. Among other topics
column10: Cook   discussed why AR is the way to go.""AR allows individuals to be present in the world""Perhaps the most off-putting aspect of VR for the average   consumer is the fact that users must don a headset to fully   immerse themselves into a virtual world. Even before discussing   the technical requirements or costs associated with a VR headset
column11: it's fundamentally isolating. In contrast
column12: AR sits on top of the   real world as an overlay without the isolation.I'm excited about Augmented Reality because unlike Virtual     Reality which closes the world out
column13: AR allows individuals to be     present in the world but hopefully allows an improvement on     what's happening presently. Most people don't want to lock     themselves out from the world for a long period of time and     today you can't do that because you get sick from it. With AR     you can
column14: not be engrossed in something
column15: but have it be a part     of your world
column16: of your conversation. That has resonance.Cook continued that he sees the opportunity in AR as analogous   to the smartphone
column17: believing that it can be for ""everyone."" AR   still isn't there quite yet
column18: and needs to improve until its ""good   enough for the mainstream
column19: according to the chief executive.How and when?Cook's comments are but the latest in the ongoing debate over   AR's future. In 2016
column20: Cook discussed AR three consecutive months   in a row:The Washington Postin August
column21: ABC Newsin September
column22: andBuzzFeed Newsin October. It's obviously been on his mind quite a bit.At this point
column23: the two most important questions are how Apple   will implement it -- a separate AR headset or integrated into the   iPhone camera system
column24: or both -- and when Apple will officially   release its AR offering. If Apple goes the route of first   integrating AR into the iPhone
column25: which would largely be   software-based
column26: it could reduce the likelihood of leaks. In   contrast
column27: if Apple wants to jump straight to an AR headset
column28: its   supply chain will inevitably leak as prototypes are manufactured   and there will be more physical evidence of its aspirations.Hopefully sooner rather than later
column29: Apple will unveil its next   ""big idea.""10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: It Can Get Worse for Qualcomm: Legal Blitz Threatens NXP Semiconductor Acquisition;2/10/2017;"It's been a rough start to the year for semiconductor giantQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) . After putting what many hoped were the worst of   its legal troubles behind it
column2: Qualcomm's shares have plummeted so   far this year
column3: as several new legal entanglements place continued   pressure on the company's patent licensing segment.These legal troubles could negatively affect the chipmaker in   a number of ways. Particularly worrisome
column4: though
column5: is that at   least one analyst has expressed concerns that its courtroom   battles could hamper Qualcomm's pending acquisition ofNXP Semiconductor(NASDAQ: NXPI) .makeArticleAd();QCOMdata byYChartsInside Qualcomm's legal troublesHaving unfolded in several stages around the world
column6: Qualcomm's   five-year legal ordeal can be broken down into five major points.   Each suit has focused on the company's Qualcomm technology   licensing (QTL) segment
column7: which produces roughly two-thirds of the   chipmaker's annual pre-tax profits.In 2013
column8: the Chinese government launched an antitrust   investigation into Qualcomm's patent licensing   practices
column9: which led Qualcomm to pay a $975 million fine to   Chinese regulators early last year. As part of its settlement
column10: Qualcomm agreed to lower the per-device royalty rates it charges   Chinese mobile-device OEMs. Collecting royalty payments for its   standard-essential 3G and 4G patents
column11: which typically range from   3.25% to 5% of a mobile device's wholesale price before potential   rebate savings
column12: has been a headache for Qualcomm in China. Many   Chinese OEMs either simply didn't pay Qualcomm or allegedly   underreported their royalty payments to the company
column13: so many had   hoped that resolving its Chinese legal issues would represent the   conclusion of Qualcomm's legal woes. As it turns out
column14: those   problems were just the beginning.In late 2015
column15: the EU initiated a similar antitrust   investigation into potential anti-competitive practices by   Qualcomm. The European Commission
column16: the EU's regulatory watchdog
column17: has yet to reach a verdict against Qualcomm. Many expect the EU   to render its findings
column18: including potential fines
column19: at some point   this year.Then late last year
column20: South Korean regulators fined Qualcomm   $854 million on similar antitrust grounds. Qualcomm is currently   appealing this decision.Finally
column21: Qualcomm was hit with two more blockbuster lawsuits   in late January. Thefirst suitcame from the Federal Trade Commission
column22: claiming that   Qualcomm used its competitive position to gain unfair advantages   in the baseband chip market. Three days later
column23: Apple
column24: one of Qualcomm's largest customers
column25: filed a $1 billion lawsuit   against Qualcomm
column26: alleging that the chipmaker engaged in a number   of anticompetitive tactics. The charges make for someugly reading.Qualcomm is fighting each of its suits and has responded with   some compelling arguments. It doesn't make sense to   speculate about possible verdicts at this point
column27: though some   analysts say the company's mounting legal woes could delay or   even jeopardize its pending NXP Semiconductor acquisition
column28: an   outcome that would damage Qualcomm's long-term growth   trajectory.Image source: QualcommWill the lawsuits affect the NXP buyout?Few analysts seem to believe that Qualcomm's patent licensing   lawsuits alone could compel regulators to block the NXP   acquisition. The important issue here is that Qualcomm's current   products don't compete in the same areas of the semiconductor   market as NXP.However
column29: it appears Qualcomm's growing number of legal   entanglements could slow the merger approval process
column30: especially   in markets such as the EU
column31: where Qualcomm is currently battling   antitrust charges. In fact
column32: one sell-side analyst recently   downgraded Qualcomm shares on the assumption that the NXP deal   will indeed now take longer than expected to close
column33: in which case   NXP's growth will take longer to have a positive impact on   Qualcomm's financial performance.Equally important
column34: extending the time for the deal to close   also increases the odds that an unforeseen event could affect the   acquisition. What if Apple's suit fundamentally alters QTL's   licensing practices? Could that affect Qualcomm's ability to   finance the $39 billion deal? Perhaps. Could Apple's lawsuit   embolden other major customers -- say
column35: Samsung-- to file a similar complaint? If so
column36: what would that   mean? What if another country files yet another antitrust charge   against it?The point is that even a delay leaves the door open for some   other outside factor to come along and derail Qualcomm's critical   NXP purchase. Again
column37: such a scenario appears unlikely. However
column38: given NXP's place as Qualcomm's entry point to the Internet of   Things market
column39: any potential overhang that could threaten the   deal becomes a must-watch item for its investors.10 stocks we like better than QualcommWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: 7 Stocks to Buy for the Future of TV;2/10/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsBack when I was a kid
column3: a half-century ago
column4: most people saw only three TV networks - CBS
column5: NBC and ABC.makeArticleAd();Source:Flash.pro via Flickr (modified)If you're old enough to remember the DuMont network
column6: please check outmy recent gallery on dividend stocksthat provide solid retirement income. If you think ofTwenty-First Century Fox Inc(NASDAQ:FOXA) as the fourth network
column7: read on.A quarter-century ago
column8: when my children were small
column9: a host of cable networks rose to challenge the broadcast networks for viewers. It was the age of""57 channels and nothing on""with ESPN
column10: the USA Network
column11: CNN
column12: the Weather Channel and the Food Network all having their heyday.Over time
column13: the broadcasters bought out most of the new operators
column14: sometimes after being bought themselves.CBS Corporation(NYSE:CBS) now owns Showtime and the Smithsonian Network.Comcast Corporation(NASDAQ:CMCSA)
column15: the parent of NBC
column16: owns all or part of a dozen networks
column17: including CNBC
column18: Syfy and USA.Walt Disney Co(NYSE:DIS)
column19: the parent of ABC
column20: owns ESPN
column21: the biggest franchise of all
column22: and the Disney networks. And Fox
column23: which grew up in this era
column24: has clones for nearly all of them.But in the 2010s
column25: a new force has arisen to challenge the network owners
column26: a force they will find difficult to compete with and almost impossible to buy.That force is streaming services
column27: which deliver their shows to your TV
column28: over the internet through plug-in dongles rather than set-top boxes - unless you prefer viewing on a PC
column29: tablet or phone. These offer all the entertainment a TV zombie might ever need
column30: and the services can cost less than $10 per month
column31: much less than a cable service. They don't have schedules
column32: so you watch what you want to watch
column33: when you want to watch it.Streaming through the internet is the future of TV
column34: and we are just at its dawn. It's still unclear how we will discover shows
column35: how we will interface with what we want to watch or how much we'll eventually pay for the privilege of watching. But cable
column36: at least as we knew it
column37: is drifting away
column38: as broadcast television previously drifted away. It will continue to exist
column39: as broadcasting does
column40: just in a smaller
column41: truncated form.What is the future of live events in the new world? Is TV even going to remain a one-way
column42: passive medium? We don't know.In addition to being better
column43: and cheaper
column44: for viewers
column45: the new TV environment right now looks great for entertainers and show producers
column46: who suddenly have a host of new options on where and how to sell their wares
column47: which they're using to gain new creative freedom if not new wealth.But the new media landscape is a lot less stable than the old one and
column48: given the wealth of choices available
column49: it may prove much less lucrative for stars
column50: writers and producers.Just a few years into the new era
column51: moreover
column52: it's apparent that the new streaming companies are big enough to regard the cable networks' owners as minnows. This is not a problem the networks can buy their way out of
column53: as they bought out of cable.7 High-Risk
column54: High-Reward Stocks to Buy NowYour mission
column55: as an investor
column56: is to examine the new TV stocks and decide whether to invest your money in them. And along the way
column57: you will be buying a lot more than TV.Stocks to Buy for the Future of TV: Netflix (NFLX)Source:Via NetflixThe business model of the new TV era was created byNetflix
column58: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX).A decade ago
column59: Netflix was a relatively small but interesting company that mailed DVDs. You paid a monthly fee to hold a few
column60: then got more when you sent them back. It was a relatively simple business based on physical media
column61: but it had potential.By simply moving that business model online
column62: using cloud services and open-source technology
column63: Netflix now delivers unlimited amounts of content to viewers as a stream
column64: rather than on a disk.Cofounder Reed Hastings has transformed TV as no one has since Ted Turner. If you bought Netflix when it went public in 2002
column65: your $1 investment is now worth $137.Hasting's second big innovation
column66: which came on the heels of the streaming business model
column67: was tostart funding his own programmingrather than just reselling existing movies and TV shows. His string of hits began withHouse of Cards
column68: based on a British mini-series
column69: which by itself made his monthly $8 per month subscription fee seem a bargain.Netflix offers its shareholders low profit margins
column70: but great growth. Between 2013 and 2016
column71: revenue doubled
column72: from $4.37 billion to $8.83 billion
column73: and profits nearly followed
column74: from 26 cents per share to 43 cents. Along the way
column75: the company has increased its debt dramatically - it now represents about one-fourth of assets - to pay for its delivery infrastructure and to obtain new programming assets
column76: which it is assumed will retain their value over time. (Your grandkids will watchHouse of Cardsthe way your kids now watchM*A*S*H.)With a market cap of $62 billion
column77: Netflix could now buy other TV stocks
column78: like CBS. Its value exceeds that of Fox. ABC and NBC are protected from a Netflix acquisition by deep-pocketed parents
column79: Disney and Comcast. HBO
column80: a subscription service based on cable
column81: will be protected in the same way once parentTime Warner Inc(NYSE:TWX) is bought byAT&T Inc.(NYSE:T).NFLX retains its value as an investment because ofits international operations
column82: which by the fourth quarter of 2016 represented around 40% of the total and continue to grow. In the last three months of 2016 alone the company added 7.05 million new members
column83: after forecasting it would add just 5.2 million. Netflix' growth is accelerating
column84: and its ability to buy must-see programming is growing with it.The problem for Netflix is that the cloud providers on which its success rests have seen what it has done. They're on to the trick. A network today isn't necessarily just a provider of content
column85: but the scaled infrastructure necessary to provide that content. The owners of cloud networks and vast internet networks are copying what Netflix does.These challengers have more zeroes in their asset bases than those NFLX has faced before. Once more
column86: Reed Hastings is a minnow in a sea of sharks.Everything about the industry has changed
column87: but whether Netflix can ride the changes
column88: or whether it will eventually be bought out as Turner was
column89: remains up for debate.Stocks to Buy for the Future of TV: Amazon (AMZN)Source: ShutterstockThereisa price cheaper than Netflix' $8 per month for all-you-can-eat entertainment - the nothing extra I payAmazon.com
column90: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) to access its video as a Prime member.It is true that you can buy Amazon Prime Video
column91: separately
column92: for $8.99 per month. But that's silly since the regular price for Prime
column93: which includes free two-day shipping on most Amazon items
column94: is $99 per year (about $8.25 per month).Lately
column95: Amazon has also been outperforming Netflix on the awards front. In addition to11 Golden Globe nominations this year alone
column96: there are six Oscar nominations forManchester by the Sea(Amazonpaid $10 million for the distribution rightsa year ago).Frankly there is so much free stuff on Amazon (which I can watch on a big screen with my Fire Stick
column97: a wireless dongle that fits on the side of the TV
column98: connects to the internet via WiFi
column99: and supports a host of other services including Netflix) that I don't need anything else. Were it not for live sports
column100: I would kill my cable in a heartbeat
column101: and as my favorite sports signstreaming contracts
column102: that motivation is disappearing as well.And it's not just TV either. I'm fortunate enough to have a wife who hates TV. She reads instead. Amazon's Kindle Unlimited
column103: for another $99 per year
column104: became fantastic over the last year as more authors have signed up and Amazon's algorithms have gotten better at anticipating what people might want to borrow next from its vast library.My son doesn't watch TV either. He's a gamer
column105: and has been for years. He is constantly talking aboutTwitch
column106: which offers live streams of people playing video games. I don't get it
column107: but Amazon does. They paid $970 million for Twitchlast March
column108: making them partners with characters such as Bunnyfufu
column109: who stream their gamingon Twitch.Like most people
column110: I watch very few cable channels. Cancel cable and there is $100-150 per month I can pay for whatever programming I want. There are only so many hours in a day - who needs hundreds of channels with nothing on when a streaming service (or maybe two) can meet my needs?If I sound like an Amazon fanboy
column111: it's because I am. As previously noted
column112: my TV has an Amazon Fire Stick plugged into it
column113: and I use a Fire tablet for reading. I also started accumulating Amazon shares in 2014
column114: at an average price of $330. They're now worth about $800
column115: and they're a bargain at that price.For the fourth quarter of 2016 Amazon earned $749 million
column116: $1.54 per share
column117: on revenues of$43.741 billion. It is making the turn from a company investing in front of growth to one that starts earning profits regularly. Its cloud operation
column118: Amazon Web Services
column119: now brings one-quarter of its $3.5 billion in quarterly revenue to the bottom line - and one of its customers is Netflix.10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy TodayImagine. Amazon creates infrastructure that lets other companies make money
column120: then competes with its customers to make even more money with the same infrastructure. I recently dumped shares before earnings
column121: at $832 per share
column122: because they had become such a huge portion of my retirement account.I may have to buy them back.Stocks to Buy for the Future of TV: Alphabet (GOOG
column123: GOOGL)Source: ShutterstockNetflix may have created the new business model and Amazon may have perfected it
column124: but the technology began atAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL
column126: with Google and YouTube.One of YouTube's co-founders says the idea started afterthe Janet Jackson ""wardobe malfunction""at the 2004 Super Bowl. They just couldn't find any video of it
column127: and so asked others to upload it so they could see it. The service was an immediate sensation
column128: and Google's purchase of the site for $1.65 billion was just the beginning.The business model was simple. People upload videos
column129: people watch videos. Google places ads in front of the videos
column130: and shares some of the revenue with those who uploaded the videos. Like Google itself
column132: although it now has a paid version called YouTube Red.YouTubedid not make a profit for its parentuntil after Amazon and Netflix got going. It is now estimated to be bringing in$10 billion per year
column134: with 80% of views outside the U.S. By 2020 that will mean$27 billionin revenue per year. Its audience is tilted toward young people
column137: and a growing percentage access it via phones or tablets.An analysis from STL Partners indicates YouTube's profit contribution is mainly indirect. Its traffic helps Google get the best prices for internet bandwidth. Its meta data is contributed to other Google services. It gives Google a place at the tablewhenever video copyright issuesare discussed.Veteran TV producer Susanne Daniels joined Google in 2015
column138: and is charged withgrowing the YouTube Red service. She is not onlybuying TV showsand makinga splash at movie festivalsbut aiming to take veteran TV hosts likeConan O'Brien online. (Chelsea Handler has already moved to Netflix.) Daniels is helped by continuing sales ofChromecast
column139: a TV streaming device which competes with the Apple Fire StickYouTube has created its own stars
column140: most of whom are unknown to their parents' generation. The most popular YouTube celebrity
column142: drew $15 million in income last year and hadalmost 50 million viewers.By taking advantage of Google's low-cost infrastructure
column143: YouTube has carved out a unique niche for itself in the new TV universe
column144: one that is subsidizing its entrance into more ""traditional"" areas like YouTube Red subscriptions.Thanks to Amazon's purchase of Twitch
column145: TV stocks Google and Amazon are now on a collision course in the world of streaming video. Customers of both will be the big winners
column147: too.Stocks to Buy for the Future of TV: Apple (AAPL)Source:via AppleApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) was a latecomer to TV streaming in the cloud.Apple began ramping up spending for its own cloud only a few years ago
column148: investing $15 billion in 2016 aloneto build a global network of cloud data centers and
column150: a place for itself in the new industry.The money was spent mainly to serve existing paid Apple services
column153: which are nowbigger profit drivers than the Macintosh or iPad. CEO Tim Cook said in his most recent earnings call that Apple Services brought in$7.17 billionin the December quarter alone
column154: which he expects will double by 2020.Apple's streaming business is distinguished from that of Google because it consists of paid subscribers
column155: and distinguished from Amazon and Netflix by being primarily fee-for-service rather than subscription revenue.While iPhone sales are stagnating
column156: Apple has found a new growth engine in services
column157: and built a platform to challenge the other streaming players. Apple Music now has about21%of the music streaming market
column159: but Spotify is not profitable and struggling to justify a $8 billion valuation
column160: which at One Infinite Loop is considered seat cushion money.Apple's push into TV streaming will be through a new app called
column163: which aims to solve one of the most vexing problems for a streaming user - deciding what to watch next. The Apple TV streaming service itself has yet to launch
column164: butrumors about it abound. Apple wants to get the same 30% revenue cut on TV streaming it gets on apps
column165: producing a service that will cost $20-30 per month.The most persistent rumors about Apple's intent regarding streaming involveHBO Now
column166: a Time Warner service that costs $15 per month
column167: and which was Apple exclusive for a few months in 2015. Apple has the financial wherewithal to buy HBO as part of Time Warner's merger with AT&T
column168: or to buy a broadcasting company like CBS for cash. Apple TV hardware isused by an estimated 11.9%of TV streaming customers.Thanks to its existing service businesses
column169: global reach and over $200 billion in cash
column170: Apple has the freedom to be patient and negotiate with rights holders before launching a TV streaming service. But it is far more concerned with maintaining its high margins than with driving traffic
column171: which hurts it in competition with services whose prices start at virtually free
column172: like Google's YouTube and Amazon Prime.It is hard for me to see how Apple can win in streaming when it's unwilling to bend on margins to win market share
column173: and willing to dither aimlessly with existing TV rights holders while rivals are creating their own shows and even new types of experiences.7 Tech Stocks That Are Bucking the DowntrendBut that's just my opinion. I bought Apple shares before its 7:1 split in 2014
column175: but retain them in my retirement account. It's going to be a nice retirement.Stocks to Buy for the Future of TV: AT&T (T)Source:Mike Mozart via FlickrI got my first glimpse of the future several years ago
column176: when rights to English Premier League games came up for bids.The winners weren't the traditional networks
column177: public or private. They wereSky TV
column180: the state phone company.This was years before AT&T said it would buy Time Warnerfor a reported $85.4 billion. It was even years before AT&T agreed to spend$48.5 billion forDirecTV
column181: the direct broadcast satellite business.The two deals will combine to transform AT&T from a phone company into a streaming player. It will be able to bundle wireless
column183: and let its customers stream shows from DirecTV to their mobile deviceswithout cost.Its new streaming service
column185: carried an introductory price of $35 per month for 60 channels and attractedover 200
column186: 000 customers during the fourth quarterwhich helped offset a loss of customers from its more traditional cable service
column187: U-Verse. It competes ina cord-cutting nichealongsideSling TV
column188: owned by DirecTV rivalDISH Network Corp(NASDAQ:DISH)
column190: owned bySony Corp (ADR)(NYSE:SNE)For the fourth quarter
column191: AT&T reported net income of $2.44 billion
column193: on revenue of $41.84 billion. While this didn't clear the company's 49-cent-per-share dividend payment during the quarter
column194: for the year the company did earn $2.10 per share
column195: beating the $1.93 annual dividend. It's the dividend
column196: a 4.7% yield to today's stock buyer
column197: that you're buying when you buy AT&T stock. The shares themselves are worth little more than they were in 2007.I switched from Comcast to AT&T for my own TV and internet service last year
column198: combining it with my existing mobile phone subscription. I now pay the company about $400 per month for various services. That's a lot of cash flow. I should probably buy the stock.AT&T is the most traditional of the new streaming players. It earns a place in this gallery for its sheer size
column200: and its control of key internet infrastructure in the core of the network and at the edge.AT&T has moved into streaming for defensive reasons. Internet advocates have criticized it for DirecTV Now
column201: which gives its own customers free bits that others are charged for
column202: ignoring the concept of network neutrality
column203: but the Donald Trump Administration isgiving it a free pass on that.When the acquisition of Time Warner is finalized - and that looks like a better bet with Trump in charge - AT&T will own a big hunk of the traditional cable universe
column205: CNN and Cartoon Network.Time Warner agreed to be bought
column207: because it needs cash to compete for programming against deep-pocketed rivals like Netflix
column209: Google and possibly Apple. AT&T bought Time Warner because the vertical integration - owning the programming as well as the network so you write rights checks to yourself - should allow it to maintain that dividend.Comcast made the marriage of network infrastructure and content work with NBC Universal
column210: mainly by keeping its hands off its creative people. It is still unclear to me whether AT&T will be willing to do the same
column211: or whether it will focus on milking a dying industry for profits
column212: which has been its way of doing business since I began covering them over three decades ago.That's the only thing keeping me from buying the shares. That and the lack of capital gains.Stocks to Buy for the Future of TV: Facebook (FB)Source:SilverIsdead Via FlickrFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) is the newest and
column214: the second-smallest of the new streaming players
column215: behind only Netflix.During the December quarter Facebookearned $1.41 per shareon $8.81 billion in revenue. This makes it four times bigger than Netflix by revenue. With a market cap of about $390 billion
column216: it isthe sixth most valuable company in the country
column217: less than five years after first going public.Facebook got into streaming withFacebook Live
column218: a sort of YouTube for streaming
column219: which has already made news with House Democrats streaming a sit-in when Republicans turned off their cameras and with Donald Trump announcing a Supreme Court pick on the service.Facebook Live is already getting Facebook into trouble with rights holders
column220: like the TV network which saw sales of a recent pay-per-view fight in Australia impacted when one subscribersimply held his phone up to his TV and streamed it. There is even a name for this kind of thing -""stream ripping.""Facebook is reportedlyworking on an app for streaming
column221: which would put it into more direct competition with Apple TV and Google's YouTube. This would be a software solution that lets it piggyback on others' hardware
column223: Amazon's Fire Stick and Apple TV. In addition to supporting its streaming
column224: the app would also support 10-minute TV shows with commercials inserted into them
column225: like broadcast TV in the 1940s.What makes Facebook powerful in streaming is the sheer number of people using the service - nearly 2 billion - and the amount of time they spend with it. The average global user spends 20 minutes per day on the service
column226: andthe average American spends twice that amount of time.Analysts are divided on analogiesfor Facebook's strategy here. Is it Netflix? Is it YouTube?In fact
column227: neither analogy is correct. Facebook mainly wants to integrate video into its existing offering. It is backing away frompaying publishers for streams
column228: and may be backing away in the near term as people use its unmoderated do-it-yourself streaming to show themselvescommitting violent crimesandeven committing suicide.All this reminds me of something I wrote 20 years ago
column229: about telephony. Telephony is simply an internet service. Today
column231: an internet service. The difference is that video is far more intimate than a phone call
column232: easier to make money from and subject to discussion of rights
column233: or right and wrong.12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's PenIntegrating video
column235: as just one part of a broader computer experience is the road not being taken by anyone but Facebook.Stocks to Buy for the Future of TV: Alibaba (BABA)Source: ShutterstockAlibaba Group Holding Ltd(NASDAQ:BABA) got into streaming in 2015 by buyingYouku Tudou
column237: for $4 billion-plus.Alibaba was late to this business
column238: but is working hard to make up for lost time. It launched a paid streaming service calledTmall Box Officein September
column239: 2015. It has a TV operating systemcalled YunOS
column240: which is getting its streaming services into homes throughout East and South Asia.In 2016
column241: Alibaba launchedpartnerships with a host of global producers
column242: the most important being with Steven Spielberg'sAmblin Entertainment
column243: which is aiming to bring Chinese stories to American audiences and vice versa. Alibaba also took a stakein China'sHeHe Picturesand signed a deal withHarry Potterproducer David Heyman to produce a series of movies aroundWarriors
column244: a children's book series about warring cats. Already in 2017 Alibaba has signed to becomea major sponsor of the Olympic Games
column245: responsible for streaming events and back-end cloud computing.Thanks to deals like this
column246: Alibaba's digital media revenues grew 270% year-over-year
column247: inits most recent quarterly report.The segment produced $585 million in revenue.Despite all this
column248: Alibaba is still a relative minnow in the streaming TV stocks waters. Its streaming revenue is just one-quarter that of Netflix. What makes it powerful
column249: and a threat to the giants
column251: not just in China; its willingness to buy its way into businesses like movie production; and its highly profitable growth trajectory
column252: which gives it a cash hoard worth $15 billion
column253: which it is far more aggressive about investing than Apple.Because Alibaba enables commerce
column254: rather than buying inventory as Amazon does
column255: it brings over 25% of its revenue to the net income line
column256: with operating cash flow that has grown four-fold in the last four years. It has enormous advantages in China
column257: the world's second-largest and one of its fastest-growing markets. This has given it a springboard into other markets like India
column259: where it is also growing a range of services.It is just a matter of time before Alibaba becomes a major factor in the U.S. market
column260: through its ownership of content and cloud operations if nothing else. Any innovation a U.S. company can come up with
column262: can be jumped on by Alibaba in a flash
column263: grown in China as a captive market
column264: and then sprung on the world quickly.It may be the most important story of the next four years
column265: but it won't be televised. It will definitely be streamed. I'm a buyer.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column266: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing he owned shares in AAPL
column269: BABA and FB.The post7 Stocks to Buy for the Future of TVappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 7 Dividend Stocks for the Retirement You Deserve;2/10/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsDividend stocks are a great choice for achieving the retirement you deserve. Yet there is perhaps no concept in the cultural lexicon that has been more perverted in recent years than the concept ""deserve.""makeArticleAd();Source:Mike via Flickr (Modified)In America today
column3: many people think they deserve a decent job
column4: good health
column5: safety and security … just by the accident of their existence. Children and young adults are taught they deserve a trophy for participating in sports
column6: and that they deserve good grades in school just for showing up.Call me old school
column7: but I think the only thing one deserves in life is what one earns. That's true of a job
column8: healthcare
column9: safety
column10: recognition
column11: grades or anything else that is a value one mustactupon to gain and/or keep. It's also true when it comes to your retirement.You see
column12: you don'tdeservewell-funded golden years unless you take action to earn it.Fortunately
column13: acting now to ensure a deserving retirement isn't really difficult to know how to do. It is
column14: however
column15: actually hard to do.Let's face it: Deferring the short-term gratification that comes from spending money on today's needs
column16: wants and luxury indulgences requires an uncomfortable exercise in self-restraint. Yet mustering the fortitude to think long-term is usually what's required if you want that well-funded retirement you think you deserve.While I can only help you with the self-restraint aspect of this task by identifying the reality of this requirement
column17: I can help you much more by identifying some of the best dividend stocks to buy that will help provide you the financial fertilizer by which you can grow those deserving golden years.10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy TodayHere are seven dividend stocks to buy for the retirement you deserve.Dividend Stocks to Buy for Retirement: General Motors (GM)Source: ShutterstockGM Dividend Yield:4.3%General Motors Company(NYSE:GM)
column18: or ""Government Motors
column19: has finally escaped the fiscal speed bump it hit during the Great Recession. Now the company is firing in all cylinders
column20: selling vehicles to U.S. and international consumers at a record pace.GM cleared the 10 million mark for vehicles soldfor the first time ever in 2016. That's thanks to successes in China
column21: where the automaker sold an all-time best 3.87 million vehicles - a 7.1% improvement from the previous year.Although the short- and intermediate-term fate of GM stock will rev and stall based on monthly sales figures and quarterly reports
column22: there is no denying that this behemoth is here to stay for the long haul. As long as the world needs transportation via cars and light trucks
column23: GM is likely to be there to sell them. We know this because despite the government bailout in December 2008
column24: the company is back and better than ever before.That's the power of a stalwart brand - and one that U.S. government won't let go down under any circumstances.Dividend Stocks to Buy for Retirement: Johnson & Johnson (JNJ)Source:Dawn Via FlickrJNJ Dividend Yield:2.8%When selecting dividend stocks for the retirement you deserve
column25: concentrate on consumer non-discretionary companies making things we all can't do without.I suspect that healthcare products giantJohnson & Johnson(NYSE:JNJ) is in your medicine cabinet right now. The iconic and ultra-diversified consumer
column26: pharmaceutical and medical device maker is famous for shampoo
column27: skin lotion
column28: baby oil
column29: wound care and over-the-counter (OTC) medicines.And that's just the consumer segment.The company's medical devices are used in orthopedic surgical care
column30: cardiovascular care
column31: diagnostics and vision treatments. Yet it's the success of its pharmaceutical division that vaults JNJ on to our list of dividend stocks. The company's treatments for chronic and ever-growing afflictions such as rheumatoid arthritis
column32: prostate cancer and diabetes give it the financial heft needed to be a long-term retirement hold.The Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryAnd acquisitions like its$30 billion buyout of biopharma outfitActelionwill keep JNJ ahead of the game.Dividend Stocks to Buy for Retirement: Apple (AAPL)Source: Carved.comAAPL Dividend Yield:1.7%Personal technology giantApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) is a profit machine
column33: and after years of building up billions in cash on its balance sheet
column34: the Cupertino behemoth decided to give some of that cash back to shareholders.While AAPL's yield is on the lower end of this list of deserving dividend stocks to buy
column35: that shouldn't dissuade you from putting it on your list.You see
column36: part of a deserving retirement requires some of your stocks to also deliver outsize share price appreciation. In that department
column37: AAPL tastes sweet. Over the past 10 years
column38: the stock is up more than 1
column39: 000%. And while the odds of another 1
column40: 000% gain over the next 10 years are low
column41: I suspect a decade from now
column42: those who own AAPL today will be flashing triple-digit-percentage-gain smiles.Dividend Stocks to Buy for Retirement: AT&T (T)Source:Mike Mozart via FlickrT Dividend Yield:4.7%Classic widow-and-orphan stockAT&T Inc.(NYSE:T) is just one of those telecom dividend stock giants perfectly tailored for delivering that deserved retirement. The company's massive 100% fiber network delivers wireless and TV services across the country
column43: and the revenues it generates from these services is reason alone to own the stock.Yet the company also is very inventive (it holds more than 20
column44: 000 patents)
column45: and it has demonstrated business savvy in its merger deals withDirecTV
column46: and soon (if the government doesn't block it) withTime Warner Inc(NYSE:TWX). AT&T says it's on pace toclose the merger by year's end.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatDividend-wise
column47: T is in elite status
column48: havingraised its payout for the past 33 yearswhile also offering one of the highest yields in theS&P 500.Dividend Stocks to Buy for Retirement: Disney (DIS)Source:Richard Stephenson via Flickr (Modified)DIS Dividend Yield:1.4%If you're reading this
column49: I can make one obvious assumption about you
column50: and that is you're sentient in the year 2017. That's enough information for me to know that you also know whatWalt Disney Co(NYSE:DIS) is
column51: and what it does.The purveyors of iconic American characters such as Mickey Mouse
column52: Donald Duck and Snow White know what the world wants to see
column53: and has built a media and entertainment empire that now includes characters such as Captain America
column54: BB-8 and Merida.The company
column55: founded on the genius of Walt Disney the man
column56: was set up to be a dream factory capable of igniting children's imaginations all over the world. It's safe to say that it has done just that.DIS the stock also has ignited investors' portfolios. Over the past decade
column57: shares are up nearly 220% while also paying a solid (though admittedly not spectacular) dividend yield of 1.4%. But like AAPL
column58: Disney is one of those dividend stocks likely to keep delivering the sort of outsize total returns that can provide you the retirement you deserve.Dividend Stocks to Buy for Retirement: Merck (MRK)Source:Ryan via Wikimedia (Modified)MRK Dividend Yield:2.9%Drug giantMerck & Co.
column59: Inc.(NYSE:MRK) is similar to JNJ in that it makes products that people can't do without. Although in Merck's case
column60: many of its products literally keep people alive (e.g.
column61: its top-selling treatment
column62: the diabetes pill Januvia).The company's diverse lineup of high-margin drugs will keep delivering strong revenue and strong profits for years to come. Moreover
column63: its pipeline of new drugs also should keep its top and bottom lines healthy enough to deliver strong returns on invested capital over the long-term.Although the company has faced robust competition from branded drugs going off-patent in recent years
column64: industry analysts tell me the company has gotten past the worst of the off-patent losses. My research also indicates recent R&D is on the upswing
column65: which means even more high-margin drugs in the years to come.10 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still BargainsThat means good fiscal therapy for that deserved retirement.Dividend Stocks to Buy for Retirement: Goldman Sachs (GS)Source:Erik DrostGS Dividend Yield:2.6%If you were asked to name the first Wall Street investment bank that comes to mind
column66: I suspect that name would beGoldman Sachs Group Inc(NYSE:GS). The company has financed America's growth since 1869
column67: racking up a storied history of providing the capital
column68: as well as the financial framework
column69: that's nurtured the rise of American capitalism.By recruiting and hiring some of the smartest
column70: most business-savvy people on earth to carry on the company's stellar tradition
column71: Goldman Sachs has managed to deliver big for investors even through the dark days of the Great Depression and the Great Recession. And while GS isn't the biggest yielder among financial dividend stocks
column72: its decent 2.6% yield has helped smooth out a few rough periods.It's no coincidence that many former Goldman Sachs employees rise to positions of power in government after stints at the premier investment house. The company and its personnel have earned their immense influence world … and that influence translates directly to deserving investor bottom lines.As of this writing
column73: Jim Woods was long AAPL and GS.The post7 Dividend Stocks for the Retirement You Deserveappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: The Next iPhone Wants to Look Into Your Eyes;2/10/2017;"Expectations for the 2017 iPhone are running high
column2: given the   fact that it will be the 10th-generation ofApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) most important product. As always
column3: a steady   stream of supply-chain leaks are stoking speculation as to what   features the Mac maker may or may not include. The most expensive   feature-packed model may even set customers backover $1
column4: 000. Today's rumor comes from the notoriously hit-or-missDigiTimes
column5: which says that in addition to an OLED display and wireless   charging
column6: the device will also include iris-scanning   technology.A boulder of saltAs always
column7: investors should treat any and all iPhone rumors   with a healthy bit of skepticism. That's especially true since   we've heard similar reports before. Apple first started exploring   iris-scanning technology back in 2014
column8: andDigiTimessaid in July 2016 that the iris-scanning feature wouldn't be   included until the 2018 iPhone. A month later
column9: the same outlet   said 2017 would be the year Apple would debut the technology   after placing orders for iris-recognition chips with Taiwan-based   Xintec.Separately
column10: there are conflicting reports that Apple may   instead prefer to use some type of facial recognition system
column11: as   Apple has filed numerous patents around bio-recognition   methods.makeArticleAd();Biometrics are all the rage right nowIt makes sense that Apple is exploring iris-recognition   technology; what's less clear is the timing of when Apple will   pull the trigger. Iris recognition would be a strong complement   to Touch ID
column12: adding another layer of biometric security. Iris   scanning is even more secure than fingerprint scanning since it's   harder to fake. You may remember when researchers cracked Touch   ID shortly after the feature's launch in 2013
column13: although it still   stands that Touch ID is still vastly superior to alpha-numeric   passwords.Imagine Apple Pay using iris recognition. Image source:     Apple.Beyond logging in
column14: it's also easy to imagine how Apple may   wish to add another layer of biometric security to Apple Pay
column15: making the company's mobile payment service even more secure.Everybody's doing itThis is an area rivals have already been exploring.Microsoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) included an iris scanner and Windows Hello
column16: Microsoft's biometric login functionality
column17: in 2015's Lumia 950   and 950 XL. The software giant has yet to bring iris recognition   to other Windows Hello-enabled devices
column18: although many Windows 10   PCs can use facial recognition technology.Samsung's Galaxy Note 7 from last year also included an iris scanner
column19: which in addition to its propensity to spontaneously combust was   a differentiating feature from Samsung's other flagship devices   from 2016 like the Galaxy S7 or S7 Edge. While the South Korean   company's initial efforts to popularize iris-scanning technology   went down in literal flames
column20: the forthcoming Galaxy S8 is   expected to feature an iris scanner. Samsung also launches its   Galaxy flagships in the spring
column21: and the S8 is expected to be   unveiled in March ahead of an April launch.Apple cares little about being the first -- it just wants to   be the best. If it can implement iris scanning in a more seamless   and integrated way than rivals
column22: it could accelerate the   popularization of biometric security better than anyone else.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column23: it can pay to listen. After all
column24: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column26: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: This 50% Dividend Grower Is Hiding in Plain Sight;2/10/2017;"There are two ways to get big dividends: you can buy stocks that boast highcurrentyields
column2: or you can buy stocks that consistently grow their payouts.A well-balanced portfolio will include both types of companies
column3: withdividend-growth stocksbeing the cornerstone of a longer-term income strategy.Still
column4: investors sometimes get frustrated with dividend growers because to get their outsized payout growth
column5: you often have to settle for a low current yield. And why buy a risky asset that yields 1% when you can get a long-term Treasury that pays 2%?makeArticleAd();There are two answers to this question. The first is that Treasuries aren't risk-free. If you buy a 10-year note and interest rates go up
column6: the value of your Treasury will go down. If you need to sell early for some reason
column7: you'll lose money.Secondly
column8: dividend-growth stocks will increase their income over time - something Treasuries will never do. In fact
column9: if you choose thebest dividend growth stocks
column10: you'll see your income skyrocket in a few short years.And the best dividend growth stock is one of the world's most recognizable and popular brands:Apple (AAPL).If you read about investing in Apple
column11: you almost always see a focus on iPhone sales
column12: the value of future products and so on. Bears note slowing iPhone sales growth (or negative sales growth)
column13: devices that didn't quite catch on and rising competition. Bulls counter that Apple has a valuable and unique market position and innovative products that captivate consumers.Both arguments are really missing the point.The main reason to buy Apple is more boring but more important: net income
column14: free cash flow (FCF) and dividends.Let's start with FCF
column15: which is now $9.65 per share
column16: meaning Apple's dividend-payout ratio is a measly 24%. But the really amazing thing is how the company's cash flow has exploded and continues to rise:FCF Boots UpYes
column17: there's been a bit of a dip in the last year
column18: but you can also see that FCF has already bottomed out and is now back on the rise.The next thing to consider is Apple's operating margin
column19: which is currently 27%. This is important because it means the company is so profitable that it can continue to pay out dividends at the current payout rate. That operating margin has fallen slightly in recent years
column20: partly as a result of changes in the smartphone market
column21: but it's still historically high:Apple Remains a Profit MonsterNote that we've seen Apple's profit margin remain over 25% since 2009. This is great news for investors
column22: but it also means Apple has become a very different company than it was in the 1990s and 2000s. It's no longer a burgeoning tech firm but an enterprise that reliably and consistently produces cash it can distribute to shareholders. In other words
column23: it's a blue chip stock
column24: not a speculative bet.Again
column25: great news for investors - especially those looking for income. Ironically
column26: many dividend-growth investors forget about Apple
column27: or they may allocate a very small part of their portfolios to the company out of fear that it's risky. That's a mistake.In the last five years since Apple started paying dividends
column28: its payout has soared 50.6%:Strong Dividend GrowthIf we compare that to some of the most popular and supposedly ""safer"" dividend payers
column29: we see that Apple's dividend growth is a big outperformer:Apple Trounces the RestAs you can see
column30: General Electric (GE)
column31: AT&T (T)
column32: Johnson & Johnson (JNJ)
column33: Chevron (CVX)
column34: Consolidated Edison (ED)andExxon Mobil (XOM)are all growing their dividends at a slower pace than Apple.The tech giant also has a lower P/E ratio than all of these names (just 15.6
column35: which is 39% lower than the rest of the S&P 500).It's time to think different about Apple; this is a relatively safe dividend stock that is destined to be a Dividend Aristocrat. While headlines about iPhone sales may cause some volatility in the short term
column36: the company's strong cash generation will reward you with big payouts in the long run.7 More Buys for 100%+ GainsApple isn't the only cheap dividend grower out there - there are plenty more (yes
column37: even in a market that's trading at a nosebleed 24 times earnings!).In fact
column38: we're cashing in on 7 other stocks hiking their payoutseven fasterthan Apple: I'm talkingreliable yearly dividend hikes of 20%+!These 7 low-key stocks are where you need to be with the Trump bump sputtering and the Fed sending mixed signals on interest rates. With each of these ""magnificent 7"" throwing off regular 20%+ payout hikes
column39: their prices will simply be forced up 100% - and higher - in the coming months and years.The full story is in our exclusive new guide:""7 Great Dividend-Growth Stocks for a Secure Retirement
column40: yours FREE.Click here to get your copy and discover these stealth dividend-growth plays for yourself."

column1: Nvidia Shows Artificial Intelligence Revolution Is Biggest Trend Of Our Time;2/10/2017;"Nvidia (Shutterstock photo)It's no secret that Nvidia (NVDA) was the best performing stock in the S&P 500 in 2016
column2: gaining more than 370%. But while the company's graphics processor unit (GPU) chips are being used in everything from gaming PCs to autonomous cars to virtual reality to data centers
column3: the reinvigoration of Nvidia is built by one thing: artificial intelligence.AI is increasingly being used in everything and everywhere
column4: most notably data centers for machine learning
column5: where Nvidia's GPUs have a tremendous lead over the competition
column6: including anything from AMD (AMD) and Intel (INTC). Data center revenue was up 67% year-over-year in the quarter at $296 million and more impressive
column7: up 23% from the impressive fiscal third-quarter 2017 results that helped send the stock soaring more than 30% in November 2016.makeArticleAd();The technology is touching everything and anyone
column8: be it on your smartphone or when you shop on Amazon (AMZN) or using software. In fact
column9: Nvidia CEO Jen-Hsun Huang toldBarron'sthat AI is just the future of software.If you read Nvidia's conference call transcript and itsearnings press release
column10: AI is mentioned everywhere and with good reason: deep learning is only made possible by the advancements in AI being made by university researchers and big companies such as Google (GOOG)
column11: Apple (AAPL)
column12: Facebook (FB)
column13: Amazon and others.In reacting to the blow-out earnings results
column14: Jefferies analyst Mark Lipacis called Nvidia essentially the only publicly traded company solely focused on AI. ""[Nvidia] posted its 7th consecutive beat
column15: and while YoY rev growth of 55% likely marks 2nd derivative peak
column16: the 200% growth in its Datacenter business and improving GM reinforce our thesis that NVDA is emerging as the de facto standard in AI - one of the most exciting growth drivers in tech
column17: Lipacis wrote
column18: while raising his price target to $140 from $125.Of the aforementioned areas
column19: perhaps the one that is most tangible to show consumers the AI revolution is autonomous driving.Tesla (TSLA) and CEO Elon Musk have pioneered autonomous driving in the Model S (though to which extent is up for debate)
column20: but Tesla has chosen to use Nvidia's chipsets to not only help it with its infotainment unit
column21: but more importantly
column22: the software that helps withautonomy
column23: using the NVIDIA DRIVE™ PX 2 AI computing platform.Society is a little bit away from true autonomy in a car (Level 5)
column24: in which a human does not need to do anything
column25: but Tesla is working on getting towards Level 4/5 faster than anyone else
column26: thanks to Nvidia. (For a good primer on what each level means
column27: clickhere.)Nvidia has several other automotive partnerships
column28: including recently announced ones with Bosch andAudi.All of this highlights that self-driving cars is not just a science fiction fantasy
column29: it's real and it's coming. And it's being powered by AI. The societal impact AI will have is up for debate
column30: whether it will be a net positive or a net negative
column31: but there is no stopping it.AI is continuing to become more prevalent in everything we do
column32: but we are nowhere near general AI
column33: in which computers can make decisions just as a human can. What we're experiencing right now is soft (weak) AI
column34: in which humans tell a computer to do a task and it does it better than any human can. But thanks to deep/machine learning
column35: we're getting closer to general AI
column36: even if it's still decades away. That means the AI revolution is only just getting started and it has years and years on which to run.All thanks to Nvidia."

column1: Apple Inc. a 50% Dividend Grower Hiding in Plain Sight (AAPL);2/10/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThere are two ways to get big dividends: you can buy stocks that boast highcurrentyields
column3: or you can buy stocks that consistently grow their payouts.makeArticleAd();A well-balanced portfolio will include both types of companies
column4: withdividend-growth stocksbeing the cornerstone of a longer-term income strategy.Still
column5: investors sometimes get frustrated with dividend growers because to get their outsized payout growth
column6: you often have to settle for a low current yield. And why buy a risky asset that yields 1% when you can get a long-term Treasury that pays 2%?There are two answers to this question. The first is that Treasuries aren't risk-free. If you buy a 10-year note and interest rates go up
column7: the value of your Treasury will go down. If you need to sell early for some reason
column8: you'll lose money.Secondly
column9: dividend-growth stocks will increase their income over time-something Treasuries will never do. In fact
column10: if you choose thebest dividend growth stocks
column11: you'll see your income skyrocket in a few short years.And the best dividend growth stock is one of the world's most recognizable and popular brands:Apple Inc.(AAPL).If you read about investing in Apple
column12: you almost always see a focus on iPhone sales
column13: the value of future products and so on. Bears note slowing iPhone sales growth (or negative sales growth)
column14: devices that didn't quite catch on and rising competition. Bulls counter that Apple has a valuable and unique market position and innovative products that captivate consumers.Both arguments are really missing the point.The main reason to buy Apple is more boring but more important: net income
column15: free cash flow (FCF) and dividends.Let's start with FCF
column16: which is now $9.65 per share
column17: meaning Apple's dividend-payout ratio is a measly 24%. But the really amazing thing is how the company's cash flow has exploded and continues to rise:FCF Boots UpYes
column18: there's been a bit of a dip in the last year
column19: but you can also see that FCF has already bottomed out and is now back on the rise.7 Tech Stocks With Explosive Growth PotentialThe next thing to consider is Apple's operating margin
column20: which is currently 27%. This is important because it means the company is so profitable that it can continue to pay out dividends at the current payout rate. That operating margin has fallen slightly in recent years
column21: partly as a result of changes in the smartphone market
column22: but it's still historically high:Apple Remains a Profit MonsterNote that we've seen Apple's profit margin remain over 25% since 2009. This is great news for investors
column23: but it also means Apple has become a very different company than it was in the 1990s and 2000s. It's no longer a burgeoning tech firm but an enterprise that reliably and consistently produces cash it can distribute to shareholders. In other words
column24: it's a blue chip stock
column25: not a speculative bet.Again
column26: great news for investors-especially those looking for income. Ironically
column27: many dividend-growth investors forget about Apple
column28: or they may allocate a very small part of their portfolios to the company out of fear that it's risky. That's a mistake.In the last five years since Apple started paying dividends
column29: its payout has soared 50.6%:Strong Dividend GrowthIf we compare that to some of the most popular and supposedly ""safer"" dividend payers
column30: we see that Apple's dividend growth is a big outperformer:Apple Trounces the RestAs you can see

column33: Johnson & Johnson(JNJ)

column35: Consolidated Edison

column37: which is 39% lower than the rest of the S&P 500).It's time to think different about Apple; this is a relatively safe dividend stock that is destined to be a Dividend Aristocrat. While headlines about iPhone sales may cause some volatility in the short term
column38: the company's strong cash generation will reward you with big payouts in the long run.Buy Apple Now … Then Add These 6 High YieldersThere's no doubt Apple is a best-in-class dividend-growth stock. But you also need high yields to go with that dividend growth-especially if you're in or near retirement.Should Bill Gates Sell His Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock?That's where the 6 reliable income generators in our new""No-Withdrawal"" retirement portfoliocome in. column1: So Why Not Buy Apple?;2/10/2017;"ByWexboy:We all know the type: Born-again value investors who still have that new car smell. No longer clueless
column2: but the market hasn't beaten adequate sense (or humility) into them just yet
column3: so they're still insanely overconfident. Which we tolerate - after all
column4: we were like them once - then they start expounding their new and improved value investing philosophy
column5: and it all goes downhill. I recall one encounter
column6: some years back
column7: where I struggled to get a word in
column8: let alone offer some kind of reality check. Finally
column9: my new guru was forced to pause and finally breathe
column10: so I did the only sensible thing. I lobbed this hand grenade:So why not buy Apple?All I got was a puzzled look. Repeating the question
column11: I then pummeled him with a veritable laundry list ofApple(AAPL) fundamentals and ratios. If he was such a value expert
column12: surely Apple was a screaming value buy? Needless to say
column13: I never got much of a reply
column14: but it stopped him in his tracks and scared him off. Job well done! But the more I thought about it
column15: the more it seemed like a valid question for other investors (and even me). And a question to be asked in a spirit of honest inquiry. I mean
column16: let's look at Apple's numbers today:makeArticleAd();- Net sales have reached $216 billion (as of FY-2016).- Net sales increased by 99% and over 1
column17: 000% in last 5 and 10 years
column18: respectively.- Gross margin increased to 39% ($84 billion) in last 10 years.- Operating profit margin more than doubled to 28% ($60 billion) in last 10 years.- Net income increased by 76% and almost 2
column19: 200% in last 5 and 10 years.- EPS compounded by 16% pa and 38% pa in last 5 and 10 years.- Net cash and investments increased almost 1
column20: 400% to $151 billion in last 10 years.- Current share price (as of cob Feb-7th): $131.53- Current market cap: $690 billion- Current Price/Sales ratio: 3.2 times- Ex-net cash and investments Price/Sales ratio: 2.4 times- Current P/E ratio: 15.7 times- Ex-net cash and investments P/E ratio: 12.1 times- Current FCF ratio: 13.2 times- Ex-net cash and investments FCF ratio: 10.1 timesOk
column21: just take a moment and marvel. Even with the share price now approaching all-time highs again
column22: surely Apple's still a screaming value buy?So why not buy Apple?Ever since
column23: I pose this question to fellow value investors on a regular basis; but I'm not sure I've ever received a satisfactory reply! As in: 'Yes/No
column24: I bought Apple/I decided not to buy Apple - based on a detailed analysis
column25: and the following specific attributes.' Instead
column26: people tend to shrug their shoulders
column27: roll their eyes
column28: flash a rueful grin
column29: and maybe toss out one of the usual objections. I'm sure you can guess a few:- But Apple's market cap is almost $700 billion now!- It's far too well-researched and efficiently priced for investors to ever have an edge.- A much cooler/better/cheaper brand will surely come along for the kids to buy.- It will inevitably hurtle off a cliff into technological obsolescence and irrelevance.- The micro-cap
column30: sum-of-the-parts thesis we discussed is far more interesting.- Steve Jobs is dead… the company's sure to go off the rails any day/month/year now.- Look at thebloody chart- who's going to buy it now
column31: after that rally?Now
column32: before the fanboys start to lose their minds
column33: this is where I should reveal this post is NOT about Apple. No
column34: really.Sorry
column35: fanboys…Study the long-term chart of any outstanding growth stock
column36: and it's quite obvious most of the objections above are just red herrings. Part of a litany of excuses too many value investors trot out to justify hiding within their own circle of comfort. Because we fear the risks and challenges of the unknown. Instead
column37: we reject (or simply ignore) entire sectors and hundreds/thousands of companies
column38: because we've decided they're just too large
column39: too expensive
column40: too unpredictable
column41: too uninteresting
column42: to be worthy of consideration.And then we citeBuffett: Always remain within yourcircle of competence!Except this rule would imply buying no individual stocks - since newbie investors should always choose passive investing initially
column43: as the most prudent choice. And anyway
column44: Buffett evolved his investing approach and continually expanded his circle of competence over his entire career. [Yefei Lu'snew Buffett bookoffers good perspective]. Mere mortals should emulate such an evolution - not Buffett himself! Unless you plan on being a deca-billionaire too - then you can avoid/invest in absolutely anything you fancy.Let's not forget
column45: when Buffett started out
column46: technology was a nascent sector - which required a VC approach - something he clearly wasn't too comfortable with. [But readPhilip Fisheragain: Now
column47: he was a great venture capitalist - albeit one who chose to invest in listed companies]. And technology-related hype/promotion during theGo-Go Yearsprobably compounded this aversion
column48: which Buffett rationalized as avoiding the sector's obvious unpredictability. Except that never stopped him from investing in the likes of banks and retail! Which are potentially just as lethal and unpredictable
column49: but obviously they were sectors in which he was actually comfortable investing.But in sticking religiously to his comfort zone
column50: Buffett also displayed his true genius. His apparent caution is deceptive - rest assured
column51: he never doubted his investing ability. Instead
column52: he deliberately chose to leverage his prowess in a new and more aggressive way
column53: via the use of long-term
column54: interest-free insurancefloatanddeferred taxes. Of course
column55: the potential risks of taking on such significant leverage would ensure he remained laser-focused on investing (primarily) in predictable sectors and businesses
column56: and obviously inspired his two main rules:Rule No. 1: Never lose money.Rule No. 2: Never forget Rule No. 1.Couple this with super-human patience and fifty years later it seems almost inevitable Buffett's actually accrued an entirely unique investment record.Whereas we don't have the luxury of float. And it's 2017: We live in a world where technology and innovation play an ever increasing role
column57: for decades now
column58: in all aspects of our economy
column59: workplaces and daily lives. And technology isn't (necessarily) any more unpredictable than biotech/pharma
column60: fashion
column61: media
column62: retail
column63: natural resources
column64: emerging/frontier markets
column65: etc. But it deserves far more focus and study - since its potential impact on other sectors
column66: in terms of innovation and disruption
column67: is obviously far greater today (and as we look ahead). [Withautonomous trucksnow being tested on open highways
column68: it's both astonishing and alarming to realizetruck drivingmay still be the most common male occupation in the US! (with almost 3 million drivers)].A value investor who deliberately avoids technology and other such (unpredictable) sectors is foregoing a world of investment opportunity - especially now
column69: when an ever increasing share of economic value-creation is derived from technology
column70: not to mention other intangible assets and intellectual property. And trapped in a low-growth
column71: low-return world (like today - or in due course
column72: as debt and entitlements keep escalating)
column73: such investors may end up condemned to choosing between: i) traditional blue chip/Buffett classics (e.g. food and beverage stocks) which now seem to trade at ever-expanding multiples (vs. historic and prospective earnings growth)
column74: or ii) traditional value stocks which can perhaps no longer rely on a rising tide of growth
column75: inflation and animal spirits. Who can afford such risks and opportunity cost?But for many value investors
column76: we're far more comfortable with the numbers
column77: rather than the story itself. Which is
column78: potentially
column79: our downfall [And vice versa for growth investors]. The hard assets and cheap metrics of your typical value stock offer the siren song of safety
column80: whereas investing in high quality/growth stocks may require a far more demanding leap of faith. Except value stocks are often mired in bad management
column81: bad business models
column82: bad industries and dreadful capital allocation - with little hope of compounding their intrinsic value - the best we can hope for is a realization of intrinsic value.If you're a human computer who loves to re-rank and re-invest in the world's cheapest stocks every day
column83: such an event-driven portfolio may be rewarding (and the studies do claim value beats growth)
column84: but in the real world how many investors manage to deliver sustained long-term outperformance with such an approach? Maybe a passive
column85: computer-driven portfolio is the better solution
column86: especially when the greatest human computer of them all (i.e. Buffett) has long since abandoned such an approach. In the end
column87: value investing will always be a marvelous valuation tool and framework for investing
column88: but its greatest failing doesn't lie in the stocks it green-lights for you to buy…It actually lies in the stocks it persuades youNOTto buy!I suspect most value investors will freely acknowledge this failing. And embrace the proposition that investing in high quality/growth stocks is ultimately a far more attractive way of compounding long-term portfolio value (particularly on a tax-deferred basis)
column89: IF ONLYit weren't so difficult! Because such an investing approach must inevitably be driven by qualitative
column90: not quantitative
column91: analysis. And it conflicts with having our cake and eating it - we want the best companies and the best prices! In reality
column92: we need to compromise and choose wonderful companies at fair prices
column93: not fair companies at wonderful prices. Which actually offers a far more compelling value equation
column94: since time is the friend of the wonderful company
column95: the enemy of the mediocre.And so
column96: paying up is often required - well
column97: at least from a traditional value perspective - which
column98: almost inevitably needs to be justified via comprehensive study of the company and its management
column99: its capital allocation
column100: its products and business model
column101: its industry dynamics
column102: and (most of all) whether it enjoys a significant
column103: sustainable and (ideally) an expanding competitive advantage (i.e. aneconomic moat). An exercise which is surely infinitely more challenging than assessing and ranking a bunch of value metrics. And one which can go horribly wrong - a busted value thesis may engender some rueful sympathy (wow
column104: who knew management were such idiots?)
column105: but paying up for a high flier just before it collapses will inevitably attract a perfect storm of hindsight and sniggers for making such a bone-headed investment decision. But then again
column106: nailing even a single multi-bagger growth stock might yield a payoff value investors can only ever dream of.Of course
column107: today the answer might not be Apple. But next up there's a world of other compelling investment opportunities out there just waiting to be explored. Which means it's still an excellent question to kick off your search:So why not buy Apple?See alsoRevlon Corp.: Will This Sleeping Giant Come Back To Life?on seekingalpha.com"

column1: Alphabet Inc. Takes Another Shot at Amazon With Home Control;2/10/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAlphabet Inc.'s(NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google Home connected speaker takes onAmazon.com
column3: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) Alexa on its home turf. But what about Google's big advantage over Amazon in the smart home war - all those smartphones?makeArticleAd();Source: GoogleThe company has just begun rolling out Home Control
column4: a new feature that lets Google Assistant control smart home devices by voice.However
column5: at this point
column6: Home Control - like Google Assistant - remains a feature that's exclusive to Google's own Pixel Phones.The Battle for the Smart HomeGoogle Home is a connected speaker with Google Assistant baked in. Owners can use Google Assistant on the speaker to answer questions
column7: find music and control a growing number of smart home devices using their voice only.The device is GOOGL's answer to the Amazon Echo. Amazon's Alexa-enabled speaker has been a surprise hit and allowed Amazon to take a big lead in the race to become the smart home hub - despite the distinct disadvantage of lacking a smartphone platform to host its digital assistant.Google has Google Now and the new Google Assistant
column8: whileApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) has Siri. Between them
column9: the two companies have billions of mobile devices in consumers' hands
column10: yet Amazon still managed to leapfrog them with its personal assistant hosted in a speaker
column11: to build an impressive smart home lead.Apple's Siri can control HomeKit-compatible smart home devices using voice commands
column12: and now GOOGL is rolling out asimilar feature for its Google Assistant
column13: Home Control.Home ControlGoogle's new feature for voice control of smart devices isn't actually new. Anyone who owns both a Pixel Phone and a Google Home speaker already had a Home Control setting on their smartphone.10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy TodayHowever
column14: as of yesterday
column15: GOOGL has begun to roll out Home Control to all Google Assistant users. This amounts to all Pixel Phone owners
column16: since Google Assistant remains an exclusive that third-party Android smartphones don't get.With Home Control
column17: someone with a Pixel Phone gets the same voice control ability for smart devices they would have if they owned a Google Home speaker. They can use voice commands on their phone to change the temperature on their Nest Learning Thermostat or turn off the smart lighting in the room they just left.The Battle for the Smart Home Enters a New Phase (Sort of)At the start of this fight to be the company that becomes the hub of the smart home - the one who controls all those smart devices - the smartphone was it.Smartphones ran all the apps that controlled each of the devices and everyone owned one. With smartphones
column18: the battle came down to iOS and Android
column19: Apple and Google.Then Amazon disrupted everything with the Echo and Alexa. With thousands of compatible products and services
column20: consumers have been snapping them up. Amazon sold out of the Echo at Christmas
column21: afterselling nine times moreof the smart speaker than the previous year.Voice control is in. Having to poke buttons on a smartphone is out.Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Finally Fires Back at Apple With Android Wear 2.0However
column22: Apple and Google are not about to cede the smart home to Amazon. GOOGL began its assault on Amazon with the Google Home smart speaker to directly take on the Echo and Alexa. With Home Control
column23: it's bringing voice control of smart devices to the smartphone
column24: leveraging its massive lead over Amazon when it comes to numbers. There may be millions of Alexa-powered homes
column25: but there are billions of people already carrying an Android smartphone.Except
column26: most of those people still won't be able to use Home Control. GOOGL has baked Home Control into Google Assistant
column27: a feature that's been exclusive to its Pixel Phones since they were released last fall. With Google Home and now Home Control
column28: Alphabet clearly has Amazon's number. The question will be whether Amazon gets Alexa into more third-party devices before Google decides to let third-party Android smartphone makers have access to Google Assistant.For GOOGL
column29: the decision comes down to which is more valuable: maintaining a key competitive advantage for its own Pixel Phones
column30: or giving up that Google Assistant and Home Control exclusivity to take a real shot at unseating Amazon in the smart home.As of this writing
column31: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceNo
