column14: which beat consensus estimates by a whopping 30 cents. Fourth quarter revenue also beat
column15: coming in 55% higher year over year to $2.17 billion. The Street was looking for revenue of $2.11 billion.The strong bottom-line beat was driven by record quarterly GAAP gross margin at 60.0%
column16: the company said
column17: while non-GAAP gross margin at 60.2%. When looking back at fiscal 2016
column18: the company broke several of its own records
column19: including full-year revenue of $6.91 billion
column20: which grew 38% from a year ago.""We had a great finish to a record year
column21: with continued strong growth across all our businesses
column22: said CEO Jen-Hsun Huang in a statement. ""Our GPU computing platform is enjoying rapid adoption in artificial intelligence
column23: cloud computing
column24: gaming
column25: and autonomous vehicles. Huang also added that Nvidia’s deep learning GPUs (graphical processing units) has made a breakthrough approach to AI
column26: which can now help in early cancer detection
column27: weather prediction and is helping to tackle challenges such as self-driving cars.All told
column28: it is these breakthrough areas that continue to drive interest in NVDA stock. Admittedly
column29: I wasn’t a believer until now. And while the tech battle has always been between Apple (AAPL) Alphabet (GOOGL)
column30: Amazon (AMZN) and Facebook (FB)
column31: those guys are not alone anymore.In terms of the 3% decline on these solid numbers? Nvidia is being shown the respect it now deserves. Even if the stock were to decline 5% to 10% — after a 340% one-year rise — it would still imply the momentum story is still in place. And Nvidia’s Q1 outlook for revenue to be $1.9 billion
column32: which surpass Wall Street estimates of $1.88 billion
column33: suggests it sees no signs of slowing down."

column1: No
column2: Apple Inc. Is Not Releasing the iPhone 8 Early;2/10/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsA report began circulating several days ago thatApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) may start production of the iPhone 8 early. Typically
column4: when a company starts manufacturing sooner than usual
column5: that points to an accelerated release date for a new product.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleIn this case
column6: it seems unlikely the move will result in an iPhone release date before Apple's standard September launch.If not to get it on shelves sooner
column7: why would the company want to get an early start on new iPhone production?The iPhone 8 Early Production Ramp UpApple has a pretty standard roadmap when it comes to new iPhone releases. With a late September iPhone release date
column8: the company starts to ramp up production of the new model in late summer. However
column9: this year it looks as though Apple may be breaking with tradition.According to a report from BlueFin Research Partners
column10: there are indicators in the company's supply chain that point to an unusually early production ramp up for the iPhone 8. Quoted inMSN Money
column11: the BlueFin report notes:""The most intriguing data points that we have uncovered suggests that Apple is ramping the next generation iPhones earlier than historical norms.""Why Early Production Won't Lead to an Earlier iPhone Release DateBefore anyone gets too excited about the possibility of an early iPhone 8 release
column12: that scenario is highly unlikely.First
column13: ramping up production in June means Apple will begin having stock of the new iPhones in warehouses by the summer. But no one releases a flagship smartphone during the summer months - that's a slow time for consumer technology news. People are on vacation and not only would an iPhone announcement not get the coverage Apple expects for its new product launches
column14: with so many people away the line-ups at Apple Stores the company is hoping for wouldn't happen.3 Warren Buffett Stocks to Buy in the Trump EraAn early release would also reduce iPhone 7 sales. Now that production is humming on that model
column15: Apple wouldn't want to kneecap it by releasing the iPhone 8 early.So Why Would Apple Ramp up iPhone 8 Production Early?It's become increasingly obvious that companies like Apple are pushing the limits of their supply chain and manufacturing partners with their latest smartphones. The new dual camera system
column16: haptic Home button and other components led to a shortage of some iPhone 7 models at launch. Apple ramped up production in late summer as usual
column17: but these issues caused delays.I preordered an iPhone 7 Plus
column18: but still waited a month after the new iPhones went on sale before mine was available …Then there's the issue of batteries. Apple has had to face its own headaches withiPhone 6 and 6s batteries
column19: but those problems pale in comparison to the nightmare rivalSamsung Electronics Co Ltd(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) has gone through with the Galaxy Note 7 and its exploding batteries.There's a lot riding on the iPhone 8 and Apple appears to be throwing all sorts of new features
column20: cutting-edge technology and a completely new design at its 10th anniversary iPhone. Glass construction
column21: wireless charging
column22: an OLED display
column23: virtual Home button and more. The company is even rumored to becharging $1
column24: 000-plusfor its new flagship
column25: an unprecedented price for a smartphone.In addition
column26: Samsung will likely be introducing its new Galaxy Note around the same time
column27: and pulling out all the stops to make that phablet such a smash hit that everyone forgets about the Galaxy Note 7.Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column28: NASDAQ:GOOGL) is also expected to release the followup to the worryingly successful Google Pixel Phone in the fall.Rather than ramping up for an early launch
column29: it's far more likely that Apple is starting iPhone 8 production early in order to iron out all the manufacturing bugs early. Virtually all of the components will be new and Apple will undoubtedly be pushing the limits of manufacturing capability. Having an early start will ensure any issues are caught well before the iPhone 8 goes on sale
column30: ensuring a smooth
column31: scandal-free
column32: launch. And no embarrassing issues for the competition to take advantage of.The early ramp up also ensures that even if things don't go smoothly at first
column33: there will be plenty of iPhone 8 smartphones sitting in Apple warehouses in September
column34: ensuring a record-setting launch.Should Under Armour Inc (UAA) CEO Kevin Plank Step Aside?Despite the apparent early production ramp up
column35: don't expect an iPhone release date in the summer. But Apple's move does mean you should have a flawless iPhone 8 in your hands at the launch
column36: instead of waiting weeks or months for supply to catch up to demand.As of this writing
column37: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's Pen7 High-Risk
column38: High-Reward Stocks to Buy NowThe postNo
column39: Apple Inc. Is Not Releasing the iPhone 8 Earlyappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Despite Generous Capital Returns
column2: Apple Inc. Still Has More Cash Than Ever Before;2/9/2017;"Apple's(NASDAQ: AAPL)  overseas cash position continues to grow   at an incredible rate
column3: and the possibility of some type of   repatriation holiday is the highest it has been in years
column4: thanks   to the new Trump administration.In this segment fromIndustry Focus: Tech
column5: Motley Fool analyst Dylan Lewis and senior technology   specialist Evan Niu discuss Apple's cash position and financial   structure.A full transcript follows the video.makeArticleAd();10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column6: it can pay to listen. After all
column7: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column8: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column9: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column10: 2017This podcast was recorded on Feb. 3
column11: 2017.Dylan Lewis:Speaking of their international segments
column12: I think it might   make sense to check in on their cash hoard a little bit. As of   their recent report
column13: Apple is sitting on $246 billion in cash.   Because they do so much business outside of the U.S. and   because of certain current tax regulations
column14: $230 billion of that   total
column15: or roughly 94%
column16: is held outside the U.S. Morgan   Stanley analyst Katy Hubertyasked [CEO] Tim Cook on the call about what the company   might be thinking with the current administration
column17: and the   possibility of repatriating some of that cash. I think that was a   question a lot of people wanted an answer to.Evan Niu:Yeah. That's one of the big things that the Trump   administration is pushing
column18: is this tax reform
column19: including a   potential repatriation holiday. If they could bring back a lot of   that cash
column20: there are certainly a couple things they could do   with it. Cook didn't really give a lot of clear guidance on   what he's thinking. But
column21: you could buy some companies.   He keep saying that Apple is open to really big   acquisitions if they fit
column22: if they make sense
column23: all these   things. But he's basically not concerned about pricing anymore.   You could buy some companies
column24: you could invest in the   U.S.
column25: you could potentially bring production back.   Obviously
column26: that's another big thing that Trump is pushing.Another thing I would actually like to see is strengthen   the balance sheet. The whole reason they have the $70   billion-plus in debt is because it's always been a way to   avoid the repatriation taxes. So
column27: if they can repatriate at   appealing rates
column28: it might also make sense to pay down some   of that debt
column29: because that way
column30: you can avoid some of the   interest expense
column31: and it strengthens your balance sheet a little.   Not that the balance sheet is weak
column32: by any stretch of the   imagination. It all nets out in the end. But
column33: logistically
column34: it would be nice to bring that money back
column35: pay down some debt.   Because
column36: if this is a one-time deal that they can bring back   a ton of money
column37: I would expect them to keep generating   ridiculous amounts of cash overseas
column38: and then they would want to   raise more debt
column39: again
column40: to be able to tap that
column41: in the   same way they have been doing
column42: but if they could pay down that   debt
column43: that basically gives them even more time to keep   pursuing the same strategy. And if they're taking advantage   of a one-time tax holiday
column44: I think that would make sense
column45: from a corporate finance standpoint.Lewis:Yeah. Even with $70 billion in debt
column46: where they had to   repatriate a lot of that cash that's held overseas
column47: they   still have quite a bit to work with. I think on the call
column48: Huberty specifically asked about what merger and acquisition   activity to expect
column49: or if they might continue to invest   in original content and programming that would make the   Apple ecosystem seem a little bit more appealing. I think because   she led with that question and had some specific examples of   where cash might go
column50: Cook's response followed along with   that. But
column51: I was hoping we might get some color about   an increase in the dividend
column52: or an update on what the   company was thinking with share repurchase where they'd have   that extra capital on hand. But
column53: nothing there at the   moment. Cook was notoriously cagey
column54: as always
column55: in his   response.Niu:Yeah. He didn't really give a lot away there.   They usually update their capital return program every   April. So
column56: next quarter
column57: we will get some insight. They did   buy back $11 billion in shares this quarter. Which partially   helps juice the earnings-per-share number
column58: which is another   record
column59: because they are able to retire so many   shares. They retired something like 62 million shares last   quarter. That's really highly accretive to that   earnings-per-share figure
column60: even though net income was   actually down slightly relative to a year ago
column61: in part   because of foreign exchange headwinds and things of that   nature. So
column62: right now
column63: they are up to about $144 billion   in cumulative repurchases
column64: and the current authorization is   $175 billion. So they still have plenty of room. They only   have one more quarter before they update it again.   But I would expect them to give another update and increase   it again in a couple months
column65: because this   business creates so much cash that they literally have   no idea what to do with it. [laughs] I mean
column66: think   about how much money they have given back
column67: and the fact that   they still have more money now than they've ever had before. So
column68: it's like
column69: they're trying to give this cash back at this   ridiculous rate
column70: but they generate so much of it that it   still adds on a net basis to their total cash position
column71: even   after giving back so much over the years. It's mind-boggling.Lewis:And that's with them continuing to invest in the   future
column72: as well. You hear about some of the different   projects that they may or may not be funding
column73: and some of   the initiatives they might be pushing. It's not like   they're sitting on their heels here. They're certainly   throwing money into seeing where tech might be going. It's just   that
column74: with this type of money available to them
column75: you can   only do so much of it with reinvesting in the business and with   R&D. I mean
column76: that's the beauty of having a cash cow   business like that.Niu:It's just insane how much they make.Dylan Lewisowns shares of Apple.Evan Niu

column1: Voice Control Platforms a Key Technology Trend in 2017;2/9/2017;"Technology companies have spent years on computational linguistics to solve the basic problem of making machines more efficient in an era where they would have to deal with bigger data loads and more complex queries. One of the products of this research is voice driven artificial intelligence that can connect and drive everyday devices to understand human speech and react accordingly.The most basic form of voice technology is a person directing a machine to do routine tasks such as play a track
column2: read the mail
column3: send automated response to mails and such things that Apple'sAAPLSiri
column4: Alphabet'sGOOGLGoogle Now or Microsoft'sMSFTCortana took care of. Home automation is a more recent trend and wouldn't it be cool if most of the smart devices/appliances used in the home can also take voice commands? And sync with each other to decide the desirable activity and then get it done?Amazon AheadWhile Microsoft has many years of research behind it
column5: it is AmazonAMZNthat has really taken voice controlled platforms mainstream. The company launched its first Echo device a couple of years ago and sold more than seven million devices last year. While many of them were the cheaper Dot
column6: it still puts Alexa
column7: Amazon's voice assistant into that many new homes.At this year's CES
column8: Amazon had a coup as companies ranging from FordF
column9: Huawei and LG to a large number of startups unveiled phones
column10: cars
column11: home appliances and other gadgets with Alexa integration making Amazon's voice assistant that much more useful.And Amazon has doubled down to develop Alexa's ""skills
column12: which are discrete voice-based applications that allow the system to carry out specific tasks (like ordering pizza for example). At launch
column13: Alexa had just 20 skills
column14: which has reportedly jumped to 5
column15: 200 today with the company adding about 100 skills per day.In fact
column16: Bezos has said
column17: ""We've been working behind the scenes for the last four years
column18: we have more than 1
column19: 000 people working on Alexa and the Echo ecosystem … It's just the tip of the iceberg.""Just last week
column20: it launched a new website to help brands and developers create more skills for Alexa. It also has a home consultation service called ""simplify your life"" where Amazon reps teach you to automate your home using Echo and Alexa. But all this works simply because everything is connected with AWS
column21: which transmits data between different devices.Amazon.com

column25: but competition is in hot pursuit. Google Home was launched late last year and the search leader will do all it can to grow market share.To prove the point Google too had some important announcements for the Google Assistant
column26: which drives Google Home. But some of the most important deals were for integrations into Hyundai's navigation system
column27: Chrysler's 300 model
column28: NVIDIA'sNVDAShield TV as well as others such as Belkin smart switches
column29: Switchmate smart lights
column30: Coway Airmega air purifiers
column31: etc. Google still has miles to go before it catches up with Amazon
column32: but it's made a strong start.Google has the most to lose if it can't make it big here because a lot of voice search will probably happen through these assistants going forward. But it also has an advantage
column33: i.e.
column34: all the information it has curated over the years
column35: your preferences and your habits that it can draw from to serve you. In short
column36: it knows you better.Alphabet Inc. Price and ConsensusAlphabet Inc. Price and Consensus|Alphabet Inc. QuoteApple Also in the FrayApple doesn't have a separate Home device
column37: but a useful app of the same name that can connect all the smart devices in your home and get them to communicate with each other. So it's also dependent on the number of gadget makers supporting the app and this number has been swelling in the recent past.While Apple's partners aren't making the news as much as the other two

column43: acoustics
column44: display and other systems supplier Harman. That is a big sum to pay
column45: although justified considering that Harman does offer a number of products that would be complementary with the displays and chips that are an important part of the increasingly electronic and soon-to-be self-driving cars. IHS iSuppli expects the market to grow from $42 billion in 2016 to $61 billion next year.But there's more: just last year
column46: Harman announced a number of collaborations indicating its growing importance in the world of voice activated controls. In September
column47: it agreed to incorporate Baidu speech recognition and synthesis technology in smart speakers so people can use voice commands to turn on audio experiences and access on-demand services.Earlier
column48: the two collaborated to create CarLife offering advanced Internet capabilities
column49: entertainment features and location-based services on HARMAN's in-vehicle infotainment head units for the Chinese market. At the World of Watson conference last October
column50: Harman collaborated with IBM to bring voice activated intelligent assistance based on IoT and cognitive computing to hotels
column51: offices and hospitals across the world.Along Comes SoundHoundKeyvan Mohajer of SoundHound says
column52: ""We are at the inflection point of our long-term vision that every product or service needs to have a smart voice-enabled interface
column53: and consumers have increasingly high expectations for this requirement
column54: beyond simple commands or skills
column55: said Mohajer.He may be right because of the $115 million raised in its 10-year long life

column57: Samsung's Catalyst Fund
column58: Nomura Holdings

column60: Recruit Holdings' RSI Fund
column61: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers

column63: Walden Venture Capital and Translink Capital Partners participated for a second time.The reason the investment is significant at this juncture is SoundHound's voice interface technology called Houndify that will now be empowered to reach more users. Houndify was incorporated into more than 500 products within the first 12 months of launch.Its popularity in the past and why companies like Samsung and NVIDIA are interested in it right now is simple. The technology is not designed to take over the device or transfer data to SoundHound unlike platforms like Alexa and Google Home. So its proliferation will let device makers employ the technology and also retain user data. Houndify already has 20K developers working on the platform and this number could expand rapidly with the cash infusion. Houndify already hasSumming UpInteraction with machines is set to become more interesting than ever before as they gradually understand our needs to get things done the way we want it even before we tell them to or perhaps right after. Since this is a nascent market

And I think you really see that when you look at   average selling price. That grew to $695 in the most recent   quarter

column31: the units and average selling   price

column2: Inc. iPhone Sales in China Reportedly Fell 18% Last Year;2/9/2017;"China has been the world's largest smartphone market for a few   years now
column3: underscoring how important the region is forApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) . But the Mac maker has hit a speed bump in the   Middle Kingdom in recent quarters
column4: largely due to intensifying   competition from local
column5: low-cost manufacturers. The company   occasionally mentions growth rates for various geographical   markets
column6: but doesn't disclose unit sales by region in detail.   That leaves investors having to rely on third-party estimates
column7: and the most recent ones don't look good.We're No. 5! We're No. 5!Market researcherCanalysreleased its estimates today for the Chinese smartphone market in   2016. Total unit volumes in China hit a fresh high of 476.5   million handsets
column8: up 11%. Of that total
column9: roughly 131.6 million   units were shipped in the fourth quarter
column10: a quarterly record that   represents a third of the global market. The top four brands were   all Chinese manufacturers; Apple came in at No. 5 amid declining   unit volumes.ManufacturermakeArticleAd();2016 UnitsHuawei76.2 millionOppo73.2 millionVivo63.2 millionXiaomi51.4 millionApple43.8 millionData source: Canalys.Both Xiaomi and Apple saw double-digit declines from 2015   levels
column11: with Xiaomi's units falling 21% and Apple's units down   18%. Oppo and Vivo exploded onto the scene in 2016; both   companies sold fewer than 40 million units in 2015. Huawei   strengthened its position in the tier-one and tier-two cities
column12: according to Canalys analyst Jessie Ding. Oppo and Vivo are now   looking to target those regions
column13: while Huawei moves in on   tier-three and tier-four cities.iPhone 7 with AirPods. Image source: Apple.While Apple has never aspired to be the largest vendor in any   market by volumes
column14: instead focusing on other things like customer   satisfaction and profitability
column15: that's still a discouraging   directional trend at a time when Apple has been trying to   reinvigorate investor confidence. The iPhone maker's decline in   China is also significantly worse than its worldwide volumes;   iPhone units fell 7% in 2016 to 215.4 million. If we look at it   in absolute units
column16: Canalys' numbers suggest that Apple sold 9.7   million less units in China in 2016
column17: which is a large proportion   of the 16.1 million unit decline in total iPhone units. China is   becoming an increasingly tough market
column18: and it's weighing on   results.""A very
column19: very difficult market""Last quarter
column20: Greater China was the only geographical segment   of Apple's five reportable segments that did not hit record   levels.Data source: SEC filings. Chart by author. Calendar quarters     shown.Apple's Greater China segment includes Hong Kong
column21: China
column22: and   Taiwan. The weakness appears to be coming from Hong Kong and   Taiwan
column23: and revenue in mainland China was roughly flat with the   record levels from a year ago. Here's CEO Tim Cook on the   call:If you look at how we did in the quarter
column24: as I think Luca     shared
column25: our Greater China revenue was down 12% and about 4     points of that was currency related. So it's an 8-point decline     in constant currency. And then within Greater China if you look     at the [People's Republic of China]
column26: our revenue was flat year     over year
column27: and that was against the all-time record     quarter.Cook also conceded that Hong Kong ""remains a very

column1: Thursday Apple Rumors: iPhone 8 May Cost Over $1
column2: 000;2/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of a possible price for the iPhone 8. Today
column4: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Thursday.makeArticleAd();iPhone 8 Price:A new rumor claims that Apple's iPhone 8 may cost more than $1
column6: reportsMacRumors. According to this rumor
column7: the tech company is planning to introduce several new features to the redesigned device. Features that the company may include are an OLED display
column8: wireless charging
column9: the lack of a physical Home button
column10: 3D sensing technology and more memory. If these rumors hold true
column11: then it isn't hard to see how the device will surpass the $1
column12: 000 price point. The iPhone 7 Plus with 256GB of memory costs $969 in the United States. This rumor comes from sources that are close to AAPL's plans.2017 iPhone Charging:A recent rumor claims that Apple will introduce wireless charging to all three 2017 iPhone devices
column13: 9to5Macnotes. This rumor comes from KGI analysts Ming Chi Kuo. Previous reports have claimed that only the premium 2017 iPhone
column14: which may be the iPhone 8
column15: will offer wireless charging. This rumor also claims that the premium iPhone coming out this year will feature an OLED display and a 3D Touch sensor. Kuo claims that the premium device will require an extra layer of graphite to protect the 3D Touch sensor from heat caused by the wireless charging component.Beats X Deal:Apple is offering a special deal to customers that purchase its new Beats X earbuds
column16: reportsAppleInsider. Customers that pick up the new earbuds will also get a free three-month subscription to Apple Music. This news comes from an early unboxing video of the earbuds. The offer may be an apology from the tech company for having to delay the earbuds. The earbuds were originally going to come out months ago.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postThursday Apple Rumors: iPhone 8 May Cost Over $1
column17: 000appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: How Universal Display Corp. Gained 17% in January;2/9/2017;"What happenedShares ofUniversal Display(NASDAQ: OLED) rose 17.2% in January 2017
column2: according to data from S&P Global Market Intelligence.So whatThe big driver of Universal Display's January gains came from   Chinese electronics manufacturing giantFoxconn. The company publicly ""mulled"" a $7 billion investment in a   U.S.-based manufacturing facility
column3: equipped to provideApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) with high-quality smartphone and tablet   screens.The U.S. factory plan dovetailed nicely with rumors that the   next few generations of Apple iPhones might ship with OLED   screens. Furthermore
column4: Foxconn recently acquired screen maker Sharpfor a cool $5.1 billion
column5: and that company had already dipped its   toes into OLED waters before joining the Foxconn mother ship.makeArticleAd();Put all the pieces together
column6: and it starts to look as if Apple   and Foxconn might want to order quite a bit of OLED equipment and   materials in the reasonably near future. Universal Display shares   gained more than 12% in three days
column7: based on this collection of   circumstantial evidence.Image source: Universal Display.Now whatThe American Foxconn factory is still an unconfirmed rumor
column8: and we certainly don't know for sure how Foxconn might use such a   facility. However
column9: the volume of harmonizing rumors has   increased. This week
column10: aReuters reportreaffirmed that Sharp is taking the lead on Foxconn's $7 billion   factory-building plans in America
column11: citing unnamed insider   sources.So the Apple rumors remain neither confirmed nor debunked
column12: but   the sheer weight of similar third-party reports is making the   whole thing sound plausible. And if that wasn't enough
column13: Universal   Display just announced a $15 million investment to double   materials manufacturing partnerPPG's(NYSE: PPG) OLED emitter capacity over the next three   quarters.Next up
column14: Universal Display is slated to report fourth-quarter   results on Feb. 23.10 stocks we like better than Universal DisplayWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column15: it can pay to listen. After all
column16: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column17: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column18: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Universal Display wasn't   one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even   better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column19: 2017Anders Bylundowns shares of Universal Display. The Motley Fool owns shares     of and recommends Apple and Universal Display. The Motley Fool     has the following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple     and short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley Fool has     adisclosure policy."

column1: Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is More Valuable Than You Think;2/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAs I write this
column3: Amazon.com
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) stock trades at about $824 per share. For 2017
column5: analyst consensus estimates are that AMZN stock will earn $7.25 per share for the full year. That gives Amazon stock an astronomical forward price-to-earnings ratio of nearly 62x. In comparison
column6: theS&P 500as a whole trades at about 17x next year's earnings.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockIn other words
column7: AMZN stock trades at a multiplenearly six timesthat of the average large-cap U.S. stock.Of course
column8: this isn't a new phenomenon: For years
column9: investors have considered Amazon stock overvalued based on a P/E ratio that has often been in the triple digits - and
column10: not all that long ago
column11: negative.Yet AMZN stock seems to defy gravity: Shares are up 50% over the past year
column12: 110% over the past three years and a stunning 340% over the past five years. The reason is that Amazon isn't a stock that should be valued solely on next year's earnings
column13: or the price investors are paying for those earnings. That's not because the market is crazy when it comes to AMZN stock and it's not because the fundamentals ""don't matter"". It's because Amazon is investing now for growth later - and that's exactly what itshouldbe doing.AMZN's Earnings Aren't the Only ThingIt's tempting to think that a stock with a lower P/E ratio is by definition ""cheaper"" than other stocks. Why would an investor pay 50x
column14: or 100x
column15: a year's earnings when he or she could pay 15x
column16: or 10x? Growth certainly matters.7 Tech Stocks That Are Bucking the DowntrendIntuitively
column17: an investor understands that 18x earnings for a bad business isn't obviously better than
column18: say
column19: 22x earnings for a good business. In fact
column20: it may be worse. But the P/E ratio for Amazon stock seems ridiculous on its face. AMZN is already the biggest retailer in the world; is it really going to show so much growth that it's worth paying a 100x P/E? It would have to grow its profits by a factor of five just to get the multiple to 20x
column21: which doesn't sound cheap itself.However
column22: that type of analysis is generally too simplistic. A stock is valued based on the sum ofallits future cash flows - not just next year's. That's true for AMZN stock
column23: and it's true forMacy's Inc(NYSE:M) stock as well.The fact that AMZN trades at 62x 2017 earnings and M trades at 10x doesn't
column24: in and of itself
column25: prove anything. It seems almost certain that the earnings and cash flow attributed to AMZN stock will continue to rise; it seems highly likely that Macy's earnings will
column26: in contrast
column27: fall. The rates at which those earnings rise or decline matters
column28: of course
column29: and those rates inform how investors value AMZN stock or M stock.But whether a stock is valued at 100x P/E or 3x P/E
column30: investors need to take a long-term outlook. And while it may not appear like it at first glance
column31: that's exactly what many AMZN stock holders are doing.The Two Ways For Amazon Stock to Grow EarningsEven those investors who are mostly bearish on Amazon stock would likely admit that Amazon's earnings will continue to grow going forward. But the bearish argument - one that has been made for the better part of a decade - is that it's almost impossible for AMZN earnings to growthat much. After all
column32: as a company gets bigger
column33: its growth rate fades
column34: simply due to its size. (SeeApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) for a perfect example.)At some point
column35: the optimism that keeps Amazon stock at nosebleed levels will fade - and AMZN stock will come back to Earth.But that argument assumes that Amazon is at nosebleed levels
column36: which may not be the case. The heavy-handed P/E ratio sounds highly stretched; however
column37: according to AMZN's most recent 10-Q
column38: it generated $8.6 billion in free cash flow over the last four quarters. That implies a sub-50x multiple to free cash flow ona trailing basis -a slightly less intimidating multiple. And the focus on P/E ratio also ignores that there are two ways for Amazon to grow earnings.The first is the standard way that companies grow earnings: higher sales and better margins. There's little reason
column39: barring an economic recession
column40: to see AMZN's sales declining. Even then
column41: increased market share could allow Amazon to post revenue growth
column42: if not at the 29% pace seen through the first three quarters of 2016.There's also reason to see AMZN's margins expand considerably. Somewhat incredibly
column43: on a GAAP basis
column44: Amazon's operating margin year-to-date is just 3.2%. Yet the company has built out an incredible distribution platform and it has invested billions of dollars in its Amazon Web Services business. Incremental sales thus should boost margins considerably; it takes very little in the way of investment to sell a few more items
column45: or add another cloud customer.3 Reasons Amazon.com
column46: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is STILL the KingAMZN still has years of benefits from the scale it has built out
column47: and those benefits will continue to expand margins for some time
column48: allowing for steady
column49: and even explosive earnings and cash flow growth.The second issue relative to current and 2017 earnings is that Amazon isn't currently maximizing its profits. Rather
column50: it is spending - sometimes wildly - on a variety of initiatives
column51: offering everything from restaurant delivery to photo printing to Prime Video and Prime Music subscriptions.Some of those efforts will work; many likely will fail. But looking at 2016 and 2017 earnings and not considering the impact of that spending is as short-term as buying AMZN stock in 2017 simply because it rose in 2016. Amazon's operating expenses are on pace to increase almost $10 billion year-over-year in 2016. A good chunk of that is coming from hiring employees
column52: marketing the new businesses and creating the distribution platforms for various projects.Assume
column53: then
column54: that AMZN decided to focus on near-term earnings
column55: instead of investing now for the future. Simply limiting that increase to $5 billion would come close todoublingAmazon's earnings and cash flow next year. Ignoring that new spend ignores the 'true' earnings power of AMZN stock.Bottom Line on AMZN Stock: It's ComplicatedThis is not to say that Amazon stock is necessarily a buy. As a value investor myself
column56: I still question the valuation of AMZN stock in my own way. But simply checking the P/E ratio for AMZN - or any other stock - is too simplistic. Trying to value Amazon stock is a messy
column57: difficult
column58: detailed endeavor. The Amazon Web Services business is vastly different from the price-sensitive
column59: low-margin
column60: online retail business. It's not clear how much AMZN is spending on its new projects
column61: and how much it could save.It's complicated. But so is investing the right way. And simply ignoring - or shorting - Amazon stock because of its P/E ratio isn't the right way to do it. There are reasons to be optimistic
column62: and pessimistic
column63: toward AMZN stock
column64: but those reasons go well beyond a single number.As of this writing
column65: Vince Martin did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's PenThe postAmazon.com Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is More Valuable Than You Thinkappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: A Win-Win Trade for Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Bulls;2/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) is looking better and better both off and on the AAPL price chart. But following a massive rally
column3: a well-positioned bull put spread trumps buying Apple stock near-term.makeArticleAd();Source:Yuanbin Du Via FlickrIt has been almost exactly one month since I penned some bullish analysis on AAPL onJan. 10. At the time
column4: there were plenty of potential headwinds for Apple stock. And to be honest
column5: many of those factors
column6: ranging from trade
column7: to China
column8: to a successful transition as asoftware company
column9: could still present issues for Apple.Nevertheless
column10: I didn't mind throwing caution to the wind given a dose of contrarianism
column11: a decent Apple stock chart and firm control on risk using an April bull call spread. And I'm glad I did
column12: as Apple stock has gone on to make its investors very happy and in more than one way.Back on Jan. 31
column13: Apple managed to delight Wall Street by not only beating top- and bottom-line views
column14: but also in the quality or tire-kicking aspect of the results. There were typical highlights
column15: such as $18 billion in profits for the quarter
column16: 78.3 million iPhones sold and a record cash hoard of $246 billion
column17: whose size is simply amazing. But this report was also much more than that for Apple stock.The companyshowed a return to growthspearheaded by executing with its increasingly important Services business that includes the App Store
column18: iCloud
column19: iTunes and Apple Music.7 High-Risk
column20: High-Reward Stocks to Buy NowApple also dropped hints of a major media acquisition
column21: expanding AAPL's reach into smart homes
column22: and
column23: somewhere in the dazzling dog-and-pony show
column24: the buzz  over this year's forthcoming iPhone 8 iteration.Another way the company has made its investors very happy of late has been on the Apple stock chart.Apple Stock Weekly ChartA month ago
column25: I discussed a bullish cup-and-handle pattern which had just cleared the 62% retracement level as Apple stock broke out on its daily price graph. The area is highlighted in yellow on the provided weekly stock chart of AAPL.Now
column26: with shares up about 11% and focused on the larger time frame
column27: a similar but more substantial corrective cup formation has emerged since Apple stock hit its all-time high in 2015.Looking forward
column28: there's nothing to stop Apple stock from breaking out of the cup -pattern and essentially forgoing the development of a handle consolidation on the AAPL chart. But we're inclined to think that's not going to happen.In our view
column29: an overbought stochastic and lack of an immediate catalyst for AAPL shares following a strong run will likely lead to a failed attempt at breaking out or simply a bit of price consolidation to neutralize conditions before a successful move into higher ground.AAPL Stock Bullish StrategyLooking at the Apple stock options board and given the discussed view
column30: the Weeklys 3 March $129/$126 bull put spread is interesting.Priced for 50 cents
column31: the seller of this put spread is able to collect the full credit as long as AAPL is above $129 at expiration three weeks from now. The margin of safety or downside buffer is roughly 2.3% with Apple stock trading near $132.05.If AAPL shares are above $129 at expiration
column32: the collected credit amounts to a non-annualized return of 20%.In the event Apple stock falls and the vertical goes in-the-money
column33: the trader can begin accumulating stock for no worse than a price of $128.50. Even better
column34: the trader could possibly get a much lower effective purchase price if AAPL tanked through the spread.For instance
column35: if AAPL were to fill the daily chart earnings gap and trade down to $121.50 in the next three weeks
column36: through either assignment or closing the spread and simultaneously buying stock; the trader is at worst
column37: out $2.50 or roughly 2% of Apple's share price.Ride the Energy Select Sector SPDR (ETF) (XLE) Higher With This TradeFactoring in the loss
column38: if this trader wished to buy AAPL on the extreme weakness
column39: the initial purchase price would net out to $124 ($121.50 AAPL + $2.50 vertical loss). That compares favorably to a trader purchasing AAPL today for $132 and a position that would be out 8.5% on paper.Bottom line
column40: with income potential and the opportunity to purchase Apple stock with a margin of safety that includes stronger value and limited risk
column41: this bullish AAPL put spread makes for a solid alternative to simply buying shares right now.Investment accounts under Christopher Tyler's management do not currently own positions in any of the securities or their derivatives mentioned in this article. The information offered is based upon Christopher Tyler's observations and strictly intended for educational purposes only; the use of which is the responsibility of the individual. For additional market insights and related musings

column1: 1 More Sign That Apple Inc.’s New MacBook Pro Computers Are a Huge Hit;2/9/2017;"Back in October of 2016
column2: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) released much-needed refreshes of its MacBook Pro   product line. Thanks to the launch of these new systems
column3: Apple   broke the long losing streak that its Mac business had been   seeing
column4: andreported1.1% year-over-year Mac unit growth
column5: as well as roughly 7% Mac   revenue growth in its most recent quarter
column6: implying a boost in   Mac average selling prices.Although the numbers clearly speak for themselves
column7: there's one   more bit of information that Apple disclosed on its most recent   earnings call that points to positive customer reception of the   company's new MacBook Pro systems.Apple's newest MacBook Pro. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Supply constraints curbed growthApple CEO Tim Cook said that that Apple was ""supply   constrained for the new MacBook Pro throughout the December   quarter and is just now coming into supply/demand balance"" for   the systems.Additionally
column8: CFO Luca Maestri offered some commentary about   the company's Mac channel inventory dynamics
column9: saying that the   company ""ended the quarter at the low end of [Apple's] four to   five week target range for Mac channel inventory.""Apple sells many different Mac products besides the MacBook   Pro with Touch Bar -- including the older discounted MacBook Pro   models
column10: MacBook Air
column11: 12-inch MacBook
column12: and iMac -- so even though   Apple apparently ended the quarter within its target channel   inventory range
column13: channel inventory levels of the new MacBook Pro   systems may have been at lower levels.What's next for the Mac?Apple has a reasonable shot of continuing to outperform the   broader personal computer market again
column14: especially if it gets   back to putting out new/refreshed systems at a regular pace.Next up
column15: I expect Apple to refresh its desktop systems. The   ones that Apple currently has for sale are now a generation   behind in processor technology
column16: so at the very least
column17: the company   ought to offer models with the latest chips.The performance boost from the new chips won't be   earth-shattering -- generation-on-generation improvements in   personal-computer performance are hardly dramatic these days --   but it's easier to market systems with the latest processors than   it is to try to market ones with previous-generation processors
column18: especially when the competition has moved to the newer ones.I also expect Apple to refresh the 12-inch MacBook system   soon. The current models use older processors
column19: so at the very   least
column20: a processor upgrade is in order. Once again
column21: this is not   the sort of thing that's going to be fundamentally game changing
column22: but a better
column23: faster system should be easier to sell.After those systems are updated
column24: I expect Apple to go back and   update the MacBook Pro lineup again. I don't expect significant   changes like the ones the company brought with the ones launched   back in October 2016
column25: but improved processor technology
column26: and   perhaps a larger battery
column27: could make for a ""good enough""   upgrade.Apple doesn't need to deliver ""revolutionary"" Mac products to   the market to do reasonably well -- the company's brand power
column28: its reputation for excellent customer support
column29: and perhaps even   the strength of macOS relative to Windows
column30: to some potential   buyers should be enough to allow the company to at least perform   with the market
column31: if not steadily gain share.However
column32: as we saw in the last year
column33: if Apple doesn't   regularly refresh its product line
column34: keeping it stale in an   already muted personal-computer market
column35: then there will be less   incentive for current Mac owners to upgrade
column36: and it will become   harder to convince Windows users to switch over.For the sake of Apple's Mac business
column37: let's hope that the   company has plans for annual product refreshes to keep things   interesting.Offer from the Motley Fool: The 10 best stocks to buy       nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent     more than a decade beating the market. In fact
column38: the newsletter     they run
column39: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column40: has tripled the S&P 500!*Tom and David just revealed their ten top stock picks for     investors to buy right now.Click here to get access to the full       list!*Stock Advisor returns as of 1/30/2017Ashraf Eassahas no position in any stocks mentioned. column1: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Finally Fires Back at Apple With Android Wear 2.0;2/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAfter delaying the release for months
column3: Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column4: NASDAQ:GOOGL) finally launched Android Wear 2.0
column5: the new version of its smartwatch operating system. Along with the new OS
column6: which incorporates advanced features like Google Assistant
column7: new Google smartwatch hardware was announced. Made in partnership withLG
column8: the new devices are premium quality
column9: made to take full advantage of Android Wear 2.0 and ready to take on the Apple Watch.makeArticleAd();Source: GoogleHere's what you need to know.Google knows it didn't exactly hit the ball out of the park when it first released its Android Wear smartwatch OS.Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) has dominated the smartwatch market since its release and despite an overall cooling for smartwatches in general
column10: it looks as thoughApple Watch absolutely destroyed the competition over Christmas.That has to be especially galling to Google
column11: considering the Apple Watch is only compatible with iPhones
column12: while Android Wear smartwatches work with nearly 90% of the smartphones being sold today. And while Apple Watch remains locked into a clunky square watch face
column13: Android Wear supports the traditional
column14: round wristwatch look.Android Wear 2.0 Key FeaturesGoogle was originally supposed to release Android Wear 2.0 last September
column15: but decided todelay it to this spring. Theofficial announcementlanded yesterday afternoon on GOOGL's blog.7 Tech Stocks That Are Bucking the DowntrendWhat did Google engineers spend the extra time working on? It appears that they had several major goals: improving on the basic features most smartwatch owners use (such as fitness tracking)
column16: cutting the cord to a smartphone with LTE support
column17: and making Android Wear 2.0 smartwatches as compatible as possible with the iPhone.Key features Google is showing off include:Improved fitness tracking with Google Fit appLTE support for running apps and making voice calls directly from a smartwatch without requiring connection to a smartphoneGoogle Assistant is integratedCustomizable watch face componentsGoogle Play access direct from smartwatchSupport for hardware control similar to Apple Watch digital crownIn particular
column18: the ability for more apps to run independently on Android Wear 2.0 devices - with no need to be connected to a smartwatch - means iPhone users will get almost the same experience as Android phone owners. Assuming GOOGL can convince them to skip the Apple Watch.New Google Smartwatch Is From LGRumors had been flying that alongside the new operating system
column19: the first Google smartwatch would make an appearance. That made sense considering GOOGL's push into branded hardware with the Google Pixel Phone and devices like Google Home and Google WiFi.Xiaomi Was Going to Rival Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock -- What Happened?However
column20: the two new smartwatches unveiled as part of the announcement are from LG
column21: in collaboration with GOOGL.The LG Watch Style is a relatively basic model. It lacks advanced capabilities like GPS (or even a heart rate monitor)
column22: but delivers smartwatch features in a slim
column23: traditional wristwatch form factor. The round display is a 1.2-inch OLED screen at 360 x 360 pixel resolution and the watch has all-day battery life. It comes with a leather strap and for an extra $30
column24: a Rose Gold color option.The LG Watch Style is the bigger and more capable device
column25: fully able to take full advantage of all Android Wear 2.0's new features. The 1.38-inch P-OLED display has a crisp 480 x 480 pixel resolution. The round frame is stainless steel
column26: with IP68 water resistance. There's a heart rate monitor and GPS for fitness
column27: Connectivity includes Bluetooth
column28: Wi-Fi
column29: LTE and NFC for Android Pay. Battery life is rated for all-day
column30: but use of features like LTE and the heart rate monitor can significantly cut that.They're premium devices
column31: designed to take on the Apple Watch and GOOGL's involvement means they make the most of Android Wear 2.0. But they aren't the official Google smartwatch … well see if that comes later.Availability and PricingGoogle says Android Wear 2.0 will begin rolling out ""in the coming weeks."" Most current Android Wear smartwatches should be eligible for the free update
column32: but not all watches will support all features. The LG Watch Style and LG Watch Sport will retail for $249 and $349 respectively and will go on sale in the U.S. starting Feb. 10.As of this writing
column33: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceApple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Has a New Hero: Services!Is Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Ending the Age of Intel (INTC)?The postAlphabet Inc (GOOGL) Finally Fires Back at Apple With Android Wear 2.0appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Why Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Target Was Upped Again;2/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(AAPL) stock enjoyed healthy gains in the days following the company's earnings reports
column3: and analystscrooned over the results.makeArticleAd();But not everyone was so thrilled
column4: with some pointing out the fact that the December quarter had an extra week and others focusing on the challenges being seen in the smartphone market.Nonetheless
column5: analysts are as happy as can be and continue to try to sell investors on the iPhone 8 cycle. At least one analyst has boosted his price target for AAPL stock based on the record iPhone unit number in the December quarter.AAPL Stock Target: $154 Per ShareCanaccord Genuityanalyst T. Michael Walkley raised his price target for Apple stock by more than $10 per share
column6: from $142 to $154 per share in a research note dated Feb. 6. He feels the company took a ""strong share"" of the premium end of the world's smartphone market during the December quarter
column7: as it generated 92% of profits.That is a decline from 106% of the profits in the September quarter
column8: however
column9: becauseSAMSUNG ELECTRONIC's (SSNLF) profits improved after the Galaxy Note 7 recall.Apple sold 78.3 million iPhones with an average selling price of $695 during its first fiscal quarter as consumers preferred the more expensive iPhone 7 Plus models. Walkley also believes the iPhone maker benefited from the Note 7 recall-although there was some debate about that before the results were released. Apple management said the quarter had the highest quarterly number of switchers from Android
column10: something that third-party data indicated just before the release.The analyst also expects the iPhone 7 lineup to continue doing well
column11: bridging the gap until the iPhone 8 is released
column12: probably in September.Despite Walkley's (and almost everyone else's) enthusiasm about Apple stock
column13: Neil George
column14: a contributor forThe Street
column15: feels investors are doing nothing more but attending the ""church of Apple.""Here's How Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Can Hit $200InvestorsdumpedAmazon.con
column16: Inc.(AMZN) stock immediately following the retailer's earnings results (although the shares are up today)
column17: but they have been happily slurping up Apple stock.He said the iPhone maker ""is faced with a dwindling market share and shrinking margins
column18: which means it just doesn't make sense to be so enamored with the company.Meanwhile
column19: Amazon recorded soaring revenues and the seventh consecutive profitable quarter. There's also new data from Slice Intelligence indicating that the company hoards 53% of all growth in U.S. online sales.Did Apple Take Investors For a Ride?George argues that Apple ""pulled off a sleight of hand"" by adding the extra week in the December quarter-an argument also made by Thomas H. Kee Jr. onMarketWatch. According to Kee
column20: to make up for that extra week
column21: the company would have had to report about $3.53 per share in earnings rather than the $3.38 per share it reported.He also estimates that revenue should have been about $81 billion rather than the $78.4 billion that was reported. Based on his weekly calculations
column22: the company grew at a 4.11% slower rate in the most recent December quarter than it did in the same quarter in 2015. Kee argued that Apple's growth rate contracted rather than grew in the most recently completed quarter and that it only looks like it did because of that extra week.George highlighted other ""problems"" he sees at Apple as well
column23: like the contracted gross margin
column24: which fell to 38.5% from 40.1% in the year-ago period. The iPhone maker also saw its sales in China
column25: the world's biggest market
column26: fall 12% in the December quarter
column27: reducing its market share there to 9.6%. He said the company's global market share has fallen as well
column28: down to 11.5%.Apple  is widely expected to launch the tenth anniversary edition of its smartphone under the iPhone 8 moniker
column29: and most firms have been calling this cycle a ""supercycle"" because they're expecting tremendous growth.However
column30: one analyst that's been calling for a supercycle is starting to back off from that theory and suggests now that the next cycle will be one of ""smooth"" growth rather than anything of the ""super"" variety.7 Tech Stocks With Explosive Growth PotentialUBSanalyst Steven Milunovich said in a research note dated Feb. 7 that he's now ""smoothing"" out his assumptions for iPhone growth over the next couple of years and adopting ""less of asupercycleview"" for fiscal 2018."" He noted that it should be expected for product cycles in a maturing market to become muted
column31: so he's cutting his iPhone unit growth estimate from 16% to 12% for fiscal 2018 and boosting his fiscal 2019 estimate from a 2% decline to a 7% increase.Despite this smoothing out
column32: he's still expecting the iPhone 8 cycle to bring greater growth than the fiscal 2019 cycle.He feels that it could be more beneficial for Apple stock's multiple if the company experiences more gradual growth because investors might be encouraged to see the company's hardware and services revenue combined as an annuity.Shares of AAPLstock rose by as much as 0.19% to $131.78 during regular trading hours on Wednesday and are trading slightly higher in early morning trading Thursday.The postApple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Target Upped By Another Firm For Earningsappeared first onValueWalk.Many academics claim investing is a ""random walk."" We believe this to be only partially true. It is our core belief that value investing can outperform the market
column33: hence the name ""ValueWalk."" (AAPL) Stock Target Was Upped Againappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Should Clobber Q4 Earnings
column2: But …;2/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsChip firmNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) plans to release its fourth-quarter and full-year results to the investment community after the bell on Thursday
column4: Feb. 9. In full disclosure
column5: I've been slow to warm to Nvidia's investment appeal
column6: and in the meantime
column7: NVDA stock has nearly tripled.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThe key to the forthcoming earnings release will be growth - just like it is for any company. So far
column8: the earnings momentum and increases in analyst projections suggest Nvidia's prospects are bright.But will NVDA stock holders have to tolerate some bumps along the way?Nvidia Earnings ExpectationsIn mylast updateon Nvidia in early December
column9: I suggested keeping an eye on earnings trends. At that time
column10: full-year earnings estimates (the average of the earnings all analysts covering the name expect the company to report) had jumped nearly 32% - from $1.84 to $2.42 per share. It's a key reason NVDA stock has rallied so strongly.The current full-year estimate for Nvidia earnings (according to Yahoo Finance) is $2.41 per share. It relays that 19 analysts have provided estimates. That's about flat over the past 60 days
column11: but actually down slightly from the $2.45 projected 30 days ago.But really
column12: this is splitting hairs. It's very likely NVDA reports a solid quarter in terms of bottom-line growth.7 High-Risk
column13: High-Reward Stocks to Buy NowAnd sales growth is projected to bestellar. Analysts expect at least a 36% annual bump to $6.84 billion. Next year
column14: top-line growth is projected to slow to 16% for full-year sales of nearly $8 billion; 2018 profits are currently pegged at $2.71 per share.The Business Case for NVDA StockWith a current share price of $117.40
column15: the forward price-to-earnings ratio on NVDA stock sits right below 50. That's a rather lofty multiple
column16: and it essentially means that Nvidiamustgrow rapidly. Otherwise
column17: that quickly surging share price could take a similarly speedy tumble.Fortunately
column18: Nvidia operates in some of the most exciting growth areas for semiconductors. The company is best-known for graphic chips
column19: and in particular its graphic processing units
column20: or GPUs. The company boasts it is the ""world leader"" in visual computing. This looks accurate - a recentBarron'sarticlepegged its GPU market share at 68%. This is one of the most compelling spaces in the semiconductor industry.Nvidia's chips are an integral component in the ecosystems that are pioneering growth in virtual reality
column21: cloud computing
column22: machine learning
column23: and self-driving cars. These are some hugely disruptive industries that could end up revolutionizing many facets of the gaming
column24: computing
column25: and automotive industries.The company's gaming business is the largest operating unit and growing 30% per year on average since 2013. Its data center business (to support cloud computing) is expanding at a more rapid clip - 40% annually. And automotive is skyrocketing 75% annually
column26: though from a very small initial base.In some respects
column27: and provided you are comfortable with the lofty valuation
column28: Nvidia is a very compelling way for broad exposure to multiple disruptive industries.NVDA adds exposure to the cloud-computing excitement that is creating a buzz at giant tech firms includingAmazon.com
column29: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)
column30: Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) andAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL).Tesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) is in the pole position in the autonomous automobile charge. The Nvidia Drive PX 2 computing platform currently powers the Tesla auto models that already have self-driving capabilities.The CompetitionMore direct competitors includeIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) andAdvanced Micro Devices
column31: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMD)
column32: both of which are looking to grow in these newer markets. Both key rivals are also likely to benefit from GPUs used to power gaming systems
column33: machine learning
column34: and servers used for cloud computing.Intel is somewhat hamstrung from its dominant market share in personal computing. Its 80% market share to power personal computers and related devices has literally resulted in hundreds of billions of dollars in cash flow over the past several decades. This gives it unmatched rivalry to invest in new technology and keep a leadership position over chip competitors. But computing is mature and barely expanding.Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Socks the Shorts With the Model 3AMD had been thought to have lost its way. Years of mismanagement allowed Intel to expand on its dominance and nearly put AMD out of business. But new management appears to have reinvigorated AMD
column35: and investors are starting to believe it can also benefit from the same markets Nvidia is pursuing.Bottom Line on NVDA StockIn arecent interview
column36: market strategist Ed Yardeni pegged semiconductor stocks as one of his favorite industries for 2017. In his words
column37: ""we're talking about major secular disruptions in autos
column38: consumer electronics
column39: and gaming."" Chips that power data warehouses to serve the rise in cloud computing represent yet another market for these firms.NVDA stock is an investor's best bet to gain exposure to these markets. The rub
column40: of course
column41: is its valuation already reflects many more years of rapid growth.AMD is an interesting turnaround play
column42: though with its current low levels of profitability
column43: the trading multiples are also lofty. Intel is a much safer bet in the microchip space. Its forward P/E is below 15
column44: and there is a modest dividend yield of 2.86% that should grow over time.I suggest taking a wait-and-see approach to Nvidia earnings. The fourth quarter is likely to impress
column45: but given the lofty valuation
column46: any hiccup in the expectations could result in a fair amount of share price volatility.As of this writing
column47: Ryan Fuhrmann did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceGo Long Bank of America Corp (BAC) Stock For FreeReport: Apple Inc. iPhone 8 Could Cost More Than $1

column1: Apple
column2: Inc.'s Stock's 40% Comeback -- What Investors Should Know;2/9/2017;"Over the past 12 months
column3: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) stock has absolutely trounced the S&P 500
column4: surging 40.4%
column5: from just under $95 per share to about $132 at the   time of this writing. This rise compares with the S&P 500's   22% gain during the same period. Interestingly
column6: the performance   of Apple's business during this period hasn't been particularly   impressive. So
column7: what drove the stock higher?Boring resultsIn Apple's most recently reported trailing-12-month period
column8: results actually look quite dismal. During this period
column9: revenue   fell 7% and earnings per share tumbled an even steeper 11.3%. YetApple stocksurged higher.Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Sure
column10: Apple's financial results have turned upward recently
column11: with the tech giant reporting 3.3% and 9.6% year-over-year   increases in revenue and EPS for the company's most recently   reported quarter. But this is just one quarter. Further
column12: these   aren't the sort of results often associated with 40% rises in a   stock price -- especially when referring to a popular tech   company.But despite Apple's lackluster performance in the past 12   months
column13: shares have climbed higher and easily outperformed the   market.Valuation mattersSo if Apple's business saw both revenue and EPS decline in the   past 12 reported months
column14: why are shares trading higher? While   investors could come up with a range of reasons
column15: one catalyst for   the stock during this period likely stands out the most: Apple   stock was undervalued.AAPL PE Ratio (TTM)data byYChartsOne year ago
column16: Apple stock had a mind-boggling low   price-to-earnings ratio of just 10. For context
column17: the average P/E   of stocks in the S&P 500 at the time was 21.4
column18: more than   double Apple's. Combining this dirt-cheap valuation with Apple's   dividend
column19: its sizable repurchase program
column20: and the company's long   history of successful products
column21: itwas clearthat the Street had oversold Apple stock as the market worried   about the company's ability to continue growing its business.Sure
column22: Apple's stock probably didn't justify the same 20 P/E   its peers in the S&P 500 averaged
column23: but the stockalmost certainlydidn'tdeserveto trade at a P/E of 10.What's next for Apple stock?Going forward
column24: can Apple stock continue soaring? While Apple's   higher price-to-earnings ratio today of nearly 16 does a better   job of pricing in a more optimistic outlook for the company
column25: investors should keep in mind that the stock's 40% rise during   the past 12 months doesn't automatically make Apple stock   expensive today. Indeed
column26: the stock is arguably still a buy.For Apple to live up to its valuation today
column27: the company will   need to return to more consistent revenue growth and maintain   pricing power -- two outcomes that shouldn't be a problem for the   company. Yes
column28: revenue and EPS are down in the trailing 12 months
column29: but Apple'sreturn to growthrecently
column30: it'sfast-growing services segment
column31: andconsistently strong pricing power
column32: all point to a bright future for Apple's business -- and a   bright future for the underlying business when a stock is trading   at just 16 times earnings likely means the stock will perform   well
column33: too.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column34: it can pay to listen. After all
column35: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade

column1: Why the Stock Market Under Trump Will Probably Lag the Market Under Obama;2/9/2017;"President Donald Trump's @POTUS Twitter feed sounded off in   celebration on Jan. 25 when theDow Jones Industrial Averagereached 20
column2: 000 for the first time ever
column3: just five days   after his inauguration:Great!#Dow20Khttps://t.co/wXFhXBLgag-- President Trump (@POTUS)January 25
column4: 2017In her own Tweet
column5: former campaign manager and now presidential   advisor Kellyanne Conway credited ""The Trump Effect.""makeArticleAd();The administration was right to celebrate what has been a very   bullish market rally following the election results on Nov. 8.   The market reacted bearishly to the unexpected results on   election night
column6: but ever since then
column7: it's been on the rise.However
column8: the Dow's 9%-plus rise since Election Day is just a   fraction of how much the stock market rose during President   Obama's eight-year tenure. It's very early in the Trump   administration
column9: but can we predict whether the market will   perform better or worse under President Trump than under   President Obama?Image source: Getty Images.Timing mattersThe chart below shows how theDow Jones Industrial Averagehas performed during the terms of the last 10 presidents
column10: all the   way back to when Lyndon Johnson took office in 1963 (the black   arrows mark the year in which each president was first   elected):Image source: MacroTrends.net
column11: with presidents' names tied     to election dates added by author. Gray lines = recession     periods.Now let's put that in terms of total market returns under each   president:PresidentDates of PresidencyStock Market Performance During TenureLyndon Johnson11/22/63 - 1/19/6926%Richard Nixon1/20/69 - 8/8/74(28%)Gerald Ford8/9/74 - 1/19/7740%Jimmy Carter1/20/77 - 1/19/81(1%)Ronald Reagan1/20/81 - 1/19/89147%George H.W. Bush1/20/89 - 1/19/9341%Bill Clinton1/20/93 - 1/19/01226%George W. Bush1/20/01 - 1/19/09(27%)Barack Obama1/20/09 - 1/19/17148%Donald Trump1/20/17 - present*1%*Present = Feb. 9
column12: 2017 (date of publication). Data source:MacroTrends.net.Obama took office at the tail end of the Financial Crisis.   Even though the administration enacted policies that would   typically seem to limit the earnings ability of some corporations   within the Dow
column13: such as stricter reporting regulations
column14: the   market rose handily (in percentage terms) during his eight years   in office. Setting aside any economic policies the Obama   administration enacted
column15: the fact that President Obama took office   near the market's trough meant that the market
column16: which is cyclical   in nature
column17: had a much stronger chance of rebounding during his   tenure.Meanwhile
column18: Trump assumed the presidency after an   eight-year-long bull run that saw no sustained corrections.   History shows that corrections happen at somewhat regular   intervals
column19: and many market analysts believe one is due soon.   Based on how market the cycle has worked through recent decades
column20: it seems unlikely that we'll see consistent growth during   President Trump's tenure -- but
column21: of course
column22: it's not   impossible.What business leaders are sayingMany business leaders have been speaking optimistically of   Trump's proposed financial policies in their earnings calls.Cisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO) CEO Chuck Robbins said during the company's fiscal   first-quarter earnings call in November
column23: ""I think President-elect   Trump appears to be very business-oriented and is very focused on   driving the U.S. economy
column24: and anytime the U.S. economy improves   that's certainly good for us.""Southwest Airlines(NYSE: LUV) is another company that is looking forward to lower   taxes and less regulation. In the most recent earnings call
column25: CEO   Gary Kelly finished answering an analyst question about upcoming   policy changes by saying:""We've looked at the tax reform proposals and we're quite     excited about that on the corporate front
column26: but that's just     about income tax. So that doesn't really speak to the very     heavy burden that we have for aviation taxes
column27: which we also     want to take up with the administration. So
column28: that's a long     answer to your question and I think the bottom line is: No
column29: we     don't know anything specific yet
column30: but we sure like what we're     hearing so far.""Of course
column31: there's also rising concern among many CEOs and   other business leaders about how certain policies that have been   floated or initiated could negatively affect their businesses or   the broader economy. These include tariffs on imported goods and   the controversial executive order restricting travel to the   U.S.Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) management has said positive things about   potential tax cuts
column32: especially those related to repatriating cash   kept overseas
column33: of which Apple has around $200 billion. However
column34: Apple is also one of the biggest companies that in recent weeks   have come out against Trump's immigration policy. And it is one   of many companies taking legal action against Trump's immigration   stance
column35: citing (along with moral opposition) concerns that it   could ultimately damage the company financially.How to invest during a Trump presidencyThe Dow Jones' average price-to-earnings ratio is currently   around 20 -- relatively high by historic standards. Additionally
column36: you can probably expect politics
column37: and the market's reaction to   them
column38: to be volatile in the months and years ahead. Nonetheless
column39: that shouldn't scare away investors. As the investing proverb   goes: Time in the market is more important than timing the   market.Regardless of how you believe the stock market will perform   based on cyclicalty or political volatility -- barring a massive   shift in policy that derails corporate earnings ability
column40: or a   major economic disaster resulting from an environmental
column41: social
column42: or defense crisis -- you should note that the market performance   graph above has marched upward over the long term.As a long-term investor
column43: you should continue to look for   valuable investments to buy and hold while also watching the   economic and political climate closely. And whatever you do
column44: remember that your investment horizon should be greater than four   -- or even eight -- years.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip
column45: it can pay to listen. After all
column46: the newsletter     they have run for over a decade
