column1: Boeing Co (BA) Stock Gives Savvy Investors a Good Payout;2/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsDon't let a faulty altimeter lead you to believeBoeing Co(NYSE:BA) is in need of repair. Any stray measurements in Boeing stock's share price on Wednesday were tied to a pending dividend payment - and one that has already paid nice dividends to some options traders. Let me explain.makeArticleAd();Source:Phillip Capper via FlickrShares of Boeing have been flying high in 2017 after hitting record highs following the aircraft manufacturer's earnings beat late last month. But in Wednesday's session
column3: BA stock may have appeared to have had a slight crack in its fuselage; pardon the pun.Houston
column4: Boeing Has a Problem?At a share price of $164.08 and depending on your trading vendor
column5: BA stock was off either $1 or 0.61% or a more eyebrow raising -$2.42 or -1.45%.The $1.42 difference between the two readings in Boeing shares is tied to the stock going ex-dividend Wednesday
column6: with a cash payment of $1.42 scheduled for March 3.Bearing this in mind
column7: trade vendors who recognize the ex-date will show BA stock as trading lower by the less-significant 0.61%. Any chart or quote platforms that erroneously fail to account for the ex-date will indicate Boeing has declined by a larger 1.45%.For BA stock investors who were long or purchased shares by Tuesday's close
column8: Wednesday's minor damage is reflected by the more modest 0.61% dip
column9: as $1.42 will be paid back to shareholders next month to dampen the otherwise larger 1.45% decline in Boeing.7 Stocks That Will Drop by 10% or More This QuarterWhat's the point? Dividends aren't a free lunch
column10: as the money distributed is taken out of the share price of the stock. If Wednesday wasn't an ex-date in Boeing
column11: BA stock would be trading $1.42 higher at $165.50 vs. $164.08 - bottom-line.For the proverbial free lunch
column12: you'd have to look at Tuesday's heavy volume options trading in BA stock tied to 'dividend play' activity
column13: which looks to arbitrage the future payout with an immediate overnight payoff.BA Stock Dividend Play StrategyTo illustrate how this might be accomplished
column14: we can look at the BA stock Feb $155 call
column15: as roughly $14
column16: 200 in profits was distributed to one or more options traders today due to the ex-dividend.In Tuesday's session
column17: more than 5
column18: 600 of the deep in-the-money calls traded. The heavy tally compares to open interest at the time of roughly 2
column19: 500. With the February $155 put trading for 10 cents
column20: part of the unusual volume may have been in the form of traders executing buy-writes or the equivalent of a synthetic short put.But the traders responsible for this activity weren't looking to establish buy-writes for 10 cents when buying BA stock and selling the February $155 call during Tuesday's session. Nope.What these BA stock dividend traders were really after was hoping a long $155 call holder within the pool of existing open interest of 2
column21: 500 failed to exercise the contract last night. If that were to occur
column22: those traders would in effect
column23: have shorted (synthetically) the February $155 put worth a measly 10 cents for a much more meaningful $1.42 for each buy-write still in inventory.How it works is Tuesday's dividend play traders would effectively wash on their BA stock position as the decline in share price attributed to the ex-date will be paid next month. The profit generator in this transaction is the short call portion of the buy-write
column24: which wasn't assigned.Call options don't receive dividends
column25: so a contract like the deep $155 call essentially loses the full value of the pending dividend. It's why an investor holding this contract would be greatly motivated to exercise the call and convert the position into BA stock before the ex-dividend.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Is No Longer Top Dog in ChinaAs it stands
column26: of the 2
column27: 500 in open interest roughly 2
column28: 400 call holders did elect to exercise their call into BA stock last night in order to receive the upcoming dividend. We know this based on Wednesday's open interest just shy of 100 contracts.We also know that because of the failure of those contracts to convert
column29: one or more traders short the call - and maybe part of a buy-write positioning described; already profited to the collective tune of around $14

column1: Why Fitbit Inc (FIT) Needs to Wise Up Before It Can Win Again;2/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFitbit Inc(NYSE:FIT) may be great to improve your health
column3: but as for Fitbit stock
column4: it has been lethal for investors. During the last 12 months
column5: FIT stock is off a horrendous 60%. This is certainly another case study of how high-profile IPOs can quickly come undone.makeArticleAd();Source:Via FitbitBut what about the future? Is there hope for Fitbit stock? Might there be a value play here?As I've written various times for InvestorPlace
column6: it's probably not a good idea to be hopeful. For example
column7: FIT is a company that develops a product that really is not a must-have. According to a recent study fromGartner
column8: the abandonment rate on fitness trackers is 30%. The most common reasons for this include: users either get bored or the device breaks!The conclusion from the report: ""Dropout from device usage is a serious problem for the industry. The abandonment rate is quite high relative to the usage rate. To offer a compelling enough value proposition
column9: the uses for wearable devices need to be distinct from what smartphones typically provide. Wearables makers need to engage users with incentives and gamification.""The Other Problems for FIT StockBut this is definitely not the only major issue with Fitbit stock. Let's face it
column10: the competitive environment remains intense. The company must fight against tough rivals likeGarmin Ltd.(NASDAQ:GRMN)
column11: Samsung(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) andMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT). Although
column12: the biggest threat isApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) Apple Watch
column13: which is still in the early phases.7 Stocks That Will Drop by 10% or More This QuarterIn light of all this
column14: is it any wonder that Wall Street is concerned with FIT stock? Of course not.More importantly
column15: the company is already reporting major problems
column16: as seen with the latest warning on fourth-quarter earnings. Fitbit's guidance calls for a loss of 51 cents to 56 cents a share on revenues of $572 million to $580 million. By comparison
column17: the prior forecast was for earnings of 14 cents to 18 cents a share and revenues of $725 million to $750 million. Overall
column18: it looks like the holiday season turned out to be a disaster for the company.Unfortunately
column19: the bad situation isexpected to continue. The full-year prediction is for revenues of $1.5 billion to $1.7 billion and a loss of 22 cents to 44 cents a share on FIT stock. Wall Street
column20: on the other hand
column21: was looking for a much more robust $2.38 billion on the top-line and profits of 64 cents a share.Bottom Line on Fitbit StockTo deal with the challenges
column22: FIT has a plan that looks weak. The company expects to reduce the workforce by mere 6% and to take other vague efforts to reduce operating costs
column23: leverage data and launch products into new categories. Interesting enough
column24: Fitbit wants to focus more on the smartwatch market
column25: but this will likely mean more expenses.3 Reasons Amazon.com
column26: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is STILL the KingEven worse
column27: CEO James Parksaidthat the issues with the company were ""temporary"" and the ""performance is not reflective of the value of our brand
column28: market-leading platform
column29: and company's long-term potential.""Huh? Well
column30: this really does seem like the talk of someone who is out-of-touch. And this should definitely be ominous for holders of FIT stock.Granted
column31: perhaps there may be a buyout. But when it comes to broken hardware companies
column32: this may be wishful thinking. For example
column33: think about how long the rumors for a purchase of the beleagueredBlackBerry Ltd(NASDAQ:BBRY) have existed.For the most part
column34: Fitbit stock may not be very interesting to a suitor. And this is not because the products are sub-par. Instead
column35: it could be as simple as that the market has hit maturation levels and that big players like AAPL stand to capture a big part of what's available.Tom Taulli runs the InvestorPlace blogIPO Playbook. He is also the author ofHigh-Profit IPO Strategies
column36: All About Commodities
column37: andAll About Short Selling. Follow him on Twitter at@ttaulli. As of this writing
column38: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's Pen7 Gold Stocks That Will Shine Under TrumpThe postWhy Fitbit Inc (FIT) Needs to Wise Up Before It Can Win Againappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Facebook vs. Apple: Whose Reality Will Win?;2/8/2017;"One of the most promising trends on the horizon that has   arguably the most transformative potential is virtual/augmented   reality (VR/AR). How these technologies emerge and subsequently   affect our lives remains to be seen
column2: but companies are already   placing their bets accordingly.Facebook(NASDAQ: FB) became the poster child for VR in one fell swoop in   2014 when it scooped up Oculus for $2 billion. A week ago
column3: Facebook lost a lawsuit regarding the acquisition to ZeniMax
column4: which alleged that Oculus stole trade secrets
column5: and a jury awarded   ZeniMax $500 million (ZeniMax was seeking $6 billion). Facebook   will appeal
column6: but let's call the total effective cost of   acquisition $2.5 billion for now.Once upon a time
column7: Alphabetwas the poster child for AR with Google Glass
column8: but that product   failed spectacularly.Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) has emerged as a potential candidate to assume   that title
column9: albeit unofficially until it actually unveils an AR   offering. We do know that CEO Tim Cook isfar more interestedin AR than VR
column10: believing that it will have broader appeal with   mainstream use cases.makeArticleAd();It's still early innings
column11: but whose vision of reality will   win?VR is harder and will take longerFacebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg firmly believes that VR will be   the next major computing platform that has the potential to be a   paradigm shift. But it's going to take an awful long time to get   there. VR is currently a nascent niche of video gaming
column12: and it   requires creating entire worlds to immerse users in. That also   requires both a lot of software development as well as heavy   lifting on the technical side
column13: requiring high-end gaming rigs   that cost $1
column14: 000 or more by themselves.Mark Zuckerberg speaking at Oculus Connect 2. Image source:     Facebook.His Zuckness sees VR as a richer media format that can create   a diverse array of social experiences. He's even envisioned a   distant future where you can visit a doctor in VR
column15: or hang out   with long-distance friends in a VR room (like how hechatted with Hugo Barrabefore hiring the executive). It will take at least a decade
column16: but   Facebook is in it for the long haul. Uncle Zuck is also   interested in AR
column17: but it seems that he thinks AR will come after   VR
column18: based on his comments from last year's F8 conference:Over the next 10 years
column19: the form factor's just going to keep     on getting smaller and smaller. And eventually we're going to     have what looks like normal-looking glasses that can do both     virtual and augmented reality. And augmented reality gives you     the ability to see the world but also to be able to overlay     digital objects on top of that.Earlier today
column20: Business Insiderreported that Facebook was shutting down hundreds of its Oculus   pop-up demonstration stations within big box retailers
column21: noting   that employees would go days without giving a single   demonstration to interested customers. So yeah
column22: it's going to be   a while until VR is ready for the mainstream.AR is easier and be here soonerAs usual
column23: Apple isn't giving any official clues as to its   strategy
column24: but there have been rumors of the company testing out   AR glasses and it has been hiring and acqui-hiring experts from   the field since at least 2015.It's much more plausible that AR will have a more immediate   impact. The software should be easier to develop and less   computationally intensive. Imagine the things you currently do on   your smartphone being beamed in front of you. Or you can even use   a smartphone as an AR interface
column25: which many apps already do   today.But if Apple were to jump in directly with AR integration in   iOS and/or a set of AR glasses
column26: that would have the potential to   truly bring AR to the masses
column27: much like the company's track   record with bringing many other previously niche technologies to   the mainstream. It's also a lot more approachable to the   average user.Here's another quote from Cook regarding AR from   September:My own view is that augmented reality is the larger of the     two
column28: probably by far
column29: because this gives the capability for     both of us to sit and be very present talking to each other
column30: but also have other things visually for both of us to see.     Maybe it's something we're talking about
column31: maybe it's someone     else here that is not here
column32: present
column33: but could be made to     appear to be present with us. So there's a lot of really cool     things there.Cook's point is that VR can be isolating since you have to   wear a large obtrusive headset
column34: which is a bit ironic given that   Facebook is so interested in a potentially anti-social experience   (at least anti-social in physical reality).I'm going to side with Apple here and agree that AR has much   more potential than VR.10 stocks we like better than FacebookWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column35: it can pay to listen. After all
column36: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column38: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Facebook wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Better Buy: Apple Inc. vs. IBM;2/8/2017;"Shares ofApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) andInternational Business Machines(NYSE: IBM) have performed well over the past year
column2: both up about   40% following periods of underperformance. Apple
column3: after reporting   three consecutive quarters of sales declines
column4: finally broke out   of its funk last month when it reported solid
column5: albeit muddled
column6: holiday quarter results. IBM
column7: after years of earnings declines
column8: expects to return to growth on a per-share basis this year.Both stocks are cheap relative to earnings
column9: but I think IBM is   the better buy. Here's why.Apple is cheap
column10: but growth will be toughShares of Apple trade around their all-time high following the   company's fiscal first-quarter report
column11: but the stock is still   cheap relative to earnings. Apple produced $45.2 billion of net   income over the past 12 months
column12: or $8.39 per share. With a stock   price around $131
column13: that puts Apple's PE ratio at roughly   15.6.makeArticleAd();Image source: Apple.But this calculation ignores the immense amount of cash on   Apple's balance sheet. At the end of the first quarter
column14: Apple had   $246 billion of cash and investments and $77 billion of debt
column15: leaving a net cash position of $169 billion. Valued fully and   backed out
column16: Apple's cash-adjusted PE ratio falls to just   11.5.Apple stockisn't nearly as cheap as it was a year ago
column17: but the market is   still pricing in minimal future growth even at all-time highs.   There are good reasons for this. Apple remains highly dependent   on the iPhone
column18: which accounted for nearly 70% of revenue during   the first quarter. With the smartphone market no longer growing   quickly
column19: consumers taking longer to upgrade
column20: and mid-range   devices getting better and cheaper
column21: consistent iPhone growth   going forward is going to be tough to achieve.And even though Apple managed to grow iPhone sales and EPS   during the first quarter
column22: net income declined due to a lower   gross margin and higher operating expenses. Share buybacks were   the sole source of per-share earnings growth.Apple is going to need to come up with something big in order   to grow earnings meaningfully in the coming years
column23: but it's   unclear whether Apple will be able to come up with the next big   thing. Services revenue has been growing quickly for Apple
column24: but the jury is still out on whether this will be enough to drive   earnings higher.IBM's transformation makes progressIBM stock is also cheap
column25: despite the rally over the past year.   The company produced $13.59 in adjusted EPS during 2016
column26: putting   the P/E ratio at 13. IBM's earnings have been in decline for a   few years
column27: and its revenue has been slumping since 2012. But its   multiyear transformation is making progress
column28: and the company   expects to produce at least $13.80 in adjusted EPS this year.Image source: IBM.IBM has been divesting and shifting resources away from   shrinking legacy businesses
column29: pouring money into growth   initiatives like cloud computing. This shift
column30: while painful
column31: is   now starting to bear fruit. IBM's strategic imperatives -- what   the company calls its various growth businesses -- now account   for 41% of total revenue after growing by 13% in 2016.The cloud-computing business is booming. Total cloud revenue   reached $13.7 billion in 2016
column32: up 35%. Cloud delivered as a   service
column33: which includes only infrastructure as a service
column34: platform as a service
column35: and software as a service
column36: is at an annual   revenue run rate of $8.6 billion
column37: up 61% year over year. IBM's   ongoing shift to subscription software has hurt overall software   sales in the past couple of years
column38: but thesoftware business has now posted growthfor three straight quarters.IBM's earnings have room to grow simply because the bottom   line has been beaten down so much over the past few years. As IBM   continues to remake itself as a cloud and cognitive computing   company
column39: a return to consistent earnings growth is a real   possibility.IBM is the better betWhile I don't necessarily think that Apple is a bad   investment
column40: I find it difficult to believe that the company will   be able to grow earnings from here. The iPhone is going to have   to hold up in a world where good phones are getting cheaper
column41: and   the company is going to have to come up with something new and   innovative that can move the needle.IBM
column42: on the other hand
column43: has a much broader business
column44: with a   vast customer base dependent on its products and services.   Earnings have room to grow substantially as the strategic   imperatives
column45: which are more software-heavy than the company as a   whole
column46: continue to expand. Given similar valuations
column47: I'll take   IBM any day.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Would You Buy a $1
column2: 000 iPhone?;2/8/2017;"This year is a momentous one forApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) because it marks the iPhone's 10th year. That's   ratcheting up expectations for what the company may have up its   sleeve
column3: especially since 2016's iPhone 7 and 7 Plus only received   incremental updates within the same overall design (not like that   hurt sales at all).The most recent speculation comes fromFast Company
column4: which is reporting that the 10th-generation iPhone might   incredibly be priced at $1
column5: 000 or more. That would be even higher   than $969 that it costs to buy a fully loaded iPhone 7 Plus with   256 GB of storage. As previously rumored (and widely expected at   this point)
column6: at least one variant may include an OLED display.   OLED displays don't come cheap
column7: and the one that Apple is   thinking about using will probably cost about twice as much as   traditional LCD displays. Historically
column8: the entire display   assembly often comprises about 40% of component costs
column9: so a   potential price increase makes perfect sense to offset a cost   increase related to the most expensive component.Jet Black iPhone 7 Plus. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Apple is reportedly still considering removing the physical   home button and potentially even the volume and lock buttons on   the sides
column10: all of which would join the headphone jack in iHeaven.   The iPhone maker is collaborating withLumentum(NASDAQ: LITE)
column11: whose shares were alreadypoppingafter earnings
column12: to develop a 3D sensing technology that could be   used for facial recognition and other applications. RivalSamsungstarted introducing facial recognition features in its flagship   phones years ago.Think differentThe company is hoping to pack as many new features into the   high-end model as possible
column13: which would help justify a four-digit   price tag. Apple has long enjoyed the strongest pricing power   within the smartphone industry
column14: and this would potentially   represent the strongest exhibit of Apple flexing its pricing   muscles.Data source: SEC filings. Chart by author. Calendar quarters     shown.If Apple can pull it off
column16: 000 price tag would clearly   boost average selling prices
column17: the degree of which would depend on   product mix. Samsung has attempted to launch $1
column18: 000-plus phones   in the past
column19: like 2013's horribly named Galaxy Round which   featured a curved AMOLED display that was responsible for the   higher price. But Samsung's error was believing that the curved   display itself would justify the premium to consumers
column20: even   though the device was largely similar to other Galaxy phones at   the time in other respects. Apple's task
column21: then
column22: will be to   include enough differentiating factors in the $1
column23: 000 model to set   it apart.In recent years
column24: carriers have shifted away from the subsidy   model and toward installment and leasing plans. At first
column25: consumers were hit with sticker shock that premium smartphones   cost over $600
column26: as opposed to the subsidized $200 they had   previously been paying
column27: but it's safe to say that at this point   consumers fully appreciate how much smartphones actually cost.   The increased pricing transparency associated with abandoning   subsidies indirectly helps lay the foundation for innovation
column28: because manufacturers can then appeal directly to consumers on   why a higher price tag is warranted by new features instead of   having to negotiate subsidy levels with carriers. The extra $20   bump associated with the iPhone 7 Plus dual-camera system is a   good example.Would you buy a $1

column1: Close Update: Dow Closes Lower As Falling Yields Continue to Weigh on Bank Stocks;2/8/2017;"The benchmark averages were mixed at Wednesday's close with the financial sector weighing on the Dow
column2: but strength in tech shares driving the Nasdaq just shy of another record high. The S&P 500 closed fractionally higher on gains in the defensive and consumer sectors.Banking stocks have been underwater since the start of the week
column3: plagued by lower Treasury yields as investors sought safe havens from the political environment in France and backlash from President Donald Trump's recent executive orders.And although yields were briefly tugged higher in the wake of today's disappointing 10-year auction
column4: the 10-year yield has dropped nearly 9 basis points since last week. As a result shares of Dow component stocks Goldman Sachs (GS) and JP Morgan (JPM) led decliners again on Wednesday
column5: offsetting gains in Apple (AAPL) and Nike (NKE).makeArticleAd();Earnings were also creating a drag on Wall Street Wednesday as Wall Street geared up for the final leg of fourth quarter results. Of the companies that reported Tuesday more than half beat EPS estimates
column6: but less than half topped revenue expectations. Additionally
column7: component stock Disney beat EPS estimates by a nickel
column8: but missed revenue guidance by nearly half a billion dollars.The earnings onslaught continues Thursday with Twitter (TWTR)
column9: Yum Brands (YUM)

column1: Is Apple Inc. on the Verge of Cracking This Fast-Growing Market?;2/8/2017;"Image source: Apple.Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) is growing at a fast pace in India. The company   sold 2.5 million iPhones in the South Asian country in 2016
column2: an   increase of almost 39% from estimated sales of 1.8 million units   the year before. Despite this impressive growth
column3: India remains   just a small part of Apple's overall business.makeArticleAd();When compared to estimated global iPhone sales of around 234   million units for 2016
column4: India makes up just over 1% of that   volume. This does not paint a very nice picture for the company   in a smartphone market that's currently growing at 18% compared   to the global average of just 3%.The reason for Apple's underperformance in India is quite   simple -- high prices in a country with low per capita income.   Consider this: India's GDP per capita in 2015 stood at $1
column6: while the price of the cheapest iPhone 7 in India is around $840   onAmazonat current exchange rates.However
column7: recent sales trends in India clearly indicate that   the company is gaining traction among the big-ticket smartphone   buyers in the country. Counterpoint Research reports that Apple   currently commands 62% of the premium smartphone market (phones   costing more than $450) in the country
column8: indicating that it is the   preferred brand for this group.Apple's reputation as a premium brand will be a tailwind in   the long run as India's GDP per capita is expected to rise to   $3
column10: according to Trading Economics. What's more
column11: Apple's recent negotiations with the Indian government regarding   the manufacturing of iPhones in the country indicate that it is   looking to make the most of the growing spending power of Indian   consumers.Plans for India get a boostThe Indian government is currently engaged in a campaign
column12: known as ""Make in India""
column13: to encourage domestic manufacturing of   goods by inviting multi-national companies to set up shop in the   country. Apple is looking to take advantage of this campaign and   has proposed building a local manufacturing plant in   Bengaluru.Bengaluru (aka Bangalore) in India. Image source: Getty     Images.Apple executives
column14: led by the Global Vice-President of iPhone   operations Priya Balasubramanian
column15: met a group of ministers on   Jan. 25 to discuss the company's roadmap in the country. Both   parties discussed building a local manufacturing unit
column16: while   Apple also put forward a list of concessions that it would need   from the government.The Wall Street Journalreported that an official with direct knowledge of the meeting   indicated that the deal between the government and Apple is   almost done. This means that Apple will gain customs duty   exemption on the import of equipment and components for a period   of 15 years.More importantly
column17: Apple's deal with the Indian government   could lead to the opening of company-owned stores in the country.   In order to set up single-brand retail stores in India
column18: the   government requires foreign companies to source 30% of their   manufacturing from local sources. Apple has requested relaxation   on this front
column19: and if the deal closes
column20: then it will soon be able   to set up its own stores in the country as well.Apple has reportedly taken steps to set up a manufacturing   unit in India already by selecting Wistron as its iPhone   manufacturer for the Indian market. The Taiwanese company is said   to be currently expanding its smartphone manufacturing capacity   in Bengaluru
column21: according to theTimes of India.In January
column22: an Indian government official said that Wistron   has requested rapid resolution to its request of expanding   manufacturing operations in Bengaluru. This indicates that it is   looking to meet the April target of beginning iPhone   manufacturing operations in the country.Apple has also lined up Foxconn to meet any surge in the   demand. Foxconn already has a plant in southern India
column23: where it   has doubled its manufacturing capacity in just a year. Foxconn   has already pledged to set up another facility in the country   with an investment of $5 billion. These moves to expand capacity   among Apple's manufacturing partners indicate that they are   preparing for a boost in iPhone production in India.Lower iPhone prices and improving GDP will boost     salesOnce Apple sets up its manufacturing base in India
column24: it will be   able to lower the price of its phones due to import tax   exemptions. Without the 12.5% import tax
column25: Apple could shave   almost $100 from the price of an iPhone 7 in India.This will make Apple more competitive in the premium   smartphone segment as it can grab market share from the likes ofSamsungby offering better prices. This should help Apple achieve its   target of selling seven million iPhones in the country by   2018.Lower iPhone pricing will also allow Apple to benefit from   India's expanding smartphone market. Euromonitor International   forecasts that smartphone sales there will hit the 200 million   unit mark by 2020
column26: as compared to estimated sales of just 102.4   million units in 2016.Paired with the growing spending power of Indian shoppers
column27: Apple can make significant strides in the country due to its   leading position in this segment.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column28: it can pay to listen. After all
column29: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column30: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column31: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column32: 2017Harsh Chauhanhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Amazon and Apple. The Motley Fool has     the following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and     short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Wednesday Apple Rumors: AAPL Announces Launch Day for Beats X Earbuds;2/8/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of a release date for the Beats X earbuds. Today
column3: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Wednesday.makeArticleAd();Beats X Earbuds:Apple will officially start selling Beats X earbuds this Friday
column4: Feb. 10
column5: reportsBGR. The launch of the wireless earbuds comes after months of delays. They were originally announced alongside the iPhone 7. However
column6: problems with the tech resulted in a delay for the earbuds
column7: as well as the AirPods. Color options for the Beats X earbuds are black
column8: blue
column9: grey and white. They will cost $149.95.Apple TV:AAPL is getting more serious about its TV business with a new vice president for Apple TV product marketing
column10: MacRumorsnotes. This new hire is Timothy Twerdahl. Twerdahl is the former general manager and director ofAmazon.com
column11: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) Fire TV business. The company reportedly hopes that this will allow Pete Distad
column12: its former head of TV product marketing
column13: to help with content negotiations. Content providers have allegedly been reluctant to sign deals with AAPL to include their content in streaming packages.Optical Drive Lawsuit:A settlement in a class action lawsuit can get Mac owners $10
column14: reportsAppleInsider. The lawsuit states that four optical drive makers kept prices of the components artificially high from  April 1
column15: 2003 to Dec. 31
column16: 2008. Customers that bought an optical drive from one of the four companies
column17: or a computer containing one of these drives
column18: can get $10 back per purchase. The computers or optical drives must have been bought between the above-mentioned dates. The four optical drive makers in the lawsuit arePanasonic Corporation (ADR)(OTCMKTS:PCRFY)
column19: NEC
column20: Sony Corp (ADR)(NYSE:SNE)
column21: andHitachi-LG. This offer is only available in certain states.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postWednesday Apple Rumors: AAPL Announces Launch Day for Beats X Earbudsappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Midday Update: Dow and S&P 500 Struggle to Stay Positive as Banking Shares Trade Lower;2/8/2017;"Weighed down by heavy losses in the banking sector
column2: the Dow and S&P 500 were trading lower while the Nasdaq Composite remained in positive territory as Apple (AAPL) shares flirted with another record high
column3: giving a solid boost to the technology sector.Dow component stocks JP Morgan (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS) were leading decliners within the blue-chip index
column4: offsetting modest gains in Disney (DIS) and Nike (NKE). Five of the eleven S&P 500 sectors were lower
column5: with defensive sectors leading advancers.Stocks were underwater at the open in reaction to a sell-off in oil futures amid supply pressures. Butoil pricesrebounded mid-morning in wake of the weekly Energy Information Administration report
column6: driving Brent crude oil futures higher after two days in the red. According to the EIA survey
column7: oil inventories swelled 13.8K vs 2.5K expectations while gasoline inventories shrunk by 869K and refinery utilization contracted by 0.5% versus the -0.3% consensus estimate.makeArticleAd();Earnings were also creating a drag on US markets Wednesday as Wall Street gears up for the final leg of Q4 results. Of the companies that reported Tuesday more than half beat EPS estimates
column8: but less than half topped revenue expectations. Additionally
column9: component stock Disney beat EPS estimates by a nickel
column10: but missed revenue guidance by nearly half a billion dollars.Crude oil was up $0.21 to $52.38 per barrel. Natural gas was down $0.01 to $3.12 per 1 million BTU. Gold was up $7.80 to $1

column1: Next Stop for Nokia Corp (ADR) Stock: $5 a Share!;2/8/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAfter reporting a weak third quarter
column3: Nokia Corp (ADR)(NYSE:NOK) pleased investors this time around by reporting that it would raise its dividends. It will go up from 17 cents to 18 cents a share.makeArticleAd();Source:Open Grid Scheduler / Grid Engine via Flickr (Modified)Despite other disappointments in itsfourth quarter
column4: investors bid NOK higher last week. What may follow for Nokia shares is the $5 level.NOK Stock Earnings RundownWeak Network Division:Sales at NOK's Network division fell 14% year-on-year. The market remains weak but Alcatel-Lucent lifted the performance of the unit. And Nokia maintained a strong gross margin of 40.6%. Operating margin of 8.9% for the full year is within the guidance NOK provided.Nokia Technologies:NOK's earnings did not benefit from IP payments fromSamsung Electronics(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) in the fourth quarter. The company expanded its IP licensing agreement. This is a move that should boost revenue for the technologies unit.Cashing in on Apple:Just asApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) is cashing in on patents by suingQualcomm
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM) for high IP royalties
column6: Nokia is suing Apple for infringing on Nokia patents. With 50 patents involved in the suit
column7: expect Nokia at least getting something from Apple. Also
column8: Nokiasaid:""As of today
column9: in actions across 11 countries in Asia
column10: Europe and the US
column11: there are now more than 50 Nokia patents in suit
column12: covering technologies such as display
column13: user interface
column14: software
column15: antenna
column16: chipsets
column17: video coding
column18: as well as 3G & 4G cellular standards. Apple has also filed certain complaints against Nokia.""At 1.15 times sales
column19: investors are not pricing a litigation win in favor of Nokia. Even if NOK is successful
column20: it will take years before the court makes a ruling. Nokia is not the only stock trading at low valuations.Ericsson(NASDAQ:ERIC) is valued at 0.7 times sales. ERIC reported quarterly results that only met earnings expectations. It earned seven cents per share in the quarter
column21: compared to 13 cents per share for Nokia stock
column22: which beat the consensus by five cents.12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's PenOn its press release
column23: NOK highlighted the $115 billion IP portfolio it holds
column24: thanks to its ownership in Alcatel-Lucent. This further suggests that markets are ignoring the potential for more monetization of IP in the years ahead.Risks to NOK StockEquity and Expenses:Of the nearly $20.9 billion in equity
column25: over half of that amount is goodwill and intangibles. In the fourth quarter
column26: R&D expenses amounted to $1.34 billion. Most of that was due primarily to the amortization of intangible assets from the Alcatel-Lucent acquisition.Smartphone Sales Unknown:Nokia did not forecast revenue for its technologies division. But the company's base case for revenue from patent and brand licensing will total around $863 million annualized. Any new licensing agreement will raise that base case. The networks division represents the bulk of Nokia's business. The mediocre news is that sales are growing in the single digits in the best-case scenario. It expects the primary addressable market falling in the full year (2017). Higher competition and pricing pressure for networking goods will continue to exert negative pressure on the business.Apple Inc. Taps Head of Amazon Fire to Run Apple TV (AAPL)Takeaway on NOK shares:Headwinds are a worry for Nokia shareholders but the market has low expectations for the company. An early settlement with Apple on IP would bring much-needed revenue for the former smartphone giant. Higher customer spending on 5G and networking gear will give the company a lift this year. That will lead to a minimum $5 share price. That is
column27: a forward price-earnings ratio of above 20 times
column28: for Nokia's stock.As of this writing

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Is No Longer Top Dog in China;2/8/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsEarlier this week
column3: research firm IDC released a report indicating that
column4: for the first time ever
column5: Apple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) iPhone shipments to China have decreased significantly. According to the report
column6: shipments of iPhones to China decreased last year to 44.9 million
column7: a 23.2% decrease from 2015.makeArticleAd();Source:iphonedigital via FlickrApparently
column8: Chinese smartphone makers
column9: particularlyOppo
column10: VivoandHuawei
column11: have increased market share in the region by offering""higher-end gadgetry that appeals to consumers seeking Apple-like quality and innovation.""This has led to an overall decrease in the AAPL market share in China
column12: down to 9.6% from 13.6% in 2015
column13: and a subsequent drop in revenue - Apple's""fourth consecutive year-over-year dip in the region""- by 11.4%.This new situation is potentially disconcerting to a number of analysts and investors
column14: as China has presented a fantastic opportunity for growth in years past.However
column15: due to the challenges faced by American companies attempting to conduct business in China - namely
column16: the Chinese government'soverbearing regulationand frequent demands for controversialapp and product modifications- coupled with the ""ascendancy of cheaper but just-as-good local alternatives
column17: sales of the iPhone 7 were less than spectacular.7 Tech Stocks With Explosive Growth PotentialSome analysts have attributed the reduced demand for the iPhone 7 to alack of innovationand significantly higher product prices compared to other countries. This is potentially disconcerting for AAPL stock management and investors alike
column18: since ""China remains an important market for Apple
column19: as it contributes 20.7% of its revenue and is the location for the bulk its [sic] manufacturing facilities.""It's quite possible that AAPL stock will recover in China
column20: and the lull in sales and Chinese-based revenue will reverse when Apple finally reveals its 10th-anniversary edition of the iPhone.Even considering the recent drop-off in both market share and sales in China
column21: Apple stock is still going strong. According to Strategy Analytics
column22: AAPL earned 91% of global smartphone operating profits in the third quarter.Bottom Line for AAPL Stock in ChinaOf the 43 analysts providing recommendations to MarketWatch.com
column23: 33 call Apple stock a buy and 10 call it a hold. The average target price for AAPL stock is $140.57
column24: which represents a potential upside of more than 7% from Tuesday's per-share closing price of $131.35.Overall
column25: Apple stock is still one of the best choices for your tech-centered investment portfolio. While the struggle for dominance of market share in China will undoubtedly be a long and bloody battle
column26: AAPL has a history of producing some of the world's most innovative and compelling products
column27: and this reputation - and expectation from consumers and analysts alike - will ensure Apple stock remains on everybody's short list.As of this writing

column1: Why a PepsiCo
column2: Inc. (PEP) Split Would Unlock 20% Upside;2/8/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsMany investors have urgedPepsiCo
column4: Inc.(NYSE:PEP) to split into two companies over the years. One of the most vocal has been Nelson Peltz
column5: the billionaire head ofTrian Fund Management
column6: which in 2014disclosed it owned $1.2 billion worth of PEP stock.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)Peltz then released a letter urging Pepsi's board of directors to split the company into two
column7: using the proceeds from spinning out beverages towards buyingMondelez International Inc(NASDAQ:MDLZ).Peltz didn't get very far.PepsiCo passionately defended the status quo
column8: saying the company's size helps give it clout with big retailers likeWal-Mart Stores Inc(NYSE:WMT). Having both soda and chips under one corporate roof makes it easier to gain display space. And management is convinced splitting the company in two would lead to negative synergies.Some of those arguments are valid
column9: but one simple fact remains: Pepsi stock holders would be made richer if the company split in two.7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018Here's why.The Case for a PepsiCo SplitPepsiCo currently divides itself into six different operating divisions:Frito-Lay North AmericaQuaker Foods North AmericaNorth American BeveragesLatin AmericaEurope and Sub-Saharan AfricaPacific and Northern AfricaPepsi operates a little differently in North America versus the rest of the world. In North America
column10: Frito-Lay
column11: Quaker Foods and Beverages are all essentially separate companies. They have different sales teams and different offices
column12: and share little in resources. The three divisions work together in various promotions
column13: but that's about it.Operations in the rest of the world are much different
column14: with chips and soda delivered on the same trucks in many different places.For the sake of this article
column15: let's assume the two North American food companies would form one new company
column16: leaving everything else as the other company.Now we have to look at valuation. In 2015 (the latest fiscal year in which full results are available)
column17: PepsiCo as a whole earned $8.35 billion in operating profits. Add back in unusual expenses - which mostly included a $1.4 billion write-off of Venezuelan assets - of $1.59 billion
column18: and PEP posted $9.94 billion in normalized operating profits.PepsiCo has a current market cap of $153 billion
column19: putting PEP stock at a price-to-operating income ratio of about 15.Once we dig a little deeper into the numbers
column20: a theme starts to emerge: Food is a better business than soda.The Value of FoodThe North American Beverages division posted an operating income of $2.75 billion on revenue of $20.62 billion in 2015
column21: good enough for an operating margin of 13.3%. In comparison
column22: the combined Frito-Lay and Quaker North American divisions delivered operating profits of $4.89 billion on sales of $17.33 billion - an operating margin of 28.2%.In short
column23: the soda business is dragging down the real performer: PepsiCo's food business.There is no other major food company in the United States that has 28% operating margins. Most are in the neighborhood of 15%
column24: just like PEP as a whole.There is one that gets close
column25: however.The Coca-Cola Co(NYSE:KO) posted 23% operating margins in 2015. It trades at 18 times operating earnings
column26: but shares are flirting with a 52-week low.If we value a combined Frito-Lay/Quaker company at 20 times operating earnings
column27: it alone would be worth $97.8 billion. That valuation gives it a premium versus Coca-Cola
column28: but not an excessive one. Then if we value the rest of Pepsi at 15 times operating income
column29: it's worth $75.8 billion.The Smart Money: Sears Holdings Corp (SHLD) Is Already InsolventAdd the two divisions together

column1: Earnings Preview: Guidance Is Key for Pandora Media Inc (P) Stock;2/8/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIt seems unlikely that from a fundamental standpoint
column3: there will be a lot of news in thePandora Media Inc(NYSE:P) earnings report on Thursday.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockPandora already announced last month that fourth-quarter results would come in ahead of guidance for both revenue and adjusted Ebitda. That disclosure sent P stock up 6%
column4: and would seem to limit the possibility that the numbers in the Pandora earnings report will boost the stock further.That doesn't mean there will be no news coming out of Pandora earnings. The company has set itself up for a busy 2017. The replacement of Pandora One with Pandora Plus appears to have had some success in the fourth quarter. Commentary on that initiative will be closely watched on the Q4 conference call.Meanwhile
column5: in December
column6: Pandora announced a new ""Premium"" service to compete with offerings fromSpotify
column7: Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) and others.12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's PenThat product should roll out shortly
column8: potentially boosting growth in 2017. And Pandora has said it is aiming to return to Ebitda profitability in 2017. The Q4 report should give some color as to whether investors in P stock should believe the company.A Busy 2017 for Pandora StockPandora stock actually is up about 65% over the past year
column9: after coming close to all-time lows in early 2016. Those gains have come despite mixed performance in the business. Revenue is up 14% through the first nine months
column10: and likely rose a similar figure in Q4. But about half the year-to-date growth came from the acquisition of TicketFly last October. Advertising revenue also increased 14% through the first three quarters - but came solely from higher pricing. Active users were actually down year-over-year at the end of Q3
column11: and subscription revenue declined in the quarter as well.The user and subscription figures are a major problem for Pandora stock. The market simply doesn't trust that Pandora can create consistent profits based on advertising revenue alone. That's particularly true given thehigher royalty ratesthat took effect at the beginning of last year. So the move by Pandora to upgrade One to Plus - adding features like song replays - and to develop Premium are a clear step toward a subscription-based model.The plan from Pandora
column12: as detailed after the third quarter
column13: is for that type of model to provide a more stable revenue base. Moving customers to subscription-based services both helps margins and improves retention. If Pandora is successful
column14: Pandora stock likely will rise. But that remains a relatively big ""if.""What to Watch for in Pandora EarningsIn the Pandora earnings report
column15: then
column16: the most important numbers likely will come from the company's guidance. That guidance will give some color as to how successful management thinks Plus has been so far - and what kind of opportunity Premium has to boost Pandora earnings this year.But the Pandora earnings conference call also seems like it might move P stock. Management will have another opportunity to detail its strategy for 2017 and beyond. The company laid out its ""three-legged stool"" strategy - Plus
column17: Premium and Ticketfly - after the third quarter
column18: but investors weren't terribly impressed. Pandora stock fell about 14% over the next seven sessionsThe issue with P stock is that there's a real fear that Pandora's model simply doesn't quite work. The product itself is attractive
column19: as evidenced by the nearly 80 million active users. But it's not clear that Pandora can pay higher royalty rates through ad revenue alone. The company did announce layoffs ofabout 7%of its employees in a bid to improve 2017 profits. That simply raised additional concerns about Pandora stock. The most notable is: Can Pandora really compete with Apple
column20: Spotify andAmazon.com
column21: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)?After all
column22: those companies have much larger businesses - and much more cash - than Pandora. P stock still is worth almost $3 billion
column23: yet the company has burned about $127 million in cash just in the first three quarters of 2016. Full-year Ebitda loss is likely to be huge as well
column24: and that's not counting depreciation or the additional $139 million in Pandora stock awards.Make Free Profits From Tesla Inc (TSLA) StockFor Pandora stock to appreciate in the near term
column25: the company needs to get at least close to breakeven in 2017. So full-year guidance given in the Pandora earnings report will be key. But that aside
column26: investors also will be looking for more information on the plan going forward here.Can Pandora find a niche in the music industry? Is Pandora Premium ""too little
column27: too late"" against the offerings from Spotify
column28: Amazon and Apple? And is there really a profitable business model here
column29: or are royalty rates simply too difficult to manage?Those questions can't be answered quite yet
column30: but investors will be looking at the Pandora earnings report closely to better assess the company's prospects. And it's likely the commentary on the future - not the past - that will determine how Pandora stock reacts to Q4 earnings.As of this writing

column1: How Good Was Apple Inc.'s Q1 Earnings Report?;2/8/2017;"Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) stock has soared about 8% since the company   reported better-than-expected Q1 earnings results last week.   Revenue hit a new record of $78.4 billion
column2: $1 billion ahead of   the average analyst estimate. Earnings per share also reached a   record at $3.36
column3: up from $3.28 a year earlier. This was $0.15   ahead of analysts' estimates.Thanks to this strong performance
column4: numerous Wall Street   analystsraised their price targetsforApple stock. Still
column5: not everybody is convinced. Some pundits have argued   that Apple's results were far worse than Mr. Market seems to   think. Let's take a look at whether there's any substance to that   argument.Good results aside from the iPadFrom a high-level perspective
column6: Apple's Q1 earnings report   looks rock solid. Sure
column7: iPad sales declined yet again -- with   unit sales down 19% year over year and revenue down 22% -- but   the iPad is far less important for Apple's business than it was a   few years ago. Apple only got 7% of its revenue from iPad sales   last quarter.makeArticleAd();The iPad is becoming less and less important to Apple's     results. Image source: Apple.The iPhone business is what really matters for Apple these   days. Apple sold a record 78.3 million iPhones last quarter
column8: generating $54.4 billion of revenue -- nearly 70% of the   companywide total. Mac sales also returned to growth and the   services segment continued to surge higher
column9: with revenue up 18%   year over year.Did Apple pull a fast one on investors?Writing for MarketWatch last week
column10: Thomas Kee
column11: Jr. argued that   investors have completely misunderstood Apple's earnings report.   He points out that Apple's fiscal first quarter had an extra week   this year.Measured on a per-week basis
column12: Apple's revenue
column13: iPhone sales
column14: and EPS were alldown on a year-over-year basis. In other words
column15: without the extra week
column16: Apple would likely have   posted declines rather than increases for all three key metrics.   As a result
column17: Kee thinks that Apple stock is significantly   overvalued.It's true that the extra week helped Apple last quarter.   However
column18: in highlighting one anomaly in Apple's first quarter   results
column19: Kee ignored two others that hurt Apple during the   quarter.Channel inventory changes weighed Apple downFirst
column20: Apple is being much more careful with channel inventory   this year than it was in fiscal 2016. Since Apple reports revenue   when it ships devices to retailers -- not when they are sold to   end users -- changes in channel inventory can distort Apple's   revenue and earnings relative to underlying demand.Apple didn't increase iPhone channel inventory by very much     in Q1. Image source: Apple.For the iPhone
column21: Apple grew channel inventory by 1.2 million   units last quarter. This means that 77.1 million of the 78.3   million iPhones Apple shipped during Q1 made it into the hands of   customers.By contrast
column22: a year earlier
column23: Apple increased iPhone channel   inventory by 3.3 million units. Sell-through to end users totaled   71.5 million in that quarter. After adjusting for these channel   inventory changes
column24: last quarter's weekly iPhone sales rate was   almost exactly in line with the prior-year result.This adjustment is even starker for the iPad. Apple reduced   its iPad channel inventory by about 700
column25: 000 units last quarter
column26: compared to a 900
column27: 000-unit increase a year earlier. This explains   about half of the year-over-year decline in iPad sales. The   negative impact of the channel inventory changes more than offset   the benefit of having an extra week.A patent settlement skewed Apple's Q1 2016 resultsA second factor that hurt Apple last quarter is that it had   received a one-time $548 million gain related to a patent   infringement case in Q1 2016. This was pure profit
column28: so it boosted   Apple's gross margin by more than 0.7 percentage points in that   quarter and added about $0.10 per share in pre-tax income.Stripping out this one-time gain and the changes in channel   inventory
column29: Apple's revenue and EPS growth would have been much   higher last quarter than what the company actually reported.Additionally
column30: the $548 million patent gain in Q1 2016 created   a tough comparison for Apple's fast-growing services segment last   quarter. Apple reported 18% revenue growth in services last   quarter anyway
column31: but on an apples-to-apples basis it would have   posted a 30% revenue increase.Apple's quarter was as strong as it seemed to beIt's impossible to know precisely how much channel inventory   changes impacted Apple's revenue and profit last quarter. But a   reasonable guess is that they cost Apple $2 billion-$2.5 billion   of revenue and close to $1 billion of pre-tax profit
column32: relative to   Q1 2016. The non-recurrence of the patent gain was an additional   $548 million headwind to revenue and pre-tax profit.After making these adjustments
column33: Apple's revenue may have been   down slightly year-over-year on a per-week basis
column34: but EPS still   increased. Even this sort of slow growth is fairly good for Apple   right now
column35: as the strong dollar is causing persistent revenue and   profit headwinds.Furthermore
column36: Apple is widely believed to be working on a   massive upgrade of the iPhone for 2017. There's a good chance   that these rumors are already impacting the upgrade rate as some   customers hold out for the new model. That bodes well for a   return to robust (and indisputable) revenue and earnings growth   in 2018.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column37: it can pay to listen. After all
column38: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column39: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column40: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column41: 2017Adam Levine-Weinbergowns shares of Apple and is long January 2018 $90 calls on     Apple. The Motley Fool owns shares of and recommends Apple. The     Motley Fool and is long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and     short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Q4 Earnings Preview;2/8/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsForNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA)
column3: 2016 was as good a year as it was for the Atlanta Falcons. But we know how the Falcons' story ended.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockIs NVDA stock about to undergo a similar fourth-quarter collapse?Going into the Feb. 9 earnings report
column4: analysts are wary
column5: with just half saying buy and most of the rest saying hold - which is something they say when they don't know what to say.Earnings are expected to be just a little better than the previous quarter
column6: net income of something over $550 million
column7: 87 cents per share
column8: on revenues of $2.11 billion
column9: just a little more than last quarter's $2 billion.If Nvidia meets those expectations
column10: however
column11: or even exceeds them only by a little bit
column12: I expect NVDA stock to fall. Here is why.An Overpriced StockNVDA is
column13: to the surprise of no one
column14: incredibly overpriced right now. At the opening bid of $119 per share on Feb. 8
column15: Nvidia stock is trading for 44 times next year's earnings estimates. Its market cap
column16: almost $65 billion
column17: is 13 times its fiscal 2016 revenue
column18: and nearly 9 times its anticipated 2017 revenue.7 Stocks That Will Drop by 10% or More This QuarterMeeting analysts' targets this quarter will show that its incredible October performance was not a fluke
column19: where revenues rose 60% over the previous quarter and profits doubled.My call is not based on Nvidia having done anything wrong.In fact
column20: it isdoing an enormous amount right.Its graphics chips are finding new markets in cloud data centers and in cars. Its original niche in gaming is the only thing happening in the PC space. Huge new markets in augmented and virtual reality are beckoning. Along withQualcomm
column21: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM)
column22: Nvidia is ending the age ofIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) general purpose microprocessors
column23: replacing it withan era of specialization.The problem is
column24: as our Tim Biggan has observed
column25: that NVDA stock is currently priced for perfection
column26: and perfection is in the eye of the beholder. Any misstep
column27: even an imagined one
column28: can hit a stock hard when it's up 280% in a year.Lots of things could happen. Analysts could decide that meeting expectations is not good enough. They could find a shinier object somewhere else in the market. They could start getting jumpy over a possible trade war
column29: one that has alreadystarted with curbs on visas.Or
column30: perhaps
column31: Nvidia could get intoa spat over licensing of intellectual property
column32: a hot topic wherever silicon chips are made and sold.It's possible.Who Missed the Boat on NVDA Stock?Of course
column33: there is always the chance that this is wishful thinking
column34: as often occurs with hot stocks.Investors and analysts who missed the boat on a stock will talk it down
column35: in hopes that it will drop and they can get on board. This has happened many times with such stocks asAmazon.com
column36: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) andApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL). No tree grows to the sky.For these investors
column37: a fall in Nvidia stock of 15%
column38: to a market cap of about $50 billion - worth 7 times 2017 revenue - would seem more reasonable.Is Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Due for a Correction?What happens in these cases is that a stock will start to fall
column39: and investors will immediately buy it back to its original
column40: overvalued position. Nvidia does make some very hot hardware
column41: it is continually pushing the performance envelope
column42: and it has strong positions in all the fastest-growing markets of our time.This is one of the differences between investing and trading that investors need to understand. Traders want a hot stock to go down
column43: but that desire
column44: or that fact
column45: does not mean a hot company has grown cold.It means that a lot of people who missed a good dealstill want it.NVDA stock may indeed fall after earnings Thursday evening
column46: in other words. But if it does
column47: a lot of investors will be waiting to pick it up and consider it a bargain.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column48: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing
column49: he was long AAPL

column1: If It Weren't For Capital Returns
column2: Apple Would Have Nearly $400 Billion in Cash By Now;2/8/2017;"Here's an interesting factoid: IfApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) had not implemented its capital return program   back in 2012 and consistently updated it in the years since
column3: the   Mac maker would be sitting on nearly $400 billion in cash.That's not to say that I believe Apple's capital returns are a   mistake. Quite the contrary; I'm a huge fan.A numbers gameAs of the end of 2016
column4: Apple had approximately $246 billion in   total cash on the balance sheet. After adjusting for $77 billion   in total term debt
column5: that leaves a net cash position of $169   billion. But that debt load is predominantly there in order to   fund Apple's capital return program
column6: so if we wanted to imagine   how much cash Apple would have absent its capital return program
column7: you need to add the total amount returned cumulatively to date to   the current net cash position. Between dividends
column8: dividend   equivalents
column9: net share settlements
column10: and share repurchases
column11: Apple   has now returned $201 billion total. Here's a breakdown:makeArticleAd();Type of Capital ReturnCumulative ReturnedShare repurchases$144 billionDividends and equivalents$51 billionNet share settlement$6 billionTotal$201 billionData source: Apple.Theoretically adding that all back in to net cash
column12: Apple would   be sitting on $370 billion in cash right about now. If it weren't   already clear
column13: that's an inordinate amount of money and far more   than any company would ever need to operate.To help put the sheer magnitude of that hypothetical figure   into perspective
column14: consider how few companies ever get their   entire market capitalization or enterprise value that high.   That's comparable to the current market caps of peer tech giantsAmazon.com($383 billion) andFacebook($381 billion). That's equal to the entire 2015 GDP of the United   Arab Emirates.Thanks
column15: TimNot only does Apple earn very little on that cash since it   invests very conservatively (in CEO Tim Cook's words from 2013
column16: Apple's investment subsidiary only invests in ""the most conservative investments known to   man"")
column17: but that cash also needlessly inflates Apple's total assets.   This in turn increases the shareholders' equity on the balance   sheet.Tim Cook holding the billionth iPhone. Image source:     Apple.In itself
column18: this isn't cause for concern
column19: but there are many   important performance metrics that investors look at which are   derived from these figures. Ratios like return on assets (ROA) or   return on equity (ROE) come to mind
column20: which suffer and reflect   negatively on management's performance if the denominator is   excessively large for no good reason.Steve Jobs had long been irrationally averse to any type of   capital return program
column21: and Cook's implementation of one is   easily one of the most financially significant things he has done   for investors.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column22: it can pay to listen. After all
column23: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column24: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column25: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Is Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Due for a Correction?;2/8/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThere's no doubt thatApple Inc(NASDAQ:AAPL) has been on fire lately. AAPL stock is up roughly 24% since November
column3: and shares recently popped more than 8% following asolid first-quarter earnings report.makeAd('4'
column5: 'mktsnews'
column6: 'vanguard'
column8: '');Source: ShutterstockIn fact
column9: Apple's year is shaping up to be a banner one - especially if the iPhone supercycle comes to pass for the iPhone 8
column10: as many analysts are predicting.But while the long-term looks rosy for AAPL stock
column11: there is plenty of short-term risk in the shares right now.Click to EnlargeApple's impressive run and earnings surge has put shares well into overbought territory. Additionally
column12: AAPL stock is struggling to pull away from the gravity of $130 - an area rife with heavy options open interest in the February and March series.Furthermore
column13: AAPL stock has outrun support from its 10- and 20-day moving averages - trendlines that provided key support throughout the back half of Apple's late 2016 rally. Currently
column14: the 10-day trendline lies near $125
column15: and a correction back to this region would not be unthinkable should a round of profit taking set in.There are short-term sentiment risks for AAPL stock as well. Thomson/First Call reports that 41 of the 49 analysts following Apple rate the shares a ""buy"" or better
column16: with only one ""sell"" rating to be found.That's plenty of room for adjustment.7 Stocks That Will Drop by 10% or More This QuarterAnd with Apple drawing near to the consensus 12-month price target of $139.07
column17: we could see a few brokerage firms downgrade AAPL stock to hold in the next month or so to bring expectations back in line - similar to what Barclays did back in late January
column18: cutting AAPL to ""equalweight"" from ""overweight.""Looking at Apple options
column19: speculative traders appear to be preparing for just such a correction. Typically
column20: Apple's put/call open interest ratio for the nearest two months rests in the 0.6-0.7 range
column21: with a heavy focus toward call OI. The current February/March ratio
column22: however
column23: rests at 0.9
column24: with puts gaining considerable traction and hinting at potential short-term weakness for AAPL stock.As for the magnitude of the anticipated move
column25: March implieds are pricing in the potential for a nearly 4% rise or fall in Apple stock ahead of expiration. That places the upper bound near $135 and the lower bound near $125.Given Apple's reluctance to continue to move higher in the wake of last week's earnings
column26: a correction to the stock's 10-day moving average near $125 could be in the cards.2 Trades for AAPL StockPut Spread:Those traders looking to profit from a short-term drop in Apple might want to consider a March $125/$130 bear put spread. At last check
column27: this spread was offered at $1.28
column28: or $128 per pair contracts. Breakeven lies at $128.72
column29: while a maximum profit of $3.72
column30: or $372 per pair of contracts
column31: is possible if AAPL stock closes at or below $125 when March options expire.Ride Netflix
column32: Inc. (NFLX) Stock on Its Next Pop HigherPut Sell:If you're not willing to bet directly against Apple  stock at this point - and with the shares on a hot streak now
column33: I wouldn't blame you - then we can turn that put spread into a more neutral play by just selling the March $125 put. At last check
column34: this put was bid at 68 cents
column35: or $68 per contract.As always
column36: the upside to this put sell strategy is that you keep the premium as long as Apple stock closes above $125 when March options expire. The downside is that if AAPL stock trades below $125 ahead of expiration
column37: you could be assigned 100 shares for each sold put at a cost of $125 per share.As of this writing

column1: Apple Inc. Taps Head of Amazon Fire to Run Apple TV (AAPL);2/8/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhenApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) reported its Q1 financials in January
column3: there was little said about Apple TV sales. The poor performance of AAPL's Other Products division - despiterecord setting Apple Watch sales- said it all. However
column4: it looks as though AAPL is turning its focus once again to its often neglected set-top streamer.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleThere's no word of new Apple TV hardware
column5: but the company has made a big move. News just broke that the company hired the former head of rivalAmazon.com
column6: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) Fire TV to take over as marketing vice president for Apple TV.New Apple TV Hire Sends SignalsBloombergreported last night that AAPL has hired Timothy D. Twerdahl as thenew marketing VP for Apple TV. Any new hire for the position would be worth noting
column7: but in this case the company's choice is very interesting.According toBloomberg
column8: Twerdahl came to Apple by way of Amazon
column9: where he headed up the very successful Fire TV unit. Snagging one of your primary competitors is always a bit of a coup
column10: but in this case
column11: Apple's hire has an even more compelling background. Prior to his work with the Fire TV
column12: Twerdahl was an executive withNetflix
column13: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX) and a vice president overseeing consumer devices atRoku.In other words
column14: the new Apple TV boss previously headed up the top two competing video streamers and had a senior position with the world's number one video streaming service. That's a pretty good hire and not one the company would make unless it's serious about goosing those sliding Apple TV sales.7 Tech Stocks With Explosive Growth PotentialBloombergnotes that the previous head of Apple TV marketing is being moved to a role helping to lead AAPL's efforts in securing streaming content deals.Apple TV Needs the PushWhile AAPL's set-top streamer got a sales push with the release of the new fourth-generation Apple TV in 2015
column15: it wasn't able to maintain that momentum. The Apple TV may have games and its own App Store
column16: but unlike the competition
column17: there's no 4K video support and AAPL's box carries a hefty price premium.Even though AAPL doubled its Apple TV sales compared to the previous year when it introduced the new Apple TV in 2015
column18: it still fell short of Roku
column19: Amazon Fire TV andAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOG
column20: NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google Chromecast in market share.AAPL lumps the Apple TV into its Other Products division and doesn't spike out sales numbers. However
column21: in the company's Q1 earnings report
column22: revenue for Other Products declined by 8% year-over-year. Considering that it had a record-setting quarter for Apple Watch sales - the other major product in that division - the numbers point toward poor holiday sales for the Apple TV.No New Apple TV Hardware
column23: YetOf course
column24: even poaching the competition's top guy and someone with the breadth of experience that APPL's new hire appears to have can only go so far without revamping the product.Xiaomi Was Going to Rival Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock -- What Happened?The current
column25: nearly year and a half old
column26: Apple TV carries a huge price premium. AAPL charges a minimum of $149 for its box - double the going rate for competing hardware from Amazon
column27: Google and Roku - and despite the big dollars the Apple TV lacks 4K video support.AAPL was able to shrug that off in 2015 when 4K video was more bleeding edge
column28: but consumers now expect the feature. New content to populate thatTV app hubApple has been showing off won't hurt
column29: but job one for Twerdahl will be dealing with the hardware gap.There's no word on new Apple TV hardware
column30: yet. But with a new VP in place
column31: his predecessor focusing on acquiring additional content and sales continuing to slide
column32: the pressure is on for AAPL to either cut prices or introduce a new
column33: fifth-generation box. Or both.As of this writing
column34: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceApple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Has a New Hero: Services!Is Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Ending the Age of Intel (INTC)?The postApple Inc. Taps Head of Amazon Fire to Run Apple TV (AAPL)appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Nears $100 Billion In Debt: What Does This Mean?;2/8/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsA few days after declaring its earnings
column3: Apple Inc.(AAPL) raised $10 billion indebt. Similar to the bond sales done in the past
column4: this will also be carried out in various tranches with maturities of up to 30 years.makeArticleAd();The bonds will include both fixed rate notes and floaters.Apple Raises Debt a Little Earlier Than UsualThere was nothing much to say about the new bond offering
column5: and it was much like other papers sold by the company every year.However
column6: this time
column7: the company raised bonds a little earlier than the tradition
column8: and it is now nearing $100 billion in debt
column9: according to Evan Niu ofThe Motley Fool.Usually
column10: these bond offerings are announced after the iPhone maker gives updates to its capital return program
column11: which is conducted some time in April or May. However
column12: the company needed to sell the bonds a little early this year due to various reasons. The California-based company started its ninth share repurchase program in the previous quarter
column13: and total share repurchases came at $11 billion.This depleted its cash reserves
column14: and totalcashat the end of the quarter came in at around $15.9 billion. This is the low end of the usual  range of $15 billion to $25 billion that the company keeps for operational and strategic needs
column15: notes Niu.As the company uses debt for capital returns purposes
column16: its total debt taken over the past five years has grown significantly large.By the end of 2016
column17: the iPhone maker had $87.5 billion in long-term debt and commercial paper. With the recently-raised $10 billion
column18: it will total somewhere around $97.5 billion. The debt has an investment-grade rating.12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's PenHowever
column19: in the future
column20: Apple's credit rating profile may deteriorate with a rise in debt levels
column21: notes Niu.Meanwhile
column22: RBC Capital Market analyst Amit Daryanani advises investors to buy Apple stock
column23: as the iPhone maker might increase its capital return to shareholders.RBC Capital Markets maintained its 'Outperform'rating.The analyst said that most investors are assuming that upside is somewhere around $140-$150 at present
column24: but there could be an uptick in the stock on the back of higher capital allocations.""We believe the fundamental reality remains that AAPL's valuation is materially sub-par to what we anticipate its long-termrevenueand EPS potential
column25: Daryanani says.On Monday
column26: Apple shares closed up 0.95% at $131.53. Year to date
column27: the stock is up more than 12%
column28: while in the last year
column29: it is up almost 39%.The postApple Inc. Nearing $100 Billion In Debt: What Does This Mean?appeared first onValueWalk.Many academics claim investing is a ""random walk."" We believe this to be only partially true. It is our core belief that value investing can outperform the market
