column11: we can ""Look for delivery soon.""History of Amazon Prime AirHow can you talk about the history of a service that doesn't yet exist? In the case of Amazon Prime Air and its use of Amazon drones
column12: there's already a big backstory to talk about. AMZNhas a websitewhere it describes the services
column13: shows off a number of Amazon drone videos and even has an FAQ section that spikes out many of the details about Amazon Prime Air.""We're excited about Prime Air - a delivery system from Amazon designed to safely get packages to customers in 30 minutes or less using unmanned aerial vehicles
column14: also called drones. Prime Air has great potential to enhance the services we already provide to millions of customers by providing rapid parcel delivery that will also increase the overall safety and efficiency of the transportation system.""The Amazon Prime Air storykicked off in 2013
column15: when AMZN CEO Jeff Bezos took the wraps off a top secret project with Amazon drones on60 Minutes. Delivery of items under five pounds that would fit in the quadcopter's bucket would take place in under 30 minutes. At the time
column16: Bezos told viewers to expect Amazon Prime Air within four to five years.Last December
column17: a milestone was reached when AMZN claimedthe first Amazon drone delivery- an Amazon Fire TV and a bag of popcorn. As part of an Amazon Prime Air trial in the U.K.
column18: the company's drones had begun autonomously delivering packages to a very small group of consumers.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Has a New Hero: Services!At the end of the year
column19: the company hit the news again when it was discovered it hadfiled a patent for a flying warehousethat would serve as an airborne base for Amazon drone deliveries.When Can You Expect an Amazon Drone atYourWindow?Despite the Super Bowl ad and Alexa's promise that Amazon Prime Air is coming soon
column20: it's a little early to get excited yet. In particular
column21: there are regulatory hurdles to overcome. FAA restrictions on drones that aren't flying in line-of-site operation were the primary reason why the Amazon drone trial is taking place in the U.K. instead of here. AMZN even put up a small disclaimer on its ad:""Prime Air is not available in some states (or any really). Yet.""But the fact that it spent the big Super Bowl ad bucks and showed off that Amazon drone to millions of viewers shows AMZN is serious about this. Amazon Prime Air may not be launching tomorrow
column22: but the company is determined to get people excited about drone delivery. The campaign to turn Amazon drone delivery into the next big thing has officially begun.As of this writing
column23: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceIs Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Ending the Age of Intel (INTC)?Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Steps on Amazon and Google's TurfThe postAmazon.com
column24: Inc. (AMZN) Prime Air Drones Surprise in Super Bowl Adappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column2: Google's Brand Is Not More Valuable Than Apple's;2/5/2017;"Last week
column3: Brand Finance came out with itsannual listing of brand valuations. In a somewhat shocking finding
column4: the consulting group declared   thatApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) had lost its supremacy toAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) subsidiary Google.Alphabet is a phenomenal company with a long track record of   innovation
column5: and the Google brand is extremely powerful.   Nevertheless
column6: it still isn't in the same league as Apple's brand   in terms of total value.Is Apple turning sour?While Brand Finance still rates Apple as the second most   valuable brand in the world
column7: it appears to have a fairly negative   view of the iPhone maker. According to the recent report:makeArticleAd();However
column8: Apple's evangelists are beginning to lose their     faith. The snaking queues of early adopters have shrunk almost     to the point of invisibility. Apple has failed to maintain its     technological advantage and has repeatedly disillusioned its     advocates with tweaks when material changes were expected.Put simply
column9: Apple has over-exploited the goodwill of its     customers
column10: it has failed to generate significant revenues from     newer products such as the Apple Watch and cannot demonstrate     that genuinely innovative technologies desired by consumers are     in the pipeline. Its brand has lost its luster and must now     compete on an increasingly level playing field not just with     traditional rivalSamsung(NASDAQOTH: SSNLF)
column11: but a slew of Chinese brands such as     Huawei and OnePlus in the smartphone market
column12: Apple's key source     of profitability.As a result of this assessment
column13: Brand Finance reduced its   estimate of the Apple brand's value by 27% year over year
column14: to   $107.1 billion. Meanwhile
column15: it estimated Google's brand value at   $109.5 billion
column16: up 24% from $88.2 billion a year ago. Brand   Finance cited Google's dominance in search
column17: among other things
column18: to justify the big increase in its brand value.Consumers are paying more and more for iPhonesBrand Finance's declining opinion of the Apple brand is   contradicted by consumers' willingness to pay more and more for   iPhones. Last quarter
column19: Apple reported record quarterly iPhone   sales of 78.3 million units. Even more impressively
column20: the average   selling price (ASP) reached a new record of $695.The iPhone's ASP hit a new record last quarter. Image     source: Apple.In the same quarter two years ago
column21: right after Apple released   the hugely popular iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus
column22: the iPhone's ASP   had surged 8% year over year
column23: to $687. Apple's ability to   continue growing that ASP over the past two years
column24: despite facing   stiff foreign exchange headwinds in both years
column25: is a testament to   the massive value of its brand.Indeed
column26: the cost of high-quality smartphones is coming down.   Leaving aside Samsung
column27: several Chinese manufacturers have become   known for designing high-quality smartphones and selling them at   near-breakeven prices in recent years. Apple's ability to command   a huge price premium over competitors -- which extends beyond   smartphones to PCs and (to a lesser extent) tablets -- indicates   that its brand is as strong as ever.Apple is a profit machineAccording to Brand Finance
column28: Apple has failed to maintain a   technological lead over Samsung and other rivals. In fact
column29: many   tech pundits have argued in recent years that Samsung has   overtaken Apple in terms of innovation.Assuming that the two companies are on a relatively even   technological footing
column30: they should be able to produce roughly   similar earnings. However
column31: that's not even close to being   true.Last quarter
column32: Apple barely retook the lead in terms of   smartphone shipments with 78.3 million
column33: compared to 77.5 million   shipments for Samsung
column34: according to Strategy Analytics. Yet Samsung's mobile-division operating profit totaled just   $2.1 billion for the quarter. By contrast
column35: Apple's operating   profit was more than 10 times higher at $23.4 billion.On a full-year basis -- or looking just at the smartphone   business -- Apple's advantage is somewhat smaller. But any way   you slice it
column36: Apple generates many times more profit than   Samsung. (In its most recent fiscal year
column37: Apple's operating   profit was $60 billion
column38: compared to about $10 billion for   Samsung's mobile division.)If Apple doesn't have superior technology relative to Samsung
column39: its brand must be doing most of the heavy lifting to generate $50   billion of additional operating profit on an annual basis. That's   more than double Alphabet'stotalannual operating profit of $23.7 billion.Google may be a powerful brand. However
column40: it doesn't come close   to the value of the Apple brand
column41: which has turned the   traditionally low-margin technology hardware business into a   long-term cash cow that churns out tens of billions of dollars of   profit every year.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column42: it can pay to listen. After all
column43: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: Apple Inc. Has Big Plans for Its Fast-Growing Services Business;2/4/2017;"Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) is primarily a hardware company. Most of its   revenue comes from the sale of iPhone
column2: iPad
column3: and Mac products.   Beyond those key product categories
column4: the company generates   meaningful revenue from its Apple Watch family of smartwatch   products
column5: as well as from the various accessories
column6: such as its   well-received AirPod line of wireless earbuds.Apple music running on different Apple products. Image     source: Apple.makeArticleAd();However
column7: one of the most exciting parts of the company's   portfolio is the services business
column8: which the company says   ""includes revenue from Digital Content and Services
column9: AppleCare
column10: Apple Pay
column11: licensing and other services.""This segment has been on a robust growth path for quite some   time
column12: with revenue here growing 10% in the company's fiscal year   2015 and then a whopping 22% in fiscal year 2016. In the   company's most recent quarter
column13: it reported that services revenue   was up another 18% year-over-year.This isn't a small business
column14: either -- at least in absolute   terms. It generated more than $24 billion in the company's last   fiscal year
column15: making up more than 10% of the company's   consolidated revenue. To really put it into proper perspective
column16: services was Apple's second-largest business by revenue in 2016   -- bigger than the iPad and Mac.On the company's most recent earnings call
column17: CEO Tim Cook made   public the company's vision for services over the next four   years
column18: and it's quite ambitious.Doubling revenue in just four years""Services are becoming a larger part of our business
column19: and we   expect the revenues to be the size of a Fortune 100 company this   year""
column20: Cook said.Cook then went on to say that Apple ""feel[s] great about this   momentum"" and that the company aims to ""double the size of [its]   Services business in the next four years"".Of course
column21: what Apple's goals are and what happens aren't   necessarily the same thing
column22: but the fact that management is   willing to put a growth figure out there -- a hard number that   investors will now hold Apple accountable for -- speaks to the   company's confidence.What would a doubling of this business mean?Put simply
column23: doubling the business from the revenue levels seen   in 2016 would mean that
column25: Apple's services business will   be bringing in about $48 billion. If Apple can get the business   to that scale and then grow it at a modest rate from that point   forward (perhaps 5% to 10% annually)
column26: then that would do wonders   for Apple's longer-term revenue growth prospects.What's not entirely clear
column27: however
column28: is how that growth will   translate into incremental profitability. CFO Luca Maestri said   on the call that
column29: on average
column30: the gross profit margin of Services   businesses ishigherthan the corporate average
column31: so an increase in Services mix should   help Apple on the gross profit margin front.That said
column32: as Apple scales up its services revenue
column33: it will   likely need to drive up operating expenses associated with the   business
column34: as well. While I do expect nice growth in profitability   from a boost in services
column35: the incremental gross profit isn't all   flowing to the bottom line.At the end of the day
column36: if Apple hits its growth target with   respect to this growing segment
column37: it should be less dependent on   the iPhone and could ultimately see earnings multiple expansion   as software/services companies tend to be valued more by   investors than pure hardware plays.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column38: it can pay to listen. After all

column1: Will Donald Trump Target Share Buybacks Next?;2/4/2017;"Donald Trump. Image source: Whitehouse.gov.President Donald Trump has taken several bold steps since   taking office
column2: but one area seems to be a bigger priority than   any other. Trump has been adamant about getting American   companies to invest in the U.S. by building factories and plants   and hiring American workers. In his inaugural address
column3: he   declared that as a central theme of his presidency
column4: imploring   American companies to ""buy American and hire American.""makeArticleAd();Before he even took the oath of office
column5: Trump said he had   struck a deal withUnited Technologies'Carrier Industries to keep about 800 jobs in Indiana that were   slated to go to Mexico. He pressured other manufacturers like   automakers to keep jobs in the country
column6: and may have influencedFord'sdecision to scrap plans for a new plant in Mexico.Once in office
column7: Trump backed out of the Trans Pacific   Partnership
column8: a 12-nation trade deal
column9: and met with leaders of the   Big 3 automakers to urge them to expand in the U.S.While those moves may help curry the favor of Trump's base
column10: their effect on investment in the U.S. is uncertain. The   automakers already believe that the auto market is at its   cyclical peak
column11: as last year marked a record for vehicle sales
column12: and they are therefore reluctant to invest in new factories.Manufacturing jobs have certainly declined over the past   generation
column13: but analysts tend to blame that on automation rather   than outsourcing.Trump has supported tax breaks that would encourage companies   to bring back money kept overseas. Some see this as step one to   getting the companies to invest in American jobs. Others see it   as priming the companies to use the money to buy back their own   shares. Larry Fink
column14: BlackRock founder and CEO and a member of   Trump's ""President's Strategic and Policy Forum
column15: recently warned   that companies should only engage in buybacks ""when they are   confident that the return on those buybacks will ultimately   exceed the cost of capital and the long-term returns of investing   in future growth.""Fink mentioned Trump by name twice in his Jan. 24annual letter to CEOs
column16: saying in part:If tax reform also includes some form of reduced taxation     for repatriation of cash trapped overseas
column17: BlackRock will be     looking to companies' strategic frameworks for an explanation     of whether they will bring cash back to the U.S.
column18: and if so
column19: how they plan to use it. Will it be used simply for more share     buybacks? Or is it a part of a capital plan that appropriately     balances returning capital to shareholders with prudently     investing for future growth?President Trump has indicated an interest in infrastructure     investment
column20: which has the dual benefits of improving overall     productivity and creating jobs
column21: especially for workers     displaced by technology.Fink went on to write that infrastructure investing is not a   solution to automation taking jobs
column22: saying ""businesses will need   to increase the earnings potential of the workers who drive   returns
column23: helping the employee who once operated a machine learn   to program it.""Trump has showed himself committed to American jobs. We don't   know if he will use his bully pulpit to try to force companies to   forgo buybacks
column24: but he might if he follows the logic that doing   so would result in the companies instead putting the money to use   in ways that would boost American workers. Let's take a look at   the issue.A Wall Street favoriteShare repurchases
column25: orbuybacks
column26: in which a company buys share of its own stock
column27: were once   illegal
column28: as they were seen as facilitating insider trading   because a company could act on information not available to the   public. The SEC changed the rule in 1982
column29: and since then
column30: stock   buybacks have become increasingly popular. According toHSBC
column31: American companies have spent $2.1 trillion on repurchases over   the last five years.Often called a form of financial engineering by detractors
column32: share buybacks boost a company's earnings per share
column33: not by   increasing earnings
column34: but by reducing the number of shares   outstanding. The pie is split among fewer shares. Investors to   tend to cheer share buybacks due to the lift they give to stock   prices
column35: but from a larger economic perspective
column36: and possibly from   Donald Trump's point of view
column37: they may be the least efficient   form of spending cash.Image source: Getty Images.By allocating money to buy back shares
column38: business are choosing   to spend profits on inflating earnings per share instead of   potentially investing in the long-term growth of the business by   opening new plants
column39: hiring or training new workers
column40: investing in   research and development
column41: or even acquiring other companies.   Unlike dividends
column42: the other from of returning capital to   shareholders
column43: buybacks don't give money to current shareholders   that can be reinvested
column44: and they do not add market value to the   company
column45: which is based in part on the number of shares   outstanding. In other words
column46: no value is being created by   repurchases in the aggregate.  Share repurchases are   controversial for a number of reasons
column47: but their ability to   dissuade companies from investing in long-term growth is   certainly one of the biggest.How the pros do itWith interest rates especially low in recent years
column48: many   companies have taken on debt
column49: not to expand their businesses
column50: but   to reward shareholders with buybacks.Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) founder Steve Jobs refused to pay a dividend
column51: believing that it meant the company was out of ideas. He also   didn't authorize share repurchases.Apple under Tim Cook
column52: however
column53: has taken out $87 billion in   debt to fund repurchases
column54: reducing the share count by 1.3 billion   in the process
column55: and spending about $125 billion in the process.   Part of the reason Apple has done so is because much of its cash   is parked overseas and it wants to avoid repatriation taxes
column56: but   one could see the Trump administration cutting a deal with the   iPhone maker to reduce or eliminate repatriation taxes if it   agreed to invest in jobs in the U.S.Apple
column57: with nearly $200 billion overseas
column58: has been demanding   such an arrangement for years
column59: and could be willing to invest   some of that cash in the U.S. if the tax rate was significantly   reduced. Notably FoxConn
column60: its biggest supplier
column61: said it was   considering opening a plant in Pennsylvania that would employ   50
column62: 000 Americans. Apple is unlikely itself to invest in domestic   manufacturing
column63: but since FoxConn assembles iPhones and other   Apple products
column64: if it opened a plant in Pennsylvania
column65: it would   mean that some Apple products would be made in America
column66: though   outsourced to a Chinese company.Trump has said he would like to make deals with corporations   to bring some of their overseas cash back home
column67: though that would   likely come with stipulations.Goldman Sachspredicted Trump's tax and repatriation plans would encourage more   buybacks as it frees up cash for companies
column68: but BlackRock's Fink   scolded corporations in his recent letter for spending so much on   buybacks.He noted that the total thatS&P 500companies have spent on dividends and buybacks in the last   12 months is greater than the operating profits they've   earned. With $5 trillion in assets under management
column69: the   Blackrock CEO's missives attract attention on Wall Street
column70: and if   he gets the President's ear
column71: Trump could end up using the bully   pulpit to excoriate big business for its excessive buybacks.IBM's(NYSE: IBM) recent misadventures perhaps best illustrate the   folly of buybacks. After outlining a goal in 2010 of reaching $20   in earnings per share (EPS) by 2015
column72: Big Blue spent aggressively   on repurchases to pump up EPS to meet that target
column73: pouring $70   billion between 2010-2014 into lowering its share count. As a   result
column74: however
column75: the business suffered.Revenue at the tech giant has now fallen for 19 quarters in a   row
column76: and the company was forced to step back from its $20 EPS   goal in 2014. In 2016
column77: adjusted EPS was just $13.59
column78: down 9% from   the previous year. In the meantime
column79: IBM has also slashed   headcount as the number of employees has fallen by close to   100
column81: since its peak in 2014
column82: to 368
column83: 000. Considering Big   Blue's decision to use profits to reward investors while laying   off employees
column84: the company would seem to be a target ripe for   Trump's ire.It's not just tech companies that are using this tactic
column85: as   manufacturers likeGM
column86: Ford
column87: andCaterpillarhave all been spending on share repurchases recently.Any attempt by the Trump administration to tackle share   repurchases would likely rankle Wall Street
column88: which favors the   practice. But as the president looks for more levers to pull to   boost the ""forgotten men and women"" of America
column89: share buybacks   may start to look like a worthy target.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column1: Why This 1 Number Is So Important to Apple Investors;2/3/2017;"Image source: Apple.The iPhone is by far the most important product inApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) lineup. The device accounted for over 69% of the   company's first-quarter sales. After three consecutive quarters   of unit sales declines
column2: Apple righted the ship with the release   of the iPhone 7 last fall
column3: driving a near-5% increase in unit   sales.makeArticleAd();But more important than the growth in units is Apple's ability   to sell its higher-end device
column4: the iPhone 7 Plus. CEO Tim Cook   revealed the newest model was the best selling Plus model it's   released yet during the company's first-quarter earnings call.   The ability to sell higher-end devices is key for the company   going forward as it becomes increasingly difficult to grow unit   sales.A look at selling pricesData source: Apple quarterly reports.The first thing that stands out in the chart above is the huge   drop in average sales price (ASP) during the previous three   quarters. The drop coincides with the release of the lower-priced   iPhone SE
column5: which starts at just $399. After a late second-quarter   release
column6: sales of the model seemed to peak in the third quarter
column7: resulting in a low $595 ASP for all iPhone units.Apple also faced significant foreign exchange headwinds over   the past year. CFO Luca Maestri noted the dollar has strengthened   25% against the basket of currencies where Apple does business   since June 2014. That led Apple to raise some of its prices in   foreign countries last year.But more iPhone shoppers opted for the high-end iPhone 7 Plus   last quarter
column8: leading to a record ASP of $695. That's even more   astonishing considering the inclusion of the iPhone SE in those   sales.What's so telling about the popularity of the iPhone 7   Plus?Unlike in the two previous Plus models of the iPhone
column9: the 7   Plus included a higher-end camera compared to its   smaller-screened sister. That point of differentiation may be   what led more consumers to opt for the more expensive device last   quarter.The significant demand for the 7 Plus shows that Apple has the   potential to drive sales growth by further differentiating the   Plus lineup from the standard iPhone model. Instead of just   offering a larger screen
column10: Apple can keep its best innovations   exclusively for its highest-paying customers before letting them   trickle down to the lower-priced models.Such a move would strengthen the position of the Plus model in   the simple good
column11: better
column12: best price positioning Apple uses. Just   as importantly
column13: the upsell is easy thanks to installment plans --   just $4 more per month gets you the best ever phone
column14: camera

column17: and so on.But don't get excited just yetThere's no doubt that Apple benefited from one of its biggest   competitors running into some technical difficulties late last   year.Samsung(NASDAQOTH: SSNLF) had to recall its Galaxy Note 7 after units   started randomly exploding due to battery malfunctions.Many Note 7 customers likely ended up buying an iPhone 7 Plus   for its similarly sized screen. Cook noted it saw the highest   Android switcher rate of any quarter.Obviously
column18: Apple can't rely on Samsung or one of its other   major competitors having problems with their large-screen phones   every quarter. That's why investors must pay attention to the   iPhone ASP going forward to see if last quarter was a fluke or if   Apple's differentiation strategy is paying off. If ASP continues   to rise

column1: Why 2 Well-Known Tech Companies Are Making Significant AI Acquisitions;2/3/2017;"With the race for artificial intelligence (AI) shifting into   high gear
column2: companies are not only developing AI systems in-house
column3: but are increasingly bringing start-ups into the fold to augment   their efforts. Market intelligence firm CB Insights released its   list ofAI acquisitionsover the last five years. A review of the most active acquirers   can provide insight into future developments at those companies
column4: and show how the new technologies are being integrated.Artificial intelligence acquisitions are skyrocketing. Image     source: Pixabay.makeArticleAd();One intriguing revelation is that many of the acquired   companies work in the areas of deep learning and machine   learning
column5: two disciplines within AI. Algorithms and software are   used to develop models of the human brain called neural networks
column6: attempting to recreate our capacity to learn. Another revelation   is that much of the acquired technology can be directly   integrated intovirtual personal assistants. This is an area of great interest to big tech
column7: but is alsobeing pursuedby a surprising number ofother companies.Apple is on an AI buying spree. Image source: Author.Apple is giving Siri a makeoverApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) has been at the leading edge of AI since its   introduction of Siri five years ago. While it is making a   significant number of acquisitions
column8: each appears to specialize in   a different area:VocalIQ concentrated its deep-learning capabilities to     better understand human speech. This could provide Siri with an     upgrade.Perceptio can run neural-network algorithms and perform     advanced calculations locally on a cellphone
column9: without uploading     user data to the cloud. This would help Apple protect consumer     data bykeeping it localto each phone.Emotient attempts to read facial expressions in order to     determine a person's emotional state. This recent acquisition     is likely related to apatent Apple applied forin 2014
column10: describing a system for determining mood based on     numerous factors
column11: including facial expressions.Tuplejump provided a better way to apply deep learning to     large data sets as they are uploaded. Apple has previously     stated that it could receive filtered data from iPhones
column12: and     this technology would enable it to process the data in real     time.One especially compelling acquisition was Turi
column13: described as a   ""machine learning platform for developers and data scientists.""   It had created tools that allowed developers to build apps   utilizing deep learning that could scale for many users; this   tool kit was described as being similar to Google's TensorFlow   open-source machine-learning library. Turi allows Apple to bring   AI capabilities to developers for its App Store offerings.Twitter wants a seat at the big tech tableTwitter acquired Whetlab to boost AI efforts. Image source:     Whetlab.Twitter(NYSE:TWTR) has made a number of AI-related acquisitions in the area of   machine learning. Each appears to provide the company with   specific opportunities to improve its current business:Madbits focused on technology related to searching and     understanding images
column14: and the ability to organize large data     sets. It previously released an iOS app that created photo     collages.Magic Pony developed neural networks that can sharpen     blurry cellphone images or video to near HD-quality. It also     can use information in the original to improvise new or     expanded images -- great for use in virtual reality. These will     both help Twitter increase its image features.TellApart allows marketers to better target potential     customers across device platforms. This could improve     monetization of Twitter's ads.Whetlab is probably the most interesting acquisition. While it   is less business-specific
column15: it will bring the most advanced AI   capability. It created technology that helps companies jump-start   their deep learning by providing an infrastructure; the time   required to train AI systems is reduced from months to days. This   technology can be used to improve a variety of areas in Twitter's   business
column16: including language understanding
column17: image recognition
column18: and user profiles.These acquisitions reveal how two very different technology   companies are integrating AI with a goal of improving their   respective businesses. Acquisitions for their own sake are folly
column19: but using them to gain a competitive advantage
column20: improve business   processes
column21: or to better serve customers can lead to success. Time   will tell how successful each of these companies has been in   leveraging these technologies.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Apple (AAPL) On Track to "Make in India" by April 2017?;2/3/2017;"Reportedly
column2: AppleAAPLwill set up its iPhone assembly line in India by the end of Apr 2017. The iPhone-maker will set up its first manufacturing unit in Bangalore
column3: Karnataka and has teamed up with Wistron Corp. from Taiwan to take care of the assembly of the iPhones.Why India?The decision comes at a time when the smartphone market is witnessing a slowdown in other parts of the world except India
column4: which remains the fastest growing market in the segment.With Narendra Modi at the helm
column5: the tagline of ""Make in India"" is fast catching up with global manufacturing majors. The Apple deal could open the doors for other global players to set up their manufacturing units in the country.However
column6: China still remains a major contender in the manufacturing space.Apple Inc. Price and ConsensusApple Inc. Price and Consensus|Apple Inc. QuoteWhat Does This Mean for Apple?Currently
column7: the smartphone scene in India is being dominated by Samsung Electronics Co. and other comparatively cheap Chinese brands such as Oppo.As per a Counterpoint Research report
column9: Apple shipped 2.5 million iPhones to India. However
column10: the company ranked 10thin the top smartphone vendors list for the December quarter. An estimated 750 million smartphones are projected to be sold in the country by 2020
column11: where Apple currently has only a 2% market share.As per capita income in the country is on the rise
column12: this trend is likely to witness a major shift with people turning to premium-priced phones such as the iPhone in the future.Moreover
column13: Apple's strategy to remain a fabless firm by handing over capital intensive processes such as manufacturing
column14: factory building and staff hiring to third parties (in this case Wistron Corp.) are expected to positively impact the company's bottom-line going ahead.Stock Performance OverviewShares of Apple have performed more or less in line with the broader ZacksComputer - Mini Computersindustry over the last one year. While the industry gained 33.1%
column15: the stock gained 32.7%The in-line performance of the stock could be primarily attributed to good growth in its services revenues
column16: especially with regard to Apple Music and App Store. However
column17: as mentioned above
column18: the company is seeing sluggish demand for its flagship offering
column19: the iPhone in major markets worldwide. Also
column20: intensifying competition and macroeconomic headwinds remain concerns for the company.Zacks Rank & Key PicksAt present

column25: the consensus estimate for Acxiom's current year has remained stable at 29 cents over the last 60 days.Similarly
column26: the consensus estimate for Aspen's current year has improved to $1.67 from $1.62 over the last seven days.Also
column27: the consensus estimate for Inphi's current year has remained stable at 85 cents over the last 90 days.The Best Place to Start Your Stock SearchToday

column1: The Zacks Friday Finish Line Highlights: An Investors Preview of Super Bowl LI;2/3/2017;"For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column2: IL-February 3

column9: the biggest television extravaganza of the year.AppleThe first earnings report that Maddy and Ryan highlighted came from Apple Inc.AAPL. The iPhone maker beat estimates on both the top and bottom lines

column11: showing year-over-year growth after three consecutive quarters of declines.FacebookNext up was Facebook'sFBfourth quarter earnings report. The social media giant again posted impressive earnings and revenue results
column12: beating expectations on both fronts. Facebook also saw continued daily and monthly user growth
column13: as well as a huge bump in mobile advertising revenue.AmazonThe hosts then moved on to recap Amazon'sAMZNfourth quarter earnings. The e-commerce king reported mixed results

column15: however

column17: showing strong year-over-year growth.Super Bowl LIFinally

column1: 3 Interesting Things We Learned From Snapchat's IPO Prospectus;2/3/2017;"Snap Inc.
column2: the parent company of photo-sharing application Snapchat
column3: recently filed a prospectus with the SEC and is officially gearing up for an initial public offering. Snapchat has taken the social media landscape by storm since its debut in 2012
column4: and with private valuations hitting nearly $25 billion
column5: investors should be anticipating what could be the biggest tech IPO of the year.Snapchat co-founder and CEO Evan Spiegel
column6: alongside fellow founder and CTO Bobby Murphy
column7: will lead his company through this important period. At just 26 and 28 years of age
column8: Spiegel and Murphy are set to become some of the wealthiest under-30s in the world after Snap Inc. debuts; just how much their net worths will swell depends on how big the company's IPO can get
column9: and we got a better sense of this size from its recent prospectus filing.(Also Read:Inside Snapchat: The Best Tech IPO of 2017?)The prospectus contained tons of juicy information
column10: including key financial and membership data. For example
column11: we learned that Snapchat now has about 158 million average daily active users and its annual revenue swelled to $404.4 million in 2016. We also know that Snapchat plans to list its shares in March under the ticker ""SNAP."" The company filed for $3 billion debut
column12: but this is expected to be a placeholder until Snap Inc. prices the deal.All of this information is important to know and understand as investors think about investing in Snapchat at its IPO. However
column13: the juiciest details in the prospectus were ones that not every investor expected to see or knew to look for. Check out these three key facts that you may have missed:1.It's a ""camera company"" … kind ofWhile most people would consider Snapchat a social media company
column14: its prospectus proudly proclaimed that ""Snap Inc. is a camera company."" In the sense that Snapchat is inherently interested in its users' phone cameras
column15: this is a logical statement; however
column16: Snapchat is certainly not-nor does it seem interested in becoming-a major manufacturer of camera-based hardware.Sure
column17: the company recently debuted its own line of camera-equipped sunglasses called ""Spectacles
column18: but as its prospectus points out
column19: 96% of revenue comes from advertising and that is unlikely to change soon. Do you know any other ""camera companies"" that rely on advertising revenue? Not really
column20: which means Snapchat's labeling of itself as a ""camera company"" is more about its focus on the importance of the camera as a communicative device
column21: not its business model.2.Mysterious third founder is goneThose who have followed Snapchat since its earliest days are probably already familiar with the impressive leadership of Spiegel and Murphy. However
column22: every Snapchat-related story seems to include a mention of Reggie Brown
column23: Snapchat's mysterious third founder who reportedly came up with the idea of disappearing photos.While we knew that Brown was no longer at the company
column24: the prospectus finally revealed the full details on the situation
column25: and it is a classic case of ""hush money"" that resembles the Winklevoss-Zuckerberg fiasco. According to the filing
column26: Brown sued the company over intellectual property violations in February 2013. The parties involved eventually settled in September 2014
column27: with Snap Inc. agreeing to pay Brown about $158 million in cash.3.They know their competitionOne of the key elements of a prospectus for a company like Snap Inc. is the information the company shares about its perceived challenges within its own industry. In that regard
column28: it is clear that Snapchat is acutely aware of its competitors right now.The company underscores the dangers of competitors that ""mimic"" Snapchat's features throughout the report
column29: and it uses a rhetoric of caution to describe the businesses that challenge it.""Many of our current and potential competitors have significantly greater resources and broader global recognition and occupy better competitive positions in certain markets than we do
column30: the prospectus said
column31: identifying FacebookFB
column32: AppleAAPL
column33: Alphabet Inc.GOOGL
column34: LINELN
column35: Twitter (TWTR)
column36: and many others as key foes.Final DetailsStartups like Snapchat benefit greatly from keeping their books closed and operating under the cover of being private
column37: but the era is nearly over for Snap Inc.
column38: and the company will soon have many new shareholders to please.Looking ahead
column39: we can expect a SNAP offering in March
column40: and pricing details should come closer to that time. Other than that
column41: we know that SNAP will be listed on the NYSE and some of the world's biggest banks
column42: including Morgan StanleyMS
column43: Goldman SachsGS
column44: JPMorganJPM
column45: Deutsche BankDB
column46: BarclaysBCS
column47: and Credit SuisseCS
column48: are working on the deal.Which Stocks are Zacks Experts Talking   About?Stocks in today's headlines may be tempting buys

column1: Friday Apple Rumors: AAPL is Facing a FaceTime Lawsuit;2/3/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of a lawsuit over FaceTime. Today
column3: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Friday.makeArticleAd();Source: Martin HajekFaceTime Lawsuit:Apple is facing a new lawsuit that claims it intentionally hurt FaceTime for iOS 6
column4: reportsMacRumors. According to the lawsuit
column5: AAPL allegedly placed a bug in FaceTime for iOS 6 in an effort to force users to upgrade to iOS 7. The lawsuit claims that this was done so that the company could avoid fees to Akami
column6: which handled the service in iOS 6. The release of iOS 7 saw the tech company introduce new peer-to-peer tech that didn't require Akami for use.LG UltraFine Fix:A new version of the LG UltraFine 5K display will fix issues with the device
column7: AppleInsidernotes. The new versions of the LG UltraFine 5K display will feature additional shielding to protect the devices from interference with routers. The company also says that it will put the additional shielding in current models of the display as well. It hasn't announced how it will do this yet. The problem with the current LG UltraFine 5K displays has them not working properly when near routers.BeatsX Launch: Apple is reportedly getting ready to launch its BeatsX headphones
column8: reports 9to5Mac. The BeatsX has faced a long delay after being announced at the same time as the iPhone 7. The delay had the company pushing back the launch to February. Now there are reports that the headphones will launch as soon as this week. The headphones will cost $149 when they launch.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postFriday Apple Rumors: AAPL is Facing a FaceTime Lawsuitappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 3 Tech Stocks That Will Win as Qualcomm Collapses;2/3/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIt's often stated by motivational speakers that the Chinese word for ""crisis"" is composed of two characters - one signifying danger
column3: the other opportunity. It's alsoembarrassingly inaccurate. This goes to show you that if the crux of an investment argument invokes ""the Chinese
column4: stop! You might be getting had. Still
column5: this ""Chinese philosophy"" is extremely relevant for tech stocks these days.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThat's because semiconductor and digital communications giantQualcomm
column6: Inc. (NASDAQ:QCOM) is having a year to forget. Despite the fact that it's only early February
column7: QCOM shares are down 18.5% year-to-date. Not surprisingly
column8: Qualcomm is trading firmly below its 50- and 200-day moving averages. If something substantive doesn't happen soon
column9: it risks repeating the disaster of 2015
column10: when QCOM lost nearly 31%.The disaster that Qualcomm is currently facing was seen well in advance by those watching the industry closely. The crux of the issue is the company's technology licensing business. This is themost lucrativedivision for QCOM
column11: accounting for the majority of its profits. By ""selling the rights to use patents that are essential to all modern mobile phone systems
column12: QCOM had a monopoly. That's an incredible opportunity
column13: so long as you don't get caught.Of course
column14: they got caught. First
column15: it was
column16: you guessed it - the Chinese. Regulators in the world's second-biggest economy found Qualcomm guilty of violating theiranti-monopoly law. Then
column17: individual companies began filing complaints. Finally
column18: the Federal Trade Commission got involved in mid-January
column19: claiming that QCOM illegally maintained a monopoly. Shares never looked the same after that
column20: and who knows when Qualcomm will recover.Those are questions that analysts will squabble over. But for rival tech stocks
column21: they only have one message - better you than me. It's not just the fact that a major competitor is falling. This is a classic case where an enemy of an enemy is a friend. Furthermore
column22: the benchmarkTechnology SPDR (ETF)(NYSEARCA:XLK) is up 4.6% YTD. Granted
column23: these aren't the best numbers
column24: but it's much more preferable than what Qualcomm is going through.The Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryWhile QCOM is swimming with the sharks
column25: here are three tech stocks that are now set up to win big!Tech Stocks That Will Win as QCOM Falls: Apple Inc. (AAPL)Click to EnlargeUndoubtedly
column26: of all the tech stocks that were affected by Qualcomm
column27: Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) stands to be the biggest winner.On Jan. 20
column28: AAPL filed suit against Qualcomm
column29: alleging that the company ""withheld $1 billion in rebates in retaliation for Apple cooperating with Korean efforts to open the radio chip market."" Although it's difficult to call a stalwart like AAPL a ""victim
column30: the pattern of allegations is pretty damning.First
column31: we already saw Qualcomm violate foreign anti-competition laws
column32: and pay dearly for it. Second
column33: Korean manufacturerSamsung Electronics Co. Ltd(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) alleged similar shenanigans
column34: although they later backed down. Finally
column35: and most importantly
column36: the FTC claimed that Qualcomm forced AAPL to use their chips to prevent competitor encroachment. For Qualcomm
column37: Applr is its biggest customer
column38: so the potential ramifications are deep and wide.Of course
column39: Cupertino isn't going to shed any tears.Last October
column40: AAPL ""reported its first decline in annual sales and profit in 15 years
column41: according toThe Guardian. There are serious concerns that the king of consumer tech stocks has reached peak popularity. Whatever it is
column42: Apple needs to boost its profitability. Getting out of unfavorable contracts is a good start.And with the world seemingly against Qualcomm
column43: AAPL has an excellent chance of reviving itself at their expense.Tech Stocks That Will Win as QCOM Falls: Intel Corporation (INTC)Click to EnlargeAlthough I believe that Apple will get the most benefit out of the QCOM fiasco
column44: Intel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) has a strong case as well. I wouldn't be surprised if most people viewed it as a toss-up between the two titans.Among tech stocks
column45: INTC is one of the most recognizable
column46: but for the wrong reasons. Everybody knows the ""Intel Inside"" slogan
column47: but the only problem is that it relates to the aging personal computer business.It's a common challenge for consumer tech stocks - INTC needs to find new blood. The company'srevenue growthisn't the most consistent in the world. That's why the partnership last year between Intel and AAPL was a much-needed step in the right direction. Up until that point
column48: Qualcomm was the sole provider of chips for the iPhone.In 2016
column49: INTC stepped in to provide half the demand. Apparently
column50: QCOM took exception to this arrangement; hence
column51: the FTC charges of competitive foul play.So far
column52: the market response towards Intel stock has been mixed. Therefore
column53: I still give the advantage to Apple. Nevertheless
column54: encouraging signs do exist. Yes
column55: shares are down 4% from its high of the year. However
column56: it's still very close to parity for the year. Furthermore
column57: INTC remains inside a bullish trend channel that began in late summer of 2015.7 Stocks to Sell as Fear Returns to the MarketThe collapse at Qualcomm just gives other tech stocks more options
column58: and Intel is happy to help.Tech Stocks That Will Win as QCOM Falls: Broadcom Ltd (AVGO)Click to EnlargeWhile virtually all tech stocks are affected by the Qualcomm crisis
column59: few were as glued to their TV screens asBroadcom Ltd(NASDAQ:AVGO).As a semiconductor and communications company themselves
column60: AVGO is a direct competitor and rival to QCOM.Naturally
column61: if your primary nemesis goes down hard
column62: it raises the boat for everyone else. And Qualcomm is sinking quite nicely for the Singapore-based firm.It's not just the fact that QCOM has transitioned into the world's most hated stock. Nor is it the money that they'll have to dish out in penalties. Rather
column63: Qualcomm will be forced to fundamentally change its business plan. If it doesn't
column64: government watchdogs are on standby
column65: eager to pounce. That just gives AVGO and others a leg up. Maybe Broadcom is no saint. However
column66: at the moment
column67: the spotlight isn't on it
column68: providing a margin of comfort.Most importantly
column69: AVGO is making the most of its ""Chinese crisis."" On a YTD basis
column70: shares are up a smoking 16% - that's almost the exact inverse of Qualcomm's results. Furthermore
column71: Broadcom is trending inside a steadily rising channel. With so much ugliness associated with its primary rival
column72: it's hard not to see anything but optimism for AVGO.As of this writing
column73: Josh Enomoto did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.The post3 Tech Stocks That Will Win as Qualcomm Collapsesappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: If You Like Apple Inc.
column2: You’ll Love Skyworks Solutions Inc (AAPL
column3: SWKS);2/3/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsSuccessful stock market investing over the long term takes skills in several disciplines. First
column5: you need to be able to think outside of the box by looking behind the headline stocks into lesser-known names operating behind the scenes.makeArticleAd();Now
column6: I am certainly not saying to avoid the headline names. Getting in early on a favorite stock is a sure way to stock market profits. But often
column7: once a stock starts making mainstream news headlines it's upward price momentum is about to slow or fail altogether.Identifying companies that support one or a combination of headline names yet do not get the same attention as the headliner is a consistent way to locate winning stocks for the long term.Once you locate your behind-the-news stock
column8: it's time to take a close look at its fundamentals to make certain there is support behind the price move. Are the fundamentals improving over time? Are revenue and sales upward-trending from quarter to quarter? Do the products and services support an overall societal or economic trend? These are the basic questions to answer before making an investing decision.Next
column9: make certain the share price is in an overall upward trend. This means judging whether the shares higher over the last year and by how much they are up relative to the headline name.Ideally
column10: the stock should be outpacing the headliner price-performance wise and consistently making new highs on the daily price chart.I like stocks that are trading at or near their highs for one of my favorite investing tactics
column11: trend following.I define trend following as buying stocks as they make new highs
column12: then riding the upward trend and protecting profits via trailing stops. Certainly
column13: there are many permutations of this basic method
column14: such as waiting for a short term pullback to enter long
column15: but for the purpose of this article
column16: buying breakouts to new highs will suffice.The ideal trend-following stock isSkyworks Solutions Inc(SWKS). This stock holds the key to the future of the Internet of Things. It has soared over 42% in the last 52 weeks
column17: and the company just keeps outperforming. With both strong fundamentals and robust technicals
column18: if there ever was a stock made to order for the trend-following investing method
column19: this is the one.The Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryI found this company by first noticing that thatApple Inc.(AAPL) shares had posted over 35% gains in the last 52 weeks
column20: despite the apparent slowdown in iPhone sales. This observation led me to look behind the headlines to see what companies Apple depends on as suppliers.Skyworks jumped out immediately
column21: as it obtains approximately 40% of its revenue from Apple
column22: and is also a supplier to Apple's Chinese smartphone competitors such as Huawei.The fact that shares of Skyworks had skyrocketed around 42% over the last year truly piqued my interest
column23: and here's why…Skyworks specializes in connecting devices and technology
column24: and experts are predicting there will be 70 billion internet connected devices by 2020. Called the Internet of Things
column25: this burgeoning new web structure is expected to grow exponentially into the near future.Skyworks Solutions
column26: Inc. officially describes itself as an analog semiconductor company powering the wireless networking revolution. Its innovative products are connecting people
column27: places and things. These objects span some new and previously unimagined applications within the automotive
column28: broadband
column29: cellular infrastructure
column30: connected home
column31: industrial
column32: medical
column33: military
column34: smartphone
column35: tablet and wearable markets.The company posted strong results for its first fiscal quarter
column36: with revenue for the first fiscal quarter at $914.3 million
column37: up 9.4 percent sequentially and exceeding consensus estimates of $902.7 million.Operating income for the first fiscal quarter of 2017 was $321.9 million with diluted earnings per share of $1.38. Cash flow from operations for the quarter was also a record $495.9 million.""Skyworks delivered exceptional financial results in the first fiscal quarter of 2017 fueled by global demand for ubiquitous mobile connectivity and the Internet of Things
column38: said Liam K. Griffin
column39: president and chief executive officer of Skyworks. ""We are enabling the next phase of the wireless revolution
column40: powering new and previously unimagined applications… Skyworks is uniquely positioned to capitalize on this connectivity megatrend.""The company also positively guided that it will beat consensus revenue and non-GAAP EPS estimates in its fiscal second quarter.Even better
column41: the company just launched a $500 million stock buyback program that should further accelerate the upward price trend.Risks To Consider:Whenever one is investing in high tech
column42: there is always a competitive risk. New companies with innovative products cause disruption in the high-tech sector on a consistent basis. The disruption can dethrone leading firms and cause havoc to share prices.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Smartwatch Is Still Dominant Despite All the DoubtAction To Take:Following the trend following theme
column43: enter long on an upside break of $93.00 per share with an upside target of $135.00 per share. Initial stops are suggested at $83.00 per share.Editor's Note:These are ourTop 10 ""win-win"" stocksfor a chaotic 2017. No matter what Trump does (or how the markets respond) these stocks are poised to soar into double-digit gains over the next few months.Check out the list here…StreetAuthority's mission is to help individual investors earn above-average profits by providing a source of independent

column1: How Options Traders Nailed Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Earnings;2/3/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIn a market known for its power of perfect pricing
column4: nowhere is that more obvious than inAmazon.com
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN). But if you're looking for answers from AMZN stock
column6: that's only one-half of this puzzling confirmation.makeArticleAd();Source: AmazonIf you're an Amazon shareholder
column7: Friday's early morning low of $801 - off more than 4% - wasn't exactly money in the bank. AMZN stock is on the defensive followinglast night's earnings release
column8: which put investors into profit-taking mode.AMZN Stock by the NumbersAmazon reported better-than-expected profits of $1.54
column9: beating the Street view by 17 cents. Sales
column10: on the other hand
column11: were short of estimates
column12: at $43.7 billion versus a $44.68 billion bar. For the full year
column13: though
column14: profits quadrupled on a 27% increase in revenues.The company's operating income outlook has possibly raised some hairs on the backs of AMZN bulls. A forecast of $250 million to $900 million falls well below the Street's consensus of $1.33 billion. But it's not as bad as it looks
column15: as most of the ""warning"" is tied to aggressive investments in media
column16: fulfillment and India.As well
column17: while investors are failing to rejoice Friday
column18: Amazon also delivered the goods with its operating cash flow
column19: which jumped by 38% to $16.4 billion.7 Stocks to Sell as Fear Returns to the MarketWhat's more
column20: revenues of $3.54 billion from its coveted Amazon Web Services (AWS) unit climbed an impressive 47% over last year's same-quarter result of $2.41 billion
column21: while contributing 9% to Amazon's net revenues for the year.By the ""Other"" Numbers …That said
column22: Amazon's report hasn't been nearly as punishing from the standpoint of professional options traders.Based on last night's 03 Feb $840 straddle market
column23: pricing of $42 for the non-directional spread with AMZN stock at $840 amounted to traders putting the over/under bet at 5% or estimated range from $798 to $882. This weekly contract
column24: which expires today
column25: is the purest play on the earnings event and collectively tells us what traders expect for Amazon shares in the immediate aftermath of the announcement.Further
column26: as most often it's the professional options traders and market makers that sell options premiums
column27: the basic assumption is this more informed and disciplined group is collectively wagering on the ""under"" side of the 5% in AMZN stock.So far
column28: not only has Friday's low of $801 in Amazon shares fallen within the forecast by options traders
column29: but relative to past earnings events of the last few years
column30: call and put premiums were decidedly below average.Thehistorical recordshows that over the past five years
column31: the average up or down move in Amazon stock has been 8.4%
column32: with a median reaction of 8.1%. Fine-tuning the price activity down to the last five quarters
column33: AMZN's average move has been slightly higher at 9%
column34: but a modestly lower median of 7.7%.AMZN Stock Daily ChartClick to EnlargeFinally
column35: Friday's conditions in Amazon shares may not have been as fierce as we've been led to believe.Take a look at the accompanying chart. Ifcharts don't lie
column36: then AMZN stockclearlywas a double-top pattern.I'm being facetious
column37: of course. But even if I wasn't
column38: I'd always look to hedge my directional bet with options and money management opportunities in case I read a chart like Amazon's with less-than-perfect forecasting.Investment accounts under Christopher Tyler's management do not currently own positions in any of the securities or their derivatives mentioned in this article. The information offered is based upon Christopher Tyler's observations and strictly intended for educational purposes only; the use of which is the responsibility of the individual. column1: Advanced Micro Devices
column2: Inc. (AMD) Stock: 2 Reasons to Steer Clear;2/3/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAdvanced Micro Devices(NASDAQ:AMD) is coming off a fourth-quarter earnings beat in which the company reported $1.1 billion in revenue. AMD stock bounced 16% to above the $12 level as a result
column4: continuing a red-hot streak of nearly 500% returns in just 52 weeks.makeArticleAd();Source:Matthew Rutledge via FlickrThis was a sub-$2 stockjust a year agoamid fears about competition and potential bankruptcy.AMD is a leading maker of graphics cards
column5: including Radeon for consumers and FirePro for workstations. The company operates in two segments: Computing and Graphics
column6: which makes desktop and notebook processors and professional graphics; andEnterprise
column7: Embedded and Semi-Custom
column8: producing server chips
column9: embedded processors for the Internet of Things and chips for gaming consoles.Since taking the helm two years ago
column10: Advanced Micro Devices CEOLisa Su-  an MIT-educated electrical engineer who has authored over 40 technical papers - has presided over a remarkable recovery. Now
column11: AMD
column12: having played second fiddle toIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) for decades
column13: ismaking a playfor the PC and server markets
column14: Intel's bread and butter. AMD's Ryzen CPU will challenge Intel's Core i5 and i7 chips.AMD is moving up the value chain amid a falling PC market
column15: going from low-end to high-end PC processors .Even if prospects for Advanced Micro Devices' business are good
column16: though
column17: investors have to deal with a few issues. AMD hasn't posted an operating profit since the third quarter of 2014
column18: holds a great deal of debt and yet trades at a stratospheric valuation.Amid these high expectations and gains worthy of bubble talk
column19: is AMD stock still a buy? Here are two problems that should have the bulls taking a second look.AMD Has a Not-Great Balance SheetDespite many chipmakers such as AMD going ""fabless"" and outsourcing the fabrication of their chips to contract manufacturers such asTaiwan Semiconductor Mfg. Co. Ltd. (ADR)(NYSE:TSM)
column20: the industry remains capital-intensive.7 Stocks to Sell as Fear Returns to the MarketAdvanced Micro Devices escaped bankruptcy last year. It took advantage of low interest rates and improved investor confidence to restructure its debt in September 2016. AMD issued$600 million in sharesand $450 million in convertible senior notes. This enabled AMD to pay off $676 million in debt due in 2020. So instead of $600 million in AMD debt maturing in 2019
column21: only $196 million will mature that year.Still
column22: AMD is highly leveraged by several measures. With $1.435 billion in long-term debt and $416 million in shareholder equity as of Dec. 31
column24: AMD's long-term debt-to-equity ratio stands at 3.44. That figure is much lower for Intel
column26: andNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA)
column28: indicating less leverage. Likewise
column29: AMD's debt-to-capital ratio of 0.775 stands above 0.27 for both INTC and NVDA.Intel and Nvidia also are better able to service debt. For the year ended December 31
column31: AMD generated only $90 million in operating cash flow
column32: with $2.9 billion in total liabilities
column33: a ratio of 0.031.NVDA earned $1.462 billion in operating cash flow for the four quarters ended October 30
column35: with $4.24 billion in total liabilities
column36: a ratio of 0.34.Intel showed an even healthier balance sheet
column37: with $19.09 billion in operating cash flow for $48 billion in total liabilities
column38: a ratio of 0.396.AMD Stock Is Much More ExpensiveNvidia and Intel are profitable and have a better track record of generating operating cash flow. They earned positive operating cash flow in the four most recent quarters
column39: while AMD's operating cash flow went negative for two quarters.Still
column40: AMD stock trades at a huge premium to both.AMD trades at a whopping 25.66 times book
column41: versus 11.5 for Nvidia (which itself is high)
column42: and 2.61 for Intel. It's not difficult to justify a higher price than Intel given AMD's growth prospects
column43: but for comparison's sake
column44: know that while Wall Street sees Advanced Micro Devices growing revenues roughly 10% this year and next
column45: NVDA should be sitting at roughly 37% annual sales growth after it reports Q4 earnings
column46: with analysts expecting that to slow to ""only"" 16% next year.ConclusionIt's difficult to fight the momentum
column47: but you might just want to in AMD stock. At this point
column48: anyone tussling with Advanced Micro Devices is playing with overpriced fire.Should You Buy FireEye Inc (FEYE) Stock? 3 Pros
column49: 3 ConsFrom a valuation standpoint
column50: INTC actually looks like the best buy
column51: simply because the market expects less from it than from AMD and NVDA. Also
column52: Intel leads in the production of microprocessors
column53: and this matters in the semiconductor industry
column54: since often only the market leaders can turn a profit
column55: while laggards destroy value.AMD made some mistakes in the past
column56: switching back and forth between ARM and x86 architectures
column57: and never was quite able to catch up to Intel. The stock looks promising
column58: but dislodging Intel and showing a steady track record of profits will not be easy in this industry.As of this writing
column59: Lucas Hahn did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Awful Stocks You Need To Ditch Right AwayExxon Mobil Corporation (XOM) Stock Is Going to BounceApple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Moved Too Far

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Smartwatch Is Still Dominant Despite All the Doubt;2/3/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhenApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) CEO Tim Cook went on the attack against claims Apple Watch sales were in the dumpster his comments about record holiday sales were taken with a healthy dose of skepticism.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleAfter all
column3: it was his job to talk up his company's products. Even a similar claim in Apple's Q1 earnings report seemed questionable
column4: with no detail provided. However
column5: a report on global smartwatch shipments for Q4 2016 supports AAPL's claims.The numbers say Apple Watch sales did indeed set a holiday record and took an even larger share of overall smartwatch sales that quarter than in the 2015 holidays.Defending Apple Watch SalesTim Cook had his work cut out for him after AAPL launched the Apple Watch Series 2 in September. Apple was counting on the new model to boost sales going into the holiday quarter of a year where consumer interest in smartwatches was slipping.Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column6: NASDAQ:GOOGL) opted to skip its expected Android Wear 2 smartwatch operating system upgrade.Pebble
column7: the early smartwatch pioneer
column8: would soon collapse and have its assets bought up byFitbit Inc(NYSE:FIT).When research firm IDC released a report in December saying Apple Watch sales had tanked
column9: dropping 71% from the previous year
column10: Cook went on the offensive.In an e-mailtoReuters
column11: he wrote:""Our data shows that Apple Watch is doing great and looks to be one of the most popular holiday gifts this year. Sales growth is off the charts. In fact
column12: during the first week of holiday shopping
column13: our sell-through of Apple Watch was greater than any week in the product's history. And as we expected
column14: we're on track for the best quarter ever for Apple Watch.""The problem was
column15: with a new model just launched and the crucial holiday shopping season ramping up
column16: everyone was expecting AAPL to put a positive spin on Apple Watch sales. And without numbers to back it up
column17: Cook's statement wasn't necessarily taken at face value.10 Companies That Are Bringing Jobs Back to AmericaEven Apple's Q1 earnings report
column18: where the Apple Watch was noted to have set an ""all-time revenue record"" didn't convince everyone. AAPL didn't spike out any actual number to back that up and the Other division that includes the Apple Watch saw its revenue drop 8% year-over-year.AAPL Wasn't Blowing Smoke About Apple Watch SalesResearch firm Strategy Analytics released itsreport on global smartwatch shipments for Q4
column19: 2016(the period corresponding to AAPL's Q1 2017). In it
column20: global smartwatch sales are shown to have recovered from a slow first half
column21: to mark a 1% increase over 2015. As for the Apple Watch?""Demand for Apple's new Watch Series 2 as a holiday-season gift in Western markets was surprisingly strong and it enabled Apple to clear a large backlog of smartwatch inventory during the quarter.""According to Strategy Analytics
column22: that translated to a record 5.2 million Apple Watch sales in the fourth quarter
column23: up from 5.1 million the previous year. In addition
column24: while AAPL lost ground in the overall smartwatch market in 2016 - dropping to a 55% share compared to over 65% in 2015 by selling 2 million fewer smartwatches on the year - during the holiday quarter
column25: the company captured over 63% of all smartwatch sales.Where Does This Leave AAPL and the Apple Watch?Apple is still the dominant smartwatch maker
column26: and the Apple Watch Series 2 showed the company isn't sitting still. Its overall market share dropped to 55%
column27: but it remains firmly on top.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Has a New Hero: Services!Second placeSamsung Electronics Co Ltd(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) took a big hit over the holiday quarter
column28: despite releasing a new model of its own
column29: the Gear S3. Samsung's holiday quarter marketshare dropped from 16% to 9.8%
column30: while its overall marketshare for 2016 dropped from 13% to 11.4%. A collection of other manufacturers from Fitbit toLGtook over one third of the market in 2016 (up from 21.6%) showing the increasing diversification of smartwatch sales.The smartwatch market still isn't setting the world on fire
column31: but despite a slow 2016
column32: any reports of its death are greatly exaggerated. And while AAPL is sharing the market with an increasingly diverse group of competitors
column33: Apple Watch sales have not cratered. They were down overall for the year

column1: GoPro (GPRO) Q4 Results Mixed with Earnings Beat & View Cut;2/3/2017;"After four back-to-back quarters of posting quarterly losses
column2: GoPro
column3: Inc.GPROmanaged to get back in the green as it posted adjusted earnings of 16 cents per share in its fourth-quarter 2016 results. The action camera maker's bottom-line figure beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate of 12 cents by an impressive 33%.However
column4: the earnings figure was a result of several adjustments made to the huge GAAP loss that GoPro reported (82 cents per share).Shares tumbled almost 14% at one point in late trading in the aftermath of the results
column5: as investors were disillusioned with the company's bleak sales outlook for first-quarter 2017. This was in spite of the fact that this was the second biggest quarter in terms of revenue in GoPro's history. The drab guidance must have spooked investors as 2017 was supposed to be a turnaround time for GoPro and this is a terrible start to the same.In addition
column6: investors were likely upset with the multiple missed opportunities and goof-ups that GoPro had this quarter.The huge GAAP loss of 82 cents for the quarter was much wider than the 25 cents loss generated in the comparable quarter last year.For full-year 2016
column7: the company reported a non-GAAP net loss of $1.44 per share
column8: in stark contrast to net income of 76 cents in 2015.Inside the HeadlinesGoPro's revenues grew 23.8% from the prior-year quarter's tally to $540.6 million. This marked the company's return to revenue growth after four successive quarters of sales declines. The top-line figure still lagged the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $576 million.This was the first quarter that reflected the performance of the recently launched Hero5 camera and its consumer drone Karma
column9: and revenues were far short of the company's earlier guidance of $625 million. The Karma recall hit the top line and manufacturing issues related to Hero5 camera also strained growth.Nevertheless
column10: Hero5 Black was the best-selling digital imaging device in units and dollars in the U.S. and Europe. Also
column11: Hero5 Black sold more units in a single quarter in Europe
column12: in this quarter
column13: than any other GoPro camera ever.For the quarter
column14: non-GAAP gross margins expanded 990 bps year over year to 39.5%. Non-GAAP operating income came in at $31.6 million
column15: as against an operating loss of $21.6 million generated last year.R&D expenses were up almost 40% year over year
column16: driven by investment in HERO5 cameras
column17: Karma
column18: accessories and software. In addition
column19: sales and marketing expenses shot up 36% year over year.The company recently launched GoPro Plus - a cloud-based subscription service - that enables auto-upload of footage from a GoPro camera to a GoPro Plus cloud account for on-the-go access
column20: editing and sharing using a smartphone and the Quik app. Even though it is early days
column21: the GoPro Plus is enjoying high retention rates in the U.S. and its subscriber base seems to be expanding.In the quarter
column22: the rebranded Quik mobile app was downloaded over 4 million times (up almost 30% sequentially)
column23: as its active users and monthly exports tripled in Dec 2016 over the prior year.For full-year 2016
column24: revenues plunged 26.8% year over year to $1.62 billion.Notable DevelopmentsTill date
column25: GoPro's Hero 5 Black cameras and Karma drones have faced production issues and delayed shipments
column26: which restrained the company's ability to meet demand in the quarter. The company's new products also had a rocky start with Amazon.com Inc.AMZN
column27: as GoPro had temporarily stopped selling them on the e-commerce site in mid October due to a pricing dispute.Further
column28: supply constraints made retailers cancel marketing support of GoPro's new products
column29: particularly its new Hero 5 camera
column30: which obviously hurt revenues. Further
column31: the company had to announce a recall of its new Karma drone after a mere fortnight of its commercial launch
column32: as a few of them lost power during flight due to battery issues. This was also a huge setback for the company.However
column33: earlier this week
column34: the company resumed Karma sales and the company plans to ramp production further. Karma is scheduled to be available in international markets this spring. We believe that GoPro is well set to capitalize on the fast-growing consumer drone market.The company also launched several accessories during the quarter
column35: including Karma Grip
column36: a handheld stabilizer; Remo
column37: a waterproof
column38: voice-activated remote and Quik Key
column39: a microSD card reader enabling quick editing and sharing from smartphones.LiquidityExiting the quarter
column40: the company had cash and cash equivalents of $192.1 million
column41: down significantly from $280 million a year back.GuidanceIn light of such unfortunate events and uncertain market reaction
column42: the company gave a very disappointing guidance for first-quarter 2017. It projects revenues for the current quarter in the range of $190-$210 million
column43: which is well below the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $268 million for the quarter. The company expects gross margin in the low 30% range.GoPro refrained from offering specific revenue or margin guidance for full-year 2017.However
column44: GoPro declared plans to limit its adjusted operating expenses in 2017 to $600 million
column45: in an attempt to try to return to full-year profitability next year. This is comparable to a 2016 figure of about $709 million.GoPro should be able to attain these massive cost reductions
column46: in light of its recent business restructuring
column47: which did away with many high-cost operations including its entertainment division.It is likely that GoPro's sales will gradually improve as it ramps production and expands Karma's reach to international markets. This will supplement its cost-reduction initiatives and enable it to achieve sustained
column48: profitable growth.GoPro

column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) reportedearnings Tuesdayof $3.38 per share on revenues of $78.35 billion. Both of these metrics were significant beats as consensus expectations were $3.22 EPS and $76.2 billion in sales. Apple stock initially shot up nearly 9 points
column5: post earnings and briefly traded above the critical $130 before pulling back.makeArticleAd();Source:via AppleWhile the earnings report certainly was solid

Return on risk is 13.63%. The short $140 strike price is nearly 9% above the Thursday closing price of $128.53 and also well above the $130 resistance level.I would close out the trade on a significant move to new all-time highs on AAPL while looking to let the spread expire worthless and keep the initial $60 premium if AAPL remains well behaved.As of this writing
