column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Could Be a Step Closer to Booting Intel From Macs;2/3/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIt's an idea that has been around for several years now: replace theIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) chips currently powering Mac computers with ARM chips fromARM Holdings plc (ADR)(NASDAQ:ARMH). Doing so would have many advantages forApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL). According to aBloombergreport
column3: the prospect of ARM CPUs in Macs is getting closer
column4: with AAPL working on a new chip that would independently control a MacBook's low power mode.makeArticleAd();Source: ARM HoldingsWhether you think it's a great idea or a head scratcher
column5: theTouch Baris the tentpole feature of Apple's new MacBook Pro. The Touch Bar is an OLED strip that replaces the laptop's function keys with a programmable touch display
column6: with virtual buttons based on the application currently being run. It also incorporates a fingerprint reader.And the Touch Bar is powered by the T1
column7: Apple's first ARM-based Mac chip.New ARM CPUs in Macs?Bloombergis now reporting thatAAPL engineers are taking the next step toward ARM in Mac
column8: by having the ""Power Nap"" mode controlled by an ARM chip. Power Nap is a feature that lets Mac laptops run basic background functions such as retrieving e-mail and installing software updates
column9: while closed and sleeping. By shifting control of Power Nap from the Intel CPU to an ARM chip
column10: less power is used and MacBook battery would last longer.Why the excitement about the possibility of Apple making a complete switch and replacing Intel processors with ARM CPUs in Macs?ARM in Mac: The PayoffsThere are many compelling reasons
column11: includingthose laid out last yearby theMacObserver. ARM chips power all of Apple's mobile devices
column12: so switching to ARM CPUs in Macs would simplify and unify code development between MacOS and iOS.10 Companies That Are Bringing Jobs Back to AmericaIntel has moved away from tick-tock processor development cycles
column13: so it may not be moving forward fast enough for Apple's needs. Modern
column14: 64-bit ARM processors are becoming competitive with Intel on power
column15: including the power needed to run an operating system like Windows in a virtual environment; therefore
column16: ARM in Mac wouldn't have to mean Macs lose the option to runMicrosoft Corporation's(NASDAQ:MSFT) Windows.Then there's cost. In a post dating back to 2015AppleInsiderbroke down thepotential financial gain should Apple ditch Intel. It estimated the cost of the A-series chips used in the iPhone and iPad at roughly $25
column17: while Intel CPUs used in Macs were somewhere in the $180 to $300 range.The site points to the Apple TV as an example of Apple making the switch. The first generation ran a version of OS X on Intel processors. For the second generation
column18: AAPL switched to an ARM-based A4 chip running iOS. That move shrunk the Apple TV size and knocked the price from $299 to $99. The numbers may have changed a little since then
column19: but the same basic math applies: ARM is considerably cheaper.Will Apple Ditch Intel?There would be many risks in switching to ARM CPUs in Macs. Even if AAPL did make that decision
column20: it would still need Intel CPUs for a number of years while it made the transition across the Mac product line - and Intel would be able to stick it to Apple for those chips. There would be challenges around integrating ARM chips with high-end graphics cards like those made byNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA). Other third-party hardware would also require work.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Has a New Hero: Services!There is also the issue of manufacturing capacity: AAPL's suppliers would need to be able to pick up the slack from Intel and churn out the needed ARM chips.However
column21: as intense as all this sounds
column22: it's worth remembering that AAPL has done it all before. Twice! The company transitioned the entire Mac platform from 68k to PowerPC in 1998
column23: and then from PowerPC to Intel in 2005.ARM CPUs in Macs aren't a reality yet
column24: but with the new ARM chips rumored for MacBooks
column25: it seems as though AAPL is testing the waters. With Nvidia already causing it grief byturning its video cards into high-powered CPU-bustersand Microsoft once again trying for a version ofWindows on ARM processors
column26: Intel has to be watching the ARM in Mac situation with more than a little consternation.As of this writing
column27: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceMicrosoft Corporation (MSFT) Steps on Amazon and Google's TurfApple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Has a New Hero: Services!The postApple Inc. (AAPL) Could Be a Step Closer to Booting Intel From Macsappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Apple Inc's iPad Business Isn't as Bad as It Looks;2/3/2017;"Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) reported a strong quarter
column2: driven by   better-than-expected demand in its key product line
column3: the iPhone.   However
column4: while investors often pay far more attention to the   iPhone business than to any of the company's other segments
column5: it's   important to watch the others nonetheless.Apple's 9.7-inch iPad Pro. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();That includes the iPad business.Apple reported a 19% year-over-year drop in iPad unit   shipments and a full 22% year-over-year drop in iPad revenue
column6: making it the company's worst-performing business unit by far.   Although these results are quite disappointing -- making it   increasingly difficult to have confidence in the future of this   product line -- the business isn't in as dire shape as it   appears.Channel inventory dynamicsIn Apple's most recent quarter
column7: it shipped 13.08 million   iPads
column8: down from 16.12 million in the same period a year ago. One   of the drivers of the steep year-over-year drop was channel   inventory dynamics. Remember that Apple ships products to   distributors (i.e.
column9: channel partners)
column10: and then those   distributors sell those products to end customers. To get a   true sense of underlying customer demand
column11: it's important to not   just watch the change in unit shipments but the amount of   inventory that's sitting out there in the hands of Apple's   channel partners.With that in mind
column12: Apple says that in the most recent quarter
column13: the companyreducediPad channel inventories by 700
column14: 000 units. The company says that   in the year-ago quarter
column15: Apple hadboostedits channel inventory levels by 900
column16: 000 units.So to get a sense of the underlying demand
column17: we can adjust the   numbers to account for the channel inventory changes. Apple   shipped 13.08 iPads
column18: but channel inventories were down 700
column19: 000   units
column20: which suggests that actual demand was more like 13.78   million units. Performing the same math for the year-ago   quarter
column21: Apple increased channel inventory by 900
column22: 000 units
column23: meaning that underlying customer demand was 15.22 million   units.To be clear
column24: demand wasstilldown year-over-year and that's far from ideal
column25: but adjusting for   these channel inventory dynamics
column26: it looks like the decline was   ""just"" 9.4%.Product cycle dynamicsAnother factor that impacted the iPad results
column27: at least   according to CEO Tim Cook
column28: were product cycle dynamics.On the earnings call
column29: Cook explained that in the year-ago   quarter
column30: Apple had just launched its 12.9-inch iPad Pro
column31: which he   reminded investors is ""the iPad with
column32: obviously
column33: the highest   price on it"".""We would have done the channel fill plus the launch of the   product
column34: and so that would have bolstered [average selling   prices] in that particular quarter""
column35: Cook said.Indeed
column36: Apple reported that in addition to iPad units being   down 19%
column37: iPad revenue was down 22% in the most recent quarter
column38: suggesting a weaker product mix. Cook's commentary absolutely   makes sense here
column39: especially as demand for the 12.9-inch model is   probably well below where it was when it first launched.Looking aheadOn the call
column40: Cook tried to reassure investors that the company   has ""some exciting things coming on iPad"" and that he is ""very   optimistic about where [Apple] can take the product"".Unfortunately
column41: Apple management has been bullish about the   iPad business for a while now
column42: but it's still hard to see where   the bottom will ultimately be and even harder to predict how much   the business can grow once it hits that bottom.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column43: it can pay to listen. After all
column44: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column45: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column46: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column47: 2017Ashraf Eassahas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Apple. The Motley Fool has the     following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and     short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Investors Turned 'Very Bullish' On Tech ETFs In January Amid Earnings;2/3/2017;"[ibd-display-video id=453308]ETF investors bet big on technology stocks ahead of earnings   reports from marquee names in January. Powered by demand for the   iPhone 7 Plus
column2: Apple(AAPL) delivered supersize results on Jan. 31 and saw its shares   soar.Technology was the strongest S&P 500 sector in terms of   flow of money as the new year got underway
column3: according to Sector   SPDRs. Investors last month poured $897.3 million into   Technology Select Sector SDPR (XLK)
column4: the largest and most active exchange traded fund for exposure   to this sector.makeAd('4'
column6: 'mktsnews'
column7: 'vanguard'
column9: '');This marked a significant reversal from 2016
column10: when investors   yanked nearly $900 million from XLK for the year
column11: said   Dan Dolan of Sector SPDRs. Trading activity in XLK so far   this year suggests thatETF   investorsare ""very bullish"" on the technology sector
column12: in his view.""In addition to the flows
column13: the short positions declined by   27%"" in January
column14: Dolan told IBD via email. ""Earnings have been   very good
column15: he pointed out
column16: ""for most of the big names.""Those names includeMicrosoft(MSFT) andIntel(INTC) - tech stalwarts reinventing themselves for a new cloud-driven
column17: Internet of Things era - as well as chipmakersAdvanced Micro Devices(AMD)
column18: Texas Instruments(TXN)
column19: Microsemi(MSCC)
column20: Lam Research(LRCX) andKLA-Tencor(KLAC).Outliers includedAlphabet(GOOGL) andQualcomm(QCOM)
column21: which delivered mixed results.Tech earnings are tracking higher
column23: than the 6.6%   expected at the start of the Q4 season
column24: according to CFRA   Research. And XLK's 4.3% year-to-date gain
column25: vs. 1.8% for SPDR   S&P 500 (SPY)
column26: reflects investors's optimism   about improving industry fundamentals.[ibdchart symbol=""xlk"" type=""daily"" size=""quarter""   position=""leftchart"" ]While earnings season has put technology   companies under a spotlight
column27: the macro outlook is   driving interest too.Technology stocks are expected to benefit from the economic   strength that tends to go hand-in-hand with periods of rising   interest rates.""As business spending picks up
column28: as consumer confidence grows   and consumption increases
column29: tech companies will be the   beneficiaries of those trends
column30: said Todd Rosenbluth
column31: director of   ETF research at CFRA. Other tailwinds include the promise of   corporate tax reform and repatriation of foreign cash under   President Trump
column32: which disproportionately benefits the tech   sector
column33: Rosenbluth pointed out.Apple CFO Luca Maestri noted   at Tuesday's earnings call that 94% of   his company's record $246.1 billion cash pile is stashed   abroad. Under a Trump proposal
column34: the iPhone   maker could potentially bring home foreign earnings at   a special tax rate of 10%
column35: instead of up to 35%. That tax holiday   could be one of the single biggest catalysts for the sector going   forward
column36: CFRA analysts say.Risks to the sector include the uncertainty surrounding   Trump's vision for economic renewal
column37: the crimp that a   strengthening dollar could put on global IT spending
column38: and the   onslaught of low-cost rivals such as Huawei in key foreign   markets.Investors who remain bullish on the sector's outlook have four   dozen ETFs to choose from. Many of the new launches make   extremely focused bets in extremely small industry niches -   3D printing or Big Data or wearable devices
column39: for example.In Rosenbluth's view
column40: most investors would do well to stick   with a technology ETF offering broadly diversified exposure to   the sector
column41: and to then layer on thematic ETFs in   specific tech industries.Investors have been seeking diversification. Two tech   ETFs far outpaced their peers last year by gathering more   than $1 billion apiece in fresh assets
column42: and both hold a   broad basket of tech stocks. But they take markedly different   approaches to investing in the sector.Vanguard Information Technology (VGT) tracks a   market-cap-weighted index of U.S. tech companies
column43: including more small- and microcap stocks than most other   broad tech ETFs. It invests $10.75 billion in assets across 366   stocks for an extremely low 0.10% expense ratio.First Trust Nasdaq-100 Tech Sector (QTEC) follows an   equal-weighted index of Nasdaq-listed U.S. technology stocks. It   has virtually no exposure to small- and microcap stocks
column44: but has   a significant midcap stake. At 0.60%
column45: its expense ratio is among   the highest in the segment.Investors should be aware that ETFs may sound alike   but offer very different exposures
column46: which affects their   performance
column47: Rosenbluth says.QTEC rose 25% in 2016
column48: nearly double the gains of its   Vanguard peer. It benefited in part from its extreme overweight   to the semiconductor industry.Looking ahead
column49: Rosenbluth believes VGT may benefit more than   other broad-based peers from an improving U.S. economy
column50: given its larger stake in smaller tech companies.XLK and VGT made a 52-week high on thestock marketon Jan. 27.RELATED:High-Yield Strategy Uses 10 ETFs To Deliver     All-Weather Income With Low Risk7 Best ETFs For Your Growth And Income Needs As     Trump Takes The Wheel"

It's a little comforting to know that there are 18 analyst holds on this stock and their target price is STILL $36. That is consistent with what the charts are telling me.I'm buying here with a tight stop
column14: and looking for a move back into the mid-$30s
column15: giving me a nice risk/reward setup.J: I agree with you about ignoring the analyst ratings. I use it as a contra-indicator. Did you read that recent WSJ article?H: You know that I do not read! I reach great conclusions from looking at charts. You humans read
column16: but mostly to reaffirm your existing biases.J: I am delighted that our clients caught this at a lower price
column17: but do you realize the stock was up over $1.50 today?H: No. I am enjoying the beach in Mexico. I sent in my pick
column18: but that is like working overtime.J: Oscar's turf accountant would call your choice ""past posting.""H: Sorry. You are the one who set the schedule for Thursdays. I made the pick earlier
column19: and it is still a good buy.J: There is a rumor of a possible takeover. Did you know about that?H: No. I just know a great rebound chart when I see one.J: Are you going to have any trouble returning from Mexico? The U.S. is taking a hard look at those returning from other countries.H: My papers are all in order. I'll be back in the office in a week or so.AthenaI admit it. I still have no new picks. We do not have the fresh
column20: strongly trending stocks that I prefer. I'm still holding most of my most recent picks
column21: and I have room for one more buy.J: Maybe you could give us an update on one of your current holdings.A: Fair enough. Irecommended United Rentals (URI) on 12/22
column22: after buying it myself a few days earlier.J: Isn't this one of your few picks where I agreed?A: Yes
column23: I seem to remember that you said the pick was OK
column24: but you did not own it yourself. I have held this one through a month or so of sideways movement
column25: but now it's starting to pay off in a big way. We've seen an increase of roughly 20% in the last two weeks. That means it's about time for me to hop off this one (as fun of a ride as it's been).J: That certainly worked well. How are you doing overall?A: Not as well as the fussy guy and the dog
column26: but that will change soon. I think I am Vince's favorite.FelixI will once again begin with my responses to reader votes for the favorites list.My list provides rankings within each zone
column27: as well as the basics about buy
column28: hold
column29: and sell. The list includes the top overall vote getters from our (free) subscription list as well as some new requests I got during the week.J: The list has some interesting changes. I see that Apple (AAPL) (which we own) is still in ""hold"" territory despite the major rally after its earnings report.F: My ratings came before the report. How about Amazon (AMZN)? That did not do so well. My approach is geared to the long term
column30: usually more than one year.J: Fair enough. Do you have something new for us this week?F: No.J: What? I took a long weekend

column34: we'll let the readers decide whether they still want your opinions.OscarMy pick for this week is the Defense sector
column35: shown here by the SPDR S&P Aerospace & Defense ETF (XAR). I liked this one back in early December too - but I got out before the downslide. Now that the price has had a few weeks to level out
column36: I feel more comfortable getting back into this sector.For my next ""investment"" - I'll bet that Belichick can't put together a defense to stop the Falcons. But that really is another subject…Here are my ratings for the top reader interests. Keep the questions coming. My sectors are aggressive
column37: but have less risk than Felix's picks. I avoid the bad news from random
column38: single-stock moves.J: Interesting. Do you see evidence of that?O: I hear about it. People are very worried about something called ""tweets"" that seem to hit their stocks for no reason. Playing sectors reduces that risk.J: Interesting. The Tweeter-in-Chief has T-Wopped a few of the defense stocks
column39: but most still believe in his support for higher defense spending.O: I only follow sports tweets
column40: but I know which sectors have legs
column41: and which will fail down the stretch.J: You really like the Falcons?O: My week's pay is on the line!Background on the Stock ExchangeEach week Felix and Oscar host a poker game for some of their   friends. Since they are all traders they love to discuss their   best current ideas before the game starts. They like to call this   their ""Stock Exchange."" (Check it out for more background). Their methods are   excellent
column42: as you know if you have been following the series.   Since the time frames and risk profiles differ
column43: so do the stock   ideas. You get to be a fly on the wall from my report. I am the   only human present
column44: and the only one using any fundamental   analysis.The result? Several expert ideas each week from traders
column45: and a   brief comment on the fundamentals from the human investor. The   models are named to make it easy to remember their trading   personalities. Each week features a different expert or   stock.QuestionsIf you want an opinion about a specific stock or sector
column46: even   those we did not mention
column47: just ask! Put questions in the   comments. Address them to a specific expert if you wish. Each has   a specialty. Who is your favorite? (You can choose me
column48: although   my feelings will not be hurt very much if you prefer one of the   models).ConclusionThe current trading environment is treacherous. Many frustrated traders are bailing out. Or have blown out. Political opinions about policy have proved to be a dangerous foundation for trading and investing.Our models provide a range of diverse ideas
column49: all successful. Pick one that you like. Use it as a counterpoint for your own method. And keep control of position size and risk.The Stock Exchange does not have all the answers
column50: but it     provides good ideas and a stimulus for your own trading.See alsoING: The Fundamentals Justify The Stock Price Momentumon seekingalpha.com"

column1: 4 Stocks That Are NOT Driven by the Trump Trade;2/3/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAnyone who has been watching the markets for the past two months knows the far-reaching impact President Trump has had on stocks
column3: bonds and currencies. Stock indices soared to all-time highs
column4: bond prices dropped to 52-week lows and the value of the U.S. dollar climbed to highs last seen during the financial crisis.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockIf it seems like all sectors of the market were touched by the election
column5: they were. President Trump's campaign promises
column6: if enacted
column7: have the ability to reach every corner of the stock market.His promised changes to the business tax code would impact every business. His promised changes to the personal income tax code would impact nearly every consumer. His promised infrastructure spending would increase inflation for the entire nation. His promised changes to the Affordable Care Act (ACA) would impact nearly every employee. His promised relaxing of government regulations would affect nearly every employer. The list goes on and on.Looking at the market through this lens
column8: there is not a company or stock that will not be impacted in some way by the Trump presidency. However
column9: not all companies will be impacted to the same extent. Some companies are more vulnerable - for good or bad - to the promised policy changes than others.For instance
column10: large banks and other financial institutions - likeGoldman Sachs Group Inc(NYSE:GS) - have been the unrivaled beneficiaries of a Trump presidency up to this point
column11: because so many of the president's suggested changes benefit the banks' bottom lines. Rising inflation
column12: lower corporate taxes and decreased regulation all benefit the banks.The Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryConversely
column13: biotech companies - likeBiogen Inc(NASDAQ:BIIB) - have struggled in the aftermath of the presidential election because the uncertainty swirling around what will eventually replace the ACA after the Republican-controlled Congress repeals it
column14: coupled with the pointedTwitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR) and interview criticisms President Trump has issued regarding the high price of pharmaceuticals and other medical treatments
column15: has created a tremendous amount of uncertainty in the healthcare industry.So which companies are less vulnerable to the potential policy changes and political whims of the president?While it's important to note that no company is immune from the potential threat of a targeted Twitter tirade from the president should it happen to draw his ire
column16: there does seem to be a group of stocks that could bullishly go on its merry way during the first half of 2017 without having to look over its shoulder every morning to see if some new policy decision may threaten to derail its progress: the ""FANG"" stocks.The FANG stocks -Facebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB)
column17: Amazon.com
column18: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)
column19: Netflix(NASDAQ:NFLX) andAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column20: NASDAQ:GOOGL) [formerly Google
column21: hence the ""G""]  - have been Wall Street darlings for the past few years. The shift consumers have made to living in an online world for everything from their social networking to shopping has pushed the valuation of these companies ever higher as traders bet on this trend continuing
column22: regardless of what else happens in the economy.The FANG stocks took an initial hit after the results of the presidential election were announced in early November
column23: as traders started taking profits on some of their more lucrative positions and rotating that money into the financial sector and other sectors that were poised to rally following President Trump's win. Nobody was doubting the strength of the FANG stocks - they just needed to free up cash to invest in even hotter stocks at the time.Once the initial rotation was complete
column24: investors started coming back to the FANG stocks
column25: which were then trading at much more favorable valuations
column26: and started buying them up. After all
column27: whatever happens to inflation
column28: whatever happens with the tax code
column29: whatever happens with health care
column30: consumers are going to continue connecting with friends on Facebook
column31: buying more stuff on Amazon
column32: watching videos on Netflix and searching for information on Google.Why Amazon.com
column33: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Should Expect Fireworks SoonWe expect the FANG stocks and other tech stocks like them - stocks likeApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) andNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) - to continue to do well during the next few months. We will certainly have to keep watching what the Trump administration does in the future (watching the net neutrality debate is going to be especially important for NFLX)
column34: but the traders on Wall Street aren't going to abandon their perpetual winners just yet.InvestorPlace advisors John Jagerson and S. Wade Hansen
column35: both Chartered Market Technician (CMT) designees
column36: are co-founders of LearningMarkets.com
column37: as well as the co-editors ofSlingShot Trader
column38: a trading service designed to help you make options profits by trading the news. Get in on the next trade and get 1 free month todayby clicking here.More From InvestorPlace5 Stocks to Buy to Defy a Weak February10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatThe post4 Stocks That Are NOT Driven by the Trump Tradeappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: More iPhones
column2: Less Profit;2/2/2017;"After three quarters of declining revenue and iPhone sales
column3: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) managed to return to growth during its first   fiscal quarter. Not only that
column4: Apple put up some record numbers.   Revenue was $78.35 billion
column5: up 3.3 % year over year and a new   quarterly record. EPS grew 2.4% to $3.36
column6: also a new quarterly   record.iPhone unit sales surged 5% to 78.3 million
column7: the most ever in   a single quarter. The company also set all-time revenue records   for services
column8: Mac
column9: and Apple Watch. There was a lot to like.Apple stocksurged the following day
column10: with investors relieved that fears of a   continued slide in sales were overblown.While Apple put together a fine quarter
column11: the company's results   aren't quite as good as they seem.makeArticleAd();Image source: Apple.A profit declineApple managed to grow its per-share earnings during the first   quarter
column12: but a quick look at the income statement reveals a   different story. Apple increased its revenue by $2.48 billion   compared to the first quarter of last year
column13: but cost of sales
column14: the cost of producing its products
column15: surged $2.73 billion. Gross   profit declined by a little less than 1% as a result.So Apple sold more devices
column16: but it accepted a lower gross   margin
column17: and none of that extra revenue flowed through to the   bottom line. This gross profit decline and a 9% increase in   operating expenses led operating income to drop 3.4%. Net income   slumped by a smaller 1.6% thanks to an increase in other income
column18: which includes income for interest and dividends
column19: among other   items.Apple was able to grow its EPS because of its expansive share   buyback program. The company's diluted share count declined by   4.8% year over year
column20: fueled by billions of dollars of share   buybacks. Apple spent $10.9 billion on share buybacks during the   first quarter alone
column21: an 57% increase compared to the prior-year   period.To be fair
column22: Apple still generated $17.9 billion of net income   during the quarter
column23: a staggering sum. But the fact that profit   and revenue are moving in opposite directions should be a concern   for investors. There's nothing wrong with share buybacks
column24: especially when cash continues to pile up. But they're the only   reason Apple was able to set an EPS record.An extra weekDid you know that Apple's first quarter this year had 14   weeks
column25: compared to 13 weeks in the first quarter last year? If   you only read Apple's press release
column26: this fact may come as a   surprise. Amongst all the talk of records
column27: there's no mention of   the extra week. You would have had to delve into the 10-Q or   listen to the conference call in order to find recognition of   this substantial tailwind.If you just take the numbers and adjust them for this extra   week
column28: the quarter doesn't look so good. Revenue would have   slumped 4.1%
column29: iPhone unit sales would have declined 2.8%
column30: and   operating income would have tumbled 10.3%. This is a simplistic   way to adjust for the extra week
column31: as sales weren't spread out   uniformly throughout the quarter. But it gives a sense of how   significant an extra week can be.During the conference call
column32: CFO Luca Maestri pointed to four   factors that offset this extra week. Slower growth of China   inventory
column33: an earlier launch of the iPhone 7 compared to the   iPhone 6s in the previous year
column34: a stronger U.S. dollar
column35: and a   patent infringement payment in the first quarter of last year all   hurt the company's results relative to the prior-year period.Maestri doesn't say by what degree these factors offset the   extra week
column36: and in the absence of an extra week
column37: they would have   read like a list of excuses. Adjusted for that extra week
column38: Apple's first quarter wasn't as solid as the headline numbers   suggest. It almost certainly wasn't as bad as my simplistic   calculation above
column39: but it puts an asterisk next to Apple's   numbers.The good news for Apple investors is that the company's   guidance for the second quarter was positive. Apple expects to   produce between $51.5 billion and $53.5 billion of revenue
column40: up   from $50.6 billion during the second quarter of last year. Gross   margin is expected to decline
column41: which will again pressure Apple's   bottom line. But the major sales declines of the past few   quarters appear to be in the rearview mirror -- at least for   now.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column42: it can pay to listen. After all
column43: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column44: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column45: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: Buy Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Stock on This Q4 Earnings Dip;2/2/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsA few years ago
column4: analysts had to add numbers from dozens of retail companies to see how Christmas went. Now they just wait on the earnings fromAmazon.com
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)
column6: which came out after the market closed on Feb. 2. Unfortunately
column7: Christmas wasn't as rosy as hoped
column8: and AMZN stock is down about 4% in Thursday's after-market trade as a result.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockAmazon's final numbers were somewhat mixed. AMZN beat estimates on the earnings front
column9: bringing in $1.54 per share - better than the consensus mark of $1.40
column10: and the company's seventh straight quarter of profit.But Amazon was light on revenues
column11: at $43.74 billion versus expectations of $44.84 billion. That still was a big jump from the $35.75 billion in revs last year
column12: but not enough to please investors or experts. That caused AMZN stock to drop 4% within minutes.Bad news for most
column13: though some - includingBlue Chip Growtheditor Louis Navellier - were hoping to buy Amazon stock on the dip.CEO Jeff Bezos emphasized the variety of Amazon Prime servicesin his release
column14: mentioning new offerings in gaming
column15: storage
column16: music and its Prime Now same-day shopping services. The company's studio launched hit shows likeThe Grand TourandMan in the High Castle
column17: while the movieManchester by the Seadrew Oscar nominations but will debut on Prime within a few months.5 Stocks to Buy to Defy a Weak FebruaryOur James Brumley was expecting fireworks after earnings
column18: but most options traders were not making big bets either way. Most recently
column19: I took some money off the table on Amazon
column20: which as I noted was becoming a huge piece of my retirement savings.The biggest news from the analyst community was a super-bull call from Bill Miller
column21: chairman of LMM Investments
column22: claiming the value of AMZN stockcould double again in three years- making it more valuable thanApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL). He also stating that Amazon now has higher gross margins thanWal-Mart Stores Inc.(NYSE:WMT)
column23: which regularly sells nearly $120 billion of merchandise each quarter - not just at Christmas.The big turn in Amazon stock started when the company started breaking out numbers from Amazon Web Services
column24: its cloud services unit
column25: after the first quarter of 2015. Since then
column26: the company has more than doubled
column27: as the unit has been growing at 50% per year and proving it can book one-fourth of that revenue as operating profit
column28: even when accounting for stock options given its top employees.In the third quarter
column29: for instance
column30: AWS earned $861 million on revenues of $3.231 billion. Yes
column31: that's more thanthe whole company earned. Amazon still loses money regularly on its international expansion
column32: where it now brings in nearly one-third of its revenue. For the fourth quarter
column33: AWS brought in revenue of $3.54 billion
column34: which was seen as disappointing.Why Buy AMZN Stock Now?It's the expectation of huge growth on a massive scale that have made Amazon the fourth-largest company by market capitalization in the U.S. It recently passedBerkshire Hathaway Inc.(NYSE:BRK.B)
column35: whose revenues regularly run 50% better than Amazon's Christmas expectations.Shares dropped 5.1% the day after the third quarter missed expectations oOct. 27
column36: and you could have gotten Amazon for $719 per share two weeks later
column37: on Nov. 14. But since then the stock has been on fire
column38: and closed before earnings near $840 per share.Alibaba Group Holding Ltd (BABA) Stock Has a Secret WeaponBuyers keep coming for Amazon because every quarter
column39: it seems to do something spectacular.This quarter
column40: for instance
column41: it delivered a new credit card offering 5% all Amazon purchases to Prime members. It announced a new air hub near Cincinnati
column42: sinking sharesofUnited Parcel Service
column43: Inc.(NYSE:UPS) andFedEx Corporation(NYSE:FDX). Its Alexa personal assistant dominated the Consumer Electronics Show
column44: as our Brad Moon reported.All this has made AMZN stock a must-have for a growing number of small investors
column45: who race in whenever the stock stumbles.Just like it did this afternoon.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column46: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing
column47: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryThe 5 Best Stocks to Buy for Big Emerging Markets Profits7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018The postBuy Amazon.com

column1: Apple's Biggest Growth Engine (Services) Coming of Age;2/2/2017;"While iPhones returning to growth is good news of course
column2: it's evident that the business has lost momentum. Penetration levels have increased significantly with the scope for further innovation shrinking with each new product generation. So users not just in traditional markets but also in some emerging markets have less of a reason to upgrade.Since AppleAAPLsells a high-end product
column3: its market is further limited. So a jump in the holiday sales doesn't excite me as much as the fact that the number of iPhone users increased double-digits during the quarter. Because it is the installed base of over a billion active devices that Apple can count on to use its services and generate recurring revenue for the company.What Services Did This QuarterApple's service revenue grew 13.4% sequentially and 18.4% year over year to around $7.2 billion. Management said that growth would have been higher taking out the one-time receipt of $548 million in the year-ago quarter and adjusting for the extra week of sales in December. This is the fourth straight quarter that services grew strong double-digits and contributed an equal or greater share of revenue than both Macs and iPads
column4: making it the second most significant segment behind iPhones.At just 9% of revenue
column5: Apple however has no legal compulsion to provide too much detail on what this business is about. It does offer interesting tidbits though such as the paid subscriptions number that was over 150 million in the last quarter.Consequently
column6: services include a motley crowd
column7: the chief of which is the App Store. This business ""broke all-time records during the holiday quarter
column8: including $3 billion in purchases in December alone
column9: making it the App Store's single best month ever
column10: in the words of CEO Tim Cook. Over 2.2 million developers are currently working on apps for the App Store and payments to developers have now topped $60 billion.So it isn't surprising that both the average revenue per customer account and the number of customer accounts grew strongly. Apple also quoted App Annie as saying that App Store revenue more than doubled Google Play revenue in calendar 2016. Another positive about this business is that it isn't geographically limited
column11: meaning that even a soft market like China is currently contributing to sales.Apple Music grew for the third straight quarter as Apple enabled downloads in addition to the streaming business. It has had good luck with exclusive content to date and is currently looking at original content to further push things.Apple Pay users tripled
column12: transaction volumes jumped 500% running into the billions of dollars as the service expanded to Japan
column13: Russia
column14: New Zealand and Spain. Nearly 2 million small businesses are accepting payments through Apple Pay.AppleCare is closely linked to the growth in the installed base
column15: so it continues to grow strongly.iCloud storage services are doing well
column16: and that's all that Apple will say about it.Why's This So Important?It's hard to overstate the importance of this segment as mobile computing devices race to their saturation point. Device sales overall are coming down and what little growth is there today will be gone tomorrow. Upgrades will be fewer and sales will depend on the ability to take market share.The other reason is profitability. Management says very little about the margin profile and makes sure we understand that there are many parts to this business that don't generate the same margins. But they also say that the segment carries higher margins than the rest of the business.This makes perfect sense since hardware generally carries lower margins than software that is increasingly offered as a service these days. So as the mix of this business grows
column17: it will fetch stronger margins for Apple.Also
column18: while Apple has successfully convinced customers its devices are worth the money
column19: hardware innovation hasn't been that great in recent times and could get more difficult going forward. So differentiation could be rooted in the software ecosystem more than it has been thus far.Apple shares currently carry a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). Technology stocks with better prospects are Anixter InternationalAXE

column1: What's Next for iPhones After Strong Holiday Quarter?;2/2/2017;"AppleAAPLshares jumped over 6% yesterday after the company returned to growth in the first quarter of fiscal 2017. A lot of the optimism was on account of iPhone sales
column2: which grew 4.7% from last year to the highest ever tally of 78.3 million units or around two-thirds of total sales. Street estimates varied between 77-78 million units.Apple Inc. Price and EPS SurpriseApple Inc. Price and EPS Surprise|Apple Inc. Quote""iPhone's Best Performance for Over a Year""Neil Mawston
column3: Executive Director at Strategy Analytics
column4: said in a statement that this was the iPhone's best performance in over a year
column5: putting it back on top as the world's largest smartphone vendor. But he also said that the numbers were helped by the Samsung Note 7 fiasco. As a result
column6: Samsung didn't see as much of the fourth-quarter bump-up as it usually does (it still managed a 29% share in the U.S. compared to Apple's 31%
column7: according to Kantar Worldpanel).Apple's growth rate was also slightly lower than in the year-ago quarter
column8: and was likely impacted by the stronger dollar and by stiff competition from local players in China like Huawei
column9: ZTE
column10: Lenovo
column11: OPPO and Vivo that may have led to a loss in market share. Revenues from China were down 12% in the last quarter. Tim Cook used an optimistic tone: ""I'm encouraged with the significant improvement but we're not without challenges there.""He also said that sales would have been stronger if demand for the more expensive iPhone 7 Plus hadn't been underestimated. As it turned out
column12: the more expensive device was more popular based on new features like better cameras and more RAM
column13: which therefore led to a supply shortage. If it wasn't such a competitive market
column14: this may not have been such a bad problem to have.However
column15: it does reverse an earlier trend that saw the iPhone 6S Plus and iPhone 6 Plus growing slower than their less expensive partners. It also seems to indicate that customers are unwilling to upgrade without meaningful new features
column16: but will pay more for them when they're there.As a result
column17: the two new models that also came with water resistance while ditching the headphone socket accounted for 17% of iPhone sales
column18: according to research firm Localytics
column19: as reported in the media. This also raised the average selling price to $695 from $691 in the year-ago quarter.The Good and Bad Going ForwardSmartphone sales growth rates are not going to come back to where they've been the last few years. For example
column20: consider that the iPhone 6 launch in Sep 2014 was followed by a 46% increase in shipments the following quarter. This kind of growth is history
column21: because penetration continues to increase across the world.Second
column22: Apple's growth rates have also been fueled by market share gains in China
column23: which may not be repeated for a number of reasons including greater penetration
column24: the stronger dollar
column25: a more difficult operating environment
column26: the increasingly strained relations between China and the U.S. and the abundant supply of local makes of varying price tags.Third
column27: Apple is likely to maintain or even grow share in developed markets and markets with higher penetration on the strength of its brand. But these upgrades will be dependent on innovation. Tim Cook says: ""The smartphone is still in the early innings of the game
column28: and ""I think there's lots more to do... We've got some exciting things in the pipeline. I still feel really
column29: really good about it."" But if the upgrades over the past two years are anything to go by
column30: it seems that there's a limit to that innovation.That of course brings us to the question of the upcoming iPhone 8 that is expected to have an all-new design
column31: glass casing and other exciting features. Plus
column32: it's the iPhone's 10thanniversary
column33: so there's some pent-up excitement there. If Apple delivers in line with the hype
column34: it should have blockbuster sales. Beginning in the September quarter when it will launch that is and provided Apple doesn't under-supply the things. Until then
column35: we should expect customers to hold off purchases (more so than in earlier years because the excitement for the new phone is more this time).The other somewhat positive factor is India where Apple's talks with government officials appear to be going well. India is a faster-growing market than China at the moment because of relatively lower penetration
column36: a rising middle class and the Prime Minister's stated goal of digitizing the nation. Once Apple starts building its stores in the region
column37: its brand value is bound to appreciate and translate into increased sales for the company. But it's not a done deal yet
column38: especially considering the concessions Apple is asking for
column39: so some uncertainty persists.Apple shares currently carry a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). Technology stocks with better potential are Anixter InternationalAXE
column40: Aspen TechnologyAZPN
column41: KLA-TencorKLACor Inphi Corp.IPHI

You can even look inside exclusive portfolios that are normally closed to new investors. Starting today

column1: Thursday Apple Rumors: New AAPL Patent Includes Watch Band Battery;2/2/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is a new patent for a Watch band. Today
column3: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Thursday.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleWatch Band:AAPL has been granted a patent for a possible future Watch band
column4: reports9to5Mac. The patent shows off a Watch band that may be able to keep the company's smartwatch running for multiple days. This band includes a battery that would be able power the smartwatch. The patent also mentions that the band could be charged by the same dock used to charge the Watch. Another small detail to note in the patent is the watch itself. This watch is circular in design
column5: which is different from the current square style AAPL sells.iPad Future:Tim Cook is still excited for the iPad despite declining sales
column6: MacRumorsnotes. Cook recently said that there are ""exciting things"" coming to the iPad. He also said that he is ""optimistic"" about where things are heading for the device. All of this comes on the heels of declining sales in the holiday season. AAPL sold 13.1 million in its most recent quarter
column7: which is down from the 16.1 million sold during the same time in 2015.MacBook Processor:A new rumor claims that Apple is working on its own processor for MacBooks
column8: reportsBloomberg. According to this rumor
column9: the tech company is working withARM Holdingsto design the component. The rumor claims that this processor won't replace the ones provided byIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC). Instead
column10: is says that the processor will work alongside the Intel one and will mostly handle low power tasks. This rumor comes from unnamed sources that are close to the matter.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postThursday Apple Rumors: New AAPL Patent Includes Watch Band Batteryappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Google Earnings: The Market Has Made The Same Mistake Twice;2/2/2017;"Google Earnings (Shutterstock photo)As a general rule
column2: the market is pretty good about learning from its mistakes. After all
column3: there is nothing like a hefty loss to teach traders what not to do.That is a simple fact that must be borne in mind when looking for patterns in pricing; if the pattern involves a reaction to news that was ultimately proven wrong
column4: it is unlikely to repeat very often
column5: and the few opportunities when it does should be grabbed with both hands.makeArticleAd();That is what makes Google parent company Alphabet (GOOG:GOOGL) look like such a good buy after its reaction to Q4 earnings.As you can see from the chart below
column6: prior to last week’s earnings report Google (I’m sorry but I just can’t bring myself to call the company “Alphabet”) had dropped sharply on earnings misses contained in two of the previous three releases
column7: in April and October.On both of those occasions
column8: though
column9: the big drop in price was
column10: with the benefit of 20/20 hindsight
column11: an opportunity to buy the stock at a discount. There are different circumstances this time around
column12: of course
column13: but the dynamic that has made negative reactions to earnings in the past opportunities is still in place
column14: so the end result is likely to be the same.The biggest problems with the Q4 results as far as traders were concerned
column15: it seems
column16: were that cost per click was down
column17: and operating costs had risen to the point where earnings per Class A share (EPS) of $9.36 fell short of the Street’s estimates of around $9.64. Still
column18: revenues of $26.06 billion beat the estimated $25.26 billion.There was also a concern lurking in the background regarding Google taking on both Amazon (AMZN)’s Echo and Apple (AAPL)’s iPhone with recent hardware launches. Google said that they were pleased with the reaction to both Google Home and the Pixel phone without going into specifics
column19: but doubts about the wisdom of the strategy persist.I actually believe that Google has a chance of limited success in each case. The Pixel will be the most uphill struggle as the iPhone’s dominance of the mobile phone market is well established. Most estimates of sales of the phone so far are around 1 million
column20: which hardly puts a dent in the iPhone
column21: but may prove to be enough of a base to make the Pixel profitable as a niche product.Home has an easier
column22: more logical path to success as Google is the natural choice of those looking for what is
column23: essentially
column24: a free-standing search engine.Ultimately
column25: though
column26: neither Home nor Pixel is going to be the driver of the recovery in the stock price that history suggests will come soon.First
column27: the increase in operating costs that Google reported seems
column28: on a breakdown of the numbers
column29: to be the result of investment in the core business. Losses in what the company calls “Other Bets
column30: ” things like “Nest” and self driving cars
column31: were actually reduced somewhat in the fourth quarter
column32: but there was significant progress on the autonomous vehicle front.The possibilities of that field are endless and Google
column33: along with Tesla (TSLA) and Apple
column34: are generally seen as the leaders in driverless car research and technology.The other issue
column35: of falling cost per click (CPC)
column36: is also not what it seems on the surface. It reflects a continuing move to mobile that results in that metric falling
column37: but the volume of clicks increasing. The same issue was
column38: in part
column39: responsible for the April and October drops in GOOG after earnings
column40: and the chart tells the story of how long it was until investors realized that volume more than offset falling CPC.Looking at Google’s results and the market reaction to them
column41: I get a sense of déjà vu. We have actually been here before
column42: twice
column43: and each time the drop in GOOG gave investors a chance to buy cheaply. It seems that in this case the market is still learning from its mistake and over time the outcome here is most likely to be the same."

column6: 2017 - Zacks Value Investor is a podcast hosted weekly by Zacks Stock Strategist Tracey Ryniec. Every week
column7: Tracey will be joined by guests to discuss the hottest investing topics in stocks
column8: bonds and ETFs and how it impacts your life. To listen to the podcast
column9: click here: (https://www.zacks.com/stock/news/247797/are-your-favorite-stocks-cheap)Are Your Favorite Stocks Cheap?Welcome to Episode #28 of the Value Investor PodcastEvery week
column10: Zacks value stock strategist and the Editor ofZacks Value Investor portfolio
column11: Tracey Ryniec
column12: talks about all things happening in the value stock universe
column13: including her top stock picks.It's earnings season so that means some stocks will get a boost off their reports
column14: and others will get sold off. These days
column15: an earnings miss or a warning on guidance can be enough to send a stock down by the double digits.If you're a value investor
column16: your first thought upon seeing a big sell off in a stock is probably ""is that stock cheap enough for me to buy now?""There have been some juicy sell offs already this earnings season. Additionally
column17: some other ""favorite"" stocks that many people own seem out of favor or down on their luck.Are These Favorite Stocks Cheap Enough to Be Values?1. Under Armour (NYSE:UAA-Free Report) sold off 25% on its first earnings miss in 5 years. Shares are now down over 50% from their highs. But is it a value?2. Starbucks (NASDAQ:SBUX-Free Report) went nowhere after its earnings reports. Shares also fell 9% in the last year
column18: underperforming the market. The company appears to be out-of-favor with investors. (In full disclosure
column19: Tracey is a long-term owner of it in her personal portfolio.) Should value investors be taking a look?3. Shake Shack Inc. (NYSE:SHAK-Free Report) was once the darling of Wall Street but shares have fallen 19% over the last 2 years. Is the growth catching up with the valuation now?4. Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report) just reported earnings. Revenues surprised the Street. Is it one of the few technology stocks that might be a value stock?5. Williams-Sonoma Inc. (NYSE:WSM-Free Report) owns one of the top brands in home furnishings: West Elm. But it's other brands are struggling. It doesn't report earnings until March but should value investors be keeping an eye on this retailer?Investors should always dig deeper than simply the value fundamentals before making a decision to buy a stock. Does the company have rising earnings estimates? What does the growth picture look like?Just because a company has always been an expensive growth stock doesn't mean it always will be in the future.Find out more about what Tracey thinks about the buying opportunities in these popular stocks in this week's podcast.Have a question for Tracey?Do you have a value investing question for Tracey?Is there a topic you really want covered on an upcoming Value Investor Podcast?She wants to hear from you.Send your questions for Tracey to her e-mail address at:podcast@zacks.com.Want more insights from Tracey?Check out her weekly Value Investor service to receive more in-depth analysis on value companies and see which stocks she thinks are the best bargains now.Click here to learn more.Tracey Ryniec is the Value Stock Strategist for Zacks.com. column1: Are Garmin Ltd. (GRMN) and Fitbit Inc (FIT) the Perfect Long/Short Play?;2/2/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsRecent statistics from the two wearable rivals suggest thatGarmin Ltd.(NASDAQ:GRMN) is winning the war againstFitbit Inc(NYSE:FIT)
column3: making a hypothetical long/short play between the two stocks a very interesting proposition.makeArticleAd();Source:Via FitbitHowever
column4: thinking about buying Garmin and shorting Fitbit stock - and actually following through with it - are two entirely different beasts.I have never shorted a stock and likely never will; I'm just not built that way. Whenever I'm asked byInvestorPlace
column5: or any of the other financial publications I write for
column6: to do a ""sell"" piece on a stock or a group of stocks
column7: I always have a tougher time coming up with recommendations.I like to write about stocks that I would consider owning; negative spin doesn't enter my psyche. I can do it
column8: it's just harder.This brings me to GRMN stock and FIT stock
column9: the crux of this story.Why Fitbit Inc (FIT) Stock Can't Fall Much Lower Than ThisIn Q3 2016
column10: Garmin shipped 1.3 million wearable devices
column11: a 12.2% year-over-year increase. That compares to an 11.0% YOY increase for Fitbit. In Q2 2016
column12: Garmin shipped 1.6 million wearable devices
column13: a 106.7% increase over the same quarter a year earlier
column14: while Fitbit shipped 5.7 million wearable devices
column15: a 28.7% increase over the same quarter a year earlier.So
column16: in the nine months ended September 2016
column17: Garmin shipped 3.8 million wearable devices
column18: a 40.7% increase year over year. Meanwhile
column19: Fitbit shipped 15.8 million wearable devices
column20: a 21.5% increase year over year.Between Q1 2015 and Q3 2016
column21: Garmin's market share dropped by 40 basis points to 5.7%. During the same 18-month period
column22: Fitbit's market share dropped 980 basis points to 23.0%.Fitbit Stock Continues to DeclineSamsung Electronics(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) and the many others that compete for the 50% market share not held by Fitbit
column23: Xiaomi
column24: Garmin
column25: andApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) stand to benefit the most.Garmin is a big company and wearables are but one of many revenue streams. A 40-basis-point decline isn't a big deal for a company that generated $2.2 billion in revenue in the first nine months of fiscal 2016
column26: an increase of 5.8%. If not for its auto segment (its largest by revenue)
column27: which saw a 17% decline year over year to $656.0 million
column28: 2016 has been a winner.Over at Fitbit
column29: the top line has been outstanding
column30: with revenue growing 39.3% through the first nine months of the year to $1.6 billion. However
column31: it's the bottom line that gets a little wonky.In the quarter ended Oct. 1
column33: Fitbit's operating profit declined 33.1% to $44.4 million; for the nine months ended October 1
column35: operating income declined 69.3% to $72.9 million. R&D
column36: sales and marketing
column37: and G&A expenses all have seen huge increases in 2016 as Fitbit struggles to remain on top of a wearables market that's slowing faster than anyone expected.InvestorPlacecontributor Aaron Levitt recently discussed Fitbit stock in relation to aslowing wearables market; he was pretty blunt in his assessment of the job CEO James Park is doing guiding the company through a rough patch that's seen FIT stock decline by 65% over the past year.""Both eMarketer and IDC both cite smartwatches as the big reason for the declines
column38: wrote Levitt. ""Consumers just can't see the need for them as they overlap on features already found in smartphones. And when adding their heftier price tags
column39: smartwatches are a fading fad.""So
column40: what does Fitbit do to counter the fact that wearables' 2016 growth will be less than half the 60% projection at the start of the year? It buys not one
column41: but two companies that make smartwatches.Bottom Line on Fitbit and GarminIf Fitbit continues to waste money on bad acquisitions and wasteful overhead that doesn't move the needle
column42: you can bet that Fitbit's comfy cash position - $672 million in cash and marketable securities as of Q3 - will be gone faster than you can shake a stick at.So
column43: should you go long on Garmin? Absolutely. With$1.1 billionin cash and marketable securities
column44: no debt
column45: and an operating margin of almost 21%
column46: GRMN stock is a long-term hold.3 Stocks to Buy for Better Deals Than the Great RecessionAs for shorting FIT stock
column47: I'm of two minds on this.Yes
column48: theshorts represent almost 36% of its floatand its margins are about one-third Garmin's
column49: but with $3 in cash it's got to be attractive to somebody in the industry - maybe even Garmin. That should keep Fitbit stock from dropping much farther.So
column50: I wouldn't recommend investors buy or short Fitbit stock. Neither proposition looks like it will be a winner any time soon.More From InvestorPlaceThe 5 Best Stocks to Buy for Big Emerging Markets ProfitsHere's How Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Can Reclaim Its ThroneWhy Under Armour Inc (UA) Stock Could Be ScrewedThe postAre Garmin Ltd. (GRMN) and Fitbit Inc (FIT) the Perfect Long/Short Play?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Why Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Will NEVER Be About P/E;2/2/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOne of the biggest negatives surroundingAmazon.com
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) is the company's sky-high price-to-earnings ratio. According to Google Finance
column5: AMZN stock currently trades at an eye-popping 191 times its trailing earnings of $4.36 per share.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockBut Amazon has at least given investors the courtesy of growing profits to try to somewhat justify the lofty valuation. That 191x is on trailing 12-month earnings of $4.36 per share. In fiscal 2015
column6: AMZN earned $596 million
column7: or $1.25 per share. In 2014
column8: it lost $241 million
column9: which translates into 52 cents per share.It's obvious Amazon stock investors care about growth
column10: not valuation. AMZN's sky-high P/E has been in place for years
column11: and will likely continue for some time.And that's actually OK. Here are two important reasons why:Amazon Revenue GrowthAmazon is still one of the best growth stories in today's market.When the company releases 2016's final numbers Thursday
column12: Feb. 2
column13: analysts expect Amazon to post revenue of $137 billion. That's an improvement of more than 25% versus 2015's top line - a difficult feat when you're talking about 12-digit sales. And Amazon's $107 billion in revenue last year was 20% better than 2014.5 Stocks to Buy to Defy a Weak FebruaryWe live in a world in whichS&P 500constituents are doing well if they're posting just single-digit increases on the top line. You can blame this at least partly on the strong U.S. dollar
column14: which is weighing down American multinationals. But the fact remains that meaningful growth is a scarce quality in today's stock market - especially among blue-chip stocks.Thus
column15: AMZN stock is an easy way for investors to get access to big growth with relatively little risk.And Amazon is hardly running out of fuel. The company has only begun to expand into grocery and apparel - two huge categories. Trillions of dollars are spent worldwide each year at physical stores. That's not to mention the other gains Amazon still could make via the smart home
column16: Amazon Web Services cloud offerings and other newer initiatives.Analysts predict Amazon's revenue will increase another 22% in 2017
column17: hitting $168 billion. So again - the growth story is still well intact.But it's not all about growth. Many AMZN stock bulls argue that we're just looking at earnings the wrong way.Amazon Earnings: Better Than They Seem?One thing that separates Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos from many other executives is his ability to look at the really
column18: reallylong-term. He's also willing to spend billions of dollars on ideas
column19: and is OK with hitting a few duds if it means spawning great new ideas.Remember the company's smartphone? The Amazon Music Importer? How about a website called Askville? I'm guessing you might remember the Fire smartphone
column20: but not the other two. Amazon lost $170 million on its smartphone alone.This kind of risk taking is an inherent part of Amazon's culture. It's the line of thinking that prodded the company to introduce some of its biggest winners to date
column21: like cloud services
column22: Prime shipping and the Kindle.Thus
column23: many investors look at AMZN stock in a different way. They look at the company's operating profit
column24: then they add back its substantial research and development costs to get a ""truer"" sense of profitability.Admittedly
column25: that changes the picture dramatically.Apple Inc. Bulls: Beware These Charts! (AAPL)In its most recent quarter
column26: Amazon produced net income of $252 million
column27: which across 485 million diluted shares became diluted earnings of 52 cents per share. At the time
column28: AMZN was trading at $822 per share. If we annualize that profit (not a perfect measure
column29: as quarterly earnings fluctuate - this is just for an example)
column30: we're looking at a P/E of 395.But Amazon also reported operating profits of $575 million
column31: and spent $4.14 billion on R&D - a significant expense. Add those together
column32: and you get $4.715 billion
column33: or $9.72 per share. Annualize that
column34: then divide the share price by that
column35: and you get a P/E of about 21.Let's take the actual numbers. Amazon currently trades for 190 times trailing 12-month earnings
column36: as we said above. However
column37: over the past four quarters
column38: Amazon spent $15.11 billion on R&D and posted operating profits of more than $4 billion. That comes to $40.19 per share combined
column39: and puts AMZN stock at a P/E of just more than 20.That's a lot of creative accounting
column40: so take that with a spoonful of salt. But it's an interesting argument.Bottom Line on AMZN StockAmazon continues to be one of the best growth stories in today's market. As long as that continues
column41: investors aren't going to care about the headline P/E ratio. It just doesn't matter. AMZN stock has doubled several times over despite it.Amazon is solidly profitable
column42: even if the bottom line isn't as large as investors typically would like. But those earnings are being reinvested back in the business - which is what a high-growth company like Amazon should be doing anyway.As of this writing
column43: Nelson Smith did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceWhy Amazon.com

column1: Apple Inc. Bulls: Beware These Charts! (AAPL);2/2/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsShares ofApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rallied a strong 6% on Wednesday following the company's latest earnings report. While the rally was impressive
column3: AAPL stock is now bumping into some critical technical resistance that bulls and bears alike should be aware of.makeArticleAd();Simply put
column4: Apple's near- to possibly medium-term upside is limited at best.Apple's revenues in the latest quarter came in at a record $78.4 billion
column5: which in part was helped by strong holiday demand for the new iPhone 7 series. These numbers are impressive
column6: and I continue to be a longer-term believer in the company - particularly around the potential of AAPL being able to monetize deeper on the devices ecosystem through more services.When Ilast discussed shares of Appleon Dec. 28
column8: I offered that if AAPL stock could clear above the $118 price level
column9: then a next upside target around $123 would come into sight. Apple met and surpassed this target on Wednesday following the earnings announcement.From that perspective
column10: Apple shares have now reached an important upside price target.AAPL Stock ChartsLet's take a step back and look at the multiyear weekly chart of AAPL stock. We see that despite the big swing lower from the 2015 highs into the mid-2016 lows
column11: and most recently back up toward the 2015 highs
column12: Apple has
column13: largely speaking
column14: not really accomplished much since early 2015.Click to EnlargeBulls
column15: however
column16: note that the May 2016 lows coincided with critical technical support made up of horizontal support (lower purple-dotted line) as well as the 200-week simple moving average (red). Equally important
column17: on the other hand
column18: is that after Wednesday's post-earnings rally
column19: AAPL is now within a few points of these aforementioned previous all-time highs from 2015. Through a technical lens
column20: this could offer up as much resistance as the 2015 lows offered support.In other words
column21: before Apple stock can sustainably break to new all-time highs
column22: a consolidation phase most likely is in order.Looking at the daily chart
column23: we see that since mid-November 2016
column24: AAPL stock has now rallied approximately 25%
column25: which is not a small move for the stock to accomplish in a matter of two-and-a-half months.Click to EnlargeA simple yet accurate observation through the lens of technical analysis is that old all-time highs are not easily overcome on the first try
column26: particularly if the stock has not consolidated below or near those previous all-time highs for some time.Apple's current chart thus is in dire need of some consolidation before it can make a better attempt at fresh all-time highs on a more sustainable basis.How to Trade Apple Stock HereI see two specific trades setting up:If AAPL stock breaks and holds below Wednesday's intraday lows around $127
column27: then the stock could be played from the short side for a mean-reversion move back into the mid- to low $120s. Alternatively
column28: options traders could also look to sell out-of-the-money call spreads on the stock at that time.Quicker traders could look to buy AAPL stock for fast profits should the stock push and hold above Wednesday's intraday highs around $130.50 for a move toward the 2015 highs around $133.Either way
column29: upside in AAPL stock through a multiweek/multimonth lens is likely limited. Trades should be constructed accordingly.Like what you see? Sign up for our dailyBeat the Belle-letter and get Serge's investment advice delivered to your inbox every morning! Download Serge's Free Special Report:6 Keys for Successful Trading and Investing.The postApple Inc. Bulls: Beware These Charts! (AAPL)appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: The S&P 500 Holds in the Face of Uncertainty;2/2/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOn Wednesday
column3: shares ofApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) jumped 6.1% following a report that showed an increased demand for its iPhone 7. The record increase in revenues of $78.4 billion ended a record of three consecutive quarters of declines
column4: and helped theDow Jones Industrial Averagegain 0.1% by adding 51 points to the index. Apple's gain also helped propel theNasdaqto a gain for the day of 0.5%.makeArticleAd();Apple's gain helped the session to open higher
column5: but the positive impact of one stock's opening didn't' last long. All of the gains of the opening were lost by noon. However
column6: following the noon hour's lows
column7: a Federal Reserve decision to leave interest rates unchanged
column8: and several positive economic reports helped gain back about half of the morning's losses enabling the major indices to close with modest gains.5 Stocks to Buy to Defy a Weak FebruaryAt the close
column9: the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 27 points at 19
column11: theS&P 500eked out a point at 2
column13: the Nasdaq rose 28 points to close at 5
column14: 643 and theRussell 2000closed at 1
column16: unchanged. The NYSE's primary exchange traded 1 billion shares with total volume of 3.9 billion shares. The Nasdaq crossed 2.2 billion shares. On the Big Board
column17: decliners edged out advancers by 1.1-to-1
column18: while the Nasdaq broke even. The NYSE's blocks were reported as 6
column19: 510 down from 6
column20: 786 on Tuesday.Click to EnlargeIn spite of the many underlying uncertainties
column21: the S&P 500 (and the Nasdaq) have maintained support. The S&P 500's December high at 2
column22: 277 is the ""line in the sand"" for this major index
column23: as is Nasdaq's January high at 5
column24: 574.Conclusion:The January closing highs of the major indices are breakout points that must hold if the short-term and intermediate-term trend is to remain intact.A gap exists on the 500 from 2
column26: 286. That gap was partially closed by yesterday's intraday high at 2
column27: 289. This technical issue is an important focus for this major index
column28: since a failure to proceed higher could easily lead to a 5% to 10% correction. So far the major indices have resisted the anxiety produced by many uncertainties
column29: choosing to hold or buy rather than give in to the sellers.The line at 2
column30: 277 was pierced but recovered. The question now is
column31: ""Can it hold?""Today's Trading LandscapeTo see a list of the companies reporting earnings today
column32: click here.For a list of this week's economic reports due out
column33: click here.Tell us what you think about this article! Drop us an email ateditor@investorplace.com
column34: chat with us on Twitter at@InvestorPlaceorcomment on the post on Facebook. Read more about ourcomments policy here.The postThe S&P 500 Holds in the Face of Uncertaintyappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 5 Top Dividend Aristocrats to Buy in February;2/2/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();The Federal Reserve maintained interest rates in February
column2: providing no update on the next hike. The Fed's reluctance in raising rates should stand in good stead for dividend aristocrats.President Donald Trump's travel ban
column3: in the meanwhile
column4: could result in a possible rise in erratic share price movement this month. The stock market has also
column5: traditionally
column6: seen weak results this month
column7: especially after an election. In such a scenario
column8: investing in dividend aristocrats  seems prudent as they provide higher total returns with lower volatility
column9: which are undoubtedly the 'holy grail' of investing.Fed Leaves Rates UnchangedAs widely expected
column10: the Fed has kept rates unchanged following a two-day policy meeting on Feb 1. The central bank kept its benchmark overnight lending rate target at a range of 0.5% to 0.75%. The bank had lifted rates by a quarter percentage point in December
column11: marking the second hike in more than 10 years.In fact
column12: the central bank penciled three quarter-point moves this year in December. More importantly for investors
column13: the central bank didn't drop any hints of raising rates in the March meet
column14: placing the probability of such a move at only 18%
column15: according to CME Group.In this case
column16: high qualitydividend stockshave become more appealing as their stock prices don't suffer when rates aren't rising. Conversely
column17: bond markets
column18: which tend to benefit from a rise in interest rates
column19: have lost its lure.Trump Stirs Up a TempestThe Fed's positive view of the economy and Apple Inc.'sAAPLstellar earnings helped stocks rally a little higher on Feb 1. However
column20: investors have not yet recovered from the blow of Trump's immigration ban. An executive order by Trump banned immigration from seven Muslim-majority countries
column21: including legal residents and visa holders. Trump had earlier fostered expectations that his administration will be business friendly and therefore should bode well for the equity market. This decision has drawn congressional criticism and widespread protests. These protectionist measures may also cloud the path for pro-business initiatives as several world and corporate leaders condemn the ban.Airlines bore the brunt as well as several airports across the country saw violent protests
column22: disrupting operations to a great extent. Tech firms also faced obstacles in sourcing labor from foreign lands. Trump's first press conference since July also disappointed investors due to lack of policy detail. He severely criticized pharmaceutical companies over high drug prices
column23: dealing a blow to leading biotech stocks.Such uncertainties make dividend paying stocks more attractive as they tend to outperform when the broader markets are subject to gyrations. Notably
column24: the month of February has traditionally seen weak numbers just after the election.February: Traditionally a Weak MonthFebruary has been the weakest month for stocks over the past four decades
column25: averaging just a 0.06% gain. In fact
column26: in post-election years
column27: February tends to be weaker. The average return has decreased 1.85% since 1977.Lest we forget
column28: markets have gone 74 days without a 1% daily decline
column29: hence
column30: the seasonality pattern increases the odds of a wider decline in February.Why Dividend Aristocrats? 5 Solid ChoicesDividend aristocrats outperform other dividend payers on better quality business. This category of stocks reflect a solid financial structure and healthy underlying fundamentals. Such stocks are immune to market vagaries and have also raked in excellent risk-adjusted returns over the last decade. In fact
column31: in the last one year
column32: the S&P High Yield Dividend Aristocrats Index rallied 19.6%
column33: above the S&P 500's 17.5%.Dividend Aristocrats generated an annualized return of 9.7% over the past 10 years
column34: easily topping the broader market's 6.3% rate. During this period
column35: dividends accounted for 31% of the market's total return
column36: highlighting their importance in determining total shareholder return.We have
column37: thus
column38: selected five such dividend aristocrats to boost your returns. Such stocks also possess a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy). The favorable Zacks Rank should help these stocks gain further this year as well. You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stocks here.C. R. Bard
column39: Inc.BCRdesigns
column40: manufactures
column41: packages
column42: distributes and sells medical
column43: surgical
column44: diagnostic
column45: and patient care devices. The company has raised its dividend for over 40 straight years. Bard has a dividend yield of 0.44% while its five-year average dividend yield is pegged at 6.45%. The company's expected growth rate for the current year is 13%
column46: way ahead of the industry's estimated return of 6.7%.Illinois Tool Works Inc.ITWmanufactures and sells industrial products and equipment.
