column4: Nokia marked a growth of 3.95%
column5: while the Zacks-categorizedWireless Equipmentindustry declined 3.64%.Let's see how things are shaping up for this announcement.Factors at PlayWe are concerned about the recent below-par performance of Nokia's primary division - the Networks unit. Further
column6: the company expects net sales in Nokia Networks unit to fall in 2016 due to the declining wireless infrastructure market
column7: among other headwinds.Meanwhile
column8: we are also concerned about the outcome of the company's legal action against Apple Inc.AAPLregarding patent infringement. The company also faces tough competition from peers like Cisco Systems
column9: Inc.CSCO

column11: we are positive on the company's plans to acquire Deepfield and Eta Devices and installation of the 4.5G wireless network infrastructure globally. The company's efforts to provide the LTE-R mobile broadband network to Korea Rail Network Authority (""KRNA"") is also impressive.Earnings WhispersOur proven model does not conclusively show that Nokia is likely to beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate this quarter. This is because a stock needs to have both a positiveEarnings ESPand a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy)

column1: Videogame Stock Roundup: Microsoft Reports Q2 Earnings
column2: Nintendo Launches Pokemon Go in South Korea;1/27/2017;"Among the top stories this week
column3: Microsoft Corp.MSFTreported second-quarter fiscal 2017 results. In a separate development
column4: after almost a six-month delay
column5: South Korean gamers can now enjoy Pokémon Go as NintendoNTDOYlaunched the game officially in the country.Meanwhile
column6: Facebook IncFBzeroed in on Hugo Barra
column7: an ex-Xiaomi executive to spearhead its VR initiatives.Recap of the Developments1. Microsoft's second-quarter fiscal 2017 adjusted earnings of 83 cents and revenues $26.07 billion easily beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate. Though gaming is a very small part of the company's business
column8: Xbox is an important aspect of the overall video game industry. Microsoft's gaming revenues fell 3% (1% in constant currency). Xbox Live monthly active users were up 17% to 55 million. The company witnessed more than 26 billion hours of gameplay on Windows 10 PCs and tablets.The company's shares have surged 26% compared with the ZacksComputer-Softwareindustry's gain of 24.31% in the last one year.At present
column9: Microsoft carries a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy). You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy)   stocks here.2. After a six-month delay
column10: Nintendo has now officiallylaunchedits blockbuster hit game
column11: Pokémon Go in South Korea
column12: on both Alphabet'sGOOGLPlay Store and Apple Inc.'sAAPLiOS store. Per media reports
column13: Nintendo's Pokémon Go works with Google Maps
column14: which has ""limited access"" in South Korea. Niantic had earlier sought permission from the South Korean government for access to Korean maps
column15: which was flatly refused. Google had not agreed to South Korean government's demand to ""blur"" sensitive locations like government buildings on Maps.Reportedly
column16: the denial stemmed from the fact that South Korea remains concerned about its national security. It doesn't share warm ties with its neighbor
column17: North Korea. The simmering border tension between the two nations has led the South Korean government to disallow storage of detailed maps of the country on any other servers except those in South Korea
column18: add media reports.It remains unknown how Niantic
column19: the firm which developed Pokémon Go
column20: bypassed the Maps issue
column21: add media reports. Niantic chose to remain silent on this issue during the press conference it held in Seoul on Jan 23
column22: 2017.Nintendo carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). The success of Pokémon Go helped the company's share price. Over the past one year
column23: its shares are up 55.86% compared with ZacksToys/Games/ Hobby/Productsindustry's gain of 18.42%.3. Meanwhile
column24: Facebook chief Mark Zuckerberg in a post announced that ex-Xiaomi vice president
column25: Hugo Barra will spearhead all the company's VR initiatives as well as the Oculus unit. Zuckerberg further added ""Hugo shares my belief that virtual and augmented reality will be the next major computing platform. They'll enable us to experience completely new things and be more creative than ever before. Hugo is going to help build that future
column26: and I'm looking forward to having him on our team.""Facebook had acquired Oculus for $2 billion in 2014. With Oculus
column27: the company is trying to fuel its ambitious AR/VR efforts. Zuckerberg has time and again mentioned that VR is the next big business opportunity. Facebook has been pumping ample resources to boost its VR efforts. A few days back
column28: Zuckerberg said that Facebook was going to spend over $3 billion over the next 10 years.However
column29: Oculus has beenslappedwith a $2 billion lawsuit filed by video game company
column30: ZeniMax. Zuckerberg appeared in a Dallas courtroom to testify against the allegations. Apparently
column31: Zuckerberg has denied all allegations and stressed that ""The idea that Oculus technology is based on someone else's is just wrong.""At present
column32: Facebook has a Zacks Rank #2.  In the past one year

column34: compared with the ZacksInternet Servicesindustry's gain of 19.39%.PerformanceThe following table shows the price movement of the major video game companies over both the past five trading days as well as the last six months:CompanyLast 5 DaysLast 6 MonthsATVI1.34%-5.03%EA1.68%6.32%GLUU6.98%-3.77%MSFT2.50%13.23%NTES6.00%23.20%TTWO4.15%33.77%ZNGA-2.65%-10.76%Over the last five trading sessions

column36: Take Two InteractiveTTWOsurged the most (33.77%). The company continues to benefit from its popular offerings like GrandTheft Auto V and Grand Theft Auto Online (though sales are slowing down)
column37: along with its other releases like NBA 2K17. In fact
column38: higher sales of the digital version of the games add to the company's margins. The company continues to expect growth in digital revenues driven by higher sale of full game downloads and increases in recurrent consumer spending.Computer and Technology Sector 5YR % ReturnComputer and Technology Sector 5YR % ReturnZynga was down 10.76% over the same time frame. Slowdown in its user growth remains a major concern. Moreover

column1: How Intel Corporation Can Strengthen Its Relationship With Apple Inc.;1/27/2017;"With theApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) iPhone 7
column2: microprocessor giantIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) scored a lucky break
column3: winning a significant   portion of the cellular modem orders for Apple's latest handsets   -- arguably the highest-profile smartphone win that Intel has   ever enjoyed.Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Intel cellular modem chips
column4: branded the XMM 7360
column5: are found   inside versions of the iPhone 7 devices used on networks that   don't implement the CDMA cellular standard. Chips from rivalQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) are found in the iPhone models used on CDMA   networks
column6: as Intel's chips currently don't implement CDMA.Back in late 2015
column7: Intel purchased the CDMA chipset assets   from a company called VIA Telecom
column8: presumably in a bid to   allow the former to build chips that could address the entirety   of Apple's cellular modem needs.Though Qualcomm is widely believed to build superior modems to   what Intel produces
column9: Apple recently filed a lawsuit against   Qualcomm alleging
column10: among other things
column11: that ""Qualcomm has charged   Apple a monopolistic premium for access to CDMA chipsets that are   in all other aspects identical to chipsets sold to Apple without   CDMA functionality enabled. ... Qualcomm has used its monopoly   power in CDMA chipsets to obtain anticompetitive license and   chipset supply terms
column12: the complaint filed on Jan. 20 read.I'll be writing more on the lawsuit in the coming days and   today there is an observation I would like to share regarding   Apple
column13: Intel
column14: Qualcomm
column15: and CDMA iPhones.Apple's component costs could come down if Intel     succeeds in implementing CDMABased on this complaint
column16: we now know that Qualcomm charges   Apple more for the same exact cellular modems with CDMA enabled   compared to versions without CDMA enabled. This isn't an unusual   practice in the semiconductor industry; companies like Intel   routinely charge more for identical chips but with certain   features enabled
column17: compared with variants without those features   enabled. This is plain old product segmentation at work.Image source: Qualcomm.What's interesting is that Apple is complaining that
column18: because   Qualcomm essentially has no viable competition for its   CDMA-enabled modems
column19: it is charging a ""monopolistic premium.""The magnitude of this premium isn't clear
column20: but it's clear that   Apple isn't happy about having to pay it
column21: and therein lies the   opportunity for Intel.If Intel can develop a commercially viable LTE modem that also   supports CDMA (and is certified on all of the major CDMA   networks) using those VIA Telecom assets
column22: then this would open   the door to a couple of possibilities:Intel could win more than just the non-CDMA iPhones. It     could be a true ""second source"" for all the iPhones that Apple     ships. This could potentially boost Intel's share at Apple
column23: to     Intel's benefit (and to Qualcomm's detriment).Apple could be able to get cheaper CDMA modems from     Qualcomm. Even if Apple doesn't increase the proportion of     total modems that it purchases from Intel
column24: the fact that Intel     and Qualcomm parts would be viable for all iPhone models could     help reduce the average price that Apple pays per cellular     modem.Net-net
column25: Intel's becoming a stronger cellular modem provider   would mean that Apple should
column26: in general
column27: pay less for modems.   This could help modestly improve Apple's gross profit margin and
column28: ultimately
column29: net profit.To put this into perspective
column30: in the complaint
column31: Apple says   that LTE modems sell for between $10 and $20. Let's suppose that   Apple must pay $15 for the non-CDMA Qualcomm chips and then $20   for the CDMA-capable Qualcomm chips -- though with the iPhone 7
column32: Apple doesn't appear to be buying any non-CDMA Qualcomm chips;   the non-CDMA iPhones now use Intel.If Apple can get that $20 figure down to $15 in the presence   of a viable alternative from Intel
column33: then that's $5 saved across   potentially 100 million or more iPhone models sold in a year.   That $5 figure is for illustrative purposes only
column34: as I have no   clue what the actual delta is
column35: but multiplied across the volumes   that Apple sells
column36: the savings Apple could potentially realize are   significant.Intel needs to executeThe key to all of this is for Intel to execute to building   increasingly competitive cellular modems. If Intel can
column37: then   that's obviously a positive for Intel
column38: as an opportunity to sell   more modems
column39: and an opportunity for Apple
column40: in the form of cheaper   modems.The loser
column41: if Intel can supply more of Apple's volume --   whether or not it actually does -- would be Qualcomm
column42: as at the   very least it could see the premium that it enjoys from the sale   of CDMA-capable LTE modems evaporate.In the scheme of things
column43: though
column44: losing a bit more Apple chip   business probably isn't going to sting Qualcommthatmuch. After all
column45: Intel grabbed a bunch of iPhone share this   cycle
column46: yet Qualcomm's chip business appears to be on theright track.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock   tip

column48: the newsletter   they have run for over a decade

That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even   better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as ofDecember 12

column1: Should You Sell Qualcomm After Apple's $1 Billion Lawsuit?;1/26/2017;"Shares ofQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) plunged 13% on Jan. 23 after the chipmaker was   sued for $1 billion by one of its biggest customers
column2: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) . The lawsuit is related to the FTC's   separatelawsuit against Qualcomm
column3: which alleges that the chipmaker leveraged its portfolio of   critical wireless patents to force its baseband competitors out   of the market. Let's take a closer look at this tangled   mess
column4: and see if Qualcomm shareholders should sell their   shares.Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Why is Apple suing Qualcomm?Back in 2008
column5: Sprintdeployed its first WiMax network
column6: a 4G standard which wasn't   heavily dependent on Qualcomm's patent portfolio.Intel(NASDAQ: INTC) championed the use of WiMax chips
column7: but   Qualcomm opposed WiMax in favor of its upcoming LTE standard --   which it could generate more licensing fees from.At the time
column8: Apple considered launching an iPhone for WiMax   networks. Realizing that the move could hurt its LTE ambitions
column9: Qualcomm agreed to pay Apple ""rebates"" for sticking with its   baseband modems and waiting for its LTE standard instead. Those   rebate payments were dependent on Apple doing two things --exclusivelyusing Qualcomm's chips (from 2011 to 2016)
column10: and notinstigatingany litigation which accused the chipmaker of unfair   licensing practices. The FTC claims that Qualcomm essentially   ""bribed"" Apple with those rebates to prevent it from switching to   competing chipsets.Over the past two years
column11: Qualcomm was hit with antitrust   probes worldwide
column12: which all allege that it charges unfair   licensing fees for its 3G/4G technologies. It was fined $975   million in China
column13: another $854 million in South Korea
column14: and could   face up to $3 billion in additional fines in Europe and   Taiwan. Apple claims that because it cooperated with   authorities in Korea during the investigation
column15: Qualcomm   retaliated by withholding $1 billion in rebate payments -- which   it's now suing to recover.The outcome is anyone's guess...The battle between Qualcomm and Apple will be a long and nasty   one
column16: since it's dependent on many shifting variables. First
column17: the   FTC lawsuit could be dropped if commissioner Maureen K.   Ohlhausen
column18: a Republican who voted against charging Qualcomm that   was just appointed the acting chairwoman by the Trump   Administration
column19: chooses not to follow through. If the case is   dropped
column20: the rebates should remain a valid business arrangement;   but if it isn't
column21: the rebates could be invalidated as ""bribes"" --   which may hurt both companies.Regardless of what happens with the FTC case
column22: Apple   needs to prove that it didn't violate the two main conditions of   its rebate agreement by using Intel modems or aiding the Korean   FTC during its investigation. Apple doesn't deny aiding the KFTC   at all -- it recently told CNN that it was merely   ""responding truthfully to law enforcement agencies"" instead of   ""instigating"" litigation against Qualcomm.Meanwhile
column23: Qualcomm must justify many of its opaque licensing   practices. Qualcomm charges royalties based on a device's   entire value
column24: instead of just the chips in the device -- a   practice that was already blocked by Chinese regulators. It also   charges licensing fees on 3G/4G handsets which don't use any of   its chips
column25: since  those devices still rely on its wireless   technologies -- although Apple argues that some of Qualcomm's   licensed patents don't actually cover those core technologies.   This means that Apple still pays Qualcomm fees on iPhones using   Intel modems (and also the Infineon modems it used in the past)
column26: and that those fees are likely higher due to the lack of   rebates.Understanding the risks to QualcommIf Qualcomm loses its cases against Apple and other   regulators
column27: it could be forced to change its entire licensing   model. That move would cause the QTL (licensing) business'   margins to wither and crush its earnings since the business   generates the lion's share of its profits.It could also jeopardize Qualcomm'splanned acquisitionofNXP Semiconductors(NASDAQ: NXPI)
column28: which would make it the largest automotive   chipmaker in the world while expanding its patent portfolio. If   Qualcomm doesn't close that deal this year
column29: its top line will   remain heavily exposed to the commoditization of the smartphone   market and seemingly endless challenges against its licensing   business.But should you sell Qualcomm?Qualcomm faces plenty of legal headwinds
column30: but I believe that   the sell-off is a knee jerk reaction that has knocked the stock   down to irrational levels. Qualcomm now trades at 14 times   earnings
column31: as opposed to the industry average of 22. It also pays   a forward yield of 3.4%
column32: which is easily supported by a payout   ratio of 53%.As a Qualcomm shareholder
column33: I'm certainly disappointed with   recent developments. But I don't plan to sell my shares unless   the litigation either derails the NXP deal or forces Qualcomm to   dramatically reduce its licensing fees. Until then
column34: I'll still   consider Qualcomm a cheap (albeit riskier) dividend play with   solid growth prospects inadjacent marketslike connected cars
column35: drones
column36: and Internet of Things gadgets.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column37: it can pay to listen. After all
column38: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column40: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: Qualcomm's Earnings Call Dominated By Apple Lawsuit;1/26/2017;"CEO Steve Mollenkopf. Image source: Qualcomm.Mobile chip giantQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) reported fiscal first-quarter results last night.   While the results as well as guidance mostly topped analyst   expectations
column2: Apple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) recent lawsuit against the company expectedly   dominated the subsequent earnings call (""Apple"" was mentioned 74   times). For good reason
column3: too
column4: since Apple is widely considered   Qualcomm's largest customer
column5: combined with the fact that the   lawsuit threatens Qualcomm's licensing model.makeArticleAd();Beyond a few brief statements
column6: this is the first time that   Qualcomm has commented publicly and in granular detail regarding   the suit. Here's what management had to say.Prepared remarksCEO Steve Mollenkopf first noted that the two companies have   historically had a strong relationship
column7: and Qualcomm intends to   ""remain a good supplier"" despite the legal complaint. The company   would naturally have preferred to settle its dispute with Apple   in private negotiations instead of litigation
column8: but it remains   confident that it can defend itself in court. Mollenkopf summed   it up: ""Apple's complaint contains a lot of assertions
column9: but in   the end
column10: this is a commercial dispute over the price of   intellectual property. They want to pay less for the fair value   that Qualcomm has established in the marketplace for our   technology
column11: even though Apple has generated billions in profits   from using that technology.""President Derek Aberle continued:Touching briefly on Apple's complaints filed in San Diego     and China
column12: it claims that Qualcomm should be required to     license its cellular standard essential patents
column13: or SEPs
column14: to     modem suppliers. That even when licensing those patents at the     device level
column15: Qualcomm should only be able to charge royalties     on the price of the cellular modem chip inside the device.These positions
column16: however
column17: are inconsistent with     long-standing industry practice
column18: the [intellectual property     rights] policies of the relevant standard-setting bodies
column19: the     realities of licensing large portfolios of patents
column20: and basic     notions of efficiency
column21: fairness in economics.Aberle points out that device-level licensing is utilized   throughout the industry by many major patent holders beyond   Qualcomm. (Apple is seeking chip-level licensing.) Qualcomm says   its patents also contribute to many other features in modern   smartphones beyond cellular connectivity
column22: further justifying   device-level royalties. Shifting to chip-level royalties would   then introduce different layers of licensing for all the various   chips that Qualcomm enables or sells itself
column23: so it licenses the   entire portfolio for the sake of efficiency.Apple says that there is no limit to the royalty rates
column24: which   is why it seeks per-unit royalty relief in the form of ""rebate""   payments. Aberle says this is untrue:In addition
column25: it is well known that Qualcomm has per-unit     running royalty caps as part of its licensing program. This     effectively results in licensees not paying running royalties     as a percentage of the device price above a certain net selling     price of any given device. Apple's claim that royalties are     uncapped is simply incorrect.Aberle also reiterated that Qualcomm believes Apple is   instigating these regulatory attacks as well as providing   inaccurate information:Apple claims that Qualcomm retaliated because Apple     cooperated with government investigations. To be clear
column26: we did     no such thing. We simply objected to Apple making false and     misleading statements and withholding information to motivate     attacks against Qualcomm. We welcome the opportunity to have     Apple's claims heard in court
column27: where we will be entitled to     full discovery of Apple's practices and a robust examination of     the merits. We will prove that Apple's irresponsible claims of     extortion are false.There should be no immediate impact to sales from the lawsuit
column28: either. Apple still needs modems
column29: and Qualcomm will still supply   them. CFO George Davis said
column30: ""We are not forecasting any impact   to revenues related to the dispute with Apple
column31: as we are   continuing to meet their supply needs in good faith and expect   Apple will continue to meet its obligations.""Questions and answersAs usual
column32: the analyst Q&A often provides more color.   Qualcomm affirmed that Apple does not have a direct license
column33: but   rather an indirect license through its contract manufacturers.   Qualcomm isn't worried about collecting
column34: said Aberle:Apple does not have a direct license with Qualcomm today.     And so the royalties on Apple products that get paid to     Qualcomm are reported and paid by their contract manufacturers.     So although we do have a dispute now with Apple and they are     challenging some of the offers and some of our licensing terms
column35: the contracts that we have in place with their suppliers remain     valid and enforceable. And we would expect that our licensees     will continue to comply with the terms of their agreements. And     we would also hope and expect that Apple would not interfere     with the terms of those agreements. But of course
column36: we can't     fully control those actions.When asked about the exclusivity and monopoly power   allegations
column37: general counsel Don Rosenberg (who incidentally used   to work for Apple a decade ago)
column38: downplayed the idea that   Qualcomm wields monopoly power:With regard to your question about so-called exclusivity     deal
column39: first of all
column40: we -- I think you called this monopoly     power or had monopoly power. We don't believe we have monopoly     power in the chip market or any other market. And nor do we     have an exclusivity arrangement. We have never prevented Apple     or anybody else from buying from competitive chipmakers. And in     the Apple case
column41: it's pretty clear since
column42: as you know
column43: they have     been buying fromIntelfairly recently. So it's a mischaracterization to call it an     exclusive dealing arrangement.This is a little murky
column44: since Applehadbeen exclusively buying basebands from Qualcomm for five years
column45: and only started buying from Intel after the alleged exclusivity   ended.Overall
column46: Qualcomm thinks Apple is simply trying to finagle   lower payments -- lower being beneath fair value as established   by its hundreds of other licensing deals with many companies over   the years. That risks somewhat oversimplifying Apple's complaint
column47: because Apple is also accusing Qualcomm of various forms of   anticompetitive behavior. Whether or not those allegations stand   up in court remains to be seen.10 stocks we like better than QualcommWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column4: RGSE;1/26/2017;"Top Tech StocksMSFT +1.09%AAPL +0.12%makeArticleAd();IBM +0.11%CSCO +0.15%GOOG -0.50%Technology stocks fell for the first time this week
column5: with shares of tech companies in the S&P 500 slipping about 0.3% just before the closing bell on Thursday.In company news
column6: American depository shares of LG Display Co (LPL) have recouped all but a small slice of its prior decline Thursday in the wake of reports the South Korean manufacturer failed to receive orders from Apple (AAPL) for iPhone displays for the first time in nearly a decade.Instead
column7: Apple will be working with Samsung's display unit on its new iPhone 8 smartphone models
column8: according a report in the South Korea daily Maeil. LG Display lost the order because it did not respond fast enough to the migration from liquid crystal display to organic light-emitting diode technology
column9: according to the report.Mobile displays has accounted for a significant portion of LG Display's revenue in recent year
column10: growing to 27.9% of its $24.3 billion in total revenue during 2015
column11: the latest 12-month period that complete figures for the company were available.LPL shares were down just 0.4% at $13.29 apiece shortly before tonight's closing bell
column12: improving on a prior slide to a session low of $13.05 a share.In other sector news
column13: (+) STM
column14: Q4 EPS of $0.13 tops consensus by $0.02 per share. Revenue climbs 11.5% to $1.86 bln
column15: also beating Street view by $10 mln. Sees Q1 revenue falling 2.4% from prior quarter to $1.81 bln
column16: exceeding analyst mean by around $40 mln.(-) RGSE
column17: Begins public offering of Class A common stock and Series K warrants. Expects Q4 net loss to widen to $10.5 mln from $4.2 mln last year while revenue is projected to fall 47% from last year to $5.1 mln. Analyst estimates were not available for comparison."

column1: Thursday Apple Rumors: AAPL May Be Planning a Second Belgian Store;1/26/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of a new store coming to Belgian. Today
column3: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Thursday.makeArticleAd();Belgian Store:A new rumor claims that Apple is preparing to start construction on its second store in Belgian
column4: reportsAppleInsider. According to this rumor
column5: the tech company is planning to build its new store in Bruges. A building at 96 Steenstraat is already under construction and the rumor claims it will house the new retail location. This rumor also claims that the new store won't be opening until sometime in 2018.macOS Sierra 10.12.4 Public Beta:The first public beta of macOS Sierra 10.12.4 is out
column6: MacRumorsnote. This new public beta allows users to try out new features being tested by developers before its official release. One notable new feature is Night Shift mode. This allows users to set their Mac displays to shift colors as the day progresses and daylight wanes. This beta comes out just a couple of days after developers got their hands of the first macOS Sierra 10.12.4 beta.iOS 10.3 Public Beta:Apple fans can now check out the first iOS 10.3 public beta
column7: reports9to5Mac. The new beta is available for iPhone
column8: iPad and iPod devices. It includes the new Find My Airpods feature. This feature allows users to better keep track of AAPL's new wireless earbuds. There have also been several other small changes included in the beta. One major feature expected is Theater Mode. This is listed as coming in the next watchOS beta and that update may reveal the feature on iOS.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postThursday Apple Rumors: AAPL May Be Planning a Second Belgian Storeappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: BlackBerry Ltd (BBRY) DTEK70: Game-Changer or Non-Event?;1/26/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe rumor mill is spinning again withBlackBerry Ltd(NASDAQ:BBRY). Code-named ""Mercury
column3: the next BlackBerry device
column4: DTEK70
column5: will reportedly get a Feb. 25 launch date. And BBRY stock holders probably do not care at this point.makeArticleAd();Source:WEi WEi via FlickrBlackBerry is rebranding itself as a software company
column6: but its stock is up a mere 4.3% in the last year. By comparison
column7: Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) is up nearly 25% in the last year whileNokia Corp (ADR)(NYSE:NOK)
column8: which exited the Windows Phone market and focused on networking
column9: fell 33%.Still
column10: the DTEK70 release is important for BBRY.BlackBerry and TCL PartnershipBlackBerry outsourced its entire hardware development and manufacturing withTCL. Early signs are positive that ""Mercury"" will win customers
column11: especially in the business space. BlackBerry said that it is 100% indevelopingsoftware solutions. TCL's ""Mercury"" build offers a secure Android operating system and has a physical keyboard. The company earns IP and royalty revenue for each device TCL sells.On its conference call in December
column12: BlackBerrydescribedthe TCL deal:This licensing model allows BlackBerry to generate ongoing high margin royalty revenue from a device software based on the number of units sold. We have a pipeline of additional opportunities that are focusing on
column13: including a late discussion in India that are ongoing.""Decent Price to PerformanceBlackBerry priced the budget DTEK50 in the right range but did not win the mainstream market. DTEK60 demonstrated the company's ability to make a solid
column14: high-performance phone at mainstream prices. DTEK70 is even more practical for business users.Rumoredto run on aQualcomm
column15: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM) Snapdragon 635 or Snapdragon 821
column16: the device will have just 4.5 inches of screen real estate.5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Sell in FebruaryThis is the magic number for DTEK70: The device may sell for around just $350. At that price and size
column17: business users who crave for higher productivity will snap up this phone when it is launched.Profit MarginBlackBerry CEO John Chen will not allow the company to sell devices at a loss. Assume profit margins in the range of 25%-50% for TCL. When the costs of software development are included
column18: the profit margin for BBRY may run above 50%-60%.Launch DateOn its blog
column19: BlackBerry said it will give more details about the smartphone at the Mobile World Congress show. The event runs from Feb. 27 to March 3.Interest in ""Mercury""+ ""BlackBerry"" jumped:Click to EnlargeSource:tickertags.comGame Changer or More of the Same?Past BlackBerry Android devices did not give the company much revenue growth. In the third quarter
column20: the $172 million in software services revenue accounted for 57% of the company's revenue.The TCL licensing deal
column21: though
column22: is a game-changer for the software company. DTEK70's development costs are all shouldered by its partner. BlackBerry gets a cut in the sales through the software licensing. High profit margins from software sales will translate to more profits for the company.The one big catch is that BBRY and TCL must advertise and promote this upcoming device. BlackBerry made $12 million in operating income in the third quarter.Profit Model for DTEK 70Assuming TCL pays a 10% royalty on the profits of the $350 device
column23: or $20 per device
column24: BlackBerry could earn the following:Units Sold per quarterProfit100
column33: 000Selling 500
column34: 000 units a quarter would match the company's third-quarter operating income.3 Reasons to Buy Ford Motor Company (F) Stock on This DipBottom Line on BBRY StockThe smartphone market is still wide-open for small players like BlackBerry. Previously released Android devices demonstrated the company could deliver on supplying a highly secure
column35: bug-free operating system. The inexpensive DTEK70 targets the business user.With the rumored price and phone specifications
column36: BlackBerry may have an unexpected winner.As of this writing
column37: Chris Lau was long BBRY. Follow him onTwitter.More From InvestorPlace10 Blue-Chip Stocks That Could Be Holding You Back7 Stocks to Sell Before They ImplodeShould You Buy Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock? 3 Pros
column38: 3 ConsThe postBlackBerry Ltd (BBRY) DTEK70: Game-Changer or Non-Event?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Should You Buy Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock? 3 Pros
column2: 3 Cons;1/26/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIf you bought and held stock inMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) at the height of the dot-com run
column4: it's been an unpleasant 16 years. However
column5: after a long wait
column6: MSFT stock finally reached a new all-time high last month. Despite the tech world changing drastically in the ensuing years
column7: Microsoft's PC dominance lives on
column8: minting money for the company.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart Via FlickrThe company's various new efforts over the years have mostly been flops. There's a reason Microsoft stock has performed poorly; efforts such as Windows phones simply haven't panned out. However
column9: it seems Microsoft has finally turned the corner.It is making real headway in several promising areas
column10: including its cloud offering. And investors have cheered
column11: sending Microsoft's stock up sharply since 2013. Can the good times continue
column12: or will buyers up at these levels be in for another long decade?MSFT Stock ConsHuge Stock Run-Up: Since 2013
column13: MSFT stock has more than doubled. At first glance
column14: that seems fine
column15: the market has performed strongly in recent years after all. However
column16: Microsoft is so large
column17: that it becomes hard to achieve further such doublings. With a market cap just under $500 billion today
column18: even one more double takes Microsoft to a trillion dollar market cap. It's worth asking what the company has going from a growth perspective that could justify such a lofty figure.Sure
column19: the company has some growth initiatives under way. The cloud offering is going well. And the LinkedIn acquisition may start to bear more fruit. But after watching the stock run from under 30 in recent years to over 60 today
column20: you have to ask how much more upside really makes sense
column21: particularly since the company has had near non-existent revenue growth lately.10 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still BargainsHigh Valuation:First things first
column22: MSFT stock isn't really trading at a 30 price-earnings ratio. I know that's what financial websites report. However
column23: that's based on GAAP figures that include one-off losses related to restructuring. On an adjusted basis
column24: Microsoft is trading in the mid-20s
column25: and at 21 times forward earnings. However
column26: even that doesn't paint a flattering picture for the company. Microsoft traded at 12 times earnings or less over much of the past decade. Is Microsoft worth paying twice as much for now?Sure
column27: the PC market has stabilized
column28: but it isn't likely to ever be a meaningful growth driver again. And the newer initiatives such as cloud seem likely to take years to reach strong profitability. At 21 times forward earnings
column29: MSFT stock is pricing in some serious growth prospects that may well not materialize.Questionable Deal-Making:Microsoft has a reputation for making some head-scratching M&A moves. The less said of the aQuantive purchase and the Nokia buy
column30: the better. Those two alone resulted in almost $14 billion of write-offs. And the recent LinkedIn deal raises questions. Microsoft paid $26 billion for LinkedIn
column31: and offered a massive premium to where shares where trading previously. At the price Microsoft paid
column32: it offered around 30x free cash flow for LinkedIn. On an earnings basis
column33: LinkedIn was still losing money.Sure
column34: Microsoft can cut some costs there
column35: particularly for stock-based compensation
column36: but it's still a massive price tag. And with Microsoft having such a huge war chest on its balance sheet
column37: the temptation will surely be there for the company to make other huge value-destructive deals.MSFT Stock ProsPC Market Stabilizing:For quite a few years now
column38: the traditional PC market appeared to be in serious decline. Sales peaked in 2011
column39: with364 million unitssold that year globally. Since then
column40: sales have plunged. By 2015
column41: sales dropped 24% from that peak year
column42: falling to just 275 million units. And 2016 showed another solid decline
column43: with sales reaching just 260 million units. However
column44: the worst may now have passed. 2020 projections are for 250 million units sold
column45: only a fractional decline from current levels.And themost recent datasupports this further moderation: sales slipped just 1.5% versus the same period last year. And in several areas globally
column46: including Canada and Japan
column47: PC sales are actually increasing again. One possible reason
column48: the rate of forward technological progress has slowed for both tablets and smartphones
column49: reducing pressure on consumers to switch to smaller screens. A stable market would be great news for MSFT stock.Partnership With Qualcomm:Microsoft has partnered withQualcomm
column50: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM) for their Internet of Things efforts. Qualcomm has entered conflict withIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) at first over the IoT market. In the longer-run
column51: Qualcomm may use its chips to even forcefully attack Intel's long-held dominance in the PC market. In any case
column52: Microsoft benefits nicely from partnering up with Qualcomm.The IoT offerings born from this venture will help spread Windows 10 outside of just the traditional PC market. And given the shellacking that QCOM stock took earlier this week followingApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) lawsuit against the firm
column53: Qualcomm has reason to deepen ties with friendly partners. As an industry outcast
column54: Qualcomm needs whatever help it can get
column55: and if Microsoft can use that to expand Windows as a broader OS
column56: all the better.Solid Dividend Option:Microsoft has quietly turned into a nice yield choice for more conservative investors. The company has tripled its dividend since 2008. In total
column57: it's posted 16%
column58: 18% and 16% dividend growth rates over the past three
column59: five and ten years. While the payout ratio currently looks a little high
column60: that's based on abnormally soft recent earnings. Make no mistake
column61: there is plenty of room left here for more dividend increases. The company has an astounding $137 billion in cash on its balance sheet. Even after subtracting out debt
column62: the company has a net cash position of $62 billion
column63: leaving plenty of firepower for increased dividends
column64: share buybacks or acquisitions.VerdictMSFT stock is a decent selection if you're purely concerned with its yield and safety. The company's main PC business is looking healthier than it has in quite awhile. The balance sheet is tremendous. The dividend is significant at today's level
column65: and is bound to keep rising quickly.Here's Why Chevron Corporation (CVX) Stock Is the Best Play in OilHowever
column66: there's little to recommend Microsoft on valuation. The stock is expensive
column67: even when you look closely. Microsoft has plenty of growth initiatives in the works
column68: but actual operating results recently have only been so-so. When buying stocks at all-time highs
column69: you want to see a business with more operating momentum.At the time of this writing
column70: Ian Bezek held INTC and QCOM stock. He had no position in Microsoft. You can reach him on Twitter at @irbezek.More From InvestorPlace3 Energy ETFs That Will Keep Soaring3 Brokerage Stocks That Love Donald Trump's Big Tweetin'The postShould You Buy Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock? 3 Pros
column71: 3 Consappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Can Apple's (AAPL) "Find my Airpod" Feature Really Help?;1/26/2017;"On TuesdayApple Inc. (AAPL)announced its iOS 10.3 update with a special feature
column2: apparently called ""Find my Airpods""
column3: that will help to track misplaced Airpods.Powered by a new W1 chip
column4: the Airpods are in line with Apple's vision of wireless future. Apparently
column5: its best feature seems to be the use of sensors to detect if the plugs have been inserted in both the ears. However
column6: since its launch
column7: Airpod has been a hot topic of discussion on FacebookFBand TwitterTWTRgiven the chances of it being misplaced easily due to its size.Per media reports
column8: Apple's announcement can be seen as an answer to users' request to make a feature that will help them find these small AirPods. Due to its small size
column9: the Airpod cannot accommodate a built-in GPS system. Therefore
column10: the latest feature is tailored to locate misplaced Airpods that are within the Bluetooth range of an iPhone or iPad.Then again
column11: the problem remains that the exact location of the Airpod cannot be determined with the feature and only the last connected location will show up on the connected iOS device
column12: add further media reports. Additionally
column13: the feature is capable of activating a sound from the Airpod to indicate its location. However
column14: these features are useless once the Airpod's battery is exhausted.Apple Inc. Price and ConsensusApple Inc. Price and Consensus|Apple Inc. QuoteApple's fortunes have been tied to its most important offering
column15: the iPhone
column16: which alone contributed about 60% of its total revenue in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016.However
column17: since the last two quarters
column18: the demand for this device has been soft owing to global macroeconomic weakness
column19: especially due to currency volatility and declining commodity prices in some key regions across the globe (about 60% of Apple revenues come from International markets).The Airpod had been one of the key attractions of the iPhone 7 series. Reportedly
column20: since the launch of Airpods in December
column21: Apple has been on the top of the headphone market that boasts names likes SonySNE
column22: Bose
column23: JBL and others. Although Apple has refrained from posting its official sales figures
column24: the market reports indicate positive impact of Airpod sales on first quarter results.In the past one year
column25: Apple's shares are up 19.98%
column26: compared with the ZacksComputer Miniindustry's increase of 21.41%

column4: Amazon and Netflix highlighted as Zacks Bull and Bear of the Day Broadcom
column5: Valeant Pharmaceuticals
column6: Apple
column7: Amazon and Netflix highlighted as Zacks Bull and Bear of the Day;1/26/2017;"For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column8: IL - January 26
column9: 2017-Zacks Equity ResearchhighlightsBroadcom (NASDAQ:AVGO-Free Report)as the Bull of the Day andValeant Pharmaceuticals (NYSE:VRX-Free Report)as the Bear of the Day. In addition
column10: Zacks Equity Research provides analysis onApple (NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report)
column11: Amazon(NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report) andNetflix(NASDAQ:NFLX-Free Report).Here is a synopsis of all four stocks:Bull of the Day:Seems it was only a month ago I writing aboutBroadcom (NASDAQ:AVGO-Free Report)as the Bull of the Day and explaining why I've been strongly recommending and trading the stock since 2014 from $70.makeArticleAd();And it's true. I did choose AVGO on December 22 when it was trading around $180. Here's how I described this powerhouse technology company in that report...3 Key SegmentsThough Broadcom is generally classified as a semiconductor designer and developer
column12: its solutions serve telecom and enterprise networking customers in the build-out of data centers and high-speed
column13: broadband communications. I can't say for sure ifAT&T
column14: CiscoorAlphabetare customers
column15: but I would be surprised if they weren't.Thus about half of Broadcom's sales come from the Wired Infrastructure segment which has been seeing steady double-digit growth as these big customers transition to the 100 Gigabit Ethernet protocol.Approximately 30% of Broadcom's revenues come from its Wireless Communications division which serves top-end mobile smart-device makers likeApplewith radio frequency (RF) chips
column16: amplifiers
column17: and FBAR technology filters. Broadcom FBAR (Film Bulk Acoustic Resonator) filters are a form of bulk acoustic wave (BAW) filter that have superior performance with steeper rejection curves compared to surface acoustic wave (SAW) filters.The third major segment at Broadcom is Enterprise Storage
column18: which connects back with many customers from the Wired division and supplies just under 20% of revenues. The company's products enable the high-speed movement of digital data with a secure connection among multiple PCs
column19: servers and storage devices such as hard disk drives and solid state drives.While AVGO's Wireless business is ""dependent"" on Apple
column20: that's not exactly a bad problem to have. The coming next wave of 5G technology will keep both companies rolling in sales growth.And Broadcom's largest business
column21: the Wired segment
column22: is very busy meeting the demand of companies building high-speed
column23: broadband networks
column24: especially with the data-hogging loads of video and the storage requirements of the Internet of Things.Bear of the Day:I don't enjoy kicking this once-beloved company when it's down
column25: butValeant Pharmaceuticals (NYSE:VRX-Free Report)has it coming (again) as earnings estimates slip.In the past week
column26: another investment bank revised lower their EPS projection for this year
column27: knocking the the Zacks Consensus down to $5.17 from $5.30.And in the past 90 days
column28: the profit outlook has fallen from $7.70. This puts annual growth at -5.6% after a 2016 that could end up at over -30% ""growth.""This is why VRX shares are in the cellar of the Zacks Rank again.But it doesn't mean you should run out and sell yours only $1 from multi-year lows. The company is still projected to deliver nearly $9.2 billion in sales this year with hundreds of products and steady earners like Jublia and Wellbutrin.The unknown risks are what happens with any legal investigations or the company's massive debt load. The current debt-to-equity ratio is over 7X for this $4.7 billion company and the debt-to-capital ratio may be over 87X.Analysts Weigh In On the Debt IssueOn January 11
column29: Canaccord Genuity analyst Neil Maruoka was encouraged by Valeant's recent moves to address the leverage...""Valeant has taken its first significant steps towards de-levering its balance sheet
column30: announcing the divestiture of Dendreon and several dermatology brands (including CereVe) for combined cash consideration of ~$2.1 billion.""The analyst noted that the downside of this move is that the company may be forced to sell more quality drug franchises like CereVe
column31: thus hurting sales and operating cash flow. ""Following these divestitures
column32: we estimate that Valeant will have total debt of $28.3 billion remaining
column33: representing a leverage ratio of 6.9x forward EBITDA (down from 7.1x previously).""On January 20
column34: Deutsche Bank reiterated their Hold rating on VRX shares and dropped their price target from $24 to $20. column1: Facebook Inc (FB) Hires Former Google Exec to Lead Oculus;1/26/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFacebook Inc's(NASDAQ:FB) virtual reality division Oculus has had a rough six months
column3: but it looks as though the company is ready to to push VR in 2017 and turn things around. CEO Mark Zuckerberg took to Facebook last night to announce thatHugo Barra will be joining FB to lead VR efforts
column4: including Oculus. If the name sounds familiar it should. Barra is very well known in the technology industry.makeArticleAd();Source: FacebookSo who is Hugo Barra? He was in the news just last week when it was revealed he was leaving Chinese consumer technology giantXiaomi.He was hired in 2013 to lead that company's efforts to polish its image in western markets and help push its products into the U.S. market. At the time Barra said he was returning to his Silicon Valley roots
column5: but gave no details.What Does Hugo Barra Bring to FB?Prior to Xiaomi
column6: he served asAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOG
column7: NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google vice president of Android product management.In his announcement of Barra's hire
column8: Zuckerberg wrote:""I'm excited that Hugo Barra is joining Facebook to lead all of our virtual reality efforts
column9: including our Oculus team. Hugo's in China right now
column10: so here we are together in VR. It seems fitting.I've known Hugo for a long time
column11: starting when he helped develop the Android operating system
column12: to the last few years he's worked at Xiaomi in Beijing bringing innovative devices to millions of people. Hugo shares my belief that virtual and augmented reality will be the next major computing platform.""FB's Oculus ChallengesWhen Facebook bought Oculus for $2 billion in 2014
column13: the prospects for its new virtual reality division seemed limitless. But for the last six months
column14: the division has been struggling.10 Stocks to Buy to Survive a ""Trumpsy-Turvy"" 2017Founder Palmer Luckey was bringing inbad press over his political views
column15: complaints over the highprices for its Oculus Rift headsetand the new Touch Controllers continued
column16: andSony Corp (ADR)(NYSE:SNE) unexpectedly began to gain traction with both consumers and game developers with its much more affordable Playstation VR. In December
column17: Oculus CEO Brendan Iribe stepped down. Now
column18: FB and Luckey aretied up in a lawsuitclaiming the Oculus founder stole trade secrets and violated copyrights in order to develop his Oculus Rift VR headset.On top of all this
column19: the hype over virtual reality is beginning to fade. After being a major part of past Consumer Electronics shows
column20: there was a feeling thatVR wasn't particularly compelling at CES 2017.In short
column21: it's understandable why FB wants to kickstart Oculus. An industry veteran like Hugo Barra -someone who is experienced in leading a critical division in a technology giant and skilled at promotion - may well be the answer.Kickstarting OculusWhen Barra takes over at Oculus
column22: there are a few immediate challenges to take on. The lawsuit will have to be dealt with
column23: but FB lawyers will be able to manage most of that.The bigger issue in terms of getting consumers to buy into the Oculus rift is pricing. The Oculus Rift already has mindshare as the VR headset people think of. But where the Oculus Rift was once pretty much the only game in town
column24: every major consumer technology company - exceptApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) - is offering virtual reality gear
column25: and it's almost always cheaper.Apple Inc. New iPads Might Be Late to the Party (AAPL)That wouldn't be such a big deal if you were looking at $100 versus $75. But an Oculus Rift plus Touch Controllers goes for $798. Then you need a reasonably powerful PC (many computer owners would have to upgrade)
column26: which is at least another $1
column27: 000. In comparison
column28: a complete Sony Playstation VR system (including the PS4) can be had for about $800. However
column29: the Playstation VR headset is compatible with the original PS4 - which many gamers already own
column30: so that brings their investment to just $500.Largely as a result of those cost differences
column31: it'sestimated Sony will have sold over 745
column32: 000 Playstation VR systems in 2016
column33: while projections are for the Oculus Rift to hit just 355
column34: 000.The hire of Hugo Barra sets the stage for FB to aggressively promote the technical superiority of its Oculus virtual reality technology over that used by competitors like Sony. It's also a good move in promoting developer relations in an effort to boost the Oculus' lead in compelling VR content. And if he can find some wiggle room to get Oculus Rift pricing down a bit
column35: Barra stands a good chance of turning things around for Facebook's virtual reality division in 2017.As of this writing
column36: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 Things Apple Inc. (AAPL) MUST Do to Soar in 2017Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Steps on Amazon and Google's TurfThe postFacebook Inc (FB) Hires Former Google Exec to Lead Oculusappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column2: which increased 33.7% from the year-ago quarter. Earnings were much better than management's revised guided range of $2.10-$2.15 per share.makeArticleAd();Moreover
column3: including stock-based compensation

column5: which beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate by 33 cents. Further
column6: revenues of almost $4.89 billion surged 47.4% year over year and comfortably surpassed the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $4.75 billion.Western Digital witnessed strong demand for both hard drive and NAND-based products from all categories of customers

column8: as well as better than expected PC demand in the reported quarter.Western Digital Corporation Price
column9: Consensus and EPS     SurpriseWestern Digital Corporation Price
column10: Consensus and   EPS Surprise|Western Digital Corporation QuoteSegment Revenue DetailsClient devices (49.5% of total revenue) surged 52.9% year over year to $2.42 billion. The revenue synergies from SanDisk acquisition benefitted results in the quarter. Management noted that increasing storage capacities in mobile phones and market preference for client SSDs are long-term tailwinds for this business.Client solutions (22% of total revenue) increased a whopping 134.4% to $1.08 billion. Robust holiday season sales drove results. The company noted that the combined revenue contribution from new products such as iXpand and dual USB drives also grew in the quarter.During the quarter
column11: Western Digital announced new retail products including the four terabyte My Passport
column12: eight terabyte My Book for the PC and a new four terabyte hard drive for Apple'sAAPLMacintosh. During the quarter
column13: Western Digital commenced retail shipments and OEM sampling of its 64-layer product.Data center devices and solutions (28.5% of total revenue) increased 9.2% to $1.39 billion on the back of strong demand for high capacity storage devices. Petabyte growth of almost 40% year over year for capacity optimized hard drive was in line with management expectations. Solid adoption of 10 Terabyte third generation Helium drive was also noted in the quarter.During the quarter
column14: Western Digital shipped 44.8 million HDDs at an average selling price (ASP) of $62
column15: up from $61 reported in the year-ago quarter. However
column16: reported shipments of 44.762 million were down from 49.688 million in the year-ago quarter.Western Digital's market share in the total addressable market (TAM) came in at 39.9% compared with 43.2% in the year-ago quarter.Operating DetailsAdjusted gross margin expanded 810 basis points (bps) year over year to 36.4%. The figure was better than management's guidance of 35%. The expansion was driven by lower product cost and pricing improvement.Reported operating expenses
column17: as percentage of revenues climbed 50 bps to 20.2%
column18: owing to 20 bps increase in research and development (R&D) expense and 10 bps growth in selling
column19: general and administrative (SG&A) expense.As a result
column20: adjusted operating margin expanded 590 bps to 17.6% in the reported quarter.Interest expense was $224 million a massive increase from $7 million reported in the year-ago quarter.Acquisition SynergiesWestern Digital stated that it is on track to achieve the $800 million of annualized savings from the HGST integration by the end of calendar 2017. The company achieved $175 million of cost of revenue synergies and $300 million of operating expense synergies each on an annual run rate basis at the end of the reported quarter.In terms of SanDisk integration
column21: at the end of second quarter the company realized synergies of approximately $135 million on an annual run-rate basis. This is in line with the company's 18-month target of achieving $500 million of total run rate synergies on an annualized basis.Balance Sheet/Cash FlowAs of Dec 30
column23: cash and cash equivalents were $4.94 billion up from $4.33 billion as of Sep 30. Long-term debt during the quarter was $12.94 billion down from $13.06 billion at the end of previous quarter.During the quarter

column1: Bull of the Day: Broadcom (AVGO);1/26/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();Seems it was only a month ago I writing aboutBroadcom (AVGO)as the Bull of the Day and explaining why I've been strongly recommending and trading the stock since 2014 from $70.And it's true. I did choose AVGO on December 22 when it was trading around $180. Here's how I described this powerhouse technology company in that report...3 Key SegmentsThough Broadcom is generally classified as a semiconductor designer and developer
column2: its solutions serve telecom and enterprise networking customers in the build-out of data centers and high-speed
column3: broadband communications. I can't say for sure ifAT&T(T)
column4: Cisco(CSCO)
column5: orAlphabet(GOOGL) are customers
column6: but I would be surprised if they weren't.Thus about half of Broadcom's sales come from the Wired Infrastructure segment which has been seeing steady double-digit growth as these big customers transition to the 100 Gigabit Ethernet protocol.Approximately 30% of Broadcom's revenues come from its Wireless Communications division which serves top-end mobile smart-device makers likeApple (AAPL)with radio frequency (RF) chips
column7: amplifiers
column8: and FBAR technology filters. Broadcom FBAR (Film Bulk Acoustic Resonator) filters are a form of bulk acoustic wave (BAW) filter that have superior performance with steeper rejection curves compared to surface acoustic wave (SAW) filters.The third major segment at Broadcom is Enterprise Storage
column9: which connects back with many customers from the Wired division and supplies just under 20% of revenues. The company's products enable the high-speed movement of digital data with a secure connection among multiple PCs
column10: servers and storage devices such as hard disk drives and solid state drives.While AVGO's Wireless business is ""dependent"" on Apple
column11: that's not exactly a bad problem to have. The coming next wave of 5G technology will keep both companies rolling in sales growth.And Broadcom's largest business
column12: the Wired segment
column13: is very busy meeting the demand of companies building high-speed
column14: broadband networks
column15: especially with the data-hogging loads of video and the storage requirements of the Internet of Things.I Have $250... Do I Hear $300?So what has changed in a month to make Broadcom the Bull of the Day again?Simply this: the stock took off over 10% to new highs in the past six sessions as a couple of analysts bolstered their view of this must-own tech ""arms dealer."" While I've been following fund managers into AVGO for nearly 3 years
column16: the growth story is not over.On January 18
column17: RBC Capital analyst Amit Daryanani reiterated his Top Pick rating on AVGO shares and raised his view of the company's long term earnings potential to $17 EPS on the heels of the acquisition of Brocade (BRCD). Here's what he had to say...""Our analysis suggests the underlying EPS power of AVGO increases materially post BRCD (especially assuming they raise $1.5-2.0B from networking & real estate sales). We think AVGO could achieve >$17.00 of EPS by FY19 (prior $16) and the stock should work in an upside scenario to $250+.""Oddly
column18: the analyst did not raise his existing price target from $200.So we'll leave that to a bolder fan of the company...On January 24
column19: Morgan Stanley analyst Craig Hettenback raised his price target on Broadcom to $240 from $210
column20: and obviously reiterated his Overweight rating. Here's the MS view...""Increasing our PT to $240 from $210 and highlighting a bull case valuation of $300. Our PT is based on a 15X P/E on CY18 EPS
column21: representing a turn increase from the current multiple but still a conservative 20% discount to the high end Semiconductor peers and 15% below the market. AVGO's multiple has been flat (100% of stock appreciation has been driven by growth in EPS) compared to a roughly 2x turn increase in semiconductor stocks
column22: with investors unwilling to pay up for acquired growth.""However
column23: we now have increased conviction that clearer focus on its outperforming core business
column24: materially higher cash returns and ongoing margin expansion will drive a re-rating over the next 6-12 months.""The combination of Avago and Broadcom is unmatched in Networking (40% sales) in our view
column25: which has positive implications for both growth (share gains) and profitability. We also think the company remains well positioned in RF to exploit the next growth driver of carrier aggregation
column26: leveraging its leadership in premium filters and multiplexers.""The AVGO CampaignAnd there you have an update on the continuing saga that I call ""The AVGO Campaign."" It tells you what works and makes you money in a bull market: finding earnings momentum winners that you know institutions will continue to buy until the cycle ends.Consider AVGO your ""playbook stock"" for how to use the Zacks Rank to swing trade fundamentally-strong companies quarter after quarter.You can find out more by following me in myTAZR Traderservice.Zacks' best stocks under $10As a Zacks Rank #1 Strong Buy

column1: 3 Big Tech Companies About to Report Earnings;1/25/2017;"Earnings season is well under way
column2: and some big tech names are   up next. In the coming days
column3: investors will watchAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOGL) (NASDAQ: GOOG)
column4: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column5: andFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) report results for their most recently ended   quarters. With market capitalizations in the hundreds of billions   of dollars
column6: investors all over the world will be watching   closely. Ahead of their earnings releases
column7: here's a brief   overview of some keys areas to watch.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Alphabet: How about that new Google-branded     hardware?With its fourth quarter including the launch of some important   new Google-branded hardware
column8: investors should look for an update   from management on how the products performed during the quarter.   In October
column9: Alphabet launched its Google Pixel smartphone and a   Google Home voice-activated smart speaker. Yes
column10: the bulk of the   company's revenue will still come from its search and advertising   business
column11: but a high-performing hardware could signal growth   potential.On average
column12: analysts are expecting Alphabet to report   fourth-quarter revenue and non-GAAP EPS of $25.18 billion and   9.64
column13: respectively. These results would be up 18% and 11%   compared to the year-ago quarter.Alphabet reports results after market close on Thursday
column14: Jan.   26.Beyond looking to Alphabet's Google-branded hardware and the   company's financial results
column15: investors may want to take the time   to look atthe trajectory of the company's paid clicks and   cost per click-- two important metrics for Alphabet's core search business.iPhone 7. Image source: Apple.Apple: Will guidance point to growth or     decline?When Apple reports results for its first fiscal quarter of   2017 (or the fourth calendar quarter of 2016)
column16: one key area to   watch will be the company's guidance. While Apple is expecting   its first-quarter revenue to be slightly higher than in the   year-ago quarter
column17: ending an unfortunate streak of three quarters   of year-over-year declines
column18: it's not clear whether the company   can sustain growth throughout fiscal 2017.Analysts are expecting Apple to report first-quarter revenue   and EPS of $77.4 billion and $3.22. This compares to revenue and   EPS of $75.9 billion and $3.28 in the year-ago quarter.Apple reports its financial results after market close on   Tuesday
column19: Jan. 31.To get a closer look at the metrics that will matter when   Apple reports first-quarter results
column20: here's a more comprehensiveearnings preview.Facebook: Is revenue growth about to slow?The key thing for Facebook investors to watch when the world's   largest social network reports fourth-quarter results will be the   degree to which revenue growth decelerates. Facebook CFO David   Wehner has been warning that revenue growth rates are going to   begin coming down. Of course
column21: with revenue increasing a whopping   56% year over year in Facebook's third quarter
column22: even a meaningful   deceleration in its fourth quarter will still likely represent   big growth for the company.Image source: The Motley Fool.Analysts are looking for Facebook to report revenue and   non-GAAP EPS of about $8.49 billion and $1.31
column23: up about 45% and   66%
column24: respectively. Therefore
column25: analysts do expect Facebook's   business growth to decelerate
column26: but not too significantly.Facebook reports fourth-quarter results after market close on   Wednesday
column27: Feb. 1.For a more in-depth overview of what to expect from Facebook's   earnings report
